Buddhism.name: Sesshu
Buddhism.desc: Known as Sesshu (1420 - 1506), he was an ink painter and Zen monk active in the Muromachi period in the latter half of the 15th century, and was called a master painter.

Buddhism.name: Rinzai Zen Buddhism
Buddhism.desc: That is not a transmission based on words (logos).

Buddhism.name: Jodo Shinshu
Buddhism.desc: Jodo Shinshu (Shin-Buddhism/True Pure Land Sect) is one of the sects of Japanese Buddhism, and a religious community that Shinran, an apprentice of Honen, succeeded and which developed Honen's doctrine (Jodo Shu/Pure Land Buddhism) in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Dogen
Buddhism.desc: Infobox Buddhist

Buddhism.name: IKKYUU Soujun
Buddhism.desc: Soujun IKKYUU was a Zen monk in the Daitokuji branch of the Rinzai sect, during the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Amida triad
Buddhism.desc: Amida triad is one style to place a Buddhist image in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Shinran
Buddhism.desc: Shinran was a Japanese Buddhist monk in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Jodo Shu
Buddhism.desc: Jodo Shu is one of the denominations of Buddhism in Japan, which was founded by Honen Shonin and the teaching and practice of which is Jodo Kyo Senju-nenbutsu (Exclusive Nenbutsu).

Buddhism.name: The Shingon Sect
Buddhism.desc: The Shingon sect is a Buddhist sect of Japan that was founded by Kukai (Kobo Daishi) in the early ninth century.

Buddhism.name: The Soto Sect
Buddhism.desc: The Soto sect is one of the five Zen sects of China (Rinzai, Igyo, Soto, Unmon and Hogen) and one of the five Zen sects (Nihon Daruma, Rinzai, Soto, Obaku and Fuke) in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Kannon Bodhisattva, Kannon Bosatsu
Buddhism.desc: Kannon Bodhisattva, Kannon Bosatsu,（अवलोकितेश्वर Avalokiteśvara in Sanskrit) is a sacred image (一尊) of Bosatsu in Buddhism and a kind of Buddha (尊格) that has attained widespread faithful since ancient times, particularly in Japan.

Buddhism.name: The Obaku Sect
Buddhism.desc: The Obaku sect is a sect of Buddhism in Japan and one of the Zen sects, after the Rinzai and Soto sects.

Buddhism.name: Shakanyorai
Buddhism.desc: Shakanyorai (Shikyajirai or Shakamuni-butsu) is a title of respect for Shaka (Kudonshittaruta, Gautama Siddhaartha in Sanskrit, Gotama Siddhatthaa in Pali), a founder of Buddhism, as Buddha.

Buddhism.name: Daibutsu, a large statue of Buddha
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Daibutsu, a large statue of Buddha.html
Buddhism.desc: Daibutsu is a popular name meaning a large statue of the Buddha as a Buddhist image.

Buddhism.name: Mikkyo, Esoteric Buddhism
Buddhism.desc: Mikkyo is an abbreviation for Himitsu Bukkyo, or esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Amidanyorai
Buddhism.desc: Amidanyorai, being Amitaabha or Amitaayus in Sanskrit, is one of the Nyorai in Mahayana Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Miroku Bosatsu, Maitreya Bodhisattva
Buddhism.desc: Miroku Bosatsu (Maitreya Bodhisattva in Sanskrit) is one of the Buddhas of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Nichiren chant
Buddhism.desc: The Nichiren chant is the words of Namu Myohorenge-kyo, which are recited in the Buddhist religious services held by religious organizations such as Nichiren and the Hoke-kyo Sutra sect.

Buddhism.name: Hokke-kyo Sutra
Buddhism.desc: Hokke-kyo (Hokke-kyo Sutra) is a collective term for the Mahayana Buddhism sutra, 'saddharmapundariika-suutra ('a white lotus flower as right teaching)' in Chinese translation.

Buddhism.name: Buddhist invocation
Buddhism.desc: The Buddhist invocation is generally to recite 'Namu Amidabutsu' as a devotional exercise in the Jodo-kyo sects of Pure Land teachings.

Buddhism.name: Tendai Sect
Buddhism.desc: Tendai Sect is a sect of Mahayana (greater vehicle) Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Bosatsu, Bodhisattva
Buddhism.desc: Bosatsu, or Bodhisattva (in Sanskrit) is a disciplinant who wants to become Buddha (tries to become Nyorai) in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: History of Hongwan-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: This article describes the history of Hongwan-ji Temple of the Jodo Shinshu sect, founded by Shinran.

Buddhism.name: Godai Myoo, the Five Great Myoo
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Godai Myoo, the Five Great Myoo.html
Buddhism.desc: Godai Myoo (the five great Myoo) is a subject of faith in Buddhism and a combination of the five Myoo, which play a central role among Myoo, an honorific entity, which is specific to Mikkyo Esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Ama (nun)
Buddhism.desc: An ama is an unmarried woman over the age of 20 or a woman who becomes a priestess after the period of Shamini (a female Buddhist novice), even though she has been married.

Buddhism.name: Arakan, arhat
Buddhism.desc: Arakan (arhat in Sanskrit) is a saint in Buddhism who is eligible to receive respect and charity.

Buddhism.name: Buddhist Sutras
Buddhism.desc: Sutra,' of the Buddhist sutra (Kyoten, Kyoden, sutra in Sanskrit, sutta in Pali), means a record of Shaka's teachings among Buddhist scriptures.

Buddhism.name: Jodo-kyo (Pure Land Teachings)
Buddhism.desc: Jodo-kyo is a teaching for people to become Buddha in the Land of Bliss of Amitabha Buddha.

Buddhism.name: Heart of Great Perfect Wisdom Sutra (Hannya Shingyo)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Heart of Great Perfect Wisdom Sutra (Hannya Shingyo).html
Buddhism.desc: "Heart of Great Perfect Wisdom Sutra (Hannya Shingyo, Prajñā-pāramitā-hṛdaya in Sanskrit)" is one of the Buddhist sutras that preaches the Ku (Buddhism) of Mahayana Buddhism and Prajna thought.

Buddhism.name: Monju Bosatsu (文殊菩薩)
Buddhism.desc: Monju Bosatsu, or maJjuzrii in Sanskrit, is one of the Bosatsus which is worshiped in Mahayana Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Taishakuten
Buddhism.desc: Taishakuten is one of the Tenbu, deities of Buddhism who reside in a heavenly realm, this being one of six realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another.

Buddhism.name: Yakushi Nyorai
Buddhism.desc: Yakushi Nyorai, bhaiSajya-guru in Sanskrit, is a Nyorai of Mahayana Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Juni Shinsho, the 12 protective deities
Buddhism.desc: Juni Shinsho (the 12 protective deities) are tenbu, deities who reside in a heavenly realm, one of six realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another; they are worshiped and shaped into statues in Buddhism, and are good deities that guard Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Bishamonten, Vaisravana
Buddhism.desc: Bishamonten (vaizravaNa in Sanskrit) is a Buddha of the Tenbu, deities who reside in a heavenly realm, this being one of six realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another, in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Monzeki (Monseki)
Buddhism.desc: "Monzeki" or "Monseki" means the formal successor of the founder of a Buddhist sect in Japan.

Buddhism.name: The Jodo Shinshu sect Hongwan-ji-ha
Buddhism.desc: The sect Hong gwan-ji-ha is one of the Jodo Shinshu sects.

Buddhism.name: The Shinshu sect Otani-ha
Buddhism.desc: The Shinshu sect Otani-ha is one of the groups of Jodo Shinshu sect.

Buddhism.name: Fudo Myoo
Buddhism.desc: Fudo Myoo (acala naatha in Sanskrit) is a subject of worship in Buddhism and one of the Myoo, a venerable status (尊格) that is specific to Mikkyo, Esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Dainichinyorai
Buddhism.desc: Dainichinyorai (mahaavairocana in Sanskrit) is a venerable entity of the pantheistic Nyorai (the Dharmakaya Buddha), which is thought of as a unit of the universe itself in Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Nyonin Kinsei (No Women Admitted)
Buddhism.desc: "Nyonin Kinsei (No Women Admitted)" means forbiddance for women to enter shrines and temples, reijo (sacred ground), ceremonial sites and others, as well as the limitation to unobstructed cultivation and worship by men.

Buddhism.name: Juichimen Kannon, (Kannon with Eleven Faces) (十一面観音)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Juichimen Kannon, (Kannon with Eleven Faces) (十一面観音).html
Buddhism.desc: Juichimen Kannon (ekadaza mukha in Sanskrit) is one of the venerable entities of Bosatsu, which is worshipped in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Jizo Bosatsu
Buddhism.desc: Jizo Bosatsu (d kSiti gharbha in Sanskrit) is one of the venerable entities of Bosatsu, which is worshipped in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Aizen Myoo (Ragaraja)
Buddhism.desc: Aizen Myoo (Ragaraja) is one of the Myoos (king of wisdom), being worshipped in Buddhism and having venerable status specific to Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Zazen
Buddhism.desc: Zazen (meditation) is a fundamental method of training in Zen Buddhism, in which one meditates sitting with correct posture.

Buddhism.name: Seiryu Gongen (Seiryo Gongen)
Buddhism.desc: Seiryu Gongen (清瀧権現), or Seiryo Gongen, is a guardian goddess of Daigo-ji Temple, the grand head temple of the Shingon sect Daigo-ha branch in the Fushimi Ward of Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Enma
Buddhism.desc: According to Buddhism and Hinduism, Enma is the master of Hell.

Buddhism.name: Gochi Nyorai (Five Wisdom Buddhas)
Buddhism.desc: The Gochi Nyorai, also known as Godai Nyorai, are five nyorai (tathagatas) associated with the five wisdoms of esoteric Buddhism (wisdom of the essence of the Dharma-realm, great perfect mirror wisdom, wisdom of equality, wisdom of wondrous observation, wisdom of accomplishing that which is to be done).

Buddhism.name: Kechimyaku Sojo (Nichiren Shoshu sect)
Buddhism.desc: According to Buddhism, Kechimyaku Sojo means the handing down of law (dharma) from a mentor to a disciple.

Buddhism.name: OTANI Koen
Buddhism.desc: Koen OTANI (February 27, 1875 - February 6, 1943) was a Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) monk who was the 23rd Hossu (head priest) of the Otani School of the Jodo Shinshu.

Buddhism.name: Gozu Tenno
Buddhism.desc: Originally, Gozu Tenno (gośīrşa) was an Indian deity and the guardian deity of Gion-shoja (the Jetavana monastery).

Buddhism.name: Kujaku Myoo (the peacock king of those who hold knowledge)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Kujaku Myoo (the peacock king of those who hold knowledge).html
Buddhism.desc: Kujaku Myoo is an object of worship in Buddhism and one of the Myoo (king of wisdom) having venerable status specific to Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Jocho
Buddhism.desc: Jocho (D.O.B. unknown - died September 2, 1057) was a sculptor active in the latter part of the Heian period and is said to be the sculptor who perfected the technique called yoseki-zukuri, in which the main part of a statue is made out of two or more pieces of wood.

Buddhism.name: Komokuten (Virupaksa)
Buddhism.desc: According to Buddhism, Komokuten (viruupaakSa in Sanskrit) is the Buddha of Tenbu (deities who reside in a heavenly realm, one of six realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another).

Buddhism.name: Sohei
Buddhism.desc: The term Sohei means samurai (warriors) with the appearance of priests who were active from the Medieval Period until the early modern ages.

Buddhism.name: Rokudo
Buddhism.desc: Rokudo is a Buddhist term and it means six posthumous worlds to which the souls of the dead transmigrate.

Buddhism.name: Shojin ryori (Vegetarian dishes)
Buddhism.desc: We will introduce two kinds of Shojin ryori here; one are Shojin ryori derived from Buddhism and the other are Shojin ryori that are categorized as one of Japanese cuisine.

Buddhism.name: Kangiten (Nandikesvara)
Buddhism.desc: Kangiten (or Nandikesvara) (Ganapati in Sanskrit) is one of the tenbu, guardian deities that reside in a heavenly realm, one of six realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another, in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Kuya (Koya)
Buddhism.desc: Kuya or Koya (903 - September 11, 972) was a priest in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: SHIMOTSUMA Rairyu
Buddhism.desc: Rairyu SHIMOTSUMA (1552 - June 15, 1609) was a priest of the Otani family in the age of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Ekei in Ankoku-ji Temple (Temple for National Pacification) (安国寺)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Ekei in Ankoku-ji Temple (Temple for National Pacification) (安国寺).html
Buddhism.desc: Ekei, of Ankoku-ji Temple, was a Zen priest and a Japanese feudal lord from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) to the Azuchi Momoyama period.

Buddhism.name: Honzon (Nichiren Shoshu)
Buddhism.desc: The honzon (the principal object of worship) in Nichiren Shoshu Buddhism is the Honmonkaidan-no-Daigohonzon (usually called the Lotus Mandala).

Buddhism.name: Sandaihiho: the Three Great Secret Dharmas
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Sandaihiho the Three Great Secret Dharmas.html
Buddhism.desc: Sandaihiho (the Three Great Secret Dharmas) comprises the fundamental dharmas in Buddhism by Nichiren and consists of Honmon no Honzon (the Object of Veneration of the Essential Teachings of the Lotus Sutra), Honmon no Kaidan (the Platform for the Receipt of the Precepts and Place of Practice of the Essential Teachings of the Lotus Sutra) and Honmon no Daimoku (the Sacred Title of the Essential Teachings of the Lotus Sutra).

Buddhism.name: Jien
Buddhism.desc: Jien (May 17, 1155 - October 28, 1225) was a priest of the Tendai sect in the Kamakura period and was famous for the history book, "Gukansho."

Buddhism.name: Gukansho
Buddhism.desc: "Gukansho" is a history book written by Jien, a priest of the Tendai sect, in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Henjo
Buddhism.desc: Henjo (born 816, died February 12, 890) was an early Heian period poet and one of the Six Poets and also one of the Thirty-six Immortal Poets.

Buddhism.name: Shingi Shingon sect
Buddhism.desc: The Shingi Shingon sect is a school of the Shingon sect (whose founding father was Kobo-daishi Kukai), and this school is connected to Raiyu, a high-ranking Buddhist priest of the Kakuban school, which followed the teachings of Kogyo Daishi Kakuban, who brought about the revival of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Honzon
Buddhism.desc: Honzon has the following meanings.

Buddhism.name: Ichimai Kishomon (The One Sheet Document)
Buddhism.desc: The Ichimai Kishomon is a will left by Honen on February 27, 1212 just prior to his death.

Buddhism.name: Shaka Sanzon
Buddhism.desc: Shaka Sanzon is a style in Buddhism for installing Buddha images.

Buddhism.name: Bonsho
Buddhism.desc: Bonsho are hanging bells as a Buddhist equipment used in East Asian temples.

Buddhism.name: Seishi Bosatsu
Buddhism.desc: Seishi Bosatsu, Bon name: mahaasthaamapraapta, is a Bosatsu in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Yakushi sanzon, Yakushi triad
Buddhism.desc: Yakushi sanzon, or Yakushi triad, is one of the styles to place Buddhist images in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Yuzu Nenbutsu sect
Buddhism.desc: Yuzu Nenbutsu sect is one of the sects of pure land teachings, Jodo-kyo.

Buddhism.name: Fugen Bosatsu (Samantabhadra Bodhisattva)
Buddhism.desc: Fugen Bosatsu, samanta bhadra in Sanskrit, is a venerable Bosatsu entity and is Bodhisattva, which is worshipped in Mahayana Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Kyoto Gozan Temples
Buddhism.desc: Kyoto Gozan Temples refers the status of a Buddhist temple, and to the system of state-sponsored temples of the Zen sect (Rinzai sect) in Kyoto among the Five Mountain System.

Buddhism.name: TAIGEN Sessai
Buddhism.desc: Sessai TAIGEN or Sufu TAIGEN (1496 - November 23,1555) was a vassal of the Imagawa clan.

Buddhism.name: Sho Kannon
Buddhism.desc: Sho Kannon, aarya avalokitezvara in Sanskrit is a venerable entity of Bosatsu, Bodhisattva, which is worshipped in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Nyoirin Kannon
Buddhism.desc: Nyoirin Kannon, cintaamaNicakra in Sanskrit, is a venerable entity of Bosatsu, Bodhisattva, and is worshipped in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Kokuzo Bosatsu
Buddhism.desc: Kokuzo Bosatsu is Ākāśagarbh or Gaganagajja in Sanskrit, and is a Bosatsu that is revered in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Zao Gongen
Buddhism.desc: Zao Gongen is a venerable entity worshipped in Buddhism in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Hachibushu
Buddhism.desc: Hachibushu or Tenryu Hachibushu refers to eight deities who guard Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Juniten
Buddhism.desc: Juniten is a mixture of the twelve deities of 'Ten,' which are Goho Zenshin (good deities protecting dharma) in Buddhism and is given high value in Esoteric Buddhism, as well as Shitenno (Four Guardian Kings).

Buddhism.name: Shonyo
Buddhism.desc: Shonyo (December 23, 1516 - September 19, 1554) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Junnyo
Buddhism.desc: Junnyo (August 3, 1577 - January 21, 1632) was an individual from the Azuchi-Momoyama period and Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Senju Kannon (Thousand-Armed Goddess of Mercy)
Buddhism.desc: Senju Kannon, sahasrabhuja aaryaavalokitezvara in Sanskrit, is a venerable entity of Bosatsu, Bodhisattva, which is worshipped in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Risshu Sect
Buddhism.desc: Risshu sect is one the sects of Buddhism which research and practice commandments.

Buddhism.name: Butto (Pagoda)
Buddhism.desc: A pagoda is a Buddhist building derived from the ancient Indian stupa.

Buddhism.name: Kyoso Hanjaku (evaluation of sutras)
Buddhism.desc: Kyoso Hanjaku means evaluation of Buddhist scriptures, and was practiced in regions where Buddhist scriptures using Chinese characters were used, including China, for the purpose of evaluating and interpreting Buddhist scriptures based on the height and depth of their contents.

Buddhism.name: Sanmon and Yamato
Buddhism.desc: Sanmon

Buddhism.name: Monkan
Buddhism.desc: Monkan (1278 - November 29, 1357) was a priest who lived from the Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: SHUNOKU Myoha
Buddhism.desc: Myoha SHUNOKU (1311 - November 9, 1388) was a Zen priest of the Rinzai sect in the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Segaki
Buddhism.desc: Segaki is a title of a Buddhist mass.

Buddhism.name: Shingon Risshu Sect
Buddhism.desc: Shingon Risshu sect is one sect which practices the commandments of Vajrayana based on the dharma of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Shoku
Buddhism.desc: Shoku (or Nishiyama, 1177 - December 31, 1247) was the founder of the Seizan Jodo sect, Seizan Zenrin-ji School of the Jodo sect and Seizan Fukakusa School of the Jodo sect.

Buddhism.name: Mappo-shiso
Buddhism.desc: Mappo-shiso is a kind of Buddhist prediction philosophy under three periods which the period of 1,000 years (also said to be 500 years) after the establishment of Buddhism by Shaka is called Shobo, and the following period of 1,000 years is called Zobo and the following period of 10,000 years is called Mappo and these three periods are considered as different.

Buddhism.name: Ryokai-mandala (Mandala of the two Realms)
Buddhism.desc: Ryokai-mandala is a mandala which visually depicts the truth and the state of enlightenment that is advocated by Dainichi Nyorai (Mahavairocana), principal Buddha in Esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Godai Bosatsu (Five Great Bodhisattava)
Buddhism.desc: Godai Bosatsu are a kind of combination of Bosatsu (those who are engaged in ascetic training in pursuit of the truth and enlightment) that are objects of worship and construction of statues in Buddhist society.

Buddhism.name: Tenbu (Celestial Beings)
Buddhism.desc: Tenbu (deva in Sanskrit) means deities of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Mandala
Buddhism.desc: Mandala (Sanskrit: mandala) means works that express sanctuary, Buddhahood and/or the world view of Buddhism visually and symbolically by means of statutes of Buddha, symbols and characters (especially those of Esoteric Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: TAKUAN Soho
Buddhism.desc: Soho TAKUAN (January 3, 1574 - January 27, 1646) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect who was active in the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: GIDO Shushin
Buddhism.desc: Shushin GIDO (February 8, 1325 - May 18, 1388) was a priest of the Rinzai sect who was active from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts to the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: ONISHI Ryokei
Buddhism.desc: Ryokei ONISHI (December 21, 1875 - February 15, 1983) was a Hosso Sect Buddhist monk who served as head priest of Kiyomizu-dera Temple in Kyoto and in his later years was also renowned for holding the record as the oldest person in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Ryogen
Buddhism.desc: Ryogen (912 - January 31, 985) was a priest of the Tendai Sect who was active in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Juzu (beadroll)
Buddhism.desc: Juzu (数珠) is a Buddhist ritual implement and a kind of ring composed of many beads which are linked by piercing a bundle of threads into a hole made on each bead.

Buddhism.name: Inso (the gesture of the hands of an image of Buddha or a god of Hinduism)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Inso (the gesture of the hands of an image of Buddha or a god of Hinduism).html
Buddhism.desc: Inso is a Buddhist and Hinduism term which refers to the gesture of the hands having a certain symbolic meaning.

Buddhism.name: ANO Zenjo (or Zensei)
Buddhism.desc: Zenjo ANO (1153 - August 8, 1203) was a priest from late Heian period to early Kamakura period and the seventh son of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo.

Buddhism.name: Dakiniten
Buddhism.desc: Dakiniten (written as 荼枳尼天 or 荼吉尼天 in kanji characters) is a Buddhist goddess.

Buddhism.name: Sanmon (large triple gate to temple)
Buddhism.desc: The term Sanmon refers to a gate located in front of a temple.

Buddhism.name: Suden
Buddhism.desc: Suden (1569 - February 28, 1633) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect and a politician serving the Tokugawa shogunate from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Kaidan (Ordination Platform)
Buddhism.desc: The term kaidan (ordination platform) is a Buddhist term that refers to a place for giving the precepts of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Shinkei
Buddhism.desc: Shinkei (1406 - May 29, 1475) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai Sect and also a renga poet (linked-verse poet) in the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: INGEN Ryuki (Also known as Yinyuan Longqi)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/INGEN Ryuki (Also known as Yinyuan Longqi).html
Buddhism.desc: INGEN Ryuki (December 7, 1592 – May 19, 1673) was a Chinese Zen Buddhist priest in the periods of the late Ming Dynasty and the early Qing Dynasty, who was born in Fuqing, Fuzhou of Fujian Province, China; his secular family name was Hayashi (林), and his imperially bestowed titles in Japan were Shinku daishi (daishi: a great teacher monk) and Kako daishi; and he was given special posthumous Buddhist names, Daiko-fusho kokushi (kokushi: a posthumous Buddhist title given by the Emperor), Butsuji-kokan kokushi, Kinzan-shushutsu kokushi, and Kakusho-enmyo kokushi.

Buddhism.name: Maitreya Bodhisattva in Manas in a Semi-Lotus Position
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Maitreya Bodhisattva in Manas in a Semi-Lotus Position.html
Buddhism.desc: Maitreya Bodhisattva in manas in a semi-lotus position came to Japan when Miroku (Maitreya) worship was imported from China in the sixth through the seventh centuries, and many statues created in the Asuka and Nara period still remain in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Kancho
Buddhism.desc: Kancho (916 - July 13, 998) was a Buddhist monk of the Shingon Sect in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Sanpo-e (a Japanese literary collection of Buddhist narratives)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Sanpo-e (a Japanese literary collection of Buddhist narratives).html
Buddhism.desc: Sanbo-ekotoba is a collection of Buddhist tales compiled in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Juo-shinko (Ten Kings (Ten Judges of Hell) belief)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Juo-shinko (Ten Kings (Ten Judges of Hell) belief).html
Buddhism.desc: In Juo-shinko, the faithful beg for the mercy of ten judges, who decide the realm to which the dead would go posthumously.

Buddhism.name: KIKEI Shinzui
Buddhism.desc: Shinzui KIKEI (1401 - September 25, 1469) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect of Buddhism and also master of Inryoken Household in Rokuonin Temple in the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Ojoyoshu (The Essentials of Salvation)
Buddhism.desc: Ojoyoshu is a Buddhism book in one part and three volumes compiled in 985 by Genshin (priest), a Sozu (the Prelate) in Eshinin Temple at Yokawa on Mt. Hiei, in which he collected important passages relating to gokuraku ojo (the Pure Land of Amitabha where the dead are allowed to live peacefully), extracting from many sources such as Buddhist scriptures and instructions in terms of the Jodo Sect.

Buddhism.name: Kanjo
Buddhism.desc: Kanjo is a ceremony mainly celebrated in Esoteric Buddhism, in which a legitimate successor is declared by pouring water over the top of the head.

Buddhism.name: Gessho
Buddhism.desc: Gessho (1813 - December 20, 1858) was a Sonno Joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians) School Buddhist monk who lived at the end of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Ganami
Buddhism.desc: Ganami (? - June 23, 1486) was a priest of Ji Sect in the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Nisshin
Buddhism.desc: Nisshin (1407 - October 30, 1488) was a priest of the Nichiren Sect in the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Chogen
Buddhism.desc: Chogen (1121 - 19 July, 1206) was a Buddhist monk from the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Matsunoo-dera Temple Hotokemai
Buddhism.desc: The Matsunoo-dera Temple hotokemai (Buddhist dance) is a religious ritual conducted at Matsunoo-dera Temple (Maizuru City) in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: KITSUSAN Mincho
Buddhism.desc: Mincho KITSUSAN (1352 - 5 October,1431) was an artist monk during the early and middle Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Hokke Sect of Honmon School
Buddhism.desc: The Hokke Sect of Honmon School is a denomination of Nichiren Buddhism for which the sect founder is considered to be Nichiren and the school founder is believed to be Nichiryu.

Buddhism.name: Benzaiten
Buddhism.desc: Benzaiten is one of the deva guardian gods in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: OZEKI Soen
Buddhism.desc: Soen OZEKI (1932 -) is the head priest of the Daisen-in sub-temple of Daitoku-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Hojoe (ritual of releasing captive animals)
Buddhism.desc: Hojoe is a religious ritual in which captive animals are released into the wild to admonish against the taking of life.

Buddhism.name: Zasu (temple's head priest)
Buddhism.desc: Zasu

Buddhism.name: Nichiyo
Buddhism.desc: Nichiyo (1556 - January 1, 1641, Japan) was a Shingon Sect priest in the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: BANRI Shukyu
Buddhism.desc: Shukyu BANRI (October 26, 1428 - ?) was a Zen priest and kajin (waka poet) in the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Shobo
Buddhism.desc: Shobo (832 - July 30, 909) was a Shingon Sect priest in the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Nichia
Buddhism.desc: Nichia (? - March 10, 1407) was the seventh head priest of Taiseki-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Nichiin
Buddhism.desc: Nichiin (1518 - August 16, 1589) was the 13th head priest of Taiseki-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Butsudan (Buddhist Alter)
Buddhism.desc: Butsudan is a permanent miniature temple in an ordinary house to enshrine Buddha as well as an alter to enshrine the dead of the family.

Buddhism.name: Nichiren Shoshu Sect
Buddhism.desc: Nichiren Shoshu Sect is one of the religious schools of Buddhism which had Nichiren as the founder of a religious sect, and was founded by Nikko.

Buddhism.name: Ninkan
Buddhism.desc: Ninkan (birth date unknown - 1114) was the founder of the Tachikawa School (Esoteric Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: E Ingakyo (Illustrated Sutra of Cause and Effect)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/E Ingakyo (Illustrated Sutra of Cause and Effect).html
Buddhism.desc: The E Ingakyo is one manuscript of the "Kako Genzai Inga-kyo Sutra" (one of the sutras representing the life-story of the Buddha) with transcribed sutras in the lower half of the Kansubon (book in scroll style) as well as illustrations in the upper half depicting the contents of the sutra, and it is believed to be the origin of emakimono (picture scrolls) which spread nationwide from the time of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Fujimon School
Buddhism.desc: Fujimon School is one of the generic names for numbers of honzan temples (head temples) and their branch temples in Nichiren Sect, which succeed the dharma lineage of Nikko, who was one of 6 high-caliber disciples of Nichiren.

Buddhism.name: Jodo Shinshu Higashi Hongan-ji school
Buddhism.desc: Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) Higashi Hongan-ji school is a school of the Jodo Shinshu consisting of more than 300 branch temples and respected temples which separated from the Shinshu sect Otani school containing around 10,000 branch temples.

Buddhism.name: The Honmon Sect
Buddhism.desc: The Nichiren Honmon Sect (Also known as Honmon Sect) is a sect based on Nichiren Buddhism, which was organized by Nikkomon School (a branch temple succeeding the Nikko's Buddhist teaching lineage) in 1876, and merged with the Nichiren Sect and the Kenpon Hokke Sect in 1941 in order to form a better organization.

Buddhism.name: Hatto (Lecture Hall)
Buddhism.desc: Hatto is a construction in a Buddhist temple where priests make lectures about Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Takuhatsu
Buddhism.desc: Takuhatsu (pindapata in Sanskrit) is one of the forms of ascetic practice for monks of Ancient Indian religions, including Buddhism and Jainism, and it is an ascetic practice to make monks go around the homes of believers, beg for the least amount of food and so on required, and let the believers earn merit.

Buddhism.name: Kyonyo
Buddhism.desc: Kyonyo (6 November, 1558 - 6 November, 1614) the twelfth chief priest of the Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Tokudo
Buddhism.desc: Tokudo is a ceremony in Buddhism to enter into priesthood.

Buddhism.name: Nika Sojo Documents
Buddhism.desc: Nika Sojo are documents which were believed to be addressed from Nichiren to his disciple, Nikko, in 1282.

Buddhism.name: Daishi (priest)
Buddhism.desc: Daishi is a kind of honorific title in China and in Japan bestowed to priests with high virtue by the Imperial Court, and many of them are okurina (posthumous names).

Buddhism.name: Jetavana Vihara
Buddhism.desc: Jetavana Vihara (the formal name is "Jetavana Anathapindadasya-arama" in Sanskrit) was a temple at Sravasti in Middle India, where Buddha preached sermons.

Buddhism.name: SHUHO Myocho
Buddhism.desc: Myocho SHUHO (1282 - January 21, 1338) was a priest of Rinzai Sect in the last Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: KOUN Ejo
Buddhism.desc: Ejo KOUN ((1198 - September 26, 1280) was a priest of the Zen Sect in the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Jiun
Buddhism.desc: Jiun (August 24, 1718 - January 22, 1805) was a Buddhist priest of the Shingon Sect in the late Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Gyokyo
Buddhism.desc: Gyokyo (years of his birth and death was unknown) was a Buddhist priest of Daian-ji Temple in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kakuyu
Buddhism.desc: Kakuyu (1053 - November 3, 1140) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai Sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Nihon Daruma Sect
Buddhism.desc: Nihon Daruma Sect is a school of the Zen Sect which Nonin DAINICHIBO founded.

Buddhism.name: Kenpon Hokke Sect
Buddhism.desc: Kenpon Hokke Sect, whose sect founder was Nichiren and school founder was Nichiju, is a school of the Nichiren Sect.

Buddhism.name: Mongaku
Buddhism.desc: Mongaku (1139 - September 5, 1203) was a priest of the Shingon Sect of Buddhism who lived from the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Nichiren Hon Sect
Buddhism.desc: Nichiren Hon Sect, whose sect founder was Nichiren and school founder was Nisson of Fujimon School, is a school that inherits Nichiren's teachings.

Buddhism.name: Earthen image
Buddhism.desc: The term earthen image means images of which the material is clay.

Buddhism.name: Buddhist altar fittings
Buddhism.desc: Buddhist altar fittings are defined as special tools or accessories which are used by clergymen, such as Buddhist monks, on the occasion of Buddhist rituals and they are different from daily necessities.

Buddhism.name: Setsuna (ephemeral)
Buddhism.desc: Setsuna is one of the Buddhist concepts of time and is the briefest unit of time in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Jiin Sho-Hatto
Buddhism.desc: Jiin Sho-Hatto is a general term for a set of regulations that applied to the Buddhist religious community in the Tokugawa Shogunate in the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Wakei Seijaku
Buddhism.desc: Wakei Seijaku (literally meaning harmony, respect, purity and tranquility) is a slogan emphasized in Sado (Japanese tea ceremony), which is particularly respected in the House of Sen through the 'Shiki' (Four Principles of Tea) as laid down by SEN no Rikyu.

Buddhism.name: SANYO Genkitsu
Buddhism.desc: Genkitsu SANYO (1548 - June 19, 1612) was a Zen priest who was active during the period from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: MANZAN Dohaku
Buddhism.desc: Dohaku MANZAN (1635 - 1715) was a priest of Soto Sect in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Myoe
Buddhism.desc: Myoe (February 28, 1173 - February 18, 1232) was a Buddhist monk of Kegon Sect in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Jogyo
Buddhism.desc: Jogyo (also known as Teigyo, March 25, 1186 - April 3, 1231) was a monk living from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: IKENOBO Senkei
Buddhism.desc: Senkei IKENOBO (the dates of his birth and death were unknown) was a Buddhist priest of Kyoto Choho-ji Temple (Rokkakudo) in the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: MURATA Juko
Buddhism.desc: Juko MURATA (1432 - June 29, 1502) was a chajin (master of the tea ceremony) in the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Sotan
Buddhism.desc: Sotan (1413 - 1481) was an artist-monk in the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Shubun
Buddhism.desc: Shubun (the years of his birth and death was unknown) was a Zen priest and artist-monk in the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Josetsu
Buddhism.desc: Josetsu (the years of his birth and death was unknown) was an artist-monk from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts to the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Hibutsu
Buddhism.desc: Hibutsu are Buddhist images that are normally withheld from public view for religious reasons; they are enshrined in zushi (miniature shrines in temples) with the doors closed.

Buddhism.name: TETSUGYU Doki
Buddhism.desc: Doki TETSUGYU (August 25, 1628 - October 2, 1700) was a Zen priest of the Obaku School in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: TETSUGEN Doko
Buddhism.desc: Doko TETSUGEN (February 12, 1630 - April 27, 1682) was a Zen priest of the Obaku School in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Ryonin
Buddhism.desc: Ryonin (February 26, 1073 ? - February 26, 1132) was a Buddhist priest of Tendai Sect in the late Heian period and the founder of Yuzu Nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation) Sect.

Buddhism.name: TOSANOBO Shoshun
Buddhism.desc: Shoshun TOSANOBO (1143 - November 26, 1185) was busho (Japanese military commander) as well as a Buddhist priest in the last Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Fujufuse School of Nichiren Sect
Buddhism.desc: Fujufuse (Not Receive and Not Give) School of the Nichiren Sect is a sect whose founder was Nichiren and the school founder was Nichio.

Buddhism.name: Fujufuse Nichiren Komon Sect
Buddhism.desc: Fujufuse (Not Receive and Not Give) Nichiren Komon Sect is a school of the Nichiren Sect for which the sect founder was Nichiren and the school founder was Nichio.

Buddhism.name: Jokaku
Buddhism.desc: Jokaku (1147 - October, 1226) was a Buddhist monk of the Shingon Sect from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Annen
Buddhism.desc: Annen (841? - 915?) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: IKENOBO Seno
Buddhism.desc: Seno IKENOBO (1482 - 1543) was a Buddhist monk of Kyoto Choho-ji Temple (Rokkakudo) as well as a tatebana (flower arrangement) master in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Honmon Hokke Sect
Buddhism.desc: Honmon Hokke Sect is a school of Nichiren Sect of which the sect founder was Nichiren and the school founder was Nichiryu (Honmon School of Hokke Sect).

Buddhism.name: Gyoen
Buddhism.desc: Gyoen (the dates of his birth and death are unknown) was a monk in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Mansai (Manzei)
Buddhism.desc: Mansai (Also known as Manzei) (1378 – July 17, 1435) was a Buddhist monk of Daigo-ji Temple (Shingon Sect) from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts through the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Jokei
Buddhism.desc: Jokei (June 29, 1155 - March 3, 1213) was a Buddhist monk in the Hosso Sect in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Bencho
Buddhism.desc: Bencho (June 27, 1162 - March 23, 1238) was a Buddhist monk in the Jodo Sect from the late Heian period to the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Chosai
Buddhism.desc: Chosai (1184 - February 19, 1266) was a priest of the Jodo Sect in the middle of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Taimitsu
Buddhism.desc: Taimitsu is Esoteric Buddhism (Buddhism handed down secretly from general people) handed down by the Tendai Sect.

Buddhism.name: ASAYAMA Nichijo
Buddhism.desc: Nichijo ASAYAMA (? - November 5, 1577) was a Buddhist monk of Nichiren Sect in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

Buddhism.name: Manshuin Temple
Buddhism.desc: Manshuin Temple is a Buddhist temple of the Tendai Sect that is located at Ichijo-ji Temple in Sakyo-ku Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Gishin
Buddhism.desc: Gishin (born 781, died August 26, 833) was an early Heian-period Buddhist monk of the Tendai sect.

Buddhism.name: Taihan
Buddhism.desc: Taihan (778-?) was an early Heian period Buddhist monk of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Jichie
Buddhism.desc: Jichie (also pronounced Jitsue, born 786, died December 24, 847), was an early Heian-period Buddhist priest of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Encho
Buddhism.desc: Encho (772-837) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Gien
Buddhism.desc: Gien (October 1, 1558 - June 15, 1626) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) to Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Shuen
Buddhism.desc: Shuen (771 - July 16, 835) was a Hosso Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Enkan
Buddhism.desc: Enkan (September 1, 1281 - April 2, 1356) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Kamakura period and the Northern and Southern Courts period.

Buddhism.name: Jojin
Buddhism.desc: Jojin (1011 - November 9, 1081) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: So-do Hall
Buddhism.desc: A so-do hall is a temple building dedicated to the communal living of practitioners (monks) and the promotion of ascetic practices.

Buddhism.name: Ningai
Buddhism.desc: Ningai (951 - June 22, 1046) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Gengo
Buddhism.desc: Gengo (914 - March 30, 995) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Yukai
Buddhism.desc: Yukai (1345 - August 10, 1416) was a Shingon Sect priest scholar who lived from the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan) to the mid-Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Yua
Buddhism.desc: Yua (1291 - c.1379) was a Ji Sect Buddhist monk and Manyo scholar who lived from the latter part of the Kamakura period to the Northern and Southern Courts period.

Buddhism.name: Taa
Buddhism.desc: Taa (1237 - February 18, 1319) was a Ji Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shubin
Buddhism.desc: Shubin (dates of birth and death unknown) was a monk in the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Myoun
Buddhism.desc: Myoun (1115 - January 3, 1184) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kakuen
Buddhism.desc: Kakuen (1031 - May 19, 1098) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Raigo
Buddhism.desc: Raigo (1002 - 1084) was a Japanese monk of the Tendai sect in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kokan Shiren
Buddhism.desc: Kokan Shiren (1278 - August 11, 1346) was a Rinzai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Kamakura period and the Northern and Southern Courts period.

Buddhism.name: Zomyo
Buddhism.desc: Zomyo (843 - December 12, 927) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Eri
Buddhism.desc: Eri (852 - 935) was a Shingon Sect Buddhism monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shinzei
Buddhism.desc: Shinzei (800 - March 25, 860) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shinzen
Buddhism.desc: Shinzen (804 - October 21, 891) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Juo Sohitsu
Buddhism.desc: Juo Sohitsu (1296 - 1380) was a Rinzai Sect Buddhist monk who lived from the latter part of the Kamakura period to the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Shuei
Buddhism.desc: Shuei (809 - April 29, 884) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Josho
Buddhism.desc: Josho (906 - 983) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Jogyo
Buddhism.desc: Jogyo (birth date unknown - January 9, 867) was a Buddhist monk who lived during the first part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Daigen Suiho
Buddhism.desc: Daigen Suiho is one of the magic rituals of esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Kokua
Buddhism.desc: Kokua (1314 - October 4, 1405) was a Ji Sect Buddhist monk who lived from the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan) to the mid-Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Zoyo
Buddhism.desc: Zoyo (1032 - February 14, 1116) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Jozo
Buddhism.desc: Jozo (891 - December 27, 964) was a Tendai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shoken
Buddhism.desc: Shoken (March 30, 1138 - July 19, 1196) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shunkai
Buddhism.desc: Shunkai (date of birth and death unknown) was a Shingon sect priest who lived from the end of the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Josu
Buddhism.desc: Josu (also known as Teisu) (866 - August 19, 944) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Raiyu
Buddhism.desc: Raiyu (1226 - February 7, 1304) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived from the mid- to late-Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Taichu
Buddhism.desc: Taichu (February 23, 1552 - February 23, 1639) was a Jodo sect priest in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Kanpen
Buddhism.desc: Kanpen (1100 - July 28, 1166) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kanjo
Buddhism.desc: Kanjo (1057 - February 19, 1125) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the latter part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Priest-Imperial Prince Shoshin
Buddhism.desc: Priest-Imperial Prince Shoshin (July 1, 1005 - October 18, 1085) was a member of the Imperial Family and monk in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Saishin
Buddhism.desc: Saishin (also called Seijin) (March 12, 954 - July 14, 1030) was a monk of Shingon sect in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Jusanbutsu shinko (Thirteen Buddha belief)
Buddhism.desc: Jusanbutsu shinko refers to the belief in Juo, ten kings, who are judges in Meido hell including Enma-o (the King of Hell) who were created in Japan based on the Juo-shinko (ten Kings (ten Judges of Hell) belief) and in buddhas, according to the Honji-suijaku setsu (theory of original reality and manifested traces), whose present forms are judges who conduct the later trials (the sixth, the twelfth, and the 32nd anniversaries).

Buddhism.name: Engyo
Buddhism.desc: Engyo (799 - March 29, 852) was a monk of Shingon sect in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kenchi
Buddhism.desc: Kenchi (1226 - July 30, 1310 ?) was a monk of the Jodo Shinshu (True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) in the mid Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Kenshun
Buddhism.desc: Kenshun (1299-August 2, 1357) was a monk of Shingon sect in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Gangyo
Buddhism.desc: Gangyo (date of birth unknown, passed away on April 21, 874) was a learned priest pursuing his studies in the former Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Gonso
Buddhism.desc: Gonso was a Sanron sect priest (born in 754 and passed away in June 25, 827) in the latter Nara period and the former Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Yakushin
Buddhism.desc: Yakushin (827 - April 8, 906) was a Shingon sect priest in the former Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shunjo
Buddhism.desc: Shunjo (September 6, 1166 - April 25, 1227) was a priest in the former Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Kokei
Buddhism.desc: Kokei (977 - August 27, 1049) was a Tendai sect priest in the middle days of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Hoon-ko (a memorial services for Shinran)
Buddhism.desc: Hoon-ko refers to a memorial service which was held around the anniversary of the death of Shinran (1173 - 1262), the founder of Jodo Shinshu (True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) for the purpose of Hon shatoku (repayment for indebtedness) to the founder.

Buddhism.name: Kanku
Buddhism.desc: Kanku (884 - February 28, 972) was a Shingon sect priest in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Nichiju
Buddhism.desc: Nichiju (June 11, 1314 - February 28, 1392) was a Nichiren sect priest in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Nichio
Buddhism.desc: Nichio (July 5, 1565 - April 22, 1630) was a Nichiren sect priest from the Azuchi-momoyama to the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Nichiju
Buddhism.desc: Nichiju (1549 to 1623) was a Nichiren sect priest from the Azuchi-momoyama to the early the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Nichiko
Buddhism.desc: Nichiko (1532 - 1598) was a monk of Nichiren Sect in the Azuchi-momoyama period.

Buddhism.name: Nikken
Buddhism.desc: Nikken (1560 - December 6, 1635) was a Buddhist monk of Nichiren Sect in the Azuchi-momoyama period to the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Eun
Buddhism.desc: Eun (798 - October 31, 869) was a Buddhist monk of Shingon Sect in the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kani
Buddhism.desc: Kani (1062 - July 12, 1101) was a Buddhist monk of Shingon Sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Gakyo
Buddhism.desc: Gakyo (date birth is not known - February 8, 1013) was a Buddhist monk of Shingon Sect in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Hannyashin-gyo Hiken
Buddhism.desc: "Hannyashin-gyo Hiken" was a commentary on "Hannya Shingyo" (the Wisdom Sutras) and was written by Kukai around 818.

Buddhism.name: Soni
Buddhism.desc: Soni is part of Buddhist terminology that means listening to the precious views of a priestly mentor.

Buddhism.name: Kakunyo
Buddhism.desc: Kakunyo was a Buddhist monk of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) who was active from the end Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Kanin
Buddhism.desc: Kanin (dates of birth and death unknown) was a Tendai sect priest in the middle Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kanshun
Buddhism.desc: Kanshun (978 - October 9, 1057) was a Buddhist monk of the Tendai sect who lived during the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kanshin
Buddhism.desc: Kanshin (also known as Kanjin) (1084 - April 2, 1153) was a Shingon sect priest in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kenshin
Buddhism.desc: Kenshin (1131- December 20, 1192) was a Tendai sect priest in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Nissei
Buddhism.desc: Nissei (March 23, 1623 - March 30, 1668) was a Buddhist monk of the Nichiren sect and a poet of Chinese poetry who lived in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Gene
Buddhism.desc: Gene (the year of his birth unknown - April 9, 1350) was a Buddhist monk of the Tendai sect and a Confucian scholar who lived during he period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Genkai
Buddhism.desc: Genkai (1093 - 1156) was a Shingon sect priest in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Jokai
Buddhism.desc: Jokai (February 1, 1074 - May 20, 1149) was a Buddhist monk of the Shingon sect who lived during the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Nichiho
Buddhism.desc: Nichiho (1607 - 1698) was a Nichiren sect priest in the early Edo period and master of tatebana (standing flowers).

Buddhism.name: Kakua
Buddhism.desc: Kakua (1143 - unknown) was a priest in the Tendai Sect of Buddhism from the end of the Heian period until the beginning of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: GAKUIN Ekatsu
Buddhism.desc: GAKUIN Ekatsu (1357 - March 8, 1425) was a Rinzai sect priest from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) to the mid Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Kakukai
Buddhism.desc: Kakukai (1142 - September 13, 1223) was a Shingon sect priest from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Kakujo (a sculptor of Buddhist statues)
Buddhism.desc: Kakujo (birth year unknown to 1077) was a sculptor of Buddhist statues in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Ryonyo
Buddhism.desc: Ryonyo (January 27, 1613 - October 18, 1662) was a Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) priest in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Kakunin
Buddhism.desc: Kakunin (dates of birth and death unknown), was a priest at Todai-ji Temple in the latter part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: GAZAN Joseki
Buddhism.desc: Joseki GAZAN (1275 - November 23, 1366) was a Soto sect priest from the end of Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: The Jinmon School of the Hokke Sect
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Jinmon School of the Hokke Sect.html
Buddhism.desc: The Jinmon school of the Hokke sect is a Buddhist school under Nichiren, with Nichiren being Shuso (or Koso, the founder) and Nichijin (1339 – 1414) being Haso (the founder of the school).

Buddhism.name: The Hokke Sect Shinmon School
Buddhism.desc: The Hokke sect Shinmon school is a Buddhist school led by Nichiren with Nichiren being Koso (the founder of the religious sect) and Nichishin being the founder of the school (the Hokke sect Shinmon school).

Buddhism.name: Chonen
Buddhism.desc: Chonen (February 25, 938 - April 25, 1016) was a priest at Todai-ji Temple during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Chonen
Buddhism.desc: Chonen (February 3, 1793 - March 22, 1868) was a Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) priest in the late Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Shinkan
Buddhism.desc: Shinkan (1275 - July 16, 1341) was a Ji sect priest from the end of the Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Mukan Fumon
Buddhism.desc: Mukan Fumon (1212 – January 3, 1292) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai Sect in the mid-Kamakura Period.

Buddhism.name: Zuikei Shuho
Buddhism.desc: Zuikei Shuho (January 2, 1392 – June 3, 1473) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai sect in the mid-Muromachi Period.

Buddhism.name: Ranbakeishi
Buddhism.desc: Ranbakeishi (1417 – March 17, 1501) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai sect between the mid-Muromachi and Sengoku periods (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Ryukan
Buddhism.desc: Ryukan (1148 - January 21, 1228) was a Jodo sect priest from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Ryoankeigo
Buddhism.desc: Ryoankeigo (1425 - October 3, 1514) was a Buddhist monk of Rinzai Sect in the mid-Muromachi period and Sengoku period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Tettsugikai
Buddhism.desc: Tettsugikai (February 18, 1219 - October 18, 1309) was a Buddhist monk of Soto Sect in the mid-Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Giku
Buddhism.desc: Giku (date of birth and death unknown) was a Zen-sect priest from Tang China in the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kikai
Buddhism.desc: 1178 - January 13, 1251) was a Kegon sect priest in the middle of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Mokujikiyoa
Buddhism.desc: Mokujikiyoa (year of birth is not clear - December 25, 1763) was a Buddhist monk of Shingon Sect in the mid-Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Ane
Buddhism.desc: Ane (794 - May 2, 868) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Ryoshonyudo Shinno
Buddhism.desc: Ryoshonyudo Shinno (January 16, 1623 - August 6, 1693) was the Monzeki (head priest of temple who was a member of the Imperial Family) of Kyoto Manju-in Temple in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Nikko
Buddhism.desc: Nikko (April 23, 1626 - April 20, 1698) was a Buddhist monk of Nichiren Sect in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Shokaku
Buddhism.desc: Shokaku (1057 - April 21, 1129) was a Buddhist monk of Shingon sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Jinzen
Buddhism.desc: Jinzen (943 - March 16, 990) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Myoson
Buddhism.desc: Myoson (971 - July 24, 1063) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Yokei
Buddhism.desc: Yokei (919 - April 5, 991) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Sonjun Hosshinno
Buddhism.desc: Sonjun Hosshinno (December 1, 1591 - June 21, 1653) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Gyogen
Buddhism.desc: Gyogen (1097 - December 1, 1155) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakukai
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakukai (1134 - December 23, 1181) was a Buddhist monk of Tendai Sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kakugen
Buddhism.desc: Kakugen (1000 - September 20, 1065) was a Japanese Buddhist monk of Shingon Sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Shoe
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Shoe (1094 - March 4, 1137) was a Shingon sect priest in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Oeshiki
Buddhism.desc: Oeshiki means Daihoe (great Buddhist memorial service) (a festival) that is held on the anniversary of sects' founders etc.

Buddhism.name: Gessen
Buddhism.desc: Gessen (1741 - February 25, 1809) was a priest and artist painter living between the mid and late Edo Period.

Buddhism.name: UNSHO Priest Ikkei
Buddhism.desc: Priest Ikkei UNSHO (June 17, 1386 - February 20, 1463) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect in the mid Muromachi Period.

Buddhism.name: Togan Ean
Buddhism.desc: Togan Ean (1225 - December 6, 1277) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect of Buddhism in the mid Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Kian Soen
Buddhism.desc: Kian Soen (February 8, 1261 - April 28, 1313) was a priest of the Rinzai sect of the late Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Mukyoku Shigen
Buddhism.desc: Mukyoku Shigen (1282 - March 23, 1359) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect of Buddhism from the late Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Sokuhi Nyoitsu
Buddhism.desc: Sokuhi Nyoitsu (June 27, 1616 - June 26, 1671) was a priest of the Obaku School (Obaku Sect) Rinzai Sect, and came from the Ming Dynasty in China in the early part of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Taigaku Shusu
Buddhism.desc: Taigaku Shusu (1345 - October 27, 1423) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect of Buddhism from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) to the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Daikyu Sokyu
Buddhism.desc: Daikyu Sokyu (1468 - September 25, 1549) was a priest of Rinzai Sect in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

Buddhism.name: Nichishin (Hokke sect Shinmon school)
Buddhism.desc: Nichishin (1444 - April 18, 1528) was a priest of the Nichiren sect of the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Nichiryu (of the Honmon Hokke Sect)
Buddhism.desc: Nichiryu (1385 - April 10, 1464) was a mid Muromachi-period Buddhist monk of the Nichiren Sect.

Buddhism.name: Genyu
Buddhism.desc: Genyu (1529 - November 14, 1605) was a Shingon Sect Buddhist monk who lived from the Sengoku period (period of warring states) into the beginning of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Jitsunyo
Buddhism.desc: Jitsunyo (September 26, 1458 - March 5, 1525) was a Buddhist priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) who lived from the mid-Muromachi period into the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

Buddhism.name: Shippan
Buddhism.desc: Shippan (unknown – October 15, 1144) was a monk during the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Doko
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Doko (April 8, 1612 – August 5, 1678) was a Cloistered Imperial Prince and learned monk during the early Edo Period.

Buddhism.name: KEIJO Shurin
Buddhism.desc: Shurin KEIJO (1440 - April 11, 1518) was a priest of the Rinzai sect of the late Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Amida Worship
Buddhism.desc: Amida (Amitabha) worship is the religious belief based on the Pure Land of Buddhism which believes in justification by belief and preaches that praying to Amida Nyorai would lead you to heaven.

Buddhism.name: Shoshun
Buddhism.desc: Shoshun (year of birth unknown - January 9, 906) was a priest of the Shingon sect in the early to the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shinsho
Buddhism.desc: Shinsho (797 - August 7, 873) was a priest of the Shingon Sect in the early part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Johen
Buddhism.desc: Johen (1166 - May 16, 1224) was a priest of the Shingon Sect in the early part of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Joon
Buddhism.desc: Joon (1201 - July 7, 1271) was a priest of the Jodo Sect from the early to the middle of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shinsho
Buddhism.desc: Shinsho (1167 - August 1, 1230) was a priest of the Tendai Sect from the latter part of the Heian period to the early part of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Dokaku
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Dokaku (1204 - February 13, 1250) was a priest of the Tendai sect in the early to mid Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shonen
Buddhism.desc: Shonen (1513 - August 27, 1554) was a Buddhist monk of the Jodo Sect in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Renkyo
Buddhism.desc: Renkyo (1451 - July 5, 1492) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) (the Koshoji School of Jodo Shinshu Sect) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Jiun-Myoi
Buddhism.desc: Jiun-Myoi (1274 - July 10, 1345) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect from the latter part of the Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Junyu (a priest)
Buddhism.desc: Junyu (890 - August 18, 953) was a priest of the Shingon Sect in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Chinkai
Buddhism.desc: Chinkai (1091 - December 20, 1152) was a learned priest pursuing his studies and also an artist monk of the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Priestly Imperial Prince Dojo
Buddhism.desc: Priestly Imperial Prince Dojo (November 7, 1196 - February 28, 1249) was a Priestly Imperial Prince of the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Nippo Soshun
Buddhism.desc: Nippo Soshun (1368 - March 10, 1448) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) to the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Sekko Soshin
Buddhism.desc: Sekko Soshin (1408 - July 12, 1486) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect from the middle of the Muromachi period to the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Myogu
Buddhism.desc: Myogu (946 - August 2, 1020) was a priest of the Tendai Sect in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Ensho (a priest)
Buddhism.desc: Ensho (880 - March 6, 964) was a priest of the Tendai Sect in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Enchin
Buddhism.desc: Enchin (dates of birth and death unknown) was a priest of the Hosso sect of the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Entsu
Buddhism.desc: Entsu (1754 - 1834) was a priest of the Tendai Sect of the late Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Richu-nyoo
Buddhism.desc: Richu-nyoo (September 26, 1641 - October 9, 1689) was a Buddhist nun of the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Gyoi
Buddhism.desc: Gyoi (1177 - 1217 ?) was a priest of the Tendai Sect between the end of the Heian period and the early period of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Kechimyaku-sojo
Buddhism.desc: Kechimyaku-sojo (also referred as kechimyaku-sosho) or blood inheritance is a metaphor that is used to describe the inheritance of teachings (Buddhism) from a mentor to a pupil, taking the blood flow as an analogy.

Buddhism.name: Hanshun
Buddhism.desc: Hanshun (1038 - May 21, 1112) was a priest of the Shingon sect of the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Banzuii
Buddhism.desc: Banzuii (December 1, 1542 - February 2, 1615) was a learned monk in the Jodo Sect from the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan) to the early in the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Hotan
Buddhism.desc: Hotan (1654 - April 14, 1738) was a learned monk in the middle of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Ryukei Shosen
Buddhism.desc: Ryukei Shosen (September 15, 1602 - October 6, 1670) was a priest of the Obaku Sect in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Ryusan Tokuken
Buddhism.desc: Ryusan Tokuken (1284 - December 22, 1358) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect from the late Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Ryushu Shutaku
Buddhism.desc: Ryushu-shutaku (1308 - October 17, 1388) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai Sect in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (in Japan).

Buddhism.name: Bunei Seikan
Buddhism.desc: Bunei-seikan (1568 - May 16, 1621) was a priest of the Rinzai sect from the Azuchi-momoyama to early Edo periods.

Buddhism.name: Reigan
Buddhism.desc: Reigan (May 9, 1554 - October 15, 1641) was a priest of the Jodo sect of the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Ryohen (Shingon sect)
Buddhism.desc: Ryohen (1150 - September 7, 1232) was a priest of the Shingon sect of the late Heian period to the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Songyu
Buddhism.desc: Songyu (July 22, 1469 - January 17, 1550) was a Jodo Sect priest who lived from the middle of the Muromachi period to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Genchi
Buddhism.desc: Genchi (1183 - January 18, 1239) was a priest of the Jodo sect of the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shingon
Buddhism.desc: Shingon (1150 - December 8, 1236) was a Shingon Sect priest who lived from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Jikun Toren
Buddhism.desc: Jikun Toren (1383 - February 5, 1471) was a Rinzai Sect priest in the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Reiku
Buddhism.desc: Reiku (1652 - November 4, 1739) was a Tendai Sect priest in the middle of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Ryonen
Buddhism.desc: Ryonen (1646 - October 29, 1711) was a Buddhist nun of the Obaku Sect who lived from the early Edo period to the mid-Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Nenku
Buddhism.desc: Nenku (year of birth unknown - August 30, 1297) was a priest of the Jodo sect of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Daisetsu Sono
Buddhism.desc: Daisetsu Sono (April 7, 1313 - October 1, 1377) was a Buddhist monk of the Rinzai Sect in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Gensho
Buddhism.desc: Gensho (1146 - 1204?) was a priest of the Shingon sect of the end of the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: SHIMAJI Mokurai
Buddhism.desc: Mokurai SHIMAJI (March 10, 1838 - February 3, 1911) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) Hongan-ji school who actively worked in the Meiji period.

Buddhism.name: Nissho (Fujufuse school)
Buddhism.desc: Nissho (1829 - 1908) was a priest of the Nichiren sect (Fujufuse school) of the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Koben
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Koben (September 16, 1669 - June 6, 1716) was a Buddhist monk of the Tendai Sect in the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Kokai (Buddhist priest)
Buddhism.desc: Kokai (January 29, 1608 – November 22, 1695) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai Sect in the early part of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Joe Hosshinno
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Joe Hosshinno (1164 - April 26, 1203) was a Cloistered Imperial Prince of the end of Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Joa
Buddhism.desc: Joa (1540 – August 28, 1619) was a Buddhist priest of the Jishu School and poet between the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) and the early part of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Junson
Buddhism.desc: Junson (November 28, 1585 – June 3, 1622) was a Buddhist priest and the 18th chief priest of Kosho-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Kifudo painting
Buddhism.desc: Kifudo painting is a 'hibutsu' (Buddhist image normally withheld from public view) of a standing statue of Fudomyoo (cetaka), the entire body of which is yellow, handed down to Onjo-ji Temple, commonly called Mii-dera Temple, in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Disposition of Debts of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Disposition of Debts of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple.html
Buddhism.desc: Disposition of debts of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple was an incident in which Higashi Hongan-ji Temple asked government officials for a rescue from their debts during the Meiji period.

Buddhism.name: Shukongo-shin
Buddhism.desc: Shukongo-shin is a Buddhist Goho zenjin (good deities protecting dharma) and is also referred to as Kongoshu and Jikongo.

Buddhism.name: Monto Mono Shirazu
Buddhism.desc: Monto mono shirazu' is a phrase which believers of other sects use when they criticize monto (believers) of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) as 'they don't know about the manners of Buddhism.'

Buddhism.name: Hashiri Bozu (the Running Priest)
Buddhism.desc: The Running Priest (November 20, 1872 – November 20, 1918) was a Buddhist priest known for his eccentricity of running around the streets of Kyoto City all day long in the Meiji and Taisho periods.

Buddhism.name: Torin-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: Torin-in Temple is one of the sub-temples of Myoshin-ji Temple of the Rinzai sect.

Buddhism.name: Goma
Buddhism.desc: Goma is a phonetic translation of a Sanskrit word 'homa' into Japanese.

Buddhism.name: Zen
Buddhism.desc: Zen (the Zen sect) is a school of Mahayana Buddhism which is regarded as having been established in China after being transmitted from India by Daruma (Bodhidharma).

Buddhism.name: Horin, Dharma-wheel (chakra)
Buddhism.desc: Horin (法輪) (Sanskrit: dharma-chakra, pinyin: falun) is another name for the creed of Buddhism, especially the Four Axioms Noble and the Eightfold Path taught by Buddha.

Buddhism.name: Nichizon
Buddhism.desc: Nichizon (1265 – 1346) was a disciple of Nikko.

Buddhism.name: Tendai-zasu
Buddhism.desc: Tendai-zasu (head priest of the Tendai sect) is a post that serves as the resident priest of Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei, the head temple of the Tendai sect, exercising general supervision over all of its sub-temples.

Buddhism.name: Kankyo no Tomo
Buddhism.desc: Kankyo no Tomo is a collection of Buddhist tales written in kana in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Hokke Mandala
Buddhism.desc: The Hokke mandala (Lotus Mandala) is one of the mandala that represent the world of Hoke-kyo Sutra (the Lotus Sutra) with illustrations, Sanskrit and kanji.

Buddhism.name: Seicho no Ie Uji Bekkaku Honzan
Buddhism.jp: 生長の家宇治別格本山
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Seicho no Ie Uji Bekkaku Honzan.html
Buddhism.desc: Seicho no Ie Uji Bekkaku Honzan is the bekkaku honzan (special head temple) of Seicho no Ie, which is centered around Hozo-jinja Shrine in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Garanjin
Buddhism.desc: Garanjin is a deity that guards temples and shrines.

Buddhism.name: Nyujo
Buddhism.desc: Nyujo is one of the ultimate ascetic practices of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Dainenbutsu Kyogen
Buddhism.desc: Dainenbutsu kyogen, a silent play created from the teachings of the Yuzu Nenbutsu (reciting the name of Amida Buddha) sect (also known as Dainenbutsu), was revived by Enkaku Shonin.

Buddhism.name: Honmon Butsuryu Sect
Buddhism.desc: Honmon Butsuryu Sect was the new religious sect of the school of the Hokke sect; it was founded by Seifu NAGAMATSU, who was of a school of Nichiren, and worshiped Nichiren as the origin of the sect.

Buddhism.name: Tendai Jimon Sect
Buddhism.desc: Tendai Jimon Sect is one of the Mahayana Buddhist sects.

Buddhism.name: Kakure Nenbutsu
Buddhism.desc: Kakure Nenbutsu (Hidden Buddhist Invocation) refers to the individuals or groups of people who secretly practiced or believed in the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) (Ikko Sect), which was banned by powerful rulers.

Buddhism.name: Great Buddha Statue in Kyoto
Buddhism.desc: Great Buddha statue in Kyoto originally existed in Hoko-ji Temple (Higashiyama-ku Ward, Kyoto City).

Buddhism.name: ARIMA Raitei
Buddhism.desc: Raitei ARIMA (1933 -) is a Zen monk in the present day.

Buddhism.name: Matsuji
Buddhism.desc: Matsuji is a reference to temples under the control of Honzan (head temple), but it had a different purpose when Honmatsu seido (the system of head and branch temples) was established, compared to the present day.

Buddhism.name: SHONAN Soke
Buddhism.desc: Soke SHONAN (year of birth not known (around 1586) - 1637) was a priest of the Myoshin-ji Temple of the Rinzai sect in the Azuchi-Momoyama Period and the Edo Period.

Buddhism.name: Seki Bokuo
Buddhism.desc: Seki Bokuo (1903 - 1991) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect in Japan.

Buddhism.name: MATSUMOTO Myokei
Buddhism.desc: Myokei MATSUMOTO (1945 -) is the present-day Busshi (sculptor of Buddhist statues) who belongs to the Keiha School.

Buddhism.name: Ennyo
Buddhism.desc: Ennyo (1489 - September 30, 1521) was a monk of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Seizan-Fukakusa school of the Jodo Sect
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Seizan-Fukakusa school of the Jodo Sect.html
Buddhism.desc: Seizan-Fukakusa school of the Jodo Sect is one school of the Jodo Sect, whose head temple is the Seigan-ji Temple in Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Gudo Toshoku
Buddhism.desc: Gudo Toshoku (May 5, 1577 - November, 1661) was a high Buddhist monk of the Rinzai Sect of Zen sect.

Buddhism.name: DAITEN Kenjo
Buddhism.desc: Kenjo DAITEN (1719 - March 22, 1801), a Zen Buddhist monk and a Chinese-style poet, lived from the middle to late Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Thirty-Six Fudo Temples in the Kinki Region
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Thirty-Six Fudo Temples in the Kinki Region.html
Buddhism.desc: The designation "Thirty-Six Fudo Temples in the Kinki Region" denotes 36 sacred sites that enshrine Fudo-son (Fudo Myoo (Acala, one of the Five Wisdom Kings)) in the prefectures of Osaka, Hyogo, Kyoto, Wakayama, Shiga and Nara.

Buddhism.name: Shumidan
Buddhism.desc: Shumidan is an altar to place a principal image in Buddhist temples, which is one step higher than other places and is used to place Buddha statues and other figures.

Buddhism.name: Hossho-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Hossho-ji Temple is part of the Seizanzenrin-ji School, Jodo Sect, in Higashiyama-ku Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Kebutsu
Buddhism.desc: Kebutsu (the Artificial Buddha)

Buddhism.name: Pedestal
Buddhism.desc: The pedestal is the table on which to place a Buddha statue or an image sculpture.

Buddhism.name: Kakue
Buddhism.desc: Kakue

Buddhism.name: Zennyo
Buddhism.desc: Zennyo was a monk of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Junnyo
Buddhism.desc: Junnyo (1442 - July 13, 1483) was a monk of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the middle to late Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Renjo
Buddhism.desc: Renjo (1446 - March 17, 1504) was a monk of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the middle of Muromachi period and up to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Kosho School Jodo Shinshu
Buddhism.desc: Kosho School Jodo Shinshu Sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) is one of the religious schools of Jodo Shinshu.

Buddhism.name: The Bukko-ji Temple School of the Shin sect
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Bukko-ji Temple School of the Shin sect.html
Buddhism.desc: The Bukko-ji (佛光寺) School of Shin Sect is a school of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Kyokaku
Buddhism.desc: Kyokaku (also pronounced Gyokaku) (1395 - September 19, 1473) was a monk of the Hosso sect during the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Ryoginan
Buddhism.desc: Ryoginan is a temple of the Tofuku-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect, located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, and is tatchu (sub-temple on the site of the main temple) of Tofuku-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Hoshu
Buddhism.desc: The word 'hoshu' (also referred as 'hossu') refers to a person who keeps the creed of Buddhism and plays a central role in its teaching, and turns to refer to the supreme leader (head) of the school, sect and religious community.

Buddhism.name: Taikoan
Buddhism.desc: Taikoan is tatchu (sub-temple on the site of the main temple) of Tofuku-ji Temple, which is the Daihonzan (head temple of a Buddhist sect) of the Rinzai sect, Tofuku-ji Temple school, located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Shonin
Buddhism.desc: "Shonin" is a term of respect for a high priest in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Raigo
Buddhism.desc: In the Jodo (Pure Land) sect of Buddhism, Raigo means Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata), who is riding on the colorful clouds together with various bosatsu and tennin (heavenly beings), coming to see a person who is about to die in order to take him or her to the heavens, and who is served by Kannon Bosatsu (Kannon Buddhisattva) and Seishi Bosatsu on the side.

Buddhism.name: Amida-ji Temple (Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.jp: 阿弥陀寺 (京都市上京区)
Buddhism.desc: Amida-ji Temple is the temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Rinzo
Buddhism.desc: Rinzo means a type of sutra warehouse that is built within a Buddhist temple.

Buddhism.name: Honzen-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Honzen-ji Temple is a branch temple in the Kyoto Jinmon lineage of the Hokke sect.

Buddhism.name: Shinnyosanmayado
Buddhism.desc: Shinnyosanmayado was built by Daigo-ji Temple, Sohonzan (the head temple of a Buddhist sect) of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect in 1997, in order to solemnly display the righteous behavior of Shinjo ITO, who was the founder of the sect of a religious corporation of Shinnyoen Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Shinnyo sanmayaryu
Buddhism.desc: Shinnyo sanmayaryu is one of the religious schools of the Shingon sect, which was made famous by Daigo-ji Temple, Sohonzan (the head temple of a Buddhist sect) of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect, but it's also the system of teachings of the Buddhist Shinnyoen himself.

Buddhism.name: Tahoto
Buddhism.desc: Tahoto (literally, "multiple-treasure pagoda") represent an architecture of pagodas, which are religious buildings in Asia.

Buddhism.name: Doko
Buddhism.desc: Doko (1430 - 1527) was a Buddhist monk who was the monzeki (chief priest who is a member of the Imperial Family) of Shogo-in Temple during the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Osen Keisan
Buddhism.desc: Osen Keisan (1429 - December 25, 1493) was a Zen monk (Rinzai sect) in the middle to late Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Konren-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Konren-ji Temple, located in Kita Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Ji sect.

Buddhism.name: The Jinko-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: The Jinko-in Temple is a tanritsu jiin (a temple which belongs to no sect) of the Shingon Sect line in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: The Honpo-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: The Honpo-ji Temple, located at Teranouchi, Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a Honzan (a major temple of the Nichiren Sect) and a Yuisho jiin (a historically important temple of the Nichiren Sect).

Buddhism.name: Sesson Yubai
Buddhism.desc: Sesson Yubai (1290 - January 14, 1347) was a Zen monk of the Rinzai Sect who lived from the late Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Shakyo (copying of a sutra)
Buddhism.desc: Shakyo is a Buddhist practice to copy Buddhist scriptures, and it also means Buddhist scriptures that have been copied.

Buddhism.name: Zonnyo
Buddhism.desc: Zonnyo (1396 to July 9, 1457) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) in the Muromachi period, and the 7th head priest of the Hongan-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Gomagi
Buddhism.desc: Gomagi is a wood for burning when a holy fire is lighted.

Buddhism.name: Kyozuka
Buddhism.desc: Kyozuka (literally, "scriptures tomb") are burial sites where Buddhist scriptures were buried.

Buddhism.name: Chion-ji Temple (Miyazu City)
Buddhism.desc: Chion-ji Temple, located in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a temple of the Myoshin-ji School of the Rinzai Sect.

Buddhism.name: Hoe
Buddhism.desc: Hoe (Buddhist memorial services) are gatherings of Buddhist monks and parishioners for memorial services and Buddhist preaching.

Buddhism.name: Hokyo-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: The Hokyo-ji Temple of the Rinzai sect is located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, and the temple is known as an Amamonzeki-ji Temple, which used to be run by nuns of noble women.

Buddhism.name: The Omuro School of the Shingon Sect
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Omuro School of the Shingon Sect.html
Buddhism.desc: The Omuro School of the Shingon ("True Word") sect is one of the Shingon sect schools in Japan and belongs to the Kogi (old) Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Raigo-in Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Raigo-in Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City) is a Buddhist temple of the Sennyu-ji school of the Shingon Sect.

Buddhism.name: Tango Daibutsu
Buddhism.desc: Tango Daibutsu (Great Buddha) is a large statue of Buddha in Honzaka, Ine-cho, Yosa-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Shichijo Bussho (Shichijo Sculpture Workshop)
Buddhism.desc: Shichijo bussho was a sculpture workshop of the Keiha school of sculptures in Shichijo Street, Kyoto.

Buddhism.name: Honman-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Honman-ji Temple is a temple located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Daimyo-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Daimyo-ji Temple is a temple of the Nichiren sect, located in Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Shoko-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Shoko-ji Temple is a temple of the Nichiren sect, located in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Chomyo-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Chomyo-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Nishiiri (the west) of Shinfuya-machi, Niomon-dori, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Myoden-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Myoden-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple of the Nichiren sect located in Nijo-dori sagaru, Higashi Oji-dori Street, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Ryuhon-ji Temple
