Buddhism.desc: Ryuhon-ji Temple, located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, is one of the original temples (with a long historical lineage) of the Nichiren sect of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Seki Seisetsu
Buddhism.desc: Seki Seisetsu (1877 - 1945) was a Zen priest of the Rinzai Sect who lived from the Meiji period to the Showa period.

Buddhism.name: Entsu-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: The Entsu-ji Temple was a Buddhist temple of the Myoshin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect, located in Iwakura Hataeda-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: KIBE Koji
Buddhism.desc: Koji KIBE (1881-1969) was a priest in the Shinshu-kibe school of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: The Daigo School of the Shingon Sect
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Daigo School of the Shingon Sect.html
Buddhism.desc: The Daigo school of the Shingon sect, one of the Shingon Buddhist sects of Japan, belongs to the Kogi Shingon (Old Shingon) school.

Buddhism.name: The To-ji school of the Shingon sect
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The To-ji school of the Shingon sect.html
Buddhism.desc: The To-ji school of the Shingon sect is a Buddhism school of the Shingon sect in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Horin-ji Temple (Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Horin-ji Temple, located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Myoshin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect.

Buddhism.name: Jinpan
Buddhism.desc: Jinpan (1093 - 1174) was a Buddhist priest in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Daiun-in Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Daiun-in Temple, located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, is an independent temple belonging to the Jodo sect.

Buddhism.name: Noen
Buddhism.desc: Noen (1140-1199) was a Buddhist monk who lived at the end of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Muhoto (Stone Pagoda)
Buddhism.desc: Muhoto is a stone pagoda (Buddhist pagoda) mostly used as a priest's tomb tower.

Buddhism.name: To-ji Choja
Buddhism.desc: To-ji Choja is the chief abbot of To-ji Temple (Kyoogokoku-ji Temple), and acts as its manager and Kami (director).

Buddhism.name: Choshin
Buddhism.desc: Choshin (1014 - November 12, 1072) was a Buddhist monk of the Shingon sect, in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Ichiji Kinrin Buccho (a Buddhist deity with a golden wheel, represented by a sacred Sanskrit syllable)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Ichiji Kinrin Buccho (a Buddhist deity with a golden wheel, represented by a sacred Sanskrit syllabl.html
Buddhism.desc: Ichiji Kinrin Buccho (ekaakSara-uSNiiSacakra in Sanskrit) is one of the deities worshipped in Esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Genji Kuyo
Buddhism.desc: Genji Kuyo is to hold a commemorative service for the Tale of Genji and its author Murasaki Shikibu.

Buddhism.name: Gyonyo
Buddhism.desc: Gyonyo (1376 - November 8,1440) was a monk of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) and the sixth chief priest of Hongan-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Jonyo
Buddhism.desc: Jonyo (1641-June 14, 1694) was a priest in the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) and the 15th Head Priest of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Ichinyo (priest)
Buddhism.desc: Ichinyo (1649 - May 30, 1700) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) and the 16th hoshu (head priest) of the Higashi Hongan-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Heian Bukkyo
Buddhism.desc: Heian Bukkyo (Heian Buddhism) is a Buddhist sect established during the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kuri
Buddhism.desc: Kuri (庫裏) refers to a single building among a Buddhist temple complex.

Buddhism.name: Henso-zu
Buddhism.desc: Henso-zu, as Buddhist painting, describes the scenery of the Pure Land and Hell.

Buddhism.name: Jissetsu
Buddhism.desc: Jissetsu is a form of Zen temple in China and Japan, below the Gozan (Zen temples highly ranked by the government) and above the Shozan (zen temples other than Gozan (five great zen temples) and Jissetsu (ten important temples of the Rinzai sect)).

Buddhism.name: Genkoan
Buddhism.desc: Genkoan, a temple of the Soto sect, is situated in Takagamine in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Komyo-ji Temple (Nagaokakyo City)
Buddhism.desc: Komyo-ji, the Grand Head Temple of the Seizan Jodo sect, is located in Ao, Nagaokakyo City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Jakunyo
Buddhism.desc: Jakunyo (1651 - September 21, 1725) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) in the early part of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Kongo-ji Temple (Kameoka City)
Buddhism.desc: Kongo-ji Temple, a Buddhist temple of the Tenryu-ji school of the Rinzai sect, is located in Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Soroku
Buddhism.desc: Soroku was a position that existed in Japan following the middle ages responsible for religious human affairs such as the registration and appointment of head priests

Buddhism.name: Gozanha (group of the highest-ranked temples in the Zen sect)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Gozanha (group of the highest-ranked temples in the Zen sect).html
Buddhism.desc: The Gozanha (Gozansorin) are the Zen temples (Zenrin) that were placed under the protection and control of the Gozan-Jissetsu-Shozan system (system of five great temples, ten important temples of the Rinzai sect, and Zen temples other than Gozan and Jissetsu).

Buddhism.name: Shinnyo-ji Temple (Kita Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Shinnyo-ji Temple, located in Tojiin Kitamachi, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture is a temple of the Shokoku-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect.

Buddhism.name: Shoji-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Shoji-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Tendai Sect located in Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Komyo-ji Temple (Ayabe City)
Buddhism.desc: Komyo-ji Temple, located in Ayabe City, Kyoto, is a temple of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Daizen-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Daizen-ji Temple, located in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect.

Buddhism.name: Gio-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Gio-ji Temple, located in Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple (nunnery) of the Daikakuji school of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: OTANI Koson
Buddhism.desc: Koson OTANI (March 17, 1850 - January 18, 1903) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) and the 21st hoshu (head priest) of the Nishi Hongan-ji Temple who lived from the end of the Edo period to the early part of the Meiji period.

Buddhism.name: SHUHO Yuki
Buddhism.desc: Yuki SHUHO (the date of birth unknown - August 1372) was a Zen priest of the Rikkyoku school of Tofuku-ji Temple who was active during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Shingon Sect Daikakuji School
Buddhism.desc: The Shingon Sect Daikakuji School is one of the schools of the Shingon Sect of Buddhism in Japan and is part of the Kogi Shingon (Old Shingon) Sect.

Buddhism.name: Rinsen-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Rinsen-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Rinzai Sect Tenryuji School located in Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Henjo-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Henjo-ji Temple, located in Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a Buddhist temple of the Omuro school of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Inge
Buddhism.desc: Inge can refer to:

Buddhism.name: Rokudo Chinno-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Rokudo Chinno-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Rinzai Sect Kenninji School located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City,

Buddhism.name: Ein Kanjo
Buddhism.desc: Ein Kanjo means the system of teachings of Daigo-ji Temple Sanpo-in, a temple of the Tozan school of Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhism concepts), or a ritual conducted in the manner of Ein Horyu (ritual of the Ein school).

Buddhism.name: Shika Kakugen (Nichiren's Four Criticisms)
Buddhism.desc: Shika (or Shiko) Kakugen (or Shika no Kakugen) (Four Criticisms) refers to the criticisms expressed by Nichiren, the founder of Nichiren Buddhism, against other Buddhist sects that existed in his time.

Buddhism.name: Mountain Buddhism
Buddhism.desc: Mountain Buddhism, a form of Buddhism for the practitioner of austerities who seeks an ascetic practice place in mountains, was begun by Saicho (767-822), the founder of the Tendai sect, Kukai (774-835), the founder of the Shingon sect, and others against the secularization of Nara Buddhism (Nanto rokushu), which had strengthened its ties with the government.

Buddhism.name: Gasho
Buddhism.desc: Gasho (887 - February 20, 967) was a monk of the Tendai Sect who was active in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Chion-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Hyakumanben Chion-ji Temple, located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is the Grand Head Temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect.

Buddhism.name: Shuto
Buddhism.desc: The term "shuto," for which "doshu" is also used, is a term from after the Heian period that referred to the status of a priest who originally resided in a big temple and was in charge of the management and practical business of the temple as well as studying and practicing ascetic training.

Buddhism.name: Yokoku-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Yokoku-ji Temple, located in Nagaokakyo City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a temple of the Seizan Jodo sect.

Buddhism.name: Kanjin
Buddhism.desc: Kanjin was work done by Buddhist monks in connection with missionary activities intended to bring relief to people.

Buddhism.name: Morinobo Zoryu
Buddhism.desc: Morinobo Zoryu (dates of birth and death unknown) was a Buddhist monk in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Junen-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Junen-ji Temple, a temple of the Seizan Jodo sect, is located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Sanji Chion-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Sanji Chion-ji Temple, located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple (nunnery) of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect.

Buddhism.name: Kannon-ji Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Kannon-ji Temple, located in Sennyuji Yamanouchi, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Shingon sect's Sennyu-ji school.

Buddhism.name: Shuon-an Temple
Buddhism.desc: Shuon-an Temple, located in Kyotanabe City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a temple of Rinzai sect's Daitoku-ji school.

Buddhism.name: Shiga-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: Shiga-in Temple, a temple of the Tendai sect located in Sakamoto, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture, s a honbo (a priest's main living quarters) (Sosatobo) of Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei.

Buddhism.name: Jurin-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Jurin-ji Temple, a temple of the Tendai Sect, is located in Oshio-cho, Oharano, Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Shunoku Soen
Buddhism.desc: Shunoku Soen (1529 - 1611) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the beginning of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Jizo-in Temple (Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Jizo-in Temple, located in Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a nonsectarian temple of the Rinzai sect.

Buddhism.name: Joju-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Joju-ji Temple, located in Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Obaku Sect.

Buddhism.name: Jizo-in Temple (Kita Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Jizo-in Temple, located in Kita Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Jodo sect.

Buddhism.name: Jizo-in Temple (Uji City)
Buddhism.desc: Jizo-in Temple, located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a temple of the Jodo sect.

Buddhism.name: Choraku-ji Temple (in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Choraku-ji Temple (in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City).html
Buddhism.desc: Choraku-ji Temple, located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Ji sect.

Buddhism.name: Shobo-ji Temple (Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Shobo-ji Temple, located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Ji sect.

Buddhism.name: Shorin-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: Shorin-in Temple, a temple of the Tendai sect, is located to the north of Ohara Sanzen-in Temple, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Raigo-in Temple (Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Raigo-in Temple, located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Tendai sect.

Buddhism.name: Sorin-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Sorin-ji Temple, located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Tendai sect.

Buddhism.name: Shobo-ji Temple (Saikyo Ward, Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Shobo-ji Temple, located in Saikyo Ward, Kyoto City. is a temple of the To-ji school of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Shobo-ji Temple (Yawata City)
Buddhism.desc: Shobo-ji Temple is a temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect, located in Yawata City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Jodo-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: Jodo-in Temple, located in Ginkakuji-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect.

Buddhism.name: The Kyoto Conference
Buddhism.desc: The Kyoto Conference is a common name of the conference which is held in Kyoto (Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture).

Buddhism.name: Hojo-in Temple (Uji City)
Buddhism.desc: Hojo-in Temple, located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a temple of the Shingon Ritsu sect.

Buddhism.name: Jobonrendai-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Jobonrendai-ji Temple, located in Kita Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Chizan school of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Chofuku-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Chofuku-ji Temple, located in Umezu, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Nanzen-ji school of the Rinzai sect.

Buddhism.name: Kuhon-ji Temple (Nantan City)
Buddhism.desc: Kuhon-ji Temple, located in Nantan City (former Sonobe-cho, Funai County), Kyoto Prefecture, is a temple of the Omuro school of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Kuhon-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Kuhon-ji Temple, located in Higashi Kujo, Minami Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect.

Buddhism.name: GUCHU Shukyu
Buddhism.desc: Shukyu GUCHU (1323 - October 4, 1409) was a priest of the Rinzai sect during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Dosho (Tendai sect)
Buddhism.desc: Dosho (1281 - January 24, 1356) was a priest of the Tendai sect and a poet.

Buddhism.name: OMORI Zenkai
Buddhism.desc: Zenkai OMORI (1871- February 4, 1947) was a priest of the Soto Sect who had lived from the Meiji period to the Showa period.

Buddhism.name: Sekizanzenin Temple
Buddhism.desc: Sekizanzenin Temple, located at Shugakuin, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a temple of the Tendai sect.

Buddhism.name: Rankoku Genjo
Buddhism.desc: Rankoku Genjo (1653 - May 31, 1707) was a priest of the Rinzai sect Obaku school of the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: The Kengoin School of The Jodo Shinshu Sect
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Kengoin School of The Jodo Shinshu Sect.html
Buddhism.desc: The Kengoin school of the Jodo Shinshu sect is one of the schools of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Matarashin
Buddhism.desc: Matarashin (also known as Matarishin) is the principal image of the Tendai Sect, specially in the Genshi Kimyodan (a secret ceremony of the Tendai sect), and is also regarded as a guardian deity of the Amida-kyo Sutra and nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation).

Buddhism.name: Kontai-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: Kontai-ji Temple, located at Harayama, Wazuka-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture, is part of the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: OTANI Sonyu
Buddhism.desc: Sonyu OTANI (August 19, 1886 - August 1, 1939) was a priest and statesman of Jodo shinshu (the True Pure Land sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Isshin-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: Isshin-in Temple is a Jodoshu sect (the Pure Land sect) temple at Higashiyama Ward in Kyoto City as well as the head temple of the Shasei school of the Jodo sect.

Buddhism.name: Otani Sobyo Mausoleum
Buddhism.desc: Otani Sobyo Mausoleum is the grave of Shinran, the founder of the Shinshu sect Otani school (Higashi Hongan-ji Temple), which is located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Shingon sect Sennyu-ji School
Buddhism.desc: Shingon sect Sennyu-ji school is one of the Shingon line Buddhist schools that belongs to the Kogi Shingon school (Old Shingon school).

Buddhism.name: To-ji Temple Shingon Sect
Buddhism.desc: The To-ji Temple Shingon sect is a Buddhist sect in Japan classified into the Kogi Shingon (Old Shingon) sect.

Buddhism.name: Hedara
Buddhism.desc: The word 'Hedara' (Eurya japonica) is a Buddhist terminology which means 'the flower for altarage.'

Buddhism.name: Ninkaku
Buddhism.desc: Ninkaku (1045 - April 17, 1102) was a priest of the Tendai Sect during the latter part of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Sorin-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: The Sorin-ji Temple is a temple of the Tendai sect in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Genshin (Monk)
Buddhism.desc: Genshin was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect who lived during the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kakujin
Buddhism.desc: Kakujin (1021 - 1081) was a priest of the Enryaku-ji Temple who lived in the middle of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: The Daiun-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: The Daiun-ji Temple is an independent temple (the Tendai Shomon sect) located in Iwakura, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Sanko-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: The Sanko-ji Temple is a temple of the Seizan sect in Oharano, Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Entoku-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: The Entoku-in Temple is a tatchu (sub-temple on the site of a main temple) of the Kodai-ji Temple (Kennin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect) in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Kengo-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: The Kengo-in Temple is a temple of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) in Takagamine, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, and the Head Temple of the Kengoin school of Jodo Shinshu.

Buddhism.name: Konyo
Buddhism.desc: Konyo (1798 - August 19, 1871) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) in the end of the Edo period, the 20th head priest of the Nishi Hongan-ji Temple, and daisojo (a Buddhist priest of the highest order).

Buddhism.name: Hiten
Buddhism.desc: The term "Hiten" refers to the tennin (heavenly beings) who flies around Buddha and sings.

Buddhism.name: Rinkyu-ji Temple
Buddhism.desc: The Rinkyu-ji Temple is an independent temple of the Rinzai sect at Shugakuin, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Chugan Engetsu
Buddhism.desc: Chugan Engetsu (January 28, 1300 - February 9, 1375) was a priest of the Rinzai sect during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Shingon Sect Yamashina School
Buddhism.desc: The Shingon sect Yamashina school is a Buddhist school of the Shingon lineage in Japan, classified into the Kogi (old) Shinshu sect.

Buddhism.name: Stone Buddhist Image
Buddhism.desc: The term "stone Buddhist image" is a collective term of the Buddhist image carved in stone and the image of a deity such as Doso-shin (traveler's guardian deity), and it has a variety of sizes ranging from small one which is seen in the precincts of temples and shrines and on roadsides, to Usuki Magaibutsu (A Buddhist image carved into the surface of natural rock such as a cliff face, a large rock, or a stone cave) and other Magaibutsu carved in a large rock such as Ajanta Caves and Ellora Caves in India, Yungang Grottoes and Longmen Caves in China.

Buddhism.name: Myoen-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Myoen-ji Temple is located in Matsugasaki, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City and is a temple of the Nichiren Sect, founded by Nichiren in 1253.

Buddhism.name: Josho-ji Temple (Kyoto City)
Buddhism.desc: Josho-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Nichiren Sect located in Takagamine, Kita Ward, Kyoto City.

Buddhism.name: Otani Mausoleum
Buddhism.desc: Otani mausoleum is a graveyard in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture where the grave of Shinran, the founder of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) is located.

Buddhism.name: Rokuji-Raisan
Buddhism.desc: Rokuji-Raisan is a Pure Land Sect Buddhist memorial service.

Buddhism.name: Shisenin Kosen
Buddhism.desc: Shisenin Kosen (year of birth and death unknown) was busho (Japanese military commander), yamabushi (a mountain priest) and Buddhist monk in the Sengoku period (the period of warring states.)

Buddhism.name: Satori: Enlightenment
Buddhism.desc: Satori (悟り: enlightenment) means that one learns, becomes aware of or notices what one hasn't known; another Kanji (覚り), whose meaning is similar to awakening, is sometimes used.

Buddhism.name: Kanbutsue
Buddhism.desc: Kanbutsue is a ceremony that celebrates the birth of Buddha.

Buddhism.name: The Most Wicked Are the True Object of Salvation
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Most Wicked Are the True Object of Salvation.html
Buddhism.desc: This thought is very meaningful in Jodoshinshu doctrine, meaning 'It is evil people who are the major object of salvation based on the Vow of Amida Nyorai (Primal Vow of Other Power).'

Buddhism.name: The Jodo Sanbu-kyo (the three main sutras of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Jodo Sanbu-kyo (the three main sutras of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect).html
Buddhism.desc: The Jodo Sanbu-kyo is a collective name for the basic three sutras of the various Jodo sects in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Muryoju-kyo Sutra
Buddhism.desc: "Muryoju-kyo Sutra" is one of the Buddhist scriptures of Mahayana Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: The Kanmuryoju Kyo sutra
Buddhism.desc: "Kanmuryoju Kyo" (The Sutra of Contemplation on the Buddha of Immeasurable Life) is one of the Mahayana Buddhist sutras.

Buddhism.name: 他力本願 Tariki Hongan
Buddhism.desc: Tarikihongan (salvation by faith in Amitabha) has the following meanings:

Buddhism.name: Amida-kyo Sutra
Buddhism.desc: "Amida-kyo Sutra" (Sutra of Amida Buddha) is one of sutras of Mahayama Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Tan-luan
Buddhism.desc: Tan-luan was a Buddhist monk who lived during the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties in China.

Buddhism.name: Dao-chuo
Buddhism.desc: Dao-chuo (Doshaku) was a Chinese monk Chinese Jodo (Pure Land) sect in the Tang.

Buddhism.name: Engi
Buddhism.desc: Engi

Buddhism.name: Namu Amidabutsu (a Single, Sincere Call upon the Name of Amida)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Namu Amidabutsu (a Single, Sincere Call upon the Name of Amida).html
Buddhism.desc: The 'Namu' of Namu amidabutsu is a transcription of namo (Sanskrit), meaning 'I'm becoming a believer' and 'amidabutsu' employs amita (Sanskrit) is abbreviated from 'amitaayus (Great Buddha with infinite longevity)' and 'amitaabha (Great Buddha with infinite light),' meaning 'immeasurable' in Sanskrit.

Buddhism.name: Shomyo (Invocation of the Buddha's Name)
Buddhism.desc: Shomyo means the invocation of the name(s) of the Buddha and/or Bodhisattva.

Buddhism.name: Jodo (Pure Land)
Buddhism.desc: Jodo (Pure Land) is a Buddhist concept which pointed to a world clean and pure.

Buddhism.name: Gokuraku
Buddhism.desc: The word as geographical names in Japan.

Buddhism.name: The 48 Vows
Buddhism.desc: The 48 Vows refers to the 48 vows made by Hozo Bosatsu (Dharmakara) prior to the start of ascetic training to attain Buddhahood.

Buddhism.name: Eko (Buddhist Thoughts of Outgoing and Returning)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Eko (Buddhist Thoughts of Outgoing and Returning).html
Buddhism.desc: "Eko" (回向, also written as 廻向) or pariNaama (sanskrit) means to 'turn,' 'change' or 'proceed,' and '回向' as its translation with Chinese characters shows the meaning of rotation in '回' and device in '向', which is a thought that Mahayana Buddhism features.

Buddhism.name: Ojo
Buddhism.desc: Ojo is a methodology for becoming a Buddha, as defined by the Mahayana Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Zenjo
Buddhism.desc: Zenjo (dhyaana in Sanskrit, jhaana in Pali) is to meditate and observe the truth while focusing one's mind.

Buddhism.name: Sanmai
Buddhism.desc: Sanmai (三昧, transcription of Samādhi) means the ultimate state of mental concentration attained through zen, in the case of Buddhism, or through meditation, in the case of Hinduism.

Buddhism.name: Onriedo (abhorrence of living in this impure world)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Onriedo (abhorrence of living in this impure world).html
Buddhism.desc: "Onriedo (also called Enriedo)," a term associated with the Jodo (Pure Land) sect, is often used to express an antithesis with Gongujodo (seeking rebirth in the Pure).

Buddhism.name: Wasan
Buddhism.desc: Wasan means an anthem sung in Japanese to praise Buddha, Bosatsu, Soshi (founder of a sect), ancient virtue, Buddhist scriptures, creed, etc.

Buddhism.name: Kueissho
Buddhism.desc: Kueissho is one of the benefits in the Jodo sect, regarding one's passing into the Pure Land.

Buddhism.name: Genso-eko
Buddhism.desc: Genso-eko (Virtue as instructed by Amida for retiring from the Pure Land to this world) is one of the important Jodo Sect doctrines (teachings of the Pure Land).

Buddhism.name: Oso-eko
Buddhism.desc: Oso-eko (Amida's instructions on virtue for entering the Pure Land) is one of Jodo Shinshu's (the True Pure Land Buddhist Sect) important doctrines and corresponding term to Genso-Eko (Amida's instructions on virtue for returning to this world).

Buddhism.name: Monto
Buddhism.desc: Monto is a name one uses for comrades of the same sect.

Buddhism.name: Agui Shodo Kyodan (Agui Shodo School)
Buddhism.desc: Agui Shodo Kyodan was one of religious branches of Buddhism during the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan).

Buddhism.name: OTANI Kozui
Buddhism.desc: Kozui OTANI (December 27, 1876 – October 5, 1948) was a religionist and an explorer of Japan.

Buddhism.name: Shoshin Nenbutsuge
Buddhism.desc: Shoshin Nenbutsuge' is a Gemon (poetic writing in Buddhism, usually honoring its principles and Buddha) included at the end of 'Gyo no maki' in "Ken jodo shinjitsu kyogyosho monrui" (Selected passages revealing the true teaching, practice and attainment of the Pure Land), written by Shinran.

Buddhism.name: Hoyo (Buddhist memorial service)
Buddhism.desc: What is hoyo?

Buddhism.name: Yamabushi
Buddhism.desc: Yamabushi is a practitioner of Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism/shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts) who earnestly walks in the mountains as an ascetic practice.

Buddhism.name: Joyano kane
Buddhism.desc: Joyano kane means striking a bronze bell (temple bell) around 12:00 am on New Year's Eve (December 31).

Buddhism.name: Komuso
Buddhism.desc: Komuso were monks of the Fuke sect of Zen Buddhism who did not shave their heads in the traditional monk fashion and, co-existed as monks in the day to day lay world.

Buddhism.name: Gien
Buddhism.desc: Gien (1155 - April 25, 1181) was a priest at the end of the Heian period and the eighth son of MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo.

Buddhism.name: Jikaku (Temple Ranking)
Buddhism.desc: Jikaku was the hierarchy of a Buddhist temple used to classify its status based on its economic and social standing.

Buddhism.name: Yamabushi Shinko
Buddhism.desc: Yamabushi Shinko is a belief from the ancient times in Japan, regarding divine spirits that live in the mountains.

Buddhism.name: Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism)
Buddhism.desc: Haibutsu-kishaku (廃仏毀釈 in Chinese characters) means a movement to destroy Buddhist temples, Buddhist statues and Buddhist scriptures as well as to abolish the privileges entitled to Buddhist priests/nuns.

Buddhism.name: Jodo Shinshu Sect Shinrankai
Buddhism.desc: Jodo Shinshu Shinrankai (founded in 1958) is a new sect of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) Sect.

Buddhism.name: YOSHIDA Kenko
Buddhism.desc: Kenko YOSHIDA (1283 - c. May 14, 1350) was a Japanese author and poet in the Kamakura period through the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan).

Buddhism.name: ITO Shinjo
Buddhism.desc: Shinjo ITO (Fumiaki ITO, March 28, 1906 - July 19, 1989) was a religious leader who founded Shinnyoen, the lay Buddhist Organization.

Buddhism.name: Nenge Misho
Buddhism.desc: The Nenge misho (heart-to-heart communication (lit: holding a flower and subtly smiling) tradition is a Zen legend that holds that, Zen teachings extend from a linage that goes back to the sage Shakyamuni.

Buddhism.name: Kuon jitsujo
Buddhism.desc: "Kuon jitsujo" is the thought in the teachings of Hoke-kyo Sutra (the Lotus Sutra) according to which Buddha was not enlightened at the age of thirty-five but was coming from the eternal past as Buddha (the enlightened one) by Rinne Tensho (the belief that all things are in flux through the endless circle of birth, death, and rebirth, or the circle of transmigration).

Buddhism.name: Gyoki
Buddhism.desc: Gyoki (or Gyogi, 668 - February 23, 749) was a Buddhist monk of the Nara era in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Shukubo
Buddhism.desc: Shukubo is a form of lodging for priests who are conducting ascetic practices, mainly in Buddhist temples.

Buddhism.name: Keien
Buddhism.desc: Keien (also read as 'kyoen;' 1140 - February 28, 1223) was a priest who established Shinbutsu ryobu shiso (the idea of Dual-Shinto and Buddhism) during the early part of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Nenbutsu-odori
Buddhism.desc: Nenbutsu-odori is a kind of dance where the dancing and singing are performed by different people, and can be distinguished from odori nenbutsu which is performed by a single person who dances and chants a Buddhist sutra at the same time.

Buddhism.name: Fusan
Buddhism.desc: Fusan is the distribution of ofuda (paper charms) on which the words '南無阿弥陀仏、決定往生六十万人' are written, practiced in the Ji sect, a Pure Land sect of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: SHIMOTSUMA Raitan
Buddhism.desc: Raitan SHIMOTSUMA (year of birth unknown - 1574) was a monk and busho (Japanese military commander) of the Otani family who lived during the Sengoku period (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Kenkyo
Buddhism.desc: Kenkyo (also pronounced Kengyo) (exoteric Buddhism) is the disclosed teaching of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Nichiu (日有)
Buddhism.desc: Nichiu (May 18, 1402 - November 10, 1482) was a priest during the mid Muromachi period who was the head of Taiseki-ji Temple from 1419 to 1467 and again from 1472 to 1482.

Buddhism.name: Samue
Buddhism.desc: A samue is a garment that a zen (Buddhist) monk wears when he performs samu, or duties such as daily sutra chanting, and the cleaning of the precincts of the temple.

Buddhism.name: Isshikoshosoku
Buddhism.desc: Isshikoshosoku is a part of a Buddhist sermon taught by Honen.

Buddhism.name: Junen
Buddhism.desc: Junen is (a manner of) chanting a homage to Amida Buddha ten times.

Buddhism.name: Koge
Buddhism.desc: Koge is a gemon taken from the Jodo Hojisan (Hymns of the Pure Land Ritual).

Buddhism.name: Sanborai
Buddhism.desc: Sanborai is a gemon taken from Zunshi Jodosangangi.

Buddhism.name: Shibujo
Buddhism.desc: Shibujo is a gemon taken from Hoshozenshi Goehojisan.

Buddhism.name: Sanbujo
Buddhism.desc: Sanbujo is a gemon taken from Hojisan (Hymns of the Pure Land Ritual).

Buddhism.name: Sangege
Buddhism.desc: Sangege is a gemon taken from Shijukegon Fugengyoganbon.

Buddhism.name: Nenbutsuichie
Buddhism.desc: Nenbutsuichie means repeating a Buddhist invocation, i.e. Namu Amidabutsu (a single, sincere call upon the name of Amida).

Buddhism.name: Jikkai (the Ten Realms)
Buddhism.desc: Jikkai means all the states of a human spirit categorized into 10 types according to the creed of the Tendai sect, including Rokudo (six posthumous worlds) as well as the four of states of Shomon, Enkaku, Bosatsu and Buddhahood.

Buddhism.name: Shoyakumon
Buddhism.desc: Shoyakumon is a gemon included in Kanmuryoju-kyo shaku.

Buddhism.name: Sobutsuge
Buddhism.desc: Sobutsuge is a gemon by which to send a soul to where it should reside.

Buddhism.name: Honzeige
Buddhism.desc: Honzeige is chanted for Amida Buddha alone, and this gemon is based on "Kanmuryojukyosho" Gengibun.

Buddhism.name: Fukujoju Nyorai
Buddhism.desc: Fukujoju Nyorai (Amoghasiddh) is one of the Five Wisdom Buddhas worshipped in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Lotus Leaf
Buddhism.desc: The lotus leaf refers to the leaf of the hydrophyte called lotus, which floats on the water's surface, and is also called Kayo due to the introduction of Chinese herbal drugs.

Buddhism.name: Sanpokojin
Buddhism.desc: Sanpokojin (or also called sanbokojin) is one of the Buddhist beliefs peculiar to Japan.

Buddhism.name: The Shugei Shuchiin School
Buddhism.desc: It is said that the Shugei Shuchiin school was a private facility established by Kukai on January 27, 829, at the residence in Sakyo Kujo in Kyoto, which had been received from FUJIWARA no Mimori, for the purpose of educating the common people and providing comprehensive education in various liberal arts.

Buddhism.name: Henjo Nanshi
Buddhism.desc: The term Henjo Nanshi refers to the idea that a woman, who has been thought to have great difficulty in becoming a Buddha since ancient times, is able to accomplish it by once changing into a man.

Buddhism.name: Daibirushana Jobutsu Jinbenkaji-kyo Sutra (Mahavairocana Sutra)
Buddhism.jp: 大毘盧遮那成仏神変加持経
Buddhism.desc: "Daibirushana Jobutsu Jinbenkaji-kyo Sutra," which is also called "Birushanakyo Sutra" or "Dainichi-kyo Sutra," refers to Esoteric Buddhist scriptures that are considered to have been established in or around the period of the seventh through eighth centuries.

Buddhism.name: Namu-myoho-renge-kyo (南無妙法蓮華経, 'Glory to the Sutra of the Lotus of the Supreme Law' mantra).
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Namu-myoho-renge-kyo (南無妙法蓮華経, Glory to the Sutra of the Lotus of the Supreme Law mantra)..html
Buddhism.desc: 南無妙法蓮華経 is read as "Nam-myoho-renge-kyo".

Buddhism.name: Kudensho
Buddhism.desc: "Kudensho" is a book written in 1331 by Kakunyo, who was the third chief priest of Hongan-ji Temple of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Hokke Sanbu-kyo (Threefold Lotus) Sutra
Buddhism.desc: The "Hokke Sanbu-kyo (Threefold Lotus Sutra)" is a set of sutras of Mahayana Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Kiseki
Buddhism.desc: Kiseki is a family register for the dead ('ki' in Chinese).

Buddhism.name: Shibosatsu
Buddhism.desc: Shibosatsu (shi means four), means four Bosatsu literally, is a combination of Bosatsu as the object of worship or construction of statues in the Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: OTANI Koshin
Buddhism.desc: Koshin OTANI (August 12, 1945 -) is the 24th Monshu (the chief priest) of the Hongan-ji school of the Jodo Shinshu sect and the head priest of the religious corporation Hongan-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Oryoki
Buddhism.desc: Oryoki is tableware, as used by an individual ascetic of the Zen sect of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Gokan no ge
Buddhism.desc: Gokan no ge is gemon, meaning the verses recited before the meal, mainly in the Zen sect of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Taho Nyorai
Buddhism.desc: Taho Nyorai (Buddha of Many Treasures who is depicted in the Lotus Sutra) is one of the Nyorai (Tathagata), an object to worship in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Five Buddhas in the Womb Realm
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Five Buddhas in the Womb Realm.html
Buddhism.desc: The Five Buddhas in Womb Realm are a kind of venerable image in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Gongen
Buddhism.desc: Gongen is a kind of Japanese shingo (the title given to a Shinto shrine).

Buddhism.name: Jihen
Buddhism.desc: Jihen (date of birth unknown) was a gakuso (scholar monk) of the Tendai sect and a Shintoist who lived during the end of the Kamakura period until the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Shunkan
Buddhism.desc: Shunkan (1143 - April 17, 1179) was a priest of the Shingon sect of Buddhism in Japan, who lived during the latter Heian period.

Buddhism.name: KEIAN Genju
Buddhism.desc: Genju KEIAN (1427-July 8, 1508) was a priest of the Rinzai sect of Buddhism in Japan, who formed the Satsunan School (school of Neo-Confucian in Satsuma).

Buddhism.name: Terauke Seido
Buddhism.desc: Terauke seido was a system introduced in 1664, during the early modern age, by the Edo shogunate in order to ban Christianity and the belief of Fujufuse Group (Not Receive and Not Give Group), and to force the believers to convert.

Buddhism.name: Zenjodo
Buddhism.desc: Zenjodo is the mountain path that leads to zencho (the peak of a sacred mountain).

Buddhism.name: Zencho
Buddhism.desc: Zencho means the mountaintop, particularly the peak, of a sacred mountain.

Buddhism.name: Chinzo
Buddhism.desc: Chinzo, also called chinso or choso, is a portrait or a sculpture of a priest of the Zen sect (a sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Kukai
Buddhism.desc: Kukai was a priest who lived in the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Sotoba
Buddhism.desc: Sotoba is the Japanese transliteration of the Sanskrit word "stupa."

Buddhism.name: Nenbutsu-ko
Buddhism.desc: Nenbutsu-ko means kochu, which is the gathering for nenbutsu chanting by lay believers of Japanese Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Rinju
Buddhism.desc: Rinju is the time immediately before one dies.

Buddhism.name: SHIMOTSUMA Shinrai
Buddhism.desc: Shinrai SHIMOTSUMA (1513 - July 15, 1552) was a bokan (a priest who served the family of a monzeki (the head priest of the head temple of a sect, formerly led by the founder of the sect)), who served the Otani family.

Buddhism.name: The Seven Patriarchs
Buddhism.desc: The seven patriarchs are the seven high priests selected by Shinran, the founder of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Shingi
Buddhism.desc: Shingi (Monastic regulations in the Zen Sect), which is formally called Shojodaikaishu kikujunjo, is the regulations of a group of the Zen sect (a sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Monryu
Buddhism.desc: Monryu is a designation used to refer to branch schools of Nichiren's disciples who considered the Myohorenge-kyo Sutra (the Lotus Sutra) as Shobo (the true teachings of Buddha), by using the founder's name or the name of the area where the founder propagated Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Enni
Buddhism.desc: Enni (November 8, 1202 - November 17, 1280) was a priest of the Rinzai sect of Buddhism in Japan, who lived during the mid-Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Kanzan Egen
Buddhism.desc: Kanzan Egen (1277 - January 19, 1361) was a monk of the Rinzai sect of Buddhism from the latter stages of the Kamakura period to the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Nokotsudo (A Japanese Ossuary)
Buddhism.desc: A nokotsudo is the building in which the remains of cremation are kept.

Buddhism.name: SATA Kaiseki
Buddhism.desc: Kaiseki SATA (May 12, 1818 to December 9, 1882) from Higo Province was a Jodo Shinshu sect monk of Hongan-ji school (In his later years, he was a Tendai sect monk) from the end of the Edo period to the beginning of Meiji period.

Buddhism.name: ZEKKAI Chushin
Buddhism.desc: Chushin ZEKKAI (December 9, 1334 - May 3, 1405) was a Buddhist monk from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) to the early years of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Kaigen-hoyo
Buddhism.desc: Kaigen-hoyo is a Buddhist memorial service held at the completion of Buddhist statue, painting, altar, or tomb.

Buddhism.name: SHAKU Soyen
Buddhism.desc: Soyen SHAKU (January 10, 1860 - November 1, 1919) was a priest of the Rinzai sect of Buddhism during the Meiji and Taisho periods.

Buddhism.name: Gyoson
Buddhism.desc: Gyoson (1055 - March 28, 1135) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect and a waka poet during the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Mujaku Dochu
Buddhism.desc: Mujaku Dochu (September 16, 1653 - January 25, 1745) was a gakuso (scholar priest) of Myoshin-ji Temple school of the Rinzai sect of Zen during the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Honmatsu Seido System
Buddhism.desc: "Honmatsu seido," a system intended to control the Buddhist organizations, was established by the Tokugawa shogunate during the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Gozanban
Buddhism.desc: The term "Gozanban" refers to the books published by Gozan (the Five Great Zen Temples in Kyoto) and other temples, which were affected by the active publication of books on Zen Buddhism in the age of the Sung and Yuan dynasties.

Buddhism.name: Hondo (The main hall)
Buddhism.desc: Hondo is the building of a Buddhist temple in which the main object of worship is enshrined.

Buddhism.name: Hojo
Buddhism.desc: Hojo is a word expressing an square area with one jo (an unit of length: 1 jo = 3.03 meters) on each side.

Buddhism.name: Eison
Buddhism.desc: Eison (1201 - October 6, 1290) was a priest of Shingon Ritsu sect during the mid Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shinsei
Buddhism.desc: Shinsei (March 8, 1443 - - April 4, 1495) was a priest of the Tendai sect during the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

Buddhism.name: Myogo Honzon
Buddhism.desc: Myogo Honzon is a form of honzon (the principal object of worship at a temple) in Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Shukuzen
Buddhism.desc: Shukuzen is one of the words used in the doctrine of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Koen
Buddhism.desc: Koen (1074? - July 16, 1169) was a priest of the Tendai sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kosai
Buddhism.desc: Kosai (1163 - May 27, 1247) was a priest of the Jodo sect early in the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Kojo (priest)
Buddhism.desc: Kojo (779 - September 24, 858) was a priest of the Tendai sect early in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: HITACHIBO Kaison
Buddhism.desc: Kaison HITACHIBO (the date of birth and death unknown) is a legendary person whose name appears in "Genpei Seisui ki" (Rise and Fall of the Minamoto and the Taira clans), "Gikeiki" (a military epic about the life of Yoshitsune), and "Heike Monogatari" (The tale of the Heike), and is said to be a Buddhist priest at the Onjo-ji Temple or Mt. Hiei.

Buddhism.name: Donkai
Buddhism.desc: Donkai (1265 - March 20, 1327) was a priest of the Ji sect in the late Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Sena
Buddhism.desc: Sena (1647 - November 6, 1735) was a waka poet during the mid Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Shinga
Buddhism.desc: Shinga (801 - February 1, 879) was a priest of the Shingon sect of Buddhism during the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Koin
Buddhism.desc: Koin (1145 - July 13, 1216) was a waka poet and a priest of the Tendai sect who lived from the end of Heian period until the early part of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shoshu
Buddhism.desc: Shoshu (1215 - December 26, 1291) was a priest of Todai-ji Temple in the mid Kamakura Period

Buddhism.name: Nanpo Shomyo
Buddhism.desc: Nanpo Shomyo (1235 - February 17, 1309) was a priest of the Rinzai sect in the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Kangen
Buddhism.desc: Kangen (854 - July 9, 925) was a priest of the Shingon sect during the mid Heian Period.

Buddhism.name: Hozo (Japan)
Buddhism.desc: Hozo (905 - 969) was a priest of the Hosso sect during the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kakujo
Buddhism.desc: Kakujo (1521 - February 4, 1574) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect who lived during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Gyojo
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Gyojo (November 29, 1640 - May 28, 1695) was a member of the Imperial family and a Buddhist priest who lived during the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Shinku (Jodo sect)
Buddhism.desc: Shinku (1146 - October 15, 1228) was a priest of the Jodo sect from the latter Heian period through the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Gennin
Buddhism.desc: Gennin (818 - December 14, 887) was a priest of the Shingon sect early in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Sandai Soron
Buddhism.desc: Sandai Soron is a general name for a religious conflict in the Soto sect, which started in 1267 and lasted for about 50 years.

Buddhism.name: Nichizo
Buddhism.desc: Nichizo (September 14, 1269 - December 19, 1342) was a Buddhist priest of the Nichiren sect who lived from the late Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Nichijo
Buddhism.desc: Nichijo (1298 - August 8, 1369) was a priest of the Nichiren/Hokke sect who lived during the period of Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Zonkaku
Buddhism.desc: Zonkaku was a Buddhist priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) who lived from the late Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Genpin
Buddhism.desc: Genpin (734 - July 27, 818) was a priest of Hosso sect (The Dharama-Characteristics Sect of Buddhism) from the Nara period to the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Joto
Buddhism.desc: Joto (740 - October 13, 815) was a Buddhist priest who lived from the Nara period to the beginning of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Zenshu
Buddhism.desc: Zenshu (also known as Zenju, 723 - May 25, 797) was a Buddhist priest who lived from the Nara period to the beginning of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Yokan (a priest)
Buddhism.desc: Yokan (or Eikan) (1033 - December 11, 1111) was a priest of Sanron sect (The Three-Discourse Sect of Buddhism) in the later Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shinen
Buddhism.desc: Shinen (1153 - January 6, 1225) was a Buddhist priest of Kofuku-ji Temple from the end of the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shoshin
Buddhism.desc: Shoshin (1187 - August 16, 1275) is a Buddhist priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) who lived during the middle of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Junsai
Buddhism.desc: Junsai (year of birth unknown - March 16, 1207) was a priest of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect of Buddhism who lived from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period

Buddhism.name: Genei
Buddhism.desc: Genei (year of birth unknown – 840) was a priest of the Sanron sect of Buddhism who lived during the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kaisen Joki
Buddhism.desc: Kaisen Joki (year of birth unknown - April 25, 1582) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect of Buddhism from the Warring States period and the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

Buddhism.name: Kakuun
Buddhism.desc: Kakuun (953 - December 18, 1007) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect who lived in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kakujo (a priest)
Buddhism.desc: Kakujo (1013 - December 9, 1063) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect who lived in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Buan
Buddhism.desc: Buan (c. 764 - October 15, 840) was a priest of the Ritsu sect during the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kakucho
Buddhism.desc: Kakucho (960 - February 21, 1034), a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect, lived in the mid-Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Dosho
Buddhism.desc: Dosho (1171 - August 21, 1248), a Buddhist priest of the Soto sect, lived in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Doto
Buddhism.desc: Doto (dates of birth and death unknown) was a priest during the Asuka period.

Buddhism.name: Choken
Buddhism.desc: Choken (1126 - September 19, 1203) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect who lived from the late Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Keiso
Buddhism.desc: Keiso (955 - January 25, 1020) was a priest of the Tendai sect during the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Jakuen
Buddhism.desc: Jakuen (1207 - October 15, 1299) was a Buddhist priest of the Soto sect who came from the Southern Song of China to Japan in the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Myozen
Buddhism.desc: Myozen (1184 - July 11, 1225) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai sect who lived in the beginning of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Mokujiki Ogo
Buddhism.desc: Mokujiki Ogo (1536 - November 8, 1608) was a priest of the Shingon sect during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

Buddhism.name: Shuso
Buddhism.desc: Shuso is a name for the position of the leader of ascetic monks in Zen sects.

Buddhism.name: Shika
Buddhism.desc: Shika is one of the positions in a Zen temple.

Buddhism.name: Tenzo
Buddhism.desc: Tenzo is one of the positions in a Zen temple.

Buddhism.name: Kangangiin
Buddhism.desc: Kangangiin (1217 - October 12, 1300), a Buddhist priest of the Soto sect, lived in the mid-Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Bankei Yotaku
Buddhism.desc: Bankei Yotaku (April 18, 1622 - October 2, 1693) was a Buddhist priest of the Rinzai sect during the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Shucho
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Shucho (September 3, 1634 - June 12, 1680) was the first Rinnojinomiya Monzeki (temple formerly led by founder of sect, temple in which resided a member of nobility or imperial family) or Nikko Monzeki.

Buddhism.name: Jisan
Buddhism.desc: Jisan (1637-August 7, 1690) was a scholar monk during the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Jishu
Buddhism.desc: Jisyu (1734 - April 28, 1801), a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect and a composer of Chinese poems, lived in the mid-Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Ninjitsu
Buddhism.desc: Ninjitsu (1091-July 11, 1131) was a priest of the Tendai sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Yuizen
Buddhism.desc: Yuizen (1253-March 23, 1317) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) in the late Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shinbutsu
Buddhism.desc: Shinbutsu (March 17, 1209 - April 13, 1258) was a Pure Land Sect Buddhist priest in the mid-Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Senkan
Buddhism.desc: Senkan (918-January 23, 984) was a priest of the Tendai Sect in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Gyokei
Buddhism.desc: Gyokei (year of birth unknown-August 31, 1165) was a priest of the Tendai sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakusin
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Kakusin (May 29, 1588 - March 15, 1648) was a Pure Land Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Chomu
Buddhism.desc: Chomu (1732 – February 2, 1796) was a monk and a haiku poet during the mid Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Nisshin (of the Nichiren Sect of Buddhism)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Nisshin (of the Nichiren Sect of Buddhism).html
Buddhism.desc: Nisshin (1565 - May 17, 1626) was a monk of the Nichiren Sect of Buddhism from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Nichien
Buddhism.desc: Nichien (year of birth and death unknown) was a priest of the Tendai sect in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Jinnichi
Buddhism.desc: Jinnichi (860-December 29, 916) was a priest of the Shingon sect from the early to late Heian Period.

Buddhism.name: Jiun
Buddhism.desc: Jiun (February 18, 1673 – August 6, 1753) was a monk of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land sect of Buddhism) and a poet.

Buddhism.name: Jien
Buddhism.desc: Jien (1748-August 2, 1805) was a priest of the Tendai sect and poet from the mid to late Edo Period.

Buddhism.name: Ganshoni
Buddhism.desc: Ganshoni (953-October 16, 1034) was a nun (Buddhist nun) of the Tendai sect in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Gansaini
Buddhism.desc: Gansaini (year of birth and death unknown) was a nun (Buddhist nun) of the Tendai sect in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kanshu
Buddhism.desc: Kanshu (945-August 17, 1008) was a priest of the Tendai sect in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shakunyo
Buddhism.desc: Shakunyo was a monk of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Myogaku
Buddhism.desc: Myogaku (1056-year of death unknown) was a priest of the Tendai sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Horin
Buddhism.desc: Horin (1693 - November 24, 1741) was a gakuso (scholar monk) of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the middle of the Edo period.

Buddhism.name: NANPO Bunshi
Buddhism.desc: Bunshi NANPO (1555 - October 25, 1620) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Daigan
Buddhism.desc: Daigan (May 21, 1773 - November 12, 1850) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) (Otani school) during the late Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Doin
Buddhism.desc: Doin (1741 - July 1, 1813) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) during the middle to late Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Chido
Buddhism.desc: Chido (1736-December 12, 1805) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) from the mid to the late Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Bunchi-Jo (Princess Bunchi)
Buddhism.desc: Princess Bunchi (July 30, 1619 - February 4, 1697) was a Buddhist nun who lived during the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Bundo Shunkai
Buddhism.desc: BUNDO Shunkai (September 1, 1878-September 26, 1970) was a priest of the Tendai sect from the Taisho to Showa period.

Buddhism.name: HOAN Kokei
Buddhism.desc: Kokei HOAN (1532 - March 5, 1597) was a Rinzai Sect Buddhist monk who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

Buddhism.name: Keitetsu Genso
Buddhism.desc: Keitetsu Genso (1537 - November 26, 1611) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Sengaku
Buddhism.desc: Sengaku was a learned priest pursuing his studies priest of the Tendai sect in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Cloistered Imperial Prince Jiin
Buddhism.desc: Cloistered Imperial Prince Jiin (Jiinhosshinno in Japanese, April 18, 1617 - January 21, 1700) was a Cloistered Imperial Prince in the early to mid-Edo Period.

Buddhism.name: Kongocho-kyo
Buddhism.desc: Kongocho-kyo (Diamond Peak Sutra) is a general term for assorted 'Kongocho-kyo' texts that were compiled one after another by a group called "Shoe Kongocho-kyo" (sarvatathāgatatattvasaṃgrahaṃ nāma mahāyānasūtraṃ, or "Mahayana Sutra Named as a Collection of All the Truth of Nyorai," abbreviated as "Shinjitsu Sho-gyo").

Buddhism.name: Kenshun
Buddhism.desc: Kenshun (962 - year of death unclear) was a priest of the Shingon sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: TSUNODA Mugen
Buddhism.desc: Mugen TSUNODA (year of birth unknown - 1809) was a calligrapher in the Edo era.

Buddhism.name: Nichiryu (Honmon School of Hokke Sect)
Buddhism.desc: Nichiryu (1385 - 1464) was a Nichiren sect priest in the middle of the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Baisao
Buddhism.desc: Baisao (also sometimes pronounced "Maisao", meaning "Old Man Tea-Seller", July 8, 1675 - August 24, 1763) was a Buddhist monk of the Obaku sect in the Edo-period.

Buddhism.name: Kenson
Buddhism.desc: Kenson (March 5, 1564 - April 12, 1595) was the 17th head priest of Kosho-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Yakozen
Buddhism.desc: Yakozen is an evil kind of zen that resembles real Zen but is completely different from the real thing.

Buddhism.name: Shomyo Nenbutsu
Buddhism.desc: Shomyo Nenbutsu is one practice of praying to the Buddha (nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation)), and is a way to chant the name of the Buddha such as 'namuamidabutsu.'

Buddhism.name: Hozan Kenchin
Buddhism.desc: Hozan Kenchin (1394 - February 14, 1442) was a priest during the Muromachi Period.

Buddhism.name: Jugyuzu
Buddhism.desc: Jugyuzu is a set of ten drawings of cows which depict the path leading to the enlightenment of Zen meditation.

Buddhism.name: Honbutsu (the Primordial Buddha)
Buddhism.desc: "Honbutsu" means the Primordial Buddha among numerous Buddha (Nyorai.)

Buddhism.name: Jujushinron (Ten Stages of Mind Development)
Buddhism.desc: "Jujushinron" (Ten Stages of Mind Development), or "Himitsu Mandala Jujushinron" (Ten Abiding Stages on the Secret Mandalas) to be precise, is one of the most famous writings by Kukai, which was written around 830 and describes the system of Shingon Esoteric Buddhism in response to the imperial order of Emperor Junna.

Buddhism.name: Sogo
Buddhism.desc: Sogo refers to the profession of Sokan (official positions given to Buddhist priests by Imperial Court) to manage Buddhist priests and nuns in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Soi (rank of Buddhist priest)
Buddhism.desc: Soi (rank of Buddhist priest) is the Ikai (Court rank) assigned to Buddhist monks in Japan.

Buddhism.name: FUJII Sensho
Buddhism.desc: Sensho FUJII (April 4, 1859 - June 6, 1903) was a Japanese religious figure and explorer.

Buddhism.name: YOSHIMOTO Ishin
Buddhism.desc: Ishin YOSHIMOTO May 25, 1916 - August 1, 1988) was the founder of Naikanho (or Naikan Therapy; one of the psychotherapies).

Buddhism.name: Kurama kokyo
Buddhism.desc: Kurama kokyo is a religious school that was established in October 1947 by Shigaraki Koun, the chief priest of Kurama-dera Temple who was affected by Theosophy, separating from Tendai-shu sect.

Buddhism.name: Kakushi Nenbutsu (A General Term for Heretical Sects [and Their Beliefs] Within Buddhism)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Kakushi Nenbutsu (A General Term for Heretical Sects [and Their Beliefs] Within Buddhism).html
Buddhism.desc: "Kakushi nenbutsu" is a general term that refers to heretical sects (and their beliefs) within Buddhism, which have various secretive aspects.

Buddhism.name: ANDO Rensho
Buddhism.desc: Rensho ANDO (1239 - February 18, 1329) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the late Kamakura period who was a low-level bureaucrat (Miuchibito (private vassals) of the Tokuso family of the regent Hojo clan of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

Buddhism.name: Sentei
Buddhism.desc: Sentei (1660 - September 25, 1698) was a priest of the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: NISHIMURA Kocho
Buddhism.desc: Kocho NISHIMURA (June 4, 1915 - December 2, 2003) was a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist Statues), Buddhist Statues repair specialist, and Buddhist priest.

Buddhism.name: Choja
Buddhism.desc: Choja (or chosha) is a name for an elderly person or rich person.

Buddhism.name: Bon Toro (A Lantern-Shaped Decoration)
Buddhism.desc: "Bon toro" (also called "bon doro," written as "盆燈籠" in Japanese) is a lantern-shaped decoration, which is dedicated to the dead at a grave during the season of "Obon" (an annual festival of the dead) in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Onaibutsu (a Buddhist altar)
Buddhism.desc: Onaibutsu is a Buddhist altar, or a principal image enshrined in it.

Buddhism.name: Jurasetsunyo
Buddhism.desc: Jurasetsunyo are ten demonesses of Tenbu (group of Protectors of Buddhist Laws) in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Mokusho-zen (a method of zazen)
Buddhism.desc: The term "Mokusho-zen" indicates a method of zazen (sitting meditation) in Zen Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Homyo-jiku (a hanging scroll on which a priest's name or the posthumous name of the deceased is drawn)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Homyo-jiku (a hanging scroll on which a priests name or the posthumous name of the deceased is drawn.html
Buddhism.desc: Homyo-jiku is one of Buddhist altar fittings used in Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land School of Buddhism), on which homyo (a priest's name or the posthumous name of the deceased) is described or painted.

Buddhism.name: Fuju-fuse-gi (nothing could be received or given)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Fuju-fuse-gi (nothing could be received or given).html
Buddhism.desc: Fuju-fuse-gi is a concept of the Nichiren sect of Buddhism; "fuju" means refusing offerings from those who don't believe in the Hokekyo (Lotus Sutra) and "fuse" means giving no offerings to priests who propagates beliefs other than Hokekyo.

Buddhism.name: Heizei-gojo (a term composed of four kanji characters representing an essential doctrine of Jodo Shinshu Buddhism)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Heizei-gojo (a term composed of four kanji characters representing an essential doctrine of Jodo Shi.html
Buddhism.desc: "Heizei-gojo" is a Buddhist term of Jodo Shinshu Buddhism (the True Pure Land Buddhism,) which means that any person must complete preparation for rebirth in heaven while he is still alive.

Buddhism.name: Ofumi (letters)
Buddhism.desc: The term "Ofumi" refers to letters of sermons written in kana by Rennyo, the eighth chief priest of Hongan-ji Temple of Jodo Shinshu Buddhism, which were dispatched to followers throughout the country as a means of propagation.

Buddhism.name: TERAMOTO Enga
Buddhism.desc: Enga TERAMOTO (1872 - 1940), born in Kaito-gun, Aichi Prefecture, was a priest of Higashi Hongan-ji Temple and the third Japanese who entered Tibet.

Buddhism.name: Nyoshin (a Japanese Buddhist monk of the Jodo Shinshu school)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Nyoshin (a Japanese Buddhist monk of the Jodo Shinshu school).html
Buddhism.desc: Nyoshin was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (the Pure True Land school of Buddhism) from the middle to the end of the Kamakura Period.

Buddhism.name: Jinu
Buddhism.desc: Jinu (year of birth and death unknown) was a priest of the Tendai sect who lived in the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Rensei
Buddhism.desc: Rensei (1455 - September 17, 1521) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) who lived from the mid Muromachi period to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Myoho (Buddhist priest)
Buddhism.desc: Myoho (1184 - December 4, 1251) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) who lived in the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Sanjo-wasan (Three Books of Buddhist Hymns written in Japanese)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Sanjo-wasan (Three Books of Buddhist Hymns written in Japanese).html
Buddhism.desc: "Sanjo-wasan" is a collective term for Jodo-wasan (hymns of the Pure Land school), Koso-wasan (hymns about high-ranked priests), and Shozomatsu-wasan (hymns about three stages of the history of Buddhism), all of which were written in Japanese by Shinran.

Buddhism.name: Sanposon
Buddhism.desc: Sanposon (also pronounced as Sanboson) is the honzon (principal image of Buddha) of the Hokke sect and Nichiren Sect of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Hoto (a treasure tower)
Buddhism.desc: "Hoto" is a Buddhist pagoda composed of a cylindrical or octagonal toshin (the body of a pagoda,) with a square-shaped roof on it, and sorin (a metal pinnacle placed on the top of a pagoda).

Buddhism.name: Junshin
Buddhism.desc: Junshin (year of birth unknown, died on April 20, 1250) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) who lived in the mid Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Myoho (the Supreme Dharma)
Buddhism.desc: Myoho (Saddharma in Sanskrit) means the first victorious and mysterious dharma in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Shumon aratame (the inquisition for suppressing Christianity)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Shumon aratame (the inquisition for suppressing Christianity).html
Buddhism.desc: Shumon aratame was religion policy and the control of the public promoted by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

Buddhism.name: Shumon aratame-yaku (an officer in charge of the persecution of Christians)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Shumon aratame-yaku (an officer in charge of the persecution of Christians).html
Buddhism.desc: Shumon aratame-yaku is one of law enforcement posts set up in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and in all the domains.

Buddhism.name: Nikon no tokudo
Buddhism.desc: Nikon no tokudo refers to attain Nirvana and salvation (Jodo (completing the path to becoming a Buddha by attaining enlightenment)) by listening to the chanting of Myohorenge-kyo Sutra (the Lotus Sutra).

Buddhism.name: Sorin (metal pinnacle on the top of a pagoda)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Sorin (metal pinnacle on the top of a pagoda).html
Buddhism.desc: Sorin refers collectively to a metal pinnacle built on the roof of a five-storied pagoda, etc., which rises heavenward.

Buddhism.name: Kenmitsu taisei (a hypothesis about Japanese medieval Buddhism)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Kenmitsu taisei (a hypothesis about Japanese medieval Buddhism).html
Buddhism.desc: Kenmitsu taisei refers to a hypothesis about a medieval religious theory in Japan, which was proposed by Toshio KURODA, a historian.

Buddhism.name: Naijin (Inner sanctuary of a shrine or a temple)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Naijin (Inner sanctuary of a shrine or a temple).html
Buddhism.desc: The term "naijin" refers to a place where a honzon (a principal image of Buddha) is enshrined inside the hondo (main hall) of a temple, or where a shintai (an object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) is enshrined inside the honden (main hall) of a shrine.

Buddhism.name: Gutoku-sho (literally, idiot monk's note)
Buddhism.desc: "Gutoku-sho" is a treatise written by Shinran on his own religious faith through his master's teaching of the Jodo (Pure Land) sect.

Buddhism.name: Shinjitsu
Buddhism.desc: Shinjitsu (years of birth and death unknown) was a monk at the end of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shingon (literally, 'truthful utterances')
Buddhism.desc: The term "shingon" or "Sanskrit mantra" refers to sacred utterances, derived from Mikkyo scriptures (Esoteric Buddhism scriptures) such as Daibirushana Jobutsu Jinbenkaji-kyo Sutra (Mahavairocana Sutra).

Buddhism.name: Ajikan
Buddhism.desc: The term "Ajikan" refers to a method of meditation introduced by Kukai (a Buddhist priest) during the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Koun
Buddhism.desc: Koun (years of birth and death unknown) was a sculptor of Buddhist images at the end of the Heian period and in the early part of the Kamakura period, and a member of the Kei school of sculpture.

Buddhism.name: Genseishojoju (those guaranteed to be born in the Pure Land while still in this world)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Genseishojoju (those guaranteed to be born in the Pure Land while still in this world).html
Buddhism.desc: The term "Genseishojoju" is also referred to as 'gensho futai (the idea of "not falling back in this world").'

Buddhism.name: OK
Buddhism.desc: Chosei was a "busshi" (a sculptor of Buddhist statues) in the middle of the Heian period, whose birth year was 1010 (birth date unknown) and death date was December 27, 1091.

Buddhism.name: Kanna Zen (A Style Of 'Zazen' [Sitting Meditation])
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Kanna Zen (A Style Of Zazen [Sitting Meditation]).html
Buddhism.desc: "Kanna Zen" (also called "Kanwa Zen") is a style of "zazen" (sitting meditation) which is practiced in the Zen Sect of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Butsubachi (Buddha's punishment)
Buddhism.desc: The term Butsubachi (Buddha's punishment) refers to punishment a person receives who violates the basic truth of the Buddha (Nyorai) 's enlightenment.

Buddhism.name: OTANI Koei
Buddhism.desc: Koei OTANI was a monk of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) who lived from the Meiji period to the Taisho period.

Buddhism.name: Mitsugon-in Temple
Buddhism.desc: Mitsugon-in Temple

Buddhism.name: Makyo (An Unbalanced Mental Condition That An Ascetic Of Zen Sect Of Buddhism Can Fall Into During Meditation)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Makyo (An Unbalanced Mental Condition That An Ascetic Of Zen Sect Of Buddhism Can Fall Into During M.html
Buddhism.desc: "Makyo" refers to an unbalanced mental condition of ego-swelling that results from excessive self-consciousness, into which an ascetic of the Zen Sect of Buddhism tends to fall when halfway awakened.

Buddhism.name: YAMADA Etai
Buddhism.desc: Etai YAMADA (December 1, 1895 - February 22, 1994) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Jonyo
Buddhism.desc: Jonyo (乗如, also written as 乘如) was a Buddhist priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) in the mid Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Hijiri (A Japanese Buddhist Priest Who Traveled Around Local Provinces)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Hijiri (A Japanese Buddhist Priest Who Traveled Around Local Provinces).html
Buddhism.desc: "Hijiri" refers to a Japanese Buddhist priest who traveled around local provinces.

Buddhism.name: MOTOSAWA Chikuun
Buddhism.desc: Chikuun MOTOSAWA (March 26, 1836 - October 13, 1907) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu (True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) and a Japanese scholar of the Chinese classics, who founded Kakuchi gakusha (the Kakuchi school), known as 'Chonmage gakko' (the school of must-wear a Japanese topknot), located in the present Higashi Murayama-gun, Yamagata Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Gongyo (Otani School of the Jodo Shishu Sect)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Gongyo (Otani School of the Jodo Shishu Sect).html
Buddhism.desc: In the case of the Shinshu Otaniha (Otani school of the Jodo Shishu sect), Gongyo (devotional exercises) is to do gassho (putting the palms of hands together), raihai (adoration), shomyo nenbutsu (invocation of the Buddha's name), and to do dokuju (hailing) of gemon (recitation of verses) in front of an 'onaibutsu' (another name for butsudan (a Buddhist altar)) or portable 'mitsuori honzon' (mitsuori - can be folded into thirds, honzon - principal object of worship).

Buddhism.name: Ryaku kataginu (Buddhist stall worn around the neck)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Ryaku kataginu (Buddhist stall worn around the neck).html
Buddhism.desc: Ryaku kataginu is a hogu (ritual implements) that followers of Shinshu sect Otani school dangle from their neck as a ceremonial dress before the altar of a temple.

Buddhism.name: Hokke-do Hall
Buddhism.desc: Hokke-do Hall, abbreviation of Hokke Sanmaido Hall, is a Buddhist temple in which Tendai-shu sect's Hokekyo sanmai no gyo (religious austerities to concentrate on the Lotus Sutra in Buddhism) is performed.

Buddhism.name: OTANI Kosho
Buddhism.desc: Kosho OTANI (November 1, 1911 - June 14, 2002) was a Japanese religious figure.

Buddhism.name: Tosu (lavatory)
Buddhism.desc: Tosu is a lavatory in Buddhist temples.

Buddhism.name: Bussharito
Buddhism.desc: Bussharito is a Buddhist pagoda that allegedly contains Busshari (remains of Shakamuni-butsu).

Buddhism.name: Shoju (to embrace and spread the correct teaching)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Shoju (to embrace and spread the correct teaching).html
Buddhism.desc: Shoju is an antonym for Shakubuku (to correct another's false views and awaken that person to the truth of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Zokumyojyuho
Buddhism.desc: Zokumyojyuho means treasured heirloom to atone life and indicates the teachings in "Nehan-gyo Sutra" (The Sutra of The Great Nirvana) defined by Tendai Daishi Chigi.

Buddhism.name: Tsuisetsu Tsuimin
Buddhism.desc: The expression "tsuisetsu tsuimin" (literally meaning "re-exposition and re-effacement") is a Japanese Buddhist term that refers to an interpretation given to "the Nirvana Sutra" from the perspective (represented by the Tendai sect and Nichiren sect of Buddhism) that regards the Lotus Sutra as the fundamental sutra that brings salvation to the whole world.

Buddhism.name: Furitsukenjo
Buddhism.desc: Furitsukenjo is a term that mean "Nehan-gyo Sutra" (The Sutra of The Great Nirvana) from the viewpoint of Buddhism, especially hokke-ichijo (the doctrines called the Single Vehicle of the Lotus) including Tendai-shu sect and Nichiren-shu sect.

Buddhism.name: SAITO Tokiyori
Buddhism.desc: Tokiyori SAITO (year of birth and death unknown) was a samurai in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Denpo-kanjo (the consecration for the Transmission of the Dharma)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Denpo-kanjo (the consecration for the Transmission of the Dharma).html
Buddhism.desc: Denpo-kanjo is a ceremony to confer the title of master called Ajari (a master in esoteric Buddhism; a high priest).

Buddhism.name: Gohyaku-Jintengo
Buddhism.desc: Gohyaku-Jintengo (literally, five hundred is like a piece of dust in the infinite time frame) is a word that represents admiration for Siddhartha Gautama spending limitless time in the process of Jodo (completing the path to becoming a Buddha by attaining enlightenment), which is cited in the Nyorai Juryo-bon (the Infinite Life of Buddha Chapter) of Hokekyo (the Lotus Sutra).

Buddhism.name: Keisaku (kyosaku) (a Zen stick)
Buddhism.desc: Keisaku is the abbreviation for Keikakusakurei.

Buddhism.name: Ichinen sanzen
Buddhism.desc: Ichinen sanzen is a kanpo (meditative training to reach enlightenment) and fundamental principle of the Tendai sect.

Buddhism.name: OK
Buddhism.desc: Bokan is an organization which was in charge of the household management of the supreme leader of a temple (betto [administrator of a Buddhist temple] or sango [three monastic positions with management roles at a temple]) and so on, or the monks who belonged to such an organization in and after the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Rakkei
Buddhism.desc: Rakkei (落慶) refers to celebration of new construction or the completion of repairs to temples and shrines.

Buddhism.name: Kaigen (Eye-Opening)
Buddhism.desc: Kaigen refers to enshrining a Buddha statue or Buddhist painting newly made in a temple or hall to welcome the spirit.

Buddhism.name: Ichiryu denju
Buddhism.desc: Ichiryu denju means jiso denju (initiation of practical training) in the Shingon sect of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Ryoen
Buddhism.desc: Ryoen (August 24, 1179 - February 26, 1220) was a priest of Kofuku-ji Temple during the late Heian period through the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Sesshin
Buddhism.desc: Sesshin (接心) is sometimes described as 攝(摂)心, and it means concentration of a confused heart.

Buddhism.name: Esan kiitsu
Buddhism.desc: Esan kiitsu (Esan kiichi) means that learning ichijo (Single Vehicle) through understanding sanjo (the Three Vehicles carrying sentient beings to the world of enlightenment).

Buddhism.name: Docho
Buddhism.desc: Docho (1544 - May 12, 1608) was a Buddhist priest in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Terauke shomon
Buddhism.desc: Terauke shomon was a certificate issued by Buddhist temples to danka (supporter of a Buddhist temple) in order to prove that they were actually the danka of the relevant temple under the Terauke seido (the system in which the public should be registered in any one of the designated temples to prove their Buddhist faith) in Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Mangan (completion of a vow)
Buddhism.desc: Mangan refers to completion of the period determined to be spent praying for Shinto or Buddhist deities or to practice asceticism.

Buddhism.name: Kannodoko
Buddhism.desc: Kannodoko means connections between a Buddha and a human being, or between a teacher and a learner.

Buddhism.name: Enso
Buddhism.desc: Enso is a type of calligraphic technique in Zen calligraphy, which is a circle painted with a single stroke.

Buddhism.name: Hokke Shichiyu (The Seven Parables of the Lotus Sutra)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Hokke Shichiyu (The Seven Parables of the Lotus Sutra).html
Buddhism.desc: Hokke Shichiyu means the seven parables of Hoke-kyo Sutra (the Lotus Sutra).

Buddhism.name: Hoshi (Successor)
Buddhism.desc: "Hoshi" (Hassu) refers to a successor of his/her master's teachings.

Buddhism.name: Kokaku
Buddhism.desc: Kokaku (date of birth and death unknown) was a priest of the Tendai Sect in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Nisshin
Buddhism.desc: Nisshin (1561 - 1617) was a high priest of the Nichiren sect of Buddhism during the periods of Warring States (in Japan) and Azuchi-Momoyama period.

Buddhism.name: Jokai
Buddhism.desc: Jokai (year of birth and death unknown) is a priest of Kankiko-ji Temple of the Jishu Sect during the mid Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: OTANI Ennei
Buddhism.desc: Ennei OTANI (November 14, 1914 - January 28, 2008) was a priest of Jodo shinshu sect (True Pure Land Sect Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Ryoko
Buddhism.desc: Ryoko (born in 1142; year of death unknown) was a priest of the Ono school of the Shingon Sect during the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Chukai
Buddhism.desc: Chukai (born in 1162; died on April 10, 1227) was a priest of the Tendai Sect during the late Heian period and early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shujukudatsu
Buddhism.desc: "Shujukudatsu" is also known as "Sanyaku" (The Three Stages of Benefit).

Buddhism.name: OTANI Eijun
Buddhism.desc: Eijun OTANI (1890-May 23, 1973) was a priest of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) of Buddhism

Buddhism.name: Nyushutsu Nimonge
Buddhism.desc: The term "Nyushutsu Nimonge" refers to a gatha (geju) (poetic verse of a scripture) written by Shinran.

Buddhism.name: Jodo Monrui Jusho
Buddhism.desc: The term "Jodo Monrui Jusho" refers to a theoretical treatise in which Shinran wrote about the fundamental thoughts of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Zazenwasan
Buddhism.desc: Zazenwasan is the commentary on the nature and purpose of Zazen in Japanese which used to be written in classical Chinese and the easy explanation to understand for people.

Buddhism.name: Mappo mukai
Buddhism.desc: Mappo mukai is the education and learning of various Nichiren schools with a concept to deny the validity of precepts in the Final Dharma Age.

Buddhism.name: Kangakue
Buddhism.desc: Kangakue was a Buddhist meeting held to conduct teaching, nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation), and create Chinese-style poems themed after "Hokekyo" (Lotus Sutra), and was held by the scholars of Kidendo (the study of the histories) in Daigakuryo (Bureau of Education) and the priests of Enryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Hiei, on March 15 (in old lunar calendar) or September 15 (in old lunar calendar) at the western foot of Mt. Hiei or at the temples in and around Heian-kyo (ancient Kyoto), in the mid through latter period of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kangaku
Buddhism.desc: Kangaku (Kangaku ranking) means the title to be given to Buddhist monks who are in a commanding position with a high level of education and learning in religious schools of Japanese Buddhism after the end of modern times.

Buddhism.name: Genshi Kimyo-dan
Buddhism.desc: Genshi Kimyo-dan was a school which used to exist in the Tendai sect.

Buddhism.name: Goju no Sotai
Buddhism.desc: Goju no Sotai is a part of the Kyoso Hanjaku (a guide for evaluation of sutras and others) established by Nichiren.

Buddhism.name: Hakkotsu (Ofumi)
Buddhism.desc: The sixteenth letter 'Hakkotsu' of go jo me (the fifth quire of sutra) of Ofumi which was selected by Rennyo, the eighth chief priest of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) Hongan-ji Temple is especially famous in ofumi.

Buddhism.name: Daigen shuri bosatsu (a deity which is respected and worshipped at temples of the Soto sect)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Daigen shuri bosatsu (a deity which is respected and worshipped at temples of the Soto sect).html
Buddhism.desc: Daigen shuri bosatsu is a deity respected at and enshrined to the temples of the Zen sect, especially the Soto sect.

Buddhism.name: Ryakko shugyo (countless kalpas of practice to reach enlightenment in Buddhism)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Ryakko shugyo (countless kalpas of practice to reach enlightenment in Buddhism).html
Buddhism.desc: Ryakko shugyo is the ascetic practices which a bodhisattva (one who vows to save all beings before becoming a Buddha) does for a long period of time while being reincarnated over and over for three generations, past, present, and future.

Buddhism.name: Jogakuso (a quota for Buddhist priests, or Buddhist priests under a quota system)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Jogakuso (a quota for Buddhist priests, or Buddhist priests under a quota system).html
Buddhism.desc: Jogakuso refers to a quota system for Buddhist priests under the "kodai ritsuryosei" (ancient East Asian system of centralized governance), or priests themselves under this system.

Buddhism.name: Onan oshi
Buddhism.desc: Onan (横難) oshi (横死) means to die in an unforeseen disaster or to die an unnatural death.

Buddhism.name: Shadow of death
Buddhism.desc: The shadow of death is described as follows:

Buddhism.name: Jogakuji (Buddhist temples with status similar to state-sponsored provincial temples)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Jogakuji (Buddhist temples with status similar to state-sponsored provincial temples).html
Buddhism.desc: Jogakuji refers to Buddhist temples with the second highest temple status following "kandaiji" (state-sponsored temples of great scale) and "kokubunji" (state-sponsored provincial temples), which existed in the Nara and Heian periods.
