Buddhism.name: Shodo-mon (Gateway of the Holy Path)
Buddhism.desc: Shodo-mon (Gateway of the Holy Path) is the religious doctrine preaching to become a Buddha by self-power through various practices.

Buddhism.name: Homyo (Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism))
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Homyo (Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism)).html
Buddhism.desc: Homyo' in Jodo Shinshu is the introduction of oneself showing that he/she is to be a disciple of Shaka or Shkyamuni (a disciple of the Buddha).

Buddhism.name: Kanchu Chutai
Buddhism.desc: Kanchu Chutai (year of birth unknown-April 30, 1406) was the ninth priest of Shokoku-ji Temple in Kyoto.

Buddhism.name: Kokuanten
Buddhism.desc: Kokuanten (Sanskrit:Kālarātri,Kālarātrī) was one of Tembu-shin in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Yakuseki
Buddhism.desc: Yakuseki means dinner in Zen sect.

Buddhism.name: Kenrojishin
Buddhism.desc: Kenrojishin is one of the Tembu-shin in Buddhism and controls earth.

Buddhism.name: Eijitsu
Buddhism.desc: Eijitsu (1201 – January 21, 1215) was the third son of MINAMOTO no Yoriie, the second seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

Buddhism.name: Jogyo Zanmai-do Hall
Buddhism.desc: Jogyo zanmai-do hall is a type of Buddhist hall built to perform the jogyo zanmai which is one of the Shishuzanmai (the four kinds of samadhi) of the Tendai sect.

Buddhism.name: Genko (a Buddhist priest)
Buddhism.desc: Genko (year of birth and death unknown) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect who lived in the end of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shingonshu Juhachi Honzan
Buddhism.desc: Shingonshu juhachi honzan is an organization consisting of the 18 Head Temples of schools in the Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Daishi-do hall
Buddhism.desc: Daishi-do hall is a type of Buddhist hall in Japan built to enshrine and pray to a priest who was entitled as Daishi (literally a great master, an honorific title given by the Imperial Court).

Buddhism.name: Tenkirin
Buddhism.desc: Tenkirin (also called tenkibashira or goshouguruma) is a poll made with stone or wood having a wheel built in it which is placed at the entrance of a temple or a graveyard.

Buddhism.name: Zafu
Buddhism.desc: Zafu is a zabuton (Japanese cushions used to sit on the floor) used for zazen (Zen sitting meditation).

Buddhism.name: Otani-byodo Mausoleum
Buddhism.desc: The Otani-byodo was the mausoleum of Shinran who was the founder of Jodo Shinshu sect

Buddhism.name: Donei Eio
Buddhism.desc: Donei Eio (1424 - 1504) was a priest of the Soto sect in the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: Daimokuko
Buddhism.desc: Daimokuko is a ko (meeting to lecture Buddhist scriptures) composed by followers of Hokke sects.

Buddhism.name: Shungyo
Buddhism.desc: Shungyo (1118 - 1186) was a Buddhist priest at the end of the Heian Period.

Buddhism.name: Shumon Ninbetsu Aratame Cho (The Village People Register of Religious Faith and Relationship)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Shumon Ninbetsu Aratame Cho (The Village People Register of Religious Faith and Relationship).html
Buddhism.desc: Shumon Ninbetsu Aratame Cho refers to a register created in the Edo period, which is equivalent to a modern household register.

Buddhism.name: Kokudachi
Buddhism.desc: Kokudachi (spiritual practice of eating no grain) is one of Buddhism "gyo" (spiritual practices).

Buddhism.name: Soncho
Buddhism.desc: Soncho (year of birth unknown - 1227) is a Buddhist monk in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Nihon Ojo Gokuraku-ki
Buddhism.desc: "Nihon Ojo Gokuraku-ki" (Japanese-version collection of memoirs of persons who became Buddha) refers to ojoden (stories of the attainment of rebirth in the Pure Land) compiled by YOSHISHIGE no Yasutane (year of birth unknown - 1002) in the middle Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Rokusai Nenbutsu
Buddhism.desc: Rokusai Nenbutsu is one of Odori Nenbutsu (chanting of prayers while dancing).

Buddhism.name: Neko-dera (cat temple)
Buddhism.desc: Neko-dera is the common name for temples deeply linked to cats that exist all over Japan.

Buddhism.name: Daisenji Engi
Buddhism.desc: Daisenji engi (tales of the origin of Daisen-ji Temple) is:

Buddhism.name: Zenshin
Buddhism.desc: Zenshin (1151 - the year of death unknown) was a monk of Tendai sect in the end of Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Gyoei
Buddhism.desc: Gyoei (year of birth and death unknown) was a priest during Asuka period and Nara period.

Buddhism.name: Fushinjo
Buddhism.desc: Fushinjo is the general term to represent three letters written from Kukai to Saicho.

Buddhism.name: Soniryo
Buddhism.desc: Soniryo was a division of the Japanese ritsuryo code.

Buddhism.name: Kaimon Shocho
Buddhism.desc: Kaimon Shocho (1374 – June 6, 1443) was the prince of Emperor Chokei of the Southern Court (Japan).

Buddhism.name: Ryoen (Tendai sect)
Buddhism.desc: Ryoen (983 - July 1050) was a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect during the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Hyakumanben Nenbutsu
Buddhism.desc: Hyakumanben Nenbutsu is to repeat nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation) for a million times for the purposes of one's own birth in the Pure Land, ceremony as a memorial, and other variety of prayer.

Buddhism.name: Keien (Tendai sect)
Buddhism.desc: Keien (Kyoen, 944 - October 9, 1019) is a Buddhist priest of the Tendai sect during the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: GOTO Kanji
Buddhism.desc: Kanji GOTO (May 19, 1871 - February 23, 1936) was a battlefield missionary priest and a founder of schools in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Sekisen school
Buddhism.desc: Sekisen school is one of the schools under Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) Hongan-ji school.

Buddhism.name: Sanichigonjitsu no soron
Buddhism.desc: Sanichigonjitsu no soron refers to the disputes during the period from around 817 through 821 on Buddhism between Tokuitsu (his date of birth and death unknown) who was a Buddhist priest in Hosso sect of Buddhism (Japanese equivalent of the Chinese Faxiang sect) and Saicho (767 – 822) who was the founder of Nihon Tendai sect.

Buddhism.name: Anshin
Buddhism.desc: The term "anshin," also referred to as anjin, means a state of mind in which there is nothing to be concerned about and one feels calm and easy.

Buddhism.name: Gyoku
Buddhism.desc: Gyoku (year of birth and death unknown) was a priest of the Jodo sect of Buddhism in the late Heian and the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shue
Buddhism.desc: Shue refers to the council or self-governing body for decision-making of the Buddhist priests in the temples in medieval Japanese temples.

Buddhism.name: Jiin-ho
Buddhism.desc: "Jiin-ho" is a name for laws regarding Buddhist temples.

Buddhism.name: Honnyo
Buddhism.desc: Honnyo (1778 – January 9, 1827) was a Buddhist priest in Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) from the middle to the late Edo period who served as the 19th suzerain in Nishi Hongan-ji Temple and Daisojo (a priest of the highest rank in the highest managerial position).

Buddhism.name: Urabon festival (a Buddhist festival)
Buddhism.desc: The term urabone (ullambana) refers to the last day of an ango practice (the three-month intensified practice of Zen Buddhism), on July 15th in the old calendar, but urabone is mostly used to indicate a memorial service offered for ancestors' souls to relieve severe sufferings on that day.

Buddhism.name: Rokusodankyo (Platform Sutra)
Buddhism.desc: The rokusodankyo (Platform Sutra) is one of the Buddhist scriptures and is a collection of preaching by Eno, the rokuso (sixth leader) of the Chinese Zen sect.

Buddhism.name: Koan (Zen riddles)
Buddhism.desc: Koan can have either of the following meanings:

Buddhism.name: Genkan (entrance)
Buddhism.desc: The word genkan refers to the main entrance of a building.

Buddhism.name: Hakuin Ekaku
Buddhism.desc: Hakuin Ekaku (January 19, 1686 - January 18, 1769) was a Zen monk in the Edo Period who is called Chuko no So (father of restoration) of the Rinzaishu sect.

Buddhism.name: Daruma
Buddhism.desc: Daruma (Bodhidharma) is regarded as the founder of Zen.

Buddhism.name: Shugendo (a term relating to religions in Japan)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Shugendo (a term relating to religions in Japan).html
Buddhism.desc: Shugendo is a Japan-specific Konko-shukyo (a religion combining Buddhism, Shintoism and other religions) whose objective is to do ascetic practice while confining oneself in the mountains, in order to obtain various shirushi (evidence) which indicate that certain practice levels have been reached.

Buddhism.name: Sogi (Funeral ceremony)
Buddhism.desc: Sogi (funeral ceremony) or Soshiki (funeral ceremony) is a part of Saigi (ceremony) or Sosei (funeral system) to mourn the passing of the deceased.

Buddhism.name: Cremation
Buddhism.desc: Cremation is a type of treating the dead by incinerating the body.

Buddhism.name: Jikku Kannongyo (one of the Buddhist scriptures)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Jikku Kannongyo (one of the Buddhist scriptures).html
Buddhism.desc: Jikku Kannongyo is one of the Buddhist scriptures.

Buddhism.name: Hocho (Bird Release)
Buddhism.desc: Hocho is to let a bird which has been captured or reared by humans free from human stewardship by releasing it out of doors.

Buddhism.name: Shuni-e (Omizu-tori or Sacred Water-drawing Festival)
Buddhism.desc: Shuni-e refers to one of hoe (Buddhist mass) conducted in Japanese Buddhist temples, which is also called Shunigatsu-e.

Buddhism.name: Makura-kyo Death Guidance (Pillow Sutra)
Buddhism.desc: Makura-kyo (also referred to as makura-gyo) is one of the services held immediately after a person's death to offer sutra chanting to the dead person for the first time.

Buddhism.name: Tsuya (Wake)
Buddhism.desc: A tsuya is a ritual held throughout the night before the day of the funeral.

Buddhism.name: Meinichi
Buddhism.desc: Meinichi means a deathday, or the day of a person's death.

Buddhism.name: Inka (Certification of achievement)
Buddhism.desc: Inka refers to the license which a master grants to a disciple who has mastered his teachings.

Buddhism.name: Rankei Doryu
Buddhism.desc: Rankei Doryu (1213 - August 13, 1278) was a Zen priest and the founder of the Daikaku-ha school who came to Japan from China at the time of the Southern Sung Dynasty in the middle of the Kamakura Period.

Buddhism.name: Ango (intensified practice of Zen Buddhism)
Buddhism.desc: Ango is an ascetic practice conducted for a specified period at one place by a group of Buddhist monks who have been engaged in separate activities.

Buddhism.name: Mokujiki
Buddhism.desc: Mokujiki (1718 - 1810) was a Buddhist practitioner and sculptor of Buddhist statues during the late Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Issan Ichinei
Buddhism.desc: Issan Ichinei (1247 - November 28, 1317) was a priest who came to Japan from Yuan (Yuan Dynasty).

Buddhism.name: Nenki
Buddhism.desc: Nenki is an anniversary of the death of a person.

Buddhism.name: The Mumonkan (Wu-wen kuan; Gateless Gate) books of the Zen sect
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Mumonkan (Wu-wen kuan; Gateless Gate) books of the Zen sect.html
Buddhism.desc: Mumonkan (written as 無門関 or 無門關 in Chinese characters) is a collection of koan (questions that a master gives to a person who seeks the secret of Zen to avoid deviating from the correct way) compiled by Mumon Ekai in the Sung period in China.

Buddhism.name: The Institute for Zen Studies
Buddhism.desc: The Institute for Zen Studies is a research institute (a corporation) about Zen and Zen-related culture established jointly by the Rinzaishu and Obakushu sects, and is located on the premises of Hanazono University.

Buddhism.name: Goroku (a collection of sayings)
Buddhism.desc: Generally, the term goroku indicates a collection of what a person said.

Buddhism.name: Gyoja/Anja
Buddhism.desc: Gyoja or Anja has the following meanings.

Buddhism.name: Shobogenzo (a Zen-related book)
Buddhism.desc: A Shobogenzo is a Buddhist philosophy-related book written by a Zen priest.

Buddhism.name: Chuin
Buddhism.desc: Chuin and chuu refer to the period of mourning lasting seven weeks in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Kuyo (put offerings to Buddha, scriptures and priests)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Kuyo (put offerings to Buddha, scriptures and priests).html
Buddhism.desc: Kuyo is a translation of the Sanskrit word Puja or Pujana, and refers to making cordial offerings of incense, flowers, tomyo (brightness of a burning lamp), food, and drink.

Buddhism.name: Jodo-e (Celebration of Shakyamuni Buddha's enlightenment)
Buddhism.desc: Jodo-e is a hoyo (Buddhist memorial service) celebrating the Jodo (completing the path to becoming a Buddha by attaining enlightenment) of Shakyamuni.

Buddhism.name: Nehan-e (Memorial service for the anniversary of Buddha's Nirvana)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Nehan-e (Memorial service for the anniversary of Buddhas Nirvana).html
Buddhism.desc: Nehan-e, also referred to as Nehan-ko or Nehan-ki, is a Buddhist memorial service practiced in Japan and China on February 15 in the Chinese lunar calendar, the day when Shakyamuni entered Nirvana (died), to remember the illustrious memory of Shakamuni and repayment of a kindness.

Buddhism.name: Kokei
Buddhism.desc: Kokei (1648 to August 30, 1705) was a monk of the Sanronshu Sect who lived in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Inshun
Buddhism.desc: Inshun (1589 to February 5, 1648) was a monk and a martial artist who lived in the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: FURUICHI Choin
Buddhism.desc: Choin FURUICHI (1452 - August 22, 1508) was a priest and busho (military commander) who lived in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Shojin Otoshi (the end of maigre days)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Shojin Otoshi (the end of maigre days).html
Buddhism.desc: Shojin Otoshi originally referred to shifting from maigre meals back to normal meals after the completion of chuin (a period of mourning lasting seven weeks).

Buddhism.name: Hoshi Matsuri (Buddhist star festival)
Buddhism.desc: Hoshi Matsuri is a Buddhist festival celebrating the tonenjo (also referred to as tonenzokusho, each person's star of the year) and honmyojo (each person's star of the year of birth) to ward off evil.

Buddhism.name: Gozan (a term relating to Zen temples)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Gozan (a term relating to Zen temples).html
Buddhism.desc: Gozan indicates the status of a Zenrin (temple of the Zen sect) in China and Japan that is ranked above jissatsu (for the ten important temples of the Rinzai sect) and shozan (for ordinary Zen temples).

Buddhism.name: Sange (to scatter flowers)
Buddhism.desc: Sange means as follows.

Buddhism.name: Reijo (Sacred Places)
Buddhism.desc: A reijo is a place where human souls are said to gather after death.

Buddhism.name: Shinzan shiki
Buddhism.desc: Shinzan shiki refers to a ceremony when a new chief priest comes into a temple.

Buddhism.name: Shoko
Buddhism.desc: Shoko refers to burning incense in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Zuko
Buddhism.desc: Zuko refers to applying incense to a Buddha's statue or the body of a practitioner to cleanse impurities.

Buddhism.name: Shoryoe
Buddhism.desc: Shoryoe refers to Daihoyo (major Buddhist memorial service) for the anniversary of Prince Shotoku's death.

Buddhism.name: Daisaitogoma ceremony
Buddhism.desc: Daisaitogoma ceremony refers to large-scale Goma (Holy Fire) Mass held in the field.

Buddhism.name: Inpa
Buddhism.desc: Inpa refers to one of the busshi (sculptor of Buddhist Statues) schools from the late Heian Period to the Kamakura Period.

Buddhism.name: Enpa (En school of sculptors)
Buddhism.desc: Enpa is a school of busshi (sculptor of Buddhist Statues) which started from the mid Heian period and lasted until the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Sanjo Bussho
Buddhism.desc: Sanjo Bussho was a Buddhist sculpture workshop that was located in Kyoto's Sanjo-dori Street in the mid Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shichijo Omiya Bussho
Buddhism.desc: Shichijo Omiya Bussho was a Buddhist sculpture workshop that operated in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Rokujo Madenokoji Bussho
Buddhism.desc: Rokujo Madenokoji Bussho was a Buddhist sculpture workshop that operated in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shoyoroku (a Buddhist book)
Buddhism.desc: Shoyoroku is a Buddhist book from the era of the Sung dynasty in China.

Buddhism.name: Butto-koji Juhasson
Buddhism.desc: The Butto-koji Juhasson are reijo (sacred places) containing pagodas, located in the Kinki region.

Buddhism.name: Indo
Buddhism.desc: Indo

Buddhism.name: Shoko (a percussion instrument)
Buddhism.desc: A shoko is a percussion instrument used in gagaku (Japanese court dance and music), and is the only metal musical instrument used in gagaku.

Buddhism.name: En no Gyoja Reiseki Fudasho (a term relating to reijo sacred places)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/En no Gyoja Reiseki Fudasho (a term relating to reijo sacred places).html
Buddhism.desc: En no Gyoja Reiseki Fudasho indicates the pilgrimage of the thirty-six reijo (sacred places) in thirty-six temples and shrines, related to En no Gyoja who is said to have founded Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts).

Buddhism.name: Saigoku Aizen Junana Reijo (a term relating to reijo sacred places)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Saigoku Aizen Junana Reijo (a term relating to reijo sacred places).html
Buddhism.desc: Saigoku Aizen Junana Reijo is the comprehensive name for seventeen reijo (sacred places) that enshrine Aizen Myoo (Ragaraja) in Osaka, Hyogo, Okayama, Kyoto, Shiga, Mie, Nara, and Wakayama Prefectures.

Buddhism.name: Sokuikanjo
Buddhism.desc: Sokuikanjo is a ritual of Esoteric Buddhism conducted in an enthronement ceremony for the emperor from the 11th or 13th century up to the Edo period and its contents were treated as a secret ceremony.

Buddhism.name: Wesak Celebration
Buddhism.desc: Wesak is a Buddhist celebration conducted once a year. (Cambodia:Visaka Bochea,India, Bangladesh, Nepal: Visakah Puja, Buddha Purnima or Buddha Jayanti,Thailand: Visakha Bucha,Vietnam:Phật Đản,Indonesia:Waisak,Sri Lanka and Malaysia:Vesak (Wesak),Chinese language areas:fó dàn,Tibet:Saga Dawa,Laos:Vixakha Bouxa)

Buddhism.name: Ebusshi
Buddhism.desc: Ebusshi was a monk and specialist who was mainly engaged in the production of Buddhist paintings and coloring of statues.

Buddhism.name: Shoryodana (shelf with ancestral tablet and altarage in the Bon festival)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Shoryodana (shelf with ancestral tablet and altarage in the Bon festival).html
Buddhism.desc: Shoryodana is a shelf placed to welcome the ancestors and spirits in the Bon festival, which is a conventional event in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Mahayana Buddhism
Buddhism.desc: Mahayana Buddhism is a sect of Buddhism that has been traditionally practiced in central and eastern Eurasian Continent.

Buddhism.name: Fuke sect
Buddhism.desc: Fuke sect is a branch of Zen Buddhism in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Buddhism in Japan
Buddhism.desc: Buddhism in Japan

Buddhism.name: Sukuyodo (a type of astrology)
Buddhism.desc: The term "Sukuyodo" refers to a kind of astrology which was brought to Japan as a part of the Esoteric Buddhism by priests who studied abroad such as Kukai in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Engaku (縁覚: cause-awakened one)
Buddhism.desc: Engaku (pratyekabuddha, paccekabuddha, Sanskrit: प्रत्येक बुद्ध) is a term in Buddhism and Jainism, which means one who attains enlightenment through his own efforts without listening to the teachings of Buddha.

Buddhism.name: Kishimojin (Goddess of Children)
Buddhism.desc: Kishimojin' or 'Kishibojin' (haaritii in Sanskrit, Goddess of Children) is a yasha (yaksha in Sanskrit, Buddhist deity sometimes depicted as a demonic warrior) guarding Buddhism and a goddess.

Buddhism.name: Gongyo (the Nichirensho Sect)
Buddhism.desc: Gongyo is 'shojin' (virya, devotional exercises) of Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: The Nichiren Sect
Buddhism.desc: The Nichiren sect is a Buddhist sect founded by Nichiren in the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shakubuku
Buddhism.desc: Shakubuku is an abbreviation of hashaku-kupukku.

Buddhism.name: Kumano Gongen
Buddhism.desc: Kumano Gongen (also known as Kumano no Kami or Kumano no Okami) is a deity (Shinto) enshrined in Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-hongu-taisha Shrine, Kumano-hayatama-taisha Shrine and Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrine) and became to be called gongen (avatar) under Honji-suijaku thought (theory of original reality and manifested traces).

Buddhism.name: Kakuban
Buddhism.desc: Kakuban (July 27, 1095 - January 25, 1144) was a high priest of Shingon sect who was active in the late Heian period, and the restorer of the Shingon sect and the founder of Shingi Shingon sect.

Buddhism.name: Dosho
Buddhism.desc: Dosho (629 - April 3, 700) was a priest of the Hosso sect and he was born at Funenomuraji, Tajihi County, Kawachi Province (present Osaka Prefecture).

Buddhism.name: The Ji Sect
Buddhism.desc: The Ji sect is a sect of the Jodo sect which was established at the end of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Ippen
Buddhism.desc: Ippen was a priest in the mid Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Tannisho
Buddhism.desc: "Tannisho" (Notes Lamenting Deviations) is a Buddhist book written in the later Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Nanto Rokushu
Buddhism.desc: Nanto Rokushu' (also called 'Nanto Rikushu') is the general term of the six Buddhist sects which flourished mainly in Heijo-kyo (the capital of Japan in the Nara period) in the Nara period.

Buddhism.name: Koyasan Shingon Sect
Buddhism.desc: Koyasan Shingon sect is one of Shingon sect that was founded in the early Heian Period by Kobo Daishi (a posthumous title of the priest Kukai) who visited China and studied Esoteric Buddhism with Keika (also called Eka) in Qinglongsi Temple (in Xian City) in Changan (Xian City) during the Tang Dynasty (China).

Buddhism.name: Ganjin (Jianzhen)
Buddhism.desc: Ganjin (688-June 25, 763) was a naturalized priest in the Nara period.

Buddhism.name: Bato Kannon (horse-headed Kannon)
Buddhism.desc: Bato Kannon (horse-headed Kannon, also called Mezu Kannon), hayagriiva in Sanskrit, is one shape of Bosatsu (Bodhisattva) worshipped in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Fugen Enmei Bosatsu
Buddhism.desc: Fugen Enmei Bosatsu is one of Bosatsu worshiped in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Exclaustration
Buddhism.desc: Exclaustration means that a Buddhist monk quits the priesthood, which requires strict adherence to Buddhist precepts, and returns to secular life.

Buddhism.name: Enchin
Buddhism.desc: Enchin (814 to December 4, 891) was a monk of Tendai Sect in the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Tonan-in Temple (Nara City)
Buddhism.desc: Tonan-in Temple is the main temple of the Shingon Sect considered to have been located to the southeast of Todai-ji Temple (which is around the present Todaiji Library).

Buddhism.name: Chiko Mandala
Buddhism.desc: Chiko Mandala is the generic name for Jodo Mandalas made after the style of the Mandala which is said to have been envisioned by Chiko and has been preserved in Gango-ji Temple of Nara City

Buddhism.name: Jodo Sanmandala (Three Pure Land Mandalas)
Buddhism.desc: Jodo Sanmandala is a term representing the 3 leading types of compositions among the traditional Jodo Mandala (Pure Land Mandala) (or Jodo Henso-zu [Pictures of Amitabha's Paradise] to be precise) in Japan.

Buddhism.name: Tenkai
Buddhism.desc: Tenkai (1536 to November 13, 1643) was a monk of Tendai Sect in the Azuchi-momoyama period to the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Hosshinshu
Buddhism.desc: Hosshinshu (Tales of Awakening) is a collection of Buddhist tales compiled in the early Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Shigisan Shingon sect
Buddhism.desc: The Shigisan Shingon sect is a Shingon set that worships Bishamonten (Vaisravana; also called Tamonten) and its Grand Head Temple is Chogosonshi-ji Temple (Shigisan-ji Temple).

Buddhism.name: Keitokudentoroku (books of the genealogy of Zen Buddhism, consisting of biographies of priests in India and China)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Keitokudentoroku (books of the genealogy of Zen Buddhism, consisting of biographies of priests in In.html
Buddhism.desc: Compiled by Dogen in the Baisong Dynasty era in China, Keitokudentoroku (written 景徳傳燈録 or 景徳伝灯録 in the modern kanji, 30 volumes) is a history book representative of the Zen sect.

Buddhism.name: Goshiki Fudo
Buddhism.desc: The five types (Meguro, Mejiro, Meaka, Meao and Meki) of Fudo-son (Acalanatha) located at six different sites including Ryusen-ji Temple (Meguro), Konjo-in Temple (in Toshima Ward) (Mejiro), Saisho-ji Temple (Meki), Nankoku-ji Temple (Meaka) and Saisho-ji Temple (in Setagaya Ward) (Meao) as well as another Meki (yellow eye) in Tokyo are collectively referred to as Goshiki Fudo.

Buddhism.name: Toshi (historiography)
Buddhism.desc: Toshi is a term generally used to represent history books of the Buddhism, specifically, that of the Zen Sect.

Buddhism.name: Nicchin
Buddhism.desc: Nicchin (1469 to June 24, 1527 (old lunar calendar)) was the 12th head priest of Taiseki-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Nisshu
Buddhism.desc: Nisshu (January 8, 1556 to September 16, 1617) was the 14th head priest of Taiseki-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Nissho
Buddhism.desc: Nissho (1562 to May 17, 1622) was the 15th head priest of Taiseki-ji Temple.

Buddhism.name: Tachikawa-ryu school (a school of Esoteric Buddhism founded by Ninkan)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Tachikawa-ryu school (a school of Esoteric Buddhism founded by Ninkan).html
Buddhism.desc: The Tachikawa-ryu school is a school of Esoteric Buddhism founded by Ninkan in the Kamakura period and perfected by Monkan in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Zenji (Zen Master)
Buddhism.desc: Zenji is an honorific title for venerable Zen monks used in China and Japan.

Buddhism.name: Goto Egen (historical records of Chinese zen masters)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Goto Egen (historical records of Chinese zen masters).html
Buddhism.desc: Goto Egen is a toshi (historiography) of the Zen Sect established in the Southern Song Dynasty period of China.

Buddhism.name: Sugyoroku (Record of the Mirror of the Essential Teaching)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Sugyoroku (Record of the Mirror of the Essential Teaching).html
Buddhism.desc: Sugyoroku is a book of the Buddhism theory compiled in 100 volumes by Enju EIMIN, the monk who lived during the times between Wu-yueh in the Chinese Godai Jikkoku era and early Northern Sung Dynasty period.

Buddhism.name: Zengen Shosenshu Tojo (Commentary of the Ch'an-yuan-chu-ch'uan-chi tu-hsu)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Zengen Shosenshu Tojo (Commentary of the Chan-yuan-chu-chuan-chi tu-hsu).html
Buddhism.desc: Zengen Shosenshu Tojo is the preface 'Tojo' of "Zengen Shosenshu" (lost book), a collection of words and geju (hymns in honor of doctrine, Buddha and bodhisattva) used by various schools of Zen, compiled by Shumitsu KEIHO who was a monk in the Tang Dynasty period in China and only this part remains in existence today.

Buddhism.name: Horinden
Buddhism.desc: Horinden is the abbreviated name for Daito Shoshu Sohonzan Sokokei Horinden, a historical account of Zen Buddhism that was established in 801.

Buddhism.name: Tomitsu
Buddhism.desc: Tomitsu is Esoteric Buddhism that has been passed down in Shingon Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Juo (10 Kings; 10 judges of the hell)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Juo (10 Kings; 10 judges of the hell).html
Buddhism.desc: Juo are the 10 judges of the hell (Buddhism).

Buddhism.name: Daichi
Buddhism.desc: Daichi (1290 - January 18, 1367) was a Buddhist priest of the Sotoshu sect from the late Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Ensai
Buddhism.desc: Ensai (year of birth unknown – 877) was a priest of the Tendaishu sect of the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Kongosho (Vajra; a ritual implements in Exoteric Buddhism and Tibetan Buddhism)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Kongosho (Vajra; a ritual implements in Exoteric Buddhism and Tibetan Buddhism).html
Buddhism.desc: Kogosho, vajra in Sanskrit, is a ritual object in Esoteric Buddhism and Tibetan Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Myoitsu
Buddhism.desc: Myoitsu (728 - April 21, 798) was a Buddhist monk from the Nara period to the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Shingyo
Buddhism.desc: Shingyo (935 - December 7, 1004) was a Buddhist monk of the Hosso and Shingon sects during the middle Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Genjo (also known as Gensei)
Buddhism.desc: Genjo, or Gensei (1303 - January 12, 1359) was a military commander and a Buddhist monk in Tendai sect during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Nyoho
Buddhism.desc: Nyoho (731 - February 19, 815) was a Ritsu sect monk from China through the Nara period to the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Ryoken
Buddhism.desc: Ryoken (1611 - April 18, 1687) was a Shingishingon sect monk during the early Edo period.

Buddhism.name: Dosho
Buddhism.desc: Dosho (April 2, 798 - March 20, 875) was a Buddhist monk during the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Dosen
Buddhism.desc: Dosen (ca. 797 - ca. April 2, 873) was a Sanron sect Buddhist monk during the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: MINAMOTO no Kiyomitsu
Buddhism.desc: MINAMOTO no Kiyomitsu was a warrior in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Meihosotetsu
Buddhism.desc: Meihosotetsu (1277 - May 5, 1350) was a Soto sect Buddhist monk from the late Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Joe
Buddhism.desc: Joe (writes; 定恵) (643 - Feb. 2, 666) was a scholar monk in the Asuka period.

Buddhism.name: Ryochu
Buddhism.desc: Ryochu (August 20, 1199 - August 16, 1287) was a Jodo sect Buddhist monk during the middle of the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Daikaku
Buddhism.desc: Daikaku (1297 - May 5, 1364) was a Nichiren sect Buddhist monk during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Docho (Certificate of entering the priesthood)
Buddhism.desc: Docho is an identification card issued by a state organization to a priest or a nun who has newly entered the priesthood, in the system of entrance into the priesthood that is officially recognized by the state.

Buddhism.name: Tsugenjakurei
Buddhism.desc: Tsugenjakurei (1322 - June 7, 1391) was a Soto sect Buddhist monk during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Kohokakumyo
Buddhism.desc: Kohokakumyo (1271 - June 27, 1361) was a Rinzai sect Buddhist monk from the late Kamakura period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Joan
Buddhism.desc: Joan (790 - March 25, 844) was a Hosso sect Buddhist monk during the early Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Bodai Senna (Bodhisena)
Buddhism.desc: Bodai Senna (Bodhisena, 704-760) was a priest from a foreign country in the Nara period.

Buddhism.name: Buttetsu
Buddhism.desc: Buttetsu (year of birth and death are unkown) was a priest from a foreign country in the Nara period.

Buddhism.name: Ryuzen
Buddhism.desc: Ryuzen (1038 - August 21, 1100) was a Hosso sect Buddhist monk in the late Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Koho
Buddhism.desc: Koho (1306 - July 28, 1362) was a Shingon sect scholar-monk during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

Buddhism.name: Omi Saigoku Sanjusankasho
Buddhism.desc: Omi Saigoku Sanjusankasho (the 33 temples in Omi Province of Saigoku [provinces in Kinki region]) refers to 33 sacred places enshrining Kannon for pilgrimage and are located in present Shiga Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Shotoku sect
Buddhism.desc: Shotoku sect is one of Japanese Buddhism sect for which Horyu-ji Temple in Ikaruga-cho, Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture is Sohonzan (Grand Head temple).

Buddhism.name: Chuin School
Buddhism.desc: Chuin School is one of the sects of the Shingon Buddhism (Tomitsu) that places emphasis on jiso (one of Buddhism practical trainings).

Buddhism.name: Kamakura Bukkyo
Buddhism.desc: Kamakura Bukkyo (Kamakura Buddhism) refers to the movement for Buddhist reform developed from the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura Period.

Buddhism.name: Azuchi Shuron
Buddhism.desc: Azuchi Shuron was a religious debate waged between the Jodoshu sect and the Hokkeshu sect (Nichirenshu sect) at Jogon-in Temple in the town of Azuchi-jo Castle.

Buddhism.name: Renjun
Buddhism.desc: Renjun (1464 - October 8, 1550) was a priest in the Muromachi period and the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

Buddhism.name: Imperial Inscription
Buddhism.desc: The tem "imperial inscription" ('chokugaku' in Japanese) refers to inscriptions at temples which were written by rulers such as the emperor and typically given to temples throughout the country.

Buddhism.name: Magaibutsu (Buddha statues in cliffs and rocks)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Magaibutsu (Buddha statues in cliffs and rocks).html
Buddhism.desc: The term "Magaibutsu" refers to Buddha statues which were carved into the natural rock face or bare rock or the rock scattered on mountains including an alcove of rock face.

Buddhism.name: Ashura
Buddhism.desc: Ashura (the transcription of asura in Sanskrit with the meaning of non-heaven) is a guardian god of Hachi Bushu (or Eight Legions, Protectors of Buddhist Teachings) in Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Kuden (Zushi)
Buddhism.desc: Kuden is a kind of Buddhist altar case called 'Zushi' to contain a Buddhist object of worship such as a Buddhist statute, an image of patriarch, or the like.

Buddhism.name: Joyo
Buddhism.desc: Joyo (958 - 1047) was a Shingon sect Buddhist monk during the latter half of the Heian period.

Buddhism.name: Nijuyohai
Buddhism.desc: Nijuyohai refers to the 24 top disciples of the Buddhist monk Shinran when he propagated the Buddhist faith in the Kanto region, as well as the temples worshiping these disciples as founders.

Buddhism.name: Sanno Shinko
Buddhism.desc: Sanno Shinko is a belief of Shinto originated from Hiyoshi Taisha shrine at the foot of Mt. Hiei (Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).

Buddhism.name: Rengo
Buddhism.desc: Rengo (1468 - August 26, 1543) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) over the middle of the Muromachi period and the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Renko
Buddhism.desc: Renko (1450 - December 6, 1531) was a priest of Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) from the mid Muromachi period to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Bando-bushi (an event in the Otani school of the Shinshu Sect)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Bando-bushi (an event in the Otani school of the Shinshu Sect).html
Buddhism.desc: Bando-bushi is an event taking place at Buddhist memorial services and Hoon-ko (memorial services for Shinran) in the Otani school of the Shinshu Sect.

Buddhism.name: Ikkoshu
Buddhism.desc: Ikkoshu is a Buddhist sect founded by Ikko Shunsho, a Jodoshu sect monk during the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Danrin
Buddhism.desc: Danrin was a training facility for monks in a Buddhist temple, i.e., a school of a Buddhist sect.

Buddhism.name: Nagahama Biwako Daibutsu
Buddhism.desc: Nagahama Biwako Daibutsu (Great Buddha of Nagahama Biwako) is the statue of Buddha in Ryochu-ji Temple on Mt. Heian in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Shijokobuccho
Buddhism.desc: Shijokobuccho, prajvalosniisa in Sanskrit, is a kind of Buddha that is a deified protuberance on the top of the skull of a Nyorai (tathagata), i.e., a form of usniisa.

Buddhism.name: Kaiso
Buddhism.desc: Kaiso means to found a temple.

Buddhism.name: Butsugenbutsumo
Buddhism.desc: Butsugenbutsumo, buddhalocanii in Sanskrit, is a form of Buddha that is worshiped in Buddhism, especially in esoteric Buddhism.

Buddhism.name: Shusseken
Buddhism.desc: "Shusseken" means something transcends "Seken," which refers to all the existence of the world corrupted by evils such as earthly desires.

Buddhism.name: Shozan
Buddhism.desc: Shozan means the rank of temple 'Zenrin', temples of the Zen sect in Japan, which is under the ranks of 'Gozan' and 'Jussatsu.'

Buddhism.name: Nichiga
Buddhism.desc: Nichiga (1508 - December 21, 1586) was a Buddhist monk of Hokkeshu sect during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Kudara Kannon (wooden statue of Kannon Bosatsu [Buddhist Goddess of Mercy])
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Kudara Kannon (wooden statue of Kannon Bosatsu [Buddhist Goddess of Mercy]).html
Buddhism.desc: Kudara Kannon is a wooden statue of Kannon Bosatsu (Buddhist Goddess of Mercy) which was made during the Asuka period (from the mid until the late seventh century) and is owned by Horyu-ji Temple in Ikaruga-cho, Nara Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Ukimi-do
Buddhism.desc: Ukimi-do is a Buddhist temple of the Kaimonzan Mangetsu-ji Temple, which belongs to the Rinzai sect Daitokuji school, and it is located on a pier extending out into Lake Biwa at katata, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Rishu-kyo (Principle of Wisdom Sutra)
Buddhism.desc: "Rishu-kyo" is the Buddhist scriptures of Esoteric Buddhism, which is Part Six of 'Kongocho-kyo' (Vajrasekhara Sutra).

Buddhism.name: Kongobutsushi Eison Kanjingakushoki
Buddhism.jp: 金剛仏子叡尊感身学正記
Buddhism.desc: Kongobutsushi Eison Kanjingakushoki is an autobiography of Eison, a Buddhist monk who founded the Shingon Ritsu sect in the Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Junyoze (Buddhism Ten Factors of Life)
Buddhism.desc: Junyoze (Buddhism Ten Factors of Life) is the principle of causality which is expounded in the Chapter of Expedient Means of "the Lotus Sutra".

Buddhism.name: Murals in the Kondo (Golden Hall) of Horyu-ji Temple
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Murals in the Kondo (Golden Hall) of Horyu-ji Temple.html
Buddhism.desc: The murals in the Kondo of Horyu-ji Temple are Buddhist paintings around the late seventh century, which were painted on the walls of the Kondo of the Horyu-ji Temple in Ikaruga Town, Nara Prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Official introduction of Buddhism
Buddhism.desc: The expression "Official introduction of Buddhism" refers to the introduction of Buddhism through official negotiation between nations.

Buddhism.name: Shinku (Shingon Ritsushu sect)
Buddhism.desc: Shinku (1231 - February 28, 1316) was a Buddhist monk of the Shingon Ritsushu sect in the late Kamakura period.

Buddhism.name: Tenjikugoshoja
Buddhism.desc: Tenjikugoshoja is five vihara (monasteries or temples) of early Buddhism in the ancient India.

Buddhism.name: Makashikan (Mahayana Practice of Cessation and Contemplation)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Makashikan (Mahayana Practice of Cessation and Contemplation).html
Buddhism.desc: Makashikan (Mahayana Practice of Cessation and Contemplation), one of the textbooks on Buddhism, is a commentary on Shikan (a type of meditation).

Buddhism.name: The Koshu Sect
Buddhism.desc: The Koshu sect (Hongzhou-zong) was a sect of the Zen sect (Chan-zong) in the Tang Dynasty.

Buddhism.name: Seijun
Buddhism.desc: Seijun (year of birth unknown - May 2, 1566) was a nun of the Rinzaishu sect in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

Buddhism.name: Soshiki-Bukkyo
Buddhism.desc: Soshiki-Bukkyo' (literally, 'funeral Buddhism') refers to a way of belief in which people conduct Buddhist funerals and Buddhist memorial services while being rarely involved in Buddhist activities and in Buddhist doctrines in their daily lives.

Buddhism.name: Kushibussho [classic Zen koan (small presentations of the nature of ultimate reality, usually presented as a paradox)]
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Kushibussho [classic Zen koan (small presentations of the nature of ultimate reality, usually presen.html
Buddhism.desc: Kushibussho is one of the representatives of Zen koans.

Buddhism.name: Sekishu no koe (The voice of one hand clapping)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Sekishu no koe (The voice of one hand clapping).html
Buddhism.desc: Sekishu no koe' or sekishuonjo (The sound of the one hand) was one of the representative Koans of Zen, invented by Hakuin.

Buddhism.name: Honen Shonin nijugo reijo (25 sacred grounds of Honen Shonin)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Honen Shonin nijugo reijo (25 sacred grounds of Honen Shonin).html
Buddhism.desc: Honen Shonin Nijugo reijo (25 sacred ground of Honen Shonin) is circuit pilgrimage to 25 temples which are related to Honen Shonin, the founder of the Pure Land sect.

Buddhism.name: Muryoju-kyo Ubataisha Ganshoge (the Verses on the Aspiration to Be Born in the Pure Land)
Buddhism.jp: 無量寿経優婆提舎願生偈
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Muryoju-kyo Ubataisha Ganshoge (the Verses on the Aspiration to Be Born in the Pure Land).html
Buddhism.desc: "Muryoju-kyo Ubataisha Ganshoge" is a commentary on "Muryoju-kyo Bussetu Muryoju-kyo (the Sutra on the Buddha of Immeasurable Life)" compiled by Seshin, which was translated into Chinese by Bodhiruci in the Northern Wei dynasty.

Buddhism.name: Muryoju-kyo Ubadaisha Ganshogechu (the Commentary on Verses on the Aspiration to Be Born in the Pure Land)
Buddhism.jp: 無量寿経優婆提舎願生偈註
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Muryoju-kyo Ubadaisha Ganshogechu (the Commentary on Verses on the Aspiration to Be Born in the Pure.html
Buddhism.desc: Muryoju-kyo Ubadaisha Ganshogechu (the Commentary on Verses on the Aspiration to Be Born in the Pure Land) was compiled by Tanluan, a Buddhist monk in the Northern Wei dynasty (China).

Buddhism.name: Honganji Shonin Denne (Buddhist picture scrolls painted about the life of Shinran)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Honganji Shonin Denne (Buddhist picture scrolls painted about the life of Shinran).html
Buddhism.desc: Honganji Shonin Denne is a Buddhist scroll which illustrates the life of Shinran, the founder of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) with narration.

Buddhism.name: Kanmuryojukyosho (Commentaries on Meditation Sutra)
Buddhism.desc: "Kanmuryojukyosho" is a commentary written by Shandao of China.

Buddhism.name: Senchaku hongan nenbutsu shu (A Collection of Passages on the Nembutsu Chosen in the Original Vow)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Senchaku hongan nenbutsu shu (A Collection of Passages on the Nembutsu Chosen in the Original Vow).html
Buddhism.desc: "Senchaku hongan nenbutsu shu" is a treatise in two volumes comprising sixteen chapters written by Honen in 1198 on the request from Kanezane KUJO, who was a Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor).

Buddhism.name: Hyakuman-to Tower [also know as Hyakumanto Darani (The one million pagodas and Dharani prayers)]
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Hyakuman-to Tower [also know as Hyakumanto Darani (The one million pagodas and Dharani prayers)].html
Buddhism.desc: The Hyakuman-to Towers were produced in the late Nara period at the wish of Emperor Shotoku.

Buddhism.name: Kuhon (Kyuhin)
Buddhism.desc: Kuhon (Kyuhin) refers to a three-way classification of things and people's characters and each classification is divided into further three categories.

Buddhism.name: The Seated Statue of the Rushana-butsu (the Birushana Buddha) in the Todai-ji Temple
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/The Seated Statue of the Rushana-butsu (the Birushana Buddha) in the Todai-ji Temple.html
Buddhism.desc: The seated statue of the Rushana-butsu in the Todai-ji Temple is a Buddha statue generally known as the 'Great Buddha of Nara.'

Buddhism.name: Kaido
Buddhism.desc: Kaido (1751 to 1810) was a gakuso (scholar monk) of the Shingon sect Buzan school of the Shingi Shingon sect, who made a great contribution to bibliography.

Buddhism.name: Jujubibasharon (the Discourse on the Ten Stages)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Jujubibasharon (the Discourse on the Ten Stages).html
Buddhism.desc: "Jujubibasharon" is a treatise on Buddhism in 17 volumes.

Buddhism.name: Yakushiji Kichijoten zo (the Statue of Kichijoten at Yakushi-ji Temple)
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Yakushiji Kichijoten zo (the Statue of Kichijoten at Yakushi-ji Temple).html
Buddhism.desc: Yakushiji Kichijoten zo is a portrait of Kisshoten (Laksmi) from the Nara period and is a possession of the Yakushi-ji Temple in Nara prefecture.

Buddhism.name: Koryo (a moderately carved beam like a rainbow) of Daibutsu-den Hall (the Great Buddha hall) of Todai-ji Temple
Buddhism.url: Buddhism/Koryo (a moderately carved beam like a rainbow) of Daibutsu-den Hall (the Great Buddha hall) of Toda.html
Buddhism.desc: Two 23.5 meter-long beams of Japanese red pine are used to support the roof of Daibutsu-den Hall of Todai-ji Temple; these two beams were carried from the Shiratori Shrine of Hyuga Province (Ebino city) to Todai-ji Temple of Yamato Province by several hundred thousand people in 1704, and it took them nine months.

Buddhism.name: NENAMI Jion
Buddhism.desc: Jion NENNAMI (dates of birth and death unknown) was a swordsman and Zen monk in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) and the Muromachi period.

Buddhism.name: FURUICHI Ine
Buddhism.desc: Ine FURUICHI (year of birth unknown - 1505) is a priest and a Japanese military commander during the Sengoku period.

Buddhism.name: Busso Rekidai Tsusai
Buddhism.desc: "Busso Rekidai Tsusai" is a chronicle of Buddhism history from the ancient times to the year 1333, which was compiled in China.

building.name: Nijo-jo Castle
building.desc: Japanese Castle Data Sheet

building.name: Fushimi-jo Castle
building.desc: Fushimi-jo Castle was a castle in what is now Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.

building.name: Jurakudai
building.desc: Jurakudai (or Jurakutei) was a large residence built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in Uchino, Kyoto (the site of the Outer Palace Precincts in Heiankyo, present-day Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City) during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

building.name: Umekoji Steam Locomotive Museum
building.desc: The Umekoji Steam Locomotive Museum is a preservation and display facility for steam locomotives, operated by West Japan Railway Company (JR West Japan), located in Kankiji-cho, Shimogyo-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Kyoto Gosho (Kyoto Imperial Palace)
building.desc: Kyoto Gosho is an imperial palace located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: National Diet Library (NDL)
building.desc: The National Diet Library (NDL) provides services for members of Japan's Diet in their research and study, as well as the executive agencies of the government and the general public in Japan.

building.name: Kansai-kan of the National Diet Library
building.jp: 国立国会図書館関西館
building.url: building/Kansai-kan of the National Diet Library.html
building.desc: The Kansai-kan, as the Kansai Main Library of the National Diet Library (NDL), is located in Seika-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Mausoleum
building.desc: Mausoleum (Byo, Mitamaya, Otamaya, Hokora)

building.name: Buddha's sariras
building.desc: Buddha's sariras refer to the cremated ashes of Buddha's bones as well as the remains of the coffin and altar that were used for the cremation of Buddha when he passed away.

building.name: Garan
building.desc: Garan (伽藍) means a purified place where Buddhist monks gather and practice the religion, but eventually the term came to mean Buddhist temple or the group of buildings that forms the heart of a temple.

building.name: The Bank of Kyoto, Ltd.
building.desc: The Bank of Kyoto, Ltd., with its head office located in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, does business in Kyoto Prefecture, and neighboring areas as a regional bank.

building.name: Tanabe-jo Castle (Tango Province)
building.desc: Tanabe-jo Castle, located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture, was build between Sengoku Period and Edo Period.

building.name: Sumiya
building.desc: Sumiya was originally an ageya of Shimabara Yukaku (red-light district).

building.name: Maizuru Repatriation Memorial Museum
building.desc: The Maizuru Repatriation Memorial Museum is a facility for preservation of historical artifacts and tradition in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture

building.name: Kyoto National Museum
building.desc: The Kyoto National Museum is run by the National Institutes for Cultural Heritage.

building.name: Kyoto Prefectural Insho-Domoto Museum of Fine Arts
building.jp: 京都府立堂本印象美術館
building.url: building/Kyoto Prefectural Insho-Domoto Museum of Fine Arts.html
building.desc: The Kyoto Prefectural Insho-Domoto Museum of Fine Arts is an art museum in Kita Ward, Kyoto City.

building.name: Yurinkan Museum
building.desc: The Yurinkan Museum, located in Okazaki, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a private facility that is mainly dedicated to ancient Chinese art works.

building.name: The National Museum of Modern Art, Kyoto (MOMAK)
building.url: building/The National Museum of Modern Art, Kyoto (MOMAK).html
building.desc: Located in Okazaki-koen Park, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, The National Museum of Modern Art, Kyoto (MOMAK), is an art museum operated by the Independent Administrative Institution National Museum of Art.

building.name: Kitamura Museum
building.desc: Kitamura Museum is a private art museum mainly devoted to antiquities and tea utensils, located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

building.name: Hosomi Museum
building.desc: Hosomi Museum is a private art museum mainly devoted to Japanese antiquities, located in Okazaki, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

building.name: Ote-Mon Gate
building.desc: An ote-mon gate is a gate constructed at the most important entrance of a Japanese castle that leads to kuruwa (walls of a castle) such as a ninomaru (second bailey) and a sannomaru (outer part of the castle).

building.name: Registered Tangible Cultural Properties
building.desc: Registered Tangible Cultural Properties are the tangible cultural properties that are registered in the book of registration at the Agency for Cultural Affairs, in accordance with the registration system for cultural properties established under the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties amended in 1996.

building.name: Sanjo-ohashi Bridge
building.desc: Sanjo-ohashi Bridge is on Sanjo-dori Street in Kyoto City.

building.name: Kyoto International Conference Center
building.desc: Kyoto International Conference Center is an international conference hall located in Takaragaike, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

building.name: Kameyama-koen Park
building.desc: Kameyama-koen Park is located in Sagakamenoo-cho Town, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.

building.name: Shinden-zukuri
building.desc: Shinden-zukuri is a style of architecture used in aristocratic mansions in the Heian period.

building.name: Sukiya-zukuri
building.desc: Sukiya-zukuri is one of the Japanese architectural styles, and is characterized as a design of residential house in a sukiya (teahouse) style.

building.name: Shoin-zukuri
building.desc: Shoin-zukuri is one of the Japanese residential architectural styles which were established after the middle of the Muromachi Period.

building.name: Shoryuji-jo Castle
building.desc: Shoryuji-jo Castle was a castle that existed in Nagaokakyo City, Kyoto Prefecture between the the Northern and Southern Court and early Edo periods.

building.name: Minka (folk dwellings)
building.desc: Minka are residences where ordinary people lived.

building.name: The World Brick Museum
building.desc: The World Brick Museum is a museum in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture that collects and exhibits bricks to show a wide variety of their features.

building.name: Biwako Sosui (Lake Biwa Canal)
building.desc: Biwako Sokui (琵琶湖疏水) or Lake Biwa Canal (since 疏 is not included in the national list of Chinese characters in common use, 疎 is also used as in 琵琶湖疎水) is a waterway that was built to transport water from Lake Biwa to Kyoto City.

building.name: Kyoto Tower
building.desc: Kyoto Tower is an observation tower which soars distinctively above the Karasuma central exit of Kyoto Station.

building.name: Kameoka Sports Park
building.desc: Kameoka Sports Park is a park in Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture that has a sports complex.

building.name: Geihin-kan (State Guest House)
building.desc: The Geihin-kan (State Guest House) is a facility in which the government accommodates visiting state guests, such as heads of state or ministers.

building.name: Gojo-ohashi Bridge
building.desc: Gojo-ohashi Bridge is a bridge over the Kamo-gawa River which runs through Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Kiroku Shoen Kenkeijo (Office for the Investigation of Estate Documents)
building.url: building/Kiroku Shoen Kenkeijo (Office for the Investigation of Estate Documents).html
building.desc: Kiroku Shoen Kenkeijo was an organization which investigated manors (shoen) in the Heian period.

building.name: PLAZA KEIHANNA
building.desc: KEIHANNA PLAZA is a central facility at Kansai Science City (Keihanna Science City) in Hikaridai, Seika-cho, Soraku-gun, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Keihanna Plaza Hotel
building.jp: けいはんなプラザホテル
building.desc: Keihanna Plaza Hotel is an accommodation facility within Keihanna Plaza which is the central intersecting facility of Kansai Science City.

building.name: Shokado
building.desc: Located in Yawata City, Kyoto Prefecture, Shokado houses a Japanese garden and an art museum.

building.name: Hidenin Temple
building.desc: Based on the spirit of mercy of Buddhism, Hidenin Temple was built for the salvation of the poor and orphans.

building.name: Ryokan (Japanese-style inns)
building.desc: A ryokan is a guest house that accommodates visitors for a fee, usually in a Japanese style building with traditional furnishings.

building.name: Toei Movie Land
building.desc: Toei Movie Land is a movie theme park located in Uzumasa Higashi Hachigaoka-cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.

building.name: Yodo-jo Castle
building.desc: Yodo-jo Castle was a castle which used to be in present Fushimi Ward in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Hamaguri-Gomon Gate
building.desc: The Hamaguri-Gomon Gate is one of the west gates of Kyoto Gyoen National Garden.

building.name: Chashitsu (tea-ceremony room)
building.desc: "Chashitsu" is a facility built for a tea ceremony host (shujin) to invite and entertain guests with tea.

building.name: Goro Sky Tower
building.desc: Goro Sky Tower is an observation tower located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Rajomon
building.desc: A rajomon was a city gate built at the south end of Suzaku-oji Street (a main street) which ran north and south through the center of ancient jobo (grid-like arrangement of streets and avenues) cities such as Heijo-kyo or Heian-kyo.

building.name: Mimizuka (Ear Mound)
building.desc: Mimizuka is a tomb mound that was made to bury and pay respects to severed ears and noses of dead soldiers of the Korean (Joseon) and Chinese (Ming) armies in the Bunroku-Keicho War (wars initiated by the invasion of the Korean Peninsula by Hideyoshi's army in 1592 through to 1598).

building.name: Nihon no Oni no Koryu Museum (Japanese Oni Museum)
building.jp: 日本の鬼の交流博物館
building.url: building/Nihon no Oni no Koryu Museum (Japanese Oni Museum).html
building.desc: Nihon no Oni no Koryu Museum (日本の鬼の交流博物館) (Japanese Oni Museum) is a museum featuring Oni (demon) legends, and is located at the foot of Mt.Oe in Fukuchiyama City (former Oe-cho, Kasa-gun), Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Miyazu-jo Castle
building.desc: Miyazu-jo Castle is located in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Shisendo
building.desc: Shisendo is a National Historic Site located in Sakyo Ward in Kyoto City.

building.name: Gi-yofu architecture (imitative Western-style architecture)
building.desc: "Gi-yofu architecture" is an architectural style that Japanese carpenters created by imitating Western-style architecture.

building.name: Maizuru Shinkai Park (Maizuru Sea Park)
building.desc: Maizuru Shinkai Park (Maizuru Sea Park) is a park in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Takebeyama-jo Castle
building.desc: Takebeyama-jo Castle existed in Kasa County, Tango Province (now Shimofukui, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture) during the Muromachi and Sengoku periods (period of warring states).

building.name: Maizuru Port Toretore Center
building.jp: 舞鶴港とれとれセンター
building.desc: Located in Maizuru City in Kyoto Prefecture, Maizuru Port Toretore Center is a tourist facility that sells fish and seafood from Maizuru Port and local products from the Tango area.

building.name: The Kyoto Botanical Garden
building.desc: The Kyoto Prefectural Botanical Garden is located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

building.name: Giboshi (ornamental railing top, and flower name)
building.url: building/Giboshi (ornamental railing top, and flower name).html
building.desc: A giboshi or giboshu is: 1) an ornament that is attached to balustrades of bridges, temples or shrines and whose shape resembles that of item 2.

building.name: The Botanical Garden for Increasing Plants in Urban Areas in Fukuchiyama City
building.jp: 福知山市都市緑化植物園
building.url: building/The Botanical Garden for Increasing Plants in Urban Areas in Fukuchiyama City.html
building.desc: The Botanical Garden for Increasing Plants in Urban Areas in Fukuchiyama City, nicknamed "Sumoru-tera" (the Japanese pronunciation of 'Small Terra' or small Earth) is a botanical garden located in Sandan-ike Pond Park in Fukuchiyama City.

building.name: Navy Memorial Museum
building.desc: The Navy Memorial Museum is an exhibition facility located in Maizuru District Headquarters in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Kanzaki Seaside Resort
building.desc: Located on the coast facing the Sea of Japan in Maizuru City in Kyoto Prefecture, Kanzaki Seaside Resort is blessed with scenic beauty.

building.name: Tomb of Anjuhime
building.desc: Anjuhime is well known from Ogai MORI's novel 'Sanshodayu,' and she rests in the Tomb of Anjuhime.

building.name: Ryuguhama Seaside Resort
building.desc: Ryuguhama Kaisui Yokujo (Ryuguhama Seaside Resort) is a seaside resort facing the Sea of Japan, located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Nohara Seaside Resort
building.desc: Nohara Kaisui Yokujo (Nohara Seaside Resort) is a seaside resort facing the Sea of Japan, located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Wakasa Bay Quasi-National Park
building.desc: Wakasa Bay Quasi-National Park was designated as covering an area which includes the coastline around Wakasa Bay from the left bank of the mouth of the Shono-kawa River in Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture, to the right bank of the mouth of the Yura-gawa River in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Buke Yashiki
building.desc: A "Buke Yashiki" is typically a mansion which a daimyo (provincial lord) kept in Edo as a second house and as a branch office in the Edo period.

building.name: Red Brick Warehouses
building.desc: The "Red Brick Warehouses" are 12 red brick warehouses located at the former headquarters of the Maizuru Navy Ordnance Corps (舞鶴海軍軍需部本部地区) (now Maizuru Port Waterfront) in Maizuru city, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Kyoto Municipal Museum of Art
building.desc: Kyoto Municipal Museum of Art is an art museum located at Okazaki-koen Park in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Kyoto Municipal Central Wholesale Market
building.jp: 京都市中央卸売市場第一市場
building.desc: Located in 80, Sujakubunki-cho, Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, Kyoto Municipal Central Wholesale Market covers an area of 149,509 square meters.

building.name: Jotenkaku Museum
building.desc: Jotenkaku Museum is an art museum located in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Kachuan Seiho Takeuchi Memorial Museum(霞中庵 竹内栖鳳記念館)
building.jp: 霞中庵 竹内栖鳳記念館
building.url: building/Kachuan Seiho Takeuchi Memorial Museum(霞中庵 竹内栖鳳記念館).html
building.desc: Kachuan Seiho Takeuchi Memorial Museum is an art museum located in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Maizuru Nature Cultural Park
building.desc: Maizuru Nature Cultural Park is a park with 30,000 camellias of approximately 1500 varieties and 50,000 hydrangeas of 50 kinds.

building.name: Jingu Shikinen Sengu
building.desc: Jingu Shikinen Sengu is the Shikinen Sengu (transfer of a deity to a new shrine building once in a prescribed number of years) at Jingu (Ise-Jingu Shrine).

building.name: Higashi Maizuru Park
building.desc: Higashi Maizuru Park is located in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Maruyama-koen Park
building.desc: Maruyama-koen is a park located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Kyoto-Gekijo (Kyoto Theater)
building.desc: Kyoto-Gekijo is a theater located in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Kozuya-bashi Bridge
building.desc: Kozuya-bashi Bridge is a bridge over the Kizu-gawa River connecting Kumiyama-cho, Kuse-gun, Kyoto Prefecture and Yawata City.

building.name: Tango Yura Beach
building.desc: Tango Yura Beach is located in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture.

building.name: Taira-sanbashi Bridge
building.desc: Taira-sanbashi is a landing bridge at Maizuru Port.

building.name: Takaragaike-koen Park

building.desc: Taga Steam Locomotive (SL) Park was at one time the SL Hotel that was located at Binmanji, Taga-cho, Inukami-gun, Saga Prefecture.

building.name: Nara Prefectural Museum of Folklore
building.desc: Nara Prefectural Museum of Folklore is a museum located in Yata-cho, Yamatokoriyama City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Shitenno-ji Temple Building Layout
building.desc: The Shitenno-ji Temple building layout (Shitenno-ji shiki garan haichi in Japanese) is one of the representative styles of temple building layout in the Asuka period.

building.name: Azuchi Castle Tenshu Nobunaga no Yakata Museum
building.url: building/Azuchi Castle Tenshu Nobunaga no Yakata Museum.html
building.desc: The Azuchi Castle Tenshu Nobunaga no Yakata Museum is a facility located in Azuchi-cho, Gamo-gun, Shiga Prefecture.

building.name: Hasamiyama Remains
building.desc: Located in Fujiidera City, Osaka Prefecture, the Hasamiyama Remains are compound remains where remains and relics in various periods from the Paleolithic period (in Japan) to the early-modern times have been found.

building.name: Kitayama Juhachi Kento
building.desc: Kitayama Juhachi Kento was a welfare facility that was constructed in Nara Kitamachi in the Kamakura period for protecting and aiding persons in serious illness, such as Hansen's disease.

building.name: The Grave of OHARIDA no Yasumaro
building.url: building/The Grave of OHARIDA no Yasumaro.html
building.desc: Found in Koka, Tsuge-mura Village, Nara Prefecture (present Tsugekoka-cho, Nara City), the grave of OHARIDA no Yasumaro was for cremated remains of OHARIDA no Ason Yasumaro who was a government officer in the Nara period, and was designated as a national historical sit (on November 29, 1969).

building.name: Samida Takarazuka Tumulus
building.desc: Samida Takarazuka Tumulus is a keyhole-shaped mound built in the latter half of the earlier Kofun period (tumulus period); it is located in Kawai-cho, Kitakatsuragi-gun, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Tenri Municipal Kurozuka Tumulus Museum
building.jp: 天理市立黒塚古墳展示館
building.desc: Tenri Municipal Kurozuka Tumulus Museum is a museum in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Tsukiyama Tumulus (Yamato-takada City)
building.desc: Tsukiyama Tumulus located at of Aza Shiroyama, Tsukiyama, Yamatotakada City, Nara Prefecture, is the ancient Japanese tumulus of a circular shape rear-end with a rectangular frontage.

building.name: Oharida no Miya Palace
building.desc: Oharida no Miya Palace is a palace built during the Reign of the Empress Suiko in ancient Japan.

building.name: Tsuboi Remains
building.desc: Tsuboi Remains are the series of remains from the mid to the late Yayoi period, located across Tokiwa-cho, Kashihara City to Daifuku, Sakurai City.

building.name: Sumitomo Kakkien
building.desc: Sumitomo Kakkien is a historical building located in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

building.name: Miyazuka Tumulus
building.desc: Miyazuka Tumulus is located at Hirose 608, Kumagaya City, Saitama Prefecture, which has a unique two-stepped form with a rectangular-shaped lower layer and a circular-shaped upper layer.

building.name: Andonyama Tumulus
building.desc: Andonyama Tumulus is an ancient Japanese tumulus of a circular shape rear-end with a rectangular frontage, located at Yanagimoto-cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Shiga Prefectural Museum, Biwako Bunkakan (Biwa-ko Lake Cultural Center)
building.jp: 滋賀県立琵琶湖文化館
building.url: building/Shiga Prefectural Museum, Biwako Bunkakan (Biwa-ko Lake Cultural Center).html
building.desc: Biwako Bunkakan is located in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

building.name: Yagyu no Tokusei Hibun (The Inscription of Tokusei at Yagyu)
building.url: building/Yagyu no Tokusei Hibun (The Inscription of Tokusei at Yagyu).html
building.desc: Yagyu no Tokusei Hibun is an inscription on the stone monument found at Yagyu Town, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Ito-jo Castle
building.desc: Ito-jo Castle was a yamajiro (a castle built on a mountain to take advantage of the mountain's topography) which had been constructed on the west hillside halfway up Mt. Takasu on the boundary between Fukuoka City and Maebaru City, Fukuoka Prefecture, in the Nara period of the eighth century.

building.name: Sanden-ji Temple Toshinso (Sanden-ji Temple's stone foundation remain for the central pillar of a pagoda)
building.url: building/Sanden-ji Temple Toshinso (Sanden-ji Temples stone foundation remain for the central pillar of a pag.html
building.desc: The remain of Sanden-ji Temple is the stone foundation for the central pillar of a pagoda in the old-days Sanden-ji Temple, established in Asuka period (late 7th century) in Sohara Terajima-cho, Kagamihara City, Gifu Prefecture.

building.name: Dome-shaped Mound on a Square Base
building.url: building/Dome-shaped Mound on a Square Base.html
building.desc: A dome-shaped mound on a square base is a type of tumuli that were constructed in the past in the Japanese Islands, and also a type of mausoleums of the imperial family in modern times.

building.name: Ichiniwa Tumulus
building.desc: Ichiniwa Tumulus is a megalithic tomb which lies across Tsukamoto and Ichiniwa, Saki-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Natsumi Hai-ji (the Former Natsumi-ji Temple)
building.desc: Natsumi Hai-ji is a site of a demolished temple which existed at Natsumi, Nabari City, Mie Prefecture from the Asuka period to the Nara period.

building.name: Decorated Tombs (decorated tumulus by pictures, patterns and engravings)
building.url: building/Decorated Tombs (decorated tumulus by pictures, patterns and engravings).html
building.desc: Decorated tombs are a general term for the decorated tumulus by pictures, patterns and engravings on the interior wall or the stone coffin and it includes Yokoanabo cave tombs (tunnel graves) which has no mound.

building.name: Ryukakuji Iwaya Tumulus
building.desc: Ryukakuji Iwaya Tumulus is a square tumulus in Sakae-cho, Inba-gun, Chiba Prefecture.

building.name: Sabukaze Koyoseki-gun (Sabukaze Old Kiln Site Group)
building.url: building/Sabukaze Koyoseki-gun (Sabukaze Old Kiln Site Group).html
building.desc: Sabukaze Koyoseki-gun is a group of remains of kilns of Sueki (unglazed ware) in Nagahama, Ushimado-cho, Setouchi City, Okayama Prefecture.

building.name: Umeyama Tumulus
building.desc: Umeyama Tumulus lies at Asuka-mura, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Otsu Prince Hotel
building.desc: Otsu Prince Hotel in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture is a business hotel built on the causeway surrounding lake Biwa.

building.name: Toriya Misanzai Tumulus
building.desc: Toriya Misanzai Tumulus is a keyhole-shaped grave mound in Toriya Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Musashi Fuchu Kumano Jinja Kofun-Tumulus
building.jp: 武蔵府中熊野神社古墳
building.desc: Musashi Fuchu Kamano Jinja Kofun-Tumulus is a dome-shaped grave mound, located in Fuchu City, Tokyo (Tokyo Prefecture).

building.name: Yuminoki-jo Castle
building.desc: Yuminoki-jo Castle was a castle in Tango Province (present-day Iwataki, Yosano-cho, Kyoto Prefecture).

building.name: Nishitonotsuka-kofun Tumulus (a large keyhole-shaped tomb mound in Nakayama Town, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Nishitonotsuka-kofun Tumulus (a large keyhole-shaped tomb mound in Nakayama Town, Tenri City, Nara P.html
building.desc: Nishitonotsuka-kofun Tumulus (also known as Nishitonozuka-kofun Tumulus) is a large keyhole-shaped tomb mound in early Kofun period (Tumulus period) in Nakayama Town, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Kanjo-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Yuraku, Takatori Town, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Kanjo-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Yuraku, Takatori Town, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Kanjo Tumulus (also referred to as Yoraku Kanjo-kofun Tumulus) is a tumulus located in Yoraku, Takatori Town, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Candy-wrap (keyhole shape with one more handle) Shape Barrows
building.url: building/Candy-wrap (keyhole shape with one more handle) Shape Barrows.html
building.desc: Candy-wrap shape barrow refers to one of the form of tumulus.

building.name: Ioto no miya (Ioto Palace, an imperial palace in the capital of ancient Japan [in the early days of the Yamato dynasty])
building.url: building/Ioto no miya (Ioto Palace, an imperial palace in the capital of ancient Japan [in the early days of .html
building.desc: According to the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Ioto no miya was an imperial palace established in the capital of ancient Japan (in the early days of the Yamato dynasty).

building.name: Chihara Kitsunezuka-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Chihara, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Chihara Kitsunezuka-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Chihara, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Chihara Kitsunezuka-kofun Tumulus is a tumulus in Chihara, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Yanagimoto-kofun Tumulus Cluster (a Tumulus Cluster in Yanagimoto Town, Tenri City)
building.url: building/Yanagimoto-kofun Tumulus Cluster (a Tumulus Cluster in Yanagimoto Town, Tenri City).html
building.desc: Yanagimoto-kofun Tumulus Cluster is a tumulus cluster of early Kofun period (tumulus period) in Yanagimoto Town, Tenri City.

building.name: Makimuku-kofun Tumulus Cluster (a tumulus cluster in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Makimuku-kofun Tumulus Cluster (a tumulus cluster in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Makimuku-kofun Tumulus Cluster is located in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Higashidonozuka-kofun Tumulus (a large keyhole-shaped mound in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Higashidonozuka-kofun Tumulus (a large keyhole-shaped mound in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Higashidonozuka-kofun Tumulus is located in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Zuto (the earthen tower in Takabatake Town, Nara City)
building.url: building/Zuto (the earthen tower in Takabatake Town, Nara City).html
building.desc: Zuto is the earthen tower in Takabatake Town, Nara City.

building.name: Shinjo Futazuka-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Shinjo Futazuka-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Shinjo Futazuka-kofun Tumulus is a tumulus in Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture (former Shinjo Town, Kitakatsuragi County) and is designated as a national historic site.

building.name: Yorakukansuzuka-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in the late Kofun period in Takatori Town, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Yorakukansuzuka-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in the late Kofun period in Takatori Town, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Yorakukansuzuka-kofun Tumulus is a tumulus in Takatori Town, Takaichi County, Nara Prefecture, which was constructed in the late Kofun period (tumulus period).

building.name: Akasaka Tennozan-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Akasaka Tennozan-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Akasaka Tennozan-kofun Tumulus is a tumulus in Kurahashi, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Nishiyama-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Somanouchi Town, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Nishiyama-kofun Tumulus (a tumulus in Somanouchi Town, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Nishiyama-kofun Tumulus is a tumulus in Somanouchi Town, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture, and designated as the national historic site.

building.name: Somanouchi-kofun Tumulus Cluster (a tumulus cluster in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Somanouchi-kofun Tumulus Cluster (a tumulus cluster in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture).html
building.desc: Somanouchi-kofun Tumulus Cluster is a tumulus cluster in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Imanishi-ke Jutaku (Imanishi family's House)
building.desc: Imanishi-ke Jutaku is located in Imai-cho, Kashihara City, which has been selected as one of the Preservation Districts for Groups of Historic Buildings, in the central part of Nara Prefecture.

building.name: Niizawa Senzuka-kofun Tumulus Cluster (a large tumulus cluster in Mt. Kaifuki in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture)
building.url: building/Niizawa Senzuka-kofun Tumulus Cluster (a large tumulus cluster in Mt. Kaifuki in Kashihara City, Nar.html
building.desc: Niizawa Senzuka-kofun Tumulus Cluster is one of the famous large tumulus clusters consisting of over 600 burial mounds in total located Mt. Kaifuki in the southern part of Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

culture.name: Kyoto Shogi
culture.desc: Kyoto Shogi is a kind of board game that is played between two players.

culture.name: The Kanoha Group
culture.desc: The Kanoha group is the largest gaha (group of painters) in Japanese art history, and was active for about 400 years from the middle of the Muromachi period (fifteenth century) to the end of the Edo period (nineteenth century) as a group of expert painters that consistently dominated the art world.

culture.name: Shijin-so-o Topography
culture.desc: The term "Shijin-so-o" refers to the topography and land physiognomy that are traditionally believed to be the best suited for the 'Four Gods' that govern the four directions of the heavens in China, Korea and Japan.

culture.name: Shomyo
culture.desc: Shomyo is one of the traditional forms of Japanese music.

culture.name: Gagaku
culture.desc: Gagaku is one of the traditional forms of music in Japan, China, the Korean Peninsula and Vietnam.

culture.name: Oni
culture.desc: Oni is a Japanese specter.

culture.name: Yudofu
culture.desc: Yudofu is one of the dishes made with tofu.

culture.name: Shichimi Togarashi
culture.desc: Shichimi togarashi (seven flavor chili pepper) is a Japanese blend of seven spices.

culture.name: Wagashi
culture.desc: Wagashi (Japanese traditional confectionery) is a whole category of confectionary made using traditional production techniques in Japan.

culture.name: bean paste ('an')
culture.desc: Bean paste ('an' or 'anko') is an ingredient in manju (buns filled with bean paste) and usually indicates azuki beans or other ingredients boiled with sweeteners or ingredients gelatinized with starch.

culture.name: Tsukemono
culture.desc: Tsukemono is preserved food that vegetables (fish or meat, sometimes) are pickled together with pickling ingredients having high osmotic pressure, having an effect to decrease hydrogen-ion exponent or having an effect to shut off from the air such as salt, vinegar, rice-bran paste, soy sauce, sake lees or fat and oil, to improve preservation quality as well as to improve taste and flavor by maturing.

culture.name: Kamado
culture.desc: A kamado (cooking furnace) is an apparatus for cooking that encloses a fire when heating grain or foodstuffs.

culture.name: Kado
culture.desc: Kado is a type of Ikebana, an art of combining plants such as flowers and trees, with the aspect of Geido (accomplishments).

culture.name: Tengu
culture.desc: Tengu are legendary Japanese creatures.

culture.name: Tsukimi (月見)
culture.desc: Tsukimi is to enjoy viewing the moon, such as the full moon.

culture.name: Kimon
culture.desc: Kimon (demons' gate) means the direction of the northeast (ushi-tora; between the Ox (second sign of Chinese zodiac which means north-northeast) and the Tiger (third sign of Chinese zodiac which means east-northeast)).

culture.name: Shibazuke
culture.desc: As far as Tsukemono is concerned, '紫葉漬け' is correct and '柴漬' is wrong.

culture.name: Japanese Sword
culture.desc: Japanese swords (日本刀) are a generic term for swords forged in the originally developed way in Japan.

culture.name: Jinja Architecture
culture.desc: Jinja architecture refers to the architecture associated with jinja, or Shinto shrine.

culture.name: Important Cultural Properties
culture.desc: Important cultural properties are tangible cultural heritage (such as constructions, buildings and the art craft articles) in Japan that are designated as being culturally, historically or academically important under the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties by the Japanese government (or the Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology).

culture.name: Cultural Properties
culture.desc: The meanings of "cultural properties" are as follows:

culture.name: Yabusame (shooting arrows from a galloping horse)
culture.url: culture/Yabusame (shooting arrows from a galloping horse).html
culture.desc: Yabusame is the Japanese traditional skill, practice and rite of shooting whistling arrows from a galloping horse.

culture.name: Gissha
culture.desc: A gissha (ox-drawn carriage) is a kind of vehicle drawn by oxen or water buffalo.

culture.name: Powdered Green Tea
culture.desc: Powdered green tea is a kind of green tea.

culture.name: Nishijin Ori
culture.desc: Nishijin ori is a general term for yarn-dyed fabrics made in Kyoto.

culture.name: Noh drama
culture.desc: Noh is a type of "Nohgaku (Noh music)" used in a kind of Japanese original stage performing art of which the completion was realized in the late Kamakura period or the beginning of the Muromachi period.

culture.name: Dengaku Folk Dance
culture.desc: Dengaku is a traditional Japanese performance art.

culture.name: Kamon
culture.desc: The term "Kamon" refers to a crest used in Japan to indicate one's origins; that is, one's family lineage, blood line, ancestry and status from ancient times.

culture.name: Urasenke
culture.desc: Urasenke is one of various schools of tea ceremony.

culture.name: Japanese tea
culture.desc: "Japanese tea" is the term used in daily conversation and refers to 'tea of Japan,' that is, 'tea made in Japan' or 'a kind of tea which is often drunk in Japan.'

culture.name: OK
culture.desc: Dashi is a float used in a procession during a festival.

culture.name: Sensu/Ogi (folding fan)
culture.desc: A Sensu or Ogi (folding fan) is an implement used to move air by hand like Uchiwa fans, and its frame is several dozens of wooden strips tied together with thread at their ends (kaname referred to as pivot), and when used, a Sensu or Ogi is widely unfolded and waved back and forth to create a cooling airflow.

culture.name: Kamigatamai
culture.desc: Kamigatamai is a type of Japanese dance that emerged in Kyoto from 1800, in the middle of the Edo period, to the end of the Edo period.

culture.name: Incense burning
culture.desc: Incense burning is an example of Geido (art), aimed at enjoying incense while meditating in a quiet world away from the pressures of daily life, and to appreciate the fragrance rising from Koboku (fragrant wood) burned ("taku" in Japanese) according to traditional rituals.

culture.name: Taka-gari
culture.desc: Taka-gari (falconry) is a kind of hunting which uses a falcon.

culture.name: Onryo (Revengeful Ghost)
