culture.desc: Onryo are common supernatural or ghostly phenomenon that cannot be seen by human eyes that harbor ill will and vengeance towards humans.

culture.name: Kyujutsu
culture.desc: The term Kyujutsu refers to a technique or a martial art to put an arrow in the target from a bow (weapon).

culture.name: Suiboku-ga
culture.desc: Suiboku-ga (ink painting) is the art of painting in just one color using 'Sumi (Japanese ink),' not only for painting lines, but also gradation showing contrasting density and lighting.

culture.name: Kitayama culture
culture.desc: Kitayama culture is the culture at the beginning of Muromachi Period, represented by the Kitayama mountain villa of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, the third shogun (1358-1408) from the end of 14th centuries to the early part of the 15th centuries.

culture.name: Higashiyama culture
culture.desc: Higashiyama culture is a term which refers to the culture in the middle of the Muromachi Period.

culture.name: Makie
culture.desc: Makie is the technique of Japanese lacquer art.

culture.name: Nuka-zuke pickles
culture.desc: Nuka-zuke (or nukamiso-zuke), which is also called dobu-zuke or dobo-zuke, is one type of representative pickles in Japan, made by pickling vegetables in nuka-doko (a rice bran bed made by lactic acid fermentation).

culture.name: Ukai
culture.desc: "Ukai" is one traditional fishing method used to catch ayu (sweetfish) by using a cormorant.

culture.name: Joraku
culture.desc: "Joraku" is a term which means to enter in Kyoto.

culture.name: Miyako Odori
culture.desc: "Miyako Odori" is a dance performance of the Gion Kobu district held in April at the Gion Kobu Kabu-renjo Theater.

culture.name: Dorayaki Cake
culture.desc: Dorayaki (Cake)

culture.name: Maiko (apprentice geisha, dancing girl)
culture.desc: The term "Maiko" refers to a young geisha or a geisha apprentice.

culture.name: Basyaku
culture.desc: "Basyaku" was a road hauler who transported goods by horse.

culture.name: Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto
culture.desc: "Historic Monuments of Ancient Kyoto" is a collective term of the temples in Kyoto City and Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture and Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

culture.name: Kitano Odori (Kitano Dance)
culture.desc: The Kitano Dance is performed at the Kamishichiken Kaburenjo theater every year from April 15 to April 25.

culture.name: Geigi
culture.desc: Geigi refers to geisha (Japanese singing and dancing girl) or young geisha that add zest to banquets and entertain customers by performing traditional Japanese dance, songs with shamisen accompaniment, long epic song with shamisen accompaniment, and a Japanese band using traditional musical instruments.

culture.name: Gion odori (Gion Dance)
culture.desc: Gion odori: Gion odori is performed from November 1 to 10 annually in the Gion Kaikan Theater.

culture.name: Mikoshi (Portable shrine)
culture.desc: A mikoshi or shinyo refers to a litter on which a divine spirit temporarily rides when the divine spirit moves to a place where the sacred litter is lodged during a festival celebrated by shrines in Japan.

culture.name: Tenno-sai Festival
culture.desc: Tenno-sai Festival is a festival organized by Tennosha to honor Gozu Tenno (deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva).

culture.name: The Ogura Hyakunin Isshu Cultural Foundation
culture.jp: 小倉百人一首文化財団
culture.url: culture/The Ogura Hyakunin Isshu Cultural Foundation.html
culture.desc: The Ogura Hyakunin Isshu Cultural Foundation was established by the Kyoto Chamber of Commerce and Industry under the theme of "Hyakunin Isshu" (One Hundred Poems by One Hundred Poets) to contribute to the development of Kyoto Culture and Kyoto tourism.

culture.name: Mushanokoji-senke
culture.desc: Mushanokoji-senke is one of the tea schools.

culture.name: The Omote-senke
culture.desc: Omote-senke is one of the various tea ceremony schools that can be found in Japan.

culture.name: Yatsuhashi
culture.desc: Yatsuhashi refers to one of the Japanese-style confectioneries.

culture.name: Japanese dance
culture.desc: Nihon Buyo is Japanese translation of Japanese dance and it is a generic term for dances in Japan.

culture.name: Misomatsukaze
culture.desc: Misomatsukaze is a kind of baked confectionery.

culture.name: Shinozuka school (of dance)
culture.desc: The Shinozuka school is the oldest school of "kamigata-mai dance" established by a Kamigata Kabuki (kabuki of the Kyoto and Osaka area) shosagoto (the way of dance) choreographer Bunzaburo SHINOZUKA during Bunka and Bunsei era (1804-1830) at the end of the Edo period.

culture.name: JAL Sound Stage Series
culture.desc: The JAL Sound Stage Series is a concert featuring the invited top guest artists in Japan and abroad and is held at a temple among the Historical Landmark Buildings in Kyoto or Nara about every September.

culture.name: Send-off Bonfires of Five Mountains
culture.desc: The Send-off Bonfires of Five Mountains (Gozan no Okuribi) refers to the annual bonfires lit at various 5 locations including Nyoigatake (Mt. Nyoi known as Mt. Daimonji) on August 16 in Kyoto City.

culture.name: Ninjutsu (ninja art)
culture.desc: Ninjutsu is a generic term for techniques used by Ninja (persons in feudal Japan who used ninjutsu for the purposes of espionage, assassination, sabotage, etc.), who were active during the Muromachi Period and the Sengoku Period, to gather intelligence or to destabilize intelligence against the enemy camp and also arts of warfare and martial arts necessary to carry out Ninja's operations.

culture.name: Choju-Jinbutsu-giga (scrolls of frolicking animals and humans)
culture.url: culture/Choju-Jinbutsu-giga (scrolls of frolicking animals and humans).html
culture.desc: Choju-Jinbutsu-giga is a emakimono (an illustrated scroll) that was handed down to Kozan-ji Temple, Ukyo Ward in Kyoto City.

culture.name: Takuan-zuke
culture.desc: Takuan-zuke is a pickle and is referred to as daikon radish preserved in rice-bran and salt.

culture.name: Kuwai (Arrowhead Tubers)
culture.desc: Kuwai (arrowhead tubers or Sagittaria trifolia) are perennial aquatic herbs in the Alismataceae (water plantain) family and are also called 'tagusa', 'enbi-kusa' or 'kuwae.'

culture.name: Arare (snack)
culture.desc: Arare is short for arare mochi (rice cake) and is a snack made by cutting rice cakes into pieces two to three centimeters in length and about five millimeters wide and roasting them.

culture.name: Shishiodoshi (decorative bamboo irrigation pumps)
culture.desc: Shishiodoshi is a general name for devices used to intimidate and drive away agriculture-damaging birds and animals.

culture.name: Kocho-Junisen (twelve coins cast in Japan)
culture.desc: "Kocho-Junisen" is a collective term for twelve kinds of copper coins cast in Japan during the period from 708 AD to 963 AD.

culture.name: Omikuji (Written Oracles)
culture.desc: Omikuji (also referred to as Mikuji) are sacred lots drawn at temples or shrines to tell one's fortune.

culture.name: Minato Maizuru Chatta Matsuri Festival
culture.jp: みなと舞鶴ちゃったまつり
culture.desc: Minato Maizuru Chatta Matsuri Festival is a festival held in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Senso (to Become New Emperor)
culture.desc: The term "Senso" means to succeed the position of Tenshi (emperor) upon the demise of the previous emperor or his abdication from the position.

culture.name: Dashi Broth (local dish)
culture.desc: Dashi is a local dish originated from the inland region of Yamagata Prefecture.

culture.name: Yoshimura Shuzo
culture.desc: Yoshimura Shuzo Co., Ltd. is a company engaged in production and sale of seishu (refined sake), with its principal office at Kami-itabashi cho, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Suimono (Clear Soup)
culture.desc: Suimono is a kind of soup of Japanese cuisine consisting of suiji (soup stock flavored with soy sauce and salt), wandane (a main, solid ingredient), tsuma (a garnish lending a touch of color), suikuchi (a fragrant garnish) and so forth.

culture.name: Shoji (Paper Sliding Screen)
culture.desc: A shoji refers to a screen consisting of a wooden frame covered in paper allowing the passage of light, used as a sliding door or window in a Japanese house.

culture.name: Kyo-yasai (Specifically Certified Vegetable Varieties Grown in Kyoto)
culture.url: culture/Kyo-yasai (Specifically Certified Vegetable Varieties Grown in Kyoto).html
culture.desc: "Kyo-yasai" is a general term for varieties of vegetables that were created by selective breeding a long time ago and have been produced in a traditional manner mainly in regions in Kyoto Prefecture, generally referring to 43 varieties of vegetables in total that fall under 'Kyo no Dento Yasai' (41 varieties certified by Kyoto Prefectural Government to continue to be produced in the traditional manner) and/or 'Brand Kyo-Yasai' (21 varieties certified o have reliable quality and to be produced at such an adequate and stable volume to enable distribution to the marketplace).

culture.name: Setsugetsuka
culture.desc: Setsugetsuka (or pronounced as Yuki Tsuki Hana (Snow, the Moon and Flowers)), is a word from the phrase, 'Setsugetsuka no toki mottomo kimi wo omou (I remember you especially when snow, the moon or flowers are beautiful)' in an old Chinese poem, 'In Kyoritsu ni yosu (A poem sent to In Kyoritsu)' composed by Juyi BAI.

culture.name: Toro (Garden Lantern)
culture.desc: Toro (a garden lantern) is a kind of traditional Japanese lighting fixture.

culture.name: Oyoroi (Large Armor)
culture.desc: "Oyoroi" (large armor) is one type of Japanese armor.

culture.name: Shakkei (Borrowing landscape)
culture.desc: "Shakkei" (borrowing landscapes) is one type of landscape gardening techniques in Chinese and Japanese gardens.

culture.name: Wadaiko (Japanese drum)
culture.desc: Wadaiko (Japanese drum) is one of the percussion instruments.

culture.name: Honzen Ryori (Formally arranged meal)
culture.desc: We will introduce Honzen ryori (formally arranged meal), one type of traditional food among Japanese-style cuisines.

culture.name: Karesansui (dry landscape)
culture.desc: Karesansui (dry landscape) is a style of Japanese garden or Japanese painting.

culture.name: shirabyoshi (literally, White rhythm)
culture.desc: Shirabyoshi is a type of singing and dancing performance developed from the late Heian period to Kamakura period.

culture.name: Kemari (a type of football played by courtiers in ancient Japan)
culture.url: culture/Kemari (a type of football played by courtiers in ancient Japan).html
culture.desc: Kemari is one of the athletic sports that became popular during the Heian period.

culture.name: Kimekomi Ningyo dolls
culture.desc: Kimekomi ningyo is a type of wooden doll.

culture.name: Nihon teien (a traditional Japanese landscape garden)
culture.url: culture/Nihon teien (a traditional Japanese landscape garden).html
culture.desc: Nihon teien is a traditional Japanese landscape garden.

culture.name: Suikinkutsu (a traditional Japanese echoing system in the garden, like a water harp)
culture.url: culture/Suikinkutsu (a traditional Japanese echoing system in the garden, like a water harp).html
culture.desc: Suikinkutsu is a decoration device in a Japanese garden that generates a sound like the koto (Japanese harp) with drops of water.

culture.name: Heki School
culture.desc: Heki school was established by Masatsugu Danjo HEKI, who learned in the ancient Henmi school.

culture.name: Ohaguro (Tooth black)
culture.desc: Ohaguro (tooth blackening) is the cosmetic treatment of dyeing teeth black used chiefly by married women (or occasionally men) in Japan, southeast China or Southeast Asia, before the Meiji period.

culture.name: Akarenga-Festa (Red Brick Festival) (Maizuru City)
culture.jp: 赤れんがフェスタ (舞鶴)
culture.desc: "Akarenga-Festa" (the Red Brick Festival) is a sightseeing event held in Maizuru City of Kyoto Prefecture every year.

culture.name: Noryo-yuka (also called as Noryo-doko - breeze-enjoying floor)
culture.url: culture/Noryo-yuka (also called as Noryo-doko - breeze-enjoying floor).html
culture.desc: Noryo-yuka (Noryo-doko) or the riverbed (in general, for the Kamo-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River water system), it is pronounced as 'kawayuka;' for Kifune or Takao in Kyoto, it is pronounced as 'kawadoko') is one of the poetic sceneries of the Kyoto summer.

culture.name: Ryotei (Japanese-style restaurant)
culture.desc: Ryotei refers to a high class restaurant serving mainly Japanese cuisine.

culture.name: Tempura (Japanese deep-fried dish)
culture.desc: Tempura is a Japanese dish of deep fried battered meats, seafood, vegetables or sansai (plants growing wild in fields and mountains.)

culture.name: Kikuka-monsho/Kikka-monsho (crest of Chrysanthemum)
culture.desc: Kikuka-monsho/Kikka-monsho is a crest modeled on the Chrysanthemum blossom.

culture.name: Inoue school (of dance)
culture.desc: Inoue school is a school of traditional Japanese dance.

culture.name: Saba-zushi (rod-shaped sushi topped with mackerel)
culture.desc: Saba-zushi is a type of Bo-zushi (rod-shaped sushi topped with large slice of fish) with mackerel, or means Saba-no-narezushi (sushi fermented with mackerel and vegetables).

culture.name: Maizuru Tsutsuji (azalea) Matsuri Festival
culture.desc: Maizuru Tsutsuji (azalea) Matsuri Festival is one of the festivals that takes place in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Takayama
culture.desc: Seen in a parade during the Gion Matsuri Festival in Kyoto, Takayama is one of a "yamaboko," which is a festival float mounted with a decorative long-handled sword.

culture.name: Tosai-gogisei
culture.desc: The term "Tosai-gogisei " refers to the way of decision-making in an organization.

culture.name: Fusuma
culture.desc: The term fusuma (襖) is a fitting which is used as a partition in a Japanese-style room.

culture.name: Koshido (lattice door)
culture.desc: Koshido or lattice door can be either a sliding or swinging door style.

culture.name: Itado (wooden door)
culture.desc: Itado is a kind of door made with panel.

culture.name: Yamato-e painting
culture.desc: Yamato-e is one concept of style in Japanese paintings.

culture.name: Joya no Age-taimatsu Festival
culture.desc: Joya no Age-taimatsu (Age-daimatsu) Festival is a festival at Aza Joya, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Kanshitsuzo
culture.desc: Kanshitsuzo (literally, dry lacquer technique) is one of the oriental wood statue production techniques, in which a statue is formed by layering pieces of hemp cloth soaked in lacquer over a core, and a wood powder and lacquer mixture was thickly applied to create surface details.

culture.name: Simmered takuan pickles
culture.desc: Simmered takuan pickles (pickled daikon radish) is a local dish of some regions in Japan.

culture.name: Sonen School
culture.desc: Sonen School is a school of calligraphy founded by Cloistered Imperial Prince Sonen.

culture.name: Yonaki Ishi
culture.desc: Yonaki Ishi is one of the folk stories about stones.

culture.name: Uraku school
culture.desc: Uraku school (Uraku-ryu) is one of the various schools of sado started by Nagamasu ODA (Urakusai), who was the real younger brother of Nobunaga ODA.

culture.name: Yoshingo-ryu school
culture.desc: The Yoshingo-ryu school is a school of flower arrangement established by Seiryusai SAKURAI ichinyokoji (Ichinyo).

culture.name: Emakimono
culture.desc: Emakimono (an illustrated scroll) is a kind of Japanese style painting composed of series of illustrated scenes or stories on a horizontally long screen made up of multiple sheets of rectangular paper (or silk cloth) connected side by side.

culture.name: Kagura
culture.desc: Kagura is a chanting and dancing performance dedicated to gods in Shinto rituals.

culture.name: Tosa school
culture.desc: Tosa school (Tosa ha)

culture.name: Asahi Yaki
culture.desc: Asahi yaki is a kind of earthenware produced in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Aburimochi (scorched rice cake)
culture.desc: Aburimochi is a kind of rice cake snack, made of thumb-sized rice cakes dredged with soybean flour, skewered on a bamboo stick, roasted over charcoal fire, and then basted with white bean pastes, or otherwise okaki (cracker mix) and senbei (rice crackers) skewered on a stick.

culture.name: Jidai matsuri (Festival of the Ages)
culture.desc: Jidai matsuri is a festival of Heian-Jingu Shrine in Kyoto.

culture.name: Wabi and Sabi
culture.desc: Wabi and sabi are sense of beauty in Japan.

culture.name: Aoi Matsuri (Hollyhock Flower Festival)
culture.desc: Aoi Matsuri (formally known as Kamo Matsuri) is an annual celebration that takes place at Kamomioya-jinja Shrine (Shimogamo-jinja Shrine) and Kamowakeikazuchi-jinja Shrine (Kamigamo-jinja Shrine) in Kyoto City on May 15 (the middle day of Cock day of lunar calendar).

culture.name: Genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age)
culture.desc: Genpuku was a coming-of-age celebration for boys, a rite of passage held among Court nobles and samurai families since the Heian period.

culture.name: Tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed)
culture.url: culture/Tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed).html
culture.desc: A tokonoma is a kind of Zashikikazari (a set of decorative features), seen in a tatami room of a Japanese house.

culture.name: Raijin (god of lightning)
culture.desc: Raijin is the god of lightning in Japanese folk beliefs and the Shinto religion.

culture.name: Inkyo (Retirement)
culture.desc: Inkyo is when the head of the family gives away the reigns of the family to another family member and withdraws from official household affairs.

culture.name: Wabicha (wabi style of tea ceremony)
culture.desc: Wabicha is a style of chanoyu (Japanese tea ceremony) in a restricted sense of the word.

culture.name: Wall painting
culture.desc: Wall paintings are paintings applied to the surface of walls and ceilings of buildings and caves.

culture.name: Ikenobo
culture.desc: Ikenobo is iemoto (the head family of a school) of Kado (flower arrangement) in Japan.

culture.name: Okame (plain-looking woman)
culture.desc: Okame is the face or mask of a woman who has a short nose and swollen round cheeks.

culture.name: Daiko-daki (burning Japanese radish)
culture.desc: Daiko-daki is an annual event held in December in Kyoto.

culture.name: Jusan-mairi (thirteen year old children pray for knowledge, happiness and health to become adults)
culture.url: culture/Jusan-mairi (thirteen year old children pray for knowledge, happiness and health to become adults).html
culture.desc: Jusan-mairi is a ritual that takes place on March 13 of the lunar calendar date (today, it is held one month later on April 13) where 13 year old boys and girls visit Kokuzo Bosatsu (Akasagarbha Bodhisattva) to give thanks that they have come of age and pray for future knowledge, happiness, and health.

culture.name: Mizuna (potherb mustard)
culture.desc: Mizuna (potherb mustard)is a yearly plant of Brassicaceae.

culture.name: Asazuke (quick pickles)
culture.desc: Asazuke is a pickled dish made by marinating vegetables such as cucumbers, daikon radishes and eggplants with seasoning for a short time.

culture.name: Shokado bento
culture.desc: Shokado bento is a meal in a box, whose inside is divided into sections in a cross pattern and has a lid with high sides.

culture.name: Senmai-zuke (thousand-sliced pickles)
culture.desc: Senmai-zuke which is marketed in supermarkets are traditional pickles in Kyoto and are produced by marinating paper-thin slices of turnips with pieces of konbu (kelp), red peppers and vinegar.

culture.name: Rakuchu Rakugai Zu (Scenes In and Around Kyoto)
culture.url: culture/Rakuchu Rakugai Zu (Scenes In and Around Kyoto).html
culture.desc: Rakuchu rakugai zu are a genre paintings produced from the Muromachi period to the Edo period that depicted the town area (inner Kyoto) and suburbs (outer Kyoto) from an overhead view.

culture.name: Sencha-do tea service
culture.desc: Sencha-do tea service is a sort of Sado (Japanese tea ceremony) sensu lato.

culture.name: Manganji Togarashi (manganji pepper)
culture.desc: Manganji Togarashi is one of the spring Kyo-yasai (specifically certified vegetable varieties grown in Kyoto.)

culture.name: Kosode
culture.desc: Kosode is clothing thought to be designed in the middle of the Heian period, and is an origin of Japanese Kimono.

culture.name: Mo
culture.desc: Mo is one type of kimono that constitutes Junihiote (twelve-layer robe).

culture.name: Hosonaga
culture.desc: Hosonaga is a type of ubugi (swaddling clothes) of the Heian period with a shape similar to kariginu (a type of ancient kimono).

culture.name: Haori
culture.desc: The haori coat is a kind of traditional Japanese clothes.

culture.name: Hitatare
culture.desc: Hitatare (the large square-cut coat with cord laced sleeve edges of samurai) is one type of Japanese traditional kimono.

culture.name: Kamishimo
culture.desc: Kamishimo (old ceremonial dress) is a kind of formal kimono (traditional Japanese clothes) for men.

culture.name: Sado
culture.desc: Sado (also known as chado) (Japanese tea ceremony) is the act of a ritual preparing and serving tea for guests.

culture.name: imobo (Dish of boiled shrimp-shaped potato and dried cod. A famous local cuisine of Kyoto.)
culture.url: culture/imobo (Dish of boiled shrimp-shaped potato and dried cod. A famous local cuisine of Kyoto.).html
culture.desc: As famous cuisine of Kyoto, imobou is a local specialty of Kyoto City.

culture.name: Ichizawa Hanpu Co., Ltd.
culture.desc: Ichizawa Hanpu Co., Ltd. is a cloth bag manufacturer located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Kanzashi
culture.desc: The term "kanzashi" means Japanese traditional accessories used by women in doing up their hair.

culture.name: Uguisubari (nightingale (flooring), method of laying floors to deliberately make a noise (like a nightingale's song) when walked across - security feature)
culture.url: culture/Uguisubari (nightingale (flooring), method of laying floors to deliberately make a noise (like a nig.html
culture.desc: Uguisubari is a corridor used for warning that the enemy has entered.

culture.name: Rakuyaki (Raku ware)
culture.desc: Rakuyaki (Raku ware)

culture.name: Senjafuda (a votive card)
culture.desc: Senjafuda (also referred to as Senshafuda) is a card or slip stuck to shrines and temples on which visitor's name is printed as a memorial of the visit.

culture.name: Mitarashi dango
culture.desc: Mitarashi dango are dumplings coated with a soy-and-sugar syrup, and usually three to five are stuck on a stick.

culture.name: Chigo
culture.desc: Chigo has roughly the following meanings.

culture.name: Chozubachi (washbasin)
culture.desc: Chozubachi originally referred to a bowl holding water for people to purify themselves by rinsing out their mouths before the altar of a shrine or a temple.

culture.name: Heian-style costume
culture.desc: Heian-style costume is clothing worn by the Imperial families and court nobles during the Heian period.

culture.name: Kyo Language
culture.desc: The term Kyo language (written in Japanese as either 京言葉, きょうことば or 京ことば) or Kyoto-ben (Kyoto dialect) means a Japanese dialect spoken either in the old town area of Kyoto City, in the narrow sense, or in the area including Yamashiro Province and Nantan (around Kameoka basin), in the broad sense, both in Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Kitayama sugi
culture.desc: Kitayama sugi is a Japanese cedar that grows in the northern area of Kyoto City.

culture.name: The three portraits of Jingo-ji Temple
culture.url: culture/The three portraits of Jingo-ji Temple.html
culture.desc: The three portraits of Jingo-ji Temple are three portraits owned by Kyoto Jingo-ji Temple.

culture.name: Uji cha (Uji tea)
culture.desc: "Uji cha" is a high-class brand of Japanese tea with the image of being produced in the southern area of Kyoto Prefecture around Uji City.

culture.name: Suguki Pickles
culture.desc: Suguki pickles are one kind of Japanese pickles.

culture.name: Daigo no Hanami
culture.desc: Daigo no Hanami refers to the blossom-viewing party held in grand style at Daigo-ji Temple in Kyoto on April 20, 1598 by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI with about 1,300 people, including feudal lords and their vassals, as well as his family members such as Hideyori TOYOTOMI, Kodaiin and Yodo-dono.

culture.name: Oban (An old large-sized Japanese gold coin)
culture.url: culture/Oban (An old large-sized Japanese gold coin).html
culture.desc: Oban, in the general meaning, is a large-sized oval gold coin among noshikin (flattened by a hammer or roller, that was made of unprocessed gold) made after the 16th century in Japan.

culture.name: Toraken Game
culture.desc: Toraken is a game played in three Japanese rooms divided by closed Fusuma (Japanese sliding door) where people choose to wear or hand a tiger costume, women's clothes (implying Torajo, literally, a tiger woman, the mother of Watonai, another name of Seiko TEI - Zheng Chenggong or musket - implying Watonai or Kiyomasa KATO) and wait until the fusuma is opened, and they run off to decide who wins.

culture.name: Yoshiwara no Mandoro
culture.desc: Yoshiwara no Mandoro is a traditional and vibrant festival that takes place in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Higekiri
culture.desc: Higekiri is a sword which MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka is said to have had made in the Heian period, handed down, together with another sword, Hizamaru, through successive generations of the Minamoto clan.

culture.name: Agata-matsuri Festival
culture.desc: The Agata-matsuri Festival is held on June 5 and 6 every year in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Hizamaru
culture.desc: Hizamaru was a sword which MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka had made during the Heian period, handed down as a sword of successive generations of Genji, together with Higekiri.

culture.name: Suikan
culture.desc: Suikan was a garment worn by men during the Heian period.

culture.name: Saiten keiba (horse racing festival)
culture.desc: Saiten keiba was a horse race held at shrine festivals, etc. as dedication or as entertainment.

culture.name: The Bon Festival
culture.desc: "Obon (the Bon festival)" means a series of events to worship the souls of ancestors held in Japan on and around July 15th of the old Japanese luni-solar calendar.

culture.name: Kyoto Intercollegiate Festa
culture.desc: Kyoto Intercollegiate Festa is an annual festival which is held every year in early October (though not always in the past) in Kyoto, Japan.

culture.name: Kozubukuro (Japanese sweets)
culture.desc: Kozubukuro is nice Japanese sweet created by a Japanese pastry chef in Kyoto during the Meiji period.

culture.name: Nanzenji tofu (tofu of Nanzen-ji Temple)
culture.desc: Nanzenji tofu is a kind of tofu produced around Nanzen-ji Temple, the Grand Head Temple of Rinzai sect in Kyoto, and Shonai Region of Yamagata Prefecture.

culture.name: Ryuha (group or school)
culture.desc: Ryuha are groups of people that are headed by an Iemoto (head of school) or Soke (grand master), who passes down a certain systematic waza (craftsmanship or technique) in the fields of Japanese art, sake brewing, etc.

culture.name: Ogasawara-ryu school
culture.desc: The Ogasawara-ryu is a school of traditional samurai arts, that was originally founded to teach equestrian archery (kisha).

culture.name: Kazashi
culture.desc: "Kazashi" refers flowers and leaves worn in the hair or headdress in shrine rituals by the Japanese during the ancient times.

culture.name: Tekomai (Japanese Traditional Dance)
culture.desc: Tekomai is a dance performed to lead floats or omikoshi (portable shrine) in a festival.

culture.name: Jidai Gyoretsu
culture.desc: The Jidai Gyoretsu is a pageant or procession in festivals where the participants wear costumes from the Kofun period (tumulus period) through the early Showa period, reproduced after research into each period,

culture.name: Urayasu no Mai Dance
culture.desc: Urayasu no Mai is a type of kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines) (mikomai (female Shinto dance that the young girls each carry a small baton with bells)).

culture.name: The Yabunouchi-ryu school
culture.desc: The Yabunouchi-ryu is a school of the tea ceremony.

culture.name: Ichizawa Shinzaburo Hanpu
culture.desc: Ichizawa Shinzaburo Hanpu Co., Ltd. is a manufacturer of bags made with cloth in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Kawarake Nage (throwing an earthen cup)
culture.desc: "Kawarake Nage" refers to throwing an unglazed or sunbaked earthen sake cup or dish from a high place, wishing protection from evil and so on.

culture.name: Sekishu-ryu School
culture.desc: Sekishu-ryu is a general term for the various tea ceremony schools that regard Sadamasa (Sekishu) KATAGIRI as an original founder.

culture.name: Kansai Kabuki (Kabuki of the Kyoto and Osaka Area)
culture.url: culture/Kansai Kabuki (Kabuki of the Kyoto and Osaka Area).html
culture.desc: Kansai Kabuki

culture.name: Abdication of the throne
culture.desc: Abdication of the throne implies resignation by a monarch such as an emperor or a king from his or her position.

culture.name: Otabe
culture.desc: Otabe is the name of a Kyoto-based (Minami Ward, Kyoto City) sweet manufacturer, and also the name of its main product, a soft sweet dumpling filled with chunky sweet azuki bean paste called "nama-yatsuhashi."

culture.name: Sanpogakuso
culture.desc: Sanpogakuso was an organization for handing down gagaku (Japanese ancient court music and dance), established as a system in the early Edo period and each ho (one office) consisted of 17 musicians and, therefore, sanpogakuso consisted of 51 musicians in total.

culture.name: Naniwa kagura-dance
culture.desc: Naniwa kagura-dance is a kind of Satokagura (kagura performance held somewhere other than the imperial palace) handed down mainly in the Kansai region.

culture.name: Noami
culture.desc: Noami (1397 - 1471) is a painter, master of ceremonial tea, and a renga (linked poem) poet who lived during the Muromachi period.

culture.name: Yoken-ryu School
culture.desc: Yoken-ryu school is the name generally given to a school of Sado (tea ceremony) that regards Yoken FUJIMURA as its founder.

culture.name: Matsuo-ryu School
culture.desc: Matsuo-ryu school is a school of the tea ceremony, originated by Soji MATSUO.

culture.name: Kokawadera Engiemaki (a picture scroll of the legends of Kokawadera Temple)
culture.url: culture/Kokawadera Engiemaki (a picture scroll of the legends of Kokawadera Temple).html
culture.desc: Kokawadera Engiemaki (a picture scroll of the legends of Kokawadera Temple), one of representative picture scrolls in Japan, is designated as a national treasure.

culture.name: Somin Shorai (a Japanese old story about a folk religion)
culture.url: culture/Somin Shorai (a Japanese old story about a folk religion).html
culture.desc: Somin shorai refers to a folk tale that has been told as a legend in Japan in mainly the Kinki region, referring to folk beliefs that originated in the folk tale.

culture.name: Mikomai (ancient Japanese Shinto dance)
culture.desc: Mikomai (written in Japanese kanji characters either as 巫女舞 or 神子舞) is a type of dance performed by miko (shrine maidens) in a Kagura performance (a sacred music and dancing performance dedicated to the Shinto gods).

culture.name: Kyoto Tourism Culture Certification Test
culture.desc: Kyoto Tourism Culture Certification Test, for `Kyoto Expert Certification,' is a certification test covering knowledge about a particular place that is held by the Kyoto Chamber of Commerce.

culture.name: Hayami-ryu School
culture.desc: Hayami-ryu is a school of the tea ceremony, originated by Sotatsu HAYAMI.

culture.name: Uneme Costume
culture.desc: Uneme costume is a costume for Uneme, a court lady selected among Gozoku (local ruling families) who served in the inner palace as a waiting staff of the emperor in ancient times.

culture.name: Maizuru Kamaboko (Fish Minced and Steamed)
culture.desc: "Maizuru Kamaboko" is a brand of kamaboko (fish minced and steamed) made and sold in Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Gion Matsuri Festival
culture.desc: Gion Matsuri Festival is a kind of festival that is dedicated to the Gion-jinja Shrines which enshrine the Gion shinko (Gion belief) (Susanoo, deity in Japanese Mythology, and Gozu Tenno, deity of Disease, said to be the Indian god Gavagriva).

culture.name: Kanbayashi Shunsho Honten
culture.desc: Kanbayashi Shunsho Honten Ltd. is a tea wholesale store in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Chiso
culture.desc: Chiso is a long established firm dealing with Kyo-Yuzen (silk fabrics printed in Kyoto).

culture.name: Matsubayashi
culture.desc: Matsubayashi (or Matsuhayashi) is a traditional performing art for New Year's celebration.

culture.name: The Three Largest Festivals in Kyoto
culture.url: culture/The Three Largest Festivals in Kyoto.html
culture.desc: The three largest festivals in Kyoto refer to the three festivals held in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Kujo Negi (Leek from Kujo)
culture.desc: "Kujo negi" refers to a kind of long green onion (leek) representing Japan.

culture.name: Fucha Ryori
culture.desc: Fucha ryori is Japanese vegetarian cuisine introduced from China in the early Edo period.

culture.name: Honke Nishio Yatsuhashi (Originator Nishio Yatsuhashi)
culture.desc: Honke Nishio Yatsuhashi is the oldest manufacture of Yatsuhashi (type of sweets made with bean paste) in Kyoto, established in 1689.

culture.name: Higashi (dry sweets; dry confectionary)
culture.desc: Higashi (干菓子) or Higashi (乾菓子) is a generic term that refers to dry Japanese sweets.

culture.name: Suzuriarai (literally, washing ink stone)
culture.desc: Suzuriarai (literally, washing ink stone) is an event carried out on July 6 in the lunar calendar in preparation for welcoming the Tanabata Star festival.

culture.name: Kyokusui no En
culture.desc: Kyokusui (or Gokusui) no en is a drinking party which involves cups of sake being floated down a stream in a garden, whereby participants seated on the bank had to improvise poems; if the participant could not compose a poem, he has to drink a cup of sake as a penalty.

culture.name: KOMAZAWA Risai
culture.desc: Risai KOMAZAWA was one of the Senke Jisshoku (The Ten Craftsmen of the House of Sen).

culture.name: OKUMURA Kichibe
culture.desc: Kichibe OKUMURA was one of the Senke Jisshoku (The Ten Craftsmen of the House of Sen).

culture.name: KURODA Seigen
culture.desc: Seigen KURODA was one of the Senke Jisshoku (The Ten Craftsmen of the House of Sen), and for generations the name has been passed down through this family of craftsman in bamboo-ware and ladles.

culture.name: Zen Nihon Senchado Renmei (National Japanese Sencha Association)
culture.url: culture/Zen Nihon Senchado Renmei (National Japanese Sencha Association).html
culture.desc: Zen Nihon Senchado Renmei (National Japanese Sencha Association) is an incorporated association founded for the promotion and development of Sencha-do (the way of sencha).

culture.name: Tawawa-chan
culture.desc: Tawawa-chan is the mascot of Kyoto Tower, which is located in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto city.

culture.name: Abura-bo
culture.desc: Abura-bo is a strange light or a ghost known in Shiga and Kyoto prefectures.

culture.name: Garei (artifact spirit)
culture.desc: Garei (literally, the ghost of a picture) are said to be tsukumogami (spirits that inhabit certain objects) where a portrait has been possessed by the spirit of its painter.

culture.name: Goshiki-mame (five-colored roasted sweet beans)
culture.desc: Goshiki-mame (five-colored roasted sweet beans), roasted beans of five different colors covered with a sugar coating, are regarded as a well-known Kyoto confection.

culture.name: Ebi-imo (shrimp potato)
culture.desc: Ebi-imo (literally, shrimp potato) is a sort of taro.

culture.name: Raifuku (the Imperial Court)
culture.desc: Raifuku refers to formal clothes which were used by nobles of the Fifth Rank and higher, and worn at the New Year's court ceremony and new emperor's enthronement ceremony; it was introduced into the Japanese court and modeled after Chinese law.

culture.name: Kyo-gashi (Japanese-style confectionery from Kyoto)
culture.desc: Kyo-gashi means sweets that are made in Kyoto prefecture.

culture.name: Mata-nozoki (bending down and looking at scenery from between one's legs)
culture.url: culture/Mata-nozoki (bending down and looking at scenery from between ones legs).html
culture.desc: Mata-nozoki is one of the methods to enjoy looking at Amanohashidate from Kasamatsu Park or Ama no Hashidate View Land in Miyazu city, in Kyoto prefecture.

culture.name: Saga-giku chrysanthemums (Chrysanthemum grandiflorum cv.Saga)
culture.desc: Saga-giku chrysanthemums (Chrysanthemum grandiflorum cv.Saga) are perennial plants belonging to the family Asteraceae.

culture.name: Yusoku Cuisine
culture.desc: Yusoku cuisine is a type of taikyo ryori (dishes served at a grand banquet) which was developed through the social etiquette of nobles during the Heian period, and survived into the modern day as a cuisine in the style of the court nobles.

culture.name: Kurama Fire Festival
culture.desc: The Kurama Fire Festival is one of the annual festivals at the Yuki-jinja Shrine at Kurama, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Nishiki Market
culture.desc: Nishiki Market is a shopping street which is on Nishikikoji-dori Street between 'Teramachi-dori Street and Takakura-dori Street,' and approximately located in the center of Kyoto City; there are a lot of long-established stores and specialty stores that sell fresh foods like fish and Kyoto vegetables, and processed foods such as dried goods, tsukemono (Japanese pickled vegetables), and obanzai (precooked food in Kyoto dialect).

culture.name: Ushiwakamaru (children's song)
culture.desc: Ushiwakamaru is a children's song.

culture.name: Daisu
culture.desc: Daisu refers to tea equipment used during tea ceremony procedure, or a kind of a display stand for tea ceremony utensils such as mizusashi (cold water jar).

culture.name: Wind God and Thunder God Screens (Fujin Raijin-zu)
culture.url: culture/Wind God and Thunder God Screens (Fujin Raijin-zu).html
culture.desc: Wind God and Thunder God Screens ("Fujin Raijin-zu") is the folding screen painting of the wind god and thunder god.

culture.name: Kyoto Umbrella
culture.desc: The Kyoto Umbrella is one of traditional Japanese umbrellas.

culture.name: Dainihon Chado Gakkai (Tea Ceremony Association)
culture.desc: Dainihon Chado Gakkai is one of the schools of the tea ceremony.

culture.name: Toyoakari no sechie
culture.desc: The Toyoakari no sechie festival is the Imperial Court ceremony held on Daijosai (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor), held on the days of the Rabbit, Dragon, Snake, and Horse (note: yuki no sechie (seasonal court banquet) held on the day of the Dragon, and suki no sechie held on the day of the Snake) as well as on the final day of the Niiname-sai festival (ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities), held on the days of the Rabbit and Dragon.

culture.name: Kameoka Matsuri Festival
culture.desc: The Kameoka Matsuri Festival is a reisai (regular festival) of Kuwayama-jinja Shrine that takes place for three days from October 23 to October 25 annually in Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: The Shijo School of the Way of the Kitchen Knife
culture.url: culture/The Shijo School of the Way of the Kitchen Knife.html
culture.desc: The Shijo School of the Way of the Kitchen Knife ("Shijoryu-Hochodo" in Japanese) is a school of Japanese cuisine which is said to have originated in the Heian period.

culture.name: Kyoto Higashiyama Hanatoro (path with flowers and lanterns)
culture.url: culture/Kyoto Higashiyama Hanatoro (path with flowers and lanterns).html
culture.desc: Kyoto Higashiyama Hana Toro refers to a touristic event to herald the arrival of early spring in the middle of March, that about 2400 lanterns, which are made by Kiyomizu ceramics (traditional handicrafts in Kyoto), Kitayamasugi round cedar wood, Kyomei bamboo, stone art and metal art, are lit on the narrow path for about 4.6 km from Shoren-in Temple to Kiyomizu-dera Temple at the foot of Higashiyama mountain range of Kyoto to enjoy an evening walk.

culture.name: Kaburaya (a whistling arrow)
culture.desc: 鏑矢 (Kaburaya: in rare cases, written as 蕪矢) is the name of an arrow with kabura (to be described later) installed at the end of zoku; the top of an arrow head.

culture.name: Kinu
culture.desc: Kinu is a story of a bird with three legs in the sun; it refers to the bird (kau) and the sun.

culture.name: Gosyodoki
culture.desc: Gosyodoki is a pattern of traditional Japanese clothes.

culture.name: Go Tein Yuigo
culture.desc: Go Tein Yuigo was written by the Emperor Gouda in 1321, and it consists of 21 articles of yuikai or ikai (teachings to posterity) wishing the long prosperity of Daikaku-ji Temple and Shingon Esoteric Buddhism including the details of the erection of Daikaku-ji Temple.

culture.name: Chihana
culture.desc: Chihana (Gion chef-kappo, 'Chihana') is a Kyoto restaurant started by Motoo NAGATA (born in 1923) in 1946.

culture.name: OK
culture.desc: Kyoto ramen is a generic name given to ramen sold and eaten in Kyoto Prefecture, Japan (mainly in Kyoto City and areas to its south) when it is mentioned in magazines and books.

culture.name: Traditional Vegetables of Kyo
culture.desc: Traditional vegetables of Kyo (another name for Kyoto Prefecture) refers to the crops of vegetables that have been certified by the Kyoto Prefecture since the certification began in 1987, and 41 crops of vegetables have been certified so far, including those that are almost equivalent to traditional vegetables of Kyo, and those that are already extinct.

culture.name: Hakata-ori Textile
culture.desc: Hakata-ori textile refers to a silk textile, a local speciality of mainly Hakata in Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture.

culture.name: Toshiya
culture.desc: Toshiya was an event held as part of of Kyujutsu (the Japanese classical martial art of shooting an arrow from a bow at a target).

culture.name: Sakon no Sakura
culture.desc: Sakon no sakura (the cherry tree of Sakon) is a cherry tree which existed in the first bay of the south-east corner to the left of the South floor down from the inner court ceremonial hall of Heian-kyo.

culture.name: Ukon no Tachibana
culture.desc: Ukon no Tachibana (the mandarin orange tree of Ukon) is a mandarin orange tree which existed on the right of the South floor down from the Shishin-den Hall (hall for state ceremonies) of the Imperial Palace in the Heian-kyo.

culture.name: Kanji day
culture.desc: Kanji day is the memorial day, which the Japan Kanji Aptitude Testing Foundation has established in 1995.

culture.name: Kabuki
culture.desc: "Kabuki" is a theater peculiar to Japan, and is one of the traditional performing arts.

culture.name: Soy sauce dumpling
culture.desc: Soy sauce dumpling

culture.name: Inoda Coffee
culture.desc: Inoda Coffee is a chain of coffee shops headquartered in Kyoto City.

culture.name: Konmeichi no shoji (a type of standing screen)
culture.url: culture/Konmeichi no shoji (a type of standing screen).html
culture.desc: Konmeichi no shoji is a tsuitate shoji (a partitioning screen, which stood between Hirobisashi no futama of Seiryo-den Imperial palace and ue no mitsubone - a kind of room).

culture.name: Kitano Grand Tea Ceremony
culture.desc: The Kitano Grand Tea Ceremony on November 1, 1587 organized by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI on the grounds of Kitano Tenmangu Shrine is a large scale tea ceremony.

culture.name: Ima no Tsurugi Sword
culture.desc: In the "Gikeiki Chronicles", "Ima no Tsurugi" sword, a Japanese short sword of 19.7 cm in lengh, was used by MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune in killing himself.

culture.name: OK
culture.desc: Futatsumei Norimune is a Japanese sword believed to have been manufactured by Norimune ICHIMONJI in Bizen Province.

culture.name: Eshi no soshi (picture scroll)
culture.desc: Eshi no soshi (picture scroll) is a Japanese emakimono (an illustrated scroll).

culture.name: Anjo no Goei
culture.desc: Anjo no Goei (or Miei) is a color portrait on silk of Shinran Shonin attributed to Hogen (the second highest rank for Buddhist priests) Choen in 1255 during the Kamakura period.

culture.name: Okoge (Scorch)
culture.desc: Okoge refers to a portion of cooked food that is scorched or food that gets burned.

culture.name: Kaishaku (to assist someone committing hara-kiri by beheading him)
culture.url: culture/Kaishaku (to assist someone committing hara-kiri by beheading him).html
culture.desc: Kaishaku (to assist someone in committing hara-kiri by beheading him) refers to cutting off the head of a person committing Seppuku (Japanese ritual suicide by disembowelment) with a katana (sword) for the purpose of relieving the person's agony of disemboweling.

culture.name: Hichiriki Flute
culture.desc: Hichiriki flute is one of the wind instruments used for gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) and kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines) that was created in modern times following the flow of gagaku.

culture.name: Ju-kyo (Confucianism)
culture.desc: Ju-kyo is a system of thought and religious belief founded by Koshi (Confucius).

culture.name: Shaved Ice (Flavored with Syrup)
culture.desc: Shaved ice is a frozen sweet made from finely shaved or crushed ice that is flavored with syrup, for example.

culture.name: Japanese Calendar
culture.desc: Japanese calendar covers Japanese own subjects relating to calendars.

culture.name: Sekku (Seasonal Festival Days)
culture.desc: "Sekku" (in Chinese characters, written as "節句") means seasonal turning point when a traditional annual event is held, peculiar to Japanese culture and customs.

culture.name: Kamikiri (Paper Cutting Craft)
culture.desc: "Kamikiri" is one of the traditional Japanese performing arts, which shows the performance of cutting a piece of paper in some shape with a pair of scissors.

culture.name: The Milky Way
culture.desc: The Milky Way is a nebular cluster like a shining belt crossing the night sky.

culture.name: Unshu Mikan (Unshu or Unshiu mandarin orange)
culture.url: culture/Unshu Mikan (Unshu or Unshiu mandarin orange).html
culture.desc: Unshu Mikan (Scientific name: Citrus unshiu) is a kind of mandarin orange and evergreen bush belonging to the Rutaceae family.

culture.name: Culture Day
culture.desc: Culture Day (Bunka no hi) is a Japanese national holiday held annually every November 3.

culture.name: Jurojin (Shoulaojen)
culture.desc: Jurojin is a Tao deity (the god).

culture.name: Hot Spring (Onsen)
culture.desc: The term "hot spring "refers to a phenomenon of hot water gushing out from underground, the state of hot water or the place where such phenomenon or state is seen.

culture.name: Manzai or a comic dialogue
culture.desc: Manzai or comic dialogue is a type of entertainment or talk show performed mainly by a comedy duo, which has been uniquely developed in Japan's Kinki region based upon the traditional form of manzai observed on New Year's Day.

culture.name: Karuta
culture.desc: "Karuta" (in Chinese characters, written as "歌留多," "加留多," "嘉留太," or "骨牌") is a kind of a Japanese game using picture cards.

culture.name: Tanabata (Star Festival)
culture.desc: Tanabata (Shichiseki) is one of the days of sekku/sechinichi (a day of the turn of the season) in Japan, China, Taiwan, Vietnam, and Korea.

culture.name: Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins struck in the Ming dynasty)
culture.url: culture/Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins struck in the Ming dynasty).html
culture.desc: Eiraku-tsuho is a coin minted during the reign of the 3rd emperor of the Ming dynasty, Yongle.

culture.name: Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints)
culture.desc: Ukiyoe is a genre of the pictorial arts established during the Edo period.

culture.name: Karatedo
culture.desc: Karatedo (also known as karate), a martial art and a combat sport developed in Okinawa, is characterized as a striking art that uses kicking.

culture.name: Onsen Tamago
culture.desc: Onsen tamago (onsen eggs) are a type of soft boiled egg, or chicken eggs with the yoke soft and the white only half done.

culture.name: The Bon Festival Dance
culture.desc: The Bon festival dance is an event enjoyed in groups at night during the season of Bon, the Buddhist festival for the dead held around the fifteenth of August (or July in some regions).

culture.name: Kintaro
culture.desc: Kintoki is the childhood name of SAKATA no Kintoki (his name is sometimes written as "公時"instead of "金時."

culture.name: Shunbun
culture.desc: Shunbun (Vernal Equinox) is one of the 24 seasons in the solar year.

culture.name: Sake (rice wine)
culture.desc: Sake is a traditional alcoholic drink in Japan that is produced by fermenting rice.

culture.name: Natto (fermented soybeans)
culture.desc: Natto is a Japanese food produced by fermenting soybeans with bacillus subtilis natto.

culture.name: Tofu (bean curd)
culture.desc: Tofu is a food that's made mainly from soybeans.

culture.name: Okonomiyaki (savory pancake with various ingredients)
culture.desc: Okonomiyaki refers to one of the foods grilled on an iron plate.

culture.name: Tsuki-okure
culture.desc: Tsuki-okure means that under the Gregorian calendar (the New Style), dates of annually scheduled Japanese programs or events are deferred one month compared to the Taiin-taiyo-reki (lunisolar calendar) (the Old Style including the Tenpo calendar, the Kansei calendar, the Horyaku calendar, and the Jokyo calendar).

culture.name: Nengajo (New Year's card)
culture.desc: The nengajo is a postcard or a greeting card sent as a New Year's greeting.

culture.name: Ekiben
culture.desc: Ekiben is a box lunch mainly sold at a railway station.

culture.name: Shubun
culture.desc: Shubun (Autumnal equinox) is one of the 24 seasons in the solar year.

culture.name: Doyo no Ushi no Hi (The Ox Day During 'Doyo')
culture.url: culture/Doyo no Ushi no Hi (The Ox Day During Doyo).html
culture.desc: Doyo no ushi no hi' is the Ox day (based on the twelve signs of the Chinese zodiac) during the "doyo" (the period of about 18 days at each end of four seasons).

culture.name: Hanami (Cherry Blossom Viewing)
culture.desc: Hanami is a custom of enjoying the beauty of flowers, especially cherry blossoms and the arrival of spring.

culture.name: Kimosui (Eel Liver Soup)
culture.desc: Kimosui is a clear soup containing the guts of eel as a main ingredient.

culture.name: Unadon or Unagi-donburi (a bowl of boiled rice topped with broiled eel)
culture.url: culture/Unadon or Unagi-donburi (a bowl of boiled rice topped with broiled eel).html
culture.desc: Unadon, or unagi-donburi, is a Japanese cuisine consisting of boiled rice in a bowl topped with kabayaki (broiled eel) and poured tare (a special sauce for broiled eel) on it, and as one's preference, some powdered sansho (Sichuan pepper) added on top.

culture.name: Setsubun or Sechibun (the day before the beginning of a season)
culture.url: culture/Setsubun or Sechibun (the day before the beginning of a season).html
culture.desc: Setsubun,' or 'sechibun,' means the day before the beginning of a season, while the first day of spring, summer, autumn or winter is called 'risshun,' 'rikka,' 'risshu' or 'ritto,' respectively.

culture.name: Higan
culture.desc: The term "higan" refers to enlightenment or escape from earthly desires, and refers to the 'other side' as opposed to the term 'shigan' (this side) which means this world filled with earthly desires and doubt.

culture.name: Hangesho
culture.desc: Hangesho (the eleventh day after the Summer solstice) is one of the seasonal days (zassetsu) in the Japanese calendar and is so-called because it falls around the time that the medicinal herb Lizard's Tail (Crowdipper) flowers (the leaves of the hangesho (also called katashirogusa) also turn white on half the leaf around this time).

culture.name: Hatsu-uma (First Horse Day)
culture.desc: Hatsu-uma refers to the first day of the horse in February.

culture.name: Choyo (Chrysanthemum Festival)
culture.desc: Choyo is a festival observed annually on September 9 as one of the five seasonal festivals in Japan.

culture.name: Tango (the Boys' Festival)
culture.desc: Tango is one of the seasonal festivals held on the 5th day of the 5th month.

culture.name: Iikura
culture.desc: Ikura is salmon roe.

culture.name: Jiuta
culture.desc: Jiuta is a musical piece with shamisen (a three-stringed banjo-like Japanese musical instrument) that was played in the areas of Kyoto and Osaka.

culture.name: Sokyoku (koto music)
culture.desc: Sokyoku refers to music for the koto (long zither with 13 strings).

culture.name: Nagauta
culture.desc: Nagauta is a type of musical genre that first appeared in the Edo period, and it's formal name is therefore Edo Nagauta.

culture.name: Wagakki (traditional Japanese musical instruments)
culture.desc: Wagakki is a term used to refer to traditional musical instruments that have been used in Japan from ancient times.

culture.name: Ametsuchi no Uta (a Japanese pangram)
culture.desc: Ametsuchi no Uta (literally, song of heaven and earth) is a pangram, which contains all the kana (the Japanese syllabary) characters as syllables of song.

culture.name: Ennichi
culture.desc: Ennichi are days when people have a spiritual connection with Shinto or Buddhist deities.

culture.name: Kamaboko
culture.desc: Kamaboko, whose main ingredient is pasted whitefish such as codfish or walleye pollack, is made by mincing whitefish meat, adding salt, heating and turning it into a gel on a wooden board (wood types such as fir or Abies veitchii, which have no odor, are preferred).

culture.name: Hassaku
culture.desc: Hassaku is the abbreviation of hachigatsu sakujitsu which means August 1 on the lunar calendar.

culture.name: Green tea
culture.desc: Green tea (ryokucha, green tea in English, lchá in Chinese) refers the one processed by heating treatment to prevent fermentation, within the tea in which produced from tea leaves.

culture.name: Traditional Japanese Age System
culture.desc: The traditional Japanese age system is one method of calculating age.

culture.name: Shabu-shabu
culture.desc: Shabu-shabu is a Japanese dish in which extremely thin slices of meat are cooked by swishing them back and forth several times in dashi (broth) boiled in a special tabletop pot, dipped in sauce and eaten with boiled ingredients such as vegetables, tofu and kuzukiri.

culture.name: Seijin-shiki ceremony (coming-of-age celebration)
culture.desc: The Seijin-shiki ceremony is an event where local public bodies in Japan invite young people who enter adulthood during the fiscal year when Seijin-shiki is held, in order to encourage and cast blessings upon them.

culture.name: Joshi
culture.desc: Joshi (also called Jomi) is one of five seasonal festivals.

culture.name: Nanakusa (the seven herbs of spring)
culture.desc: The seven herbs of spring (Nanakusa) is a custom of eating hot soup containing seven vegetables on the morning of Jinjitsu no Sekku, the so-called Person-Day Festival (January 7).

culture.name: Shichi-go-san (literally, 7, 5 and 3: a gala day for children of three, five and seven years of age.)
culture.url: culture/Shichi-go-san (literally, 7, 5 and 3 a gala day for children of three, five and seven years of age.).html
culture.desc: Shichi-go-san is an annual event praying for the growth of children of three, five, and seven years of age.

culture.name: Karaoke
culture.desc: Karaoke is a reproduction of a musical performance by musical accompaniment recorded in advance, instead of a live music, when one sings a song or plays a melody part (main part) on an instrument.

culture.name: Senko (incense stick)
culture.desc: The term "Senko (incense stick)" refers to the product which uses, as materials, various substances that emit fragrant smoke and fine aroma when lighted and is produced through the process of grinding materials, kneading, molding into the shape of slender sticks or coils and drying.

culture.name: Wasabi
culture.desc: Wasabi is the plant of Brassicaceae Wasabia.

culture.name: Soup Stock
culture.desc: Soup stock is a liquid seasoning used to add certain tastes--sweetness, sourness, bitterness, saltiness, and particularly the good taste extracted from meat, vegetables, mushrooms, seaweed or others--to dishes.

culture.name: Kelp
culture.desc: Kelp is a kind of seaweed belonging to the Division Heterokontophyta, Class Phaeophyceae, Order Laminariales, Family Laminariaceae.

culture.name: Katsuobushi (A Dried Bonito)
culture.desc: Katsuobushi (dried bonito) is a Japanese preserved food made from bonito.

culture.name: Gyudon
culture.desc: The gyudon (rice covered with beef and vegetables) refers to a cuisine for the common people that consists of a bowl of rice topped with solid pieces of chopped-up pork ribs or pieces of sliced meat simmered with onions in a mixture of sugar and soy sauce.

culture.name: Seaweed
culture.desc: Seaweed (written as 若布, 和布, 稚海藻, or 裙蔕菜 in kanji; scientific name: Undaria pinnatifida) is a marine alga of the class Phaeophyceae, order Laminariales and family Alariaceae.

culture.name: Shochu
culture.desc: Shochu is a kind of distilled liquor amongst alcoholic drinks.

culture.name: Bento (lunch box)
culture.desc: Bento is a kind of portable food and is the equivalent of one meal.

culture.name: Miso Soup
culture.desc: Miso soup is a Japanese dish that is cooked by adding ingredients (called 'gu' or 'mi') such as vegetables and fish in soup, boiling and seasoning with miso.

culture.name: Soymilk
culture.desc: Soymilk is a beverage made by soaking soybeans in water, grinding them, adding water, boiling the mixture down and filtering the grounds.

culture.name: Nikujaga
culture.desc: Nikujaga is a Japanese dish.

culture.name: Sakamai (rice for brewing sake)
culture.desc: Sakamai is rice that is used as a material for sake brewing, mainly for the production of koji (malted rice).

culture.name: Katsudon (bowl of rice topped with deep-fried pork cutlet)
culture.url: culture/Katsudon (bowl of rice topped with deep-fried pork cutlet).html
culture.desc: Katsudon is one of the Japanese rice bowl dishes, in which a bowl of rice is topped with a seasoned pork cutlet.

culture.name: Tonkatsu (breaded, deep-fried pork cutlet)
culture.desc: Tonkatsu is a dish in which pork is coated with flour, beaten egg and breadcrumbs in that order, and then deep fried.

culture.name: Sukiyaki (thin slices of beef, cooked with various vegetables in a table-top cast-iron pan)
culture.url: culture/Sukiyaki (thin slices of beef, cooked with various vegetables in a table-top cast-iron pan).html
culture.desc: "Sukiyaki" is a dish consisting of meat that is broiled (cooked) or boiled in a shallow cast-iron pot.

culture.name: Sento
culture.desc: A sento (public bathhouses) is a facility that offers fee-based bathing.

culture.name: Umeboshi
culture.desc: An "umeboshi" is a shiozuke (a salted food) of ume (Japanese apricots), which is dried in the sun after being preserved in salt.

culture.name: Oyakodon (bowl of rice with chicken and egg)
culture.url: culture/Oyakodon (bowl of rice with chicken and egg).html
culture.desc: Oyakodon is a rice bowl dish that uses boiled chicken and onion in warishita (stock mixed with soy sauce, mirin and sugar) over rice with egg.

culture.name: Someiyoshino
culture.desc: Someiyoshino (scientific name: Prunus x yedoensis) is a type of cherry tree as a garden plant, having been produced by crossbreeding Cerasus spachiana 'Komatsuotome' in the line of Edohigan (P. pendula Maxim. f. ascendens (Makino) Ohwi) and the Oshima cherry (P. lannesiana var. speciosa).

culture.name: Mirin
culture.desc: Mirin is an alcoholic condiment used as a seasoning in Japanese cuisine and also as an alcoholic beverage.

culture.name: Yakiniku
culture.desc: Yakuniku refers to dishes in which meat is cooked on a grill or iron plate.

culture.name: Tamagoyaki (Japanese omelette)
culture.desc: Tamagoyaki is a general term for Japanese egg dishes in which eggs are beaten and cooked in a pan.

culture.name: Kunoichi
culture.desc: Kunoichi indicates female ninja in the jargon of ninja (professional spies in Japan, highly trained in stealth and secrecy), and the use of females as a trick was called kunoichi no jutsu (art of kunoichi).

culture.name: Kagamibiraki
culture.desc: Kagamibiraki is an event held to wish for a peaceful year for the family by cutting a kagamimochi (a large, round rice cake) offered to Toshigami (a god of the incoming year) at the New Year, cooking it in zoni (vegetable soup containing rice cakes) or shiruko (sweet red-bean soup with pieces of rice cake), and eating it.

culture.name: Budo
culture.desc: Budo has developed from a traditional Japanese martial art ("kobudo," old budo), to which has been added the aspect of "geido" (the way of artistic self-discipline), which aims for the perfection of character through practices to hone the skills, to the techniques to kill or conquer others.

culture.name: Niinamesai
culture.desc: Niinamesai (Niiname no matsuri, Shinjosai) is a ritual held each November 23, in which the Emperor offers newly harvested rice to the deities of heaven and earth, eats it and expresses gratitude for the harvest.

culture.name: Honnaoshi
culture.desc: Honnaoshi is a kind of alcoholic drink.

culture.name: Karaage
culture.desc: The term "Karaage" refers to a method of food preparation using frying oil, or the food that is prepared using this method.

culture.name: Kendo (the Japanese art of fencing)
culture.desc: Kendo means Budo (martial art), which was introduced as a competitive sport through the reorganization of Gekken (swordsmanship), which was the Shinai (bamboo sword) training of Kenjutsu (swordplay), a time-honored Japanese Bujutsu (martial art); also, it's a way or ascetic training aiming at character-building through the practice of the Ken (sword with two sharpened edges) principle.

culture.name: Chazuke (a bowl of rice and tea)
culture.url: culture/Chazuke (a bowl of rice and tea).html
culture.desc: Chazuke is a bowl of boiled rice with tea poured over it.

culture.name: Curry and Rice
culture.desc: Curry and rice is a Japanese food which consists of rice and a curry sauce poured over the rice.

culture.name: Nori
culture.desc: Nori is a general term for edible algae such as red alga, green alga, cyanobacteria (blue-green alga) and so on.

culture.name: Tsukudani
culture.desc: Tsukudani are made of sea foods that are boiled in soy sauce and originated in the Tsukuda (in Chuo Ward Tokyo) area of Tokyo.

culture.name: Takoyaki (octopus dumplings)
culture.desc: Takoyaki is a baked ball of wheat flour of three to five centimeters in diameter, into which a small piece of octopus is put, a dish originated in Osaka.

culture.name: Henohenomoheji (へのへのもへじ)
culture.desc: "Henohenomoheji" face-like pictographs are created by playing around with and arranging seven hiragana phonetic syllables to form the caricature of a human face as a picture (letter picture).

culture.name: Desiccated Foods
culture.desc: Desiccated foods are foods that have been dried with the aim of enhancing flavor and storage qualities.

culture.name: Kyudo (Japanese art of archery)
culture.desc: "Kyudo" is a Japanese martial art in which the mind and body are trained through a series of conduct in shooting a Japanese bow and arrow at a target.

culture.name: Toshikoshi-soba
culture.desc: Toshikoshi-soba (Buckwheat Noodles Eaten on New Year's Eve) is a term for buckwheat noodles which are eaten on New Year's Eve (December 31st) for good luck.

culture.name: Omisoka
culture.desc: "Omisoka" (New Year's Eve) means the last day of a year.

culture.name: Sekihan (glutinous rice steamed with red adzuki beans for eating on celebratory occasions)
culture.url: culture/Sekihan (glutinous rice steamed with red adzuki beans for eating on celebratory occasions).html
culture.desc: "Sekihan" means glutinous rice steamed with red adzuki beans or black-eyed peas at the rate of 10 to 20 percent of the total.

culture.name: Osechi-ryori
culture.desc: Osechi-ryori is originally a term used in reference to foods prepared for Sechinichi or Sekku (seasonal festivals).

culture.name: Sansho (Japanese pepper)
culture.desc: Sansho (Japanese pepper; scientific name: Zanthoxylum piperitum) is one of the deciduous shrubs of Rutaceae, Zanthoxylum.

culture.name: Yuzu Citron
culture.desc: Yuzu citron (pronounced "yuzu"; scientific name: Citrus junos, synonym C. ichangensis x C. reticulata var. austera) is a rutaceous evergreen tree.

culture.name: Uiro (a sort of sweetened steamed cake made of rice powder)
culture.url: culture/Uiro (a sort of sweetened steamed cake made of rice powder).html
culture.desc: The term Uiro refers to a sort of sweetened steamed cake made of rice powder.

culture.name: Koya-dofu
culture.desc: Koya-dofu (freeze-dried bean curd) is a food made of preserved tofu.

culture.name: Shakuhachi
culture.desc: The shakuhachi is a traditional Japanese musical instrument.

culture.name: Soh (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings)
culture.url: culture/Soh (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings).html
culture.desc: Soh is a Japanese traditional musical instrument.

culture.name: Sankyoku Gasso
culture.desc: "Sankyoku gasso" means the ensemble made up of "sankyoku" (instrumental trio); originally, the trio was "shamisen" (also called "sangen," the three-string Japanese banjo) for accompanying "Jiuta" (songs of the country), "koto" (the long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) and "kokyu" (the Chinese fiddle), but it also means the ensemble music itself.

culture.name: Sangen
culture.desc: "Sangen" is another name for the shamisen, a Japanese traditional musical instrument.

culture.name: Joruri
culture.desc: In Buddhism, Joruri means shojo (purity) or transparent lapis lazuli.

culture.name: Japanese local dishes
culture.desc: The term 'local dishes' refers to home cooked dishes that have existed for a long time as part of a culinary culture in a certain area or district.

culture.name: Daidarabocchi (a giant in Japanese mythology)
culture.desc: Daidarabocchi is a mythological giant which is handed down in many parts of Japan (a creature in legend).

culture.name: Shoronagashi
culture.desc: Shoronagashi is an event held during the Obon festival (a Festival of the Dead or Buddhist All Soul's Day in mid-August) in different parts of Nagasaki Prefecture.

culture.name: Butajiru
culture.desc: Butajiru (Tonjiru) is a Japanese cuisine that is prepared by stewing pork and vegetables with miso (bean paste).

culture.name: Aburaage
culture.desc: Aburaage is a food consisting of sliced tofu (bean curd) fried in oil.

culture.name: Zoni
culture.desc: Zoni is a soup dish which contains mochi (rice cakes) and other ingredients, and it is usually eaten in the New Year.

culture.name: Toso
culture.desc: Toso is the name for medicinal alcoholic beverages that people drink on New Year's Day in the hope of being free from noxious bad spirits that cause illness and other misfortunes during the coming year, as well as for their longevity.

culture.name: Sarugaku
culture.desc: Sarugaku is a Japanese art form that was popular during the Heian and Muromachi periods.

culture.name: Kakizome
culture.desc: Kakizome is a festival for calligraphy and drawing pictures, during which one uses brushes for the first time since the start of the new year.

culture.name: Koshogatsu
culture.desc: Koshogatsu is the day of mochi no hi in the New Year (January 15th of the old lunar calendar, or the first full moon of the New Year).

culture.name: Shigoto hajime (the first business day of the year)
culture.url: culture/Shigoto hajime (the first business day of the year).html
culture.desc: "Shigoto hajime" means working on January 2, for the first time in the new year.

culture.name: Ganjitsu no sechie (New Year's Festival)
culture.desc: "Ganjitsu no sechie" is one of the ancient events for the New Year.

culture.name: Kagami-mochi
culture.desc: Kagami-mochi is a circular, flat rice cake offered to Shinto and Buddhist deities on occasions such as the New Year.

culture.name: Hishihanabira Mochi (Water Chestnut Petal Sticky Rice Cakes)
culture.url: culture/Hishihanabira Mochi (Water Chestnut Petal Sticky Rice Cakes).html
culture.desc: Hishihanabira Mochi (Water chestnut petal sticky rice cakes) are a traditional Japanese confectionary made by wrapping burdock root, white miso paste and pink colored mochi (sticky rice cake) in either sticky rice cake or Turkish delight.

culture.name: Hatsuuri (the first sale of the year)
culture.url: culture/Hatsuuri (the first sale of the year).html
culture.desc: "Hatsuuri" means that retailers start business for the first time in the new year.

culture.name: Yumiya (bow and arrow)
culture.desc: The term "Yumiya" refers to a tool for hunting which consists of bow (weapon) and arrow.

culture.name: Hagoita (battledore) Racquets
culture.desc: Hagoita (battledore) are long oblong pieces of wood with a handle.

culture.name: Hamaya
culture.desc: Hamaya is an arrow given as a lucky charm of the New Year by a temple and/or a Shinto shrine.

culture.name: Ichimi-togarashi
culture.desc: Ichimi-togarashi (cayenne pepper powder) is a seasoning made of dried red pepper ground into powder form.

culture.name: Aikido (the art of weaponless self-defense)
culture.desc: "Aikido" is a modern martial art founded by Morihei UESHIBA early in the Showa period.

culture.name: Yakitori (grilled chicken)
culture.desc: Yakitori is a food consisting of several bite-size chunks (from one to five or so) of meat (mainly chicken) that are seasoned and grilled on skewers.

culture.name: Tsukune (meatloaf)
culture.desc: Tsukune is a food consisting of ground livestock meat or chicken (fish meat in rare cases) and a thickener that are kneaded or ground together and formed into a ball or stick shape.

culture.name: Koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings)
culture.url: culture/Koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings).html
culture.desc: The koto (also called the 'kin') is a Japanese traditional musical instrument.

culture.name: Kudzukiri (noodles made from kudzu flour and sugar)
culture.url: culture/Kudzukiri (noodles made from kudzu flour and sugar).html
culture.desc: Kudzukiri, a noodle for eating, is made with heated kudzu flour that has been dissolved in water and then set into a board shape by cooling, after which it is cut into long, thin forms udon (Japanese wheat noodles).

culture.name: Korokke (Potato Croquette)
culture.desc: Korokke is a kind of deep fried dish.

culture.name: Imagawa-yaki (Japanese pastry)
culture.desc: Imagawa-yaki is a pastry which is made by baking batter in molds.

culture.name: Taiyaki (Japanese pastry)
culture.desc: Taiyaki is a Japanese sweet made by baking batter in sea bream shaped molds, and it is mainly manufactured, sold and eaten in Japan.

culture.name: Tsuina
culture.desc: Tsuina is an annual event held on New Year's Eve (December 30 according to the old calendar) in the Imperial Court, and this ceremony of onibarai (to expel ogres) has been held since the early Heian period.

culture.name: Tarako (salted cod roe)
culture.desc: Tarako refers to the ovary (roe) of cod.

culture.name: Giccho
culture.desc: Giccho is a game in which one party smashes a wooden ball aimed at the other party's side by swinging a wooden cane with a wooden mallet head at the end.

culture.name: Kyoto Shimbun (a newspaper based in Kyoto, Japan)
culture.url: culture/Kyoto Shimbun (a newspaper based in Kyoto, Japan).html
culture.desc: Kyoto Shimbun is a local newspaper published mainly in Kyoto and Shiga Prefectures.

culture.name: Maneki-neko (a welcoming cat)
culture.desc: A "maneki-neko" is an ornament in the shape of a cat beckoning with a forepaw.

culture.name: Yuzu kosho (a spicy, hot Japanese condiment made from yuzu rind, chili and salt)
culture.url: culture/Yuzu kosho (a spicy, hot Japanese condiment made from yuzu rind, chili and salt).html
culture.desc: "Yuzu kosho" (also called Yuzu gosho) is a type of condiment that is made by seasoning a paste of chili and yuzu peel with salt and then matured.

culture.name: Karasumi
culture.desc: Karasumi is a food product made from fish roe, which is first salted down and then sun-dried after some of the salt is removed in water.

culture.name: Kusazoshi Style Illustrated Pulp Books
culture.desc: Kusazoshi illustrated pulp books are a form of light popular literature of the Edo period with pictures taking centre stage supported by story outlines written in phonetic Japanese.

culture.name: Nohgaku
culture.desc: Nohgaku is a Japanese traditional performing art.

culture.name: Shiokara (salted fish guts)
culture.desc: Shiokara is a preserved food made from flesh of seafood, salted mostly with the guts in order to prevent rot, fermented and matured with the aid of enzymes (an autolyzed enzyme and ones possessed by the internal microorganisms).

culture.name: Tendon
culture.desc: Tendon is a bowl of rice topped with pieces of tenpura.

culture.name: Treatises on Artistic Accomplishments
culture.desc: Treatises on Artistic Accomplishments were written records spanning the Heian period (794-1185) through to around the Edo period (1603-1868) relating to the pursuit of: Japanese traditional Waka poetry, Noh drama, flower arrangement (kado), tea ceremony (sado), incense ceremony (kodo), martial arts etc.

culture.name: Kanten (agar, or agar agar)
culture.desc: "Kanten" (agar, or agar agar) is made from frozen and dried mucilage of red algae such as tengusa (agar weed) and ogonori (Chinese moss).

culture.name: Sencha (green tea)
culture.desc: Sencha is a kind of Japanese tea.

culture.name: Tencha (powdered green tea)
culture.desc: Tencha is a kind of steamed green tea.

culture.name: Gyokuro (refined green tea)
culture.desc: Gyokuro is a kind of Japanese tea.

culture.name: Wakyu (Japanese bow)
culture.desc: Wakyu is the Chokyu (long bow) (weapon) used in Japanese Kyudo (Japanese art of archery).

culture.name: Cherry Blossom Front
culture.desc: Cherry Blossom Front is a line graph illustrating the forecasted blooming dates of cherry blossoms (primarily of Someiyoshino (Prunus yedoensis)) in various locations of Japan.

culture.name: Uchiwa Fan
culture.desc: Uchiwa fan (団扇 in Chinese character) is a tool to make a wind by fanning it.

culture.name: Iaido (art of drawing the Japanese sword)
culture.url: culture/Iaido (art of drawing the Japanese sword).html
culture.desc: Iaido is a kind of martial art that was developed from the battojutsu (technique of drawing a sword) called Iai.

culture.name: Okara (bean curd residue)
culture.desc: Okara is a food peculiar to countries in East Asia, such as Japan, the People's Republic of China, and the Republic of Korea.

culture.name: Jujutsu (The traditional Japanese martial arts)
culture.desc: Jujutsu is the name for traditional Japanese martial arts, which are centered on offense and defense techniques with no (or a small) weapon.

culture.name: Dohyo
culture.desc: Dohyo is a term used to refer to sumo rings made up of clay.

culture.name: Seppuku
culture.desc: Seppuku is a method of suicide that involves cutting the abdomen with a sword.

culture.name: Shusseuo (fish called by different names at different stages of its growth)
culture.url: culture/Shusseuo (fish called by different names at different stages of its growth).html
culture.desc: "Shusseuo" is a term used in Japan to refer to fishes that are called by different names depending on their growth stage, from an alevin to an adult fish.

culture.name: Hazakura
culture.desc: Hazakura is a term that refers to cherry trees during the period after the cherry blossom falls and the trees start to sprout new leaves until the cherry trees are totally covered with new leaves of tender green, or to such scenes.

culture.name: Myoga
culture.desc: Myoga is a term that refers to a herbaceous perennial belong to the family Zingiberaceae, genus Zingiber (scientific name: Zingiber mioga).

culture.name: Mustard
culture.desc: Mustard is a spice made from the seeds of Brassica juncea and related species.

culture.name: Sakurayu (cherry-blossom tea)
culture.desc: Sakurayu is a hot drink with a salt-preserved cherry blossom in it.

culture.name: Koboku (fragrant wood)
culture.desc: Koboku is kind of wood that gives off a pleasant aroma.

culture.name: Koi-nobori (carp streamer)
culture.desc: Koi-nobori was originally a Japanese custom that started among samurai families in the Edo period.

culture.name: Tazukuri
culture.desc: Tazukuri (also called tatsukuri) is a dried or cooked product of young anchovies.

culture.name: Kiriboshi Daikon
culture.desc: Kiriboshi daikon (or simply called kiriboshi) is a dried product of daikon (Japanese radish).

culture.name: Amanatto
culture.desc: Amanatto, a Japanese-style cake, is candied beans, chestnuts, lotuses, and sweet potatoes cut into round slices (called Imo natto).

culture.name: Mezashi
culture.desc: Mezashi is a dried fish product.

culture.name: Tade
culture.desc: Tade (polygonum, called water pepper in English, scientific name: Persicaria hydropiper) is polygonaceous an annual grass.

culture.name: Kanroni
culture.desc: Kanroni is one of boiled and seasoned dishes.

culture.name: Kashiwamochi
culture.desc: Kashiwamochi is a Japanese confectionery made by doubling a flatly rounded rice cake, putting bean jam in the middle, and wrapping it in an oak leaf or a leaf of Smilacaceae.

culture.name: Shirako (milt)
culture.desc: Shirako is the name of the milt of fish when the milt is used as ingredients in various dishes.

culture.name: Ganmodoki
culture.desc: Ganmodoki is one of processed foods made of tofu (bean curd).

culture.name: Kaiseki
culture.desc: A distinct strand of Japanese cuisine, kaiseki is introduced below.

culture.name: Genmaicha
culture.desc: Genmaicha is a mixture of almost the same amount of bancha (coarse tea) or occasionally sencha green tea heated at high temperatures, and brown rice steamed and roasted until it gets a light ginger color or bursts like popcorn.

culture.name: Ishiyaki Imo
culture.desc: Ishiyaki imo (stone-roasted sweet potato) is a dish using sweet potatoes.

culture.name: Kakiage
culture.desc: Kakiage is a kind of tenpura, a Japanese deep-fried dish, where several kinds of seafood and vegetables are deep-fried in batter.

culture.name: Low-malt beer
culture.desc: Low-malt beer is a type of alcohol defined by the Japanese Liquor Tax Act.

culture.name: Mizuame
culture.desc: Mizuame is a mucoid sweetener made by saccharifying acid and diastatic enzymes with starch.

culture.name: Chabudai
culture.desc: Chabu (chabudai), also known as Shippoku, is a Chinese-style table.

culture.name: Kisha
culture.desc: Kisha means to shoot an arrow or other weapon while riding a horse.

culture.name: Shuriken (Small Throwing Blade)
culture.desc: A shuriken is a small weapon shaped like a sword or needle, thrown at an opponent to diminish the fighting power of an enemy.

culture.name: Yokan (adzuki-bean jelly)
culture.desc: Yokan, in general, is a Japanese confection which is made by jellifying bean jam, mainly made from adzuki beans, with Japan agar.

culture.name: Tanin-don
culture.desc: Tanin-don or tanin-donburi is a dish in which beef or pork that is boiled with onions in a stock mixed with soy sauce, mirin and sugar, stiffened with eggs, and then placed on donburi meshi (a bowl of boiled rice).

culture.name: Rotensho
