culture.desc: "Rotensho" (露天商) are people who do business outside or under the sun, and who have no store.

culture.name: Fuji Musume (Wisteria Maiden)
culture.desc: Fuji Musume can refer to the following.

culture.name: Biwa
culture.desc: Biwa (biwa, biba, pipa) is one of the stringed instruments of the lute family in East Asia.

culture.name: Konowata
culture.desc: Konowata is salted guts of a sea cucumber.

culture.name: Anmitsu
culture.desc: Anmitsu is a kind of Japanese confectionery, which is mitsumame dessert (boiled beans, cubes of agar gelatin, and other delicacies with molasses poured on) covered with bean jam.

culture.name: Kaiseki Ryori
culture.desc: This page describes kaiseki ryori, a full course meal form of Japanese cuisine.

culture.name: Jinya
culture.desc: A jinya is a residence where a government office was located of the domain (han) of a daimyo (territorial lord) under the shogunate system in the Edo period, or a building acting as the residence and office of the daikan (local governor) of a tenryo (bakufu-owned piece of land).

culture.name: Uchitachi
culture.desc: Uchitachi is a term used in martial arts, especially in swordplay and budo (Japanese martial arts) such as in the Japanese art of fencing.

culture.name: Oharae
culture.desc: Oharae (the great purification) is an event of removing calamity held on June 30 and December 31.

culture.name: Hijiki
culture.desc: Hijiki (scientific name: Sargassum fusiforme, synonym: Hizikia fusiformis) is a kind of seaweed of the Class Phaeophyceae Family Sargassaceae Genus Sargassum.

culture.name: Green Laver
culture.desc: Green laver is a seaweed of the Green algae Class Family Ulvaceae Genus Enteromorpha, and is a generic term for Enteromorpha prolifera, Enteromorpha linza, Enteromorpha compressa, Enteromorpha intestinalis, and the like.

culture.name: Torisashi
culture.desc: Torisashi is chicken sashimi, or raw chicken meat, which is popular in the southern part of Kyushu region such as Kagoshima and Miyazaki Prefectures.

culture.name: Kangeiko
culture.desc: The term Kangeiko means training of martial arts or geigoto (accomplishment) conducted in mid-winter season.

culture.name: Katsu-Curry
culture.desc: Katsu-curry is a kind of Japanese dish called "curry and rice."

culture.name: Kobucha
culture.desc: Kobucha (Konbucha) is a beverage prepared by pouring hot water onto thinly sliced/powdered dry konbu (kelp).

culture.name: Tatami-iwashi (dried baby sardines flattened like paper)
culture.url: culture/Tatami-iwashi (dried baby sardines flattened like paper).html
culture.desc: Tatami-iwashi is a processed food of baby sardines whose production process consists of cleaning and sifting, either before or after boiling, with a reed screen or fine mesh on a wooden frame, then drying them in the sun and forming them into a thin sheet (net-like).

culture.name: Tokoroten
culture.desc: Tokoroten, written in Japanese as ところてん, 心太, 心天, or 瓊脂, is food made by boiling seaweed such as tengusa (Gelidiaceae) and ogonori (Chinese moss) until they melt and produce agar, which is then cooled down until set.

culture.name: Uchimizu
culture.desc: Uchimizu is an old Japanese custom of watering gardens and/or streets.

culture.name: Ennen
culture.desc: Ennen is a Japanese art which was performed by monks and chigo (child in a Buddhist possession) at temples after Daihoe (great Buddhist memorial service).

culture.name: Kanpyo
culture.desc: Kanpyo (dried gourd shavings) is a food that is produced through the process of tearing the fruits (called fukube) of cucurbitaceous yugao (a white flowered gourd) and drying them (yugao of convolvuluses family (=yorugao) is another plant with the same name).

culture.name: Sangaku
culture.desc: Sangaku, which was imported from the Asian continent into Japan in the Nara period, is the collective name of various amusement arts including, but not limited to, mimicry, acrobatics/stunt, trick, magic, puppet show and Japanese dancing.

culture.name: Kiichi Hogen
culture.desc: Kiichi Hogen was a legendary person who appeared in "Gikeiki" (a military epic about the life of MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune) written in the early Muromachi period.

culture.name: Doga
culture.desc: The term Doga means pictures drawn by adults for children.

culture.name: Award of the Japan Art Academy
culture.url: culture/Award of the Japan Art Academy.html
culture.desc: The Award of the Japan Art Academy refers to the awards presented by the Japan Art Academy.

culture.name: Kyo Odori
culture.desc: Kyo Odori (Kyoto Dance) is played in Miyagawa-cho Kaburenjo Theater between early April and late April.

culture.name: Chikuwa
culture.desc: Chikuwa is baked or steamed fishcake, in which fish paste is wrapped around stick or bamboo stick.

culture.name: Denbu
culture.desc: Denbu (mashed and seasoned fish with white flesh or the mixture of fish with white flesh and shrimp that has been boiled, parched, seasoned and colored with red food coloring) is a processed food made from fish or livestock meat.

culture.name: Hanpen (a white, square shaped fish paste)
culture.url: culture/Hanpen (a white, square shaped fish paste).html
culture.desc: Hanpen is kneaded fish cake made of fish such as suketo cod (Alaska Pollock) mixed with grated yam with seasonings, which is then made into thin squares or half moon shapes and boiled.

culture.name: Chirimenjako (small dried fish)
culture.desc: Chirimenjako (small dried fish) is small, young fish, such as type of sardines (anchovy, maiwashi, urume iwashi, shirouo sardine, ikanago), cooked in salted water and dried in the sun.

culture.name: Jizo-bon (an event to commemorate Jizo as the protector of children)
culture.url: culture/Jizo-bon (an event to commemorate Jizo as the protector of children).html
culture.desc: Jizo-bon is the day of the festival of Jizo Bosatsu (24th of each month), or the period of three days before the evening festival on July 24 of the old calender in the Obon festival, or it also means the day of the festival of Jizo Bosatsu, which is chosen from the days of the festival.

culture.name: Shinai
culture.desc: Shinai is a substitute sword made of bamboo used in the Japanese martial art of kendo for training or for hitting or pushing against armor (Kendo) in tournaments.

culture.name: Tororo Konbu (Kelp Shavings)
culture.desc: Tororo konbu is a foodstuff made by processing kelp.

culture.name: Fukufokuju (the god of happiness (fuku), wealth (roku) and long life (ju) with an elongated head)
culture.url: culture/Fukufokuju (the god of happiness (fuku), wealth (roku) and long life (ju) with an elongated head).html
culture.desc: Fukurokuju is one of the Seven Deities of Good Fortune.

culture.name: Tekiya
culture.desc: Tekiya are merchants who sell items such as food or toys on the street or stalls set up in the ground of shrines or temples, on the approach to them or in temple towns during festivals, markets, and fairs.

culture.name: Rakugan (Confectionery)
culture.desc: Rakugan is one of representative Japanese confectionery, and made by mixing flour of starch derived from rice or the like with starch syrup and sugar to apply coloring, and drying in a mold.

culture.name: Kagurabue flute
culture.desc: Kagurabue flute is a wind instrument used in the performance of gagaku (ancient Japanese court music).

culture.name: Ryuteki flute
culture.desc: Ryuteki flute is a wind instrument used in the performance of gagaku (ancient Japanese court music).

culture.name: Yuzen
culture.desc: Yuzen is a technique to dye cloth with patterns on it.

culture.name: The Rinpa School
culture.desc: The Rinpa school refers to artists and craftsmen in the Edo period who used a similar style, including Sotatsu TAWARAYA and Korin OGATA.

culture.name: Yuba (bean curd skin)
culture.desc: Yuba is a processed food made from soybeans.

culture.name: Shiruko (Sweet Red Bean Soup)
culture.desc: Shiruko is a food whose main ingredient is boiled red beans sweetened with sugar, and in which mochi (rice cake), shiratama dango (Japanese rice-flour dumplings), and chestnuts stewed in syrup are added.

culture.name: Irome (color combinations)
culture.desc: Irome refers to color combinations used in juni-hitoe (the ceremonial attire of a Japanese court lady consisting originally of twelve layers of unlined kimono worn one on top of another) and so on.

culture.name: Fu
culture.desc: "Fu" refers to a processed food made with wheat gluten being the main ingredient.

culture.name: Nito-ryu
culture.desc: The term "nito-ryu" (two-sword fencing) is a general term for the technique of offense and defense with Japanese swords or other swords in both hands (left and right hands).

culture.name: Surume (Dried Squid)
culture.desc: Surume is a processed food made by drying in the shade or machine-drying the squid whose internal organs have been removed.

culture.name: Konpeito (confetti)
culture.desc: Konpeito is small ball-shaped candy with horn-like prongs on the surface made from sugar and flavored liquids.

culture.name: Bonsai
culture.desc: Bonsai is an inclusive term referring to plants planted in a pot, their foliage, shape of leaves, bark on the trunk, roots and the pot, and also to the hobby of enjoying all of this form.

culture.name: Karinto (fried-dough cookies)
culture.desc: Karinto is a type of sweets and the recipe is as follows: Knead wheat flour together with other ingredients such as sugar, water, yeast, salt and baking soda into a ball of dough, fry the dough rolled into a long thin stick in vegetable oil, coat with syrup made from brown sugar or superfine sugar and dry.

culture.name: Kintsuba
culture.desc: Kintsuba is an abbreviated term for Kintsuba-yaki which is a type of Japanese confectionery.

culture.name: Eshi
culture.desc: The term "eshi," written as "絵師" in Japanese, refers to those who vocationally paint original pictures for ukiyo-e (Japanese colored woodblock prints in the Edo period).

culture.name: Dried Fish
culture.desc: Himono (dried fish) is a generic term for processed foods made by drying various sea foods such as fish.

culture.name: Kintaroame (Kintaro Candy)
culture.desc: Kintaroame is a bar of candy that is produced using a special technique.

culture.name: Naginata
culture.desc: Naginata (wielding techniques) is a modern martial art, using a wooden or bamboo sword which looks like the old Japanese weapon called "naginata" (originally, a pole with a wood shaft and a curved blade on its end).

culture.name: Rice Omelet (Omu rice)
culture.desc: A rice omelet is a rice dish of Japanese origin; it is chicken fried rice (or plain butter-fried rice) seasoned with ketchup and wrapped up with a thin round crepe of fried eggs, which is categorized as yoshoku (Western food) in Japan.

culture.name: Kodachijutsu
culture.desc: "Kodachijutsu" (swordsmanship of a short sword) is a swordplay style using a wakizashi (the shorter one of the two swords people used to carry on the waist).

culture.name: Daimonji yaki
culture.desc: Daimonji yaki is an event in which bonfires are arranged so that they form a Kanji character '大' (Dai means big).

culture.name: Tekagami
culture.desc: "Tekagami" is a collection of dankan (fragmentary pieces of a writing) written in kohitsu (ancient calligraphy), which are stuck on a folding book made from thick papers.

culture.name: Bonenkai (year-end party)
culture.desc: Bonenkai (literally, forget-the-year party) is an annual event held at the end of the year by an organization or group to give those attending a chance to look back at the past year and show their appreciation for the hardships they have each endured, before forgetting the current year and committing themselves to making a fresh start in the upcoming year.

culture.name: Shinnenkai (new year gathering)
culture.desc: Shinnenkai is an annual event of an organization or a group held at the beginning of the new year.

culture.name: Sashiko
culture.desc: "Sashiko" (an old needlework technology) is one area of handcrafts, embroidering patterns such as geometrical designs on fabrics with threads.

culture.name: Ie No Gei (the showpiece of a school of the performing arts)
culture.url: culture/Ie No Gei (the showpiece of a school of the performing arts).html
culture.desc: Ie No Gei (literally, performance of a family) means performances or repertories of traditional performing arts such as Noh, Kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle), Joruri (Ballad drama), Kabuki, Kabuki Buyo (Kabuki Dance) and Kamigata mai dance, which have been passed down by the family recognized as the iemoto (the head family of a school) for generations, and especially the family has a good skill to perform them.

culture.name: Wakatakeni
culture.desc: Wakatakeni (simmered bamboo shoots and seaweed) is one of the Japanese "nimono" (simmered foods).

culture.name: Nerikiri (a cake made of white bean jam which is artistically colored or shaped)
culture.url: culture/Nerikiri (a cake made of white bean jam which is artistically colored or shaped).html
culture.desc: Nerikiri (literally, made by kneading) is a Japanese type of unbaked cake that is made by mixing and kneading its ingredients, which are white bean jam, gyuhi (a kind of rice cake made from refined rice flour or glutinous rice flour with sugar and starch syrup) and Chinese yam.

culture.name: Nihon-ga
culture.desc: Nihon-ga (Japanese style painting) is a genre of painting unique to Japan.

culture.name: Geta
culture.desc: Geta (Japanese wooden sandals) is Japanese traditional footwear, and is put on by putting feet on wooden boards and fixing toes with a strap which is called O (or Hanao).

culture.name: Seibo (year-end gift) or (end of the year)
culture.url: culture/Seibo (year-end gift) or (end of the year).html
culture.desc: Seibo is a season word expressing the end of a year as the kanji of seibo means, also it is a season word for December.

culture.name: Yuan Yaki (a kind of grilled fish or meat)
culture.url: culture/Yuan Yaki (a kind of grilled fish or meat).html
culture.desc: Yuan yaki is a kind of yakimono (grilled fish or meat) of Japanese cuisine.

culture.name: Rikyuage
culture.desc: Rikyuage is a kind of agemono (deep-fried food) of Japanese cuisine.

culture.name: Furofuki Daikon
culture.desc: Furofuki daikon is simmered Japanese radish, which is often served with Miso sauce.

culture.name: Teriyaki (grilling with soy sauce and sugar)
culture.url: culture/Teriyaki (grilling with soy sauce and sugar).html
culture.desc: Teriyaki is a cooking technique used in Japanese cuisine.

culture.name: Hotei
culture.desc: Hotei is originally the name of a legendary Buddhist monk who actually lived in Mingzhou (now Zhejiang Province, China) in the late Tang Dynasty period.

culture.name: Mizuhiki
culture.desc: Mizuhiki is a string to decorate gifts and envelopes and varies in shape and color depending on the intended purpose of use.

culture.name: Mitsumame
culture.desc: Mitsumame is one of Japanese style sweets or desserts.

culture.name: Manzai
culture.desc: Manzai is a kind of traditional art in Japan.

culture.name: Hanetsuki (Japanese badminton)
culture.desc: Hanetsuki, with a history of 1,300 years, is one of traditional games often played in New Year's Holidays in Japan, and is a girls' game or action for good luck where two players bandy a fletched soapberry seed with Hagoita (battledore).

culture.name: Yuzuyu (Japanese citron hot water)
culture.desc: Yuzuyu refers to the drink made by boiling yuzu (citrus fruit) in sugared water and diluting the sugared water seasoned with the yuzu flavor with hot water (yuzu tea).

culture.name: Namasu
culture.desc: Namasu is the dish made by thinly cutting (or slicing) sea foods, vegetables or fruits and dressing them with seasoning materials based mainly on vinegar.

culture.name: Namaribushi
culture.desc: Namaribushi or Namabushi is a primary processed food made of raw bonito, which is cut, steamed, and boiled.

culture.name: Tataki
culture.desc: Tataki is a cooking method used mainly for preparing fish.

culture.name: Moromi
culture.desc: "もろみ (moromi) also spelled as醪・諸味" refers to the softly solidified product where the ingredients in the brewed liquid for making soy sauce, sake and so on fermented.

culture.name: Hare and Ke
culture.desc: The dichotomy of 'hare and ke' is a traditional world-view of Japanese people accompanied by time theory.

culture.name: Japanese Culture
culture.desc: Japanese culture

culture.name: Sakuramochi
culture.desc: Sakuramochi is a variety of wagashi, or Japanese confectionery, covered with a leaf of sakura (Japanese flowering cherry).

culture.name: OK
culture.desc: Geido refers to the performance of arts and handicrafts in a systematized way that is uniquely Japanese.

culture.name: Daikon Oroshi
culture.desc: Daikon oroshi is a food made by grating daikon radish with an oroshigane (Japanese grater).

culture.name: Zenzai
culture.desc: Zenzai refers to stewed red beans sweetened with sugar that are served in a bowl with mochi (sticky rice cake), shiratama dango (dumplings made of sticky rice flour called shiratamako), and chestnuts stewed in sugar.

culture.name: kayu
culture.desc: Kayu (porridge) is a dish made by boiling grains such as rice seeds, foxtail millet and buckwheat, beans or potatoes in a large quantity of water until they become soft.

culture.name: Awayuki (kind of Japanese confectionery)
culture.desc: A kind of Japanese confectionery, awayuki, or awayuki-kan, is likened to light snow and it has a texture like snow melting in the mouth.

culture.name: Hiyamugi
culture.desc: Hiyamugi is a type of noodle made of wheat flour.

culture.name: OK
culture.desc: OK

culture.name: Tejime
culture.desc: Tejime is a Japanese custom of rhythmic hand clapping performed in time with the calls of one participant in order to celebrate the fact that an event has concluded without trouble.

culture.name: Irizake
culture.desc: Irizake is an old Japanese seasoning used during the Edo period, which is made by putting umeboshi (pickled Japanese apricot) into Japanese sake (rice wine), and boiling it down.

culture.name: Issunboshi (The Inch-High Samurai)
culture.desc: Issunboshi is one of the old tales of Japan.

culture.name: Kanchumimai (a winter greeting card)
culture.desc: Kanchumimai (a winter greeting card) is one of the Japanese customs.

culture.name: Chawan-mushi (steamed egg hotchpotch)
culture.desc: Chawan-mushi is one of the Japanese cuisines.

culture.name: Sansenke
culture.desc: The name 'Sansenke' refers to the Omotesenke, Urasenke, and Mushanokojisenke schools of the Japanese tea ceremony.

culture.name: Sho
culture.desc: The sho is a type of wind instrument used in gagaku (Court music in Japan).

culture.name: Funa-zushi (crucian carp sushi)
culture.desc: Funa-zushi, a local specialty of Shiga Prefecture, is a type of nare zushi (fermented sushi) made with crucian carp.

culture.name: Kaya
culture.desc: A kaya (mosquito net) is a box-shaped net that offers protection against harmful insects such as mosquitoes.

culture.name: Sakekasu
culture.desc: Sakekasu (sake lees) is the solid white substance that remains after pressing the main fermenting mash used to make Japanese sake (rice wine)

culture.name: Japonism
culture.desc: Japonism (Japonisme in French) is a term for an interest in and an appreciation for Japanese arts that appeared in Europe.

culture.name: Hibachi
culture.desc: Hibachi are a kind of charcoal burning brazier used in Japan as a heating appliance.

culture.name: Saijiki (literary calendar)
culture.desc: Saijiki are books on the matters related with annual events by the national and local, or various organizations, and scenery and customs.

culture.name: Shugi
culture.desc: The term 'goshugi' is also used, with 'go' being an honorific prefix.

culture.name: Hishi Mochi (red, white, and green lozenge-shaped rice cakes)
culture.url: culture/Hishi Mochi (red, white, and green lozenge-shaped rice cakes).html
culture.desc: Hishi mochi is a kind of Japanese confectionery.

culture.name: Monaka
culture.desc: Monaka is a kind of Japanese sweets of bean jam wrapped with thin wafers made from rice cake.

culture.name: Bunbu Ichido
culture.desc: Bunbu ichido (literally 'the single path of the cultural and martial arts') means that both scholarship and martial arts (sports) are essentially the same, unlike bunbu ryodo (the dual path of the cultural and martial arts).

culture.name: Miki (Sacred Wine or Sake)
culture.desc: Miki (also referred to as 'shinshu') is alcohol (generally Japanese sake) offered to Shinto deities.

culture.name: shirozake (Japanese sake)
culture.desc: Shirozake refers to a sake served to celebrate the Hinamatsuri (the Doll's Festival).

culture.name: Teishoku (set meal)
culture.desc: Teishoku is a style of serving food frequently found in Japanese restaurants.

culture.name: Akumochizake
culture.desc: Akumochizake or akumochishu is a type of Japanese sake manufactured by adding charcoal to the fermented unrefined sake.

culture.name: Tamago Kake Gohan (egg-sauce over rice consisting of boiled rice topped or mixed with raw egg and optionally soy sauce)
culture.url: culture/Tamago Kake Gohan (egg-sauce over rice consisting of boiled rice topped or mixed with raw egg and op.html
culture.desc: Tamago kake gohan is a rice food prepared by mixing a raw hen's egg and rice and seasoning it with a small amount of soy sauce.

culture.name: Japanese Doll
culture.desc: Japanese doll is the general term for dolls which have Japanese clothes and hairstyles and reflect traditional Japanese culture.

culture.name: Torikabuto
culture.desc: A torikabuto is a head costume used in performances of gagaku, a type of Japanese traditional music and dance.

culture.name: Tobiko
culture.desc: Tobiko is one kind of processed fish eggs.

culture.name: Wasanbon
culture.desc: Wasanbon is one kind of sugar products traditionally produced mainly in the east region of Shikoku, such as Kagawa Prefecture and Tokushima Prefecture.

culture.name: Kakuni
culture.desc: Kakuni is one kind of prepared foods using ribs of pork.

culture.name: Kuzunoha
culture.desc: Kuzunoha is the name of a legendary fox.

culture.name: Zabuton
culture.desc: A zabuton (Japanese cushion) is an item of furnishing for placing under the legs or bottom when sitting on the floor or tatami.

culture.name: Seiza
culture.desc: Seiza refers to:

culture.name: Zori
culture.desc: Zori are a sandal-like type of Japanese traditional footwear.

culture.name: Iki (stylishness)
culture.desc: "Iki" is a Japanese aesthetic sense (aesthetic concept).

culture.name: Yamato-damashii (the Japanese spirit)
culture.desc: The common sense and social skills required to know the stream and make things go smoothly in society.

culture.name: Bokuto
culture.desc: "Bokuto" are wooden copies of Japanese swords.

culture.name: Daifuku
culture.desc: Daifuku is a traditional Japanese confectionary consisting of mochi (rice cake) filled with anko (sweet bean paste) made from azuki beans.

culture.name: Wakaayu
culture.desc: Wakaayu is a kind of Japanese confectionery which is made with gyuhi (a kind of rice cake made from glutinous rice or glutinous rice flour) wrapped in an oval sponge cake, shaped into a semicircle and marked with an eye and fins.

culture.name: Amazake
culture.desc: Amazake is a traditional Japanese sweet beverage, which is a cloudy liquid similar to doburoku (unrefined sake).

culture.name: Iemoto
culture.desc: Iemoto is a term used to refer to the family line which succeeds a school traditional Japanese art.

culture.name: Makunouchi-Bento
culture.desc: Makunouchi-bento is a type of bento (lunch box) with white rice and several accompanying dishes.

culture.name: Heshiko
culture.desc: Heshiko, salted mackerel in rice-bran paste, is a local dish and a processed marine product.

culture.name: Fukamushi-cha (Deep-steam Green Tea)
culture.desc: Fukamushi-cha (deep-steam green tea) is a type of sencha.

culture.name: Temomi-cha (Hand-rolled Tea)
culture.desc: Temomi-cha (hand-rolled tea): Hand rolling is the primary process of making sencha.

culture.name: Saiten
culture.desc: Saiten is a ritual wherein the god of Heaven is worshipped.

culture.name: Omamori (Personal Amulet)
culture.desc: Omamori (personal amulets) are items that symbolize one's wish.

culture.name: Noh Mask
culture.desc: A noh mask is a mask used in noh theater and some forms of kagura (musical dance).

culture.name: Yusoku Kojitsu (Ancient Court and Military Practices)
culture.url: culture/Yusoku Kojitsu (Ancient Court and Military Practices).html
culture.desc: Yusoku kojitsu is the study of government positions, ceremonies, and costumes based on their ancient precedents.

culture.name: Tegatana (Ceremonial Hand Movement)
culture.desc: Tegatana (pronounced either Shuto or Tegatana)

culture.name: Noshiika (Fattened Dried Squid)
culture.desc: Noshiika (伸し烏賊 or 熨斗烏賊) is a food made from dried squid.

culture.name: Hikichigiri
culture.desc: Hikichigiri is a type of Japanese sweet made from mochi (Japanese rice cake made of glutinous rice pounded into paste and molded into shape) and sweet bean paste.

culture.name: Makiwara (Japanese Archery)
culture.desc: Makiwara is a target for practicing kata (form) in kyudo or kyujutsu (Japanese art of archery).

culture.name: Soy-sauce
culture.desc: Soy-sauce is a general-purpose liquid fermented seasoning with salty taste and strong savoriness, made from soybeans and wheat using Aspergillus oryzae and yeast, and it is mainly used in Japanese cooking.

culture.name: Demae (Food Delivery)
culture.desc: Demae is a delivery service in which restaurants and food shops deliver dishes to customer's homes within a short space of time.

culture.name: Niwaka (an impromptu comic play)
culture.desc: Niwaka (written in Chinese characters as 俄) is an impromptu comic play that was performed at banquets or on the streets in the Edo/Meiji periods.

culture.name: Todoza (the traditional guild for the blind)
culture.url: culture/Todoza (the traditional guild for the blind).html
culture.desc: Todoza was an autonomous mutual support group for the male blind that existed from the medieval period through early modern times in Japan.

culture.name: Japanese lavatories
culture.desc: Here, we explain about Japanese lavatories.

culture.name: Shogatsugoto-hajime
culture.desc: Shogatsugoto-hajime (New Year Preparations) means to begin preparations for welcoming the New Year.

culture.name: Kezuribushi (shavings of dried fish):
culture.desc: The term "kezuribushi" means shavings of dried flesh of bonitos, mackerels, sardines, and other fishes.

culture.name: Ongyoku (musical performance)
culture.desc: In the early-modern times, the term "ongyoku" meant music or an art of musical performance.

culture.name: Utagaki (Poetry Reading Party)
culture.desc: "Utagaki" is a kind of folkway based on a magical belief, where young men and women gather on a specific time and date to exchange courtship songs and ballads.

culture.name: Natsumatsuri (Summer Festival)
culture.desc: "Natsumatsuri" is a collective term for festivals observed in summer.

culture.name: Okuribi (Ceremonial Bonfire to Send out Spirits of the Dead)
culture.url: culture/Okuribi (Ceremonial Bonfire to Send out Spirits of the Dead).html
culture.desc: "Okuribi" is one of the events observed in Bon festivals to usher out from this mortal world to the other world those spirits of the dead that had once returned to their old homes during the Bon period.

culture.name: Toro Nagashi (Floating Lanterns Down a River)
culture.url: culture/Toro Nagashi (Floating Lanterns Down a River).html
culture.desc: "Toro Nagashi" which is also referred to as "Shoryo Nagashi" (floating lanterns down a river carrying the spirits of the dead) is a Japanese festival where people hold a memorial service for the spirits of the deceased by floating paper lanterns and other offerings in a river or in the sea for Bon festivals.

culture.name: Motsunabe
culture.desc: Motsunabe is a nabe dish made from Motsu (offal).

culture.name: Bijinga
culture.desc: Bijinga is a general term for paintings that are in the motif of so-called feminine beauty, or feminine looks and inner beauty.

culture.name: Wafu (和風)
culture.desc: Wafu

culture.name: Mai Dance
culture.desc: Mai dances are mainly dances which include circling movements in time with melodies.

culture.name: Orikata
culture.desc: Orikata is a term used to refer to techniques of folding a sheet of paper to wrap a gift, which is one aspect of Japanese etiquette and rules.

culture.name: Kushikatsu
culture.desc: This section will describe one of the Japanese dishes kushikatsu.

culture.name: Tsunahiki (tug-of-war) of O-okuri-jinja Shrine
culture.desc: The O-tsunahiki of O-okuri-jinja Shrine is a tug-of-war festival held in Hioki, Yagi Town, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Saikyo Miso
culture.desc: Saikyo miso is the common name for a whitish yellow sweet miso containing a high proportion of malted rice made mainly around the Kinki region; and the main characteristic of this miso is that while miso usually used for miso soup contains 12% salt, Saikyo miso contains only about 5% salt.

culture.name: Jubako
culture.desc: Jubako is a term used to refer to a box consisting of two to five stacked sub-boxes, in which food is stored.

culture.name: Engawa
culture.desc: Engawa is a term used to refer to a wooden-floored corridor built along the outside of the house building, which is a structure unique to Japanese traditional houses.

culture.name: Soke
culture.desc: Soke is a term used to refer to:

culture.name: Mono no aware (the sadness or pathos of things)
culture.url: culture/Mono no aware (the sadness or pathos of things).html
culture.desc: Mono no aware (written as もののあわれ or 物の哀れ) is the key literary and aesthetic notion in the study of dynastic style literature in the Heian period.

culture.name: Warosoku (Japanese candle)
culture.desc: Warosoku is a kind of candle which is a lighting device.

culture.name: Tsurushi Kazari (Hanging ornaments)
culture.desc: Tsurushi kazari is one of the traditional art crafts.

culture.name: Hatsu Hinode (the first sunrise of New year)
culture.url: culture/Hatsu Hinode (the first sunrise of New year).html
culture.desc: Hatsu hinode refers to the appearance of the celestial object on January 1 (ganjitsu) (when the sun rises from the horizon or sea horizon).

culture.name: Karamono
culture.desc: Karamono elegantly refers to Chinese products which were esteemed from medieval times to recent times.

culture.name: Fuzei
culture.desc: Fuzei is one of the aesthetic feelings which have existed from ancient times in Japan.

culture.name: Kumade
culture.desc: A kumade (rake) is a type of Japanese farm tool used in farming or for raking gardens that consists of rough comb-like teeth that are vertically attached to a handle.

culture.name: Oke (a wooden bucket)
culture.desc: Oke is a kind of container.

culture.name: Teishitsu Gigeiin (Imperial art expert)
culture.desc: Teishitsu Gigeiin was a system for honoring craftspeople and artisans, which had been operated by the Imperial Household Ministry since 1890 until right after the end of the war (World War II).

culture.name: Shigin (reciting Chinese poems)
culture.desc: Shigin is one of Japan's traditional performing arts.

culture.name: Ikan (traditional formal court dress)
culture.desc: Ikan is the work clothes of nobles and government officials in the Imperial Court after the Heian period.

culture.name: Saibara (a genre of Heian-period Japanese court music [primarily consisting of gagaku-styled folk melodies])
culture.url: culture/Saibara (a genre of Heian-period Japanese court music [primarily consisting of gagaku-styled folk me.html
culture.desc: Saibara is a style of ancient music.

culture.name: Bachi
culture.desc: Bachi (撥) is a stick-shaped tool used to pluck (hook and release, or hammer) the string (stringed instruments) or the film.

culture.name: Hokan (Professional entertainer)
culture.desc: Hokan (also called Taiko) is a profession of a man who indulges hosts and guests at a drinking party such as a banquet or ozashiki (banquets in which guests are attended by geisha), does performances himself, and helps geisha (Japanese professional female entertainers at drinking party) and maiko (apprentice geisha) to set the groove.

culture.name: Yamakasa
culture.desc: A "yamakasa" refers to a ceremonial implement used in shrine festivals, the form of which is similar to that of a mikoshi (portable shrine carried in festivals) or a dashi (float).

culture.name: Kaiawase (shell-matching)
culture.desc: Kaiawase is a traditional game from the Heian period.

culture.name: Takarabune (treasure ship)
culture.desc: Takarabune (treasure ship) is the sailing ship on which Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck) and treasures are loaded, or the picture that depicts the scene.

culture.name: Koden
culture.desc: Koden (香典) is a term to refer to a gift of money offered to the dead at a Buddhist funeral.

culture.name: Mizutaki (chicken boiled plain)
culture.desc: Mizutaki is a kind of a one-pot dish cooked at the table, a local dish mainly eaten in Fukuoka Prefecture.

culture.name: Fukuwarai
culture.desc: Fukuwarai, (a game similar to pin the tail on the donkey) is a traditional game played on New Year's day in Japan.

culture.name: Mibu Kyogen
culture.desc: Mibu Kyogen is a form of pantomime skits performed at the Mibu-dera Temple in Kyoto every year at the time of the Setsubun Festival (February), in April, and October coinciding with the annual cycle of Noh performances.

culture.name: Sudare Bamboo Screens
culture.desc: Sudare are bamboo screens constructed by knitting together strips of bamboo or reed with string.

culture.name: Katsudo Benshi (Silent Movie Narrator)
culture.desc: A katsudo benshi is a Japanese professional narrator of an old motion picture, or a silent movie, who gives live narration to the audience.

culture.name: Chakyo (The Classic of Tea)
culture.desc: "Chakyo" (The Classic of Tea) is a book written by Lu Yu around eighth century in Tang Dynasty China.

culture.name: Shochumimai (summer greeting card)
culture.desc: A shochumimai is a letter sent to acquaintances to ask how they are doing in the mid-summer.

culture.name: Kaeshi
culture.desc: The word 'kaeshi' is an abbreviation of 'nikaeshi', a seasoning used as a soba (buckwheat noodles) dipping sauce.

culture.name: Karaginu
culture.desc: Karaginu' (唐衣) is one of the types of kimono (Japanese traditional clothing) that comprises a juni-hitoe (twelve-layered ceremonial kimono).

culture.name: Hoshigaki
culture.desc: Hoshigaki is a kind of dried fruit made by drying Japanese persimmons.

culture.name: Nerizake
culture.desc: Nerizake is a kind of sake (Japanese liquor), and it is said that it reflects the original form of ancient sake.

culture.name: Moro-haku
culture.desc: "Moro-haku" ("moro" means both sides, and "haku" means polishing) was the name of a sake brewing method which used polished rice for both the "koji-mai" (the rice in which the mold of "koji" [Aspergillus oryzae] was cultivated) and the "kake-mai" (also called "fukashi," meaning the steamed rice).

culture.name: Katahaku
culture.desc: Katahaku is a sake (Japanese rice wine) brewing method from the Heian to Edo periods which uses polished white rice only for the kakemai (steamed rice) and unpolished genmai (unpolished rice) for kojimai (malted rice).

culture.name: Namizake (Regular Grade Sake)
culture.desc: Namizake refers to a sake (Japanese rice wine) brewing method from the Heian to Edo periods which used genmai (unpolished rice) for both the kakemai (steamed rice) and the kojimai (malted rice), as well as the sake made using the method.

culture.name: Nanto Moro-Haku
culture.desc: "Nanto moro-haku" was the general term for several kinds of "soboshu" (monk's sake) produced with "moro-haku" (sake brewed using polished rice both for the mold-cultivated rice and for the steamed rice) at temples in Nara (also called "Nanto" [southern capital]), which firmly kept its reputation as the sake of the highest quality and grade from the middle of the Heian period to the end of the Muromachi period.

culture.name: Bodai-Moto
culture.desc: "Bodai-moto" is the "moto" (yeast mash), with which "Nanto moro-haku" (several kinds of "soboshu" [monk's sake] having the highest quality), especially the name-brand sake "Bodaisen," was made through fermentation at Shoryaku-ji Temple on Mt. Bodai in Nara.

culture.name: Bodaisen
culture.desc: "Bodaisen" was a name-brand sake (Japanese rice wine) which had the reputation of having the highest quality and grade from the middle of the Heian period to the end of the Muromachi period.

culture.name: Nimoto
culture.desc: "Ni-moto" was one of the producing methods of "Nanto moro-haku," the sake (Japanese rice wine) that had a reputation of having the highest quality and grade from the mid-Heian period to the end of the Muromachi period.

culture.name: Four-Seasons Brewing
culture.desc: Four seasons brewing is the brewing of Japanese sake (rice wine) throughout the year and not just in the cold of winter.

culture.name: Shin-shu (Nouveau style beverages)
culture.desc: Shin-shu is generally used in the following examples:

culture.name: Sake (rice wine) Breweries
culture.desc: The trade of sake brewers in Japan involves; making Japanese rice wine (sake) in warehouses and selling sake in retail outlets.

culture.name: Sake brewing control
culture.desc: Sake brewing control is the restriction (control) and promotion (relaxation of the control) policy adopted by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in Japan for the sake brewing industry.

culture.name: Furoshiki (wrapping cloth)
culture.desc: Furoshiki is a piece of cloth similar to a regular square shape for wrapping things for carrying or storing.

culture.name: Kezuriko
culture.desc: "Kezuriko" are gleanings of powder which is left over after dried fishes (such as a dried bonito, dried blue mackerel, and dried sardines) are chipped off to produce "kezuribushi" (shaved pieces).

culture.name: Shishimai (Japanese Lion Dance)
culture.desc: "Shishimai" (Japanese lion dance) is one of the traditional Japanese performing arts, in which performers mimic a lion's movements in a lion costume to festival music.

culture.name: The Competition of Running Up the Long Staircase of the JR Kyoto Station Building
culture.jp: JR京都駅ビル大階段駆け上がり大会
culture.url: culture/The Competition of Running Up the Long Staircase of the JR Kyoto Station Building.html
culture.desc: The competition of running up the long staircase of the JR Kyoto Station building is an event that has been held there by the Kyoto Broadcasting System Company Limited (KBS) on the third Saturday every February since 1998.

culture.name: Kinen-sai Festival (Prayer Service For A Good Crop)
culture.url: culture/Kinen-sai Festival (Prayer Service For A Good Crop).html
culture.desc: "Kinen-sai festival" (also called "Toshigoi no matsuri") is an annual Shinto ritual in February praying for the good fortune of the year, including the rich harvest.

culture.name: Ihai (mortuary tablet)
culture.desc: Ihai is a wooden tablet inscribed with the posthumous Buddhist name of a deceased person to enshrine the spirit of the person.

culture.name: Koikoku
culture.desc: Koikoku is the name of a dish of round sliced carp stewed in miso soup.

culture.name: Tenugui towel
culture.desc: Tenugui towel (called Tenogoi in Edo-ben and Hakata-ben dialects) is a plain-woven cotton fabric used to dry your hands, wash your face, or wash yourself during bath time.

culture.name: Mizu-yokan
culture.desc: Mizu-yokan is Japanese confectionery, and is a type of yokan (azuki-bean jelly).

culture.name: Kiribi (flint sparks)
culture.desc: Kiribi (flint sparks) is a ceremony for kiyome (purification) which is performed using sparks caused by striking an object with a flint.

culture.name: Hina Arare
culture.desc: Hina arare is a kind of Japanese confectionery that is offered at the Dolls' Festival (March 3rd).

culture.name: Yukimi
culture.desc: Yukimi is one of the Japanese folkways since the medieval period, where people enjoy watching the snowing or the snowscape.

culture.name: Sankyoku (instrumental trio)
culture.desc: Sankyoku is the collective name for the three musical instruments: jiuta shamisen (shamisen, or sangen--a three-stringed Japanese banjo, for jiuta, or traditional songs with shamisen accompaniment), so (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings), and kokyu (Chinese fiddle).

culture.name: Chidori No Kyoku
culture.desc: Chidori no Kyoku (a song for plover) is a musical composition for koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) and kokyu (Chinese fiddle) composed by Yoshizawa Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za [the traditional guild for the blind]) (the second).

culture.name: Nerigashi (a confection made from kneaded beans, rice, or rice powder)
culture.url: culture/Nerigashi (a confection made from kneaded beans, rice, or rice powder).html
culture.desc: Nerigashi (a confection made from kneaded beans, rice, or rice powder) is also referred to as 'konashi,' which is a snack food produced by mixing an ingredient in the form of powder or grain and an ingredient in the form of liquid or paste, applying external forces for many times to homogenize the distribution, and finishing it in a clayey state of plastic deformation.

culture.name: Teru teru bozu
culture.desc: Hanging "teru teru bozu," a hand-made doll made of white paper or cloth, at the front of a house in the straight position is a Japanese custom, which is believed to bring good weather for the next day.

culture.name: Tosenkyo
culture.desc: Tosenkyo is a Japanese game (throwing fans at a target) that is one of the Japanese traditional multiplayer games.

culture.name: Hibashi chopstick
culture.desc: Hibashi chopstick is a Japanese tool.

culture.name: Noyaki (open burning)
culture.desc: Noyaki (open burning) means burning the vegetations in the hills and fields.

culture.name: KIKUOKA Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind))
culture.url: culture/Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the bl.html
culture.desc: Kengyo KIKUOKA(1792 - December 19, 1847) was a blind musician who was active in Kyoto during the early nineteenth century (jiuta shamisen (traditional Japanese shamisen music) player, composer).

culture.name: MITSUZAKI Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind))
culture.url: culture/Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the bl.html
culture.desc: Kengyo MITSUZAKI (year of birth unknown, but estimated around 1853) was a blind musician who was active during the early nineteenth century in Kyoto (jiuta shamisen (traditional Japanese shamisen music) player, so or koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) player and composer).

culture.name: YAEZAKI Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind))
culture.url: culture/Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the bl.html
culture.desc: Kengyo YAEZAKI (around 1776 – October 7, 1848) was a blind musician who was active during the early nineteenth century in Kyoto (jiuta shamisen (traditional Japanese shamisen music) player, so or koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) player and composer).

culture.name: MATSUURA Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind))
culture.url: culture/Kengyo (the highest title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the bl.html
culture.desc: Kengyo MATSUURA (year of birth unknown – January 2, 1823) was a blind musician who was active during the early nineteenth century in Kyoto (jiuta shamisen (traditional Japanese shamisen music) player, so or koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) player and composer).

culture.name: ISHIKAWA Koto (the title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind))
culture.url: culture/Koto (the title of the official ranks within the Todo-za (the traditional guild for the blind)) ISHI.html
culture.desc: Koto ISHIKAWA (year of birth unknown) was a blind musician who was active during the early nineteenth century in Kyoto (jiuta shamisen (traditional Japanese shamisen music) player, so or koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings) player and composer).

culture.name: Tegotomono (a form of Japanese chamber music)
culture.url: culture/Tegotomono (a form of Japanese chamber music).html
culture.desc: Tegotomono is the style of composition which has instrumental parts (here, it is also called "tegotomono-form") or the kind of songs in sankyoku music which consists of jiuta, so (or koto) music and kokyu (Chinese fiddle) music.

culture.name: Toji (The Winter Solstice)
culture.desc: Toji (the winter solstice) is one of Nijushi-sekki (the 24 divisions of the solar year).

culture.name: Tosazu (tosa vinegar)
culture.desc: Tosazu is a mixture of sanbaizu (vinegar, soy sauce and sweet cooking rice wine mixed in roughly equal proportions) and soup stock made from dried bonito.

culture.name: NAKAGAWA Joeki
culture.desc: Joeki NAKAGAWA is a name that has been succeeded for generations by the head of the Nakagawa family, one of the Senke jissoku (the 10 artisans of the Sen family) specialized in the hardware craftwork.

culture.name: Tegoto
culture.desc: Tegoto is a long part of instrumental music sandwiched between vocal music in a piece by an instrumental trio, which is a collective term for jiuta (a genre of traditional songs with accompaniment by shamisen (three-stringed lute)), sokyoku (koto (thirteen-stringed Japanese zither) music), and kokyugaku (Chinese fiddle music).

culture.name: Sakana
culture.desc: Sakana is a thing with which people enjoy having alcoholic beverages; yet, it is not necessarily a food item.

culture.name: Itamae (chef)
culture.desc: Itamae is a person who cooks meals at a Japanese restaurant or ryotei (traditional Japanese restaurant).

culture.name: Shiroan (white strained sweet bean paste)
culture.desc: Shiroan, white strained sweet bean paste, is made from kidney beans or small beans boiled, crushed and sweetened with sugar or honey.

culture.name: Atsuage
culture.desc: Atsuage is a food made by deep-frying tofu (bean curd) cut into one piece or half a piece.

culture.name: Yaki-Dofu
culture.desc: A yaki-dofu is a tofu where both sides are singed after being drained.

culture.name: Yamahai-jikomi
culture.desc: Simply referred to as yamahai, yamahai-jikomi (yamahai-shikomi) is a method of brewing sake (Japanese rice wine) that belongs to the kimoto-kei (traditional moto, or yeast starter, developing method).

culture.name: Kanpukai (maple leaf viewing festival)
culture.desc: Kanpukai (maple leaf viewing festival) is a gathering to view colored leaves of maple and other trees.

culture.name: Sanpai (a visit to a shrine or a temple)
culture.url: culture/Sanpai (a visit to a shrine or a temple).html
culture.desc: Sanpai is an act of visiting a shrine or a temple and praying to gods or Buddha.

culture.name: Uta-awase
culture.desc: Uta-awase is a contest in which two teams of poets divided into the right and the left sides.

culture.name: Kasujiru (soup made with sake lees)
culture.desc: Kasujiru is a soup made by dissolving sake lees or a mix of sake lees and miso in broth and adding some ingredients, which are often carrot, daikon (Japanese radish), or fish.

culture.name: Sonkyo
culture.desc: 蹲踞 (Sonkyo or Sonko) is a way of sitting by squatting down or kneeling down on the knees to lower the hips.

culture.name: Agedashi dofu (lightly fried tofu)
culture.desc: Agedashi dofu is a dish of tofu lightly dusted with starch or flour, then deep fried, and served in dashi broth or dashi-based sauce seasoning with soy sauce.

culture.name: Tokkuri (sake bottle)
culture.desc: Tokkuri or Tokuri is a thin-necked bottle rounded at the bottom.

culture.name: Tamago Dofu (Egg Tofu)
culture.desc: Tamago dofu is a Japanese culinary dish.

culture.name: Nishime (the traditional Japanese simmered dish)
culture.desc: Nishime (煮しめ) is a dish in which a simmering cooking technique is used.

culture.name: Hojicha (roasted green tea)
culture.desc: Hojicha (written as ほうじちゃ or 焙じ茶) is a type of Japanese green tea, generally referring to tea made with roasted tea leaves.

culture.name: Fukuro shinai (bamboo sword covered with a sleeve)
culture.url: culture/Fukuro shinai (bamboo sword covered with a sleeve).html
culture.desc: Fukuro shinai (written as 袋竹刀) is a tool used in martial arts that had been used in swordsmanship training before the bamboo sword was devised.

culture.name: Johakyu
culture.desc: Johakyu is a word used in discussions regarding such arts as renga (Japanese collaborative poetry), kemari (a kick-ball game arranged by aristocrats in the Heian period), kodo (traditional incense ceremony), swordsmanship, batto-jutsu (the art of using swords and cutting with swords) and iaido (an art using swords), which was originally used in the field of Japanese traditional music including gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) and nohgaku (the art of noh).

culture.name: Kusamochi (rice-flour dumplings mixed with mugwort)
culture.desc: Kusamochi is a kind of rice cake.

culture.name: Masuseki (box seating)
culture.desc: Masuseki, or box seating, (枡席 or 升席 in Chinese characters) is a traditional kind of auditorium in Japan.

culture.name: Oshibori (wet hand towels)
culture.desc: Oshibori refer to wet hand towels that are served at restaurants and other places for customers to wipe their hands.

culture.name: Kijoshu Sake
culture.desc: Kijoshu sake is a sweet Japanese rice wine with a unique thickness brewed using sake instead of water.

culture.name: Hikimayu (painted eyebrows)
culture.desc: Hikimayu is a makeup technique applied from the Nara period to the Edo period, meaning to shave or pull out eyebrows.

culture.name: Kikizake (sake tasting)
culture.desc: Kikizake (sake tasting, written as 利き酒, ききざけ, 唎き酒 or きき酒) refers to evaluating the sake quality.

culture.name: Zashikibina (the hina doll landscape)
culture.desc: Zashikibina is a form of the Hinamatsuri (Doll Festival) celebration inherited specifically in Ma-ana district, Yawatahama City, Ehime Prefecture.

culture.name: Yakata-bune Boat (a roofed pleasure boat)
culture.desc: Yakata-bune is a kind of Japanese boat and is a roofed ship with zashiki (tatami room) for use in festivals and enjoying food on a ship.

culture.name: Sagemon
culture.desc: Sagemon is a custom that is passed down in Yanagawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture.

culture.name: Ken Asobi (fist play)
culture.desc: Ken asobi is a competitive game between two people that uses spread or closed hands or the reflection of fingers.

culture.name: Debayashi (Kabuki)
culture.desc: Debayashi is a kind of kabuki music played on a stage by performers.

culture.name: Kanzukuri (sake brewing during winter)
culture.desc: Kanzukuri is the name of a Japanese sake brewing technique and applies to those made in winter when the air temperature is low.

culture.name: Kanshu (cold sake)
culture.desc: It is the sake (Japanese rice wine) created using the cold temperature of winter, one of the shikijozo (sake brewing in all seasons) techniques used until the early Edo Period.

culture.name: Kamonabe
culture.desc: A kamonabe is a duck hot pot with other ingredients such as hakusai cabbage, green onions, tofu and so on.

culture.name: Sugitama (Fir Ball)
culture.desc: Sugitama is a craft made from collection of fir leaves (tips) and shaped into a ball.

culture.name: Katsusando (deep-fried cutlet sandwich)
culture.desc: Katsusando is a cutlet (usually a pork or beef cutlet) sandwich with white bread.

culture.name: Koji-buta
culture.desc: Koji-buta (shallow wooden trays for koji) are one of the tools used in Japanese sake brewing and used at the koji making stage of Japanese sake.

culture.name: Taikodai
culture.desc: The Japanese word "taikodai" can be used to refer to either of the following.

culture.name: Densho
culture.desc: Densho (books on the esoterica - also written as 傳書) is a manuscript or book of secret techniques of schools of Japanese art and martial arts.

culture.name: Shiraore (Twig Tea)
culture.desc: Shiraore is a type of Japanese tea that consists of tea stems eliminated from Gyokuro (refined green tea) or green tea of middle grade in processing and has an unique flavor derived from stems.

culture.name: Danjikomi
culture.desc: Danjikomi is one of the brewing steps and means of making unfiltered Japanese sake where the yeast and rice are added over three steps to the yeast mash or moto (another term for sake producing yeast) to provide a mild environmental change for yeast to adapt to while not losing its productivity.

culture.name: Mujo (absence of absolutes)
culture.desc: Mujo (anitya in Sanskrit) points out that all beings in the present world disintegrate and are in constant transition without being stationary.

culture.name: Osuberakashi
culture.desc: The osuberakashi is a hairstyle for noble women in the Heian period.

culture.name: Jozonendo (Brewing Year)
culture.desc: Jozonendo is the annual cycle used by the brewing industry that ranges from July 1 each year to June 30 of the following year.

culture.name: Aosei Sencha Seiho (Blue Sencha Method)
culture.desc: Aosei Sencha Seiho was one of the revolutionary changes made in the Japanese tea industry.

culture.name: Kogai (Traditional Hairpin accessory)
culture.desc: The 'Kogai' (Traditional Hairpin accessory) is decorative hairdressing implement used for lifting hair into a bun shape.

culture.name: Enteki (the long-distance shooting)
culture.desc: Enteki (the long-distance shooting) is one of the kyudo (Japanese art of archery) events established by the Rules of All Nippon Kyudo Federation.

culture.name: Kinteki (the regular close-ranged shooting)
culture.desc: Kinteki (the regular close-ranged shooting) is one of the kyudo (Japanese art of archery) events established by the Rules of All Nippon Kyudo Federation.

culture.name: Karawa Hairstyle
culture.desc: The karawa hairstyle was a hairstyle favored by prostitutes during the Azuchi Momoyama period in the port towns of Hyogo and Sakai City in the vicinity of Kyoto.

culture.name: Matsuribayashi
culture.desc: Matsuribayashi' (festival music) is music that is performed at festival time and forms a particular genre of musical accompaniment.

culture.name: Kyudojo (a training hall of archery)
culture.desc: "Kyudojo" is a dojo (a training hall) to do kyudo (Japanese art of archery) and kyujutsu (same as above).

culture.name: Hiiragi-iwashi
culture.desc: Hiiragi-iwashi is a holly sprig with a baked sardine's head, and Japanese people have a time-honored custom of putting Hiiragi-iwashi at their door on Setsubun (the traditional end of winter) to ward off evil spirits.

culture.name: History of Sake (Japanese liquor)
culture.desc: History of sake

culture.name: Makura no Soshi Ekotoba (Picture scrolls of scenes from the Pillow Book of Sei Shonagon)
culture.url: culture/Makura no Soshi Ekotoba (Picture scrolls of scenes from the Pillow Book of Sei Shonagon).html
culture.desc: "Makura no Soshi Ekotoba" refers to the picture scrolls on which impressive scenes selected from the passages in the diary of "Makura no Soshi" (The Pillow Book) were depicted.

culture.name: Kasafuku
culture.desc: Kasafuku is a hanging decoration seen around Sakata City, Yamagata Prefecture.

culture.name: Yamato School
culture.desc: Yamato school, one of the Kyudo (Japanese art of archery) schools, was founded by Kozan MORIKAWA in the early Edo period (in 1652).

culture.name: Gyuhi (a kind of rice cake made from glutinous rice or glutinous rice flour)
culture.url: culture/Gyuhi (a kind of rice cake made from glutinous rice or glutinous rice flour).html
culture.desc: Gyuhi is one of the materials of Japanese confectionery and a kind of rice cake made by kneading.

culture.name: Eboshi (Japanese traditional formal headwear)
culture.desc: Eboshi was the headwear which an adult man put on when he wore a Japanese formal attire from the Heian period to modern times.

culture.name: Hina no Tsurushikazari (Hanging Decorations for Doll's Festival)
culture.url: culture/Hina no Tsurushikazari (Hanging Decorations for Dolls Festival).html
culture.desc: Hina no Tsurushikazari is a custom of hanging decorations in the Izuinatori area going back to the Edo period.

culture.name: Tori no ichi (the Cock Fair)
culture.desc: "Tori no ichi" is an open-market fair held at Otori-jinja Shrines around the country on the Days of the Cock in November every year.

culture.name: Miyabi
culture.desc: Miyabi or Masa (in case of name) means sophisticated and graceful.

culture.name: The naked festival
culture.desc: The naked festival is a Japanese festival in which the participants go naked.

culture.name: Tegara
culture.desc: Tegara is a hairdressing cloth to wrap around the topknot of traditional Japanese women's hairstyles.

culture.name: Ohana
culture.desc: Ohana refers to the money and other valuables used for congratulatory gifts or for religious offerings.

culture.name: Parade
culture.desc: Parade (neri or oneri in Japanese) means to transfer a portable shrine (carried in festivals) or a festival car (float) of rites and festivals, to dedicate them to Shinto rituals or to introduce them to audience.

culture.name: Ajitsuke nori (nori flavored with soy source, mirin and seasonings)
culture.url: culture/Ajitsuke nori (nori flavored with soy source, mirin and seasonings).html
culture.desc: Ajitsuke nori (nori flavored with soy sauce, mirin and seasonings) is a generic term for processed nori (dried laver seaweed) products mainly seasoned with soy-sauce, sugar, and spices.

culture.name: Bogu (a protector) (Japanese art of fencing)
culture.desc: Bogu is protective gear to protect players' body in the Japanese art of fencing, naginata (a long pole with a sharp curving sword), and jukendo (the martial art using the bayonet).

culture.name: Hari (needle)-kuyo (a memorial service for dull and broken needles)
culture.url: culture/Hari (needle)-kuyo (a memorial service for dull and broken needles).html
culture.desc: Hari (needle)-kuyo is an event to hold a memorial service for broken sewing needles and offer them to a shrine nearby.

culture.name: Shihandai (assistant instructor)
culture.desc: Shihandai (assistant instructor) is an instructor in an art field and an assistant of Shihan (grand master).

culture.name: Tea utensils
culture.desc: Tea utensils is a generic term for utensils used in the Japanese tea ceremony.

culture.name: Kayariki (a mosquito repellent stick holder)
culture.desc: Kayariki (a mosquito repellent stick holder) is a device to steady a burning repellent stick and to facilitate the post-cleaning of it, keeping ashes from flying off, by burning a mosquito repellent stick in or on it.

culture.name: Inuoumono (dog-hunting event, a skill of an archery)
culture.url: culture/Inuoumono (dog-hunting event, a skill of an archery).html
culture.desc: Inuoumono is one of the manners of the art of Japanese archery that started from the Kamakura period.

culture.name: Hatsumiyamairi (a Shinto rite of passage for newborns)
culture.url: culture/Hatsumiyamairi (a Shinto rite of passage for newborns).html
culture.desc: Hatsumiyamairi (a Shinto rite of passage for newborns) is to thankfully report to Ubusunagami (guardian deity of one's birthplace) that a baby safely had the one month anniversary.

culture.name: Gimei (counterfeit inscription)
culture.desc: Gimei (counterfeit inscription) is an inscribed name of a person other than the original creator.

culture.name: Takigi-noh (Noh play performed at night by a fire)
culture.url: culture/Takigi-noh (Noh play performed at night by a fire).html
culture.desc: Takigi-noh (Noh play performed at night by a fire) is a Noh play that is especially chosen and performed in Noh Theater or on a Noh stage with a beacon fire around which is temporarily installed outside mainly on summer nights.

culture.name: Japanese Art
culture.desc: Japanese art has such a wide variety of arts.

culture.name: Inoko (the Young Boar Festival)
culture.desc: Inoko (the Young Boar Festival) is an annual event held on the day of boar in October (month of boar) in old calendar.

culture.name: Kocho (Butterflies)
culture.desc: Kocho (Butterflies)

culture.name: Biwa Hoshi (Biwa-playing Minstrel)
culture.desc: The term "biwa hoshi" represents blind priests who played the biwa (a Japanese lute) in a town, and they first appeared in the Heian period.

culture.name: Dairibina (festival dolls representing the emperor and the empress)
culture.url: culture/Dairibina (festival dolls representing the emperor and the empress).html
culture.desc: Dairibina is a pair of Girl's Festival dolls representing the emperor and the empress, and is placed on the top tier of a display.

culture.name: Hikari-beni (red pigment made from safflowers)
culture.desc: Hikari-beni, also referred to as tsuya-beni (which literally means "shiny red") is pigment made by separating the coloring matter of safflowers with plum vinegar.

culture.name: Yagura (Turret)
culture.desc: "Yagura" (turret), which is written as "櫓" in Japanese, is a term for Japanese traditional constructions, buildings, and structure.

culture.name: Zengoro
culture.desc: Zengoro is one of the head schools of the Kyo yaki (Kyoto style ceramic art).

culture.name: Fujin (The Japanese God of The Wind)
culture.url: culture/Fujin (The Japanese God of The Wind).html
culture.desc: Fujin (also known as "Kaze no kami," or "Fuhaku") is the Japanese god believed to control the wind.

culture.name: Shuto (salted and fermented bonito intestine)
culture.desc: Shuto is salted fish guts of a skipjack tuna, a bonito.

culture.name: Danjiri (a festival float in western Japan)
culture.url: culture/Danjiri (a festival float in western Japan).html
culture.desc: The term 'danjiri' has several meanings, as follows.

culture.name: Utsuroi-giku (the white Chrysanthemum changing its color to purple)
culture.url: culture/Utsuroi-giku (the white Chrysanthemum changing its color to purple).html
culture.desc: Utsuroi-giku refers to the variety of white chrysanthemum whose petals begin to be tinged with purple from their edges around late autumn.

culture.name: Karakuri (Japanese traditional mechanical devices)
culture.desc: Karakuri means a Japanese traditional mechanical doll or miniature, or other mechanical device.

culture.name: Mochimaki (an event of scattering rice cakes)
culture.url: culture/Mochimaki (an event of scattering rice cakes).html
culture.desc: Mochimaki is an event of scattering rice cakes for people who come to a Shinto ritual, such as jotoshiki (the framework raising ceremony held during construction of a new building).

culture.name: Zokuso (the modern music of koto [a long Japanese zither with 13 strings])
culture.url: culture/Zokuso (the modern music of koto [a long Japanese zither with 13 strings]).html
culture.desc: Zokuso (zokugoto) is the koto or the koto music from the time Yatsuhashi Kengyo reformed the koto music in the early modern ages of Japan, and his koto contrasts with gakuso (the koto used in gagaku [ancient Japanese court music and dance]).

culture.name: Kakko (a Japanese percussion instrument)
culture.desc: Kakko is a percussion instrument used in gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music), and it is a kind of tsuzumi (a long hourglass drum).

culture.name: Somato (a kind of a garden lantern)
culture.url: culture/Somato (a kind of a garden lantern).html
culture.desc: Somato is a kind of a garden lantern, which is crafted to show a revolving shadow picture with its inside and outside frames.

culture.name: Komabue (a Japanese wind instrument)
culture.desc: Komabue is one of the wind instruments used in the orchestra of gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music).

culture.name: Imayo (a popular style of Japanese songs in the Heian period)
culture.url: culture/Imayo (a popular style of Japanese songs in the Heian period).html
culture.desc: Imayo is one style of Japanese songs.

culture.name: Sagicho Festival
culture.desc: Sagicho is a fire festival held on the small New Year's Day (January 15).

culture.name: Roei (the Japanese tunes set to Chinese-style poetry)
culture.url: culture/Roei (the Japanese tunes set to Chinese-style poetry).html
culture.desc: Roei is one style of Japanese songs.

culture.name: Honne to Tatemae (one's personal feelings and the socially accepted view)
culture.url: culture/Honne to Tatemae (ones personal feelings and the socially accepted view).html
culture.desc: Honne to tatemae is a Japanese expression to explain a social phenomenon.

culture.name: Ryoto (a formal dress for ancient military officers)
culture.url: culture/Ryoto (a formal dress for ancient military officers).html
culture.desc: Ryoto is an armor of honor worn by military officers as their formal attire (at court).

culture.name: Tsune-shozoku (ordinary costumes)
culture.desc: Tsune-shozoku means a set of most ordinary costumes worn by performers of bugaku (traditional Japanese court music accompanied by dancing on stage).

culture.name: Takeda-ryu school
culture.desc: Takeda-ryu is one of the schools of the Kyuba-gunrei Kojitsu (Japanese ancient practices of customs about archery, equestrian and military etiquette).

culture.name: Ippodo (a trade name of a distributor of Japanese green tea)
culture.url: culture/Ippodo (a trade name of a distributor of Japanese green tea).html
culture.desc: Ippodo is the name of a distributor of Japanese green tea, located at Nijo-dori Agaru, Teramachi-dori, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Shigoto-osame
culture.desc: Shigoto-osame means to carry out the last business of a year near the end of December, i.e. the end of the year.

culture.name: Japanese Table Manners
culture.desc: Japanese table manners refer to the manners of dining in Japan.

culture.name: Izume
culture.desc: Izume refers a method of deciding ranking in the final of an individual tournament of Japanese archery.

culture.name: Enkin-kyosha
culture.desc: Enkin-kyosha is a method for deciding the ranking of an individual competition in Japanese archery, based on how close an arrow is shot to the center of the target.

culture.name: Kasane no irome (the color combinations for kimono)
culture.url: culture/Kasane no irome (the color combinations for kimono).html
culture.desc: Kasane no irome is a list of the color combinations in wearing kimono in layers, and was used when women decided the colors of uchigi (itsutsuginu, or in five layers) for court costumes.

culture.name: Nariki-zeme
culture.desc: Nariki-zeme (nariki, which is written as 成り木, means fruit bearing trees, and 責め, which in this case is pronounced 'zeme,' is a noun form of 責める [semeru] which in this context means to press a tree for fruition) is a folk rite praying for a good harvest, conducted on such fruit trees as persimmon, chestnut and ume.

culture.name: Noshi (traditional Japanese gift ornament)
culture.desc: Noshi is an ornament attached to gifts and presents offered on festive occasions in Japan.

culture.name: Dezomeshiki (the New Year's parade of fire brigades)
culture.url: culture/Dezomeshiki (the New Years parade of fire brigades).html
culture.desc: Dezomeshiki is a fire fighting training undertaken by fire department and fire company personnel, which is generally conducted in the early part of January as the first training for the year.

culture.name: Tokan-ya (the night on the 10th day of October)
culture.url: culture/Tokan-ya (the night on the 10th day of October).html
culture.desc: Tokan-ya (also read as Tokaya) is an annual festive event held on the night of October 10 (old lunar calendar).

culture.name: Shakubyoshi (wooden clappers)
culture.desc: Shakubyoshi is a kind of percussion instrument used in music such as gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music).

culture.name: Big Hinamatsuri (Big Doll Festival)
culture.desc: Big Hinamatsuri is a Hinamatsuri (Doll's Festival) held in Katsuura-cho, Tokushima Prefecture (former Awa Province), Katsuura City, Chiba Prefecture (former Kazusa Province), and Suzaka City, Nagano Prefecture (former Shinano Province) during February and March (during March and April in Suzaka City) every year.

culture.name: Machiai-chaya (tea houses that rented rooms in which visitors and geisha could amuse themselves)
culture.url: culture/Machiai-chaya (tea houses that rented rooms in which visitors and geisha could amuse themselves).html
culture.desc: Machiai-chaya is an industry which offers rental rooms used for waiting for others and gatherings.

culture.name: HIKI Ikkan
culture.desc: Ikkan HIKI is one of the Senke jusshoku (Senke's ten designated craftsmen families) and the name is succeeded by the head of Ikkanbari saikushi (artisan of lacquered papier-mache) from generation to generation.

culture.name: Hoshi-imo (dried sweet potatoes)
culture.desc: Hoshi-imo is made from sweet potato through the processing of steaming and then drying.

culture.name: Chabitsu
culture.desc: Chabitsu (also called chahitsu, "茶櫃" in Chinese characters) is a lidded container, in which a set of Sencha (non-powdered green tea) tea utensils are stored.

culture.name: Uta-e
culture.desc: The Uta-e is an elaborately designed pictorial work consisting of several illustrations depicting tools, natural phenomenon, plants and animals among other things that appear in Japanese poems, stories, and famous ceremonies, aimed at helping readers imagine and understand the backgrounds of these works.

culture.name: The Koami School
culture.desc: The Koami school is a group of maki-e masters engaging in Shitsugei (lacquer art).

culture.name: Tsubaki-mochi (a rice cake stuffed with sweet bean paste and coated with camellia leaves)
culture.url: culture/Tsubaki-mochi (a rice cake stuffed with sweet bean paste and coated with camellia leaves).html
culture.desc: Tsubaki-mochi is a rice cake sweets eaten as a light meal in the Heian period.

culture.name: Inarizushi
culture.desc: Inarizushi is a kind of sushi made of aburaage (deep-fried tofu) stuffed with rice.

culture.name: Monko-fuda
culture.desc: Monko-fuda are cards used in Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony).

culture.name: Enatsubo
culture.desc: Enatsubo is a container or pot in which the placenta of human beings are placed when being buried.

culture.name: Internet Sanpai
culture.desc: Internet Sanpai is the act of visiting and praying at websites provided by Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples.

culture.name: Kamigamo Mingei Kyodan
culture.desc: Kamigamo Mingei Kyodan (Kamigamo Folk Craft Association) was a craft center for the Mingei (National Art) Movement, which was located in Kamigamo, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Eboshi-oya
culture.desc: Eboshi-oya was a person who put an eboshi (formal headwear for court nobles) on a young man's head at his genpuku (attainment of manhood) ceremony.

culture.name: Kicho Screen
culture.desc: The 'Kicho' screen was used by nobles in their residences from the Heian period.

culture.name: Nirakuso
culture.desc: Nirakuso was the second house of Kozui OTANI, the 22nd chief priest of West Hongan-ji Temple, which he built in Mt. Rokko.

culture.name: Furyu
culture.desc: Furyu is one of the aesthetic values that became popular after the Middle Ages in Japan.

culture.name: Araumi no soji
culture.desc: Araumi no soji (also referred as Araumi no shoji) is an upholstered Tsuitate shoji (a partitioning screen, sometimes an opaque panel screen or sometimes a wooden screen set in a stand) set up at the end of northeast of Hiro-bisashi (broad eaves) of Seiryoden (Literally, Limpid Cool Hall, an Imperial summer palace).

culture.name: Kayuura (Porridge Fortunetelling)
culture.desc: Kayuura is an annual fortune-telling, where people's fortunes for the year are read using Kayu (porridge).

culture.name: Kanzake (warmed sake)
culture.desc: Kanzake is warmed alcoholic beverage.

culture.name: Tennyo
culture.desc: Tennyo are legendary beings in Japan.

culture.name: Astringency
culture.desc: Astringency

culture.name: Akadashi
culture.desc: Akadashi miso soup is a miso soup made from a blend of Hacho-style (soy bean and rice) miso paste.

culture.name: Fukusa
culture.desc: Fukusa

culture.name: Shobuyu (bathwater with iris petals)
culture.desc: Shobuyu is the bathwater heated with iris roots and leaves in it on Tango no Sekku (Boys' Day) of May 5.

culture.name: Teahouses
culture.desc: Chaya,' or teahouses were common from the middle ages through to recent times as a type of rest area in Japan.

culture.name: Yugake (a glove on the right hand)
culture.url: culture/Yugake (a glove on the right hand).html
culture.desc: Yugake, also referred as Kake, Sho is a deerskin glove-like gear for drawing Japanese bow used in Japanese kyudo (Japanese art of archery) or the art of Japanese archery.

culture.name: Ichiju-issai (a bowl of soup and one dish)
culture.url: culture/Ichiju-issai (a bowl of soup and one dish).html
culture.desc: "Ichiju-issai" is one of the menu compositions of meals in Japan.

culture.name: Konarai level of study (for beginners)
culture.desc: Konarai, or naraigoto, is a learning course of tea ceremony, which putting together the procedure of the use of each utensil and the procedures appropriate for the situations.

culture.name: Neriko
culture.desc: Neriko (a pastille) is a solid matter in which powdered fragrant wood, spices, or herbes are mixed together with honey or gum arabic.

culture.name: Sashiage
culture.desc: Sashiage is a way of lifting up votive objects for a Shinto home shrine, which are of a shouldered type used at a festival, such as Mikoshi (a portable shrine), Taikodai (a drum stand), Futon Daiko (a mattress drum) or Dashi (a float), higher than usual.

culture.name: Yoshuku Geino
culture.desc: In seeing the traditional perfuming arts from a religious point of view, Yoshuku Geino refers to various performing arts for celebrating the New Year such as Manzai (a traditional celebratory chant-like song) or Harukoma (a dance in which a performer carries a wooden horse's head), and Ta asobi or Onda, a performance mimicking the processes of rice production to pray for a good harvest before farm work starts.

culture.name: Shigai
culture.desc: Shigai (also known as Ito no Kutsu, or Shiai) is a pair of silk shoes worn by underage member of Imperial family, performers of Dobu (also known as Warawamai Dance, performed by children), or young shrine maidens who participate in the Shinto rituals.

culture.name: Mochibana
culture.desc: Mochibana is a decoration made of small-cut rice cake or dango (sweet rice dumpling) on a branch of Japanese sumac, hackberry, or willow tree for New Year's Holidays or small New Year's festival around January 15.

culture.name: Engimono
culture.desc: Engimono (a lucky charm) is an object with which to celebrate or pray for something good.

culture.name: Kishamitsumono
culture.desc: Kishamitsumono' is a general term that refers to forms of traditional Japanese horseback archery:'Inu oumono' (dog hunt), 'Yabusame' (shooting at fixed targets), and 'Kasagake' (shooting at suspended targets at closer range).

culture.name: Kasagake
culture.desc: Kasagake' (笠懸) is a traditional Japanese form of horseback archery technique/practice/event/form where the archer mounted on a galloping steed shoots 'Kaburaya' arrows (arrows that whistle) at targets.

culture.name: Kiri-mon
culture.desc: Kiri-mon (paulownia patterns) is a generic name for Monsho (crests or coats of arms) that are based on paulownia.

culture.name: Kamashi
culture.desc: Kamashi is a craftsman to found chagama (iron tea ceremony pot).

culture.name: Dashi-maki Tamago
culture.desc: Dashi-maki Tamago is a kind of an omelet (a Japanese style omelet) and a dish of fried beaten eggs mixed with dashi broth soup.

culture.name: Mato (kyudo [Japanese archery])
culture.desc: Mato refers to a target used in kyudo and other Japanese archery arts.

culture.name: Okowa
culture.desc: Okowa refers to rice served as a meal cooked by steaming glutinous rice.

culture.name: Otsukimi Dorobo
culture.desc: Otsukimi Dorobo is one of the children's moon viewing events held in various regions.

culture.name: Sekkyo-bushi
culture.desc: Sekkyo-bushi (sermon ballads), written as 説経節 in Japanese, is oral literature in the beginning of the early-modern times in Japan.

culture.name: The screen of the annual observances
culture.url: culture/The screen of the annual observances.html
culture.desc: The screen of the annual observances is a self-standing screen which was put in Hirobisashi (broad eaves) adjacent to Seiryoden (literally "Limpid Cool Hall," an imperial summer palace) and faced to the Upper Door (an entrance to the courtiers' hall).

culture.name: Nagashi-bina
culture.desc: Nagashi-bina (paper dolls floated downriver) is an event which is said to be the origin of the Dolls' Festival.

culture.name: Japanese wine
culture.desc: The section of Japanese wine describes the wine produced in Japan.

culture.name: Aiuchi
culture.desc: The term "aiuchi" means to hit or strike each other at the same time in kendo (Japanese fencing) and so on.

culture.name: Matsuri
culture.desc: The Japanese term "matsuri" (festival, written as 祭 or 祭り) refers to ceremonies or Shinto rituals worshipping Shinreikon (the spirit of God).

culture.name: Onigiri
culture.desc: Onigiri (rice ball) is a food, which flavored cooked rice, put fillings, and collectively shaped into triangle, rectangular rounds, or sphere.

culture.name: Yuin
culture.desc: Yuin is a seal that has no character belonging to any individuals or corporations such as full name, gago (pseudonym), trade name and yago (shop name), but has inmon (words or symbols engraved on the seal) curved.

culture.name: WASA Norito
culture.desc: Norito WASA was a feudal retainer of Kishu Domain in the early Edo period.

culture.name: Hidari Tachi
culture.desc: Hidari Tachi is the technique to hold and grip a sword with the left hand placed towards the Tsuba (a hand guard) and the right hand placed at the base of the hilt, meanwhile the right hand is usually placed towards a Tsuba and the left hand is placed at the base of a hilt in the art of swordsmanship.

culture.name: Sanjugen
culture.desc: Sanjugen (30-strings Koto) is a kind of So or Koto (a long Japanese zither with 30 strings).

culture.name: Hariko
culture.desc: Hariko is one of the plastic arts technique which forms papier-mache by attaching pieces of paper to frames made of bamboo or wood or molds made of clay.

culture.name: Jokisen
culture.desc: Jokisen is a brand of Japanese green tea.

culture.name: Tsuzura
culture.desc: Tsuzura (wicker clothes hamper) is originally a kind of basket with a lid and is woven out of Tsuzurafuji (Sinomenium acutum, another name is Otuzurafuji) vines.

culture.name: Sumai no Sechie
culture.desc: Sumai no Sechie was one of the ceremonies that took place in the imperial court between the Nara period through to the Heian period.

culture.name: Komahiki
