culture.desc: The 'komahiki' event was one ritual that occurred within the imperial court in August each year when horses that were agisted in the Eastern provinces according to imperial edict were brought to the south hall of the imperial palace and paraded in front of the Emperor and afterwards nobility selected some whilst the remainder were stabled or allocated to the imperial guard.

culture.name: Doko Copper Vessels
culture.desc: Doko' are utensils used to heat water and warm sake by placing on braziers.

culture.name: Fundoshi Iwai (Loincloth Rituals)
culture.desc: Fundoshi Iwai (aka Heko Iwai) is a coming-of-age ritual for men, that takes place in some regions of Japan.

culture.name: Kenjo no shoji
culture.desc: Kenjo no shoji (sliding screens of the 32 Chinese sages) are sliding screens that were placed at the main housing of the Shishin-den Hall (hall for state ceremonies) to be separated from the kitakata kitabisashi (northern eaves) in the Imperial Palace.

culture.name: Kotsuzake
culture.desc: Kotsuzake is a Japanese cuisine, and is a way of drinking sake.

culture.name: Hauta
culture.desc: Hauta (a Japanese traditional song or ballad sung to the accompaniment of the shamisen) were originally regarded as shorter versions of nagauta (ballads sung to shamisen accompaniment).

culture.name: Dakyu
culture.desc: Dakyu, also known as Uchimari (Japanese polo) is an athletic sport or a game similar to polo, once played in Japan.

culture.name: Kamigata Uta
culture.desc: "Kamigata uta" (also called "Kamigata hauta") is the songs with shamisen (the three-stringed Japanese banjo) accompaniment, performed and enjoyed in Kamigata (Kyoto-Osaka area).

culture.name: Kouta
culture.desc: "Kouta" is a popular song accompanied with shamisen (the three-stringed Japanese banjo), which was originally derived from "hauta" (a Japanese short ballad accompanied with shamisen).

culture.name: Toji (chief brewer at a sake brewery)
culture.url: culture/Toji (chief brewer at a sake brewery).html
culture.desc: The term "toji," written as 杜氏 in Japanese, refers to a person who supervises kurabito, a group of skilled workers responsible for sake brewing, and works as the chief executive brewer at a brewery.

culture.name: Sunoko
culture.desc: "Sunoko" is a Japanese wooden board made of slatted thick bars.

culture.name: Dako
culture.desc: Dako was originally a container to spit saliva or phlegm.

culture.name: Yusurutsuki
culture.desc: Yusurutsuki is a container for shiromizu (water after washing rice) which is to be used for washing and arranging hair.

culture.name: Hirezake
culture.desc: Hirezake (hot sake [Japanese liquor] flavored with fish fins) is a way of drinking sake.

culture.name: Tsujigahana
culture.desc: Tsujigahana: The title of a movie that Shochiku Co.,Ltd. released in 1972, starring Shima IWASHITA

culture.name: Hatsumode
culture.desc: Hatsumode is an event to pray for safety and peace for the year by visiting a shrine or temple (a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple), or church for the first time since the start of a new year.

culture.name: Nihon Shishu
culture.desc: "Nihon shishu" is Japanese handmade embroidery made using silk thread.

culture.name: Mentsuyu
culture.desc: Mentsuyu is a Japanese flavoring sauce made mainly from soup stock, soy sauce, mirin (sweet sake [Japanese liquor] for cooking) - or sake itself - and sugar.

culture.name: Toka no Sechie
culture.desc: Toka no sechie was an event where the emperor watched toka (stamping songs) in the Imperial Court every January (by the lunar calendar).

culture.name: Nensho Geigi
culture.desc: Nensho geigi refers to a young geigi (a woman who gives fun with a song, dance or music instrument at a feast; geisha) who is not yet a full-fledged, or a girl who appears in ozashiki (banquets in which guests are attended by geisha) in hanamachi (geisha districts) as a geigi apprentice.

culture.name: Temariuta
culture.desc: Temariuta (written in Japanese as てまりうた, 手まり唄, 手毬歌, 手毬唄, etc.) is a kind of children's song or play song to which girls sing along as they bounce temari balls (balls of cotton wound tightly around with threads of many colors).

culture.name: Tsubazeriai
culture.desc: Tsubazeriai means warding off (and pushing back) each other's sword with one's own sword guard in a duel, this is also synonymous with "neck-and-neck" competition.

culture.name: Seven Wonders of Shimabara
culture.desc: The Seven Wonders of Shimabara are wonders taught in Shimabara (the entertainment area in Kyoto City).

culture.name: Fushin
culture.desc: Fushin (普請), where fu (普) means widely and shin (請) means asking for help, refers to a request for widespread and equal community service (monetary support, labor support, financial assistance), where a whole community is asked to build and maintain public infrastructures.

culture.name: HOSHINO Shigenori
culture.desc: Shigenori HOSHINO was a feudal retainer of the Owari clan and an expert in kyujutsu (the art of Japanese archery) who lived during the early part of the Edo period.

culture.name: Haibu
culture.desc: Haibu (haimu) refers to a ritual of bowing which includes sayusa (a series of movement from left to right to left) for expressing one's gratitude on occasions such as joi (investiture of a court rank), appointment, and shiroku (receiving a stipend) in the Imperial Court during the Heian period.

culture.name: Oshorei
culture.desc: Oshorei (written as 御招霊; also pronounced as oshorai) is one of the annual events for the Japanese Urabon festival (a Festival of the Dead or Buddhist All Soul's Day, held around the 15th of July or August, depending on local customs).

culture.name: Uji saicha shi
culture.desc: Uji saicha shi was a procession that carried Uji tea leaves, one of the specialties of Uji City, Kyoto, in a chatsubo (tea jar) to be presented to the Tokugawa Shogunate Family.

culture.name: Ohara zakone
culture.desc: Ohara zakone is a custom that existed in the Ohara region, where a large number of people would all sleep together in one room on the night of Setsubun (the traditional end of winter) in Efumi-jinja Shrine in Ide, Ohara Village, Atago County, Kyoto Prefecture (present day Oharanomura-cho, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City).

culture.name: Zan-Shin
culture.desc: Zan-shin is a term used in Japanese budo (martial arts) and geido (accomplishments).

culture.name: Kinako (Soybean Flour)
culture.desc: Soybean flour is cereal flour made from soybeans that are roasted, peeled and ground.

culture.name: Tsuka
culture.desc: Tsuka (mound) means a raised round site higher than its surrounding land surface, specifically, it means an elevation made of a pile of something, a small mountain, a hill and an ancient burial mound.

culture.name: Giontsujiri
culture.desc: Giontsujiri is a corporation located in Gion, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Kuchiko (the ovaries of sea cucumbers)
culture.desc: Kuchiko are the ovaries of sea cucumbers.

culture.name: Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Luck)
culture.desc: Shichifukujin refers to seven deities which are believed to bring good luck in Japan.

culture.name: Nochi no Hina
culture.desc: Nochi no Hina refers to Hina dolls displayed on August 1st (old calendar) or September 9th (old calendar) in the Edo Period, or to displaying them.

culture.name: Hashihime (the Maiden of the Bridge)
culture.desc: Hashihime is a lady, ogress or goddess who appears in legends about bridges.

culture.name: Uguisu-an (a green sweet bean paste)
culture.desc: Uguisu-an is a green smooth bean paste made by crushing boiled green peas and sweetening with sugar or honey.

culture.name: Oden
culture.desc: Oden is a type of boiled and seasoned food in Japanese cuisine.

culture.name: Ami-ha School
culture.desc: Ami-ha school is one of the painting schools representing the Muromachi Period.

culture.name: Giondofu
culture.desc: Giondofu refers to a Dengakudofu (tofu, bean curd skewered, roasted over charcoal, and coated with miso) dish, sold by two chaya (tea houses) in front of Yasaka-jinja Shrine (Gion-jinja Shrine) in Kyoto in the Edo Period.

culture.name: Zenki and Goki (Ogre in front and the one in back)
culture.url: culture/Zenki and Goki (Ogre in front and the one in back).html
culture.desc: Zenki and Goki refer to an ogre couple which EN no Ozunu (A semi-legendary holy man noted for his practice of mountain asceticism during the second half of the seventh century), a founder of Shugendo (Japanese mountain asceticism-shamanism incorporating Shinto and Buddhist concepts), was accompanied with.

culture.name: Hiochi (putrefaction)
culture.desc: Hiochi is one of the terms on manufacturing sake (rice wine), and it means that sake in the manufacturing process has become cloudy and spoiled, while being stored.

culture.name: Zeshi rokuju igo Sarugaku dangi
culture.jp: 世子六十以後申楽談儀
culture.desc: Zeshi rokuju igo Sarugaku dangi (also known as "Sarugaku dangi") was established in the Muromachi Period, which is a written record on Zeami's discourse about the art and has been handed down from ancestors as a collection of art treatises on Nohgaku.

culture.name: Suiseki
culture.desc: Suiseki is Japanese culture or hobby of viewing stones indoors.

culture.name: Kirikane (a traditional decorative technique by cut gold)
culture.url: culture/Kirikane (a traditional decorative technique by cut gold).html
culture.desc: Kirikane (literally, cut leaf), which is also called hosogane (literally thinly cut leaf), refers to a traditional technique of creating patterns by using brushes to bond several leaves of gold, silver or platinum together, which are then burnt together and cut into shapes such as narrow rectangles, triangles, diamonds, or circles.

culture.name: Miyako Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Fortune in Kyoto)
culture.url: culture/Miyako Shichifukujin (Seven Deities of Good Fortune in Kyoto).html
culture.desc: Miyako shichifukujin are stamp places for pilgrims to visit seven deities of good fortune, which consist of seven temples and shrines in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Fushimi Jikkoku-bune Boat
culture.desc: Jikkoku-bune Boat is a pleasure boat operated by Fushimi Yumekobo Co., Ltd. funded by 55 companies including Gekkeikan Sake Co., Ltd.

culture.name: Sakai Festival
culture.desc: Sakai Festival (Sakai no Matsuri) is a festival that was held at corner points and boundaries in Oto (imperial capital) and Koku-gun in the governing system in the ancient and medieval period of Japan.

culture.name: Datotsu
culture.desc: Datotsu refers to a technique in Kendo (Japanese art of fencing.)

culture.name: Hashira-jochu (a brewing method of sake liquor)
culture.url: culture/Hashira-jochu (a brewing method of sake liquor).html
culture.desc: "Hashira-jochu" was one of the terms used for traditional manufacturing methods of sake (Japanese rice wine) that existed in the beginning of the Edo Period, which is to add shochu (distilled spirit) or kasudori-shochu (shochu made from sake lees) to moromi (unrefined sake) or newly brewed sake after separation from lees by applying pressure.

culture.name: Mushiokuri (an annual Japanese festival)
culture.desc: Mushiokuri is an annual Japanese festival.

culture.name: Kameno-o (a rice variety)
culture.desc: "Kameno-o" is a variety of Japanese rice developed by a practical farmer, Kameji ABE, of Yamagata Prefecture in the early Meiji Period of the history of Japanese sake.

culture.name: Minamikannon yama (one of decorative floats parading in Gion festival in Kyoto)
culture.url: culture/Minamikannon yama (one of decorative floats parading in Gion festival in Kyoto).html
culture.desc: "Minamikannon yama" is one of "yamahoko" (decorative floats) parading in Gion festival in Kyoto on July 17 every year.

culture.name: Hashioki
culture.desc: Hashioki is a small object placed on a table to prevent chopsticks from rolling down.

culture.name: Gozenshu
culture.desc: Gozenshu is sake (Japanese liquor) which was brewed and delivered to people such as seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) during the Edo period in Japan as a drink for so-called "tono-sama (a person with higher rank)".

culture.name: Ninja (professional spy in feudal Japan highly trained in stealth and secrecy)
culture.url: culture/Ninja (professional spy in feudal Japan highly trained in stealth and secrecy).html
culture.desc: Ninja is a name of individual or group who served daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) or feudal lord doing intelligence activities and assassinations from the Kamakura period to Edo period in Japan.

culture.name: Maiko makeover
culture.desc: "Maiko makeover" is a kind of service offered for visitors to Kyoto City, especially around Gion area, which satisfies desires of those who adore maiko girls to transform their looks by dressing them up like maiko or geiko with kimono, a wig, kanzashi (hair stick), etc.

culture.name: Toshi-otoko
culture.desc: "Toshi-otoko" (literally means a man of the year) is one of the Japanese customs.

culture.name: Warigo
culture.desc: Warigo is a kind of portable tableware which is made of thinly stripped plain wood boards such as hinoki (Japanese cypress).

culture.name: Sando
culture.desc: Sando (three ways) often means 'Sado' (tea ceremony), 'Kado' (flower arrangement) and 'Kodo' (traditional incense-smelling ceremony), and also it often includes Shodo (calligraphy).

culture.name: Syakuhashi
culture.desc: Syakuhashi is the name of the bridge which appears on the Milky Way in a Chinese legend on the day of Tanabata star festival, the seventh of July in the old lunar calendar.

culture.name: Nodate (open-air tea ceremony)
culture.desc: Nodate is an open-air tea ceremony in which people make and enjoy green tea or powdered green tea.

culture.name: Hitotsumono
culture.desc: Hitotsumono is a Buddhism or Shinto ritual/event held in festivals or gatherings in shrines and temples.

culture.name: Kuki-cha (Twig Tea)
culture.desc: Kuki-cha is one of Japanese green teas.

culture.name: Chofuku
culture.desc: Chofuku is the clothes that government officials wore from the Aska period to the Heian period when they came to work at the Imperial Court.

culture.name: Traditional Horse Racing (Japan)
culture.desc: This article describes Japanese traditional horse racing (running horses for the speed competition and then deciding which horse is superior), called kurabeuma, kisoiuma, or komakurabe.

culture.name: Winter Festivals
culture.desc: Winter festivals are the festivals celebrated during the winter

culture.name: Senmen Hokekyo Sasshi (fan-shaped articles decorated with sutras)
culture.url: culture/Senmen Hokekyo Sasshi (fan-shaped articles decorated with sutras).html
culture.desc: The Senmen Hokekyo Sasshi or Senmen Koshakyo is a collection of fan-shaped articles decorated with sutras that has been passed down by Shitenno-ji Temple in Osaka.

culture.name: Michikiri (a folk custom practiced on roads or crossroads at the entrance to villages)
culture.url: culture/Michikiri (a folk custom practiced on roads or crossroads at the entrance to villages).html
culture.desc: Michikiri is a folk custom practiced on roads or crossroads at the entrance to villages (or regions).

culture.name: Muromachi Culture
culture.desc: Muromachi culture was a Japanese culture of the Muromachi period in which the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was established in Kyoto by the Ashikaga clan.

culture.name: Hachimanyama (Yamahoko Float)
culture.desc: Hachimanyama is one of "yamahoko" floats, or decorative floats, which are paraded through streets during the Gion Festival held in Kyoto City on the seventeenth of July.

culture.name: San-shikishi
culture.desc: San-shikishi is a collective term for the "Tsugi-shikishi" (spliced shikishi), "Sunshoan-shikishi," and "Masu-shikishi" (square shishiki) and is one of the best examples of "kana-gaki" (writing in kana, as opposed to Chinese characters) calligraphy from the Heian period.

culture.name: Oharame
culture.desc: Oharame refers to the women who came from Ohara, Yamashiro Province (Kyoto City) (Ohara, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture) to sell firewood in the capital Kyoto by placing the firewood on their heads.

culture.name: Tanzaku
culture.desc: Tanzaku means paper cut into strips, or thin slices of wood.

culture.name: Hikime-Kagibana
culture.desc: Hikime-kagibana is a typological and stylized description technique for the eyes and nose of a person's face, used in the Yamato-e paintings (traditional Japanese style painting of the late Heian and Kamakura periods dealing with Japanese themes) and fuzokuga (pictures of manners and customs) during the Heian and Kamakura periods.

culture.name: Mitsuda-e (a kind of oil painting)
culture.desc: The term "Mitsuda-e" refers to a kind of painting technique.

culture.name: Shitone (cushions stuffed with floss silk)
culture.desc: The term "shitone" refers to an ancient name of cushions to sit on or lie on.

culture.name: Tocha (a tea competition)
culture.desc: The term "Tocha" refers to a tea competition where participants taste different kinds of tea to compete in discerning them, which was popular in the medieval period.

culture.name: Shibai-jaya (A tea room located in a theater)
culture.url: culture/Shibai-jaya (A tea room located in a theater).html
culture.desc: Scene of the second floor of a high class shibai-jaya (ooyaja).

culture.name: Mekabu Seaweed
culture.desc: Mekabu seaweed is the thick, folded part of the phyllodes of wakame seaweed (Undaria pinnatifida) that is located above its appressoria.

culture.name: Machiya (Merchant House)
culture.desc: Machiya is a house of common people in town.

culture.name: Konnyaku
culture.desc: Konnyaku (scientific name: Amorphophallus konjac) refers to an herb of the Araceae family or a food derived from the plant's bulb.

culture.name: Shigureni
culture.desc: Shigureni (seafood or meat that has been cooked in soy sauce and mirin) is a kind of tsukudani (small fish, shellfish, konbu (a kind of kelp used for Japanese soup stock), etc. boiled in sweetened soy sauce) cooked with ginger.

culture.name: Wayo (Japanese Style)
culture.desc: The Japanese "Wayo" (Japanese style) means things with Japanese tastes or Japanese-style, used as the opposite of "karayo" (Chinese style) meaning those with Chinese tastes or Chinese-style.

culture.name: Autumn Festivals
culture.desc: Autumn festivals collectively mean festivals held in autumn.

culture.name: Kado
culture.desc: Kado is a skill and performing art which has been passed down in a specific family for generations.

culture.name: Saisen
culture.desc: Saisen is money offered to the gods (Shinto), Buddha and so on.

culture.name: Yugen
culture.desc: Yugen is one of the basic ideas of Japanese culture in the area of various arts such as literature, paintings, performing arts and architecture.

culture.name: Shinbashi-dori Street
culture.desc: Shinbashi-dori Street is one of the streets from east to west in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Hikihitomai
culture.desc: "Hikihitomai" is a kind of "sarugaku" (form of theatre popular in Japan during the 11th to 14th centuries).

culture.name: Sakubei (a kind of Chinese sweet)
culture.desc: Sakubei is a one kind of "togashi" (literally 'Chinese sweet'), which were introduced to Japan from ancient China, and is also said to be the origin of somen noodles.

culture.name: Buke Sado (the tea ceremony of samurai family)
culture.url: culture/Buke Sado (the tea ceremony of samurai family).html
culture.desc: Buke sado is the tea ceremony performed among the samurai families mainly in the Edo period and after.

culture.name: Karukuchi
culture.desc: "Karukuchi" is an old name of Kamigata rakugo, traditional Japanese comic storytelling as performed in the Kyoto-Osaka region.

culture.name: Konacha (Dust Green Tea)
culture.desc: Konacha is the powdery fragments collected in the production process of sencha (green tea of middle grade).

culture.name: Shijo school
culture.desc: The Shijo school is a large group among those of the Japanese painting world.

culture.name: Azuki-gayu (rice and azuki bean porridge)
culture.desc: Azuki-gayu is rice porridge cooked with azuki beans.

culture.name: Maruyama-Shijo School
culture.desc: Maruyama-Shijo School is a name collectively referring to Maruyama School founded by Okyo MARUYAMA and Shijo School founded by Goshun MATSUMURA, which became famous in Kyoto from the late Edo Period.

culture.name: Japanese Comics
culture.desc: In the section on Japanese comics, history and characteristics of the comics produced in Japan are discussed.

culture.name: Saga Goryu
culture.desc: "Saga Goryu" is a school of flower arrangement, whose founder was the Emperor Saga.

culture.name: Kyo Kano
culture.desc: Kyo Kano (Kyoto branch of the Kano School, also called "Kyo-gano") was a school of painters who created many prominent works from the end of Azuchi Momoyama period through the Meiji period.

culture.name: Kafu
culture.desc: Kafu (family tradition) is a style of behavior, including custom and procedure, which has been specifically inherited down the generations within certain individual families.

culture.name: Japanese Foods Boom
culture.desc: The Japanese foods boom indicates the situation that Japanese food is extolled by foreigners living in countries and regions other than Japan

culture.name: Classical Rakugo (classical comic story-telling)
culture.desc: Classical rakugo generally includes programs of Rakugo which were created from the Edo to Meiji eras.

culture.name: Kamigata Rakugo (Comic Storytelling in Kyoto and Osaka)
culture.url: culture/Kamigata Rakugo (Comic Storytelling in Kyoto and Osaka).html
culture.desc: Kamigata rakugo is comic storytelling mostly performed in the areas around the prefectures of Osaka and Kyoto.

culture.name: F.C. Kyoto Sanga
culture.desc: Kyoto Sanga F.C. (京都サンガF.C.) is a professional football (soccer) club which is based in Kyoto City, Japan, and is affiliated with the Japan Professional Football League (J. League for short).

culture.name: Nihon-ryori (Japanese cuisine)
culture.desc: 日本料理 (nihonryori or nipponryori in Japanese pronunciation) (Japanese cuisine) indicates the traditional Japanese dishes, in particular, using foodstuffs familiar in Japan, which have been developed uniquely in the land and environment of Japan.

culture.name: Toro
culture.desc: Toro' is fish meat cut from a specific part of tuna, and is used as an ingredient for sushi, etc.

culture.name: Hinawaju (matchlock gun)
culture.desc: Hinawaju (English: matchlock gun) is one form of gun in early times.

culture.name: Wareki (Japanese Calendar)
culture.desc: Wareki (Japanese calendar) refers to a calendar peculiar to Japan, by which time is divided into periods based on gengo (an era name) and ensuing years

culture.name: Obi
culture.desc: Obi is a kind of belt-like accessory that functions to fix clothes by wrapping around the body.

culture.name: Sakura (Cherry blossoms)
culture.desc: Sakura is the generic name of the Genus Cerasus of Rosaceae, excluding apricots and peaches, and refers to plants belonging to Subgenus Cerasus.

culture.name: Hina-matsuri (Doll's Festival)
culture.desc: Hina-matsuri is an annual event of the seasonal festival to pray for the healthy growth of girls.

culture.name: Tenpo-reki (Tenpo calendar)
culture.desc: Tenpo-reki (or Tenpo calendar) is a Japanese calendar based on the lunar solar calendar used in old Japan.

culture.name: Anpan
culture.desc: Anpan (a round soft bread with azuki bean paste in the center) is a kind of a sweet bun with 'an' (sweet bean paste).

culture.name: Curry
culture.desc: Curry (Curry in English) is a dish in which vegetables and meat are cooked with several spices.

culture.name: Otoshidama
culture.desc: Otoshidama (おとしだま、御年玉) or Toshidama (年玉) is a present which is given to celebrate the New Year.

culture.name: Sanbaizu
culture.desc: Sanbaizu is a mixed seasoning made from equal amounts of vinegar, soy sauce, and sweet cooking rice wine.

culture.name: Meat sauce (Bolognese sauce)
culture.desc: Bolognese (ragù alla bolognese in Italian, ragò a la bulgnàisa in Bolognese dialect) or bolognaise (sauce bolognaise in French) is a kind of sauce (seasoning) mainly made from meat and tomato originating in Bologna, Italy.

culture.name: Unagi (eel)
culture.desc: Unagi is a general term used for a group of fish that belong to the order Anguilliformes family Anguilidae.

culture.name: Kabayaki
culture.desc: Kabayaki is broiled fish made by cutting the fish open, removing the bones, and broiling and basting it with a sauce made of soy sauce, mirin (sweet cooking rice wine), sugar and sake (rice wine).

culture.name: Unagimeshi (Broiled Eel Rice)
culture.desc: Unagimeshi is a term used to refer to a Japanese cuisine that comes with broiled eel on top of rice.

culture.name: Naporitan
culture.desc: Naporitan (Napolitan) is a Japanese spaghetti dish flavored with tomato ketchup.

culture.name: Kadomatsu (New Year's pine decoration)
culture.desc: The kadomatsu (literally, gate pine) is a pair of displays made of pine and bamboo set up in places such as in front of houses during the New Year.

culture.name: Shogatsu
culture.desc: Shogatsu refers to the first several days of a calendar year and, from a cultural viewpoint, an event to celebrate passing of the previous year, which was uneventful, and the new year.

culture.name: Rakugoka (Rakugo Story Teller)
culture.desc: A rakugoka performs rakugo (traditional comic storytelling) as an occupation.

culture.name: Kamigata Hanashika (traditional comic storyteller of the Kansai region)
culture.url: culture/Kamigata Hanashika (traditional comic storyteller of the Kansai region).html
culture.desc: Kamigata hanashika is Hanashika (professional Rakugo storyteller) of Kamigata rakugo, traditional Japanese comic storytelling as performed in the Kyoto-Osaka region.

culture.name: Shamisen (a three-stringed Japanese banjo)
culture.desc: Shamisen is a Japanese stringed musical instrument with a neck.

culture.name: Jinjitsu
culture.desc: Jinjitsu

culture.name: Wasan (Japanese mathematics)
culture.desc: Wasan (Japanese mathematics) is a type of mathematics uniquely developed in Japan.

culture.name: Miso (fermented soybean paste)
culture.desc: Miso is a Japanese food made by fermenting grains.

culture.name: Saida
culture.desc: Saida is a Japanese term used to refer to alcohol-free, transparent and colorless soda which tastes sweet and sour.

culture.name: Western Dishes
culture.desc: Western dishes are the dishes peculiar to the Western countries.

culture.name: Udon
culture.desc: Udon noodles count among traditional noodles eaten in Japan from ancient times.

culture.name: Octopus
culture.desc: Cirrina (enCirrina)

culture.name: Sashimi
culture.desc: Sashimi is a Japanese delicacy consisting of raw seafood that is sliced and eaten with seasonings such as soy sauce and vinegared miso (fermented soybean paste) along with condiments such as wasabi (Japanese horseradish) and ginger.

culture.name: Mochi
culture.desc: Mochi (rice cake) refers to a kind of food which is produced by adding water to grain, especially mochi-gome (glutinous rice), heating, thereafter, kneading, applying an external force and shaping the kneaded mixture, and mochi is also called tsuki-mochi (pounded rice cake).

culture.name: Hanbagu (Hamburger)
culture.desc: Hanbagu (hamburger) or hanbagu suteki (hamburger steak) is a dish, made by adding minced vegetables such as onions, and seasonings such as pepper into ground meat (pork, beef, other meat of livestock, or a combination of meats), mixing eggs and bread crumbs together, forming the meat mixture into ovals or circles, and broiling them.

culture.name: Shungiku
culture.desc: Shungiku (the scientific name: Chrysanthemum coronarium, Syn, Leucanthemum coronarium, or Glebionis coronaria, the English name: Crown daisy) is a plant native to the Mediterranean coast, and is classified in the genus Chrysanthemum of the family Asteraceae.

culture.name: Shiso (Perilla)
culture.desc: Shiso (紫蘇,Perilla, the scientific name: Perilla frutescens var. crispa) is a plant, a genus of Perilla that belongs to the Lamiaceae family.

culture.name: Ise Ebi (Japanese spiny lobster)
culture.desc: Ise ebi, or Japanese spiny lobster (Panulirus japonicus) is a species of lobsters that belongs to Parimuridae of Decapoda.

culture.name: Kenjutsu (剣術) (Swordplay)
culture.desc: Kenjutsu is one of Japan's Kobudo (classical martial arts) with the focus of killing and wounding opponents with a katana (Japanese sword).

culture.name: Kobudo (Japanese classical martial arts)
culture.desc: Kobudo is a generic name which refers to the systematized Japanese traditional martial arts to fight without arms or with arms like dull weapons, cutting tools, firearms, and so on (kobudo is sometimes called koryubujutsu, kobujutsu, etc. which have almost the same meaning as kobudo).

culture.name: Kappumen (cup-packaged instant noodles)
culture.desc: Kappumen indicates the item consisting of instant noodles such as dried noodles and fresh noodles put into a container usable as tableware and the attached ingredients.

culture.name: Umeshu (Ume Liqueur)
culture.desc: "Umeshu" is a liqueur which is popular in Japan and made by steeping green ume (Japanese apricots), which are generally picked around June, in alcohol (normally in white liquor or shochu - distilled spirits).

culture.name: Nihon eiho (Japanese style of swimming)
culture.desc: Nihon eiho, also called Koshiki eiho, is a Japanese traditional style of swimming.

culture.name: Nue (a fabulous creature)
culture.desc: Nue is a legendary creature that is called a specter and has been talked about in Japan from ancient times.

culture.name: Senmyo Calendar (a variation of the lunar calendar that was created in ancient China)
culture.url: culture/Senmyo Calendar (a variation of the lunar calendar that was created in ancient China).html
culture.desc: Senmyo Calendar is a kind of Chinese calendar.

culture.name: Jokyoreki (Jokyo Calendar)
culture.desc: The Jokyoreki (Jokyo calendar) is a Japanese lunar-solar calendar, formerly used in Japan.

culture.name: Horyakureki (Horyaku Calendar)
culture.desc: The Horyakureki or Horekireki is a Japanese lunar-solar calendar, formerly used in Japan.

culture.name: Kanseirei (Kansei Calendar)
culture.desc: The Kanseirei (Kansei calendar) is a Japanese lunar-solar calendar, formerly used in Japan.

culture.name: Kaitenzushi (conveyer belt sushi)
culture.desc: Kaitenzushi is a type of inexpensive semi-self-service sushi restaurant where various kinds of sushi on small plates are traveling continuously on the conveyer belt passing along the counter seats.

culture.name: Kokyu (a stringed instrument)
culture.desc: Kokyu is a Japanese stringed instrument.

culture.name: Genkareki
culture.desc: Genkareki is one form of Chinese calendar, a lunisolar calendar formerly used in China and Japan.

culture.name: Kaijitsu/Tsugomori/Misoka (last day of month)
culture.desc: Kaijitsu, tsugomori or misoka is the last day of month in the Chinese and Japanese calendars, which are lunisolar calendars.

culture.name: Giho reki (Giho calendar)
culture.desc: Giho reki is a Chinese calendar and is a lunisolar calendar which was compiled by Chunfeng LI, an astronomer during the Tang dynasty.

culture.name: Fukubukuro (Lucky bags)
culture.desc: Fukubukuro are bags containing random goods to sell at department stores for the first day of business at the beginning of the year.

culture.name: Horagai (Conch)
culture.desc: Horagai, with the scientific name Charonia tritonis, is a type of snall that belongs to the Cymatiidae family, formerly classified under Cymatiidae, Mesogastropoda.

culture.name: Hatsuka Shogatsu (Cerebration on 20th day of the new year)
culture.url: culture/Hatsuka Shogatsu (Cerebration on 20th day of the new year).html
culture.desc: Hatsuka Shogatsu is the last day of the New Year.

culture.name: Ehomairi (visit to a shrine or a temple in the lucky direction)
culture.url: culture/Ehomairi (visit to a shrine or a temple in the lucky direction).html
culture.desc: Ehomairi is one of the events of the New Year from ancient times.

culture.name: Wakamizu (the first water drawn from the well on New Year's Day)
culture.url: culture/Wakamizu (the first water drawn from the well on New Years Day).html
culture.desc: Wakamizu means drawing water from a well early on New Year's Day morning and offering it at a household Shinto altar.

culture.name: Donburimono (a rice dish)
culture.desc: Here, descriptions of a Japanese dish Donburimono are given.

culture.name: Hatsuni (first cargo of the year)
culture.desc: Hatsuni means shipping goods (products) from distribution bases including factories and warehouses to stores for the first time after the new year starts.

culture.name: Taienreki
culture.desc: Taienreki (大衍暦: also read as Daienreki) was a lunisolar calendar once used in China and Japan.

culture.name: Misodengaku (skewed and roasted foodstuff with miso coating)
culture.url: culture/Misodengaku (skewed and roasted foodstuff with miso coating).html
culture.desc: "Misodengaku" is a dish prepared by skewering foodstuffs such as tofu, konnyaku, egg plant and satoimo (taro), pasting them with Japanese-lemon (citron) or Japanese-pepper flavored miso (bean paste) and then roasting them.

culture.name: Wafuku
culture.desc: Wafuku is traditional Japanese clothing.

culture.name: Ehomaki (maki-zushi, eating on the day of Setsubun)
culture.url: culture/Ehomaki (maki-zushi, eating on the day of Setsubun).html
culture.desc: Ehomaki (written as 恵方巻 or 恵方巻き) refers to the maki-zushi (sushi roll) eating which on the day of Setsubun (the traditional end of winter) is considered to bring good luck, or the custom centered around the Kinki region of eating the ehomaki.

culture.name: Somen (Japanese vermicelli)
culture.desc: Somen is a kind of noodle made from flour.

culture.name: Korozen no Goho (黄櫨染御袍)
culture.desc: Korozen no goho is a word in the glossary of Japanese clothes meaning an upper garment which constitutes the traditional formal court dress worn by an emperor at a formal ceremony.

culture.name: Enka (Japanese Ballad)
culture.desc: Enka, or 演歌, is one of the categories of Japanese popular music, which is considered to represent entertaining songs based on feeling and pathos that are unique to Japanese people.

culture.name: Yokai (specter)
culture.desc: Yokai (specter), in folk beliefs handed down in Japan, is an unusual being with supernatural powers that can cause bizarre and abnormal phenomena that are beyond human understanding.

culture.name: Junsai (Water Shield)
culture.desc: Junsai (Brasenia schreberi) is perennial hydrophyte.

culture.name: Kodan (storytelling)
culture.desc: Kodan is a form of traditional Japanese performing arts.

culture.name: Menchi Katsu
culture.desc: Menchi katsu or minchi katsu is a meat dish, in which ground pork or beef (minchi) is mixed well with minced onions, salt and pepper, formed into flat ovals, coated with breading made of flour, beaten eggs and panko (Japanese-style coarse bread crumbs), and deep fried in oil.

culture.name: Kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle)
culture.url: culture/Kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle).html
culture.desc: Kyogen is a traditional form of public entertainment developed from Sarugaku (comical mimicry and speech performance in the Heian period), similar to Noh.

culture.name: Hitsumabushi
culture.desc: Hitsumabushi is a regional cuisine made with eel that is eaten mainly in the Nagoya area.

culture.name: Ochi (the punch line of a joke)
culture.url: culture/Ochi (the punch line of a joke).html
culture.desc: Ochi (the punch line of a joke)

culture.name: Tabi (a kind of split-toe-socks specific to Japan)
culture.url: culture/Tabi (a kind of split-toe-socks specific to Japan).html
culture.desc: A pair of tabi is a Japan-specific traditional item of clothing, and a kind of underwear worn on the feet.

culture.name: Etenraku (Ancient Japanese court dance and music)
culture.url: culture/Etenraku (Ancient Japanese court dance and music).html
culture.desc: "Etenraku" is a piece of gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music).

culture.name: KURATSUKURI no Tori
culture.desc: KURATSUKURI no Tori was a busshi (sculptor of Buddhist Statues) of the naturalized citizen group who was active in the Asuka period.

culture.name: Busshi (sculptor of Buddhist statues)
culture.desc: Busshi is a name for someone who is in charge of making Buddhist statues and so on, in Japan.

culture.name: Rien (Theatrical World)
culture.desc: Rien refers to the theatrical world of Kabuki and/or Kabuki itself.

culture.name: Soboro (Seasoned fish or meat powder)
culture.desc: Soboro is the soy-simmered, fine-crumb ground meat using pork, chicken, fish or shrimp.

culture.name: The Kyoto Prize
culture.desc: The Kyoto Prize is the international award given to the people who made great contribution to science, technology and culture.

culture.name: Shiyu no Utage
culture.desc: Shiyu no Utage is a public event of cheerleading clubs sponsored by K.K.D.R.UNIV. Cheerleader Union (the four private universities cheerleading league in Kansai region).

culture.name: Sesson
culture.desc: Sesson (ca. 1504-1589) was a suiboku (ink-wash painting) painter who lived in the late Muromachi period.

culture.name: Yoshoku (western food)
culture.desc: The term "Yoshoku" refers to western food served in Japan.

culture.name: Sojutsu (the art of the spearmanship)
culture.desc: The art of Sojutsu (the spearmanship) is one of the martial arts that has been performed since ancient ages in Japan.

culture.name: Bojutsu
culture.desc: The term "Bojutsu" refers to the art of using a long stick as a weapon in Japanese martial arts.

culture.name: Hojutsu (the art of gunnery)
culture.desc: Hojutsu (the art of gunnery)

culture.name: Yo-ryu hojutsu (gunnery of Yo school)
culture.desc: Yo-ryu hojutsu was a school of gunnery.

culture.name: Morishige-ryu hojutsu (gunnery of Morishige school)
culture.desc: Morishige-ryu hojutsu was a school of gunnery.

culture.name: Seki-ryu Hojutsu (Gunnery of Seki school)
culture.desc: Gunnery of Seki school is one of the schools of gunnery.

culture.name: Fue (an instrument producing sound with an air current)
culture.url: culture/Fue (an instrument producing sound with an air current).html
culture.desc: The term "fue" generally refers to instruments which produce sound with an air current.

culture.name: Gotoku
culture.desc: Gotoku is described as below:

culture.name: Sumi (Chinese Ink)
culture.desc: Sumi refers to soot derived from substances such as lampblack or burnt pine, solidified by mixing with gelatin (solid sumi).

culture.name: Suzuri (ink stone)
culture.desc: Suzuri is a stationery made of stone or kawara (the clay tile of the roof) that sumi (ink) stick is ground on it with water.

culture.name: Suribachi
culture.desc: The term "Suribachi" (mortar) refers to cookware that is used to grind food materials into small grains or mash them up into paste.

culture.name: Shodo (calligraphy)
culture.desc: Shodo or Sho is a creative eastern art that expresses the beauty of characters by writing.

culture.name: The Kikujin no Ho (Surrey green round-necked robe)
culture.url: culture/The Kikujin no Ho (Surrey green round-necked robe).html
culture.desc: The 'Kikujin no ho' is a kind of Sokutai (a traditional ceremonial court dress) that was worn by the emperor at small ceremonies, including special festivals such as Teiza (a festival in which the emperor would be seated in a garden), Noriyumi (betting on archery), and Yuba Hajime (imperial ceremony held to celebrate the first arrow to be shot at the Noriyumi).

culture.name: Shiro Shozoku
culture.desc: Shiro Shozoku means white clothing in the broad sense.

culture.name: Karakasa-kozo (A Japanese popular monster)
culture.desc: Karakasa-kozo (It is also inscribed in different manners such as in all hiragana, one of the Japanese phonetic characters, or in all kanji, Chinese characters) is a yokai (supernatural beings) into which an old umbrella changed.

culture.name: Canned Coffee
culture.desc: Canned coffee means coffee in a can ready to drink without any preparation.

culture.name: Unaju
culture.desc: The terms "Unaju" (written as 鰻重, うなじゅう, うな重) refer to a Japanese dish, which contains broiled eel on rice with sauce in Jubako (generally tiered square wooden boxes with a cover which is coated by urushi Japanese lacquer) or refers to a specific kind of container used to serve broiled eel.

culture.name: Awabi
culture.desc: Awabi (abalone) is a collective term referring to mollusks classified as Haliotidae.

culture.name: Conger Pike
culture.desc: Conger pike (Muraenesox cinereus) is a kind of fish classified in the Muraenesocidae family, order Anguilliformes.

culture.name: Hakumai (White Rice)
culture.desc: Hakumai (white rice) is polished brown rice.

culture.name: Chicken Rice
culture.desc: Chicken rice is a stir-fried rice dish created in Japan, with thinly sliced chicken flavored with ketchup.

culture.name: Shitachi (who counterattacks)
culture.desc: "Shitachi" is a term used in Bujutsu (martial art) especially in Kenjutsu (swordplay), and Budo (martial art) especially in Kendo (Japanese art of fencing).

culture.name: Jinbei
culture.desc: Jinbei or Jinbee is Japanese-style home wear worn by males and children.

culture.name: Dagashi
culture.desc: Dagashi is confectionery aimed at children that can be bought for a small amount of money, such as pocket money.

culture.name: Harakomeshi
culture.desc: Harakomeshi is a dish in which cooked rice is served with salmon flesh and salmon roe placed on top.

culture.name: Kyoto Animation
culture.desc: Kyoto Animation Co., Ltd. is a Japanese corporation engaged in the design and production of animation as well as technical guidance related to animation production.

culture.name: Robatayaki (Japanese grill over charcoal)
culture.desc: Robatayaki refers to the style of premises and serving at restaurants, which originated in Sendai City, Miyagi Prefecture and developed in Kushiro City, Hokkaido, as well as the dishes served there.

culture.name: Oyatsu (afternoon snack)
culture.desc: The term "oyatsu" (おやつ), also written in katakana (one of the Japanese syllabaries) as オヤツ, refers to an afternoon snack that was originally eaten at yatsudoki (approximately 2 p.m.) according to the old Japanese way of counting time.

culture.name: Shunga (erotic art)
culture.desc: Shunga (erotic arts) is a kind of ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints) that portrayed sexual culture (especially the scenes of sexual intercourse between the sexes or the same sex) that was in fashion in the Edo period.

culture.name: Oboro-guruma
culture.desc: Oboro-guruma is a Japanese specter of gissha (ox cart) depicted by Sekien TORIYAMA in the collection of specters "Konjaku Hyakki Shui" (Ancient and Modern Gleanings of the Haunted Demon) in the Edo period.

culture.name: Shokuyo-giku (edible chrysanthemum)
culture.desc: Shokuyo-giku is a kind of chrysanthemum which is especially grown as food.

culture.name: Important Intangible Cultural Property
culture.desc: Juyo mukei bunkazai' refers to 'intangible cultural properties' designated by the Japanese Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology under 'the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties' in Japan.

culture.name: Tango Chirimen (silk crepe)
culture.desc: Tango Chirimen is a high-quality silk fabric produced in the Tango region of Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Modern Gagaku (contemporary music that uses the composition of gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance and music]) and some gagaku instruments)
culture.url: culture/Modern Gagaku (contemporary music that uses the composition of gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance .html
culture.desc: Modern gagaku is a form of newly created modern music that uses partial compositions and some instruments of gagaku, which is a traditional music of ancient Japan.

culture.name: tarutaru sauce (tartar sauce)
culture.desc: Tarutaru sauce (tartare sauce or tartar sauce in English) is a kind of sauce (seasoning) made from mayonnaise.

culture.name: Mozuku (Nemacystus decipiens)
culture.desc: Mozuku (Nemacystus decipiens) is marine alga classified under the family Spermatochnaceae or the family Chordariaceae in the order Chordariales, the class Phaeophyceae.

culture.name: Tsumugi (Pongee)
culture.desc: Tsumugi is a kind of fabric that tsumugi yarn, spun from floss silk, is used as either warp thread or weft thread, or both of them on weaving.

culture.name: Otoshidama-bukuro (envelopes for money)
culture.desc: Otoshidama-bukuro is an envelope in which you put money (mainly bills) when you give otoshidama (New Year's gift) on New Year's holidays.

culture.name: Fude (ink brush)
culture.desc: The term "fude" refers to a tool made out of a stem (thin stick such as bamboo tube) with a brush (a bundle of fiber) on the top, which is used for writing and painting.

culture.name: Fukujinzuke (pickle of seven kinds of vegetables)
culture.url: culture/Fukujinzuke (pickle of seven kinds of vegetables).html
culture.desc: Fukujinzuke (or fukusinnzuke depending on regions) (literally, pickles of the gods of good fortune).

culture.name: TSUTAYA Juzaburo
culture.desc: Juzaburo TSUTAYA (February 13, 1750 - May 31, 1797) is a "hanmoto" (publisher) in the Edo period.

culture.name: Teppanyaki
culture.desc: Teppanyaki food, which is an area of Japanese cuisine, and teppanyaki cooking are introduced here.

culture.name: Togashi
culture.desc: Togashi refers to a series of cakes and the technique used to make them that were introduced from Tang (China) in the Nara period.

culture.name: Fuji Matsuri (a festival of Japanese wisteria)
culture.url: culture/Fuji Matsuri (a festival of Japanese wisteria).html
culture.desc: Fuji Matsuri is a festival being held in various regions in Japan.

culture.name: Ebi furai (Fried prawn)
culture.desc: Ebi furai is a kind of deep fried cuisine using shrimp.

culture.name: Kyoto Prize in the Category of Arts and Philosophy
culture.jp: 京都賞思想・芸術部門
culture.url: culture/Kyoto Prize in the Category of Arts and Philosophy.html
culture.desc: The Kyoto Prize in the category of Arts and Philosophy is a prize awarded to an artist or philosopher for outstanding achievements in his or her respective field.

culture.name: Kyoto Prize in the Basic Sciences
culture.url: culture/Kyoto Prize in the Basic Sciences.html
culture.desc: The Kyoto Prize in the category of Basic Sciences is a prize awarded to an scientist for outstanding achievements in his or her respective field.

culture.name: Ninjo-banashi (Sentimental Story)
culture.desc: Ninjo-banashi is a category of rakugo program (traditional comic storytelling).

culture.name: Kikugoro ONOE, The Seventh
culture.desc: Kikugoro ONOE, the Seventh (October 2, 1942 -) is a Japanese actor and a kabuki actor, and the present head of the profesional name of kabuki, 'Kikugoro ONOE.'

culture.name: Kanjincho
culture.desc: "Kanjincho" is a kabuki program which is based on the Noh play "The Ataka Barrier."

culture.name: Kirishitan-ban (Jesuit Mission Press)
culture.desc: Kirishitan-ban (Christian editions) refers to a common name of printing in Roman characters, kanji (Chinese characters) or kana (the Japanese syllabary) which was published by the Society of Jesus mainly in Japan in the early modern period (from the end of the 16th century to the beginning of the 17th century).

culture.name: Arai (slices of fish washed in cold water)
culture.url: culture/Arai (slices of fish washed in cold water).html
culture.desc: "Arai" is a kind of "sashimi," fresh slices of raw fish.

culture.name: Yubeshi
culture.desc: Yubeshi (written as 柚餅子) is a processed food which is made using citron.

culture.name: Nabeyaki-udon
culture.desc: Nabeyaki-udon is a type of dish which is made by using udon (Japanese wheat noodles).

culture.name: Jakuemon NAKAMURA The Fourth
culture.desc: Jakuemon NAKAMURA the Fourth (August 20, 1920 -) is an actor and Kabuki actor.

culture.name: Juni-hitoe (twelve-layered ceremonial kimono)
culture.desc: Juni-hitoe is a formal attire of a Japanese noblewomen who emerged around the tenth century in the Heian period.

culture.name: Hakama (pleated and divided skirt made in fine strips)
culture.url: culture/Hakama (pleated and divided skirt made in fine strips).html
culture.desc: Hakama is a kind of wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes) that is put on to cover the lower part of a person's body below the waist.

culture.name: Kenpo or yawara
culture.desc: Presently, kenpo and yawara mean martial arts with bare hands using striking and kicking techniques..

culture.name: Hayashi rice
culture.desc: Hayashi rice is a dish featuring a sauce served atop white rice, the sauce of which is cooked by stir-frying thin pieces of beef and chopped onion with butter and stewing it with red wine and demi-glace sauce.

culture.name: Katsuo no Tataki (lightly-roasted bonito)
culture.desc: Katsuo no tataki is one of the fish dishes made with katsuo (bonito or skipjack tuna).

culture.name: Kesa
culture.desc: Kesa is a cloth robe worn by a Buddhist priest

culture.name: Yukata (a kind of traditional Japanese clothing)
culture.url: culture/Yukata (a kind of traditional Japanese clothing).html
culture.desc: Yukata is a kind of wafuku (traditional Japanese clothing).

culture.name: Habutae (a kind of woven silk fabric)
culture.url: culture/Habutae (a kind of woven silk fabric).html
culture.desc: "Habutae" (habutae silk in English) is a kind of plain woven cloth with warp and weft yarns alternately interwoven.

culture.name: Chirimen (a kind of plain woven fabrics)
culture.url: culture/Chirimen (a kind of plain woven fabrics).html
culture.desc: "Chirimen" (crepe in French) is a kind of plain woven silk cloth.

culture.name: Tai Meshi (Sea Bream and Rice)
culture.desc: Tai Meshi is one of the local dishes in which sea bream is used.

culture.name: Ankoromochi
culture.desc: Ankoromochi is a type of Japanese confectionery.

culture.name: Ogiri (Professional rakugo storytellers play on words.)
culture.url: culture/Ogiri (Professional rakugo storytellers play on words.).html
culture.desc: Ogiri (pronounced as ogiri or okiri)

culture.name: Furikake
culture.desc: Furikake consists of powdered, particulate or soboro-like (crumbled and seasoned meat, fish, egg) condiments sprinkled mainly on rice for seasoning.

culture.name: Chawan
culture.desc: Chawan originally referred to a porcelain bowl made for drinking tea.

culture.name: Kama
culture.desc: Kama is an equipment used to heat food materials.

culture.name: Tenshin-han
culture.desc: Tenshin-han is a Chinese-style dish originating in Japan.

culture.name: Kotenmyo Hiragumo
culture.desc: It is a kettle used for tea ceremonies and is owned by a ringleader in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), Hisahide MATSUNAGA.

culture.name: Kyoto SF Festival
culture.desc: "Kyoto SF Festival" is a SF Convention held in Kyoto every autumn since 1982.

culture.name: Sakura Meshi
culture.desc: Sakura meshi is a takikomi gohan (Japanese rice dish seasoned with dashi and soy sauce) without any other ingredients.

culture.name: Montsuki Haori Hakama (Japanese formal attire for men)
culture.url: culture/Montsuki Haori Hakama (Japanese formal attire for men).html
culture.desc: "Montsuki Haori Hakama" is a Japanese traditional costume that is commonly regarded as the most formal attire for men at present.

culture.name: Busu
culture.desc: Busu is a generic name for 'poison and Chinese herbal medicine' of torikabuto (aconite) and also a nick name of torikabuto.

culture.name: Jinko (agarwood)
culture.desc: Jinko (agarwood), formally known as Jinsui Koboku (sinking fragrant wood), is one of the most popular types of koboku (fragrant wood).

culture.name: Haigo (a pen name of a haiku poet)
culture.url: culture/Haigo (a pen name of a haiku poet).html
culture.desc: Haigo or Haimei (or Haimyo) is the pen name used in making Haikai or later Haiku.

culture.name: Engeki Kairyo Undo (Theatrical Performance Improvement Movement)
culture.url: culture/Engeki Kairyo Undo (Theatrical Performance Improvement Movement).html
culture.desc: Engeki Kairyo Undo (Theatrical Performance Improvement Movement) was a campaign launched during the Meiji period, that advocated reforming Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) so it could meet standards of modern society.

culture.name: Maizuru-ben (Maizuru dialect)
culture.desc: "Maizuru-ben" is a Japanese dialect descended from Kinki dialect and extended over the area from Maizuru City of Kyoto Prefecture along Wakasa Bay to a part of the Reinan region of Fukui Prefecture (Takahama-cho).

culture.name: Fundoshi (traditional Japanese underwear)
culture.desc: "Fundoshi" is a traditional underwear for men in Japan and other areas.

culture.name: Rokushaku Fundoshi
culture.desc: Rokushaku fundoshi is Japanese male underwear composed of sarashi (bleached cloth) which is approximately 180-300 cm long and 16-34 cm wide.

culture.name: Sushi
culture.desc: Food called sushi (described as 寿司, 鮨, 鮓, 寿斗, 寿し or 壽司 in Japanese) is Japanese cuisine combining vinegared rice mainly with seafood.

culture.name: Ko-no-Zu (lines used as a pattern of artistic work in Kodo)
culture.url: culture/Ko-no-Zu (lines used as a pattern of artistic work in Kodo).html
culture.desc: Ko-no-Zu is a kind of Kumiko or a design consisting of longitudinal and horizontal lines used as a pattern of artistic work in Kodo.

culture.name: Baiko ONOE (The Seventh)
culture.desc: Baiko ONOE the Seventh (August 31, 1915 to March 24, 1995) was a kabuki actor.

culture.name: Issen Yoshoku (literally, one cent Western food)
culture.url: culture/Issen Yoshoku (literally, one cent Western food).html
culture.desc: Issen Yoshoku consists of a wheat flour mixed with water, baked on a cast-iron pan, with green onion added onto it.

culture.name: The Kyoto Prize in the Category of Advanced Technology
culture.url: culture/The Kyoto Prize in the Category of Advanced Technology.html
culture.desc: The Kyoto Prize in the category of Advanced Technology is one of the categories of the Kyoto Prize, and is given to a scientist who achieved great results.

culture.name: Soba (buckwheat noodles)
culture.desc: Soba is a type of Japanese noodles made from buckwheat berries and cuisine using those noodles.

culture.name: Takemoto
culture.desc: Takemoto is the surname of Gidayu TAKEMOTO (stage name), the founder of Gidayu-bushi (musical narrative of the puppet theatre).

culture.name: Yose (a place where rakugo stories are mostly told for audiences)
culture.url: culture/Yose (a place where rakugo stories are mostly told for audiences).html
culture.desc: A yose originally referred to a permanent hut operated by a promoter where professionals of rakugo (traditional comic storytelling), rokyoku (naniwabushi recitation), kodan storytelling, manzai or a comic dialogue, or magicians entertained their audiences by exhibiting their skills in speaking or trickery.

culture.name: Chasen (a bamboo tea whisk)
culture.desc: Chasen is one of the tea utensils used for preparing powdered green tea in the Japanese tea ceremony.

culture.name: Chashaku (bamboo tea spoon for making Japanese tea)
culture.url: culture/Chashaku (bamboo tea spoon for making Japanese tea).html
culture.desc: Chashaku (tea scoop) is one of the tea ceremony utensils used for brewing tea (particularly, maccha, or green powdered tea).

culture.name: Ryugi
culture.desc: Ryugi (style)

culture.name: The First Three Days of the New Year
culture.url: culture/The First Three Days of the New Year.html
culture.desc: The first three days of the New Year refer to January 1, or New Year's Day, and January 2 and 3 of every year.

culture.name: Noh Actor
culture.desc: Those who perform Noh plays as a profession are called the Noh actors or Noh performers.

culture.name: Kizushi (salted blue-skinned fish)
culture.desc: Kizushi refers to the salted blue-skinned fish.

culture.name: Shinobue (Japanese Bamboo Flute)
culture.desc: The shinobue is one of the Japanese woodwind instruments.

culture.name: Utaemon NAKAMURA (the sixth)
culture.desc: Utaemon NAKAMURA, the sixth (January 20, 1917 - March 31, 2001) was a kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) actor representative of the postwar period.

culture.name: Kata (a form) training
culture.desc: Kata training is a training to improve Kata in Geido (Accomplishments of art), Budo (Martial art) and Bujutsu (Martial art) etc.

culture.name: Chicken Nanban (fried chicken in Japanese sweet and peppery vegetable sauce)
culture.url: culture/Chicken Nanban (fried chicken in Japanese sweet and peppery vegetable sauce).html
culture.desc: Chicken nanban is a local cuisine originally created in Nobeoka City, Miyazaki Prefecture.

culture.name: Kinden School
culture.desc: Kinden school is the largest school of taishogoto (Taisho lyre) in Japan which have more than four hundred thousand members and more than ten thousand teachers throughout Japan.

culture.name: Sazae no Tsuboyaki (Turbo cooked in its own shell)
culture.url: culture/Sazae no Tsuboyaki (Turbo cooked in its own shell).html
culture.desc: Sazae no Tsuboyaki (Turbo cooked in its own shell) is a way of cooking a snail, sazae (turbo).

culture.name: Natsume (a container for powdered tea) (Chaki [tea utensil])
culture.url: culture/Natsume (a container for powdered tea) (Chaki [tea utensil]).html
culture.desc: Natsume is a kind of tea utensil and a lacquered wooden container with a lid used to hold powdered green tea.

culture.name: Ohitashi (boiled greens)
culture.desc: Ohitashi (also called hitashi or hitashimono) is a kind of cookery.

culture.name: Makiwara (straw butt)
culture.desc: Makiwara

culture.name: Karashi-mentaiko (spicy salted cod roe)
culture.desc: Karashi-mentaiko (spicy salted cod roe) is foodstuff made from the ovaries of a kind of cod, Walleye pollack, processed by seasoning it with red pepper sauce.

culture.name: Shinja (a kind of Noh mask)
culture.desc: Shinja is a kind of Nohmen (Noh mask).

culture.name: Roji (the garden outside a ceremonial tea room)
culture.url: culture/Roji (the garden outside a ceremonial tea room).html
culture.desc: Roji is also called Chatei and is the common name of a garden attached to a tea-ceremony room.

culture.name: Ancient Chinese Chromatic Scale (primarily used in Japan for gagaku, etc.)
culture.url: culture/Ancient Chinese Chromatic Scale (primarily used in Japan for gagaku, etc.).html
culture.desc: Ancient Chinese chromatic scale is the twelve kinds of average pitch that are used in Chinese or Japanese traditional music.

culture.name: Roppo (acting motion)
culture.desc: Roppo is an acting motion in Kabuki, Ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater), and Buyo dance (classical Japanese dance).

culture.name: Mokugyo (a fish-shaped wooden drum)
culture.desc: Mokugyo (木魚; a fish-shaped wooden drum) (also written in 杢魚) is a kind of butsugu (Buddhist altar fittings).

culture.name: Sakai-Senke
culture.desc: Sakai-Senke is the head family of the House of Sen.

culture.name: Jodaiyo (Japanese calligraphy styles of the ancient era)
culture.url: culture/Jodaiyo (Japanese calligraphy styles of the ancient era).html
culture.desc: Jodaiyo is a general term for the "Japanese calligraphy school Japanese style" and "kana calligraphy," such as the three great brush traces and ancient calligraphy in the Heian period.

culture.name: Kamikoromo
culture.desc: Kamikoromo (Kamikinu) is a Kimono made of Japanese paper.

culture.name: Kakejiku (Japanese hanging scroll)
culture.desc: Kakejiku is a Japanese hanging scroll made of paper or cloth on which a Japanese painting or calligraphy is mounted; it is displayed and appreciated in the tokonoma alcove and so on.

culture.name: Itsumade (monster)
culture.desc: Itsumade, or Itsumaden is one of the monsters that have been handed down in Japan.

culture.name: Tenkasu (bits of deep-fried dough)
culture.desc: Tenkasu (天かす, also written as てんかす, 天カス, 天滓) are small pieces of deep-fried dough produced during cooking tenpura.

culture.name: Kasuri (cloth with splashed patterns)
culture.desc: Kasuri refers to weaved patterns, some of which look as if they were 'scratched,' or refers to a fabric that has such patterns.

culture.name: Tsuzumi (hand drum)
culture.desc: Tsuzumi (hand drum) is a traditional instrument unique to Japan, and refers to Kotsuzumi (small hand drum) in a narrow sense.

culture.name: Haboku-sansui
culture.desc: Haboku-sansui refers to Sansui-ga (Chinese-style landscape painting) which is painted using haboku (the broken-ink technique) technique (to be described later).

culture.name: nagikama (sickle-weapon)
culture.desc: Nagikama is a weapon which has an approximately 210 cm-long columnar wooden stick as a handle, to the upper part of which a short straight sword with its edge facing toward is orthogonally attached.

culture.name: Kyo-Yuzen (dyeing technique)
culture.desc: Kyo-Yuzen (dyeing technique) is one of the traditional arts of Kyoto, and refers to dyeing technique that was designed by Yuzensai MIYAZAKI, who was a painter of folding fan, in the Genroku era.

culture.name: KANZE Tetsunojo
culture.desc: Tetsunojo KANZE is the name used mostly after the Meiji period, by the head of a branch family of the Kanze family, the head family of Kanze school of Nohgaku.

culture.name: UMEWAKA Minoru
culture.desc: Minoru UMEWAKA is the name used as an "inkyomei" (name after retirement) in the UMEWAKA family, shite-kata (main roles) of Kanze school of Noh.

culture.name: setsugo (pseudonym using the character, 雪)
culture.desc: Setsugo is a pseudonym after the retirement, using a Chinese character, '雪,' in shite-kata (main roles) of Kanze school of Noh.

culture.name: KATAYAMA Kuroemon
culture.desc: Kuroemon KATAYAMA is the name of the family head of the Kyoto Katayama family, of shite-kata (main roles) of Kanze school of Noh.

culture.name: Kanze-ryu (Kanze School)
culture.desc: Kanze-ryu is one of the schools in Nohgaku theater

culture.name: Juban (undershirt for kimono)
culture.desc: Juban; undershirt for kimono (it is also called juhan, jiban), is one of the undershirts for wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

culture.name: Aburakasu (food)
culture.desc: "Aburakasu" is residue obtained by removing fats from meat and is called by various names depending on the kind of raw material or the region.

culture.name: Kuden (oral instruction)
culture.desc: "Kuden" is a method of orally transmitting information.

culture.name: UMEWAKA Manzaburo
culture.desc: "Manzaburo UMEWAKA" is the name of the head of Umewaka family, a branch family of Kanze-ryu school of Noh shite-kata (main roles).

culture.name: Manzaburo UMEWAKA (the third)
culture.desc: Manzaburo UMEWAKA the third (1941-) is a Noh actor, of shite-kata (main roles) of Kanze school.

culture.name: Fuku no kami (The God of Good Fortune)
culture.url: culture/Fuku no kami (The God of Good Fortune).html
culture.desc: "Fuku no kami" is a program of Kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle).

culture.name: monpe (women's work pants)
culture.desc: Monpe is a pair of work pants for women and a sort of "hakama" (a formal divided skirt for men) in Japan.

culture.name: Konoha-don (egg rice bowl with kamaboko)
culture.desc: Konoha-don, also referred to as Konoha-donburi, is a kind of donburimono (rice dish) which is commonly served in Osaka and Kyoto area.

culture.name: Nanboroku
culture.desc: Nanboroku (also pronounced "Nanporoku") is an old book which has been handed down in the Tachibana clan in Hakata (a part of Fukuoka City, Fukuoka Prefecture), as a book of SEN no Rikyu's secret teachings.

culture.name: Meibutsu (in this case, good tea utensils)
culture.url: culture/Meibutsu (in this case, good tea utensils).html
culture.desc: Meibutsu can be regarded as a rating of tea utensils.

culture.name: Korai mono (Korean pieces)
culture.desc: Korai mono is the collective name of tea utensils made in Korean Peninsula in contrast to 'karamono,' Chinese tea utensils.

culture.name: chaire
culture.desc: Chaire, in its broadest sense, means chaki (tea utensils) in general into which powdered green tea is poured, and in a more limited sense means ceramic tea utensils, in contrast with wooden tea utensils (see "usuchaki" (tea utensils for a light tea)) as typified by natsume (a container for powdered tea).

culture.name: nohkan (noh flute)
culture.desc: Nohkan is a sort of the Japanese transverse flutes.

culture.name: YAMANOUE no Soji ki (The Record of Soji YAMANOUE)
culture.url: culture/YAMANOUE no Soji ki (The Record of Soji YAMANOUE).html
culture.desc: YAMANOUE no Soji ki is a book of secrets written in 1588 by Soji YAMANOUE, who was a highly regarded disciple of SEN no Rikyu.

culture.name: Usuchaki (tea caddy for tea powder for thin tea)
culture.url: culture/Usuchaki (tea caddy for tea powder for thin tea).html
culture.desc: Usuchaki is a kind of chaki (tea utensil), used to hold powdered tea, and the term is used in contrast to koichaki, which refers to a ceramic chaire specially used to contain the powdered tea for thick tea.

culture.name: Chaki (tea utensils)
culture.desc: Chaki is a general term for containers used in Chanoyu (the tea ceremony) to hold green powdered tea.

culture.name: Chatsubo (tea urn)
culture.desc: Chatsubo is an earthenware jar (tea leaf jar), that is used to store the tencha (leaf tea), non-powdered green tea before mortared by stone mill.

culture.name: Shimamono (imported tea caddy)
culture.desc: Shimamono is a type of classification of tea utensils.

culture.name: SAKATA Tojuro (IV)
culture.desc: Yodai-me (IV) Tojuro SAKATA (male, December 31, 1931 -) is a Japanese actor and kabuki actor.

culture.name: Gekkin
culture.desc: Gekkin (Chinese name: yueh-chin, yueqin; English name: moon guitar, moon-zither; and Vietnamese name: {-D}{a`}n nguy{e^.}t) is a traditional musical instrument in China, Japan and Vietnam.

culture.name: surigane (small gong)
culture.desc: Surigane is one of the metal percussion instruments.

culture.name: Sokutai
culture.desc: Sokutai is a formal costume for those from the Emperor to the court nobles in and after Heian period (Heian costume).

culture.name: Sukisha (familiar name for a person infatuated with geido)
culture.url: culture/Sukisha (familiar name for a person infatuated with geido).html
culture.desc: Sukisha (also referred to as Sukimono) is a familiar name for a person infatuated with geido (accomplishments of art).

culture.name: KATAOKA Nizaemon (XIII)
culture.desc: Jusandai-me (the thirteenth) Nizaemon KATAOKA (male, December 15, 1903 to March 26, 1994) was a kabuki actor.

culture.name: Hiraki (first performance for a Noh actor, acting an important role)
culture.url: culture/Hiraki (first performance for a Noh actor, acting an important role).html
culture.desc: Hiraki is what a Nohgakushi (Noh actor) performs for the first time as a shite (a main actor of a Noh play) or a quasi shite role for a certain music, Kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle), or hayashi (musical accompaniment played on traditional Japanese instruments).

culture.name: Rajomon no oni (an ogre at the Rajo-mon Gate)
culture.url: culture/Rajomon no oni (an ogre at the Rajo-mon Gate).html
culture.desc: "Rajomon no oni" or "Rashomon no oni" is an ogre who was said to have lived at Rajo-mon Gate, the main gate of Heiankyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto).

culture.name: NOMURA Manzo
culture.desc: Manzo (kanji character is 万蔵) NOMURA is a stage name that has been handed down for generations of Kyogen (farce played during a No play cycle) actors of the Izumi school.

culture.name: Tomesode
culture.desc: Tomesode is a type of Japanese traditional clothes and is a formal dress of the highest rank worn by married women.

culture.name: Iromuji
culture.desc: Iromuji is a type of traditional clothes in Japan which is a plain kimono of color other than black with no patterns woven in.

culture.name: Obiage
culture.desc: Obiage is a type of small tool used when wearing kimono, and it wraps around obimakura (a small oval cushion to keep the obi (kimono sash) knot in place).

culture.name: Obijime
culture.desc: The obijime is one of the essential items when one wears kimono; it's a string used to hold a kimono sash in place.

culture.name: Furisode
culture.desc: Furisode is a type of Japanese kimono worn by girls in their minority.

culture.name: Kurama Tengu
culture.desc: Kurama Tengu

culture.name: Sojuro-zukin
culture.desc: "Sojuro-zukin" is a kind of hood for men.

culture.name: Montsuki (Japanese Traditional Clothing That Carries Family Crests)
culture.url: culture/Montsuki (Japanese Traditional Clothing That Carries Family Crests).html
culture.desc: "Montsuki" refers to "kimono" (Japanese traditional clothing) that bears family crests.

culture.name: The Yarai Kanze family
culture.desc: The Yarai Kanze family is one of the occupational branch families of Kanze school of Nohgaku theatre shite-kata (main roles).

culture.name: Tozaigoe (the word tozai)
culture.desc: Tozaigoe refers to shouts of 'tozai, tozai' (east west) from the backstage at the jobiraki (an opening) or before kojo (a ceremony to announce that an actor takes a new stage name) of kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) or ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater).

culture.name: Otsuzumikata
culture.desc: Otsuzumikata refers to a special duty that is to take charge of an otsuzumi (big drum) in Nogaku-hayashi (Japanese orchestra for Noh performance) or kabuki musical accompaniment.

culture.name: Sarashi
culture.desc: Sarashi is white, long cloth (34cm in width, 2 to 10m in length), and it is usually used by wrapping around the stomach.

culture.name: Shike (teaching master)
culture.desc: Shike ([Zen] teaching master)

culture.name: Kyoto Symphony Orchestra
culture.desc: Kyoto Symphony Orchestra is a professional orchestra headquartered in Kyoto City.

culture.name: Suteteko
culture.desc: Suteteko is underpants with the long length under the knee, and it is usually worn by men.

culture.name: Hiyashiame (cold candy drink)
culture.desc: "Cold candy" drink or ameyu ("candy"drink) is one of Japan's traditional sweet drinks made from malt syrup dissolved in hot water with ginger juice or grated ginger added as a seasoning or flavoring agent.

culture.name: ioriten
culture.desc: Ioriten "&amp12349" is one of yakumono (punctuation marks and other special symbols [term used in printing]) put at the beginning of a song in Japanese.

culture.name: Hitoe
culture.desc: Hitote

culture.name: Uchiginu
culture.desc: Uchiginu is one kimono of many kimonos forming juni-hitoe (twelve-layered ceremonial kimono).

culture.name: Omoteginu
culture.desc: Omoteginu is one of many kimonos forming juni-hitoe (twelve-layered ceremonial kimono).

culture.name: Uchiki
culture.desc: Uchiki (also known as "uchigi") is a kind of kimono that is worn by women as part of Heian-period costumes, such as the twelve-layered ceremonial kimono and five-layer robe, although it may also be worn by itself.

culture.name: Homongi
culture.desc: Homongi is kimono for Japanese females.

culture.name: Tsukesage
culture.desc: Tsukesage, which is written as '付け下げ' or '付下げ' (pronunciation is the same), is kimono for Japanese women.

culture.name: Komon
culture.desc: Komon is a kind of Japanese kimono (Japanese clothes).

culture.name: Tsutsusode
culture.desc: As the name suggests, tsutsusode (sleeve like tube) is a sleeve in the shape of tube, however all the European clothes have sleeve in the shape of narrow tube, so tsutsusode usually refers to such sleeves of Japenese kimono.

culture.name: Datemaki
culture.desc: Datemaki is a kind of egg dish.

culture.name: Yosozake (sake brewed outside of the Kyoto area)
culture.url: culture/Yosozake (sake brewed outside of the Kyoto area).html
culture.desc: People living in Kyoto called sake (rice wine) brewed outside of the Kyoto area and brought to Kyoto as yosozake over the Muromachi period and the Edo period.

culture.name: Uchikake
culture.desc: Uchikake (打掛) is a kind of kimono (or wafuku, either of them means Japanese traditional clothing) worn by Japanese women.

culture.name: Koshimaki
culture.desc: Koshimaki (腰巻)

culture.name: Soboshu
culture.desc: Soboshu is a collective term referring to Japanese sake brewed in major temples from the Heian period to Edo period.

culture.name: Nohgakushorin
culture.desc: Nohgakushorin Co., Ltd. is a publishing company in Chiyoda Ward, Tokyo which mostly produces books on nogaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Kitcho
culture.desc: Kitcho is a high-class Japanese-style restaurant serving Japanese cuisine based in Osaka City.

culture.name: Hari-ogi
culture.desc: Hari-ogi, also called Hari-sen, refers to a special fan that is made for the purpose of making noise by slapping something during Nohgaku theatre, kodan storytelling and rakugo (traditional comic storytelling) (Kamigata rakugo (traditional Japanese comic storytelling as performed in the Kyoto-Osaka region)).

culture.name: Tsukeshugen (a short celebratory noh play)
culture.desc: Tsukeshugen (付祝言, also written as 附祝言) is one of the performance styles of noh (traditional masked dance-drama).

culture.name: Kinagashi
culture.desc: Kinagashi (dressing kimono casually) is a style in which a man doesn't put on hakama (pleated and divided skirt made in fine stripes) when he wears wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

culture.name: Shimai
culture.desc: Shimai refers to a part of the Noh play where a performer dances without wearing masks or costumes.

culture.name: Kappogi
culture.desc: Kappogi is a kind of apron originated in Japan and mainly worn over wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

culture.name: Senshuraku (the last day of a performance)
culture.url: culture/Senshuraku (the last day of a performance).html
culture.desc: 千秋楽 (senshuraku) is also written as 千穐楽 or 千龝楽, and, being an industrial term, indicates the last day, when plays on the same program are performed repeatedly every day for two or more days.

culture.name: Han-Noh
culture.desc: "Han-Noh" is a style of "Nohgaku" that a play is performed with largely shortened "Maeba" (the first half of the drama), focusing on "Nochiba", (the second half of the drama) for "Tsukeshugen" (a short celebratory Noh play).

culture.name: Kamaburo
culture.desc: Kamaburo is a kind of Japanese traditional sauna baths existing around Yase, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Mai-goto (concerns Noh dance)
culture.desc: Mai-goto means abstract acts (mai) that, in Noh, the shite (an actor playing the leading part), tsure (a supporting actor) and waki (the partner of a shite) perform accompanied solely by the hayashi (music played in the background), mostly in the latter half of a Noh or a Kyogen (a farce played during a Noh cycle) play.

culture.name: Shiki Sanban (The three rituals)
culture.desc: "Shiki Sanban" is one of the performing arts that form part of Nohgaku (the theatrical art of Noh), along with Noh (Noh plays) and Kyogen (a farce presented between Noh plays).

culture.name: Izumi school
culture.desc: The Izumi school is one of the schools of Kyogen (farce played during a Noh cycle).

culture.name: Mingaku (Ming-era Chinese music, popularized in Japan during the early 17th century)
culture.url: culture/Mingaku (Ming-era Chinese music, popularized in Japan during the early 17th century).html
culture.desc: A lecture and concert held by the Sakata Classic Music Institution (located in Tokyo).

culture.name: Shingaku (Qing-era Chinese music)
culture.desc: "Shingaku" is a group of music that is centered on "minyo" (traditional folk songs) and "zokkyoku" (folk songs), introduced from Qing.

culture.name: Anagomeshi
culture.desc: Anagomeshi (conger rice) is a local dish from the Setouchi area in Hiroshima Prefecture.

culture.name: RAKU Kichizaemon
culture.desc: Kichizaemon RAKU is a name inherited from generation to generation by the leader of the Raku family of chawanshi (tea bowl maker) who makes Raku-yaki ware, which is one of the Senke jissoku (Senke's ten designated craftsmen families).

culture.name: Utakai Hajime
culture.desc: Utakai Hajime is a poetry reading which is held at the beginning of the New Year.

culture.name: Chagama
culture.desc: Chagama is a type of tea utensils used in Sado, which is used to boil water for tea.

culture.name: A list of cultural properties designated and registered by Kyoto Prefecture
culture.jp: 京都府指定・登録文化財一覧
culture.url: culture/A list of cultural properties designated and registered by Kyoto Prefecture.html
culture.desc: A list of cultural properties designated and registered by Kyoto Prefecture lists the cultural properties and historical sites and the like, designated or registered by Kyoto Prefecture in a view format, but not all the data are recorded.

culture.name: Kogetsu Enshu School
culture.desc: Kogetsu Enshu School, also referred to as Kogetsu Enshu's Zen School of Tea ceremony is one of various tea ceremony schools in Japan, and it branched off from Enshu School.

culture.name: Agon Shu's Hoshi Matsuri
culture.desc: Agon Shu's Hoshi Matsuri is a religious event organized by the Agon sect on February 11 of every year as the "Fire Rites Festival/Agon Shu's Hoshi Matsuri" in the precincts of Honzan (main temple) of Agon sect in Omine-cho, Kita-kazan, Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Hataraki-goto (descriptive pieces)
culture.desc: Hataraki-goto refers to shosa (conduct) that has certain ideographical and representational elements in the parts that consist of performers' shosa and Noh-hayashi (percussion ensemble) in Noh plays.

culture.name: Wanyudo
culture.desc: Wanyudo is a Japanese specter described in Konjaku Gazu Zoku Hyakki (Continued Illustrations of the Many Demons Past and Present), a collection of illustrations of specters by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Tsuchigumo
culture.desc: Tsuchigumo is not a name of an actual living spider.

culture.name: Tsukumogami
culture.desc: Tsukumogami, the notion of Japanese folk beliefs, is a collective name of old or long-used yorishiro (objects representative of divine spirits) (tools, living things and natural things) in which deities (Shinto religion) or divine spirits reside.

culture.name: Kakoishio
culture.desc: Kakoishio is specially purified traditional salt for preservation, and also called furuzumijio (traditional Japanese purified salt for preservation).

culture.name: Tsunokakushi
culture.desc: Tsunokakushi is a wide strip of cloth worn by a bride at a Japanese-style wedding ceremony, covering her head including the coiffure called Bunkintakashimada.

culture.name: Haneri (neckpiece on a kimono)
culture.desc: The "haneri" is a detachable neckpieces for kimonos that is sewed on a juban, underwear for wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

culture.name: Heihoka/Hyohoka (tactician)
culture.desc: 兵法家 (reads heihoka/hyohoka) refers to the following.

culture.name: Hanhaba obi (a half-width sash)
culture.desc: The hanhaba obi is a kind women's obi sash used in Japan.

culture.name: Engawa
culture.desc: "Engawa" is a part of fish meat and one of the toppings of sashimi or sushi.

culture.name: Nogoya obi
culture.desc: The Nagoya obi is a kind of Japanese woman's obi (sash).

culture.name: Maruobi
culture.desc: "Maruobi" is a kind of women's obi (sash) used in Japan.

culture.name: Fukuro obi
culture.desc: The fukuro obi is a kind of obi (sash) that is used in Japan.

culture.name: Heko obi
