culture.desc: The heko obi is a kind of men's obi (sash) used in wearing wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

culture.name: Fukujuen
culture.desc: Fukujuen CO., LTD is a tea company located in Yamashiro-cho, Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Obi ita (cardboard belt to stiffen the obi sash)
culture.url: culture/Obi ita (cardboard belt to stiffen the obi sash).html
culture.desc: An obi ita is an accessory used to set the shape of obi (sash).

culture.name: Fugu Cuisine
culture.desc: Fugu cuisine' is the collective name for a variety of dishes that use pufferfish.

culture.name: Awase
culture.desc: The term "awase" means wafuku (traditional Japanese clothes) with a lining.

culture.name: Yosenabe (a pot of chowder)
culture.desc: Yosenabe is a one-pot dish.

culture.name: Bunko-musubi knot
culture.desc: Bunko-musubi knot is a kind of obi-musubi (style of tying obi [sash]) for furisode (kimono with long, trailing sleeves).

culture.name: Oni no ho
culture.desc: "Oni no ho" is a ho (round-necked robe worn by members of nobility and the imperial court) of sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress) costume, worn by a crown prince in the rituals.

culture.name: Futaeorimono (double technique brocade)
culture.desc: "Futaeorimono" (or "Futabeorimono") is a fabric on which two kinds of patterns are arranged; the one is called 'jimon' (textile pattern), running patterns such as kikko (hexagonal pattern) and karakusa (arabesque) that spread over a fabric, and the other called 'uwamon,' patterns of marumon (round pattern) and kachomon (pattern of flowers and birds) which are woven with colored threads different from those of jimon and arranged at random.

culture.name: Fuguruma-yobi
culture.desc: "Fuguruma-yobi" is a Japanese specter which appears in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro"(The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons), a collection of paintings of specters drawn by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Bo-no-te (stick-in-hand performances)
culture.desc: Bo-no-te is a traditional performing arts of classical Japanese dance, in which basic forms of Japanese martial arts such as sword, staff, and halberd techniques are transformed into dancing.

culture.name: Karyobin
culture.desc: Karyobin is a piece of Gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music), and one of 'Rinyu hachigaku' (eight old gagaku pieces from Vietnam).

culture.name: Fugaku sanjurokkei (Thirty-six Views of Mt. Fuji)
culture.url: culture/Fugaku sanjurokkei (Thirty-six Views of Mt. Fuji).html
culture.desc: Thirty-six Views of Mt. Fuji is a notable example of a landscape painting or Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints) created by Hokusai KATSUSHIKA.

culture.name: Onna-gidayu (female gidayu reciter)
culture.desc: An onna-gidayu is a female reciter of Gidayu-bushi (musical narrative of the puppet theatre).

culture.name: Chasen-mage
culture.desc: Chasen-mage is a hairstyle which looks like a tea whisk.

culture.name: ONOE Shoroku
culture.desc: Shoroku ONOE (II) (March 28, 1913 - June 25, 1989) was a Kabuki actor in the Showa period.

culture.name: Jukai ICHIKAWA (Sandaime (third))
culture.desc: December 1951, Osaka Kabukiza kaomisekogyo (the season's first performance with the new company) "Shosho Shigemoto no haha" (Mother of shosho Shigemoto)

culture.name: Ganjiro NAKAMURA (the Second)
culture.desc: Ganjiro NAKAMURA, the second (February 17, 1902 - April 13, 1983) was a kabuki actor who is representative of the Showa period.

culture.name: Yakizakana (broiled fish)
culture.desc: Yakizakana is a dish in which fish is broiled.

culture.name: Wasai (Japanese clothing manufacture)
culture.desc: Wasai is the making of wafuku (Japanese traditional clothing) or the technique that is employed.

culture.name: Kainokuchi knot (Japanese traditional clothes)
culture.desc: Kainokuchi knot means a kind of the methods of tying an obi (sash).

culture.name: Hifu
culture.desc: Hifu means a kind of jackets that is put on over kimono.

culture.name: The Mifa shanshui style
culture.desc: the Mifa shanshui is a style of Sansui-ga (Chinese-style landscape painting) with ink that Futsu BEI and his son Mi Youren, literati painters during Sung dynasty in China, are reported to have started

culture.name: Tanzen
culture.desc: Tanzen is a thickly padded winter garment of Japanese style.

culture.name: Konbushime (raw fish sandwiched between kelp)
culture.desc: Konbushime is a local dish in Toyama Prefecture.

culture.name: Kaki furai (fried oyster)
culture.desc: Kaki furai is a type of fried food.

culture.name: Kettekino ho, open sleeve seams outer robe
culture.url: culture/Kettekino ho, open sleeve seams outer robe.html
culture.desc: The kettekino ho is a garment of chofuku (cloths which the people who came to work at the court on a regular basis wore in the Heian period) in Japan.

culture.name: Umajirushi (commander's battle standard)
culture.desc: This term is written as 馬印, 馬標, or 馬験 in Japanese.

culture.name: Sightseeing Volunteer Guide
culture.jp: 観光ボランティアガイド
culture.desc: A sightseeing volunteer guide is an individual who voluntarily assists and guides tourists for free or a nominal fee on a continual basis.

culture.name: Kouchigi
culture.desc: Kouchigi is one of Japanese clothing.

culture.name: Kichiya musubi
culture.desc: Kichiya musubi was a way of tying an obi for kimono that was in style during the Genroku era in Edo Period.

culture.name: Aonyobo (young woman who serves a high-ranked person)
culture.url: culture/Aonyobo (young woman who serves a high-ranked person).html
culture.desc: The term "aonyobo" refers to a middle or low-ranked young noblewoman who serves a high ranked person.

culture.name: Kikuzake (Japanese sake with chrysanthemum blooms)
culture.desc: The term "kikuzake" refers to sake in which chrysanthemum blooms are steeped, which is provided on the Chrysanthemum Festival (September 9 according to the old calendar), which is called 'Choyo no sekku' or 'Kiku no sekku' in Japanese.

culture.name: Tango dialect
culture.desc: Tango dialect is a kind of Japanese dialect that is spoken mainly in an area encompassing Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture and Kyotango City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Shittaku (wet rubbing)
culture.desc: The term "shittaku" refers to a rubbed copy made by placing wet paper on an object and then putting black ink on it.

culture.name: Kuromoji (literally, black letters)
culture.desc: Kuromoji:

culture.name: Kyoto Onuma soroe (the great military parade in Kyoto)
culture.url: culture/Kyoto Onuma soroe (the great military parade in Kyoto).html
culture.desc: Kyoto Onuma soroe was the great military parade in Kyoto which was staged by Nobunaga ODA on April 11, 1581.

culture.name: Kongo school
culture.desc: The Kongo school is one of the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters) schools of Noh in Nohgaku (the art of Noh), which is one of the Japanese traditional performance arts.

culture.name: Hosho school
culture.desc: The Hosho school is one of the Nohgaku (the art of Noh) schools.

culture.name: Kita school
culture.desc: The Kita school is one of the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters) schools of Noh in Nohgaku (the art of Noh), which is one of the Japanese traditional performance arts.

culture.name: The Konparu school
culture.desc: The Konparu school (in the original meaning of its Chinese characters, "golden spring") is one of the schools of Noh.

culture.name: Hisada school
culture.desc: The Hisada family are a "chake" (a family known as traditional masters of the tea ceremony).

culture.name: Horinouchi family
culture.desc: The Horinouchi family (Horinouchi-ke) were a hereditary tea family who served as tea masters under the Omotesenke for many generations.

culture.name: Shino School (Tea Ceremony and Traditional Incense-smelling Ceremony)
culture.url: culture/Shino School (Tea Ceremony and Traditional Incense-smelling Ceremony).html
culture.desc: The Shino school is one of the schools of Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony) and tea ceremony.

culture.name: Juko School (Tea Ceremony)
culture.desc: The Juko school is one of the schools of tea ceremony.

culture.name: Oribe School (Tea Ceremony)
culture.desc: The Oribe School is one of the schools of the tea ceremony.

culture.name: Nogaku Kyokai (The Nohgaku Performers' Association)
culture.desc: Nogaku Kyokai is an organization comprised of nogakushi (Noh actors) who belong to the schools that have directly inherited the methods of Yamato-yoza or Yamato-shiza (four sarugaku performance groups in the Yamato Province).

culture.desc: Ueda Soko School is one of the tea ceremony schools and also one of the buke sado (the tea ceremony of samurai family) which has been handed down in the Ueda family, the former chief retainer of the Asano family in the Hiroshima domain.

culture.name: Atsugesho
culture.desc: Atsugesho is a word in Japanese referring the use of heavy makeup and cosmetics in order to make one's face look obviously different from a face without makeup.

culture.name: Enshu School

culture.name: NAKAMURA Tomijuro V

culture.name: Higo-koryu Old School (a school of tea ceremony)

culture.desc: The Higo-koryu old school is one of the schools of tea ceremony passed on in the Kumamoto Domain.

culture.name: Sansai-ryu School (a school of tea ceremony)

culture.name: Oie-ryu School (a school of tea ceremony)

culture.desc: Oie-ryu school is a school of tea ceremony which had been traditionally practiced by Shigenobu group of Mikawa-Ando clan, which was a family of fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family).

culture.name: MATSUMOTO Hakuo I
culture.desc: Hakuo MATSUMOTO (July 7, 1910 - January 11, 1982) was a Japanese theater, film and kabuki actor.

culture.name: SAWAMURA Tanosuke VI
culture.desc: Tanosuke SAWAMURA VI (August 4, 1932 -) is a kabuki actor.

culture.name: Sowa-ryu School (a school of Tea Ceremony)
culture.url: culture/Sowa-ryu School (a school of Tea Ceremony).html
culture.desc: Sowa-ryu school is one of the schools of tea ceremony.

culture.name: Hanayorimo Hananogotoku

culture.name: Hannya no Men (The Mask of Hannya [female demon])

culture.desc: Hannya no Men, also known as Hannyamen or simply Hannya, is a mask of a female demon representing 'the face of a woman harboring jealousy and resentment' used in Noh theater.

culture.name: Chinshin-ryu School (a school of tea ceremony)

culture.name: Meisho Edo Hyakkei (100 Famous Views of Edo)
culture.url: culture/Meisho Edo Hyakkei (100 Famous Views of Edo).html
culture.desc: Meisho Edo Hyakkei is a series of ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints) created by Hiroshige UTAGAWA, an ukiyoe artist, from 1856 to 1858.

culture.name: Tsuma (garnish)
culture.desc: Tsuma is a garnish used for sashimi dish.

culture.name: Kiku no Kisewata (Chrysanthemum Covers, a custom of the Imperial Court in the Chrysanthemum Festival)
culture.url: culture/Kiku no Kisewata (Chrysanthemum Covers, a custom of the Imperial Court in the Chrysanthemum Festival.html
culture.desc: Kiku no Kisewata is a custom of the Imperial Court held in Chrysanthemum Festival.

culture.name: Kogo (incense container)
culture.desc: Kogo refers to a lidded small container to put incense in.

culture.name: Kidomaru
culture.desc: Kidomaru is an oni (or ogre, a creature from Japanese folklore) that appears in Kamakura period texts such as the collection of stories entitled "Kokon Chomonshu" (A collection of Tales Heard, Past and Present).

culture.name: Koka-Isshin School (a school handed down within the Hanamoto family)

culture.name: Sanjaku Obi (a short kimono waistband)
culture.desc: Sanjaku Obi is a kind of kimono waistband for men.

culture.name: Tobiroppo (a performing technique of exiting the stage by leaping)
culture.url: culture/Tobiroppo (a performing technique of exiting the stage by leaping).html
culture.desc: Tobiroppo refers to a performing technique in Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) to raise the excitement by taking big sideways jumps when an actor exits the stage.

culture.name: Fumai-ryu School (a school of tea ceremony established by Fumai MATSUDAIRA)
culture.url: culture/Fumai-ryu School (a school of tea ceremony established by Fumai MATSUDAIRA).html
culture.desc: Fumai-ryu school is one of tea ceremony schools which was founded by Fumai MATSUDAIRA and was handed down within the Matsue Domain.

culture.name: Sohenryu School of Tea Ceremony
culture.desc: The Sohenryu school is a branch of tea ceremony founded by Sohen YAMADA.

culture.name: Soen-kei Group of Sekishu-ryu School (a school of tea ceremony for samurai family)

culture.desc: Soen-kei group of Sekishu-ryu school is a group in buke sado (the tea ceremony of samurai family)

culture.name: BANDO Mitsugoro VII

culture.name: Edosenke
culture.desc: Edosenke is a school of tea ceremony that was originated by Fuhaku KAWAKAMI.

culture.name: Fuki (yose (storyteller theater))
culture.desc: Fuki was a yose of Kamigata rakugo (traditional Japanese comic storytelling as performed in the Kyoto-Osaka region) that existed in the past.

culture.name: Susoyoke petticoat
culture.desc: Susoyoke petticoat is an inner wear that is worn under wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

culture.name: Ranryo-o (a number in gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance and music]).

culture.desc: Ranryo-o is a number in gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music).

culture.name: Haba
culture.desc: Haba is a unit used to measure width of cloth, especially for wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

culture.name: Seigaiha (a program of gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance and music])
culture.url: culture/Seigaiha (a program of gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance and music]).html
culture.desc: Seigaiha is a program of gagaku (described in this section).

culture.name: Kukurio no Hakama
culture.desc: Kukurio no hakama is a general term for hakama (a type of traditional Japanese clothing) whose hem is tied.

culture.name: Hanpi (sleeveless body wear)
culture.desc: Hanpi is a formal court dress of military officers and a bugaku (traditional Japanese court music accompanied by dancing) costume, which are a sleeveless body wear worn underneath ho (outer robe/vestment).

culture.name: Nasori (a musical piece of gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance and music])
culture.url: culture/Nasori (a musical piece of gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance and music]).html
culture.desc: Nasori is a musical piece in gagaku.

culture.name: Yumoji
culture.desc: Yumoji is a type of female inner wears.

culture.name: Soburen (a musical piece of gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance and music])
culture.url: culture/Soburen (a musical piece of gagaku [ancient Japanese court dance and music]).html
culture.desc: Soburen is a piece of music for gagaku.

culture.name: Buri Daikon (fatty yellowtail head simmered with daikon radish)

culture.desc: Buri daikon is a dish in which ara (discarded portions) of buri is broiled in soy sauce with daikon.

culture.name: Gobomaki (rolled dish with a burdock root)
culture.url: culture/Gobomaki (rolled dish with a burdock root).html
culture.desc: Gobomaki is a dish using gobo (burdock root).

culture.name: Shitagasane (long inner robe)
culture.desc: The term "shitagasane" refers to an inner robe which is put on between ho (outer robe/vestment) and hanpi (sleeveless body wear) when wearers put on a sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress) or an ikan shozoku (traditional formal court dress).

culture.name: Chikushi
culture.desc: Chikushi;

culture.name: Happi coat (livery coat)
culture.desc: Happi (written 法被) coat is worn at festival, and also is a craft man's livery coat with the crest or name of store on the back and lapels.

culture.name: Tako to Ama (The Dream of the Fisherman's Wife)
culture.url: culture/Tako to Ama (The Dream of the Fishermans Wife).html
culture.desc: "Tako to Ama" is a woodblock print by Hokusai KATSUSHIKA, which was included in the enpon (pornography) "Kinoe no Komatsu" published around 1820.

culture.name: Shirouneri (a ghost of a white dish towel)
culture.url: culture/Shirouneri (a ghost of a white dish towel).html
culture.desc: Shirouneri is a Japanese specter and a type of Tsukumo-gami (artifact spirit) described in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness), a collection of specters illustrations, by Sekien TORIYAMA, and it is written 白溶裔, 白容裔 or 白うねり.

culture.name: Skeleton woman
culture.desc: Skeleton woman is a specter described in "Konjaku Gazu Zoku Hyakki" (Continued Illustrations of the Many Demons Past and Present), a collection of specters illustrations, by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Chochin Obake (Lantern ghost)
culture.desc: Chochin obake is a lantern ghost, a kind of a Japanese ghost.

culture.name: Soroban Bozu (Abacus imp)
culture.desc: Soroban Bozu or Soroban Kozo is a ghost whose stories are told in Tanba Province (Kyoto Prefecture).

culture.name: Akabozu (a red monk ghost) (specter)
culture.desc: Akabozu is a specter that has been told in Kyoto Prefecture and Ehime Prefecture.

culture.name: Mitsuba-aoi (Three Leaves of Hollyhock)
culture.desc: Mitsuba-aoi is a type of aoi-mon (mallow patterns), which have been used as Japanese family crests.

culture.name: Korai Chawan (Tea Bowl coming from Korea)
culture.url: culture/Korai Chawan (Tea Bowl coming from Korea).html
culture.desc: The term "korai chawan" refers to a type of tea bowl which was used in Sado (Japanese tea ceremony) from around the middle of the 16th century and was originally a bowl for everyday use made in the Korean peninsula that came to be appreciated as a tea bowl by Japanese chajin (tea ceremony masters).

culture.name: Sekitai (Leather Belts)
culture.desc: A sekitai (leather belt) is a belt of black leather, used when dressing in sokutai costume.

culture.name: The Gyotai
culture.desc: A Gyotai (fish box) is an accessory used for Sokutai costume (traditional formal court dress).

culture.name: Shikan NAKAMURA (the seventh)
culture.desc: The seventh Shikan NAKAMURA (March 11, 1928 -) is a Kabuki actor.

culture.name: Shimaibakama
culture.desc: Shimaibakama (also called Shimaihakama) is a "hakama" (a kind of trousers worn with a kimono) of a special shape, mainly used in Noh drama.

culture.name: Ichigo Daifuku (Japanese confection made from a strawberry and rice cake)
culture.url: culture/Ichigo Daifuku (Japanese confection made from a strawberry and rice cake).html
culture.desc: Ichigo daifuku is a kind of Japanese confection consisting of a strawberry inside 'daifuku', which is a rice cake stuffed with sweet bean paste.

culture.name: Maedare
culture.desc: Maedare (also 'Maedara' in Edo dialect), sometimes known as Maekake, was a cloth worn by shop workers or housemaids to protect their clothes from dirt, which hangs from an obi, a kind of belt for a kimono.

culture.name: Tsukumo Nasu (tea caddy from China)
culture.desc: Tsukumo Nasu refers to a 'karamono chaire' (tea caddy from China) that was a treasured possession of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, the third Shogun of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

culture.name: Tenka San Nasu (three eggplant-shaped tea caddies)
culture.url: culture/Tenka San Nasu (three eggplant-shaped tea caddies).html
culture.desc: Tenka San Nasu refers to the following three Nasu (eggplant-shaped tea caddy): Tsukumo Nasu (literally, Nasu of gray hair), Matsumoto Nasu (Nasu originally owned by Shuho MATSUMOTO), and Fuji Nasu (literally, Nasu of Mt. Fuji).

culture.name: Yuzamashi (a tea utensil used in Senchado [green tea ceremony])
culture.url: culture/Yuzamashi (a tea utensil used in Senchado [green tea ceremony]).html
culture.desc: Yuzamashi is one of the tea utensils used in Senchado.

culture.name: Kensui (a utensils used for making Japanese tea)
culture.url: culture/Kensui (a utensils used for making Japanese tea).html
culture.desc: Kensui is one of the utensils which are used for making tea.

culture.name: Visit Japan Campaign
culture.jp: ビジット・ジャパン・キャンペーン
culture.desc: The Visit Japan Campaign is a promotional scheme to encourage foreign tourists to visit Japan.

culture.name: Kyogen-mawashi
culture.desc: Kyogen-mawashi (狂言回し) is a key person who plays an important role in the plot of a drama or movie throughout the story.

culture.name: Taganojo ONOE the third
culture.desc: Taganojo ONOE the third (Sep 21, 1889 - June 20, 1978) was a Kabuki actor who was popular around the World War II.

culture.name: Chataku (tea bowl saucer)
culture.desc: Chataku is a tea bowl saucer.

culture.name: Ryoro (brazier used in Senchado [green tea ceremony])
culture.url: culture/Ryoro (brazier used in Senchado [green tea ceremony]).html
culture.desc: Ryoro is a utensil used to boil water in senchado.

culture.name: Bofura (a ceramic kettle)
culture.desc: Bofura is a utensil for boiling water and a type of dobin (earthenware teapot).

culture.name: Charyo (scoops for green tea leaves)
culture.desc: Charyo is a type of utensil used in Senchado (Japanese tea ceremony using Sencha [brewed green tea]).

culture.name: Suichu (fresh water container)
culture.desc: Suichu (also called "mizutsugi") is a utensil used in the sado and sencha tea services for pouring water.

culture.name: Kinto (tea cloth container)
culture.desc: Kinto is a utensil used in the art of Sado (Japanese tea ceremony using Matcha [green powdered tea]) or Senchado (Japanese tea ceremony using Sencha [brewed green tea]), as a container for chakin (tea cloth).

culture.name: Teiran (basket for tea set)
culture.desc: Teiran is one of tea utensils used in Senchado (Japanese tea ceremony using Sencha [brewed green tea]).

culture.name: Kikyoku (cabinet for Senchado)
culture.desc: Kikyoku is a tea utensil used in Senchado (Japanese tea ceremony using Sencha [brewed green tea]).

culture.name: Kagetsuan-ryu School (a school of Senchado [Japanese tea ceremony using Sencha, brewed green tea])
culture.url: culture/Kagetsuan-ryu School (a school of Senchado [Japanese tea ceremony using Sencha, brewed green tea]).html
culture.desc: Kagetsuan-ryu school is a school of Senchado established by Kakuo TANAKA at the end of the Edo period.

culture.name: Akome
culture.desc: Akome is a kind of uchigi (daily wear or inner wear) worn under certain costumes.

culture.name: Uzagaku (Ozagaku)
culture.desc: Uzagaku (Ozagaku) is chamber music of the Ryukyu kingdom.

culture.name: Okuchi bakama
culture.desc: Okuchi bakama is red-colored wide sleeve hakama which is worn as underwear of the outer hakama for sokutai shozoku (traditional ceremonial court dress).

culture.name: Abumikuchi
culture.desc: Abumikuchi is a Japanese specter in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness), a collection of specters illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Abura tokkuri (oil bottle)
culture.desc: Abura tokkuri is a traditional Japanese folk utensil used as a container when purchasing or preserving oil for tomyo (votive light.)

culture.name: Igo no sei
culture.desc: Igo no sei is a spirit of Igo which is described in old books and so on from the Edo Period.

culture.name: Kameosa
culture.desc: Kameosa is a Japanese specter that is introduced in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness), a collection of specters illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Kotofurunushi
culture.desc: Kotofurunushi is one of Japanese specters that is introduced in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness) which is a collection of specters illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA, and it is Tsukumo-gami (gods to a variety of things) of koto (a long Japanese zither with thirteen strings).

culture.name: Shamichoro
culture.desc: Shamichoro is a Japanese specter that is introduced in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness), a collection of specters illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Setotaisho
culture.desc: Setotaisho is a Japanese specter that is introduced in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness) which is a collection of specters illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA, and it is a type of Tsukumo-gami (gods to a variety of things) of chinaware.

culture.name: Zenfusho
culture.desc: Zenfusho is a type of Tsukumo-gami (gods to a variety of things) and a specter of chagama (iron tea ceremony pot) that is introduced in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness) by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Bakefurugeta
culture.desc: Bakefurugeta or Baketafurugeta is one of Japanese specters, and a type of Tsukumo-gami (gods to a variety of things) that have come to life after geta (Japanese footwear, wooden clogs) became old.

culture.name: Biwabokuboku
culture.desc: Biwabokuboku is a Japanese specter that is introduced in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness), a collection of specters illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA, and it is a specter of biwa (Japanese lute).

culture.name: Menreiki
culture.desc: Menreiki is one of Japanese specters that is introduced in "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idleness) which is a collection of specters illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA, and it is a specter of Gigaku-men Mask (masks for Gigaku, an ancient masked drama).

culture.name: Mishige
culture.desc: Mishige or Mishige-Majimun is a kind of Fumo-gami which has been known in Okinawa Prefecture and is a kind of Majimun (the general name for devils in Okinawa and Amami Islands south of Kagoshima Prefecture).

culture.name: Mokugyo-daruma
culture.desc: Mokugyo-daruma is a Japanese specter included in a specter art collection book entitled "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" by Sekien TORIYAMA and is the Tsukumo-gami of a Mokugyo (wooden fish, temple block).

culture.name: Nyoijizai
culture.desc: Nyoijizai is a Japanese specter included in a specter art collection book entitled "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" by Sekien TORIYAMA and is a kind of the Tsukumo-gami (a specter changed from a utensil).

culture.name: Konoshi
culture.desc: A konoshi is a kariginu robe on which a ran (horizontally-wrapped fabric forming the bottom part) similar to that of a ho (a round-necked robe) or a noshi (an unlined, long-sleeved garment) has been stitched.

culture.name: Katabiragatsuji
culture.desc: Katabiragatsuji' is said to have been located in the northwestern of Kyoto City.

culture.name: Matcha (powdered tea) ice cream
culture.desc: Matcha ice cream is ice cream flavored with Matcha.

culture.name: Ubagabi (the mysterious fire of an old woman)
culture.url: culture/Ubagabi (the mysterious fire of an old woman).html
culture.desc: Ubagabi' refers to mysterious fiery apparitions handed down from generation to generation in Kawachi no kuni (present-day Osaka Prefecture) and Tanba no kuni (present-day the northern part of Kyoto prefecture).

culture.name: Kanoko shibori
culture.desc: Kanoko shibori' is one of the methods of dyeing cloth regularly patterned with spots like the back of the fawn.

culture.name: Kaichigo
culture.desc: Kaichigo' refers to a type of Japanese spirit appearing in "Hyakki Tsurezurebukuro Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro' (One hundred bags in idleness), collections of ghosts, spirits, spooks and monsters, described by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Oshouo (Monk Fish)
culture.desc: Oshouo' refers to a kind of 'Umibozu', a 'yokai' (apparitions, spirits, spooks or monsters) living in the ocean recorded in an encyclopedia, "Wakansansaizue", compiled in the Edo period.

culture.name: Mitsugoro BANDO (the 8th)
culture.desc: Mitsugoro BANDO the 8th (October 19, 1906 - January 16, 1975) was a kabuki actor.

culture.name: Bakezori (apparition turning into thonged sandals)
culture.desc: Bakezori' is one of Tsukumogami (the spirits of discarded object) and a yokai (apparition) of zori (thonged sandals).

culture.name: Antique Kimono
culture.desc: Antique Kimono refers to Kimono made before the beginning of the Showa period and particularly in good condition.

culture.name: Sakabashira (a pillar erected upside-down)
culture.desc: Sakabashira' or 'sakasa bashira' refers to one of superstitions about Japanese wooden structure (architecture),

culture.name: Obidome
culture.desc: Obidome' refers to an accessory passed through 'Obijime'(a string tied around the waist to fix obi).

culture.name: Koromodako
culture.desc: Koromodako' refers to a yokai (monster) in the sea handed down in Yosa County, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school (a group of Sekishu-ryu school of Japanese tea ceremony)
culture.url: culture/Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school (a group of Sekishu-ryu school of Japanese tea ceremony).html
culture.desc: The Kajun-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school performs the buke-sado (the art of the tea ceremony of samurai families).

culture.name: Isa-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school (a group of Sekishu-ryu school of Japanese tea ceremony)
culture.url: culture/Isa-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school (a group of Sekishu-ryu school of Japanese tea ceremony).html
culture.desc: The Isa-ha group of the Sekishu-ryu school is the buke-sado (the art of the tea ceremony of samurai families).

culture.name: Ukiyo-e Ruiko (Various Thoughts on Ukiyo-e)
culture.desc: The Ukiyo-e Ruiko is basic material of the art history, collected biographies and backgrounds of ukiyo-e (Japanese woodblock prints) artists.

culture.name: Kyo-yaki (Kyoto pottery)
culture.desc: Kyo-yaki is a type of Japanese pottery.

culture.name: Sashimono (cabinetwork)
culture.desc: The term "sashimono" is a generic name given to traditional craft products which are made without any joint parts such as nails; for example, furniture, doors, and other household things made by assembling wooden pieces.

culture.name: UMEWAKA Rokuro
culture.desc: Rokuro UMEWAKA is a name used by the headman of the Umewaka family, which is one of the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters in Noh performances) Kanze school groups.

culture.name: HOSHO Kuro
culture.desc: Kuro HOSHO is a stage name used by the headman of the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters in Noh performances) Hosho school.

culture.name: KANZE Sakon
culture.desc: Sakon KANZE is a name which has been handed down from generation to generation by the headmen of the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters in Noh performances) Kanze school.

culture.name: Azuma-asobi (ancient Japanese dance suite that originated in eastern Japan)
culture.url: culture/Azuma-asobi (ancient Japanese dance suite that originated in eastern Japan).html
culture.desc: Azuma-asobi is a fairly long suite that needs approximately 30 minutes to be completed, which is classified into the Kuniburi no Utamai (native-style songs and dances based on the music of ancient Japan), a type of gagaku (Japanese Imperial Court music).

culture.name: Fukuo school
culture.desc: The Fukuo school is a school of waki-kata (supporting actors) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Mizusashi (water jug)
culture.desc: Mizusashi is a tea utensil.

culture.name: UMEWAKA Kichinojo
culture.desc: Kichinojo UMEWAKA is a name used by the head of the Kichinojo Umewaka family, one of the branch families of the Rokuro Umewaka family, which is one of the schools of the shite-kata (actors who play leading characters in Noh performances) Kanze school.

culture.name: Takekiri danuki (raccoon dog cutting bamboo)
culture.desc: Some people insist the sound was not auditory hallucination or hallucinatory image because sometimes, dozens of people heard the sound at the same time.

culture.name: Tenka-ippin
culture.desc: Tenka-ippin (which means the best in the world), is a chain of ramen (Chinese-style noodles served in a hot soup) stores founded in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Suzuri no Tamashii (the soul of Chinese inkstone)
culture.url: culture/Suzuri no Tamashii (the soul of Chinese inkstone).html
culture.desc: Suzuri no tamashii' or 'suzuri no sei' is one of 'tsukumogami' (a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive) as described in "Konjaku Hyakki Shui" (literally, Supplement to The Hundred Demons from the Present and the Past), a yokai (Japanese ghosts, spirits, spooks and monsters) art collection book or supernatural bestiary by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Osei-chu
culture.desc: An 'Osei-chu' (mimicking roundworm) or 'Osei' (literally, mimicking or parroting the host's words) is a weird disease or a ghostly roundworm which causes the disease known in China and Japan, as described in collected essays written in the Edo period, such as "Shin Chomonju" (literally, a new collection of famous tales) and "Kanden jihitsu" (literally, fallow-field essays, continued; miscellaneous essays).

culture.name: kishimai (court dances and music)
culture.desc: Kishimai is a bugaku (court music and dance) directed by the family head of Abe clan and others, and was danced mostly in uniforms of military officers, such as ketteki no ho (open sleeve seams outer robe) at events such as Daijo-sai Festival (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor).

culture.name: Rinsenji group of Sekishu School
culture.desc: The Rinsenji group of Sekishu school is one of the groups of buke sado (the tea ceremony of samurai family).

culture.name: Wagashi no hi (the Day of Japanese Confectionery)
culture.url: culture/Wagashi no hi (the Day of Japanese Confectionery).html
culture.desc: Wagashi no hi' (the Day of Japanese Confectionery) was a memorial day, established by 'Zenkoku Wagashi Kyokai' (Japan Wagashi Association) in 1979.

culture.name: Kazenbo
culture.desc: Kazenbo (literally, a bonze in front of the fire) is a type of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) described in "Konjaku Hyakki Shui" (literally, Supplement to The Hundred Demons from the Present and the Past), a yokai art collection book or a supernatural bestiary by Sekien TORIYAMA.

culture.name: Kentsuba-monyo-tsuki enkei Kintsuba
culture.jp: 剣鍔文様付き円型きんつば
culture.desc: Kentsuba-monyo-tsuki enkei Kintsuba' (literally, samurai-sword-guard-patterned round kintsuba-cake) is one of the Japanese confectionery known as 'kintsuba' (a Japanese confection made from red bean paste wrapped with a skin made from flour and water kneaded and spread thinly).

culture.name: Nyubachibo
culture.desc: Nyubachibo (literally, mortar [a bowl-shaped vessel] bonze) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was transmuted from a copper disk (cymbal) used as a musical instrument for theatrical performance.

culture.name: Hyotankozo
culture.desc: Hyotan-kozo (literally, a calabash or bottle gourd boy) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was transmuted from a calabash or bottle gourd.

culture.name: Eritategoromo
culture.desc: An Eritate-goromo (literally, standing-collar robe) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Gazu Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Illustrated Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Minowaraji, also called Minosoji
culture.desc: Minowaraji or Minosoji is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) which is portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book, "Gazu Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Illustrated Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Tsunohanzo
culture.desc: Tsunohanzo is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) which is portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book, "Gazu Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Illustrated Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Gotokuneko
culture.desc: Gotoku-neko (literally, tripod cat) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Gazu Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Illustrated Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Kigo (to write with a brush)
culture.desc: Kigo, or 揮毫 in Chinese characters, means writing words or phrases with brushes.

culture.name: Stuffed Bell Peppers
culture.desc: The stuffed bell pepper is a dish made with ground meat and bell peppers.

culture.name: Chayatsuji
culture.desc: Chayatsuji is a pattern for wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

culture.name: Zashiki
culture.desc: Zashiki (literally, sitting mat) is the place where (in the medieval times) the floor was covered with a mat or carpet so as to, literally, sit down.

culture.name: Shichihoda (also called Shichifuja)
culture.desc: Shichihoda which is also called Shichifuja is a Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters).

culture.name: Noborigama (Climbing kiln)
culture.desc: "Noborigama" these days generally means a kiln with a partitioned chamber for firing large quantities of ceramics and other ware, built on a slope so that gravity draws the flue gas through the kiln, keeping the high temperatures constant throughout the chamber.

culture.name: Suzuhikohime
culture.desc: Suzuhiko-hime (literally, Princess Bells) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Gazu Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Illustrated Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Nyunaisuzume
culture.desc: Nyunaisuzume (Russet Sparrow) or Sanekatasuzume is a mysterious bird appearing in legend of FUJIWARA no Sanekata, a poet in the Heian period.

culture.name: Heiroku
culture.desc: Heiroku is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Burabura
culture.desc: Burabura is a lantern specter and one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Honekarakasa
culture.desc: Hone-karakasa (literally, an oil-paper umbrella with a bamboo frame, the oil paper of which is gone) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Game Archive Project
culture.jp: ゲームアーカイブ・プロジェクト
culture.desc: Game Archive Project, also known as GAP, was inaugurated in 1998, by Kyoto Prefecture as a leasing body and other organizations.

culture.name: SHIRAKURA Yoshihiko
culture.desc: Yoshihiko SHIRAKURA (1940 -) is a researcher and a writer on Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints).

culture.name: Chirizuka-kaio (ghost king of waste)
culture.desc: Chirizuka-kaio (ghost king of waste) is a type of Japanese yokai (specter).

culture.name: Kurayaro
culture.desc: Kurayaro (literally, saddle guy) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]) and is a yokai of horse saddles.

culture.name: Furuutsubo
culture.desc: Furu-utsubo or Utsubo is a Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book named "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Kutsutsura
culture.desc: Kutsu-tsura (literally, shoe cheek) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive])

culture.name: Narikama
culture.desc: A Narikama (also called Narigama or Kamanari) is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

culture.name: Achimenowaza (songs to accompany kagura performances)
culture.desc: Achimenowaza (also known as Achimewaza, Achimesaho, Ajimenosaho, and so on) is a Kagurauta (songs to accompany kagura [sacred music and dancing performed at shrines] performance) performed in the Imperial Court or shrines.

culture.name: Ogumo (Giant spider)
culture.desc: Ogumo is a gigantic spider monster which appears in Japanese Kaidan (ghost stories), essays, folk material and so on.

culture.name: Kyo rin rin
culture.desc: A Kyo rin rin is one of Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) that was portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book: "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]), and a yokai of Buddhist scriptures.

culture.name: Kosode no te
culture.desc: Kosode no te (literally, the hand of kosode [short sleeved kimono]) is one of Japanese yokai (monsters, spirits, ghosts and specters) which is drawn in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book "Konjaku Hyakki Shui" (Supplement to The Hundred Demons from the Present and the Past).

culture.name: Byobu nozoki
culture.desc: Byobu nozoki (literally, a voyeur at a folding screen) is one of Japanese yokai (specters, monsters, spirits and ghosts) drawn in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book "Konjaku Hyakki Shui" (Supplement to The Hundred Demons from the Present and the Past).

culture.name: Gomashio (salt with parched sesame)
culture.desc: Gomashio is a mixture of sesame seeds and salt and used as a seasoning.

culture.name: Samon (ripple marks)
culture.desc: Samon (ripple marks) are regular wave-like undulations formed by water and wind currents.

culture.name: Oribe-yaki (Oribe ware)
culture.desc: Oribe ware is pottery made mainly in Mino Province from the Tensho era (1573-1592) of the Momoyama period.

culture.name: SHIGEYAMA Sengoro
culture.desc: Sengoro SHIGEYAMA is a family name of Kyogen Okura-ryu (comic actors of Okura school) and the name of the head of the Sengoro Shigeyama family.

culture.name: Aikata
culture.desc: Aikata is a term used in the fields of classical Japanese music and dance.

culture.name: Kudo

culture.desc: Koboku is the ink stick that has gone through the years among Bunboshiho (four stationary goods for calligraphy; writing brush, ink, ink stone and paper), and is recognized as a good quality ink stick.

culture.name: Hatsuhana
culture.desc: Hatsuhana is one of the three major Chaire (tea caddy).

culture.name: Heirakuji Shoten
culture.desc: Kabushiki Kaisha (a joint stock corporation) Heirakuji (literally, Heiraku-ji Temple) Shoten is a publishing company located at Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Yohen Tenmoku Tea Bowl (spotted Tenmoku tea bowl)
culture.url: culture/Yohen Tenmoku Tea Bowl (spotted Tenmoku tea bowl).html
culture.desc: The term "Yohen Tenmoku tea bowl" refers to a tea bowl considered to be the best of Tenmoku (a stoneware glaze which is deeply stained by iron oxide) tea bowls.

culture.name: Sotan Gitsune
culture.desc: Sotan gitsune (fox) was a monster fox, a story of which has been passed down at the Shokoku-ji Temple in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Kurokawa-Noh
culture.desc: Kurokawa-Noh is a traditional entertainment preserved in Tsuruoka City, Yamagata Prefecture.

culture.name: Futaoki (lid rests)
culture.desc: Futaoki, one of the tea ceremony equipment, is a rest on which the lid of the iron tea pot or the dipper end of the water ladle is placed; it is made of bamboo, metal, or ceramic.

culture.name: Furosaki Byobu (folding screen)
culture.desc: Furosaki Byobu, one of the tea ceremony equipment, is a folding screen of two panels, which is placed in the corner at the upper end of the tea-making tatami mat when the tea ceremony procedure is done in a room of more than 4.5 tatami mat size.

culture.name: Nishiki-e-shinbun
culture.desc: Nishiki-e-shinbun (a newspaper having nishiki-e prints in it) refers to a visual news medium which was issued for several years in the early Meiji period in Japan, and was a newspaper which explained each one newspaper article using one nishiki-e (an especially colorful Japanese woodblock print) which was a kind of ukiyo-e (a Japanese wood-block print).

culture.name: Katawa-guruma
culture.desc: The term "Katawa-guruma" refers to a Japanese ghost seen in old books of ghost stories and others written during the Edo period.

culture.name: Ungaikyo
culture.desc: The term "Ungaikyo" is a type of a Japanese ghost, that metamorphizes from a peculiar mirror after the passing of many long years.

culture.name: Onmoraki
culture.desc: Onmoraki is a monster bird written in Chinese and Japanese classics.

culture.name: Ittan-momen
culture.desc: The term "Ittan-momen" refers to a folkloric ghost that is said to haunt Takayama-cho (the present Kimotsuki-cho), Kimotsuki-gun, Kagoshima Prefecture.

culture.name: Kagami-ita
culture.desc: Kagami-ita boards are wainscoting in the front and on the right side face of the Noh stages.

culture.name: Shinsaku-Noh (a Noh song written in and after Meiji period)
culture.url: culture/Shinsaku-Noh (a Noh song written in and after Meiji period).html
culture.desc: Shinsaku-Noh refers to songs of noh which were written in and after Meiji period.

culture.url: culture/Umewaka-ryu school (a school of Noh play).html
culture.desc: Umewaka-ryu school refers to a school of Noh play which existed only for a period from 1921 to 1954.

culture.name: Yamato Enshu School
culture.desc: The Yamato Enshu school is one of the Japanese tea ceremony schools headed by the Kobori Gonjuro family, which originated from Masai KOBORI, the third son of Enshu KOBORI (also known as Masakazu KOBORI).

culture.name: Mai-ogi (folding fan used in a Japanese dance)
culture.url: culture/Mai-ogi (folding fan used in a Japanese dance).html
culture.desc: A mai-ogi is a folding fan used in Japanese dances.

culture.url: culture/Kanjin-Noh (Noh performances held to raise subscriptions for the construction of shrines or temples).html
culture.desc: "Kanjin-Noh" refers to Noh performances which charged admission fees in order to raise subscriptions for the construction or the reconstruction of shrines or temples.

culture.name: Kogetsu
culture.desc: Kogetsu is a Kyo-gashi (Kyoto style confectionary) manufacturing and sales company whose headquarters is located in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Kaishi (Japanese tissue)
culture.desc: Kaishi (Japanese tissue)

culture.name: Fukusa basami (pouch for a silk wrapping cloth and other small items used for the tea ceremony)
culture.url: culture/Fukusa basami (pouch for a silk wrapping cloth and other small items used for the tea ceremony).html
culture.desc: Fukusa basami, also referred to as Kaishi ire (literally, Japanese pocket tissue pouch), is a generic name given to pouches used to put together and carry small items necessary for tea ceremony lessons or tea ceremony parties.

culture.url: culture/Kobukusa (cloth which is about one fourth of the size of a regular silk cloth used in the tea ceremo.html
culture.desc: A kobukusa is a small cloth used at some tea ceremony schools when they view tea bowls or when they carry out already whisked tea and present it to various other guests.

culture.name: Kojakin (small wet cloth to wipe a tea bowl)
culture.url: culture/Kojakin (small wet cloth to wipe a tea bowl).html
culture.desc: A kojakin is a small cloth used to clean off a tea bowl after drinking tea at the Urasenke (the House of Urasen) school, which is one of the Japanese tea ceremony schools.

culture.name: Desaku
culture.desc: Desaku, also referred to as Detsukuri (literally, going out to plow) means that inhabitants in a region cultivate fields in other regions.

culture.name: Takayasu school
culture.desc: The Takayasu school is one of Noh schools.

culture.name: Shindo school
culture.desc: The Shindo school is an extinct school of waki-kata (supporting actors) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Shundo school
culture.desc: The Shundo school is an extinct school of waki-kata (supporting actors) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Morita school
culture.desc: The Morita school is a school of fue-kata (flute players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Isso school
culture.desc: The Isso school is one of the schools of fue-kata (flute players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Fujita school
culture.desc: The Fujita school is one of the schools of fue-kata (flute players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Shunnichi school
culture.desc: The Shunnichi school is an extinct school of fue-kata (flute players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Hiraiwa school
culture.desc: The Hiraiwa school is an extinct school of fue-kata (flute players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Itoku school
culture.desc: The Itoku school is an extinct school of otsuzumi-kata (large hand drum players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Kenshibu (sword and poetry dancing)
culture.desc: Kenbu or a sword dance refers in a broad sense to dancing holding a sword.

culture.name: Kensenbu (sword and fan dancing)
culture.desc: Kensenbu refers to dancing holding a sword or a fan, or both of them.

culture.name: Ko school
culture.desc: The Ko school is one of the schools of kotsuzumi-kata (small hand drum players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Kosei school
culture.desc: The Kosei school, or Ko Seijiro school, is one of the schools of kotsuzumi-kata (small hand drum players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Okura school
culture.desc: The Okura school is one of the schools of hayashi-kata (people who play hayashi, or the musical accompaniment) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Ishii school
culture.desc: Ishii school is one of the schools of otsuzumi-kata (large hand drum players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Kadono school
culture.desc: Kadono school is one of the schools of otsuzumi-kata (large hand drum players) in Nohgaku (the art of Noh).

culture.name: Suzuribako (case containing ink stone and other materials)
culture.url: culture/Suzuribako (case containing ink stone and other materials).html
culture.desc: Suzuribako means a box that is used for keeping suzuri (ink stone) and other articles.

culture.name: Kokatsuji-bon (Old Movable Type Imprints)
culture.desc: Kokatsuji-bon or Kokatsuji-han (old type editions) are general terms for movable type imprints published in Japan from the Bunroku era (1592 - 1596) to around the Keian era (1648 - 1652).

culture.name: Higeyagura
culture.desc: Higeyagura is a title of kyogen (farce played during a Noh play cycle).

culture.name: Hachi no ki
culture.desc: Hachi no ki is one of the Noh plays.

culture.name: Shura Noh
culture.desc: Shura Noh is one of the programs of Noh theatrical performance, in which a warrior is the shite (the main actor of a Noh play).

culture.name: Kyoto Ongaku Hakurankai (Kyoto Music Expo)
culture.desc: The term "Kyoto Ongaku Hakurankai (Kyoto Music Expo)" refers to a music festival that has been held annually since 2007 in Umekoji-koen Park, in Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Kamiarai (Hair washing)
culture.desc: Kamiarai is a part of Shakkyo (Stone Bridge, Noh Play) in Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) and is a shosa (conduct) in which a shishi lion bends forward and sways its head side to side with its long hair hung down in the front.

culture.name: Kazura Noh
culture.desc: Kazura Noh is one of the programs of Noh theatrical performance, when the shite (the main actor of a Noh play) performs the roles of a beautiful woman, a scion of a noble family, or a heavenly being.

culture.name: Waki Noh
culture.desc: Waki Noh is one of the programs of Noh theatrical performance, when the shite (the main actor of a Noh play) performs the roles of gods.

culture.name: Kiri Noh
culture.desc: Kiri Noh is one of the programs of Noh theatrical performance, when the shite (the main actor of a Noh play) performs the roles of Oni (ogre), Tengu (a long-nosed goblin), Tenjin (the heavenly god), Raijin (the god of thunder), Ryujin (the god of dragon), etc.

culture.name: Shini-e (death prints)
culture.desc: The Shini-e is a Japanese woodcut print Ukiyo-e, (lit. Pictures of the floating world) produced and published for the commemoration of a famous actor or a writer when he passed away.

culture.name: Grilled eggplant
culture.desc: Grilled eggplant is one of the popular recipes for cooking eggplants in Japan.

culture.name: Hoeki no ho (robe with a round collar, stitched sides and a ran, worn by an emperor and high-ranking officials)
culture.url: culture/Hoeki no ho (robe with a round collar, stitched sides and a ran, worn by an emperor and high-ranking.html
culture.desc: Hoeki no ho is one of the Japanese robes of chofuku (clothes worn by the people who come to work at the court on a regular basis), and a ho (round-necked robe worn by members of nobility and the Imperial Court), which has sewn sleeve seams, an outer robe and fabrics called ran (brocade) running sideways around the hem.

culture.name: Super Kabuki
culture.desc: The Super Kabuki is a modernized, contemporary Kabuki dance drama directed in a different manner from the original, classical Kabuki theatrical dance, which was introduced by the third Ennosuke ICHIKAWA in 1986.

culture.name: Shukuba Ichiya Yumekaido (One Night of Dream Road at Inn Town)
culture.url: culture/Shukuba Ichiya Yumekaido (One Night of Dream Road at Inn Town).html
culture.desc: Shukuba Ichiya Yumekaido is a festival that takes place in Furuichi, Sasayama City.

culture.name: Kayuzue (rice porridge stick)
culture.desc: Kayuzue is a stick made by shaving a piece of firewood that was not completely burnt when making kayu (rice porridge) on January 15.

culture.name: The scandal of Shunpoan
culture.desc: The scandal of Shunpoan is the large-scale criminal case of counterfeit hand-painted Ukiyo-e (Japanese woodblock prints), which occurred in the early Showa period around 1930s.

culture.name: Haseo Zoshi
culture.desc: The Haseo Zoshi is one of the Japanese Emakimono (a traditional Japanese illustration/painting format developed for a narrative/storytelling purpose, produced in a narrow, horizontal scroll for representing various scenes and stories in a single scroll) remaining today.

culture.name: Niwabi
culture.desc: Niwabi (garden fire) is a piece of music used for the court kagura (sacred Shinto music and dancing performed in the Imperial Court).

culture.name: Unden Shindo school
culture.desc: Unden Shindo school is one of the schools of Japanese tea ceremony.

culture.name: Senmyo (an Imperial Edict)
culture.desc: Senmyo is a written document in which emperor's commands are recorded in a Japanese orthography only with Chinese characters, as compared with Shochoku (an imperial edict) written in classical Chinese.

culture.name: Nukiemon
culture.desc: Nukiemon is a method of wearing a kimono.

culture.name: The Ogre of Suzaku-mon Gate
culture.desc: The ogre of Suzaku-mon Gate is said to have lived in the Suzaku-mon Gate of Heian-kyo (the ancient capital in what is now Kyoto).

culture.name: Narashiba Katatsuki
culture.desc: The Narashiba Katatsuki is a tea canister which was called one of the three major Katatsuki, along with Nitta Katatsuki and Hatsuhana Katatsuki.

culture.name: Yamato Sarugaku
culture.desc: The Yamato Sarugaku is one of the groups performing Sarugaku (a traditional form of a Japanese theatre) mostly in Yamato Province (today's Nara Prefecture).

culture.name: Kone
culture.desc: Kone (also pronounced Koni) is the Japanese name given to an emperor's costume in the Tang style.

culture.name: Ishikiate (Hip Reinforcement)
culture.desc: Ishikiate is a square piece of thick cloth for the reinforcement of an unlined garment; it prevents the seams from coming apart and is applied from the back (inside) to the part that presses against the wearer's hip.

culture.name: Ogawa school
culture.desc: The Ogawa school is one of the schools of Senchado (the way of brewed green tea) established by Kashin OGAWA (Koraku OGAWA the first) in the last years of Edo period.

culture.name: Gyuro-Shukujo
culture.desc: "Gyuro-Shukujo" (The Cowherd and the Weaving Girl) is a myth and legend of the People's Republic of China and is believed to be one of the country's folk tales.

culture.name: Kyoto Shoin
culture.desc: Kyoto Shoin was at one time a publishing company in Kyoto that published large numbers of art books.

culture.name: Kyogoku Toho
culture.desc: Kyogoku Toho is a Toho-affiliated movie theater that was located in Shinkyogoku Shijo, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Karakuri-Doji ULTIMO (a title of a Japanese manga [comic] series written by Stan LEE and illustrated by Hiroyuki TAKEI)
culture.url: culture/Karakuri-Doji ULTIMO (a title of a Japanese manga [comic] series written by Stan LEE and illustrated.html
culture.desc: "Karakuri-Doji ULTIMO" is the title of a Japanese manga (comic) series written by Stan LEE and illustrated by Hiroyuki TAKEI.

culture.name: Tochi mochi (conker rice cake)
culture.desc: Tochi mochi is a rice cake made by steaming conkers after removal of harshness with glutinous rice and then pounding them.

culture.name: Hyonenzu (a painting of Catching a Catfish with a Gourd)
culture.url: culture/Hyonenzu (a painting of Catching a Catfish with a Gourd).html
culture.desc: Hyonenzu is a painting created by Josetsu, a leading painter and priest in the early stage of ink-and-wash paintings in Japan.

culture.name: Kyo ningyo (dolls)
culture.desc: Kyo ningyo is a general term for luxurious Japanese dolls, which have been traditionally made around the city of Kyoto, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Imo-yokan (azuki-bean jelly containing sweet potato paste)
culture.url: culture/Imo-yokan (azuki-bean jelly containing sweet potato paste).html
culture.desc: Imo-yokan is a Japanese sweet having sweet potatoes as a main ingredient that is kneaded and molded.

culture.name: Komagaku
culture.desc: Komagaku is a form of Gagaku (traditional Japanese court music) that was introduced into Japan from Korea.

culture.name: Kyoto City Half-Marathon
culture.jp: 京都シティハーフマラソン
culture.desc: Kyoto City Half-Marathon is an event that takes place annually on the second Sunday in March, in the city of Kyoto, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Shinkei Sanjurokkaisen (New Forms of Thirty-six Ghosts)
culture.url: culture/Shinkei Sanjurokkaisen (New Forms of Thirty-six Ghosts).html
culture.desc: Shinkei Sanjurokkaisen is a series of monster pictures by ukiyo-e artist Yoshitoshi TSUKIOKA from the late Edo period to the early Meiji period.

culture.name: Chikkin
culture.desc: Chikkin is a koto (a traditional Japanese stringed musical instrument) with three strings, which was invented by Chikkin (Yosaburo) TAMURA from Numazu City, Shizuoka Prefecture, in August, 1886.

culture.name: Kyoto Photographers' Society
culture.desc: The Kyoto Photographers' Society (KPS), an organization for professional photographers in Kyoto Prefecture, was founded in 1970.

culture.name: Kyoto International Student Film and Video Festival
culture.url: culture/Kyoto International Student Film and Video Festival.html
culture.desc: The Kyoto International Student Film and Video Festival is a film and video festival held in Kyoto every fall.

culture.name: Ko school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family
culture.url: culture/Ko school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family.html
culture.desc: The Ko school of tea ceremony of the Ogasawara family is a tea ceremony school descended in the Kokura Domain, Buzen Province (Kitakyushu City, Fukuoka Prefecture).

culture.name: Shinshi
culture.desc: Shinshi is a tool for use in Arai-hari of Wafuku (Japanese traditional clothing) (a Kimono cleaning technique of laying or stretching out a starched Kimono to dry) or dyeing fabrics by sticking each of its ends into a longer edge of the fabric, respectively, so as to stretch out the fabric in the shape of a bow (a type of weapon) and support it while keeping its width without shrinkage.

culture.name: Itabari (to stretch out a piece of washed, starched fabric on a board after washing)
culture.url: culture/Itabari (to stretch out a piece of washed, starched fabric on a board after washing).html
culture.desc: Itabari is one of the Arai-hari (washing and stretching out) techniques used to stretch out a piece of washed, starched fabric on a board so as to flatten out any creases and give the finished fabric a shiny appearance.

culture.name: Patch (men's long underpants)
culture.desc: Patch is a men's underwear covering between the waist and ankles.

culture.name: The Kyo Top
culture.desc: The Kyo top is a kind of Japanese spinning top.

culture.name: Shinodamaki (various foods wrapped in deep-fried bean curd)
culture.url: culture/Shinodamaki (various foods wrapped in deep-fried bean curd).html
culture.desc: Shinodamaki is a dish of meat, vegetables, tofu, kamaboko (boiled fish paste) and other ingredients rolled with a sheet of opened abura-age (deep-fried bean curd), and simmered to season.

culture.name: Kanko-ken (sightseeing areas)
culture.desc: Kanko-ken (sightseeing areas) are areas (each of which is located in one prefecture or multiple prefectures in Japan), being organized for tourism; they are designated by the Japan Tourism Agency, an extra-ministerial bureau of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism of Japan, to develop sightseeing areas in order to distinguish Japan as a tourism nation and promote tourists' visits and extended stays.

culture.name: List of present Noh (traditional masked dance-drama) programs
culture.url: culture/List of present Noh (traditional masked dance-drama) programs.html
culture.desc: The list of present Noh programs is a list of current programs performed by the five schools of Noh's shite-kata (actors who play leading characters).

culture.name: Daitokuji natto
culture.desc: Daitokuji natto is natto (fermented soybeans) made in Daitokujimonmae, Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City.

culture.name: Hanten
culture.desc: Hanten is a kind of wafuku (Japanese traditional clothing) and winter clothing that has been worn by ordinary people since around the eighteenth century.

culture.name: Nana Komachi (Seven Komachis)
culture.desc: Nanakomachi is a generic term for seven Yokyoku (Noh songs) dealing with ONO no Komachi.

culture.name: Fukusa (a double-layer square piece of silk cloth)
culture.url: culture/Fukusa (a double-layer square piece of silk cloth).html
culture.desc: Fukusa is a piece of cloth used in handling tea utensils mainly in a tea ceremony.

culture.name: Uchine
culture.desc: An uchine is an arrow-shaped weapon 36 to 54cm in length and 18mm in diameter.

culture.name: Takenaka Mokuhan (a Japanese woodblock printing craft center)
culture.url: culture/Takenaka Mokuhan (a Japanese woodblock printing craft center).html
culture.desc: Takenaka Mokuhan is a craft center of Japanese woodblock printings, inaugurated in 1884, with a workshop located in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

culture.name: Portraits of Court Nobles
culture.desc: Portraits of Court Nobles (called "Kugeretsueizu" or "Kokeretsueizu" in Japanese) is a book of portraits that is thought to have been compiled in the Kamakura period.

culture.name: Murasakino Senke school (a school of tea ceremony)
culture.url: culture/Murasakino Senke school (a school of tea ceremony).html
culture.desc: Buke style (samurai style) Murasakino Senke school is considered to have descended from Imasawa school inherited by the family of karo (chief retainer) of the Owari Tokugawa family.

culture.name: MISHOSAI Koho
culture.desc: Koho MISHOSAI (1791- August, 1861) was a Japanese expert of flower arrangement.

culture.name: Misho school
culture.desc: Misho school is one of the schools of flower arrangement, founded by Ippo MISHOSAI.

culture.name: MISHOSAI Ippo
culture.desc: Ippo MISHOSAI (1761 - 1824) was a Japanese flower arrangement expert.

culture.name: Homekotoba (words of praise)
culture.desc: Homekotoba refers to words of praise to be uttered or shouted to applaud playactors of Kabuki play on stage.

culture.name: Kuraki Park
culture.desc: Kuraki Park is a park with an area of approximately 230,000 square meters that expands over Konan Ward and Isogo Ward in Yokohama City.

culture.name: Junka (a diving method)
culture.desc: Junka is a diving method of Japanese martial arts swimming.

culture.name: Makumo (a musical instrument)
culture.desc: Makumo (written as 莫目 in Japanese) is a musical instrument used in Komagaku (the court music of Japan introduced from Korea) and Kudaragaku (the court music of Japan introduced from Paekche) music.

culture.name: Mojiri jutsu (art of entanglement)
culture.desc: Mojiri jutsu refers to a martial art using a weapon called mojiri.

culture.name: Sumo
culture.desc: Sumo is a Japanese traditional ritual ceremony or festival.

culture.name: Meiji
culture.desc: Meiji is the name of an era in Japan.

culture.name: Sugoroku
culture.desc: Sugoroku is a boardgame that a player throws a dice to move a piece as many squares as the numbers shown on the rolled dice.

culture.name: Hyakunin Isshu
culture.desc: Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred poets) is a poetry anthology containing one hundred waka (classical Japanese poems), one each by distinguished poets from ancient times; in the past, it had been called 'Hyakunin-shu.'

culture.name: Fubutsushi (a poetic expression for certain events or things)
culture.url: culture/Fubutsushi (a poetic expression for certain events or things).html
culture.desc: Fubutsushi means events or things unique to a season--natural phenomena, tastes, living things, and street vendors-- that characterize the season in people's mind.

culture.name: Jidaigeki (Period Drama)
culture.desc: Jidaigeki (period drama) is a genre of theater, film and television shows based on various periods in Japanese history.

culture.name: The Sea of Japan
culture.desc: The Sea of Japan is a marginal sea of the Western Pacific being surrounded by Sakhalin, Hokkaido, Honshu (the main island of Japan), Kyushu as well as the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea), the Republic of Korea and the Russian Federation in the Eurasian Continent.

culture.name: Shojo
culture.desc: Shojo (Xingxing, written as 猩猩 or 猩々) is an imaginary animal first appeared in Chinese legends.

culture.name: Religions of Japan
culture.desc: "Religions of Japan" describes religions in Japan.

culture.name: Origami (Paper folding)
culture.desc: Origami is the traditional Japanese art of folding paper to make models of plants, animals, daily-use tools and amongst others.

culture.name: Old Calendar
culture.desc: The old calendar refers to a calendar previously used when a new one is introduced.

culture.name: Hi Izuru Tokoro no Tenshi (Emperor of the Land of the Rising Sun)
culture.url: culture/Hi Izuru Tokoro no Tenshi (Emperor of the Land of the Rising Sun).html
culture.desc: Hi Izuru Tokoro no Tenshi (Emperor of the Land of the Rising Sun) is Japanese manga (cartoon or comics), written by Ryoko YAMAGISHI.

culture.name: Mizukiri
culture.desc: Mizukiri

culture.name: Fashion
culture.desc: Fashion (described as fashion in English, mode in French) refers to the style of clothes, hairstyle, the manner of make-up or outfits.

culture.name: Coming-of-Age Day
culture.desc: Coming-of-Age Day is a national holiday in Japan.

culture.name: National Foundation Day
culture.desc: National Foundation Day is a national holiday in Japan.

culture.name: Autumnal Equinox Day
culture.desc: The Autumnal Equinox Day is the day when the autumnal equinox occurs.

culture.name: The Vernal Equinox Day
culture.desc: The vernal equinox (the spring equinox) is the day when the vernal equinox occurs.

culture.name: Kimariji (a term used for Hyakunin Isshu play cards)
culture.url: culture/Kimariji (a term used for Hyakunin Isshu play cards).html
culture.desc: Kimariji is a term used for Hyakunin Isshu play cards (a game based on a famous poetry anthology, One Hundred Poems by One Hundred Poets); when a card of the first half of a poem is read out, players compete to take a matching card of the last half, and Kimariji means the first several letters of poems with which players can be sure which card to take.

culture.name: Jinrikisha
culture.desc: Jinrikisha (or rickshaw) is a human-powered vehicle for transporting people, used as a means of getting around mainly from the Meiji period to the Taisho and early Showa periods.

culture.name: Kawara (tile)
culture.desc: A tile named Kawara is a material mainly used to cover roofs with.

culture.name: Chankonabe (Weight-gaining stew for sumo)
culture.desc: Chankonabe is a hot pot dish eaten mainly by professional sumo wrestlers and professional wrestlers in Japan.

culture.name: Meshi (cooked rice, meal)
culture.desc: Meshi (meshi, ii, han, manma) is a food that is steamed or boiled until no water is left by adding water to rice, wheat or grains from gramineous plants.

culture.name: SHIGEMORI Koen
culture.desc: Koen SHIGEMORI (July 27, 1926 - October 13, 1992) was a photography critic.

culture.name: Manju (Bun stuffed with filling)
culture.desc: Manju is a cake steamed with fillings such as azuki-bean paste wrapped in the cake dough which flour is kneaded into.

culture.name: Bunmeiron no gairyaku (An Outline of a Theory of Civilization)
culture.url: culture/Bunmeiron no gairyaku (An Outline of a Theory of Civilization).html
culture.desc: Bunmeiron no gairyaku (An Outline of a Theory of Civilization) is a book written by Yukichi FUKUZAWA.

culture.name: The Japanese plum (Ume)
culture.desc: Japanese plum (technical name: Prunus Mume) refers to a deciduous tall tree of Rosaceae Prunusor or its fruits.

culture.name: Hanamichi (literally, flower path)
culture.desc: Hanamichi is the extension area of the stage which runs through the audience in theaters which hold performances such as kabuki.

culture.name: A street vendor's stall
culture.desc: A street vendor's stall (Yatai in Japanese) is a simple mobile store.

culture.name: Yukaku (red-light district)
culture.desc: Yukaku was a block enclosed with walls and moats where licensed prostitute houses were concentrated.

culture.name: Shinnen Enkai (New Year's Banquet)
culture.desc: Shinnen Enkai is a holiday which used to be celebrated before the World War II.

culture.name: Okage Mairi (a pilgrimage to the Ise-jingu Shrine)
culture.url: culture/Okage Mairi (a pilgrimage to the Ise-jingu Shrine).html
culture.desc: Okage mairi refers to mass pilgrimages to the Ise-jingu Shrine, made in the Edo period.

culture.name: Sarayashiki (The Haunted Plate House)
culture.desc: Sarayashiki is a general term for Kaidan telling (Ghost Stories telling) famous for a woman's ghost named Okiku counting plates.

culture.name: Tokuhon/Yomihon
culture.desc: Tokuhon are textbooks for language learning and/or introductory books intended for the wide public.

culture.name: Nanso Satomi Hakkenden (The Chronicles of the Eight Dog Heroes of the Satomi Clan of Nanso)
culture.url: culture/Nanso Satomi Hakkenden (The Chronicles of the Eight Dog Heroes of the Satomi Clan of Nanso).html
culture.desc: Nanso Satomi Hakkenden is Yomihon (copy for reading) written by Bakin KYOKUTEI (Bakin TAKIZAWA) during the late Edo period.

culture.name: Senbei (rice cracker)
culture.desc: Senbei (煎餅) is a kind of food made from flour.

culture.name: Bunraku (Japanese puppet theater)
culture.desc: "Bunraku" originally referred to playhouses especially for performing ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater).

culture.name: Yurei (Ghosts)
culture.desc: In Japanese folk belief, yurei are faintly visible figures who have remained in Utsushiyo (the land of the living) even after their soul left their body after death, in order to resolve some form of lingering attachment or to seek revenge for a wrong.

culture.name: Kadensho
culture.desc: Kadensho is a type of written record on noh play.

culture.name: Daruma (Daruma Doll)
culture.desc: A daruma is a doll or toy representing the sitting figure of Bodhidharma, the founder of the Zen, a sect of Buddhism, who is practicing Zen meditation; at the present time, it is widely popular as a lucky charm not only in the Zen sect, but also in different religious sects, across religions.

culture.name: Danjiri (decorative portable shrine, float used in festivals)
culture.url: culture/Danjiri (decorative portable shrine, float used in festivals).html
culture.desc: Danjiri is a type of dashi (float) or danjiri used at shrine festivals.

culture.name: Komehyappyo (a hundred straw rice bags)
culture.desc: Komehyappyo (a hundred straw rice bags) is a historical episode regarding the education by Torasaburo KOBAYASHI, a vassal of Nagaoka Domain Echigo Province, who was active from the end of Edo period through until the early Meiji period.

culture.name: Equestrianism
culture.desc: Equestrianism (called 'bajutsu' in Japan) refers to recreational activities and competitive sports and a system of technique of riding or driving horses and aiming at accuracy, activity, beauty, and so on.

culture.name: Kyo-shikki (Kyoto lacquerware)
culture.desc: "Kyo-shikki" is a handicraft of lacquerware produced in Kyoto City.

culture.name: Japanese-style Painter
culture.desc: Japanese-style painter is a term used as an antonym to Western-style painter as Japanese paintings separated into Western-style and Japanese-style after the Meiji period.

culture.name: Bunshichi's Mottoi
culture.desc: Bunshichi Mottoi was created by Encho Sanyutei, and is one of human-interest stories among rakugo (traditional comic story telling).

culture.name: Scabbard (saya)
culture.desc: A scabbard is a sheath for the blade of an edged tool.

culture.name: Oyama or Onnagata (Actor of female roles)
culture.url: culture/Oyama or Onnagata (Actor of female roles).html
culture.desc: Oyama or Onnagata refers to the actor who acts the role of a young woman, the duty of the actor, or the pattern of acting itself, in Kabuki.

culture.name: Yosegi zaiku (mosaic woodwork)
culture.desc: Yosegi zaiku is a traditional craft often seen at souvenir shops in the town of Hakone as well as in countries overseas.

culture.name: Botamochi
culture.desc: Botamochi is a Japanese traditional sweet and generally refers to a small mochi shaped like a stick ('mochi' is a rice cake; in this case, it is made from steamed rice and steamed glutinous rice, and the both are not completely pounded nor baked) with an (a sweet red paste made from red azuki beans).

culture.name: Cormorant
culture.desc: Cormorants (Phalacrocoracidae) are waterfowls forming the family Phalacrocoracidae of the order Pelecaniformes.

culture.name: Rice-polishing ratio
culture.desc: The rice-policing ratio ia specified in the National Tax Administration Agency's Notification No. 8 'Standard that regulates the method of manufacturing and quality labeling of refined sake' dated November 22, 1989 as follows:

culture.name: Japanese leek (edible plant, Allium bakeri, Allium chinese)
culture.url: culture/Japanese leek (edible plant, Allium bakeri, Allium chinese).html
