culture.desc: Japanese leek (scientific name: Allium chinese syn. Allium bakeri) is herbaceous perennial as well as a vegetable which belongs to liliaceae (or alliaceae).

culture.name: Important Arts
culture.desc: An important art object is a tangible cultural property so accredited by the Japanese government (the Minister of Education) under the former "Law relating to the reservation of important fine arts" with the main purpose of preventing outflow of antiques to outside Japan, prior to the enactment of the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties.

culture.name: Sobagaki (Boiled buckwheat-flour dumpling)
culture.desc: Sobagaki is a dish made from buckwheat-flour, and one characteristic of the sobagaki is that a ball of dough, not a noodle, is made by mixing buckwheat-flour with boiled water or heating a mixture of buckwheat-flour and water and then quickly stirring the mixture into gruel with tools such as chopsticks.

culture.name: Mata kokoni Kabuki no Hanadashi
culture.desc: "Mata kokoni Kabuki no Hanadashi" is a song of Kiyomoto bushi (Theatrical music).

culture.name: Sanbai Zojo Seishu
culture.desc: Sanbai zojo seishu (sanzoshu for short, sake swelled by adding distilled alcohol, sugars, acidulants, monosodium glutamate, etc.) is a common name of zojoshu, a kind of sake which was introduced at the time of rice shortage after World War II.

culture.name: Kinpira (Burdock roots cooked in soy sauce and sugar)
culture.url: culture/Kinpira (Burdock roots cooked in soy sauce and sugar).html
culture.desc: Kinpira is one of Japanese side dishes.

culture.name: Tekkamaki (tuna sushi roll)
culture.desc: Tekkamaki is a kind of sushi (maki-zushi [sushi roll]).

culture.name: 賛 San
culture.desc: For '賛 san' mainly the following two things can be cited:.

culture.name: Genji Chakuryu (direct descendant of the Minamoto clan)
culture.url: culture/Genji Chakuryu (direct descendant of the Minamoto clan).html
culture.desc: Genji Chakuryu means the direct descendant of Genji (the Minamoto clan).

culture.name: Takana (Leaf mustard)
culture.desc: Takana (scientific name: Brassica juncea var. integlifolia) is a biennial grass belonging to brassica family, and a variety of Brassica juncea.

culture.name: Bettarazuke (Radish pickled in salt and rice bran with rice malt and sugar)
culture.url: culture/Bettarazuke (Radish pickled in salt and rice bran with rice malt and sugar).html
culture.desc: Bettarazuke is a kind of pickled daikon (Japanese radish).

culture.name: Gigaku (Japanese silent dancedrama in which performers wear masks)
culture.url: culture/Gigaku (Japanese silent dancedrama in which performers wear masks).html
culture.desc: "Gigaku" is one of the traditional theatrical performance in Japan.

culture.name: MATSUI Yukan
culture.desc: Yukan MATSUI was a civil officer in the Azuchi-Momoyama period (the period of warring states in Japan).

culture.name: Netsuke (miniature carving attached to the end of a cord hanging from a pouch)
culture.url: culture/Netsuke (miniature carving attached to the end of a cord hanging from a pouch).html
culture.desc: Netsuke (also called "nezuke") is an attachment used in the Edo period when people carried tobacco pouches, yatate (brush holder), inro (a tiny box which contains medicine or one's seal and a small red ink pad) and leather bags (pouches for accessories including money, foods, writing utensils, medicines and tobaccos) by suspending from the obi sash by a cord.

culture.name: Tokaidochu Hizakurige (Foot Travelers along the Tokai-do Road)
culture.url: culture/Tokaidochu Hizakurige (Foot Travelers along the Tokai-do Road).html
culture.desc: Tokaidochu Hizakurige is a book of comical stories by Ikku JUPPENSHA, with their first printings taking place between 1802 to 1814.

culture.name: Gigaku-men Mask
culture.desc: Gigaku-men mask is a mask used for gigaku (an ancient pantomime in which performers wear masks).

culture.name: Kagemusha (The Shadow Warrior) (movie)
culture.desc: "Kagemusha" (The Shadow Warrior) is a 1980 Japanese film directed by Akira KUROSAWA.

culture.name: Tourism in Japan
culture.desc: The history of tourism in Japan is discussed in this section.

culture.name: Gas Light
culture.desc: A gas light is illumination produced by burning a gaseous fuel.

culture.name: Japanese cats
culture.desc: Japanese cats (nihon neko) are cats native to Japan which have long enjoyed the companionship with the Japanese.

culture.name: Doburoku (unrefined sake)
culture.desc: Doburoku (Dakushu) is a kind of sake produced by adding yeasts remaining in malted rice, sake lee and the like and other ingredients to steamed rice.

culture.name: Ranteijo
culture.desc: The Ranteijo is the work of calligraphy written by Wang Xi-Zhi and the most famous in the calligraphy world.

culture.name: A list of kabuki ie no gei (specialty pieces of kabuki schools)
culture.url: culture/A list of kabuki ie no gei (specialty pieces of kabuki schools).html
culture.desc: Kabuki ie no gei is a program list that is especially selected by the influential members of kabuki actors as the specialty pieces of their kabuki schools.

culture.name: Kabuki Juhachiban (18 best plays of the Ichikawa family of kabuki actors)
culture.url: culture/Kabuki Juhachiban (18 best plays of the Ichikawa family of kabuki actors).html
culture.desc: Kabuki Juhachiban refers to performances selected by Danjuro ICHIKAWA (the seventh), that are specialties of his kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) school.

culture.name: Suppon (a stage setting through which an actor or actress appears from the trap cellar onto the stage)
culture.url: culture/Suppon (a stage setting through which an actor or actress appears from the trap cellar onto the stag.html
culture.desc: Suppon is a stage setting for an actor to make a stage appearance from the trap cellar, and it is located on the hanamichi (an elevated runway) in kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) theater.

culture.name: Kiseru (Tobacco Pipe with Metal Tipped Stem)
culture.url: culture/Kiseru (Tobacco Pipe with Metal Tipped Stem).html
culture.desc: Kiseru is one of Japanese smoking tools and similar to a Western pipe (tobacco).

culture.name: Kusuguri (tickling)
culture.desc: Kusuguri (tickling) is to give 'tickling' sensation by stimulating skin surface and 'make someone laugh.'

culture.name: Shin Kabuki Juhachi Ban
culture.desc: Shin Kabuki Juhachi Ban refers to the specialty plays of Danjuro ICHIKAWA of Naritaya selected by Danjuro ICHIKAWA the seventh and Danjuro ICHIKAWA the ninth.

culture.name: Kyoka Gikyoku Jusshu
culture.desc: Kyoka Gikyoku Jusshu refers to the eight specialty plays of Sadanji ICHIKAWA of Takashimaya (kabuki) selected by Sadanji ICHIKAWA the second.

culture.name: Eno Jusshu
culture.desc: Eno Jusshu refers to the specialty plays of Ennosuke ICHIKAWA of Omodakaya selected by Ennosuke the third in 1964.

culture.name: Omodaka Jusshu
culture.desc: Omodaka Jusshu refers to the specialty plays of Ennosuke ICHIKAWA of Omodakaya selected by Ennosuke the third in 1975.

culture.name: Ennosuke Juhachi Ban (18 programs of Ennosuke)
culture.url: culture/Ennosuke Juhachi Ban (18 programs of Ennosuke).html
culture.desc: Ennosuke Juhachi Ban refers to the specialty plays of Ennosuke ICHIKAWA of Omodakaya selected by Ennosuke ICHIKAWA the third in 1988.

culture.name: Kakoshu
culture.desc: Kakoshu refers to twelve programs selected by Uzaemon ICHIMURA the fifteenth for which he had gained a reputation.

culture.name: Shinko Engeki Jusshu
culture.desc: Shinko Engeki Jusshu refers to the specialty plays of Kikugoro ONOE of Otowaya selected by Kikugoro ONOE the fifth and Kikugoro ONOE the sixth.

culture.name: Kataoka Junishu (12 stories of Kataoka)
culture.desc: Kataoka Junishu refers to the specialty plays of Matsushimaya selected by Nizaemon KATAOKA the eleventh.

culture.name: Koga Jusshu
culture.desc: Koga Jusshu refers to the specialty plays of Sojuro SAWAMURA of Kinokuniya (kabuki) selected by Sojuro SAWAMURA the seventh.

culture.name: Braided cord
culture.desc: Braided cord is the traditional Japanese craft, a cord made by interlacing fine silk threads and cotton yarns.

culture.name: Noppe
culture.desc: Noppe is a Japanese local dish.

culture.name: Yodogimi shu
culture.desc: Yodogimi shu refers to the arts handed down from father to son, selected by Utaemon NAKAMURA the fifth.

culture.name: Ganjiro-Junikyoku (12 Ganjiro roles)
culture.desc: Ganjiro-Junikyoku refers to the specialty plays of Ganjiro NAKAMURA of Narikomaya selected by Ganjiro NAKAMURA the first.

culture.name: Shuzan Jusshu
culture.desc: Shuzan Jusshu refers to the specialty plays of Kichiemon NAKAMURA of Harimaya (kabuki) selected by Kichiemon NAKAMURA the first.

culture.name: Habutae Mochi
culture.desc: Habutae Mochi is a traditional sweet of Fukui Prefecture, made from steamed and kneaded rice flour with sugar and starch syrup; it usually takes a long time to make a beautiful translucent paste which becomes a base of the sweet.

culture.name: Uguisu Mochi
culture.desc: Uguisu Mochi is a Japanese traditional sweet made from gyuhi (kneaded rice flour with sugar or starch syrup; by being kneaded for a long time, it becomes a translucent paste) and an (a sweet red paste made from red azuki beans); an is lapped by gyuhi which is shaped like an uguisu (Japanese bush warbler).

culture.name: Dango
culture.desc: Dango is a Japanese traditional sweet and a kind of dumpling made from rice flour (rice flour is kneaded with water or hot water and steamed or boiled to make a dumpling which is called 'mochi'; the mochi is cut into pieces which are shaped like small balls which are called 'dango').

culture.name: Jodai Tokushu Kanazukai (ancient Japanese phonetic orthography)
culture.url: culture/Jodai Tokushu Kanazukai (ancient Japanese phonetic orthography).html
culture.desc: Jodai Tokushu Kanazukai is Japanese phonetic orthography used in ancient Japan (around the Nara period), which can be observed in the documents written in Manyo-gana (Chinese characters used as phonetic characters) such as "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).

culture.name: Nanori (self-introduction), Shimenawa-kiri (sacred rice-straw rope cut), Himatsuri (fire festival)
culture.jp: 名のり・注連縄切り・火祭り
culture.url: culture/Nanori (self-introduction), Shimenawa-kiri (sacred rice-straw rope cut), Himatsuri (fire festival).html
culture.desc: "Nanori, Shimenawa-kiri, Himatsuri" is a series of annual events held from New Year's Eve through New Year's Day in Daio-cho, Shima City, Mie Prefecture.

culture.name: Zosui (porridge of rice and vegetables)
culture.desc: Zosui is made by simmering cooked rice again with meat, fish and shellfish, mushroom and vegetable, seasoned with soy sauce, miso, etc.

culture.name: Kiraibashi
culture.desc: Kiraibashi, also called Imibashi or Kinjibashi, is the banned usage of chopsticks in Japan.

culture.name: Narutomaki
culture.desc: The Narutomaki (written in Japanese character as: 鳴門巻き) is a type of kamaboko, steamed fish paste, made from minced fish and with a spiral pattern in cross section.

culture.name: Sukeroku
culture.desc: "Sukeroku" is a nickname for one of the Kabuki plays.

culture.name: Kumano-fude
culture.desc: The Kumano-fude is a writing brush produced in Kumano-cho, Aki County, Hiroshima Prefecture.

culture.name: Kyoen Kankan (the wood strip on which ancient Chinese characters are written)
culture.url: culture/Kyoen Kankan (the wood strip on which ancient Chinese characters are written).html
culture.desc: Kyoen Kankan is mokkan (a narrow strip of wood on which an official message is written) of the Former Han and the Later Han periods, discovered in the Kyoen Hosui site covering from Ejin Banner of Inner Mongolia, China to the northeastern region of Jiuquan City, Gansu Province, China.

culture.name: Yamada-nishiki
culture.desc: Yamada-nishiki is a variety of rice.

culture.name: Preservation Districts for Groups of Important Historic Buildings
culture.jp: 重要伝統的建造物群保存地区
culture.url: culture/Preservation Districts for Groups of Important Historic Buildings.html
culture.desc: The preservation districts for groups of important historic buildings refer to 'Historic Buildings Preservation Areas' ordained by local authorities under Article 144 of the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties of Japan, of which the state (Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology) selects those which are especially important.

culture.name: Ichimatsu ningyo (Ichimatsu dolls)
culture.desc: Ichimatsu ningyo is a kind of fashion dolls.

culture.name: Toso (the mixture of sawdust of paulownia wood and wheat starch)
culture.url: culture/Toso (the mixture of sawdust of paulownia wood and wheat starch).html
culture.desc: Toso is a kind of clay.

culture.name: Buried cultural property
culture.desc: Buried cultural properties are cultural properties (cultural heritages) that are found under the ground.

culture.name: Rikyu shichitetsu
culture.desc: The term "Rikyu shichitetsu" means the seven leading disciples of Rikyu.

culture.name: Edomae-zushi (a kind of sushi)
culture.desc: Edomae-zushi (江戸前ずし, also written as 江戸前鮨, 江戸前鮓 or江戸前寿司) is haya-zushi (quick sushi), centered on nigiri-zushi (hand-shaped sushi).

culture.name: Shin Kabuki (new kabuki)
culture.desc: Shin Kabuki refers to kabuki plays written by authors independent from theaters after the Meiji period.

culture.name: Ecchu Fundoshi (a Japanese loincloth with strings)
culture.url: culture/Ecchu Fundoshi (a Japanese loincloth with strings).html
culture.desc: Ecchu fundoshi (越中褌) is a kind of fundoshi, a traditional Japanese undergarment for adult males.

culture.name: Michiyuki Tabiji no Hanamuko
culture.desc: Michiyuki Tabiji no Hanamuko is a dance drama ("shosagoto" in Kabuki terms) performed between the fourth act, "Hangan Seppuku" (a judge's suicide by disembowelment), and the fifth act, "Yamazaki Kaido" (Yamazaki-kaido Road), in the Kabuki play "Kanadehon Chushingura" (The Treasury of Loyal Retainers).

culture.name: Rikyu manju
culture.desc: Rikyu manju (利休饅頭) is a Japanese cake served with tea, which was named after chasei (great tea master) SEN no Rikyu.

culture.name: Ichikawa-ryu
culture.desc: Ichikawa-ryu

culture.name: Beni-shoga (Red pickled ginger)
culture.desc: Beni-shoga is a pickles made from pickling groundnuts of ginger in plum vinegar.

culture.name: Matsukaze
culture.desc: "松風" (Matsukaze) literally means the wind blowing against the forest of pine trees.

culture.name: Whale meat
culture.desc: Whale meat is defined as the edible parts of cetaceans and of smaller-sized cetaceans called dolphins, which are used for food.

culture.name: Obake (changing from its proper state, or 'ghost')
culture.url: culture/Obake (changing from its proper state, or ghost).html
culture.desc: "Obake" (お化け) (also "henge") refers to something or someone that/who has changed significantly from its/their proper state.

culture.name: Sekimon Shingaku (popularized blend of Buddhist, Shinto and Confucian ethical teachings)
culture.url: culture/Sekimon Shingaku (popularized blend of Buddhist, Shinto and Confucian ethical teachings).html
culture.desc: Sekimon Shingaku is a school of ethics established by Baigan ISHIDA (1685-1744), a Japanese thinker in the middle of the Edo period.

culture.name: Yabo (unrefined, gauche)
culture.desc: "Yabo"means the unsophisticated condition.

culture.name: Genbunicchi
culture.desc: Genbunicchi (unification of the written and spoken language) refers to the movement in the Meiji period that asserted that writers should write in a style close to the colloquial style Japanese, using everyday expressions instead of the previous literal style Japanese and practiced it, and to the works written in that style.

culture.name: Bankara
culture.desc: Bankara is a pun for the word haikara (westernized appearances or life styles).

culture.name: Selected Intangible Cultural Properties
culture.desc: A selected intangible cultural property refers to intangible cultural property whose expense related to record, preservation and disclosure is partly subsidized by public funds, except important intangible cultural properties.

culture.name: Yashima (Noh play)
culture.desc: Yashima is a Noh play based on Heike Monogatari (The tale of the Heike).

culture.name: Betobeto-san (one of Yokai [Japanese folk monsters])
culture.desc: Betobeto-san is one of Yokai (Japanese folk monsters), and follows a man walking in the dark at night.

culture.name: Funa benkei (Noh play)
culture.desc: Funa benkei (船弁慶: Benkei in the Boat) is a Noh play based on "Heike Monogatari" (The tale of the Heike) and "Azuma Kagami" (The Mirror of the East).

culture.name: Haikara
culture.desc: "Haikkara" is a Japanese word that means airs, persons, and things and so on that suggest westernized appearances and way of life.

culture.name: Ataka
culture.desc: Ataka is a Noh piece covering "Gikeiki" (a military epic about the life of Yoshitsune) and so forth.

culture.name: Sanseki (Three Brush Traces)
culture.desc: "Sanseki"refers to three established calligraphers.

culture.name: Nihon Ikebana Geijutsu Kyokai (Japan Ikebana Association)
culture.jp: 日本いけばな芸術協会
culture.url: culture/Nihon Ikebana Geijutsu Kyokai (Japan Ikebana Association).html
culture.desc: Nihon Ikebana Geijutsu Kyokai is a Japanese foundation intended for the promotion of the art of flower arrangement.

culture.name: Hanjo
culture.desc: "Hanjo" is a Noh play, which is reportedly created by Zeami.

culture.name: Kinuta (Noh)
culture.desc: Kinuta is a Noh play which is said to have been created by Zeami.

culture.name: Yuya (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Yuya" is one of the most representative Noh pieces.

culture.name: Matsukaze (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Matsukaze" is a Noh play (classical Japanese dance theater).

culture.name: Shakkyo (Stone Bridge) (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Shakkyo" is a Noh play (classical Japanese dance theater).

culture.name: Takasago (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Takasago" is a Noh play (classical Japanese dance theater).

culture.name: Narazuke (gourd pickles seasoned in sake lees)
culture.url: culture/Narazuke (gourd pickles seasoned in sake lees).html
culture.desc: Narazuke is a kind of pickles made with vegetables such as gourd, cucumber, watermelon, and ginger first pickled in salt, then in fresh sake lees several times.

culture.name: Kanadehon Chushingura (The Treasury of Loyal Retainers)
culture.url: culture/Kanadehon Chushingura (The Treasury of Loyal Retainers).html
culture.desc: "Kanadehon Chushingura" (written in old character form: 假名手本忠臣藏) is the title of a representative ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater) as well as kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) based on the Genroku Ako Incident.

culture.name: Zeze-yaki Pottery
culture.desc: Zeze-yaki Pottery is a pottery that is produced in Zeze, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

culture.name: Sumida-gawa River (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Sumida-gawa River" is a Noh play (classical Japanese dance theater).

culture.name: Izutsu (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Izutsu" is one of the most representative Noh pieces.

culture.name: Tobishoku
culture.desc: Tobishoku (same as hikiya [a workman who moves a whole building without demolishing] and yarikata [a workman who make a rough design before building]) generally means a workman specializing in working in high places in the construction industry.

culture.name: Eiji Happo (the eight basic techniques)
culture.desc: Eiji Happo (the eight basic techniques) is a term to express that the Chinese character '永(ei)' contains all the 八法 (happo or hachiho, eight techniques) that are required in calligraphy.

culture.name: Dojigiri
culture.desc: Dojigiri is a Japanese sword designated as a national treasure of Japan.

culture.name: Haimyo
culture.desc: Haimyo is originally synonymous with Haigo (the pen name of a haiku poet), but it was used as follows in the field of public entertainment after the mid Edo period:

culture.name: Ci
culture.desc: Ci is a form of Chinese poetry or an art form of ballad.

culture.name: Sankyoku (sanqu in Chinese)
culture.desc: Sankyoku is a kind of music (qu) and a form of poetry in the spoken language and is also literature of songs and ballads.

culture.name: Kayo
culture.desc: Kayo refers to works of a poetry form with a musical nature.

culture.name: Onsen-manju
culture.desc: Onsen-manju reffers to a manju (a bun stuffed with azuki-bean paste) sold in towns and resorts of hot springs.

culture.name: Jinen Koji (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Jinen Koji" (Jinen the Lay Monk) is a Noh piece by Kanami.

culture.name: Tsukkorobashi
culture.desc: Tsukkorobashi is an acting role in a Kabuki play.

culture.name: Gasan (or 画賛: inscriptions associated with paintings)
culture.url: culture/Gasan (or 画賛 inscriptions associated with paintings).html
culture.desc: Gasan

culture.name: Yojinbo
culture.desc: "Yojinbo", which hit the screens in 1961, is a period action movie directed by Akira KUOSAWA,.

culture.name: Kado-ka
culture.desc: A Kado-ka is a person who arranges flowers.

culture.name: Kabuki-mono
culture.desc: Kabuki-mono (かぶき者) is also written as "傾奇者" or "歌舞伎者."

culture.name: Suiba
culture.desc: Suiba was an annual event in the Edo period held by Edo bakufu (a Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in which people rode horses across water.

culture.name: Kasei Culture
culture.desc: Kasei Culture was townsman culture that developed in the late Edo period, mainly between 1804 and 1829.

culture.name: Kagetsu (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Kagetsu" is a yukyomono (musical entertainment piece) Noh play.

culture.name: Kangakai
culture.desc: The Kangakai was a fine art association in the early Meiji period.

culture.name: Oiran
culture.desc: An oiran refers to a high-ranking courtesan in the pleasure quarter of Yoshiwara.

culture.name: Momijigari (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Momijigari" is a Noh piece.

culture.name: Dojo-ji Temple (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Dojo-ji Temple" is a Nogaku piece that is based on the Legend of Anchin and Kiyohime which has been passed down in Dojo-ji Temple, Kishu Province (present day Wakayama Prefecture).

culture.name: Japanese clock
culture.desc: A Japanese clock is a clock made in Japan mainly during the Edo period.

culture.name: Chanbara
culture.desc: Chanbara is a swordplay scene acted in historical dramas of theatrical performances and movies.

culture.name: Mikka gojoho (Three-day rules)
culture.desc: Mikka gojoho or Gojoho mikka is a term used to refer to unwritten rules in kabuki world.

culture.name: Buddhist Paintings
culture.desc: Buddhist paintings are paintings whose subject matter is Buddhism.

culture.name: Uiro uri (The Medicine Peddler)
culture.desc: Uiro uri is one of Kabuki juhachiban (eighteen best plays of the Ichikawa family of kabuki actors).

culture.name: Jidaimono (Historical drama)
culture.desc: Jidaimono

culture.name: Aesthetic Areas
culture.desc: An aesthetic area is an 'Area Designated for Conservation of Scenic Beauty of Cities' (City Planning Act Article 9).

culture.name: Tento (the sun, providence, god)
culture.desc: Tento is the sun god in Japan.

culture.name: Yohanasake Ukinano Yokogushi
culture.desc: "Yohanasake Ukinano Yokogushi" is one of the Sewamono (play dealing with the lives of ordinary people) masterpieces of Kabuki.

culture.name: Goshu-no-nikki (The technical book on sake brewing)
culture.url: culture/Goshu-no-nikki (The technical book on sake brewing).html
culture.desc: Goshu-no-nikki is the first technical book on sake brewing in existence in Japan that was handed down in the Satake clan.

culture.name: Licensed brewer
culture.desc: Licensed brewer is someone who passed the written and practical tests about sake brewing which is a kind of skill assessment system of nationally-accredited qualification conducted by prefectural governors (the questions are made up by Japan Vocational Ability Development Association and the administrator is Prefectural Vocational Ability Development Association).

culture.name: Tsujiura
culture.desc: Tsujiura is a kind of fortune-telling seen in Japan.

culture.name: Genroku no Daikoshu
culture.desc: Genroku no Daikoshu is sake which is believed to be prepared in the Genroku era and took off a seal in Mochizuki-machi, Kitasaku County, Nagano Prefecture in 1968.

culture.name: Kamameshi (cooked rice in an iron pot)
culture.url: culture/Kamameshi (cooked rice in an iron pot).html
culture.desc: Kamameshi is a rice dish cooked in an individual pot, seasoned with soy sauce and mirin (sweet sake) with ingredients such as shiitake mushrooms and chicken on top.

culture.name: Aotozoshi hanano nishikie
culture.desc: "Aotozoshi hanano nishikie" refers to 'Shiranami-mono' (stage works with thieves and lowlifes) of Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) which was performed at Ichimura-za Theater in 1862 for the first time, and written by Shinshichi KAWATAKE the second (later Mokuami KAWATAKE).

culture.name: Kurogo
culture.desc: Kurogo

culture.name: Nara-ryu (Nara style sake making)
culture.desc: Nara-ryu is one of the styles of Japanese sake-brewing.

culture.name: Sempuku
culture.desc: Sempuku is a sake brand produced by MIYAKEHONTEN, a sake brewer in Kure City, Hiroshima Prefecture.

culture.name: Kyogi Karuta
culture.desc: Kyogi Karuta is a game using the karuta (Japanese card game) of Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred poems by one hundred poets) and played by the rule established by All-Japan Karuta Association.

culture.name: Domoshuzoki (a technical book on sake brewing)
culture.url: culture/Domoshuzoki (a technical book on sake brewing).html
culture.desc: Domoshuzoki is a representative technical book on sake brewing in Japan, which was written in the early Edo period.

culture.name: Sanshamairi
culture.desc: Sanshamairi is to visit three Shinto shrines.

culture.name: Shoka (Subject)
culture.desc: Shoka (music) is one of the subjects in the former ordinary and higher elementary schools.

culture.name: Kamigata Bunka (Kamigata Culture)
culture.desc: Kamigata Bunka is a culture cultivated in Kamigata centered in Osaka and Kyoto.

culture.name: Gando gaeshi
culture.desc: Gando gaeshi (to pivot one large piece of scenery onto its side so as to reveal a different one) is a stage term used in Kabuki and means one of 'Idokoro-gawari' (place change) methods for scene changes or a device which uses Gando-gaeshi.

culture.name: Itahi
culture.desc: Itahi (board monument) is a kind of sekihi (stone monument) mainly used as a memorial tower.

culture.name: Ama (Noh play)
culture.desc: Ama ('海人' otherwise written as '海士') is a Noh play (classical Japanese dance theater).

culture.name: Tomikuji (lottery in the Edo period)
culture.desc: Tomikuji also called Tomitsuki is a way to collect fund for mutual aids and a kind of lottery that is said to be the origin of takarakuji and also a gamble.

culture.name: Meijin and Queen
culture.desc: Meijin' and 'Queen' refer to Kyogi Karuta (karuta [Japanese card game] match) in which karuta of Hyakunin Isshu (one hundred waka poems by one hundred poets) are used and they played by the rule of All-Japan Karuta Association; for male players the Meijin-sen (literally, 'master tournament') is held, and for female players the Queen-sen is held; they also refer to the titles given to the champions; male player has to pass the preliminary of the Meijin-sen and beat the champion of the previous year, and female player has to pass the preliminary of the Queen-sen and beat the champion of the previous year as well, and the champions become 'Meijin' and 'Queen.'

culture.name: Shibaraku
culture.desc: "Shibaraku" is a program of Kabuki and is one of the Kabuki juhachiban (eighteen best plays of the Ichikawa family of Kabuki actors).

culture.name: Eight Views of Lake Biwa
culture.desc: Eight Views of Lake Biwa is a special selection of eight views around Lake Biwa.

culture.name: Tachiyaku
culture.desc: Tachiyaku means the role in Kabuki (traditional performing act) of a normal adult male, and it also stands for the actor who plays the role.

culture.name: Kakinoha-zushi (persimmon leaf sushi)
culture.desc: Kakinoha-zushi is a local dish of Nara Prefecture, Wakayama Prefecture, and Ishikawa Prefecture.

culture.name: Gari (pickled ginger)
culture.desc: Gari is ginger thinly sliced and pickled in sweetened vinegar.

culture.name: Goma-dofu
culture.desc: Goma-dofu is one of Shojin-ryori (vegetarian diet).

culture.name: Saikan no sanyu (the three friends of winter)
culture.url: culture/Saikan no sanyu (the three friends of winter).html
culture.desc: "Saikan no sanyu" were the popular subjects of bunjinga, the literati paintings that first appeared in the Sung period (China)

culture.name: Tesso
culture.desc: Tesso (iron rat, a huge rat as large as a bull with a stone body and iron teeth) is a specter of the ancient Japan which was connected to a deep-seated grudge of a priest and a rat.

culture.name: Usukawa-manju
culture.desc: Usukawa-manju is cha-manju (steamed yeast bun with filling) smaller than its normal size.

culture.name: Genroku Culture
culture.desc: Genroku culture was a culture that flourished from the end of 17th century to the early 18th century, especially in the Genroku Period (1688-1707), and was centered in mainly Kamigata (Osaka and Kyoto area).

culture.name: Tsumoru Koi Yuki no Seki no To
culture.url: culture/Tsumoru Koi Yuki no Seki no To.html
culture.desc: "Tsumoru Koi Yuki no Seki no To" (The Barrier Gate), often shortened to "Seki no To," is the title of a Tokiwazu-bushi (a style of narrative music to accompany a Kabuki performance) and also the title of the Kabuki play performed to Tokiwazu music.

culture.name: Nozuchi
culture.desc: Nozuchi is a specter that exists in Japan.

culture.name: Ippon-datara
culture.desc: Ippon-datara is a specter of Japan, living in the mountains of Kumano (Wakayama Prefecture) and other areas.

culture.name: Ehon Taikoki (The Illustrated Chronicles of the Regent)
culture.url: culture/Ehon Taikoki (The Illustrated Chronicles of the Regent).html
culture.desc: The Ehon Taikoki is a play of ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater).

culture.name: Shinju Tenno Amishima
culture.desc: "Shinju Tenno Amishima" refers to Joruri (dramatic narrative chanted to a samisen accompaniment) written by Monzaemon CHIKAMATSU.

culture.name: Sugawara Denju Tenarai Kagami
culture.desc: "Sugawara Denju Tenarai Kagami" (Sugawara's Secrets of Calligraphy) (classic word: 傳授) was Gidayu-bushi (musical narrative of the puppet theatre) and a program of ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater) and Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) played along with it.

culture.name: Inji (Slinging techniques)
culture.desc: Inji is a Japanese combat technology that kills and wounds the objects by slinging, or an event.

culture.name: Kangaku (Sinology)
culture.desc: In a narrow sense, "kangaku" refers to traditional keigaku (study of Keisho in Confucianism) and the study of old documents during the period of Qin dynasty as opposed to Neo-Confucianism in the Song and Ming dynasties; in a broad sense, it is a general term for studies of knowledge imported from China, as opposed to Western learning and the study of Japanese classical culture.

culture.name: Bunjinga (literati painting)
culture.desc: "Bunjinga"refers to the paintings that bunjin (literati) painted as their pastime, as opposed to paintings by the professional artists in China (Intaiga, a type of Chinese painting associated with the Imperial Court Academy).

culture.name: Kumadori
culture.desc: Kumadori was the make up method unique to Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) play.

culture.name: Chinzei Yumiharizuki
culture.desc: "Chinzei Yumeharizuki" (The Crescent Moon) was a book written by Bakin KYOKUTEI and illustrated by Hokusai KATSUSHIKA.

culture.name: Classification of Sake in the Liquor Tax Act
culture.url: culture/Classification of Sake in the Liquor Tax Act.html
culture.desc: Classification of Sake in the Liquor Tax Act is a general classification system of sake under the Liquor Tax Act, which long existed in Japan from 1940 to 1992.

culture.name: Sake of low alcohol concentration
culture.desc: Sake of low alcohol concentration is the recently invented sake with the alcohol content of 13 percent or less, normally with around 8 percent alcohol.

culture.name: Chirashizushi
culture.desc: Chirasizushi is a kind of sushi.

culture.name: Multiple parallel fermentation
culture.desc: Multiple parallel fermentation ("並行複発酵") is a type of fermentation that takes place in the sake brewing process, meaning that saccharification (the conversion of starch into glucose by koji enzyme) and fermentation (the conversion of glucose into alcohol by yeast) occur simultaneously in the same container.

culture.name: Vertical type rice-milling machine
culture.desc: A vertical type rice-milling machine was introduced around 1930 and originally used to produce sake.

culture.name: Sake yeast
culture.desc: Sake yeast is the generic term referring to yeasts used for brewing sake (Japanese liquor).

culture.name: Hoba-zushi
culture.desc: Hoba-zushi is a local dish of the south of Hida region (Gifu Prefecture), and of Tono (the eastern Mino region of Gifu), and of Chuno (the middle Mino region of Gifu), and of Kiso region (Nagano Prefecture).

culture.name: Sekkobun
culture.desc: Sekkobun refers to 10 stone monuments, or characters inscribed thereon, made of granite which were excavated in Tien-xing Prefecture in Feng-xiang County in Shan-xi Province in the early Tang period.

culture.name: Yumai-zukuri
culture.desc: Yumai-zukuri is the modern method for brewing sake (rice wine) wherein rice is reduced to a gruel-like consistency to enable saccharification at a high temperature.

culture.name: Baisho-zukuri
culture.desc: Baisho-zukuri is one of the production methods of Japanese sake (rice wine) in the modern days and is one kind of the high-temperature saccharization method.

culture.name: Yasei-kobo
culture.desc: Yasei-kobo (wild yeast) refers to all kinds of yeast which originally live in the nature including the air, the soil, and plants while, in the fermentation process of Japanese sake, refers to all kinds of yeast other than those that are used to obtain the desired sake quality.

culture.name: Happo Nihon-shu
culture.desc: Happo Nihon-shu (sparkling Japanese sake) is sparkling, that is, carbon-dioxide-containing Japanese sake which has attracted attention in recent years.

culture.name: Ushioni
culture.desc: Ushioni (cow demon), or gyuki, is a specter orally handed down in western Japan.

culture.name: Mizore Nabe (Hot Pot Served with Grated Daikon Radish)
culture.url: culture/Mizore Nabe (Hot Pot Served with Grated Daikon Radish).html
culture.desc: Mizore Nabe is a kind of dish cooked in a pot at the table.

culture.name: Asukanabe (hodgepodge from Asuka)
culture.desc: Asukanabe is one of the local dishes of Nara region.

culture.name: Seiryu-buai
culture.desc: Seiryu-buai refers to one of the criteria of determining the state of rice and represents in percentage how many seiryu, that is, rice grains each having an ordered excellent shape are present in a specific amount of unmilled rice.

culture.name: Koon-toka-ho (a high-temperature saccharification method)
culture.desc: Koon-toka-ho is a Japanese sake-making method used today, in which the starch component of polished rice is gelatinized not by being steamed but by being heated at a high temperature, and then is fermented with the rice malt and yeast that is added at the next stage.

culture.name: Haze
culture.desc: Haze is a notion considered to be important in the seigiku process, that is a manufacturing process of sake rice malt, in the brewing process of sake.

culture.name: Mizuage
culture.desc: Mizuage has the following meanings.

culture.name: Kirimodoshi
culture.desc: Kirimodoshi is one of the treatments for prolonging the lives of the cut flowers used in Japanese flower arrangement or in fresh flower business.

culture.name: Fukamizu
culture.desc: Fukamizu is one of the Mizuage (method of prolonging the lives of flowers) in Japanese flower arrangement.

culture.name: Yuage
culture.desc: Yuage is one of the Mizuage (method of prolonging the lives of flowers) methods.

culture.name: Sakamizu (the way to prolong the lives of flowers)
culture.url: culture/Sakamizu (the way to prolong the lives of flowers).html
culture.desc: Sakamizu is one of the methods of mizuage (making a cut flower suck the water).

culture.name: Minazukibarai (Purification in June) (Noh play)
culture.desc: Minazukibarai is a Noh play.

culture.name: The lactic acid for making sake
culture.url: culture/The lactic acid for making sake.html
culture.desc: The lactic acid for making sake is the high-purity lactic acid required in making yeast mash in the process of brewing Japanese sake (rice wine).

culture.name: Ikakeya
culture.desc: Ikakeya indicates the craftsman who does the work of ikake (repairing pots and rice cookers).

culture.name: Mizuko (aborted, stillborn or miscarried fetuses)
culture.desc: "Mizuko" is a term that refers to the following:

culture.name: Japanese Coiffure
culture.desc: The Japanese coiffure by a broad definition refers to the coiffure unique to Japan from the Tumulus Period to the pre-war Showa Period.

culture.name: Ichikawa soke
culture.desc: Ichikawa soke

culture.name: Shuppinshu
culture.desc: Shuppinshu is an alcohol beverage brewed for the purpose of entering the shows or competition.

culture.name: Teiseihakushu (Japanese sake with low rice polishing rate)
culture.url: culture/Teiseihakushu (Japanese sake with low rice polishing rate).html
culture.desc: Teiseihakushu is a kind of Japanese sake developed around 2005.

culture.name: Nara Tokae Festival
culture.desc: Nara Tokae is the annual event that has been held in Nara (mostly in and around Nara Park) in the early August (for ten days) since 1999 using the candles called toka (lantern).

culture.name: Kamo (Noh)
culture.desc: Kamo is one of the Noh works.

culture.name: Ichomage (men's hairstyle)
culture.desc: Ichomage is the most popular men's hairstyle through the Edo period.

culture.name: Kanu (kabuki)
culture.desc: "Kanu" is one of the eighteen best plays of kabuki by the Ichikawa family.

culture.name: Uwanari (jealousy)
culture.desc: Uwanari is one of the eighteen best plays of kabuki by the Ichikawa family.

culture.name: Oshimodoshi (the repeller of demons)
culture.desc: Oshimodoshi is one of the scenes as well as one of "aragoto" (dynamic performance or a role of kabuki, featuring exaggerated posture, makeup, and costume).

culture.name: Zohiki (Pulling the Elephant)
culture.desc: Zohiki (Pulling the Elephant) is a kabuki play.

culture.name: Fudo
culture.desc: "Fudo" is one of the best eighteen Kabuki plays.

culture.name: Aosagibi or Aosaginohi (Blue heron fire)
culture.desc: Aosagibi is defined as a mysterious phenomenon in Japan in which the body of a heron emits a pale blue light mainly at night.

culture.name: Kyukyodo
culture.desc: Kyukyodo is a long-established store of stationary products and incense.

culture.name: Hondamage (men's hairstyle)
culture.desc: Hondamage is a male hairstyle that was popular among Suijin (men of refined tastes) during the Edo period.

culture.name: Kokei
culture.desc: Kokei (high chignon) was hair style for noblewomen in Nara period.

culture.name: Raiden (Noh)
culture.desc: Raiden (written in two Chinese characters meaning thunderbolt) is one of noh-gaku (noh and kyogen) works.

culture.name: Tatsumi Geisha (professional female entertainers)
culture.desc: Tatsumi Geisha refers to professional female entertainers, who were particularly popular in Fukagawa in Edo (present-day Fukagawa, Tokyo) around the Edo period.

culture.name: Chigomage (hair-style for kids)
culture.desc: Chigomage (also pronounced "chigowage") is a form of hair which was worn by boys from the Heian period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period, and also the similar hairstyle for girls which dates from the Edo period.

culture.name: Shidarezakura (a weeping cherry tree)
culture.desc: Shidarezakura is a variety of Edohiganzakura.

culture.name: Yoshitsune Senbonzakura (Yoshitsune and One Thousand Cherry Trees)
culture.url: culture/Yoshitsune Senbonzakura (Yoshitsune and One Thousand Cherry Trees).html
culture.desc: Yoshitsune Senbonzakura is a program of ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater) or Kabuki of Gidayu-bushi (musical narrative of the puppet theatre) or performed along with Gidayu-bushi.

culture.name: Warikanoko (a kind of traditional hair styles of females which were popular in the Edo period)
culture.url: culture/Warikanoko (a kind of traditional hair styles of females which were popular in the Edo period).html
culture.desc: Warikanoko was a hairstyle widely worn by women from their late teens to early twenties in the late Edo period.

culture.name: Marumage (rounded hair style of a married woman)
culture.url: culture/Marumage (rounded hair style of a married woman).html
culture.desc: Marumage is the most representative hairstyle (Japanese coiffure) for married women from the Edo period to the Meiji period.

culture.name: Important Intangible Folk Cultural Property
culture.desc: Important Intangible Folk Cultural Property refers to intangible folk culture which people have created in their daily lives and passed on to subsequent generations, such as manners and customs, folk performing arts, occupations, religious faiths, folk techniques related to clothing, food and housing, and festivals, and which have been designated as especially important by the national government.

culture.name: Fukiwa
culture.desc: Fukiwa is a mage (chignon) which was tied on the head of Himegimi (daughter of a person of high rank) of a samurai since the early Edo period.

culture.name: Kamiyui (Hairdresser)
culture.desc: Kamiyui is a general term referring those who were engaged in hairdressing from the Edo period to the Meiji period, who are now called hairdressers.

culture.name: Sumida-gawa Gonichi no Omokage
culture.desc: "Sumida-gawa Gonichi no Omokage" is one of the kabuki kyogen play written by Shimesuke NAGAWA.

culture.name: Ukontaku (an black engraved print as a feather)
culture.url: culture/Ukontaku (an black engraved print as a feather).html
culture.desc: Ukontaku (also called Ukintaku) refers to a engraved print which is as black as a crow feather.

culture.name: Senyokoutaku (an thin engraved print as a cicada wing)
culture.url: culture/Senyokoutaku (an thin engraved print as a cicada wing).html
culture.desc: Senyokutaku refers to a light-colored engraved print like a cicada wing, or a technique of such rubbing.

culture.name: Zoi (conferral of a posthumous rank)
culture.desc: Zoi

culture.name: Narukami (The rolling God)
culture.desc: Narukami is one of the kabuki plays.

culture.name: Yamato-cha
culture.desc: Yamato-cha green tea is a kind of Japanese tea produced in an area centering Yamato Plateau in Nara Prefecture.

culture.name: Kingyozake
culture.desc: Kingyozake is a familiar name of sake which is so weak that a kingyo (goldfish) can swim in it.

culture.name: Kyakushiki
culture.desc: Kyakushiki refers to laws and ordinances which were passed in complement to the Ritsuryo codes, or law codes which were the collections of those codes.

culture.name: Genroku chushingura
culture.desc: Genroku chushingura is a program of Kabuki, and is a Shin-kabuki (new Kabuki) written by Seika MAYAMA.

culture.name: Throne of Blood
culture.desc: "Throne of Blood" is a film released in 1957 by Toho.

culture.name: Akudaikan (cruel bailiff)
culture.desc: Akudaikan is an emblematic expression of the bailiffs who oppressed people of the domain or committed a fraud.

culture.name: Inoko mochi (a rice cake imitating a little wild boar)
culture.url: culture/Inoko mochi (a rice cake imitating a little wild boar).html
culture.desc: Inoko mochi' is a rice cake cooked on inoko (the day of boar).

culture.name: Registered tangible folk cultural properties
culture.desc: Registered tangible folk cultural properties are registered on the cultural property registry ledger by the Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology.

culture.name: Selected intangible properties of folk culture
culture.url: culture/Selected intangible properties of folk culture.html
culture.desc: Selected intangible properties of folk culture refers to an intangible cultural property (except important intangible folk cultural properties), which is allowed to receive financial aid at public cost to cover a part of the expense to record, preserve, and exhibit.

culture.name: SEN Soshitsu
culture.desc: Soshitsu SEN is the name of the head of Urasenke which is one of the tea schools.

culture.name: Chonmage (a topknot)
culture.desc: Chonmage is a topknot tied by old men in the Edo period.

culture.name: Jijojo (Calligraphy works written by Kaiso from Tang, China)
culture.url: culture/Jijojo (Calligraphy works written by Kaiso from Tang, China).html
culture.desc: Jijojo is the works of calligraphy written by Kaiso, a calligrapher in the period of the Tang Dynasty.

culture.name: Omigyu (beef cattle grown in Shiga prefecture)
culture.url: culture/Omigyu (beef cattle grown in Shiga prefecture).html
culture.desc: Omigyu is wagyu (Japanese beef) grown in Shiga Prefecture.

culture.name: Five-and-seven Syllable Meter
culture.desc: Five-and-seven syllable meter is a form of poem in which words of Goon (five syllables) and Shichion (seven syllables) repeat one after another.

culture.name: Seven-and-five Syllable Meter
culture.desc: Save-and-five syllable meter is a form of poem in which words of Shichion (seven syllables) and Goon (five syllables) repeat one after another.

culture.name: Ko (incense)
culture.desc: "Ko" originally referred to fragrances of natural aromatic trees such as eaglewood, agalloch, and sandalwood.

culture.name: Jika (Market Price)
culture.desc: Jika means market price as an economic term ->see "Market Price"

culture.name: Atsusa Samusa mo Higan made (Neither heat nor cold lasts beyond higan (two periods of seven days with the middle day falling on the spring or autumn equinox))
culture.url: culture/Atsusa Samusa mo Higan made (Neither heat nor cold lasts beyond higan (two periods of seven days wit.html
culture.desc: "Atsusa Samusa mo Higan made" is a Japanese idiom that means 'The cold of winter lasts until the spring equinox, and the heat of summer calms by the autumnal equinox, and will become easier to bear."

culture.name: Oni
culture.desc: Oni was a system of conferring a rank above a certain court rank to the descendants of high officials, according to the court ranks those high officials, the descendants' forefathers, had under the system of the Ritsuryo codes in Japan.

culture.name: Kusunokiryu Hanami no Makuhari
culture.desc: "Kusunokiryu Hanami no Makuhari" is a program of Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors).

culture.name: Yukeibunkazai (tangible cultural properties)
culture.desc: Tangible Cultural Properties are as follows.

culture.name: Kosode Soga Azami no Ironui
culture.desc: "Kosode Soga Azami no Ironui" is a program of Kabuki (traditional performing act).

culture.name: Kuzumochi (kudzu starch cake)
culture.desc: "Kuzumochi" are Japanese cakes made of kuzuko (kudzu starch).

culture.name: Jinku
culture.desc: Jinku is a form of traditional Japanese songs.

culture.name: Hinowan (Hino Lacquered Bowl)
culture.desc: Hinowan refers to lacquered bowls produced in and around Hino-cho, Gamo-gun, Shiga Prefecture.

culture.name: Kami no Megumi Wago no Torikumi
culture.url: culture/Kami no Megumi Wago no Torikumi.html
culture.desc: Kami no Megumi Wago no Torikumi is the title of a Kabuki play.

culture.name: Danmari (a term for kabuki)
culture.desc: Danmari (暗闘) is a piece of choreography in Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors).

culture.name: Suitengu Megumi no Fukagawa
culture.desc: Suitengu Megumi no Fukagawa is a program of the Kabuki play.

culture.name: Zangirimono (cropped-hair plays)
culture.desc: The term "Zangirimono" (cropped-hair plays) refers to kabuki kyogen plays (plays [programs] presented in Kabuki [traditional drama performed by male actors]) which are classified into Sewamono (plays dealing with the lives of ordinary people) and reflect the folkways after the Meiji Restoration.

culture.name: Kamikakete sango taisetsu (a kabuki kyogen play)
culture.url: culture/Kamikakete sango taisetsu (a kabuki kyogen play).html
culture.desc: Kamikakete sango taisetsu was a kabuki kyogen play written by Nanboku TSURUYA (the fourth)

culture.name: Sushi restaurant
culture.desc: Sushi restaurant is also called sushisho or sushiten and is a restaurant which serves Japanese food sushi.

culture.name: Hachiman Matsuri Yomiyano Nigiwai (a kabuki play)
culture.url: culture/Hachiman Matsuri Yomiyano Nigiwai (a kabuki play).html
culture.desc: "Hachiman matsuri yomiyano nigiwai" is a kabuki play.

culture.name: Okurisuzume
culture.desc: The okurisuzume (sparrow that sends off) is a specter handed down in Wakayama Prefecture and Higashi-yoshino Village, Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture.

culture.name: Jigokumon (Gate of Hell)
culture.desc: "Jigokumon" is a Japanese film made in 1953.

culture.name: Showa-modern (昭和モダン)
culture.desc: Showa-modern is a term referring to a modern civil culture that flourished in the early Showa period merging Japanese and Western styles.

culture.name: Magemono (bentwood work)
culture.desc: "Magemono"or "wagemono" is a container made by bending a shaved lumber of Japanese cypress or Japanese cedar, and by sewing its joint with the bark of birch or Japanese cherry.

culture.name: Akago (yokai)
culture.desc: "Akago" is yokai (specter) who is said to live in Nagano Prefecture and Yamato Province (present-day Nara Prefecture).

culture.name: Share
culture.desc: Share' describes the way in which someone/something is refined and tasteful.

culture.name: Shiratama (rice-flour dumplings)
culture.desc: "Shiratama" is dumplings made from rice flour called shiratamako.

culture.name: Miyakokoryu
culture.desc: Miyakokoryu is a style of ikebana (flower arrangement, or kado) which was created by Kuhyodo Hitoami ISOGAI in November 1902.

culture.name: Rakugo (Japanese Traditional Comic Storytelling, or the Comic Story Itself)
culture.url: culture/Rakugo (Japanese Traditional Comic Storytelling, or the Comic Story Itself).html
culture.desc: Rakugo is a traditional Japanese narrative art handed down through the generations that was established in early modern times.

culture.name: Danjiri-bayashi (music performed in festivals)
culture.desc: Danjiri-bayashi is festival music which is played to accompany the drawing danjiri (decorative portable shrines; floats used in festivals), and in the region centered on the northern part of Osaka City which does not possess danjiri for some reasons it refers to the 'hetari' style which is festival music played by itself on a stage, turret and also a boat for funatogyo (a ritual to place divine spirits on boat, to cross a river).

culture.name: Dragon lantern (ryuto).
culture.desc: Dragon lantern (ryuto) refers to a fire of mysterious or suspicious origin, passed down across Japan.

culture.name: Janjanbi (fire of mysterious)
culture.desc: "Janjanbi" is a fire of mysterious or suspicious origin which comes down in various regions of Nara Prefecture.

culture.name: Sotoba Komachi (卒都婆小町)
culture.desc: Sotoba Komachi is a Noh play.

culture.name: Fu-Rin-Ka-Zan (the movie)
culture.desc: "Fu-Rin-Ka-Zan" (as fast as the wind, as quiet as the forest, as daring as fire, and as immovable as the mountain) is a Jidaigeki-eiga (the period movie) which was released on March 1, 1969.

culture.name: Saigyo-zakura (Saigyo's Cherry Blossoms)
culture.desc: Saigyo-zakura is a Noh play written by Zeami.

culture.name: Onzoshi
culture.desc: Onzoshi

culture.name: Togaki (stage direction)
culture.desc: The term "Togaki" refers to a stage direction which is distinguished from dialogues spoken by actors and actresses in a play, script, etc.

culture.name: Kinoko (literally a child of tree) (Yokai [supernatural beings])
culture.url: culture/Kinoko (literally a child of tree) (Yokai [supernatural beings]).html
culture.desc: Kinoko is a Yokai whose presence has been told in the Kinki area.

culture.name: Kasuga Wakamiya Onmatsuri (Kasuga Shrine Festival)
culture.desc: Kasuga Wakamiya Onmatsuri is a festival held at Sesha Wakamiya shrine (a subordinate shrine) of Kasuga-taisha Shrine in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

culture.name: Kajin
culture.desc: Kajin is the name which professionals such as 'flower arrangement experts,' 'Ikebana artists,' 'flower artists' and 'flower designers' prefer to call themselves in public.

culture.name: Matoi
culture.desc: Matoi were used by fire brigades in the Edo Period, and it expressed their own "kumi" (brigade).

culture.name: Onnagoroshi Abura no Jigoku
culture.desc: "Onnagoroshi Abura no Jigoku" is a play created by Monzaemon CHIKAMATSU, and has been performed at ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater).

culture.name: Wayo secchu
culture.desc: Wayo secchu' refers to the way in which Japanese style and Western style are blended together.

culture.name: Goso (direct petition)
culture.desc: "Goso" refers to an act of petition in a firm attitude.

culture.name: Shigure (a shower of rain in late autumn and early winter).
culture.url: culture/Shigure (a shower of rain in late autumn and early winter)..html
culture.desc: Shigure refers to rain or snow which falls and stops temporarily mainly from autumn to winter.

culture.name: Yoshimura school (of dance)
culture.desc: Yoshimura school refers to Kamigata mai (dance from the pleasure quarters of Osaka and Kyoto, and are very reserved and refined) originated by Fuji YOSHIMURA during the early Meiji period.

culture.name: KANZE Motomasa
culture.desc: Motomasa KANZE (1930-1990) was a shite actor (a principal actor) of the Kanze school of Noh.

culture.name: KONDO Kennosuke
culture.desc: Kennosuke KONDO (April 18, 1928-) is a shite-kata (a main actor) of the Hosho school of Noh.

culture.name: KONGO Hisanori
culture.desc: Hisanori KONGO (June 24, 1951 -) is a shite-kata (a main actor) of the Kongo school of Noh.

culture.name: SHIOTSU Akio
culture.desc: Akio SHIOTSU (January 22, 1945 -) is a shite-kata (a main actor) of the Kita school of Noh.

culture.name: Inugui (eating like a dog)
culture.desc: Inugui refers that 'people eat like a dog' in Japanese food culture and means that people move their faces (mouths) closer to the meal on the table in an extreme stooped position, and eat them as if they put their heads into the food.

culture.name: Kurimanju (A steamed yeast bun with filling and Japanese chestnut)
culture.url: culture/Kurimanju (A steamed yeast bun with filling and Japanese chestnut).html
culture.desc: Kurimanju, one of traditional Japanese confectioneries, is a type of manju (a bun stuffed with azuki-bean paste).

culture.name: Hojo Kudai Meika no Isaoshi
culture.desc: Hojo Kudai Meika no Isaoshi is the title of kabuki kyogen play.

culture.name: Kyuso
culture.desc: Kyuso is a specter in Japan which has the form of a mouse and is said to have lived for hundreds and thousands of years by undergoing transformation.

culture.name: Kinukatsugi (cooked satoimo taro potatoes)
culture.desc: Kinukatsugi is a dish which small satoimo taro potatoes are steamed with their skins on and eaten by pealing their skins.

culture.name: Oshiroibaba
culture.desc: Oshiroibaba (also called "Oshiroibabaa") or "Oshiroi Basan" is a specter in the form of an old woman according a legend told in the basin of Totsu-kawa River, Yoshino-gun, Nara Prefecture.

culture.name: Tamamushi-no-Zushi
culture.desc: Tamamushi-no-Zushi is a piece of furniture for storing a Buddha statue.

culture.name: Taisho Roman
culture.desc: Taisho Roman (often described in the Chinese character '大正浪漫') refers to a trend of thought or cultural events that conveys the atmosphere of the Taisho period.

culture.name: Dangiku jiji・Kikukichi jiji
culture.desc: Dangiku jiji and Kikukichi jiji are slang or jargon used among Kabuki fans.

culture.name: Matsu-ura no Taiko (The drum in Matsura)
culture.url: culture/Matsu-ura no Taiko (The drum in Matsura).html
culture.desc: "Matsu-ura no Taiko" (The drum of Matsu-ura) a play of kabuki.

culture.name: Gagoze (specter)
culture.desc: Gagoze (also called "Gagoji" or "Guwagoze"), or an ogre at Gango-ji Temple, is a specter which is said to have appeared at Gango-ji Temple in Nara Prefecture during the Asuka period.

culture.name: Kazarimusubi (Decorative Knots)
culture.desc: Kazarimusubi is as follows.

culture.name: Heike nyogo no shima (The Heike and the Island of Women)
culture.url: culture/Heike nyogo no shima (The Heike and the Island of Women).html
culture.desc: "Heike nyogo no shima" (The Heike and the Island of Women) is ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater) created by Monzaemon CHIKAMATSU.

culture.name: Furiuri (Peddling or Peddler)
culture.desc: Furiuri

culture.name: Intangible cultural properties
culture.desc: The term "intangible cultural properties"

culture.name: Monuments
culture.desc: Monuments

culture.name: Amezaiku (candy fashioned in human and animal forms)
culture.url: culture/Amezaiku (candy fashioned in human and animal forms).html
culture.desc: Amezaiku refers to one of the techniques of confectionery production and making of shaped forms by using candy-paste which is made from heating sugar, or the shaped forms.

culture.name: Teratsutsuki
culture.desc: Teratsutsuki is an ominous bird which is a specter described in "Konjaku Gazu Zoku Hyakki" (Continued Illustrations of the Many Demons Past and Present), a collection of specters' illustrations by Sekien TORIYAMA, and which looks like a peckerwood.

culture.name: Genjo (Noh play)
culture.desc: Genjo (written as 絃上, also called "Kenjo") is a Noh play program.

culture.name: Shoso (public repository)
culture.desc: Shoso is an repository for grain and property, and is placed in the public facilities, such as central and regional kanga (government office) and temples in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

culture.name: Miwa Somen (thin noodles made in Miwa)
culture.url: culture/Miwa Somen (thin noodles made in Miwa).html
culture.desc: Miwa Somen is a somen (Japanese fine noodles) produced in Miwa area centering around Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture, and it is a local special product of the area.

culture.name: Hikae yagura
culture.desc: Hikae yagura is Zamoto (leaders of theatrical companies) which took over the performance rights and ran the theaters on behalf of the playhouses (Hon yagura [the three licensed theaters, Edo Sanza]) authorized by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) because the playhouses could not give any performance due to financial woes etc. in the Edo period.

culture.name: Nagi
culture.desc: Nagi is the Japanese word that indicates the state of flat and stable condition and it is also an archaic word.

culture.name: Kotobuki Soga no Taimen
culture.desc: Kotobuki Soga no Taimen (Soga Brother's Confrontation with the Enemy) (Chinese characters in orthographic style: 壽曾我對面) is a program of the Kabuki Kyogen (comic drama) theater.

culture.name: Kosamebo
culture.desc: Kosamebo is a specter handed down in Japan and looks like a figure of a Buddhist priest.

culture.name: Tsukigase Bairin (Plum-grove Park)
culture.desc: Tsukigase Bairin refers to the plum grove located at Mt. Tsukigaseoyama and its surrounding areas (former Tsukigase Village, Soekami County) in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

culture.name: Nagara-gawa ukai
culture.desc: Nagara-gawa ukai is ukai (cormorant fishing) that is conducted in Nagara-gawa River in Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture during the period from May 11 to October 15 every year.

culture.name: Adoption of Western Clothing
culture.desc: The adoption of western clothing refers to when people other than westerners stop wearing indigenous clothing on a day-to-day basis and instead begin wearing Western clothing.

culture.name: Kado Enshu school
culture.desc: Kado Enshu school is a school of ikebana (Japanese traditional flower arrangement) that originated independently from sado (tea ceremony) Eenshu school.

culture.name: Folk-cultural properties
culture.desc: Folk-cultural properties refer to material folk-culture with a particularly high value which require preservation measures, or measures or rules for such preservation are expected to be effective.

culture.name: Itoin
culture.desc: Itoin is a copper seal made in China in Ming Dynasty and brought into Japan over the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and the Momoyama period.

culture.name: Aioi jishi
culture.desc: Aioi jishi is one of nagauta (long epic songs) of Kabuki theater.

culture.name: Sanmon Gosan-no-kiri
culture.desc: "Sanmon Gosan-no-kiri" is the gedai (title) of a kabuki that was written by Gohei NAMIKI (the first) and first performed at Kado-za Theatre of Osaka in April, 1778.

culture.name: Sangaku
culture.desc: "Sangaku" means mathematical puzzles or solutions described on wooden tablets or set in frames, which were dedicated to Shinto shrines or temples during the Edo Period in Japan.

culture.name: Kugeaku (a noble villain in Kabuki)
culture.desc: Kugeaku is a role in Kabuki, representing a noble (Kuge) of high rank who plots to usurp the imperial throne.

culture.name: Imose-yama Onna Teikin (Proper Upbringing of a Young Lady at Mount Imose)
culture.url: culture/Imose-yama Onna Teikin (Proper Upbringing of a Young Lady at Mount Imose).html
culture.desc: "Imose-yama Onna Teikin" (Proper Upbringing of a Young Lady at Mount Imose) is a play of Ningyo Joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater) and Kabuki.

culture.name: Ukai in the Kiso-gawa River
culture.desc: Kiso-gawa ukai(木曽川うかい)is the name of cormorant fishing carried out in the Kiso-gawa River in Inuyama City, Aichi Prefecture every year from May 11 to October 15, except for August 10.

culture.name: Toki wa Ima Kikyo no Hataage
culture.url: culture/Toki wa Ima Kikyo no Hataage.html
culture.desc: "Toki wa Ima Kikyo no Hataage" is the title of a Kabuki play.

culture.name: Oze ukai
culture.desc: Oze ukai is ukai (cormorant fishing) that is conducted in Nagara-gawa river at Oze, Seki City, Gifu Prefecture during the period from May 11 to October 15 every year.

culture.name: Hanabishi
culture.desc: Hanabishi is a type of hanabishi-mon (a crest that represents the head of the Takeda family and the military governor of Kai Province) which is used as a family crest in Japan.

culture.name: Kokindenju no Tachi.
culture.desc: Kokindenju no Tachi refers to Japanese sword made by Hirasaku YUKI, sword craftsman in Bungo Province.

culture.name: Traditional Craftsman
culture.desc: The Traditional Craftsman is the accreditation examination conducted by the Traditional Crafts Industry Promotion Association Foundation in accordance with Paragraph 8 of Section 24 of the Act concerning the Promotion of Traditional Craft Industries.

culture.name: Inseki
culture.desc: Inseki refers to books in general on tenkoku (engraving letters on the material of a seal).

culture.name: Kyoto Cultural Exhibition
culture.desc: Kyoto Cultural Exhibition is an exhibition which is held in Kyoto.

culture.name: Kiwametsuki BANZUI Chobei
culture.desc: Kiwametsuki BANZUI Chobei refers to a play of Kabuki.

culture.name: Nimame
culture.desc: Nimame (boiled beans) is a type of dish that is prepared by rehydrating soybeans, azuki, or other dried beans and then boiling them with sugar until they are tender.

culture.name: Ketto! Takadanobaba
culture.desc: Ketto! Takadanobaba (Duel! Takadanobaba) is a Japanese kabuki play written and directed by Koki MITANI.

culture.name: Shiranami-mono (a Kabuki Play)
culture.desc: Shiranami-mono is the name of a kabuki play.

culture.name: Tenmonkata
culture.desc: Tenmonkata was a scientific research institution established by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

culture.name: Tojinuta
culture.desc: Tojinuta is a category of popular song during the Edo period and the Meiji era.

culture.name: Godaimon (The five major family crests in Japan)
culture.url: culture/Godaimon (The five major family crests in Japan).html
culture.desc: Godaion refers to the five family crest designs that are especially widely used throughout Japan, and they are fuji (wisteria), kiri (paulownia), takanoha (feathers of hawks), mokko (cross-section of a gourd), and katabami (yellow sorrel).

culture.name: Atariburumai (Full-house Feasting)
culture.desc: Atariburumai was a feast to celebrate a full house production.

culture.name: Atsumori (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Atsumori" is the title of a Noh program, which belongs to the category of nibanme-mono (second-category play) and the subcategory of Kindachi mono (play featuring a courtier).

culture.name: Kaomise
culture.desc: Kaomise refers to the first kabuki performance played by new actors following an annul renewal of actors.

culture.name: Seiobo (Noh play)
culture.desc: "Seiobo" is a Noh play (classical Japanese dance theater).

culture.name: Miyakodori nagare no shiranami
culture.desc: "Miyakodori nagare no shiranami" is the title of a kabuki kyogen play which is commonly known as "Shinobu no Sota" (Sota who avoids being seen).

culture.name: Bunshi-Geki
culture.desc: The bunshi-geki is an amateur drama performed mainly by literary people such as writers and journalists.

culture.name: Kanei-bunka (Kanei culture)
culture.desc: Kanei-bunka means the culture that prospered during the first half of the 17th century (the early Edo period), namely the culture sandwiched between Momoyama-bunka of the latter half of the 16th century and Genroku-bunka of the latter half of the 17th century.

culture.name: Kiri Hitoha (a single paulownia leaf)
culture.desc: Kiri Hitoha (a single paulownia leaf) is a glance Shoyo TSUBOUCHI's Kabuki program.

culture.name: Kuchikami-sake (mouth chewed sake)
culture.desc: Kuchikami-sake means sake that is produced through the process of chewing grain, such as rice, or seed in the mouth, spitting it out and leaving it as it is.

culture.name: Imayo Satsuma Uta.
culture.desc: Imayo Satsuma Uta is a Kabuki play written by Onitaro OKA.

culture.name: Tsutamomiji Utsunoya-toge (literaly, Painted maples in the Utsunoya-toge pass)
culture.url: culture/Tsutamomiji Utsunoya-toge (literaly, Painted maples in the Utsunoya-toge pass).html
culture.desc: Tsutamomiji Utsunoya-toge (literaly, Painted maples in Utsunoya-toge pass) is a Kabuki play.

culture.name: Sunakake-babaa (The Sand-throwing Hag)
culture.desc: "Sunakake-babaa" is a specter said to inhabit Nara Prefecture and Hyogo Prefecture.

culture.name: Ehon Gappo ga Tsuji
culture.desc: "Ehon Gappo ga Tsuji" (A Picture Book of the Crossroads of Gappo) is a Kabuki Kyogen play written by Nanboku TSURUYA the fourth.

culture.name: Urajimai
culture.desc: Urajimai is a Japanese custom of conducting traditional ceremonies and handling the aftermath of accidents at sea.

culture.name: Uzuka
culture.desc: Uzuka is a monument located in Gifu City, Gifu Prefecture that was constructed for the repose of cormorants of Nagara-gawa ukai (cormorant fishing in Nagara-gawa River).

culture.name: Tekka
culture.desc: Tekka is the sate of red hot iron or sparks generated during forging.

culture.name: Townscape preservation
culture.desc: Townscape preservation refers to activities intended to renew distinctive characteristics and attractiveness of towns and to improve living conditions of the residents by preserving townscapes that retain traditional architecture and so on.

culture.name: Sannin Kichisa Kuruwa no Hatsugai (a title of Japanese Kabuki)
culture.url: culture/Sannin Kichisa Kuruwa no Hatsugai (a title of Japanese Kabuki).html
culture.desc: Sannin Kichisa Kuruwa no Hatsugai is a Kabuki program in the late Edo period written by Mokuami KAWATAKE.

culture.name: Complete Fermentation
culture.desc: Complete fermentation is one of the important notions in producing Japanese sake, and means that, in parallel multi-fermentation, yeast has almost completed decomposing sugar in Japanese sake moromi (raw unrefined sake), resulting in getting weak by itself and terminating fermentation activity, or that the yeast has thus far completed fermentation by itself.

culture.name: Natural Fermentation
culture.desc: The natural fermentation is one of notions in Japanese sake production and means that, without artificial or non-artificial inhibition of simultaneous plural fermentation, the power which original sake yeast has by itself is fully utilized to complete fermentation without any inhibition.

culture.name: Himeii Method
culture.desc: Himeii method is one of modern Japanese sake production methods and a kind of high-temperature saccharification method.

culture.name: Nippon (Newspaper)
culture.desc: The "Nippon" was a newspaper first published by Katsunan KUGA on February 11, 1889.

culture.name: Awa Manju
culture.desc: "Awa-manju" is a local sweet of Yanaizu Town, Kawanuma County, Fukushima Prefecture.

culture.name: Dainihon Enkaiyochi Zenzu (a map of Japan)
culture.url: culture/Dainihon Enkaiyochi Zenzu (a map of Japan).html
culture.desc: Dainihon Enkaiyochi Zenzu is a surveyed map of the whole of Japan drawn by Tadataka INO, a geographical surveyor in the late Edo period.

culture.name: Nezumi komon haruno shingata
culture.desc: Nezumi komon haruno shingata is a program of Kabuki.

culture.name: Byakue Costumes (for pilgrimage)
culture.desc: Byakue costumes are white jackets worn when people make pilgrimage of sacred ground.

culture.name: Toji Union
culture.desc: The toji union is a union organized by toji (sake brewers) who are professionals of sake production.

culture.name: Chiyogami (Japanese paper with colored figures)
culture.desc: "Chiyogami" is square sheets of Japanese paper with crests or patterns used for a traditional play in Japan called "origami" (paper folding), making costumes of paper dolls, or covering handicraft or presentation box for decoration purpose.

culture.name: Muramai System
culture.desc: The muramai system refers to a sake rice dealing system which is concluded between sake rice production areas in Harima region and specific Kuramoto (sake brewer) including Nada gogo (five districts in Nada).

culture.name: Misozuke (pickling in miso (fermented soybean paste))
culture.desc: Misozuke is vegetable, meat, or fish pickled in miso paste (bean paste).

culture.name: Ryori Monogatari (a tale of food)
culture.desc: Ryori Monogatari is a food book written in the Edo period.

culture.name: Hanawachigai
culture.desc: Hanawachigai is a type of wachigai-mon (emblem with geometric design), which is a Japanese family crest.

culture.name: Mokkatsuji-ban (wood movable-type printing)
culture.desc: Mokkatsuji-ban is the generic term for wood movable-type prints; however, it is sometimes narrowly interpreted as printed books of wood movable-type printing published from the mid Edo to the early Meiji periods (Kinsei [the early modern times] Mokkatsuji-ban).

culture.name: Kasuzuke (pickling fish or vegetables in sake lees)
culture.url: culture/Kasuzuke (pickling fish or vegetables in sake lees).html
culture.desc: Kasuzuke is to pickle food in sake lees or sweet sake lees.

culture.name: Natsumatsuri Naniwa-kagami (Naniwa's mirror in a summer festival)
culture.url: culture/Natsumatsuri Naniwa-kagami (Naniwas mirror in a summer festival).html
culture.desc: Natsumatsuri Naniwa-kagami is the title of ningyo joruri (puppet drama) and kabuki kyogen (comic drama).

culture.name: Jimonkoryu
culture.desc: Jimonkoryu is a monthly magazine of Japan.

culture.name: Yamato-yasai (Yamato Vegetables)
culture.desc: "Yamato-yasai" collectively refers to locally produced vegetables that have been recognized by the Nara Prefectural governament (old Yamato Province), consisting of 17 types of local produce called 'Yamato no dento yasai' (traditional vegetables of Yamato) and four types called 'Yamato no Kodawari yasai' (particular vegetables of Yamato) which are grown with particular technique.

culture.name: Traditional vegetables
culture.desc: Traditional vegetables are vegetables of native varieties that have been cultivated in various places since the ancient times.

culture.name: Nara Chameshi
culture.desc: Nara chameshi is a kind of takikomi gohan (rice boiled with seasonal ingredients) and a local cuisine in various regions of Nara Prefecture.

culture.name: Shika senbei (deer crackers)
culture.desc: Shika senbei are sold in Nara Park, Nara City, to tourists for them to feed the deer that roam free in and around the park.

culture.name: Kogeki hasshu (eight old dramas)
culture.desc: Kogeki hasshu is a family's specialty (iegei) of Danzo ICHIKAWA, Mikawaya (Kabuki), that Danzo ICHIKAWA VI had picked out.

culture.name: Judgment of Nyobutsu
culture.desc: Judgment of Nyobutsu is a leading case in Kamakura period concerning the life-and-death judgment in the rules of Igo (board game of capturing territory), admitting a kasho (tentative life) in double ko.

culture.name: Mekuranagaya Umegakagatobi
culture.desc: "Mekuranagaya Umegakagatobi" is a play of Kabuki (traditional performing art).

culture.name: Yama-arashi
culture.desc: Yama-arashi is a Japanese Yokai (specter) introduced in books such as a Yokai picture book, "Hyakki Yagyo Emaki" (picture scroll of a hundred specters strolling at night) by Yoshi ODA.

culture.name: Meiboku Sendai Hagi (The Disputed Succession of the Date Family)
culture.url: culture/Meiboku Sendai Hagi (The Disputed Succession of the Date Family).html
culture.desc: "Meiboku Sendai Hagi" (The Disputed Succession of the Date Family) is a play for Ningyo Joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater) and Kabuki, based on Date Sodo (the Date family disturbance).

culture.name: Yomei Tenno Shokunin Kagami (The Mirror of Craftsmen of the Emperor Yomei)
culture.url: culture/Yomei Tenno Shokunin Kagami (The Mirror of Craftsmen of the Emperor Yomei).html
culture.desc: Yomei Tenno Shokunin Kagami (The Mirror of Craftsmen of the Emperor Yomei) is a play written by Monzaemon CHIKAMATSU for Bunraku (Japanese puppet theater).

culture.name: Wadagassen Onna Maizuru
culture.desc: Wadagassen Onna Maizuru (Wada Battle and Woman Flying-Crane) is a Kabuki play, but originally a ningyojoruri.

culture.name: Middle Japanese
culture.desc: Middle Japanese is a stage in the development of the Japanese language located between Early Middle Japanese and Early Modern Japanese.

culture.name: Soshi Arai Komachi (Komachi Washing the Manuscript)
culture.url: culture/Soshi Arai Komachi (Komachi Washing the Manuscript).html
culture.desc: 草子洗小町' (Soshi arai Komachi; aka. 草紙洗 [Soshi Arai] or 草紙洗小町 [Soshi arai Komachi]) is a Noh program categorized into sanbanme-mono (third-category plays), genzai kazura-mono (realistic women plays) and daishomono (plays with three instruments of fue [a Japanese flute], kozutsumi and ozutsumi [small and large hand drums]).

culture.name: Tsuru Kame (Crane and Tortoise)
culture.desc: "Tsuru Kame" is a program of Noh, traditional masked dance-drama.

culture.name: Awa Wasanbonto (Japanese traditional refined sugar)
culture.desc: Awa Wasanbonto is traditionally made Japanese refined sugar particularly produced in Tokushima Prefecture.

culture.name: O-muko
culture.desc: O-muko (written as '大向う' or '大向こう'; literally, 'the welcome other side') comes originally from seats seen from the stage, and at present, it is used as a term referring to the front seats of the third floor of theatres and to the audience at those seats (in present Kabuki-za Theatre of Tokyo, it refers to the seats for b-class tickets and the seats on the highest balcony for a single act).

culture.name: Japanese whisky
culture.jp: ジャパニーズ・ウイスキー
culture.desc: Japanese whisky is the whisky that is produced in Japan.

emperor.name: Emperor Go-Daigo
emperor.desc: Basic Information: Emperor

emperor.name: SHIRAKAWA Emperor
emperor.desc: Personal information of Emperor SHIRAKAWA

emperor.name: Emperor Uda
emperor.desc: Emperor Uda (June 14, 867 - September 8, 931), the fifty-ninth Japanese Emperor, was in power from December 9, 887 to August 8, 897.

emperor.name: Emperor Tenchi (Tenji)
emperor.desc: Emperor Tenchi (Tenji)

emperor.name: Emperor Kammu
emperor.desc: Emperor Kammu (737 - April 3, 806) was the 50th Japanese Emperor.

emperor.name: Daikakuji-to
emperor.desc: Daikakuji-to is a royal ancestry between the late Kamakura Period to the Northern and Southern Courts Period and used to oppose to Jimyoin-to.

emperor.name: Jimyoin-to
emperor.desc: Jimyoin-to was Japanese Imperial Family ancestry between the late Kamakura period and the Southern and Northern Courts period and is a descendant of the eighty-ninth Emperor Go-Fukakusa, whose father was the eighty-eighth Emperor Go-saga.

emperor.name: Emperor Ichijo
emperor.desc: Emperor Ichijo (July 15, 980 - July 25, 1011) was the sixty-sixth Emperor.

emperor.name: Emperor Reigen
emperor.desc: Emperor Reigen (July 9, 1654 - September 24, 1732) was the 112th Emperor, counting from Emperor Jimmu.

emperor.name: Shihohai
emperor.desc: Shihohai is the name of ceremony held at Imperial Palace in the beginning of the year.

emperor.name: Emperor Antoku
emperor.desc: Emperor Antoku (December 22, 1178 - April 25, 1185) was the eighty-first Emperor.

emperor.name: Gyobutsu
emperor.desc: Gyobutsu

emperor.name: Emperor Go-Toba
emperor.desc: Emperor Go-Toba (August 6, 1180 - March 28, 1239) (his reign was August 20, 1183 - January 11, 1198) was the eighty-second Emperor, being in power during the end of the Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

emperor.name: Emperor Sanjo
emperor.desc: Emperor Sanjo (February 5, 976 - June 5, 1017) was the sixty-seventh Emperor.

emperor.name: Arisugawa no miya
emperor.desc: Arisugawa no miya was the name of the Miyake (house of an imperial prince) that existed long ago.

emperor.name: Emperor Ninko
emperor.desc: Emperor Ninko (March 16, 1800 - February 21, 1846) was the 120th Emperor (his reign was from October 31, 1817 to February 21, 1846).

emperor.name: Emperor Saga
emperor.desc: Emperor Saga (October 3, 786 - August 24, 842) was the fifty-second Emperor (his reign lasted from May 8, 809 to May 29, 823).

emperor.name: Emperor Daigo
emperor.desc: Emperor Daigo (February 6, 885 - October 23, 930) was in power during the Heian period.

emperor.name: Emperor Ogimachi
emperor.desc: Emperor Ogimachi (June 18, 1517 - February 6, 1593) was the 106th Emperor (his reign was from November 17, 1557 to December 17, 1586).

emperor.name: Emperor Heizei, Heijo
emperor.desc: Emperor Heizei, Heijo (September 26, 774 - August 5, 824) was the fifty-first Emperor (his reign was from June 8, 806 to May 8, 809).

emperor.name: Emperor Junna
emperor.desc: Emperor Junna (786 - June 7, 840) (his reign was from May 30, 823 to March 22, 833) was the fifty-third Emperor during the early Heian Period.

emperor.name: Emperor Nimmyo
emperor.desc: Emperor Nimmyo (810 - May 6, 850), the fifty-fourth Emperior, reigned from March 30, 833 to May 4, 850 (in the early Heian period).

emperor.name: Emperor Montoku
emperor.desc: Emperor Montoku (827 - October 7, 858), the fifty-fifth Emperor, reigned from May 31, 850 to October 7, 858.

emperor.name: Emperor Seiwa
