emperor.desc: Emperor Chuai (year of birth unknown - March 8, 200) was the fourteenth Emperor of Japan, as recorded in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) (period of reign: February 11, 192 - March 8, 200).

emperor.name: Emperor Yuryaku
emperor.desc: Emperor Yuryaku (January 419 – September 9, 479; reign: December 26, 456 – September 9, 479) was the twenty-first emperor of Japan.

emperor.name: Yamatohime no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Yamatohime no Mikoto is a character in Japanese Mythology.

emperor.name: Oto Tachibana Hime
emperor.desc: Oto Tachibana Hime was the wife of a mythical Japanese prince called Yamatotakeru.

emperor.name: Kinashi no Karu no Miko
emperor.desc: Born as the first prince of the 19th imperial ruler, Emperor Ingyo, Kinashi no karu no miko was the Crown Prince.

emperor.name: Karu no Oiratsume
emperor.desc: Karu no oiratsume was a princess, who was a daughter of the 19th imperial ruler, Emperor Ingyo.

emperor.name: Sotoorihime
emperor.desc: Sotoorihime (or Sotooshihime) is a woman described as exquisitely beautiful in the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Prince Kusakabe
emperor.desc: Prince Kusakabe (662-May 10, 689) was a son of Emperor Temmu and Princess Uno no Sarara (Empress Jito).

emperor.name: TAKEUCHI no Sukune
emperor.desc: TAKEUCHI no Sukune (his name can also be pronounced TAKENOUCHI no -, TAKESHIUCHI no -, 84? - April 367? (old lunar calendar)) was a legendary person recorded in the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), who is said to have served as the Munemachi no Kimi or Oomi (Grand Minister) and advised the government during the early Yamato Dynasty (a period covering the reigns of Emperor Keiko, Emperor Seimu, Emperor Chuai, Emperor Ojin, and Emperor Nintoku).

emperor.name: Onie no Matsuri Festival
emperor.desc: The Onie no matsuri Festival is the first Niiname-sai Festival (ceremonial offering by a emperor of newly-harvested rice to the deities) solemnized by an emperor after his or her Sokui no rei (ceremony of enthronement).

emperor.name: Mihara no Okimi
emperor.desc: Mihara no Okimi (year of birth unknown - August 27, 752) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Amatarashihikokuni Oshihito no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Amatarashihikokuni oshihito no mikoto (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (the royal family), described in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Ozaho no Okimi
emperor.desc: Ozaho no okimi (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Myth.

emperor.name: Okinaga no Sukune no Miko
emperor.desc: Okinaga no sukune no miko (息長宿禰王; year of birth and death unknown; around the second century) was a member of the Imperial family.

emperor.name: Hikoyai no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Hikoyai no mikoto (日子八井命, year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Myth.

emperor.name: Kamuyaimimi no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Kamuyaimimi no mikoto (year of birth unknown; died in May, 578B.C.) was a member of the Imperial family (the royal family), described in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan), etc.

emperor.name: Hikofutsuoshinomakoto no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Hikofutsuoshinomakoto no mikoto (彦太忍信命: year of birth and death unknown) was a member of Imperial family (Royal family), who appears in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Yanushioshiotakeogokoro no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Yanushioshiotakeogokoro no mikoto (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who lived in the period around the third to fourth century.

emperor.name: Inahi no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Inahi no mikoto was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Mythology.

emperor.name: Iwatsukuwake no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Iwatsukuwake no mikoto (磐撞別命: year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who lived during the early Kofun period (tumulus period) according to the historical documents such as the "Kojiki " (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Kamukushi no Miko
emperor.desc: Kamukushi no miko (神櫛王: year of birth and death unknown) was a member of Japanese Imperial family (Royal family), who appears in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Minabe no Himemiko
emperor.desc: Minabe no Himemiko (660 - year of death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Takefurukuma no mikoto
emperor.desc: Takefurukuma no mikoto (武振熊命) was a figure in the Kofun period (tumulus period), whose name was also written as 建振熊命(Takefurukuma no mikoto) and who was also called Naniwanekotakefurukuma (難波根子建振熊).

emperor.name: Sahohime no mikoto
emperor.desc: Empress Sahohime no mikoto (year of birth unknown - November, 25 B.C.) was the first wife of Emperor Suinin (she became Empress on March 29, 28 B.C.), and she is mentioned in the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Sahohiko no miko
emperor.desc: Sahohiko no miko (year of birth unknown - November, 25 B.C.) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who appears in the Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Homutsuwake no mikoto
emperor.desc: Homutsuwake no mikoto (誉津別命: year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Tanbanomichinoushi no mikoto
emperor.desc: Tanbanomichinoushi no mikoto (丹波道主王:year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Soga no ishikawa no sukune
emperor.desc: Soga no ishikawa no sukune, was a Japanese mythological figure, also called Soga no ishikawa, and he was said to be the ancestor of the Soga clan

emperor.name: Toyosukiiribime no mikoto
emperor.desc: Toyosukiiribime no mikoto (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family, who is said to have lived in the Kofun period (tumulus period) according to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Hoshikawa no Wakamiya no miko
emperor.desc: Hoshikawa no Wakamiya no miko (year of birth unknown - 479), was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who is said to have lived in the Kofun period (tumulus period) according to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Aketatsu no o
emperor.desc: Aketatsu no o was a member of the Imperial family, who appeared in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

emperor.name: Tagishimimi no mikoto
emperor.desc: Tagishimimi no mikoto (year of birth unknown - 585 B.C.), was a member of the Imperial family, who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto is a Shinto god.

emperor.name: Itsuse no mikoto
emperor.desc: Itsuse no mikoto was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who appears in the Japanese Mythology.

emperor.name: Mikenu no mikoto
emperor.desc: Mikenu no mikoto was a member of Japanese Imperial family, who is mentioned in the Japanese Mythology.

emperor.name: Inishikiiribiko no mikoto
emperor.desc: Inishikiiribiko no mikoto (五十瓊敷入彦命) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who is said to have been lived in the Kofun period (tumulus period), according to "Kojiki " (The Record of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Hibasuhime no mikoto
emperor.desc: Hibasuhime no mikoto was a member of the Imperial family, who appears in the legend ("Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)).

emperor.name: Michinoomi no mikoto
emperor.desc: Michinoomi no mikoto was a figure who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Saitansai
emperor.desc: Saitansai (a Shinto ritual to mark the beginning of New Year followed by a special sharing of sake (rice wine) in the barrel and a mochi (rice cake) pounding ceremony) is one of the holidays designated by the Koshitsu Saishi Rei (Imperial household religious rites ordinance) as a festal day, which were celebrated before World War II.

emperor.name: Ahiratsuhime
emperor.desc: Ahiratsuhime (吾平津姫) was the wife of Emperor Jinmu.

emperor.name: Amatoyotsuhime no mikoto
emperor.desc: Amatoyotsuhime no mikoto was the Empress of Emperor Itoku, one of the eight emperors living during the Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns).

emperor.name: Yosotarashihime
emperor.desc: Yosotarashihime was the Empress of Emperor Kosho, one of the eight emperors who reigned during the Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns).

emperor.name: Oshihime
emperor.desc: Oshihime was the Empress of Emperor Koan, one of the eight emperors who reigned during the Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns).

emperor.name: Kuwashihime no mikoto
emperor.desc: Kuwashihime no mikoto was the Empress of Emperor Korei, one of the eight emperors who reigned during the Kesshi-Hachidai (Eight Undocumented Sovereigns).

emperor.name: Nunasokonakatsuhime no mikoto
emperor.desc: Nunasokonakatsuhime no mikoto was the Empress of Emperor Annei.

emperor.name: The Empress
emperor.desc: Empress is the wife of the emperor.

emperor.name: Shinno (Imperial Prince)
emperor.desc: Shinno is the title given to the male members in an Imperial family in East Asia, or is somebody who owns the title.

emperor.name: NAKAYAMA Yoshiko
emperor.desc: Yoshiko NAKAYAMA (January 16, 1836 - October 5, 1907) was real mother of the Emperor Meiji.

emperor.name: Kinjo Tenno (the present emperor)
emperor.desc: Kinjo Tenno (the present emperor) is the name indicating the person who is on the throne at the time.

emperor.name: Emperor Shomu
emperor.desc: The Emperor Shomu (701 - June 8, 756, reign: March 7, 724 - August 23, 749) was the 45th Emperor in Nara Period.

emperor.name: Teiki (records of Emperor's family tree)
emperor.desc: Teiki (records of Emperor's family tree)

emperor.name: Empress Suiko
emperor.desc: Prior to her ascending the throne, her name was Nukatabe no Himemiko (Imperial Princess Nukatabe).

emperor.name: Empress Dowager Shoken
emperor.desc: Empress Dowager Shoken (May 9, 1849 – April 9, 1914) was a member of the Japanese Imperial family.

emperor.name: The Empress Teimei
emperor.desc: Empress Teimei (June, 25, 1884 - May 17, 1951) belonged to the Imperial Family of Japan.

emperor.name: The Imperial Family
emperor.desc: The definition of an imperial family depends on the historical timeframe and the country concerned, but in general it refers to the emperor's male family members and their spouses.

emperor.name: Daijo Tenno
emperor.desc: Daijo Tenno (the Retired Emperor) is an honorary title awarded to an Emperor who handed over the Imperial Throne to his successor.

emperor.name: the Emperor Organ Theory
emperor.desc: The Emperor Organ Theory (Tenno kikan setsu) is a theory from the Study of Constitution about Emperor, and it was established under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

emperor.name: Kesshi-Judai (Ten Undocumented Sovereigns)
emperor.desc: Kesshi-Judai refers to the ten Emperors from the twenty-fourth Emperor Ninken to the thirty-third Empress Suiko, who only have their genealogy and not their achievements recorded in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), or to this period of time.

emperor.name: Empire Day (Kigensetsu)
emperor.desc: Empire Day was established as a national holiday on which, according to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), Emperor Jinmu ascended the throne.

emperor.name: Choso
emperor.desc: Choso means reaccession of retired emperors to the throne.

emperor.name: Abdication of the throne
emperor.desc: Abdication of the throne means that a person with the position of a monarch, such as emperor and king, transfers the position to a successor.

emperor.name: Empress Kogyoku.
emperor.desc: Empress Kogyoku (594 - August24, 661) was the thirty-fifth Emperor of Japan (reign: February 19, 642 - July 12, 645).

emperor.name: Emperor Kotoku.
emperor.desc: Emperor Kotoku (596 - November 24, 654) was the thirty-sixth Emperor of Japan (reign: July 12, 645 - November 24, 654).

emperor.name: OK
emperor.desc: OK

emperor.name: Imperial Household Agency
emperor.desc: The Imperial Household Agency (called Kunai-cho in Japanese) is one of the administrative agencies in Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Kitashirakawanomiya Yoshihisa
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Kitashirakawanomiya Yoshihisa (April 1, 1847 - October 28, 1895) was a member of the imperial family and a military man in the army over the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.

emperor.name: Emperor Sushun
emperor.desc: Emperor Sushun (Year of birth unknown - December 12, 592), the thirty-second Japanese Emperor, was in power from September 9, 587 to December 12, 592.

emperor.name: Crown prince
emperor.desc: Kotaishi' (Crown Prince) is the Japanese word used to refer to the prince that is next in line to the imperial throne in Japan.

emperor.name: YANAGIHARA Naruko
emperor.desc: Ms. Naruko YANAGIHARA (June 26, 1859, to October 16, 1943) was a Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank) to the Emperor Meiji.

emperor.name: Emperor Buretsu (Muretsu)
emperor.desc: Emperor Buretsu (489 - January 7, 507) was the twenty-fifth Japanese Emperor (reign: 498 - 507).

emperor.name: Crown princess
emperor.desc: The crown princess is a person who has the position of the wife of a prince.

emperor.name: Jinmu Tenno Sokui Kigen (Imperial era)
emperor.desc: Jinmu Tenno Sokui Kigen (Imperial era) is a Japanese way of counting years, the first year being that of accession of Emperor Jinmu, the first emperor, to the throne.

emperor.name: Kotaigo (Empress Dowager)
emperor.desc: Kotaigo, or empress dowager (pronounced "huang tai hou" in Chinese), is a title held by the widow of a deceased emperor or a term used to refer to such a person.

emperor.name: Emperor Nintoku
emperor.desc: Emperor Nintoku (257-February 7, 399) was the sixteenth Emperor of Japan, who was in the reign from February 14, 313 to February 7, 399.

emperor.name: Emperor Ojin
emperor.desc: Emperor Ojin (January 5, 201-March 31, 310) was the fifteenth Emperor, who was in the reign from February 8, 270 to March 31, 310.

emperor.name: The five kings of Wa
emperor.desc: The five kings of Wa refer to San (讃), Chin (珍), Sai (済), Ko (興) and Bu (武) who paid tribute to the Eastern Jin and Song (Southern Dynasty) in the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties (China) in 5th century and received sakuho (homage by Chinese emperors) as 'King of Wa'.

emperor.name: Hogyo (demise)
emperor.desc: Hogyo refers to the death of emperors, czar, kings, grand empress dowagers, empress dowagers, empresses, and other monarchs euphemistically and respectfully.

emperor.name: Emperor Kobun
emperor.desc: Emperor Kobun (648 - August 24, 672) was the 39th emperor (the period of reign: January 12, 672 -August 24, 672).

emperor.name: Prince Nagaya
emperor.desc: Prince Nagaya (684? - March 20, 729) was a member of the imperial family and Kugyo (high court noble).

emperor.name: Imperial House Act
emperor.desc: Imperial House Act is a law of Japan, institution of which was indirectly obligated by the Constitution of Japan and which establishes the system, composition, and the like of the Imperial family, such as an order of succession of the Imperial Throne.

emperor.name: Emperor Keitai
emperor.desc: Emperor Keitai (450 - March 10, 531), the twenty-sixth Japanese emperor, was in power from March 3, 507 to March 10, 531.

emperor.name: Emperor Konin
emperor.desc: Emperor Konin (November 22, 709 - January 15, 782) was the 49th Emperor who reigned from October 27, 770 to May 4, 781.

emperor.name: Grand Empress Dowager
emperor.desc: Grand empress dowager is an honorific title for the legal wife (Empress) of the late Emperor but one or for the grandmother of the present Emperor.

emperor.name: Empress Koken
emperor.desc: Empress Koken (718 - August 28, 770), the forty-sixth Japanese Emperor, was in power from August 19, 749 to September 7, 758.

emperor.name: Emperor Junnin
emperor.desc: Emperor Junnin (733 - November 10, 765) was the forty seventh emperor of Japan (the period of reign: September 7, 758 - November 6, 764).

emperor.name: Emperor Kinmei
emperor.desc: Emperor Kinmei (509 - May 24, 571) was the 29th emperor of Japan (the reign: December 30, 539 - April 15, 571 [old calendar]).

emperor.name: Emperor Ankan
emperor.desc: Emperor Ankan (466-January 25, 536) was the 27th Emperor (whose reign lasted from March 10, 531 to December 17, 535).

emperor.name: Emperor Senka
emperor.desc: Emperor Senka (467-March 15, 539) was the 28th Emperor (whose reign lasted from January 14, 537 to March 15, 539).

emperor.name: Emperor Bidatsu
emperor.desc: Emperor Bidatsu (538?-September 14, 585) was the 30th Emperor (whose reign lasted from April 30, 572 to September 14, 585).

emperor.name: Emperor Yomei
emperor.desc: Emperor Yomei (circa 540 - May 21, 587) was the thirty-first Emperor (reigned from October 3, 585, to May 21, 587).

emperor.name: Emperor Monmu
emperor.desc: Emperor Monmu (683 - July 18, 707) was the forty-second Emperor (who reigned from September 7, 697, to July 18, 707).

emperor.name: Empress Genmei
emperor.desc: Empress Genmei (also known as Empress Genmyo) (661 – December 29, 721) was the first tenno (emperor) in the Nara period and the forty-third tenno (empress regnant) who reigned from August 18, 707 – October 3, 715).

emperor.name: Empress Gensho
emperor.desc: Empress Gensho (680 – May 22, 748) was the forty-fourth emperor of Japan (empress regnant who reigned from October 3, 715, to March 3, 724), who lived in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Emperor Ninken
emperor.desc: Emperor Ninken (449 – September 9, 498) was the twenty-fourth emperor of Japan (who reigned from February 4, 488, to September 9, 498.)

emperor.name: Emperor Kenzo
emperor.desc: Emperor Kenzo (450 - June 2, 487) was the twenty-third Emperor, described in "Kojiki" (literally, The Record of Ancient Matters), "Nihonshoki" (literally, Chronicles of Japan), and "Harimanokuni Fudoki" (literally, Records of the Culture and Geography of the Harima Province), who reigned from February 1, 485, to June 2, 487.

emperor.name: Emperor Richu
emperor.desc: Emperor Richu (circa 336 - April 29, 405) was the seventeenth Emperor who reigned from March 12, 400, to April 29, 405.

emperor.name: Emperor Hanzei
emperor.desc: Emperor Hanzei (circa 336 - February 12, 410) was the eighteenth Emperor who reigned from February 3, 406, to February 12, 410.

emperor.name: Emperor Ingyo
emperor.desc: Emperor Ingyo (circa 376 - February 8, 453) was the nineteenth Emperor of Japan (reigned from January, 413, to February 8, 453).

emperor.name: Emperor Anko
emperor.desc: Emperor Anko (c. 401 - September 24, 456), who reigned from January 28, 454, to September 24, 456, was the twentieth Emperor.

emperor.name: Emperor Seinei
emperor.desc: Emperor Seinei (c. 444 - February 27, 484), who reigned from February 11, 480, to February 27, 484, was the twenty-second Emperor of Japan.

emperor.name: Kitashirakawanomiya
emperor.desc: Kitashirakawanomiya is a Miyake (family allowed to have the status of Imperial family) which was established by Imperial Prince Satonari, who was the thirteenth prince of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie, in the early Meiji period.

emperor.name: Takedanomiya
emperor.desc: Takedanomiya is a Miyake (family allowed to have the status of Imperial family) created by Takedanomiya Prince Tsunehisa, who was a prince of Imperial Prince Kitashirakawanomiya Yoshihisa, in the late Meiji period.

emperor.name: Kachonomiya
emperor.desc: Kachonomiya is a Miyake (family allowed to have the status of Imperial family) which was established in 1868 by Imperial Prince Kachonomiya Hirotsune, who was the twelfth prince of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie.

emperor.name: Kotofu (the Record of Imperial Lineage)
emperor.desc: Kotofu refers to a register to keep records concerning the statuses of emperors and members of Imperial family.

emperor.name: Taiko-Tenno
emperor.desc: Taiko-Tenno is an appellation of emperor, which is applied during a period from the demise of the Emperor to the grant of Tsuigo (posthumous title).

emperor.name: Emperor Nan
emperor.desc: Emperor Nan (year of birth unknown-January 24, 1459) was an emperor of the Gonan-cho Dynasty.

emperor.name: Chokugo (Imperial Rescript)
emperor.desc: Chokugo means, in principle, the Emperor's verbal expression of his or her intention concerning official matters, and is a type of Shochoku (imperial rescript).

emperor.name: Empress Komyo
emperor.desc: Empress Komyo (701 - July 27, 760) was a person in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Queen (of imperial family)
emperor.desc: A queen (of imperial family) is a female who is in the direct line and in the third or more degree of kinship from the emperor (not in a collateral line, and counted from the emperor who was a direct ancestor) according to the Imperial House Law.

emperor.name: King (of imperial family)
emperor.desc: King (O, miko, or okimi in ancient time) is one of the positions or titles of the Imperial family.

emperor.name: Chugu
emperor.desc: Chugu is one of the names given to wives of Japanese emperors.

emperor.name: Princess Yamanobeno Himemiko
emperor.desc: Princess Yamanobeno Himemiko (663 - October 25, 686) was an imperial princess of Emperor Tenchi.

emperor.name: Ko-zoku Gunjin (the Military from Imperial Family)
emperor.url: emperor/Ko-zoku Gunjin (the Military from Imperial Family).html
emperor.desc: Ko-zoku Gunjin refer to the members of the imperial family who became general officers of the Imperial Japanese Army or Imperial Japanese Navy.

emperor.name: Goyotei (Imperial Villa)
emperor.desc: Goyotei is a villa of imperial family or royalty of Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Princess Inoe
emperor.desc: Imperial Princess Inoe (717 - May 30, 775) was the first Princess of the 45th Emperor Shomu.

emperor.name: Tochi no Himemiko (also pronounced Toichi no Himemiko)
emperor.url: emperor/Tochi no Himemiko (also pronounced Toichi no Himemiko).html
emperor.desc: Tochi no Himemiko (653 [Some say 648] - May 3, 678) was the first Princess of Emperor Tenmu (Mother was Nukata no Okimi) and the lawful wife of Prince Otomo (Otomo no Oji) (Emperor Kobun).

emperor.name: Prince Asaka
emperor.desc: Prince Asaka (728 - March 7, 744) was the second Prince of Emperor Shomu.

emperor.name: Prince Shioyaki (Shioyaki no Okimi)
emperor.desc: Prince Shioyaki (Year of birth unknown - October 21, 764) was a grandchild of Emperor Tenmu and a child of Imperial Prince Niitabe.

emperor.name: FUJIWARA no Otomuro
emperor.desc: FUJIWARA no Otomuro (760 - April 28, 790) was an Empress in the late Nara period.

emperor.name: Giving the title of Imperial Prince
emperor.url: emperor/Giving the title of Imperial Prince.html
emperor.desc: Giving the title of Imperial Prince is to give the title of Imperial Prince or Imperial Princess to the children of the Imperial family.

emperor.name: Amako no Iratsume
emperor.desc: Amako no Iratsume (year of birth and death unknown) was a daughter of MUNAKATA no Kimi Tokuzen, a Gozoku (local ruling family) of Chikushi Munakata-gun County.

emperor.name: Imperial Princess Fuwa
emperor.desc: Imperial Princess Fuwa (around 723 - around 795) was a member of the imperial family in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Jiju (chamberlain)
emperor.desc: The term "chamberlain" refers to a person who serves another person (generally a noble person) to take care of his or her personal affairs, and its Japanese equivalent term "jiju" also represents a chamberlain's service itself in a broad sense.

emperor.name: Prince Takechi (Takechi no Miko)
emperor.desc: Prince Takechi (Takechi no Miko or Takechi no Oji) (c.654 - August 13, 696) lived during the Asuka period of Japan and a son (the oldest son) of Emperor Tenmu.

emperor.name: Kinjo no Mikado (The Reigning Emperor)
emperor.desc: Kinjo no Mikado (the emperor regnant) can also be pronounced as Kinjo-tei.

emperor.name: Agata no Inukai no Hirotoji
emperor.desc: Agata no Inukai no Hirotoji (year of birth unknown - November 8, 762) was the wife of Emperor Shomu.

emperor.name: Prince Motoi (Motoi O)
emperor.desc: Prince Motoi (November 20, 727 - October 24, 728) was the first Prince of Emperor Shomu.

emperor.name: Bansei-Ikkei (Unbroken Imperial line)
emperor.desc: "Bansei-Ikkei" literally means one family line through all ages.

emperor.name: Imperial Princess Kibi
emperor.desc: Imperial Princess Kibi (year of birth unknown - March 20, 729) is the second daughter of Prince Kusakabe and Empress Genmei.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Kawashima
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Kawashima (657 - October 6, 691) was a member of Imperial family in the latter half of the seventh century.

emperor.name: Oshisakano onakatsunohimeno Mikoto
emperor.desc: Oshisakano onakatsunohimeno Mikoto was the Empress of the nineteenth Emperor Ingyo and the mother of the twenty-first Emperor Yuryaku.

emperor.name: Prince Funado (Funado no Okimi)
emperor.desc: Prince Funado (year of birth unknown - July 757) was a member of the Imperial family in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Prince Yamamura (Yamamura-O)
emperor.desc: Prince Yamamura (722 - December 16, 767) was a Kugyo (a high court noble) of the Nara period.

emperor.name: Prince Anahobe (Anahobe no Miko)
emperor.desc: Prince Anahobe (year of birth unknown - July 19, 587) was one of the Imperial family members of the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Rittaishi (Investiture of Crown Prince)
emperor.desc: Rittaishi (the investiture of Crown Prince) is a ceremony prevailed in East Asia to officially designate an heir of Chinese or Japanese Emperor as Crown Prince for prospective enthronement.

emperor.name: The Emperor Akihito
emperor.desc: The Emperor Akihito (December 23, 1933-) is the 125th Emperor in Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Sawara (Sawara Shinno)
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Sawara (750? - November 8, 785) is one of the Imperial family members of the late Nara period.

emperor.name: Sokui no rei (ceremony of the enthronement)
emperor.url: emperor/Sokui no rei (ceremony of the enthronement).html
emperor.desc: Sokui no rei is a ceremony that notifies publicly that the Emperor succeeded the Imperial Throne after the accession.

emperor.name: Minu no Okimi
emperor.desc: Minu no Okimi (year of birth unknown - May, 708) was one of the Imperial family members of the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Furuhito no Oe no Miko
emperor.desc: Furuhito no Oe no Miko (year of birth unknown - October 7, 645) was a member of the Imperial family in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Prince Yamashiro no oe
emperor.desc: Prince Yamashiro no oe (year of birth unknown - December 30, 643) was a member of the Imperial family in the early seventh century according to "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Osabe
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Osabe (761 ? - June 3, 775) was a member of the Imperial family and Crown Prince in the late Nara period.

emperor.name: HIKAMI no Kawatsugu
emperor.desc: HIKAMI no Kawatsugu (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family between the Nara period and the early Heian period.

emperor.name: HIKAMI no Shikeshimaro
emperor.desc: HIKAMI no Shikeshimaro (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Muro no Okimi
emperor.desc: Muro no Okimi (year of birth unknown - 746) was a member of the Imperial Family in Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Niitabe
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Niitabe (year of birth unknown - October 24, 735) was the tenth son of the Emperor Tenmu.

emperor.name: FUJIWARA no Yoshiko
emperor.desc: FUJIWARA no Yoshiko (year of birth unknown - December 18, 807) was the consort of the Emperor Kanmu from the late Nara period to the early Heian period.

emperor.name: FUNYA no Kiyomi
emperor.desc: FUNYA no Kiyomi (693 - October 31, 770) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Nara period (Later demoted from nobility to subject.)

emperor.name: Nihonkoku Kotei (Emperor of Japan)
emperor.desc: Nihonkoku Kotei is one of the titles of the Emperor of Japan that had been used up to early Showa period and was mainly used in diplomatic domain.

emperor.name: Takasaka no Okimi
emperor.desc: Takasaka no Okimi (year of birth unknown - June 6, 683) lived in the Asuka period in Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Kaninnomiya Naohito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Kaninnomiya Naohito (October 7, 1704 - July 3, 1753) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Mino no Okimi
emperor.desc: Mino no Okimi (date of birth and death unknown) lived in the Asuka period in Japan.

emperor.name: Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko
emperor.desc: Oshisaka no Hikohito no Oenomiko (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Takeda no miko (the Imperial Prince Takeda)
emperor.url: emperor/Takeda no miko (the Imperial Prince Takeda).html
emperor.desc: Takeda no miko (date of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Anahobe no hashihito no himemiko
emperor.desc: Anahobe no hashihito no himemiko (year of birth unknown - February 6, 622) was a one of the Imperial Family members during the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Yamabe no Okimi
emperor.desc: Yamabe no Okimi (year of birth unknown - c. July 31, 672) was a person lived in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Miko)
emperor.desc: Prince Hikoimasu (Hikoimasu no Miko [彦坐王]; His date of birth and death are unknown.) first appeared in the "Record of Ancient Matters" and "Chronicles of Japan," as he was a member of an Imperial family (Royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

emperor.name: Hikoushio
emperor.desc: Hikoushio (also pronounced Hikousi no Okimi; date of birth and death unknown) was a member of an Imperial family (royal family) in fifth century.

emperor.name: Ishiwaka no Okimi
emperor.desc: Ishikawa no Okimi (year of birth unknown - April 24, 679), lived in the Asuka period in Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince (Fushiminomiya) Fushimi Sadanaru
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushimi Sadanaru (Fushiminomiya Sadanarushinno) was (June 9, 1858 to February 4, 1923) a Japanese Imperial family and a member of the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA).

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Kachonomiya Hirotsune
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Kachonomiya Hirotsune (April 19, 1851-May 24, 1876) was a member of the Imperial family of Japan and a military man of the Imperial Japanese Navy.

emperor.name: Kobetsu Sekke
emperor.desc: Kobetsu Sekke refers to the Imperial Family or its male descendants who succeeded Sekke (line of regents and advisers) in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Chinu no Okimi
emperor.desc: Chinu no Okimi (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial (royal) Family between the late sixth century and seventh the century in Japan.

emperor.name: Hashihito no Himemiko
emperor.desc: Hashihito no Himemiko (year of birth unknown - March 16, 665) was an Imperial Family member during the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Prince Oi
emperor.desc: Prince Oi (Oi no Kimi or Oi no Miko, his date of birth and death were unknown) first appeared in the Itsubun (unidentified or lost writings) written articles of the 'Joguki' (Record of the Crown Prince) being an Imperial family (Royal family) around the fifth century in Japan

emperor.name: Prince Ohodo
emperor.desc: Prince Ohodo (Ohodo no Okimi; his date of birth and death were unknown) appeared in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the 'Joguki' (Record of the Crown Prince) as an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Prince Kanimeikazuchi (Kanimeikazuchi no Miko)
emperor.desc: Prince Kanimeikazuchi (Kanimeikazuchi no Miko; his date of birth and death are unknown) was a member of an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) appeared in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

emperor.name: Prince Okinaga no Mate
emperor.desc: Prince Okinaga no Mate (Okinaga no Mate no Okimi; his date of birth and death were unknown) was a Japanese Imperial family during the fifth to sixth century.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Kagosaka (Kagosaka no Miko)
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Kagosaka (Kagosaka no Miko; his date of birth is unknown; he died in February, 201) appeared in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) as an Imperial family (royal family) during Kofun period (tumulus period) of Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Oshikuma (Oshikuma no Miko)
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Oshikuma (Oshikuma no Miko; his date of birth was unknown, the date of his death was in March of 201.) first appeared in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) as an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

emperor.name: Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko)
emperor.url: emperor/Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko).html
emperor.desc: Prince Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka (Yamashiro no Otsutsukimawaka no Miko; his date of birth and death are unknown) first appeared in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) as an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

emperor.name: Kado no okimi
emperor.desc: Kado no okimi (c. 669 - December, 705) was the first prince of the Prince Otomo (the Emperor Kobun).

emperor.name: Wakasa no Okimi
emperor.desc: Wakasa no Okimi (year of birth unknown - September 678) was a person who lived during the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Iitoyo no himemiko.
emperor.desc: Iitoyo no himemiko (440? - 484) was one of Imperial family (the royal family) during the end of fifth century, according to "A Record of Ancient Matter" and "Chronicles of Japan."

emperor.name: Osakabe no Miko (Prince Osakabe)
emperor.desc: Prince Osakabe (year of birth unknown - June 2, 705) was a member of the Japanese Imperial Family from Asuka period.

emperor.name: Koseki, a family register of the Imperial Family.
emperor.url: emperor/Koseki, a family register of the Imperial Family..html
emperor.desc: Koseki refers to a family register or eligibility to be a member of the Imperial Family.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie (November 19, 1802 - September 7, 1872) was a member of the Imperial family at the end of Edo Period in Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadayuki
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadayuki (January 1, 1776 - February 12, 1841) was a member of the Imperial family in the Edo Period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniyori
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniyori (December 4, 1733 - October 4, 1802) was a member of the Imperial family in the Edo Period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Yasuhito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Hachijonomiya Yasuhito (June 15, 1643 - November 9, 1665) was a member of the Imperial family in the early Edo period.

emperor.name: Kurikuma no Okimi
emperor.desc: The Kurikuma no Okimi (year of birth unknown - July, 676) was a member of the Japanese Imperial Family in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Ingo
emperor.desc: Ingo means followings.

emperor.name: Takeie no Okimi
emperor.desc: Takeie no Okimi (year of birth and death unknown) was a person from the Asuka period, Japan.

emperor.name: MINAMOTO no Hikaru
emperor.desc: MINAMOTO no Hikaru

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Hachijo-no-miya Osahito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Hachijo-no-miya Osahito (June 18, 1655 - August 16, 1675) was a member of the Japanese imperial family who lived in the early Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushimi-no-miya Sadamochi
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushimi-no-miya Sadamochi (April 9, 1760 - July 20, 1772) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushimi-no-miya Kunitada
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushimi-no-miya Kunitada (January 20, 1732 - June 26, 1759) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Arisugawa-no-miya Yukihito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Arisugawa-no-miya Yukihito (April 9, 1656 – August 20, 1699) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Arisugawa-no-miya Tadahito
emperor.desc: Arisugawa-no-miya Imperial Prince Tadahito (March 6, 1694 – November 7, 1716) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Arisugawa-no-miya Orihito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Arisugawa-no-miya Orihito (August 19, 1754 – April 2, 1820) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Arisugawa-no-miya Tsunahito
emperor.desc: Arisugawa-no-miya Imperial Prince Tsunahito (January 29, 1785 - April 4, 1845) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Kanin-no-miya Haruhito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Kanin-no-miya Haruhito (January 4, 1758 – November 4, 1818) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Kanin-no-miya Naruhito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Kanin-no-miya Naruhito (February 17, 1818 – October 20, 1842) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Tomokuyu or Yunomura
emperor.desc: Tomokuyu or Yunomura was a territory which was given to a part of the Imperial Family in the ancient China and Japan from the Asuka period to the Heian period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Hachijo-no-miya Naohito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Hachijo-no-miya Naohito (December 10, 1671 – September 19, 1689) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the early Edo period.

emperor.name: Saku-no-miya
emperor.desc: Saku-no-miya (August 12, 1689 - June 7, 1692) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the middle of the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Kyogoku-no-miya Kinhito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Kyogoku-no-miya Kinhito (February 18, 1733 – July 14, 1770) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the middle of the Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Katsura-no-miya Takehito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Katsura-no-miya Takehito (July 28, 1810 – July 7, 1811) was a member of the imperial family of Japan who lived in the late Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Katsura-no-miya Misahito
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Katsura-no-miya Misahito (December 11, 1833 – April 20, 1836) was a member of the Japanese Imperial family who lived in the late Edo period.

emperor.name: Ichishihime no Okimi
emperor.desc: Ichishihime no Okimi (year of birth and death unknown) was a person from the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Takata no himemiko (Imperial Princess Takata)
emperor.desc: The Imperial Princess Takata (674 - April 22, 728) was a princess of the Emperor Tenmu.

emperor.name: Ota no himemiko (Imperial Princess Ota)
emperor.desc: The Imperial Princess Ota (year of birth unknown - c. March, 667) was one of the Imperial Family members during the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Izumi no himemiko (Imperial Princess Izumi)
emperor.desc: The Imperial Princess Izumi (year of birth unknown - March 21, 734) was a princess of the Emperor Tenchi (Tenji).

emperor.name: Tennosei (Emperor System) in Japan
emperor.desc: The Tennosei (Imperial Family system) is a state system with the emperor acting as the monarch or titular head.

emperor.name: Imperial Princess Asuka
emperor.desc: The Imperial Prince Asuka (year of birth unknown - April 27, 700) was a princess of the Emperor Tenchi.

emperor.name: KONOE Koreko
emperor.desc: Koreko KONOE (December 6, 1760 – November 6, 1783) was "Nyogo" (a wife or concubine of Emperor) of the Emperor Gomomozono.

emperor.name: Prince Mayowa
emperor.desc: Prince Mayowa (Mayowa no Okimi; born in 450, and died in 456) appeared in Kiki, ("Kojiki" [A Record of Ancient Matter] and the "Nihonshoki" [Chronicles of Japan]) as an Imperial family (royal family) in fifth century in Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuninaga
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuninaga (May 10, 1676 - November 14, 1726) was a member of the Imperial family in the middle of the Edo period.

emperor.name: TACHIBANA no Ooiratsume
emperor.desc: TACHIBANA no Ooiratsume (year of birth and death unknown) was a wife of the Prince Shotoku.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadayuki
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadayuki (July 14, 1632 - June 10, 1694) was a member of the Imperial family during the early Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kunimichi
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kunimichi (1641 - September 1, 1654) was a member of the Imperial family in the early Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushimi-no-miya Kuninari
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushimi-no-miya Kuninari (1615 - January 17, 1654) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the early Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadakiyo
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadakiyo (1596 - August 16, 1654) was a member of the Imperial family in the early Edo period.

emperor.name: Prince Ichinobe no Oshiha
emperor.desc: Prince Ichinobe no Oshiha (Ichinobe no Oshiha no Miko; his birth date is unknown and his death date was in 456) appeared in the Kiki ("Kojiki" [A Record of Ancient Matte]) and "Nihonshoki" [Chronicles of Japan]) and Fudoki (description of regional climate, culture, etc.) as an Imperial family (royal family) in fifth century Japan.

emperor.name: FUJIWARA no Miyako
emperor.desc: FUJIWARA no Miyako (year of birth unknown - August 11, 754) was the first daughter of FUJIWARA no Fuhito.

emperor.name: Princess Tomoko
emperor.desc: Princess Tomoko (March 10, 1738-September 28, 1771) was a member of the Imperial family in the late Edo period, and the lawful wife of Ieharu TOKUGAWA, the tenth Shogun.

emperor.name: Prince (Crown Prince) Uji no Wakiiratsuko
emperor.desc: Prince Uji no Wakiiratsuko [(菟道稚郎子) Uji no Wakiiratsuko; his date birth is unknown and his date of death was in '312.'] appeared in the Kiki ["Kojiki" (A Record of Ancient Matter) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan)] as an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

emperor.name: Sokui (Enthronement)
emperor.desc: The enthronement means an ascension to the throne, succeeding a monarch (emperor or king) who passed away or abdicated the throne.

emperor.name: Suzuka no Okimi
emperor.desc: Suzuka no Okimi (year of birth unknown - October 17, 745) was an Imperial Family member during the Nara period.

emperor.name: The order of the succession to the Imperial Throne
emperor.url: emperor/The order of the succession to the Imperial Throne.html
emperor.desc: The order of the succession to the Imperial Throne means the order in which the Imperial Throne is succeeded to from generation to generation.

emperor.name: Shinnohi (Imperial princess by marriage)
emperor.desc: Shinnohi or Miko-no-mime (imperial princess by marriage) is the title given to a wife of a Shinno (imperial prince) or refers to a person holding such a title.

emperor.name: Ohi (Empress of the Imperial Family)
emperor.desc: Ohi (empress) is the title of the Imperial family standing provided for queens consort of the Imperial family, or herself of such standing.

emperor.name: Miyasundokoro
emperor.desc: Miyasundokoro or Miyasudokoro

emperor.name: Shini
emperor.desc: Shini means a social status and a position.

emperor.name: Kumenomiko (Prince Kume)
emperor.desc: Kumenomiko (year of birth unknown - March 25, 603) was an Imperial Family member during the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Miko (Imperial Prince)
emperor.desc: Miko, also referred to as Oji is the naming of the sons of Kotei or Tenno (emperor).

emperor.name: Himemiko (Imperial Princess)
emperor.desc: Himemiko (also referred to as Ojo or Kojo) is the naming of daughters of Tennoo (emperor).

emperor.name: Junbo
emperor.desc: Junbo means equating a woman who is not the real mother of the emperor with his mother or the title of a woman who is equated with the mother of the emperor.

emperor.name: Princess Yukiko
emperor.desc: Princess Yukiko (November 14, 1680-March 18, 1720) was a member of the Japanese Imperial family in the Edo period.

emperor.name: Prince Fune
emperor.desc: The Prince Fune (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family during the Nara period.

emperor.name: Jun Daijo tenno
emperor.desc: Jun Daijo tenno is the treatment which is equal to that of Daijo tenno (retired emperor).

emperor.name: KONOE Hisako
emperor.desc: Hisako KONOE (April 5, 1702-February 27, 1720) was Nyogo (a wife of Emperor) of the Emperor Nakamikado in the Edo period, who was the real mother of the Emperor Sakuramachi.

emperor.name: Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume
emperor.desc: Princess Kasuga no Oiratsume (Kasuga no Oiratsume no Himemiko) appeared in the Kiki ("Kojiki" [A Record of Ancient Matter] and the "Nihonshoki" [Chronicles of Japan]) as a member of the Imperial family (royal family) in Japan.

emperor.name: Princess Yamatototo Wakaya Hime
emperor.desc: Princess Yamatototo Wakaya Hime (Yamatototo Wakaya Hime no Mikoto; her date of birth and death are unknown) was a princess of the Emperor Korei.

emperor.name: Princess Chichihaya Hime
emperor.desc: Princess Chichihaya Hime (Chichihaya Hime no Mikoto; the date of birth and death unknown) was a princess of the Emperor Korei.

emperor.name: Princess Yamatototo Hime
emperor.desc: Princess Yamatototo Hime (Yamatototo Hime no Mikoto; the dates of her birth and death unknown) was the first princess of the Emperor Kogen.

emperor.name: Princess Mimatsuhime
emperor.desc: Princess Mimatsuhime (Mimatsuhime no Mikoto; the dates of her birth and death are unknown) was a princess of the Emperor Kaika.

emperor.name: Princess Kunikatahime
emperor.desc: Princess Kunikatahime (Kunikatahime no Mikoto; the dates of her birth and death are unknown) was a princess of the Emperor Sujin.

emperor.name: Princess Chichitsuku Yamatohime
emperor.desc: Princess Chichitsuku Yamatohime (Chichitsuku Ymatohime no Mikoto; the dates of her birth and death are unknown) was a princess of the Emperor Suinin.

emperor.name: Princess Numaki iribime
emperor.desc: Princess Numaki iribime (Nunaki iribime no Mikoto; the dates of her birth and death are unknown) was a princess of the Emperor Suinin.

emperor.name: Princess Tochini iribime
emperor.desc: Princess Tochini iribime (Tochini iribime no Mikoto; the dates of her birth and death are unknown) was a princess of the Emperor Suinin.

emperor.name: Prince Oousu
emperor.desc: Prince Oousu (Oousu no Mikoto) appeared in the Kiki ("Kojiki" [A Record of Ancient Matter] and the "Nihonshoki" [Chronicles of Japan]) as an Imperial family (royal family) during the Kofun (tumulus period) period in Japan.

emperor.name: Ashikamino kamami wakenomiko
emperor.desc: Ashikamino kamami wakenomiko was a member of the Imperial family that appears in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), and he was the son of YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto.

emperor.name: Ryoan (諒闇)
emperor.desc: Ryoan is a period when the Emperor is in mourning for his father and mother.

emperor.name: Prince Hachiko
emperor.desc: Prince Hachiko (562? - Nov 28, 641?) is the first prince of Emperor Sushun and the male cousin of Prince Shotoku.

emperor.name: The usurpation of the imperial throne
emperor.url: emperor/The usurpation of the imperial throne.html
emperor.desc: The usurpation of the imperial throne is either when those who do not have direct blood relationship or have remote blood relationship seize the Emperor's position or when this is expressed in a critical manner.

emperor.name: Ujinokaitako no himemiko (Princes Ujinokaitako)
emperor.desc: Ujinokaitako no himemiko

emperor.name: Shichidengosha (palace buildings for empresses)
emperor.desc: Shichidengosha refers to the palace buildings located behind Shishinden (The Throne Hall) and Jijuden (literally, hall of benevolence and longevity) in the dairi (inner palace grounds) of the Heian Palace, which were mainly used as the residence of the empresses of the emperors.

emperor.name: Hiogi wooden fan
emperor.desc: Hiogi is a fan made of wood that was used in the Imperial court.

emperor.name: Yamatohime no Okimi
emperor.desc: Yamatohime no Okimi (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the imperial family who lived in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: HIKAMI no Otoji
emperor.desc: HIKAMI no Otoji (year of birth unknown - 682) was a daughter of FUJIWARA no Kamatari.

emperor.name: Yagi's Double Year Theory
emperor.desc: Yagi's Double Year Theory is a theory that Soji YAGI insists the existence of mythological Emperors.

emperor.name: Yamatototohimomosohime no mikoto
emperor.desc: Yamatototohimomosohime no mikoto (date of birth and death unknown) was the Imperial princess of Emperor Korei.

emperor.name: Shiki no miko (Prince Shiki [磯城])
emperor.desc: Shiki no miko (around the latter half of the seventh century) was a member of the Imperial Family who lived in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Ojo (Princess)
emperor.desc: Ojo is the title given to a daughter of a king or its equivalent monarch.

emperor.name: Prince Asukabe
emperor.desc: The Prince Asukabe (year of birth and death unknown) was a bureaucrat who lived in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Taki no himemiko (Princess Taki)
emperor.desc: Taki no himemiko (before 686? - March 1, 751) was a member of the imperial Family who lived from the Asuka peirod to the Nara period.

emperor.name: Hatsusebe no himemiko (Princess Hatsusebe)
emperor.desc: Hatsusebe no himemiko (before 686? to 741) was a member of the Imperial Family who lived in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Nitabe no himemiko (Princess Nitabe)
emperor.desc: Nitabe no himemiko (year of birth unknown - October 26, 699) was a princess of the Emperor Tenchi.

emperor.name: Japanese Court Caps
emperor.desc: Japanese Court caps are headgear for Court nobles and adult samurai to wear when they visit the Imperial Palace.

emperor.name: OGIMACHI Naoko
emperor.desc: Naoko OGIMACHI (December 14, 1803 - August 6, 1856) was Nyoin (a woman bestowed with the title "in") in the late Edo period.

emperor.name: Jikimiyake
emperor.desc: Jikimiyake refers to a Miyake (family allowed to have the status of Imperial family) which was established by a child of an emperor.

emperor.name: The deposed/disinheritance of a crown prince
emperor.url: emperor/The deposeddisinheritance of a crown prince.html
emperor.desc: The deposed/disinheritance of a crown prince means to disinherit a heir in an imperial family or royal family.

emperor.name: Rokujo no Miya
emperor.desc: Rokujo no Miya is Miyake (house of an imperial prince) thought to have existed in the Kamakura Period.

emperor.name: Iwakuranomiya
emperor.desc: Iwakuranomiya was Miyake (house of an Imperial prince) in the early Kamakura period.

emperor.name: Ki no himemiko (Princess Ki)
emperor.desc: Ki no himemiko (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family who lived in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Prince Kibumi
emperor.desc: The Prince Kibumi (year of birth unknown - July 28, 757) was a member of the Imperial Family who lived in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Choku
emperor.desc: Choku is the words of the emperor or a document that directly conveys the emperor's order.

emperor.name: The Imperial Throne
emperor.desc: The notion of the Imperial Throne means the throne of Emperor in Japan.

emperor.name: Tsuburameo
emperor.desc: Tsuburameo was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Taijoko (retired emperor)
emperor.desc: The Taijoko is the honorary title given to a retired emperor or empress in his or her life.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Okusaka
emperor.desc: Imperial Prince Okusaka (Okusaka no miko, year of birth unknown - March 16, 454) was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Suminoenaka no oji
emperor.desc: Suminoenaka no oji (c. 336 - 399) was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Aga no himemiko (Princess Aga)
emperor.desc: Aga no himemiko (648 - c. 709) was a princess of the Emperor Tenchi.

emperor.name: Abe no miko
emperor.desc: Abe no miko (648 - year of death unknown) was a prince of the Emperor Tenchi.

emperor.name: Takeru no miko
emperor.desc: Takeru no miko (651 - 658) was a member of the Imperial Family in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Princess Yoshiko
emperor.desc: Princess Yoshiko (October 28, 1804 - January 27, 1893), who was from the Imperial family, lived from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.

emperor.name: Nukadehime no himemiko
emperor.desc: Nukadehime no himemiko (year of birth unknown - July, 664) was a member of the Imperial Family from the late Tumulus period to Asuka period.

emperor.name: Mimimotoji
emperor.desc: Mimimotoji, also referred to as Mimomonotoji (year of birth and death unknown) was a female who lived in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Koi (the Position of Empress)
emperor.desc: Koi (the Position of Empress) indicates Grand Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager or Empress that was the position given to a legitimate wife of the present or previous retired Emperor.

emperor.name: Koshi (Imperial Heir)
emperor.desc: The Koshi (imperial heir) is a successor of Tenshi (monarch or emperor).

emperor.name: Imperial proclamation
emperor.desc: Imperial proclamation is to issue an official document conveying the Emperor's order.

emperor.name: Imperial paper
emperor.desc: Imperial paper is an official document written emperor's order in the Ritsuryo system.

emperor.name: Chokushimaki (Imperial pastures)
emperor.desc: In ancient Japan, Chokushimaki was a ranch developed by the emperor's Chokushi and was used to supply war horses for the Meryo (the section taking care of imperial horses).

emperor.name: Iwanohimenomikoto
emperor.desc: Iwanohimenomikoto (year of birth unknown – June, 347) was an Empress of the Kofun period.

emperor.name: Imperial Princess Noto
emperor.desc: The Imperial Princess Noto (735 - March 20, 781) was a member of the Imperial Family who lived in the Nara period.

emperor.name: Otarashihime
emperor.desc: Otarashihime (year of birth and death unknown) was a daughter of ABE no Uchimaro.

emperor.name: TACHIBANA no Iratsume
emperor.desc: TACHIBANA no Iratsume (year of birth unknown - March 26, 681) was a daughter of ABE no Kurahashimaro.

emperor.name: Ikisomimi no mikoto
emperor.desc: Ikisomimi no mikoto (or Okisomimi no mikoto, the date of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family who appears in 'Nihonshoki' (Chronicles of Japan) who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Princess Masako
emperor.desc: The Princess Masako (September 10, 1691 - June 30, 1710) was the lawful wife of Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, the fifth lord of the Kishu Domain (later the eighth seii taishogun [literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"]).

emperor.name: Hikohitooe no mikoto
emperor.desc: Hikohitooe no mikoto or Oeo was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Koshohajime (New Year lecture in the court)
emperor.url: emperor/Koshohajime (New Year lecture in the court).html
emperor.desc: Koshohajime (New Year lecture in the court) is an annual event of the Imperial court in which Shinko (Scholars give a lecture or explain achievements to the Emperor, the Empress, and the nobility) is given by scholars as a part of the Emperor's start of learning in January every year.

emperor.name: Wakatakehiko no mikoto
emperor.desc: Wakatakehiko no mikoto or Wakahikotakekibitsuhiko no mikoto was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Iokiiribiko no miko
emperor.desc: Iokiiribiko no miko was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: Hikosashima no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Hikosashima no Mikoto (Hikosashima [written as Hikosamema in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters)] no mikoto) was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

emperor.name: TAKATSUKASA Tsunako
emperor.desc: Tsunako TAKATSUKASA (March 17, 1798 - May 14, 1823), later Zokogo (a title of empress given after her death) Tsunako, was the nyogo (a court title of the Emperor's consort) of the Emperor Ninko during the late Edo period.

emperor.name: Toki no fuda (a board for time)
emperor.url: emperor/Toki no fuda (a board for time).html
emperor.desc: The Toki no fuda was a board that was placed in a small garden in the Seiryoden (literally "Limpid Cool Hall") to show time.

emperor.name: TAKATSUKASA Yasuko
emperor.desc: Yasuko TAKATSUKASA (March 19, 1811 - November 20, 1847), later the Empress Dowager Yasuko, was the nyogo (a court title of the emperor's consort) of the Emperor Ninko during the late Edo period.

emperor.name: Imperial Princess Takako
emperor.desc: Imperial Princess Takako (November 4, 1650 - August 4, 1725) was a member of the Imperial family during the Edo period.

emperor.name: Prince Toma
emperor.desc: The Prince Toma (year of birth and death unknown) was in the Imperial Family between the late sixth century and the early seventh century.

emperor.name: Kudara no Okimi (Imperial Family)
emperor.desc: Kudara no Okimi, also referred to as Kudara no miko (year of birth and death unknown) was in the Imperial Family in the Asuka period.

emperor.name: Imperial Princess Shushi (Akiko)
emperor.desc: The Imperial Princess Shushi (Akiko) (the Imperial Princess Shushi, the wife of the Imperial prince Sadatake, February 23, 1700 - April 28, 1756) was an Imperial Family member during the Edo period.

emperor.name: Goshogo
emperor.desc: Goshogo is a title given to an Imperial family in Japan.

emperor.name: Kyugo
emperor.desc: Kyugo (reigning name) is a title given to an Imperial family in Japan.

emperor.name: Imperial Prince Shogoinnomiya Yoshikoto (Shogoinnomiya Yoshikoto Shinno)
emperor.url: emperor/Imperial Prince Shogoinnomiya Yoshikoto (Shogoinnomiya Yoshikoto Shinno).html
emperor.desc: The Imperial Prince Shogoinnomiya Yoshikoto (February 28, 1821 - September 26, 1868) was one of the Imperial Family members between the end of Edo period and the Meiji period.

emperor.name: Daikinban (the imperial standard [flag] for the ceremony of enthronement)
emperor.url: emperor/Daikinban (the imperial standard [flag] for the ceremony of enthronement).html
emperor.desc: The Daikinban is made of gold brocade and one of the imperial standards (flags) erected at Sokui no rei (ceremony of enthronement) in the garden in front of Shishinden (hall for state ceremonies).

emperor.name: Wakamiya
emperor.desc: Wakamiya

emperor.name: Princess Akiko (Akiko Joo)
emperor.desc: The Princess Akiko (April 4, 1640 - September 12, 1676) was Midaidokoro (the legal wife) of Ietsuna TOKUGAWA, the fourth Shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

emperor.name: Kobetsu
emperor.desc: Kobetsu or oson is a term that refers to shizoku (clan, family), a branch family of a royal family or imperial family, especially a family which has seceded from Japanese Imperial Family.

emperor.name: Koka
emperor.desc: Koka means that an Imperial princess or a princess marries a man who is not a member of Imperial family nor the royal family.

emperor.name: Princess Masuko
emperor.desc: The Pricess Masuko (November 28, 1711- November 9,1733) was the legal wife of Ieshige TOKUGAWA, the ninth Shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

emperor.name: Ippon Shinno (the first-ranked imperial prince)
emperor.desc: The Ippon Shinno (the first-ranked imperial prince) was the imperial prince who was granted Ippon, the highest rank (status) under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

emperor.name: Princess Takako
emperor.desc: The Princess Takako (July 29, 1795 - February 18, 1840) was the legal wife (Midaidokoro) of Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the 12th seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

emperor.name: Kyuchu Sekiji (Order of Precedence in the Imperial Court of Japan)
emperor.url: emperor/Kyuchu Sekiji (Order of Precedence in the Imperial Court of Japan).html
emperor.desc: Kyuchu Sekiji is the order of precedence at official events in the Imperial Court.

emperor.name: Yoru-no-otodo (Emperor's bedroom)
emperor.desc: Yoru-no-otodo is the bed room for the emperor in Seiryoden.

emperor.name: Kuredake no dai (Wu Chinese bamboo in the eastern garden of Seiryoden)
emperor.url: emperor/Kuredake no dai (Wu Chinese bamboo in the eastern garden of Seiryoden).html
emperor.desc: Kuretake no dai was where planting Wu Chinese bamboo in the eastern garden of Seiryoden (Literally "Limpid Cool Hall," an imperial summer palace).

emperor.name: Kenrei Gate
emperor.desc: The Kenrei-mon Gate is one of the outside gates in the Imperial Palace.

emperor.name: Kencho
emperor.desc: Kencho refers to a woman who raises and open Tobari (curtains) of the Takamikura (Imperial Throne) during a state ceremony such as one for enthronement or Chouga (New Year's greetings or well-wishes offered by retainers to the Emperor).

emperor.name: ICHIJO Tomiko
emperor.desc: Tomiko ICHIJO (February 27, 1743-January 9, 1796) was the Empress Dowager during the middle of the Edo period.

emperor.name: SONO Kuniko
emperor.desc: Kuniko SONO (1624 - August 3, 1677) was a member of the Imperial Family during the early part of the Edo period.

emperor.name: SONO Mitsuko
emperor.desc: Mitsuiko SONO (1602 - March 6, 1656) was one of the consorts of the Emperor Gomizunoo.

emperor.name: Prince Isonokamibe
emperor.desc: Prince Isonokamibe (also pronounced Isonokamibe no oji, Isonokamibe no miko [date of birth and death unknown])

emperor.name: Prince Isonokami
emperor.desc: Prince Isonokami (Also pronounced Isonokami no oji, Isonokami no miko [date of birth and death unknown])

emperor.name: Prince Kazuraki
emperor.desc: Prince Kazuraki (also pronounced Kazuraki oji, Kazuraki no miko, Katsuragi oji, or Katsuragi no miko [date of birth and death unknown])

emperor.name: Prince Honoo
emperor.desc: Prince Honoo (Also pronounced Honoo oji, Honoo no miko [date of birth and death unknown]).

emperor.name: Hi
emperor.desc: Hi was one of the empress's title in Kokyu palace (which is an imperial harem including the empress's residence).

emperor.name: Prince Kasuga
emperor.desc: Prince Kasuga (around 560 - 615) was the second son of Emperor Bidatsu and his wife, OMINAGO no Otoji.

emperor.name: Prince Naniwa
emperor.desc: Prince Naniwa (around 560 - 587) was the first son of Emperor Bidatsu and his wife, KASUGA no Ominago.

emperor.name: Prince Sakurai
emperor.desc: Prince Sakurai (around 560 - 587) was the sixth son of Emperor Bidatsu and his wife, SOGA no Kitashihime.

emperor.name: Mimakihime
emperor.desc: Mimakihime (date of birth and death unknown) was the empress of Emperor Sujin.

emperor.name: Yamato hiko no Mikoto
emperor.desc: Yamato hiko no Mikoto (year of birth unknown - October 30, 2 B.C.?) was a member of the Imperial family transmitted by "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

emperor.name: Oyamamori no miko
emperor.desc: Oyamamori no miko (earlier than 257 - March 31, 310) was the first prince of Emperor Ojin.

emperor.name: Sakai no kurohiko no miko
emperor.desc: Sakai no kurohiko no miko (earlier than 401 - 456) was the second prince of Emperor Ingyo.

emperor.name: Prince Yatsurishirohiko
emperor.desc: Prince Yatsurishirohiko (after 401 - 456) was the fourth prince of Emperor Ingyo.

emperor.name: Prince Yakabe
emperor.desc: Prince Yakabe (March 27, 539 - July 20, 587) was the Imperial prince of Emperor Senka.

emperor.name: Prince Oha
emperor.desc: Prince Oha (about 560 - year of death unknown) was the third prince of Emperor Bidatsu.

emperor.name: Prince Tame
emperor.desc: Prince Tame (Tame no miko, 572 - year of death unknown) was the first son of Emperor Yomei.

emperor.name: Prince Ekuri
emperor.desc: Prince Ekuri (578 - year of death unknown) was the fifth son of Emperor Yomei.

emperor.name: Kouin (Imperial descendant or posterity)
emperor.desc: The term Kouin refers to Imperial descendants.

emperor.name: The Emperor's Birthday
emperor.desc: The Emperor's Birthday is one of Japanese national holidays.

emperor.name: Daihi
emperor.desc: Daihi was the empress dowager who was an empress previously.

emperor.name: Daio ohi
emperor.desc: Daio ohi was a grandmother to the king and mother of the previous king.

emperor.name: Johyo
emperor.desc: Johyo (memorial to the emperor) was an act of handing Monjo (written material) (or Hyo [letters]) or the Monjo itself to the Emperor from any Koshin (Emperor's family) including Togu (crown prince), all the officials or general public.

emperor.name: Shunka-mon gate
emperor.desc: Shunka-mon gate is one of the outside gates in the Imperial Palace.

emperor.name: Kibitsuhime Okimi
emperor.desc: Kibitsuhime Okimi (year of birth unknown - October 31, 643) was in the Imperial (royal) family in Japan.

emperor.name: setto (a sword given by the emperor in the symbol of his trust to the appointment of someone to a mission)
emperor.url: emperor/setto (a sword given by the emperor in the symbol of his trust to the appointment of someone to a mi.html
emperor.desc: Setto (or Sechito) refers to the sword which was granted by the Emperor to Shogun who was going to the front or Japanese mission to Tang Dynasty China as the sign of commission in ancient times of Japan (from the Nara period to the Heian period).

emperor.name: Sojifujitsu
emperor.desc: Sojifujitsu is to make a false statement to the Emperor or to make a false charge.

emperor.name: Umaya no himemiko
emperor.desc: Umaya no himemiko (date of birth and death unknown) was the eighth child (fourth princess) between Prince Shotoku and Kashiwadenominoiratsume.

emperor.name: Tashiraka no Himemiko
emperor.desc: Tashiraka no Himemiko was a member of the Imperial family who lived during the Kofun period (tumulus period), and was the empress of Emperor Keitai.

emperor.name: OE Iwashiro
emperor.desc: Iwashiro OE (1744-January 11, 1813) was a member of Japan's Imperial Family.

emperor.name: Kotaifujin (title for previous retired emperors' consort)
emperor.url: emperor/Kotaifujin (title for previous retired emperors consort).html
emperor.desc: Kotaifujin (also called Sumemioya) means a person who was the biological mother of an Emperor and consort of the previous Emperor.

emperor.name: Kotaihi
emperor.desc: Kotaihi means a person who was the biological mother of an Emperor and the wife of the previous Emperor.

family.name: Sandai-Kyaku-Shiki
family.desc: Sandai-Kyaku-Shiki is a term used to collectively refer to three Kyaku-Shiki acts (laws supplementary to the Ritsu-ryo, which were the statutes of the Nara and Heian periods) that were codified during the Heian era: the Konin-Kyaku-Shiki Act, the Jogan-Kyaku-Shiki Act and the Engi-Kyaku-Shiki Act.

family.name: The Kujo Family
family.desc: The Kujo Family is one of the Sekke and a court noble.

family.name: The Sumitomo Family
family.desc: The Sumitomo Family is the founding family of Sumitomo Zaibatsu.

family.name: The Saionji Family
family.desc: The Saionji Family were court nobility descended from the Fujiwara clan.

family.name: The Otani Family
family.desc: Otanike (Otani family) is the yago (literally, the "house name") of the descendants of Kakue, a son of Hirotsuna HINO and Kakushin-ni.

family.name: The Matsunaga clan
family.desc: The Matsunaga clan was a warlord group in Yamato-no-kuni.

family.name: The Rokkaku clan
family.desc: The Rokkaku clan was a samurai family (shugo guar feudal lord) descended from the Sasaki clan of Uda-Genji (Uda-Gen clan) and whose influence was centered in the southern part of Omi-no-kuni from the Kamakura era through the Sengoku period (Japan).

family.name: The Yamashinanomiya Family
family.desc: The Yamashinanomiya family was the Imperial family, created by Imperial Prince Yamashinanomiya Akira, the son of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie, at the end the Edo period.

family.name: The Higashifushiminomiya Family
family.desc: The Higashifushiminomiya family is the Imperial family, which was founded by Imperial Prince Higashifushiminomiya Yorihito, a son of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Kuniie, during the late Meiji Era.

family.name: The Northern House of the Fujiwara clan
family.url: family/The Northern House of the Fujiwara clan.html
family.desc: The Northern House of the Fujiwara clan was a family line whose originator was FUJIWARA no Fusasaki, the second son of FUJIWARA no Fuhito, the minister of the right.

family.name: Fujiwara Nanke (Fujiwara Nan Family)
family.desc: The Southern House of the Fujiwara clan was a family line whose originator was FUJIWARA no Muchimaro, the eldest son of FUJIWARA no Fuhito, the minister of the right.

family.name: The Sekke (Setsu Family)
family.desc: The Sekke consisted of five families that the main branch of the Fujiwara Family clan had established during the Kamakura era, whereby it achieved the top rank of court nobility kakaku (family status).

family.name: The Seiga Family
family.desc: The Seiga Family was one of the kakaku (family status) of court nobles or nobility, which is the kakaku above the daijinke (Daijin Family) and was next to the sekke (Setsu Family).

family.name: The Konoe Family
family.desc: The Konoe Family was the premier court nobility of the sekke (Setsu Family).

family.name: The Isshiki Clan (Isshikiuji)
family.desc: The Isshiki clan comprised a samurai family.

family.name: The Takatsukasa Family
family.desc: The Takatsukasa Family is one of the five sekke (regent) houses and kuge (court nobility).

family.name: The House of Ichijo
family.desc: The Ichijo Family is one of the sekke (regent) houses and a kuge (court nobility).

family.name: The Nijo Family
family.desc: The Nijo Family is one of the sekke (regent) houses and a kuge (court nobility).

family.name: The Urin Family
family.desc: The Urin Family was of the house status of kuge (court nobility) subsequent to the Kamakura period; it was inferior to the sekke (the house of regents), Seigake (one of the statuses of court nobility that was inferior to the sekke but superior to the minister) and the house of minister, but it was equal to meike (kuge), a kuge of lower rank, and superior to hange (kuge), a kuge of lower rank.

family.name: The Hino Family
family.desc: The Hino Family is a court noble having meika, the upper rank of kuge (the status of the house) of the House of the Fujiwara North Line of the Fujiwara clan.

family.name: Kiyohara clan
family.desc: The Kiyohara clan was a family (lineage) of the Heian period.

family.name: The Sanjonishi Family
family.desc: The Sanjonishi Family is a house of a branch line of the House of Ogimachi-Sanjo, of the Kanin Line, of the House of Fujiwara North of the Fujiwara clan, as well as a court noble having the house status of the house of Minister (Old houses, or Uchiuchi).

family.name: The Tokudaiji Family
family.desc: The Tokudaiji Family is a kuge (court noble) having the house status of Seigake (one of the statuses of court nobility which is inferiror to the sekke but superior to minister).

family.name: Miyazu han (Miyazu domain)
family.desc: Miyazu han was one of the han (feudal lord's domain) located in Yosa County, Tango Province, during the Edo period.

family.name: Tango Tanabe domain
family.desc: Tanabe domain was one of the domains in Tango Province during the Edo period.

family.name: the Kyogoku clan
family.desc: The Kyogoku clan is a house of Samurai in Japan.

family.name: The Kideranomiya Family
family.desc: The Kideranomiya family was one of Imperial Houses that existed from the Kamakura period through to the middle of the Muromachi period.

family.name: The Reizei family
family.desc: The Reizei family belonged to the court nobility.

family.name: The Kii Tanabe domain
family.desc: The Kii Tanabe domain was governed by the Mikawa Ando clan, who were the chief retainers of the Kishu Tokugawa family and were granted the fief in Kii Province for helping successive lords of Kishu.

family.name: The Naito clan
family.desc: Naito-shi or Naito-uji is a Japanese surname.

family.name: Tanba-Kameyama Domain
family.desc: The Kameyama Domain was a feudal domain in Tanba Province during the Edo period.

family.name: Omura Domain
family.desc: Omura Domain was a feudal domain that ruled the Sonogi region of Hizen Province.

family.name: HOJO Yasuie
family.desc: Yasuie HOJO (? - 1335) was from the Hojo family which existed in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

family.name: Sonpi Bunmyaku, the biographies of the nobles and humbles
family.url: family/Sonpi Bunmyaku, the biographies of the nobles and humbles.html
family.desc: Sonpi Bunmyaku is a text compiled in early Japan that records the lineages of the aristocracy.

family.name: The Sugawara clan
family.desc: The Sugawara clan was a noble family that existed from ancient to early-modern times in Japan.

family.name: The Matsudono Family
family.desc: The Matsudono Family, established as a house of Regents and Senior Regents was, in theory, ranked at the same level as the houses of Regents such as the Konoe family and the Kujo family in the Court nobility.

family.name: The Higashibojo Family
family.desc: The Higashibojo Family, one of the houses of Dojo, was established by Shigenaga HIGASHIBOJO (Court Rank, Councillor, Department of Etiquette and Ceremonies, 1284-1343) who was the second son of Nagatsune GOJO (Senior Second Rank, Councillor, Department of Justice, 1242-1315).

family.name: The Karahashi family
family.desc: The Karahashi family, one of the houses of Dojo, was established by SUGAWARA no Ariyoshi (Court Rank, Department of Civil Office and Education, Conferred Junior Third Rank, 1041 - 1121).

family.name: The Niwata family
family.desc: The Niwata family, one of the clans of Dojo, was descended from the Uda-Genji (Minamoto) clan.

family.name: The Takakura family
family.desc: The Takakura family, one of the families of Dojo, was established by Nagasue TAKAKURA (Court Rank, Councillor, 1338 - 1392) whose father was FUJIWARA no Norikata, a descendant of FUJIWARA no Nagayoshi of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan.

family.name: The Ayabe Domain
family.desc: The Ayabe Domain existed in Tanba Province (Aono cho or Hongu cho, Ayabe City, Kyoto Prefecture in the present day).

family.name: The Sonobe Domain
family.desc: The Sonobe Domain existed in Funai County in Tanba Province (Sonobe-cho Kozakura Town, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture in the present day).

family.name: The Anegakoji/Anekoji family
family.desc: The Anegakoji/Anekoji family were court nobility of Fujiwara lineage.

family.name: The Fushimi Domain
family.desc: The Fushimi Domain existed in Fushimi in the Yamashiro Province (present day Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture).

family.name: Yodo Domain
family.desc: The Yodo Domain was located in the Yamashiro Province (present-day Yodohon cho, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture).

family.name: Fukuchiyama Domain
family.desc: The Fukuchiyama Domain was located in Amada County in Tanba Province (present-day Naiki, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture).

family.name: Seshu-Shinno-ke (the hereditary Imperial prince's family)
family.desc: The Seshu-Shinno-ke is also known as "the Tei-Shinno-ke" (the legitimate Imperial prince's family).

family.name: The Kazanin Family
family.desc: The Kasannoin family was directly descended from the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan-Morozane branch (Kazanin branch).

family.name: The Kose school
family.desc: The Kose school was a family of painters which existed from the early Heian period, through the Muromachi, to the Meiji period.

family.name: The Hata Clan
family.desc: The Hata clan had existed since ancient times.

family.name: The Yamashina Family
family.desc: The Yamashina family was court nobility with a family status of Urin.

family.name: The Kamo Clan
family.desc: The Kamo clan (or the Kamoji clan) is a Japanese family which has a past stretching back to ancient times.

family.name: The Muromachi Family
family.desc: The Muromachi family was court nobility with a family status of the Urin.

family.name: The Mibu Family
family.desc: The Mibu family

family.name: The Nakanomikado Family
family.desc: The Nakanomikado family

family.name: The Hashimoto Family
family.desc: The Hashimoto family

family.name: The Shijo Family
family.desc: The Shijo family belonged to the court nobility and had a family status of Urin.

family.name: The Ano Family
family.desc: The Ano family belonged to the court nobility and had a status of Urin.

family.name: Daidoji Clan
family.desc: The Daidoji clan is one of the Japanese clans.

family.name: Shinke (new family)
family.desc: Shinke (new family)

family.name: The Kajuji/Kanjuji Ryu (The Kajuji/Kanjuji lineage)
family.desc: The Kajuji/Kanjuji ryu is one of the lineages of court nobility of FUJIWARA no Takafuji-ryu of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan.

family.name: The Sengoro SHIGEYAMA family
family.desc: The Sengoro SHIGEYAMA family is one of the most famous families in Kyogen (a comic interlude performed during a Noh program) and their Kyogen style belongs to that of the Okura-ryu school.

family.name: The Kadenokoji/Kageyukoji Family
family.desc: The Kadenokoji/Kageyukoji family is a Japanese clan.

family.name: The Toin Family
family.desc: The Toin family belonged to the court nobility of the Dojo family of Kanin-ryu (the Kanin family) of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, which existed from the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period.

family.name: The Shibayama Family
family.desc: The Shibayama family was a "Tosho-ke" (hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) of an illegitimate family lineage of Kajuji of the Takafuji group of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and its social standing was a prestigious family.

family.name: The Kanroji Family
