family.desc: The Kanroji family was "Tosho-ke" (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) of the main branch of the Kajuji line of the Takafuji group of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, and its social standing was prestigious family.

family.name: The Kurahashi Family
family.desc: The Kurahashi family was a "Tosho-ke" (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) of a branch family of Tsuchimikado of the Abe clan and its social standing was hange, kuge of lower rank.

family.name: The Ashikaga Shogunate Family
family.desc: The branch of the main families of the Ashikaga clan (head family) that had inherited the post of Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by shogun) since the first generation of Takauji ASHIKAGA was referred to as the Ashikaga Shogunate family.

family.name: Minamoto Clan
family.desc: The Minamoto clan (Genji) is a family whose honorary surname was Minamoto.

family.name: The Taira clan
family.desc: The family name of the Taira clan was derived from "TAIRA no Ason," which was one of the official titles given to a member of the Imperial Family if they became vassals.

family.name: The Hojo clan
family.desc: The Hojo clan was a gozoku (local ruling family) originating in Izu Province which provided hereditary regents of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

family.name: Koga Family
family.desc: The Koga family is a Japanese clan.

family.name: Ushiku Domain
family.desc: The Ushiku Domain was a feudal domain that lay in Kawachi County of Hitachi Province.

family.name: Abe Clan
family.desc: The Abe clan (the original kanji used for the Abe clan was 阿部氏, later 安倍氏) was one of the nobles derived from Gozoku (local ruling family) of ancient Japan.

family.name: The Nishinotoin family
family.desc: The Nishinotoin was a Kuge (court noble) family descended from TAIRA no Takamune of the Taira clan.

family.name: The Hiramatsu family
family.desc: Belonged to the lineage of the Prince Takamune of the Taira clan, the Hiramatsu was a family of dojo kuge (nobles occupying relatively high ranks) of which the founder was Tokitsune HIRAMATSU (Chunagon (vice-councilor of state) of Junii (Junior Second Rank)) (1599-1654), the second son of Tokiyoshi NISHINOTOIN (Sangi (councilor) of Junii (Junior Second Rank)) (1552-1640).

family.name: Nagatani Family
family.desc: The Nagatani family, which claimed to be descended from the Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan) TAIRA no Takamune-o line, belonged to the Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks); the founder of the family was Tadayasu NAGATANI (Shosanmi Minbu taifu, or Senior Third Rank, Senior Assistant Minister of Popular Affairs) (1612 - 1669), who was the fifth son of Tokiyoshi NISHINOTOIN (Junii Sangi, or Junior Second Rank, Councilor) (1552 -1640).

family.name: Katano Family
family.desc: The Katano family, which claimed to be descended from Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan) TAIRA no Takamune-o line, belonged to the Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks); the founder of the family was Tokisada KATANO (Daizen no daibu, or Master of the Palace Table), who was the last son of Tokiyoshi NISHINOTOIN (Junii Sangi, or Junior Second Rank, Councilor) (1552 - 1640).

family.name: Iwai Family
family.desc: The Iwai family, which claimed to be descended from the Kanmu-Heishi (Taira clan) TAIRA no Takamune-o line, beloged to the Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks).

family.name: Fujinami Family
family.desc: The Fujinami family, which claimed to be descended from the Onakatomi clan, belonged to the Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks).

family.name: The Shirakawa-hakuo Family
family.desc: The Shirakawa-hakuo family, or the Shirakawa family was the court noble that had been originated from 'Prince Nobuzane' (the prince of Imperial Prince Kiyohito), who was the imperial grandson of Emperor Kazan, and the family inherited the ancient tradition handed over through Jingikan (officer of the institution for dedicating to religious ceremony).

family.name: Oyumi-kubo
family.desc: Oyumi-kubo was one of Kubo (shogunate) families of the Ashikaga clan (of Motouji-ryu or the Motouji lineage) in Kanto region.

family.name: Nakatomi Clan
family.desc: The Nakatomi clan, together with the Inbe clan, was a powerful family serving the Yamato court in ancient Japan, who took charge of Shinto rituals and religious services, and had occupied the region Yamashina -approximately corresponding to today's Nakatomi-cho, Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City - as their base through the ages.

family.name: Iwakura Family
family.desc: The Iwakura family was a Court noble lineage that was descended from the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan) Koga family.

family.name: Hirohata Family
family.desc: The Hirohata family was a court noble with the social standing of the Seiga family (Shinke or a newly established family, Uchiuchi or a family with close relations with Emperor).

family.name: Higashikuze Family
family.desc: The Higashikuze family was a Kuge who had the family grade of Urin.

family.name: Togi Family
family.desc: The Togi family is one of the Sanpo gakuso (organization of transmission of gagaku, ancient court music) Gaku families (families of musicians served in the Imperial court in Kyoto, Nanto in Nara, and Tennoji in Osaka), which has passed down the tradition of gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) for over 1,300 years from the Nara period to today.

family.name: Nakahara Clan
family.desc: The Nakahara clan was a group of noble families sharing the same ancestor, which existed from ancient times to the early-modern times in Japan.

family.name: Kuze Family
family.desc: The Kuze family was a Tosho-ke (the hereditary lineage of Court nobles occupying relatively high ranks) (new family) of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan) line.

family.name: The Ozuki clan
family.desc: The Ozuki (Otsuki) was a Kuge (court nobles) clan which could trace its history back to ancient times.

family.name: Chigusa Family
family.desc: The Chigusa family is a Japanese clan.

family.name: The Miyoshi clan
family.desc: The Miyoshi is one of clans in Japan.

family.name: Ononomiya School
family.desc: The Ononomiya school was a school of Yusoku-kojitsu (knowledge of court rules, ceremony, decorum and records of the past), which dated back to the Heian period.

family.name: Shinpan (Tokugawa's relatives)
family.desc: Shinpan is one of the classifications of clans during the Edo period, that distinguished the clans forefathers as male descendants through a line of males from Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

family.name: Kuge (court noble)
family.desc: Kuge is a general term to refer to nobles and government officials who serve chotei (Imperial Court) in Japan.

family.name: Tokuso
family.desc: Tokuso was a family line of the successors of the Hojo clan of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

family.name: The Takeda clan
family.desc: The Takeda clan was a samurai family that existed during the time from the end of the Heian to to the Sengoku period (Japan).

family.name: The house of minister
family.desc: The house of minister was one of the kakaku (family status) of kuge (court noble) and it was kakaku after Sekke (line of regents and advisers) and the Seiga family (one of the highest court noble families in Japan at that time).

family.name: Meike (important noble family) (kuge (court noble))
family.desc: Meike (also pronounced Meika) was one of the kakaku (family status) of kuge (court noble) established after the Kamakura period and it was of equal rank to the House of Urin and positioned in a higher rank than hanke (a kind of family status of the Court nobles) (kuge).

family.name: The Sanjo Family
family.desc: The Sanjo family (as written三條 in orthographic style) was a clan that directly descended from the Kan-in Line ofthe Northern House of the Fujiwara clan in Japan.

family.name: The Ogimachisanjo Family
family.desc: The Ogimachisanjo family was a branch family of the Sanjo family which was the Kan-in Line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, being a family of court nobles with their social standing being the house of minister.

family.name: Hanke (Kuge)
family.desc: Hanke (a kind of family status of the Court nobles) is a classification term for the court noble class established subsequent to the Kamakura period being the lowest-ranked family in social standing among Tosho-ke (high court nobility allowed to enter the Imperial Palace).

family.name: The Uematsu Family
family.desc: The Uematsu family was a family of court nobles with Masanaga UEMATSU being the patriarch.

family.name: The Tsuchimikado Family
family.desc: The Tsuchimikado family is a clan of court nobles that served the Imperial Court in Japan.

family.name: The Gojo Family
family.desc: The Gojo family is a kuge (family of court nobles) and a toshoke (hereditary lineage of court nobles above a certain rank), whose patriarch was Takanaga GOJO (Junii - Junior Second Rank), Shikibusho (Ministry of Ceremonies) (1210 - 1285), who was a son of Shonii (Senior Second Rank), Sangi (councilor) and Ministry of Treasury, SUGAWARA no Tamenaga (Tamenaga TAKATSUJI).

family.name: The Takatsuji Family
family.desc: The Takatsuji family is toshoke (hereditary lineage of court nobles above a certain rank), whose patriarch was Michizane SUGAWARA's descendant, Koretsuna TAKATSUJI (Shoshiinoge - Senior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Daigakuryo (Bureau of Education under ritsuryo system) (1030 - 1107).

family.name: The Kiyooka Family
family.desc: The Kiyooka family is a toshoke (hereditary lineage of court nobles above a certain rank) established during the Edo period by Nagatoki KIYOOKA (Junii - Junior Second Rank), Sangi (councilor), Shikibusho (Minister of Ceremonies) (1657 - 1718), who was the second son of Tameyasu GOJO (Shonii -Senior Second Rank) Dainagon (chief councilor of state) (1619 - 1677).

family.name: The Kuwabara Family
family.desc: The Kuwabara family is a toshoke (hereditary lineage of court nobles above a certain rank) established during the Edo period by Nagayoshi KUWABARA (Shonii - Senior Second Rank), Chunagon (vice-councilor of state), Shikibusho (Minister of Ceremonies) (1661 - 1737), who was the fourth son of Tameyasu GOJO (Shonii - Senior Second Rank), Dainagon (chief councilor of state) (1619 - 1677).

family.name: The Ohara Family
family.desc: The Ohara family was a member of Genji Tosho Genji (Minamoto clan members who were court nobles above a certain rank), descendants of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan).

family.name: The Ayanokoji Family
family.desc: The Ayanokoji family was a member of Genji Tosho Genji (Minamoto clan members who are court nobles above a certain rank), descendants of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan).

family.name: The Itsutsuji Family
family.desc: The Itsutsuji family is a member of Genji Tosho Genji (Minamoto clan members who are court nobles above a certain rank), descendants of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan).

family.name: The Jikoji Family
family.desc: The Jikoji family is a member of Genji Tosho Genji (Minamoto clan members who are court nobles above a certain rank), descendants of Uda-Genji (Minamoto clan).

family.name: Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan)
family.desc: Murakami-Genji was a shisei kozoku (member of the Imperial Family conferred with a family name) who was descended from a son of the sixty second Emperor, Murakami.

family.name: The Funabashi Family
family.desc: The Funabashi family are descendants of Imperial Prince Toneri, the son of the fourtieth emperor, Emperor Tenmu.

family.name: Fusehara family
family.desc: The Fusehara family was a toshoke (the hereditary lineage of court nobles allowed to enter the tenjonoma in the palace) that was a branch family of the Funabashi family in direct line of descent from the Kiyohara clan.

family.name: Sawa family
family.desc: The Sawa family was a toshoke (within the hereditary lineage of court nobles allowed to enter the tenjonoma in the palace) down line of the Kiyohara clan.

family.name: Hagiwara family
family.desc: The Hagiwara family was a toshoke (within the hereditary lineage of court nobles allowed to enter the tenjonoma in the palace) and their original name was Urabe.

family.name: Nishigori family
family.desc: The Nishigori family was a toshoke (within the hereditary lineage of court nobles allowed to enter the tenjonoma in the palace) down line of the Urabe clan.

family.name: Fujii family
family.desc: The Fujii family was a toshoke (within the hereditary lineage of court nobles allowed to enter the tenjonoma in the palace) down line of the Urabe clan.

family.name: Tominokoji family
family.desc: The Tominokoji family was a toshoke (within the hereditary lineage of court nobles allowed to enter the tenjonoma in the palace) down line of the Fujiwara clan.

family.name: Takeuchi family
family.desc: The Takeuchi family were a court noble.

family.name: Sesonji family
family.desc: The Sesonji family was a clan derived from the Fujiwara clan.

family.name: The Rokkaku Family
family.desc: The Rokkaku family is a family of court nobles that were established during the Edo Period.

family.name: Oe clan
family.desc: The Oe clan were nobles from ancient times until early modern times.

family.name: Daigo family
family.desc: Daigo family are a kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of seigake (the second highest family status for court nobles).

family.name: Kikutei family
family.desc: The Kikutei family were kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of seigake (the second highest family status for court nobles).

family.name: The Oinomikado family
family.desc: Oinomikado family were kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of seigake (the second highest family status for court nobles).

family.name: The Nakanoin family
family.desc: The Nakanoin family were kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of daijinke (the third highest status for court nobles).

family.name: The Shigenoi family
family.desc: Shigenoi family were kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of urinke (the fourth highest family status for court nobles).

family.name: Nakayama family
family.desc: The Nakayama family were kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of urinke (the fourth highest family status for court nobles).

family.name: The Bojo family
family.desc: Bojo family were kuge (court nobles) with kakaku (family status) of meike (the fourth highest status for court nobles).

family.name: Toshoke

geographical.desc: Saikachihama Swimming Area is a swimming area operated by Nagahama City which is located in Takahashi-cho and Tamura-cho in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture facing Lake Biwa.

geographical.name: Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido (the Nara Highway passing over Tatsuta)
geographical.url: geographical/Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido (the Nara Highway passing over Tatsuta).html
geographical.desc: The Tatsuta-goe Nara Kaido is one of the highways to Nara.

geographical.name: Mt. Bunagatake
geographical.desc: Mr. Bunagatake is a mountain which is 1,214.4 m high above sealevel and located in Otsu City in Shiga Prefecture.

geographical.name: Fukura-ko Port
geographical.desc: Fukura-ko Port (福浦港 in Chinese characters) is a local port in Shika-machi (former Togi-machi), Ishikawa Prefecture.

geographical.name: Kaizu-osaki
geographical.desc: Kaizu-osaki is a shore reef area jutting out into Lake Biwa located in Makino-cho, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture and it is one of Biwako Hakkei (Eight Views of Lake Biwa).

geographical.name: Imai Town
geographical.desc: Imai Town is a town located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

geographical.name: Masuda-ike Pond
geographical.desc: Masuda-ike Pond is a reservoir which once existed in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture but does not now exist.

geographical.name: Biwako-onsen Hot Spring (a hot spring near Biwako [Lake Biwa])
geographical.url: geographical/Biwako-onsen Hot Spring (a hot spring near Biwako [Lake Biwa]).html
geographical.desc: The term "Biwako-onsen Hot Spring" refers to a hot spring located at Chagasaki, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

geographical.name: Otsu Port (Shiga Prefecture)
geographical.desc: Otsu Port is a port located in Shiga Prefecture.

geographical.name: Ano
geographical.desc: Ano is a valley along the lower Nyu-gawa River and is located in Gojo-shi City (former Nishi-yoshino Village in Yoshino District), Nara Prefecture.

geographical.name: Sugatani-onsen (a hot spring located in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture)
geographical.url: geographical/Sugatani-onsen (a hot spring located in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture).html
geographical.desc: Sugatani onsen is a hot spring located in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture (formerly, Omi Province).

geographical.name: Mt. Yoshino
geographical.desc: Mt. Yoshino is located in Yoshino-cho, Yoshino County in the central part of Nara Prefecture.

geographical.name: Yoshino-onsen Hot Spring
geographical.desc: Yoshino-onsen Hot Spring is located in Yoshino-cho, Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture.

geographical.name: Nara
geographical.desc: Nara, or 奈良, a historic city in Japan, was once Heijo-kyo Capital.

geographical.name: Hira-shofuku onsen (a hot spring in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture)
geographical.url: geographical/Hira-shofuku onsen (a hot spring in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).html
geographical.desc: Hira-shofuku onsen is a hot spring located at 948-10, Kitahira, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

geographical.name: Momonoo no-taki Falls
geographical.desc: Momonoo no-taki Falls is in Takimoto-cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

history.name: Shinsengumi
history.desc: The site of Shinsengumi military post at Mibu

history.name: The Ikedaya Incident
history.desc: The Ikedaya Incident is the name given to an event that took place on July 8,1864 towards the end of the Edo Period in which the Shinsengumi, who was a peacekeeping organization under the Kyoto protectorate, attacked the imperial loyalist faction from Choshu who were hiding out at the Ikedaya Inn at Kiyamachi (Sanjou-Kobashi Bridge) on Sanjou-Street in Kyoto.

history.name: Muromachi Bakufu
history.desc: Muromachi Bakufu was a samurai government established by Takauji ASHIKAGA.

history.name: The 53 Stations of the Tokaido Road
history.url: history/The 53 Stations of the Tokaido Road.html
history.desc: The 53 stations of the Tokaido Road (Tokaido gojusan tsugi) can mean:

history.name: Heian-kyo
history.desc: Heian-kyo (literally "tranquility and peace capital") was the old capital of Japan established by Emperor Kanmu in 794.

history.name: Honnoji Incident
history.desc: Honnoji Incident is about an event on June 21, 1582 whereby Mitsuhide AKECHI, a key vassal of Nobunaga ODA, rose in revolt and attacked his master, Nobunaga, who had been staying in Honno-ji Temple in Kyoto and Nobunaga committed suicide.

history.name: Battle of Yamazaki
history.desc: The Battle of Yamazaki was fought between Mitsuhide AKECHI, who had defeated Nobunaga ODA in the Honnoji Incident in June and July 1582, and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI returning from an attack on Takamatsu-jo Castle (in Bicchu Province); the scene of the battle was Yamazaki (Yamazaki, Shimamoto-cho, Mishima-gun, Osaka Prefecture and Oyamazaki-cho, Otokuni-gun, Kyoto Prefecture), located on the border between Settsu Province and Yamashiro Province, where Toyotomi's forces passed on their way to Kyoto and clashed head on with Akechi's on July 2.

history.name: Insei
history.desc: Insei refers to a form of government in which the retired Emperor (Joko), who is the direct ancestor of the current Emperor, directly conducts the affairs of state.

history.name: The Azuchi Momoyama Period
history.desc: The Azuchi Momoyama period (1568 - 1603) is one of the age classifications in Japan, referring to the period in which Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI held the right to rule Japan (Oda government, Toyotomi government).

history.name: The Tobaku movement
history.desc: The Tobaku movement refers to the political movement at the end of the Edo period, which aimed to overthrow Edo Bakufu as well as the political power structure.

history.name: Onin War
history.desc: Onin War, fought from 1467 till 1477, was a civil war that broke out during the Muromachi period when the ruling Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") was Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth person to hold this position.

history.name: Hogen Disturbance (Hogen-no-ran)
history.desc: The Hogen Disturbance occurred during the first year (1156) of the Hogen era in the Heian period, when Emperor Sutoku and Emperor Goshirakawa had a dispute, and the Emperor's side made a surprise attack on the retired emperor's side.

history.name: The Boshin War
history.desc: The Boshin War from 1868 to 1869 was a civil war in Japan in which the new Meiji government, brought about by the restoration of the Japanese monarchy, eradicated the power of the Edo Shogunate.

history.name: The Kanno Disturbance
history.desc: The Kanno Disturbance was a power struggle within the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) that reached its height during the Kanno era from 1350 to 1352 of the Northern and Southern Court period.

history.name: Shugo daimyo
history.desc: The shugo daimyo is a concept in Japanese history that refers to the shugo of the Muromachi period, who acquired not only the function of the military and law enforcement but also the economic power, and strengthened the territorial, pervasive control over a province.

history.name: Gekokujo
history.desc: Gekokujo ("the low overturning the high," a term used to describe retainers overthrowing their lords) describes situations in Japanese history that occur when a person of lower rank overthrows a superior either politically or militarily, and then supplants the superior's position in society.

history.name: The Nanbokucho Period
history.desc: The Nanbokucho era (the period of the Northern and Southern Courts) in Japan refers to one subsection of medieval Japanese history.

history.name: The Jokyu Rebellion
history.desc: The Jokyu Rebellion (jokyu no ran) occurred in the third year of the Jokyu era (A.D. 1221) during the Kamakura period; in this armed conflict, Emperor Gotoba raised troops to attack the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) but was defeated.

history.name: The Kenmu Restoration
history.desc: The Kenmu Restoration (kenmu no shinsei) refers to the period of direct Imperial rule (where the Emperor personally controls the government) initiated by Emperor Godaigo in the sixth month of 1333, as the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) collapsed; it can also refer to the administrative unit of Imperial rule.

history.name: The Hamaguri Rebellion
history.desc: The Hamaguri Rebellion (kinmon no hen) occurred on August 20, 1864 (the first year of the Genji era, July 19th in the old calendar) in the final days of the Edo period.

history.name: The Third Conference of Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
history.jp: 第3回気候変動枠組条約締約国会議
history.url: history/The Third Conference of Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.html
history.desc: The Third Conference of Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP3, the Third Session of the Conference of the Parties) held on December in 1997 by the United Nations in the Kyoto International Conference Center (Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture), was an international conference of which the main object was to reach an international consensus on regulations concerning the emission of greenhouse gases,

history.name: Eiroku
history.desc: Eiroku is one of the eras of Japan.

history.name: Tokyo Tento (transferring the capital)
history.desc: The Tokyo Tento is when Edo was designated as Tokyo during the Meiji Restoration.

history.name: The Kyoto Shugoshoku
history.desc: The Kyoto Shugoshoku (literally, "office of the protector of Kyoto") was an important post in the Edo bakufu that was newly created at the end of the Edo period; it was one of the three key posts in the bakufu, the others being the Seiji-Sosaishoku (literally, "political governor") and the Shogun-Kokenshoku (literally, "guardian of the Shogun").

history.name: Kyoto mimawarigumi
history.desc: Kyoto mimawarigumi was an organization for maintaining public order in Kyoto, which was formed by the shogun's retainers at the end of the Edo Period (end of Edo period).

history.name: Goryo-eji (guards of Imperial mausoleums)
history.desc: Goryo-eji was an organization created to protect the imperial palace of the Emperor Komei.

history.name: Aburanokoji Incident
history.desc: An incident in which Kashitaro ITO, a staff officer of the Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate), and others were assassinated.

history.name: Kanji of the Year
history.desc: Kanji of the Year is a Chinese character representing the social conditions in Japan or World of the year which is announced once a year by the Japan Kanji Aptitude Testing Foundation on the "Kanji's day", December 12.

history.name: The Sumiya Incident
history.desc: The Sumiya Incident refers to violent acts which Kamo SERIZAWA, head of Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate), carried out during a party held in ageya (a restaurant where high-class harlots and geisha dispatched from a geisha house entertained guests) called Sumiya in Shimabara, Kyoto in June, 1863.

history.name: The Battle of Dannoura
history.desc: The battle of Dannoura was fought in the closing days of the Heian period, on April 25, 1185, under the old lunar calendar), and took place in Nagato Province, at Akamaseki, Dannoura (modern-day Shimonoseki, Yamaguchi Pref.).

history.name: Gonancho (Second Southern Court)
history.desc: Gonancho (Second Southern Court) is a general term that refers to descendants of the Southern dynasty (Japan) lineage and their former retainers and their attempts to revive the Southern Court after the two Courts were unified in 1392, and to the political administrations and the members of the Imperial household who were involved.

history.name: The Koryaku Coup
history.desc: The Koryaku Coup was a coup d'etat that occurred in 1379 (the fifth year of Tenju (Southern)/first year of Koryaku (Northern)) during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), in which the Kanrei, or deputy (de facto leader) of the Muromachi Shogunate, Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA, was overthrown and lost his position.

history.name: The Oei Rebellion
history.desc: The Oei rebellion, which broke out in the sixth year of the Oei era (1399) during the Muromachi period, was a revolt against the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) led by the shugo daimyo (feudal lord) Yoshihiro OUCHI, in which he occupied the city of Sakai (modern-day Osaka) which was eventually brought to ruin.

history.name: Ryoto Tetsuritsu
history.desc: "Ryoto tetsuritsu" refers to the situation where the family line of a country's monarchy is split into two and the monarch is alternately selected from these two family lines.

history.name: The Northern Court
history.desc: The term "Northern Court" (hokucho in Japanese) describes the Japanese Imperial Court, dynasty, and government that broke off from the Southern Court and was located geographically north of its southern rival at Yoshino.

history.name: The Teradaya Incident
history.desc: The Teradaya Incident can refer to one of two incidents that occurred at the Teradaya inn in Fushimi (present-day Fushimi ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture) in the suburbs of Kyoto at the end of the Edo period.

history.name: The Battle of Tatarahama
history.desc: The Battle of Tatarahama was a battle in 1336 during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

history.name: Mibu Roshi
history.desc: Mibu Roshi, or Seichu Roshi, is a predecessor of the Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

history.name: The Battle of Toba-Fushimi
history.desc: The Battle of Toba-Fushimi from January 27 to 30, 1868 was the beginning of the Boshin War, and was fought in Kamitoba (Minami Ward, Kyoto City) on the outskirts of southern Kyoto, Shimotoba, Takeda, and Fushimi (Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City).

history.name: The Tokusei uprising during the Kakitsu era
history.url: history/The Tokusei uprising during the Kakitsu era.html
history.desc: The Tokusei uprising during the Kakitsu era was a peasant uprising to demand Tokuseirei (ordering return of land sold and dissolution of debts) and occurred in Kyoto and its surroundings such as the Omi Province in 1441(the first year of the Kakitsu era).

history.name: The Heiji Rebellion
history.desc: The Heiji Rebellion (Heiji no ran), which began on January 19, 1159 in Heian period, was a coup d'etat that occurred because of antagonism among the close vassals of the retired emperor.

history.name: Tokuseirei
history.desc: The "Tokuseirei" (ordering return of land sold and dissolution of debts) was acts by the Imperial Court and the bakufu (Japanese feudal governments headed by a shogun) during the Middle Ages in Japan, from the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period.

history.name: The Shochu Incident
history.desc: The "Shochu Incident" occurred in 1324 (late Kamakura period), where a plan to overthrow the Kamakura bakufu by Emperor Godaigo was discovered beforehand and the main perpetrators were executed.

history.name: The Shishigatani-no-Inbo (Shishigatani Conspiracy)
history.desc: The Shishigatani Conspiracy was a plot to overthrow the Taira clan and occurred in Kyoto in July, 1177, during the Heian period.

history.name: The Nanbokucho-Seijun-ron
history.desc: The Nanbokucho-Seijun-ron is a debate on which of the Imperial Courts, Southern or Northern, was the legitimate dynasty during the Nanbokucho period in Japan ("jun" is the same as "uruu" and means "not legitimate but also not fake").

history.name: The Meio Incident
history.desc: The Meio Incident involved the enthronement and dethronement of the Ashikaga seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and occurred in the Muromachi period in 1493.

history.name: Maizuru Chinjufu (Maizuru Naval District)
history.desc: Maizuru Chinjufu was Chinjufu (navy base) of Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN) located in Maizuru City, Kyoto.

history.name: The Regency
history.desc: The regency is a form of government during the Heian period where actual power was long monopolized by a deputy or adviser to the emperor from Yoshifusa's line in the Fujiwara family (the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan), who was installed as a regent, a chancellor or a nairan (private inspection) from generation to generation.

history.name: Otenmon no Hen (The Otenmon Gate Incident)
history.url: history/Otenmon no Hen (The Otenmon Gate Incident).html
history.desc: The "Otenmon no Hen" (the Otenmon gate incident) was a political incident which happened in 866, in the early Heian period.

history.name: Akebonotei Jiken (Akebonotei Incident)
history.desc: Akebonotei Jiken, which occurred in Kyoto at the end of the Edo period, was an incident where a retainer of the Tosa clan was wounded and committed suicide, together with a retainer of the Aizu clan who also committed suicide with his own sword, which resulted from mis-information during an operation to arrest masterless samurai from the Choshu clan.

history.name: Songo-ikken (The Honorary Title Incident)
history.desc: Songo-ikken was a case of dissension between the Imperial Court in Kyoto and the Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government, headed by a shogun) in the later Edo period of Japan.

history.name: The Kinketsu Incident
history.desc: The Kinketsu Incident was an attack on Emperor Gohanazono's Inner Court in Kyoto that occurred in September 1443 (Muromachi period).

history.name: Sanjo-ohashi Bridge Noticeboard Incident
history.desc: Sanjo-ohashi Bridge Noticeboard Incident occurred on October 20, 1866 during the the end of the Edo Period.

history.name: Jogen no Honan
history.desc: Jogen no Honan was an incident where monks following Senju-Nenbutsu (intently praying to Buddha) led by Honen were suppressed and Honen, Shinran and other monks with central roles were exiled throughout the country.

history.name: The Jisho/Juei Rebellion
history.desc: The Jisho/Juei Rebellion was a large-scale internal rebellion that lasted for 6 years from 1180 to 1185 during the later Heian Period.

history.name: The Hokke Ikki (Hokke Riot)
history.desc: The "Hokke Ikki" is the religious riot which occurred in Kyoto, of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) around 1532, in Japan.

history.name: The Kusuko Incident
history.desc: The Kusuko Incident is an incident that occurred in the early Heian period.

history.name: Hanzei (Half Payment of Taxes)
history.desc: "Hanzei"means that the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) gave the power of collection of half of the customs or taxes on production from manors and lands under the control of the feudal government to the provincial constables.

history.name: Omiya Incident
history.desc: The Omiya Incident occurred at the end of the Edo period during the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, on December 10, 1867 (November 15 according to the old calendar) when Ryoma SAKAMOTO and Shintaro NAKAOKA were killed at Omiya, the home of Shinsuke IGUCHI in Kawara-machi, Kyoto Prefecture.

history.name: Omiya
history.desc: Omiya is a venerable soy sauce store in Kyoto.

history.name: The Southern Court (Japan)
history.desc: The Southern Court is also called the Yoshino Court and was the court belonging to Emperor Godaigo of the Daikaku-ji Temple line established in the period of Northern and Southern Courts and based in the Yoshino (present day Yoshino Town, Yoshino County, Nara Prefecture), Ano (present day Nishiyoshino Town, Gojo City, Nara Prefecture) in the province of Yamato, south of Kyoto, Sumiyoshi-angu (Sumiyoshi Ward, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture) in the province of Settsu.

history.name: The Shie Incident
history.desc: The Shie Incident occurred in the early Edo period and was a conflict between the Shogunate and the Imperial Court that shows the oppression and control exercised by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) on the Imperial Court.

history.name: Ritsuryo Law
history.desc: Ritsuryo law includes statutory laws such as; codes and ethics covering conduct, and various common laws established in the Heian period based upon ritsuryo.

history.name: Shichikyo-ochi (Seven nobles' rustication)
history.desc: "Shichikyo-ochi" was an incident where seven nobles were banished from Kyoto in the political turmoil of August 18, 1863, at the end of Edo period.

history.name: The Battle of Uji-gawa River
history.desc: The Battle of Uji-gawa River was a battle that took place in January 1184, at the end of Heian period, between MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, and MINAMOTO no Noriyori and MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune who were dispatched by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo in Kamakura.

history.name: Shoen Seiri-rei (orders given to consolidate manors)
history.url: history/Shoen Seiri-rei (orders given to consolidate manors).html
history.desc: Shoen Seiri-rei is a set of acts issued during the Heian period.

history.name: Anna Incident
history.desc: The Anna Incident was a case of ostracism caused by the Fujiwara clan against other clans that occurred during the Heian period in 969.

history.name: The Muromachi Period
history.desc: The Muromachi period (1336-1573) is a period of Japanese history spanning the length of time the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was in existence.

history.name: The Kamakura Period
history.desc: The Kamakura period (1185-1333, called "Kamakura jidai" in Japanese) describes one distinct period in Japanese history in which the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was located in the city of Kamakura.

history.name: The Shotai Conspiracy
history.desc: The Shotai Conspiracy (Shotai no hen in Japanese), which occurred in January 901, was a coup in which Emperor Daigo, acting on the false charges of FUJIWARA no Takahira, the Minister of the Left, against SUGAWARA no Michizane, the Minister of the Right, demoted Michizane and sent him into de facto exile to Dazaifu (an outpost in far off Kyushu) as Dazai Gon no Sochi (Deputy Commander of Dazaifu); also, Michizane's children as well as MINAMOTO no Yoshi, the Middle Captain of the Guardsmen of the Right, were either demoted or exiled.

history.name: The incident of Ashikaga-sandai mokuzo kyoshu
history.jp: 足利三代木像梟首事件
history.url: history/The incident of Ashikaga-sandai mokuzo kyoshu.html
history.desc: In the incident of Ashikaga-sandai mokuzo kyoshu, heads of the wooden images and the mortuary tablets of the first Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) Takauji ASHIKAGA, the second Seii taishogun Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, and the third Seii taishogun Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA were taken away from Kyoto Jito-in Temple on April 9, 1863 in the late Edo period, and were cast to the riverbed of Kamo-gawa river.

history.name: The Taira Clan Administration
history.desc: The Taira clan administration was the administration by the Ise-Taira clan led by TAIRA no Kiyomori who lived in the late Heian period (1160s to 1185).

history.name: Kawaramono (discriminated position)
history.desc: Kawaramono is also referred to as Kawarabito, and they were a type of people which were discriminated against in medieval Japan.

history.name: The Shoen-Koryo System
history.desc: The Shoen-Koryo system was a multilayered land governance structure which was grounded in shoen (manors) and lands under the control of the koryo (feudal government) in medieval times in Japan.

history.name: Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials)
history.desc: Jimoku (aka Jomoku) refers to a ceremony to appoint officials of kyokan (an official of the Capital) and gekan (a provincial official) after the mid Heian period.

history.name: Military Government
history.desc: The military government was an administration under the control of samurai.

history.name: Fushimiban
history.desc: Fushimiban are block printed books printed at the Enko-ji Temple (now Ichijoji, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City), which was established on a corner of the Fushimi School in Fushimi Ward of Yamashiro Province by order of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in the early Edo period.

history.name: The Consortium of Universities in Kyoto
history.jp: 大学コンソーシアム京都
history.url: history/The Consortium of Universities in Kyoto.html
history.desc: The Consortium of Universities in Kyoto is a foundation consisting of universities in and around Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, Japan, including Ritsumeikan University, Ryukoku University, and Doshisha University.

history.name: Bunan no Koji Sodo (Bunan-era Koji Dispute)
history.url: history/Bunan no Koji Sodo (Bunan-era Koji Dispute).html
history.desc: Bunan no Koji Sodo was an incident in which Kitano koji za (a guild in Kitano for producers of koji malt, a kind of mold grown on produce such as boiled rice), who controlled production of koji malt (which is part of the sake brewing process) in Kyoto, was attacked by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) causing its decline during the Muromachi Period.

history.name: The Battle of Fushimi Castle
history.desc: The Battle of Fushimi Castle is a preliminary skirmish of the Battle of Sekigahara, which took place from August 26, to September 8, 1600.

history.name: The Battle of Tanabe-jo Castle
history.desc: The Battle of Tanabe-jo Castle is a battle that erupted over Tanabe-jo Castle in Tango Province (present-day Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture) from August 27 to October 12, 1600.

history.name: The Arson Case of Kinkaku-ji Temple
history.url: history/The Arson Case of Kinkaku-ji Temple.html
history.desc: The Arson Case of Kinkaku-ji Temple was an arson case which occurred at Rokuon-ji Temple (commonly called Kinkaku-ji Temple) located in Kinkakuji Town, Kamigyo Ward (present-day Kita Ward), Kyoto City early on July 2, 1950.

history.name: The Northern Court (Japan)
history.desc: Hokucho (Northern Court) was the Imperial Court of the Jimyo-in line supported by many samurai led by the Ashikaga clan during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

history.name: Kanpyo no chi (Glorious rule in Kanpyo era)
history.url: history/Kanpyo no chi (Glorious rule in Kanpyo era).html
history.desc: Kanpyo no chi is the name of the rule by Emperor Uda in the mid-Heian Period (late 9th century) which was largely regarded as ideal.

history.name: Konin-Jogan Culture
history.desc: Konin-Jogan culture is considered in Japanese history to be the culture that flourished in Japan during the Konin and Jogan era of the early Heian period (about the ninth century).

history.name: Kuraryo
history.desc: The Kuraryo is an institution affiliated with the Ministry of Central Affairs of the Ritsuryo system during the Ritsuryo system period of Japan.

history.name: Pilgrimage
history.desc: A pilgrimage is a religious act of traveling to holy places.

history.name: Ibaraki Doji
history.desc: Ibaraki Doji was a Heian-period oni (a mythical creature resembling a demon or ogre) who supposedly went on a rampage in Kyoto from his lair on Mt. Oe.

history.name: Childhood Names
history.desc: The term "childhood name" (yomyo or yomei in Japanese) refers to a name for use by someone only in his childhood (this custom was more or less limited to male children).

history.name: The Yamagunitai
history.desc: The Yamagunitai (the Yamaguni Corps or Troop) was an armed force of farmers that was formed during the Bakumatsu period (a fifteen-year period, from 1853-1868, that saw the demise of the Tokugawa bakufu) in the hamlet of Yamaguni in Kuwata county of Tanba Province (the modern-day Keihoku-cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto).

history.name: Eiroku Incident
history.desc: In the Eiroku Incident, troops led by the so-called "Miyoshi Triumvirate" (Nagayuki MIYOSHI, Masayasu MIYOSHI and Tomomichi IWANARI) and Hisahide MATSUNAGA attacked and killed Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA, the 13th Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), at the then Imperial Palace in Nijo, Kyoto on Eiroku 8, the 19th day of the 5th month (according to the old calendar) (June 17, 1565).

history.name: Engikyaku
history.desc: Engikyaku, a collection of amendments to and enforcement regulations for Ritsuryo (basic national laws), was completed in November 907 (old calendar) during the Heian period and put into force by a senji (written order of the Emperor) in December of the following year (old calendar).

history.name: Ogura Incident
history.desc: The Ogura Incident was a dispute over succession of the imperial throne in which Emperor Reigen forced Ichinomiya (later Cloistered Imperial Prince Saishin), his oldest son, to become a Buddhist priest in 1681, and purged the greater imperial household of the Ogura family, Ichinomiya's maternal relatives.

history.name: Battle of Fubeyama (Mt. Fube)
history.desc: The Battle of Fubeyama (Mt. Fube) was a war between an army of the Amago clan which was directed by Yukimori YAMANAKA to reconstruct the Amago clan and the Mori clan who was attempting to prevent it.

history.name: Tango okoku ron (the theory of the Tango Kingdom)
history.url: history/Tango okoku ron (the theory of the Tango Kingdom).html
history.desc: Tango okoku ron is a theory in which Teiji KADOWAKI asserted an existence of "Tango Kingdom" in and around Tango region (present Tango City, Kyoto Prefecture) during the Kofun period (tumulus period), which is believed to have been independent and rivaled Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) (It is also referred to as "Tanba Kingdom" because Tango Province was divided from Tanba Province later).

history.name: Kanpaku Soron
history.desc: Kanpaku soron was a dispute over the position of Kanpaku (chief advisor to the Emperor) that happened between Akizane NIJO and Nobusuke KONOE in 1585.

history.name: Shinryo Kogyo
history.desc: Shinryo Kogyo was a policy implemented by the Emperor and the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a Shogun nominally appointed by the Emperor) mainly in the mid-Kamakura period to promote the performance of Shinto rituals on the basis of tenjin sokan shigo (an idea of correspondence between Heaven and Man).

history.name: Heike Nokyo
history.desc: "Heike Nokyo" is a general term representing the Buddhist scriptures donated to Itsukushima-jinja Shrine by Heike (Taira family [the same character is read Hei or Taira depending on the context]) with prayer for prosperity of the greater Taira family including Ise-Heishi.

history.name: Inokuma Incident
history.desc: The Inokuma Incident was a big scandal involving high-ranking officers of the Imperial Court in 1609 the early Edo period.

history.name: Rokuhara
history.desc: Rokuhara is a name of an area spanning from Gojo-oji Street on the east bank of Kamo-gawa River to Shichijo-oji Street in Kyoto.

history.name: Kugonin
history.desc: Kugonin was a group, during the medieval period in Japan, that belonged to the Imperial court who presented food such as special products from the mountains and the sea, and various handicraft products to the Emperor and the Imperial Family.

history.name: Shoke
history.desc: Shoke refers to a family that branched off from the head of a family or the head of a household.

history.name: Chakuryu
history.desc: Chakuryu refers to the direct line of descent from a clan.

history.name: Nikyo Jiken (Dual incidents triggered by two court nobles)
history.url: history/Nikyo Jiken (Dual incidents triggered by two court nobles).html
history.desc: The Nikyo Jiken was an abortive coup d'etat in which Michiteru OTAGI and Mitsusuke TOYAMA, nobles in joi-ha (supporters of expulsion of the foreigners), attempted to overthrow the Meiji Government in 1871.

history.name: Kaisho (meeting place) (Medieval Era)
history.desc: Kaisho, interpreted literally, was some sort of place where a meeting, exhibition, Yoriai (debate), or association was held, but developed in the medieval era in Japan where certain divisions, or even independent buildings were named 'kaisho.'

history.name: Koetsu mura (Koetsu Village)
history.desc: Koetsu mura was a village that flourished in arts and crafts, and managed by Koetsu HONAMI during the early Edo Period.

history.name: Kogi
history.desc: Kogi (also referred to as Kugi) is the term used for "official authority" in the middle and early modern ages.

history.name: Reisen
history.desc: The reisen was originally a gift money presented from Shugo Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord as provincial constable), temples and shrines in celebrations such as the appointment of Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") at the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Prince Mochihito's Uprising
history.desc: Prince Mochihito's uprising was an incident that occurred in 1180 (Jisho 4), when Prince Mochihito (also Prince Takakura and Prince Sanjo), with MINAMOTO no Yorimasa, planned to raise an army and overthrow the Taira clan (who were then in power); Mochihito issued a command urging the Minamoto clan warriors in all provinces together with the forces of the great temples and shrines to rise up against the Taira clan.

history.name: Seisei Nikki
history.desc: Seisei Nikki was a camp diary written by Tenkei, a diplomat priest of Myoshin-ji Temple, who accompanied Yukinaga KONISHI's army during the Bunroku-Keicho War.

history.name: Hachijoin-ryo (territory of Hachijo-in)
history.desc: The Hachijoin-ryo was one of the groups of shoen (manor in medieval Japan) possessed by members of the imperial family under shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in the medieval period.

history.name: Hyoro-ryosho (grant areas for the support of troops in the field)
history.url: history/Hyoro-ryosho (grant areas for the support of troops in the field).html
history.desc: Hyoro-ryosho were areas of land set aside during the medieval period and devoted to producing rations and provisions (specifically, rice) for soldiers.

history.name: Chodoin
history.desc: The Chodoin was a state chamber of the Greater Imperial Palace (called daidairi) in the palace in the ancient times.

history.name: Eikyu no goso
history.desc: The Eikyu no goso was a collective petition to the Imperial Court by a few thousand monks at the Kofuku-ji Temple on May 14, 1113, requesting Ensei, a sculptor of Buddhist statues who became a priest at Enryaku-ji Temple and was appointed to the position of the betto (the superior of a temple) of the Kiyomizu-dera Temple, a branch temple of the Kofuku-ji Temple, be dismissed from the position.

history.name: Jisho Sannen no Seihen (Coup of the Third Year of Jisho)
history.url: history/Jisho Sannen no Seihen (Coup of the Third Year of Jisho).html
history.desc: The Jisho Sannen no Seihen was an incident where TAIRA no Kiyomori led an army to conquer Kyoto and stalled the government by Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa in December (November in old lunar calendar) 1179.

history.name: In-no-hyojo
history.desc: In-no-hyojo was an agreement presided by the retired emperor or cloistered emperor during his post-retirement government.

history.name: Honjo Soemon Oboegaki
history.desc: The Honjo Soemon Oboegaki is a record sent by Soemon HONJO, a samurai serving Mitsuhide AKECHI during the Honnoji Incident, to three people who are thought to be his relatives, during his late years in the Edo period.

history.name: Nanakuchi No Seki (Seven Entrance Checkpoints)
history.desc: "Nanakuchi no seki" refers to the checkpoints which were set on the seven roads leading to Kyoto from outlying regions (Kyoto nanakuchi, Kyoto's seven entrances) during medieval times.

history.name: The Heian Nobles
history.desc: The "Heian nobles" refer to the noblemen in the Heian Period.

history.name: The Choroku–Kansei Famine
history.desc: The Choroku–Kansei Famine was a country-wide famine that struck Japan in 1459 (the third year of the Choroku era) and lasted until 1461 (the second year of the Kansei era).

history.name: The Kyoto Town Magistrate
history.desc: The Kyoto Town Magistrate was one of the ongoku-bugyo (magistrates placed at important areas) that was set up in Kyoto by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Kanshoku Hisho
history.desc: The Kanshoku Hisho was a reference book concerning the yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette) written by TAIRA no Motochika in 1200 in the early Kamakura period.

history.name: Jisho-guso
history.desc: Jisho-guso is a Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette) written by Sadamichi ISE, the military governor of Yamashiro Province in the early Sengoku Period (the Period of Warring States) in Japan.

history.name: Tsubo-sen (the tax charged on sake dealers)
history.url: history/Tsubo-sen (the tax charged on sake dealers).html
history.desc: Tsubo-sen, which was also called shuzo-yaku and sakatsubosen, was the most ancient form of the tax imposed on "Sakaya", sake dealers.

history.name: Sakaya-yaku
history.desc: Sakaya-yaku was a tax imposed upon sake breweries in Kyoto by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Hyojohajime
history.desc: Hyojohajime was a ceremony held by an influential house of medieval Japan conducted at the first consultation in the New Year.

history.name: The Incident of Honkoku-ji Temple
history.desc: The Incident of Honkoku-ji Temple, on January 31, 1569, was an attack of Miyoshi sanninshu (three chief retainers of the Miyoshi clan) on Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), who was in his temporary residence (Rokujo Palace) in Kyoto Honkoku-ji Temple (it was called 'Honkoku-ji' then).

history.name: Sanshoku suinin mondai (the question of the three alternative positions
history.url: history/Sanshoku suinin mondai (the question of the three alternative positions.html
history.desc: Sanshoku suinin mondai is a controversy in relation to the interpretation of the articles in Haretoyo KAJUJI's diary "Haretoyo-koki (summer in the 10th year of Tensho)" dated April 25 (old calendar) and May 4 (old calendar) of 1582.

history.name: Kodaireki (a chronicle)
history.desc: Kodaireki is a chronicle written between the Period of Northern and Southern Courts and the Muromachi period.

history.name: Gyaku-en
history.desc: The gyaku-en indicates the concept of not believing in the teachings of Buddha (i.e., defying the 'en', or connection with Buddha) unquestioningly or someone who can not be saved.

history.name: Famine of Yowa
history.desc: The famine of Yowa was a devastating famine that occurred in 1181.

history.name: Kamiyain
history.desc: As an affiliate department of Zushoryo (the Bureau of Drawings and Books) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), Kamiyain manufactured paper used in the Imperial Court.

history.name: Ichoku
history.desc: Ichoku refers to a charge meted out as a reuslt of not following an Emperor's command.

history.name: Shunki
history.desc: The Shunki is a diary written by the court noble FUJIWARA no Sukefusa in the Heian period.

history.name: The Heian Period
history.desc: The Heian period denotes a period of Japanese history spanning roughly 390 years, from 794 when Emperor Kanmu moved the capital to Heian Kyo (ancient Kyoto) to the establishment of the Kamakura Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in 1185.

history.name: Katagihara haiji ato (the ruins of deserted Katagihara Temple)
history.url: history/Katagihara haiji ato (the ruins of deserted Katagihara Temple).html
history.desc: Located in Katagihara in Saikyo Ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, Katagihara haiji ato are the ruins of an ancient temple, which are designated as a National Historic Site.

history.name: Battle at Makishima-jo Castle
history.desc: The Battle at Makishima-jo Castle refers to the battle which occurred between Nobunaga ODA's army and Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA's army from April (March in old lunar calendar) to August (July in old lunar calendar) in 1573.

history.name: City Ordinances on the Preservation of Vistaed View
history.jp: 京都市眺望景観創生条例
history.url: history/City Ordinances on the Preservation of Vistaed View.html
history.desc: The City Ordinances on the Preservation of Vistaed View are ordinances in Kyoto City to 'create Kyoto's surrounding scenery and vistaed views, and preserve them for future generations' (Article 1).

history.name: Ezo, Emishi or Ebisu
history.desc: Ezo (also referred to as "Emishi" or "Ebisu") is an appellation for the people who once lived in the eastern and northern areas of what is now Japan, and who were considered by the Japanese to belong to a different ethnic group.

history.name: Japanese History
history.desc: Nihon-no-rekisi (literally, Japanese history) or Nihonshi (literally, Japan history) is used for indicating history of Japan or that of the Japanese archipelago.

history.name: Kimigayo (Reign of Your Majesty)
history.desc: Kimigayo is Japan's National Anthem.

history.name: Kokufu-bunka
history.desc: Kokufu-bunka is one of the Japanese historical cultures.

history.name: Bakufu
history.desc: Bakufu refers to the government office of military rule or samurai government itself; however, there are some exceptions, such as, the Taira clan government and the Shokuho government (the government of Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI. "Shoku" and "ho" are the initial letters of Oda and Toyotomi).

history.name: Japanese missions to Tang China
history.desc: Japanese missions to Tang China were diplomatic missions sent to Tang China by Japan, as described in the "Old Book of Tang" and the "New Book of Tang."

history.name: Fushu (barbarians)
history.desc: The Fushu were Emishi who lived in the provinces of Mutsu and Dewa and came under the control of the Imperial Court.

history.name: Bushi
history.desc: Bushi (武士, mononofu, samurai) existed from the 10th century to the 19th century and was a member of a family community whose top was the master of Soke (the head family) and whose profession was a warrior.

history.name: Samurai
history.desc: "Samurai" is the positional title for officials in Japan from the ancient to middle ages, and an alternative name for "bushi" (warrior) that was derived from the first meaning.

history.name: Arahabaki
history.desc: Arahabaki belief is a folk belief found in the Tohoku region.

history.name: Konpira
history.desc: Konpira (金毘羅) is a water god and demon god of Mt. Ryojusen in India, and is the head of the Juni Shinsho (the twelve protective deities) of Yakushi Nyorai (the Healing Buddha).

history.name: The Oei Invasion
history.desc: The Oei Invasion (known in Korea as the Gihae Eastern Expedition, with Gihae being a reference to the year 1419) refers to a raid on the Japanese island of Tsushima by Joseon Korean forces that occurred in 1419 (the 26th year of the Oei era, from which the Japanese name is taken), meaning that it took place during the Muromachi period according to the standard classification of Japanese history.

history.name: Tonden
history.desc: Tonden

history.name: Za
history.desc: The za, established mainly by merchants, manufacturers and entertainers, refers to the guilds that existed from the Heian period to the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

history.name: Jokamachi
history.desc: Jokamachi (castle towns) were cities that were established with the lord's castle in the center.

history.name: Sengoku Period (period of warring states) (Japan)
history.desc: The Sengoku Period in Japan (from around 1493 (or 1467) to around 1573) is a chronological period in the history of Japan that commenced from the Coup of Meio in 1493 or the Onin Disturbance in 1467 and ended by the disappearance of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) with the purge of Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA by Nobunaga ODA, the fifteenth shogun, of the Muromachi bakufu, in 1573.

history.name: Shoen
history.desc: Shoen refers to the privately owned or managed land which was over a certain scale and not under public governance (or limiting the public governance as much as possible).

history.name: Military Aristocracy
history.desc: The military aristocracy consisted of aristocrats specialized in military affairs who emerged in history in the late ancient period through the early medieval period.

history.name: Taiko-kenchi (the land survey by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI)
history.url: history/Taiko-kenchi (the land survey by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI).html
history.desc: The Taiko-kenchi is a series of land surveys (surveys of agricultural lands [i.e. except mountains and forests] and production) conducted by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI throughout Japan.

history.name: Rakuichi-rakuza
history.desc: Rakuichi-rakuza (free markets and open guilds) was an economic policy implemented in the markets of government controlled areas such as castle towns by the Shokuho government (the government of Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) and the Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) during the early modern period (16th century to 18th century) in Japan.

history.name: Ashigaru
history.desc: Ashigaru (common foot soldiers) were a type of low-ranking soldier.

history.name: Tsuchi Uprising (Tsuchi-ikki or Do-ikki)
history.desc: The term "tsuchi uprising" (called tsuchi-ikki or do-ikki in Japanese) refers to political appeals by the masses which had occurred from the middle to the late Muromachi period.

history.name: Shinbutsu-bunri (Separation of Buddhism and Shintoism)
history.desc: Shinbutsu-bunri is to prohibit conventional syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism and to distinguish between Shintoism and Buddhism, Kami (Shinto) and Buddha, and shrines and temples.

history.name: Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku
history.desc: Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku (The True History of Three Reigns of Japan) is a Japanese history text compiled during the Heian period and completed in the year 901.

history.name: Nihongi Ryaku
history.desc: Nihongi Ryaku (Summary of Japanese Chronologies) is a Japanese history text compiled during the Heian period which contains excerpts from Rikkokushi (the Six National Histories) and details of the history from the completion of Rikkokushi until the reign of Emperor Goichijo.

history.name: The National Anthem of Japan
history.desc: Japan's national anthem is called 'Kimigayo.'

history.name: Ochimusha
history.desc: An ochimusha is a samurai of a defeated army who survives and flees from the war.

history.name: Zaibatsu (a financial clique or group, or a company syndicate)
history.url: history/Zaibatsu (a financial clique or group, or a company syndicate).html
history.desc: The word Zaibatsu means a tremendous exclusive capitalist or enterprise of the pre-disposition of the era of financial cliques, but generally it is defined as a business group in which a parent company (holding company) capitalized by a family or its kinship forms the core of the group and has its subsidiaries run a variety of businesses, some of which hold monopoly positions in their respective fields or industries.

history.name: Shinchogumi
history.desc: The Shinchogumi was a security force established by the Edo bakufu (a Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in 1862, during the late Edo period.

history.name: Busho
history.desc: Busho refers to those who stood out among people engaged in military affairs, such as a military officer and a samurai.

history.name: Kosa
history.desc: Kosa indicates the following weather phenomenon: Dust in inland deserts or dry zones in eastern Asia centered around People's Republic of China, is flung up into the air, for example, by a sandstorm, and is carried and falls over a wide area of eastern Asia centered around spring.

history.name: Yoshida dormitory of Kyoto University
history.desc: Yoshida dormitory of Kyoto University is one of Kyoto University's dormitories.

history.name: The Meitoku War
history.desc: The Meitoku War was a war against the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) that was started by the Yamana clan members, such as Ujikiyo YAMANA and Mitsuyuki YAMANA, in 1391 during the Muromachi period.

history.name: Buke (Samurai Families)
history.desc: The word "buke" refers to the collection of various powers which support the authority of a bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and this word sometimes also refers to a Shogun family or general samurai.

history.name: Toiya
history.desc: Toiya (Tonya) refers to a wholesale agent as a general meaning used today; it has different meanings, however, if it is used in the context of history or the law.

history.name: Nakasendai War
history.desc: The Nakasendai War was a rebellion that occurred in July 1335 in which Tokiyuki HOJO, a bereaved son of Takatoki HOJO (the 14th shikken [shogunal regent] of the Kamakura bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]), raised an army, with the support of Yorishige SUWA (the period of Northern and Southern Courts) of Shinano Province, with the aim to restore the Kamakura bakufu.

history.name: Kondei (regular soldiers guarding the Kokubu (ancient provincial offices) or Sekisho (checking station))
history.url: history/Kondei (regular soldiers guarding the Kokubu (ancient provincial offices) or Sekisho (checking stati.html
history.desc: "Kondei" means well-equipped cohorts, which were organized as local military forces from the Nara period through the Heian period.

history.name: Sanpo War
history.desc: The Sanpo War was a rebellion occurred in Gyeongsang Province, Korea, in 1510, provoked by the So clan, who was the shugo (military governor) of Tsushima Province, and kokyowa (Japanese residents who settled down in Korea with keeping Japanese nationality).

history.name: Shinsen Shojiroku (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility)
history.url: history/Shinsen Shojiroku (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility).html
history.desc: Shinsen Shojiroku is an ancient clan-name register or directory that was compiled by an order from Emperor Saga in the early Heian period.

history.name: Japanese education history
history.desc: Japanese education history deals with the state and history of Japanese education from ancient times to the modern age; additionally, it deals with the transition of educational philosophy, teaching materials and systems.

history.name: Ikki (Uprising)
history.desc: The term "ikki" refers to an attempt made by a community in Japan to achieve an objective when members of the community that share the same sentiment work closely together for a certain reason.

history.name: Kenchi
history.desc: The term "Kenchi" refers to the surveys of field size and size of yield (harvest) conducted during medieval and early modern Japan.

history.name: Ikko Ikki
history.desc: Ikko ikki (literally, "Ikko-sect riot") is a general term for riots during Japan's Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan) caused by followers of the Hongan-ji Temple branch within the Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), which was also called the "Ikko" or "only one direction (to heaven)" sect.

history.name: Battle of Minatogawa
history.desc: The Battle of Minatogawa was fought on July 12, 1336 during the period of Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) in Minatogawa, Settsu Province (modern day Chuo Ward/Hyogo Ward, Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture) between the forces of the brothers Takauji and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA who had traveled east from Kyushu and Yoshisada NITTA and Masashige KUSUNOKI who were loyal to Emperor Godaigo.

history.name: The Local Bureaucratic System of Ancient Japan
history.url: history/The Local Bureaucratic System of Ancient Japan.html
history.desc: The local bureaucratic system was formed into a three-tier administrative organization of kuni (provinces), gun/kori (districts) and ri/sato (villages) under the Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code) enacted in the year 701.

history.name: Kamakurafu
history.desc: The Kamakurafu was a government office which the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) established in the Northern and Southern courts period and the Muromachi period for the purpose of ruling the Kanto region.

history.name: Ashikaga no Sho
history.desc: Ashikaga no sho was a shoen (manor) that was located in Ashikaga County, Shimotsuke Province (Ashikaga City, Tochigi Prefecture).

history.name: Peasants' Uprising of the Shocho Era
history.url: history/Peasants Uprising of the Shocho Era.html
history.desc: The peasants' uprising of the Shocho era was an uprising that occurred between August and September, 1428 in the Muromachi period.

history.name: Takigawa Incident
history.desc: The Takigawa Incident was a crackdown on freedom of thought that occurred at the Kyoto Imperial University in 1933.

history.name: Toimaru (specialized wholesale merchant)
history.desc: "Toimaru" were organizations specialized in transport, warehousing and commission sales, which based themselves in cities by the rivers and ports where nengumai (rice paid as land tax) was unloaded.

history.name: Nengu (Land Tax)
history.desc: Nengu is a Japanese historical terminology referring to a type of taxation.

history.name: Saimen no Bushi (group of warriors guarding west side of imperial palace)
history.url: history/Saimen no Bushi (group of warriors guarding west side of imperial palace).html
history.desc: "Saimen no Bushi" referred to a group of warriors who attended Daijo-tenno (the Retired Emperor) by guarding and serving the emperor during the Kamakura period.

history.name: Terakoya
history.desc: Terakoya were educational institutes for ordinary citizens during the Edo period.

history.name: Taibon Sankajo
history.desc: Taibon Sankajo refers to the fundamental authorities of Shugo (provincial constable) in the Kamakura and Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Chosen Tsushinshi (the Korean Emissary)
history.desc: Chosen Tsushinshi is the name of envoys dispatched by Yi Dynasty Korea to Japan.

history.name: Kubunden (a term related to fields)
history.desc: Kubunden indicates a field supplied uniformly to common people in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Zuryo (The Head of The Provincial Governors)
history.url: history/Zuryo (The Head of The Provincial Governors).html
history.desc: "Zuryo" (受領) is a Japanese historical terminology referring to provincial governors.

history.name: Kimitezuri
history.desc: Kimitezuri is commonly regarded as a guardian god of the Ryukyu Kingdom that rules the sea and the sun.

history.name: Monchujo
history.desc: The Monchujo was a government body of the Kamakura and Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), which was responsible for judicial affairs.

history.name: Kendan-sata (criminal cases)
history.desc: "Kendan-sata" is a term used in medieval Japan, referring to lawsuits and trials relating to criminal cases.

history.name: Shomusata (trial dealing with land-related issues)
history.desc: "Shomusata" is a term used in medieval Japan referring to disputes, suits, and trials over shoryo (territory) and nengu (land tax).

history.name: Zatsumusata
history.desc: Zatsumusata is a term that was used in medieval Japan, referring to civil dispute, suit, and trial except for territory and land tax.

history.name: Kagemusha
history.desc: "Kagemusha" (the body double) is a person, during the Sengoku period (the period of warring states), employed by a busho (a Japanese military commander) as his straw man dressed in the identical clothes as his.

history.name: Matsugo Yoshi
history.desc: The term "Matsugo yoshi" refers to a son who was adopted on his adoptive father's deathbed.

history.name: Inzen (a decree from the retired Emperor)
history.url: history/Inzen (a decree from the retired Emperor).html
history.desc: "Inzen" is a document which an Inshi (official of the In no cho, or Retired Emperor's Office) issues in a format of hosho (a document informing a decision of the upper ranked personages such as an emperor or shogun) upon direct orders from Daijo Tenno (the Retired Emperor).

history.name: Ruiju Kokushi
history.desc: Ruiju Kokushi, completed and established in 892, is a history book edited by SUGAWARA no Michizane, which classified and recompiled the entries of six classical Japanese history texts compiled in chronological order, following the example of Leishu ("classified books") in China.

history.name: Honcho Seiki
history.desc: Honcho Seiki refers to the history book compiled during the late Heian period.

history.name: Genko no Ran (Genko Incident)
history.desc: Genko no Ran was an anti-Kamakura bakufu movement broke out in 1331.

history.name: Japanese Race
history.desc: The term "Japanese race" expresses a notion of a political community (nation) which embodies all cultural groups (ethnic groups) that possess a Japanese nationality and/or roots in the Japanese archipelago.

history.name: Identification of severed heads
history.desc: In feudal days of old, lower ranked samurai took the heads severed from the bodies of foes killed on the battlefield to their commanders for identification called "Kubi jikken"; this activity took place because a severed head was crucial piece of identification evidence leading to conferring of honors on lower ranking samurai.

history.name: Yamato Monogatari
history.desc: Yamato Monogatari (literally, "Tales of Yamato") is a story of the Middle Ages of Japan, written in the Heian period.

history.name: Ise shonin
history.desc: Ise shonin (Ise merchants) were counted among the three major Japanese merchants along with Osaka shonin (Osaka merchants) and Omi shonin (Omi merchants).

history.name: The Uprising in Yamashiro Province
history.desc: Yamashiro no kuniikki (the uprising in Yamashiro Province) occurred in three southern counties (Kuse-gun, Tsuzuki-gun and Soraku-gun) of Yamashiro Province (currently the southern part of Kyoto Prefecture) in 1485.

history.name: Basara
history.desc: "Basara" is a word which expressed the social and cultural trends during the Northern and Southern Courts period (in the Japanese medieval period), which was actually used as a vogue word at that time.

history.name: Japan-Ming trade
history.desc: The Japan-Ming trade indicates the trade carried on between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China in the Muromachi period.

history.name: Tonoi
history.desc: Tonoi was to guard the Imperial Palace, Kanshi (government officials) and the nobility under the ancient Ritsuryo Code (criminal and civil laws).

history.name: Warrior class
history.desc: The warrior class was a status given to hatamoto (a direct vassal of the shogun) and high-ranking warriors of the Edo period after the Meiji Restoration.

history.name: In no cho kudashibumi
history.desc: In no cho kudashibumi were the documents issued by Incho (Retired Emperor's Office) during the Insei (government by cloistered emperor) during the Heian period.

history.name: Daijokanpu
history.desc: Daijokanpu (also known as Dajokanpu) were official documents issued by Daijokan (Grand Council of State) to lower agencies and Kokuga (local offices of the state) under the Ritsuyo system (ancient government system).

history.name: Shinden
history.desc: A Shinden (also referred as Kanda) is a rice field whose produce is used to pay for the costs of a Shinto shrine's Saishi (religious services).

history.name: Kakitsu Treaty
history.desc: Kakitsu Treaty was a trade agreement concluded between Korean Dynasties and Sadamori SO of Tsushima Province in 1443, the Muromachi period in Japan.

history.name: Kokugaryo
history.desc: Kokugaryo is a historical term referring to koryo (an Imperial demesne) after around the mid-Heian period, differentiated from shoen (manor in medieval Japan).

history.name: Wakan
history.desc: Wakan (왜관) was a foreign settlement for Japanese people established at the Southern area of Korean Peninsula from the medieval to modern period of Japan, or in the Yi Dynasty Korea period (Korean Dynasties period).

history.name: Handen Shuju-no-ho
history.desc: "Handen Shuju-no-ho" (the law of periodic reallocations of rice land) was a legal system related to provision and expropriation of agricultural land (rice land), enforced in ancient Japan.

history.name: So-Yo-Cho
history.desc: So-Yo-Cho (a tax system, corvee) was a tax system under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) adopted in China and Japan.

history.name: So
history.desc: So as well as Zei are the goods and services that the government collect to ensure public finance for the nation.

history.name: Machi-shu
history.desc: Machi-shu (also known as Cho-shu) was a class consisting of wealthy commercial and industrial men, including doso (pawnbrokers and moneylenders), in Kyoto from the Muromachi period to the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in Japan.

history.name: Ryoke
history.desc: Ryoke is a term used in the context of Japanese shoen (manor in medieval Japan) to represent a lord of the shoen, donated by Kaihatsu-ryoshu (local notables who actually developed the land).

history.name: Kaihatsu-Ryoshu
history.desc: Kaihatsu-ryoshu (also pronounced as Kaihotsu-ryoshu) were those who owned the lands they developed as their territories in Shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in Japan.

history.name: Honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor)
history.desc: Among honke and ryoke, both of which are the lords of the manor of Nihon-shoen (manor in medieval Japan), honjo was the lord that had the right to assert Shomu (management and control of encouragement of agriculture, taxes and so on in shoen), or in other words, had the effective dominion over the shoen.

history.name: The Ningbo War
history.desc: The Ningbo War (also referred as Neiha War) was an incident caused by Japanese nationals in Ningbo in Ming Dynasty China in 1523.

history.name: Chugaisho
history.desc: Chugaisho is a collection of narrative recordings during the times under cloistered rule.

history.name: Fukego
history.desc: Fukego or Fukegodan are the quotations from FUJIWARA no Tadazane (1078 - 1162), Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor), otherwise known as Fuke-dono.

history.name: Onmyoryo
history.desc: The Onmyoryo was one of the bureaus in Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Omi shonin
history.desc: Omi shonin refers to merchants from the Omi Province (present-day Shiga Prefecture) who were active from the Kamakura period through to Edo, Meiji, Taisho and Showa periods.

history.name: Fukuhara-kyo (Capital of Fukuhara)
history.desc: Fukuhara-kyo is the name of a capital city which TAIRA no Kiyomori wanted to establish and promoted after a plan to build Wada-kyo had ended in failure 1180 (towards the end of Heian period).

history.name: Hanshi
history.desc: Hanshi were samurai who served Edo period clans.

history.name: Daigaku-ryo
history.desc: The Daigaku-ryo was a set of educational institutions that was founded under the Ritsuryo system to train government officials, which was controlled directly by Shikibu-sho (the Ministry of Ceremonies - equivalent to today's National Personnel Authority).

history.name: Tenyakuryo
history.desc: The Tenyakuryo (Bureau of Medicine) was an institution established under Japan's Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code); specifically, it was under the purview of the Kunaisho (Imperial Household Agency) of the Ritsuryo system, and was the bureau responsible for giving medical care and providing doses of medicine.

history.name: Jin no Sadame
history.desc: The Jin no Sadame was a type of privy council in use by regency governments during the Heian period.

history.name: Bunkoku
history.desc: "Bunkoku" is a unit used to delineate province-sized areas during the medieval period in Japan.

history.name: Doso
history.desc: Doso (also pronounced tokura or tsuchikura) were moneylenders during the Kamakura and Muromachi periods.

history.name: Chosan
history.desc: Chosan was means of resistance and forms of struggle waged by farmers in Japan from the middle ages to the early modern period.

history.name: Kaito Shokoku-ki
history.desc: "Kaito Shokoku-ki" (lit. Record of the Eastern Nations) is a historic book about Japan and the Ryukyu Kingdom written in classical Chinese by Joseon Dynasty minister Suk-ju SHIN.

history.name: Sakimori
history.desc: Sakimori was a military system carried out under in ancient China and in Japan under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) from the Asuka period to the Heian period.

history.name: Dogo
