history.desc: In a broad sense, dogo refers to 'specific small local clans' as opposed to large regional clans which control wide territories.

history.name: Kugutsu
history.desc: Kugutsu were groups of people who traveled around the country and made a living in the performing arts, appearing on the records from around the ninth century.

history.name: Ocho Period
history.desc: The Ocho period (Dynastic period) is a Japanese historical period.

history.name: Soson (a community comprising a self-governing association of peasants)
history.url: history/Soson (a community comprising a self-governing association of peasants).html
history.desc: A soson meant a community (in the form of a village) organized through autonomous, territorial connections among peasants in medieval Japan.

history.name: Hoan-den
history.desc: Hoan-den was the premises where portraits of the emperor and empress (called "goshin-ei portrait") and the Imperial Rescript on Education were housed before and during the war.

history.name: Buei Sodo
history.desc: The Buei Sodo was an internal conflict that occurred within the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in 1465.

history.name: The Jowa Incident
history.desc: The Jowa Incident is believed to be the first incident to expulse other clans from the Imperial Court plotted by the Fujiwara clan in the early Heian period.

history.name: Katakiuchi (Revenge)
history.desc: Katakiuchi is the practice of taking out one's revenge, by taking the law into his own hands, against someone who has killed a direct ancestor of the avenging party.

history.name: Nanori
history.desc: Kanji character readings used in Japanese people's names which differ from the standard on-yomi (Sino-Japanese reading) and kun-yomi (native Japanese reading).

history.name: So-okite
history.desc: So-okite was a statute defined independently by peasants within a soson (a community consisting of peasants' self-governing association) in medieval Japan.

history.name: Jigeuke
history.desc: Jigeuke was a system in which village communities of medieval Japan undertook the task of feudal lords to collect nengu (land tax) to be paid to shoen (manor in medieval Japan) or Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office).

history.name: Ji-zamurai
history.desc: Ji-zamurai is a rank of samurai seen from Muromachi period to Azuchi Momoyama period.

history.name: Jikendan
history.desc: Jikendan (voluntary ruling and judging) refers to rural communities in medieval Japan such as soson (a community consisting of peasants' self-governing association) and goson (autonomous village) that conduct a kendan (trial) by themselves.

history.name: Suiko
history.desc: Suiko (government loans made to peasants) was a term that indicated the loans carrying interest observed in ancient and medieval Japan.

history.name: Engi no Chi
history.desc: Engi no chi is an idealized name of the reign of Emperor Daigo during the mid-Heian period (during the first half of the 10th century).

history.name: Tenryaku no Chi
history.desc: Tenryaku no Chi describes the idealized political reign of the Emperor Murakami in mid-Heian period (in the mid-10th century).

history.name: Myoden
history.desc: The term 'myoden' (rice field lot manage by a nominal holder) refers to a basic unit of the governance and (tax) collection in the shoen-koryo system (the system of public lands and private estates), and this existed from the mid-Heian period, throughout the Middle Ages in Japan.

history.name: Ichien Chigyo
history.desc: Ichien Chigyo was a term used during the Japanese Middle Ages to mean that a particular individual has integrated control over lands in complicated and multi-layered relationships of dominance and rights of the Shoen Koryo (public lands and private estates) system.

history.name: Ikkoku Heikinyaku
history.desc: Ikkoku heikinyaku refers to land taxes and assignments evenly imposed on shoen (manor) and kokugaryo (territories governed by a provincial government office) of a particular province during the Middle Ages in Japan.

history.name: Kanno
history.desc: Kanno is a general term in the history of Japan for the overall acts by which the rulers typically promoted and encouraged agriculture.

history.name: Kajishi
history.desc: The term Kajishi (加地子) means rice (sakutokumai) delivered as a tax to a resident land-owner like myoshu (owner of rice fields) in the Japanese medieval period on top of nengu (customs)/jishi (land tax) for the lord of shoen (manor)/kokuga (provincial government officials) (kokushi (provincial governor)).

history.name: Tato
history.desc: Tato means the wealthy farmer class that managed rice fields belonging to shoen (manor) or kokugaryo (rice fields governed by provincial government office) during Japan's Heian period.

history.name: Bitasen
history.desc: Bitasen was a coin of very poor quality among those circulated during late Medieval Japan.

history.name: Erizeni
history.desc: Erizeni (also called erisen or sensen) indicates the act of not accepting low-quality coins (called bitasen coins or akusen coins) in payments, carried out in the latter half of the medieval period in Japan.

history.name: Jiden fields
history.desc: Jiden (also called terada) fields indicate, in Japan, rice fields whereby output was used for operating Buddhist temples.

history.name: Myojitaito
history.desc: Myojitaito is a term indicating the social status of samurai during the Edo period.

history.name: People Discriminated Against in the Medieval Japan
history.url: history/People Discriminated Against in the Medieval Japan.html
history.desc: In this section, people who were discriminated against in the medieval Japan are described.

history.name: Shugo-ryogoku system
history.desc: The shugo-ryogoku system (the system that a shugo [a provincial military governor] dominates a territory) is a historical concept indicating a comprehensive control system of a territory by the shugo-daimyo (shugo that became daimyo, Japanese feudal lords) in the Muromachi period.

history.name: Mokkotsu ho
history.desc: Mokkotsu ho is one of the techniques in Oriental painting.

history.name: Goteni
history.desc: Goteni (御典医) were doctors who belonged to Tenyakuryo (the Bureau of Medicine) in the Imperial Court, and were simply called teni.

history.name: Geyujo
history.desc: A geyujo is a document that, when an officer in a position is replaced with another person under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in ancient Japan, was issued confirming the change necessary for continuing office duties.

history.name: Kotaishiki
history.desc: Kotaishiki indicates the laws concerns the replacement of a government officer with a new officer under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan, matters necessary for continuing the duties of the office and how they should be handed over to the successor.

history.name: Chigyo
history.desc: Chigyo is a history-related concept indicating a territory-controlling right executed by territorial lords during the medieval period and early-modern times in Japan.

history.name: Yonin
history.desc: 遥任 (yonin) (the expression of 遙任 was also used sometimes) indicates that the person who was appointed to a kokushi (governor) of a province did not live in the province.

history.name: Nanbanboeki
history.desc: Nanbanboeki indicates trade that was carried on between merchants in Japan and those in Spain or Portugal during the era from around the middle of sixteenth century to the early seventeenth century.

history.name: Goon (favors) and hoko (services)
history.desc: Goon and hoko indicate factors and concepts that constituted master-servant relationships among samurai during medieval Japan.

history.name: Zaichokanjin
history.desc: Zaichokanjin is a general term for a local government official who undertakes the practical business of kokuga (local area) administration from the Heian period to the Kamakura period in Japan.

history.name: Heinobunri
history.desc: Heinobunri indicates the disarming of the classes pushed forward during the period from the Azuchi-Momoyama through Edo periods except for the samurai (warrior) class.

history.name: Myoshu
history.desc: Myoshu (village headmen) were a class of people who were commissioned to manage the cultivation of farmland called myoden by lords of Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) and manors during the late Ancient period and the Middle Ages in Japan.

history.name: Gunchujo
history.desc: Gunchujo were documents that proved participation in battles and other military exploits in medieval Japan.

history.name: Engi, Tenryaku no chi
history.desc: Engi, Tenryaku no chi is the magnificent imperial reign name for the reigns of Emperor Daigo and Emperor Murakami in the mid Heian Period (the 10th century).

history.name: The Gangyo War
history.desc: The Gangyo War, which occurred in the Heian period, was a rebellion by the Ifu, or less assimilated Emishi (unassimilated northerners) under the rule of the Imperial Court.

history.name: Buke hokonin
history.desc: Buke hokonin literally means a person who served a samurai family.

history.name: Ban Dainagon Ekotoba
history.desc: Ban Dainagon Ekotoba or Tomo no Dainagon Ekotoba is a narrative picture scroll depicting the Otenmon Incident at the end of the Heian period.

history.name: The Tosho-ji War
history.desc: The Tosho-ji War was a battle fought in Kamakura (the present Kamakura City), Sagami Province in 1333, at the end of Kamakura period.

history.name: Tanritsu
history.desc: The term "Tanritsu" refers to Tanritsu Shukyo Dantai (an independent religious organization).

history.name: Kangofu
history.desc: Kangofu was a tally or trading license issued by the Ming dynasty and used in trade, such as the Ming-Japanese trade, to confirm authorized tribute and trade ships between the Ming dynasty and a tributary state.

history.name: Chotoku Coup
history.desc: The Chotoku Coup, occurred after FUJIWARA no Michinaga received Nairan no senji (an imperial edict to appoint a person to the position of Nairan, who has a right to read and deal with documents before reporting to the Emperor from Daijokan, the Great Council of State), after the death of FUJIWARA no Michitaka on May 17, 995.

history.name: Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle
history.desc: The Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle was a battle that occurred from 1542 to 1543 and from 1565 to 1566 over Gassan Toda-jo Castle located in Izumo Province (present-day Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture) which was the base of the Amago clan.

history.name: Taisaku
history.desc: Taisaku is:

history.name: Ryoji
history.desc: Ryoji refers to a document issued under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code by princes, empresses, etc.) for conveying orders of princes and three sango (Grand Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager, and Empress).

history.name: Fumyo
history.desc: Fumyo means a form of collecting tax or a contractor for collecting tax under the system of the dynasty state which began sometime around the Heian period of Japan.

history.name: Kokushi Kasei Joso
history.desc: Kokushi kasei joso refers to acts and phenomena of appeals and armed struggles by Gunji (local magistrates), Tato (cultivators), Fumyo (tiller of the public rice field), and the farmer class in order to complain to the central government Daijokan (Grand Council of State) about tyrannies and illegal behaviors of Kokushi (or Zuryo) (provincial governors), Chihokan (local officials) during the Heian period in Japan.

history.name: The Battle of Tatenawate
history.desc: The Battle of Tatenawate was a war that took place in 1530 over hegemony of Kitakyushu between two daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States): the Ouchi clan of Suo Province and Shoni clan of Hizen Province.

history.name: Sanshin-shichiso
history.desc: Sanshin-shichiso is a general term for port cities of Sanshin and Shichiso defined as Japan's ten most important ports and harbors in "Kaisen Shikimoku," --the Oldest Sea Law of Japan established in the late Muromachi period.

history.name: Egoshu
history.desc: Egoshu (or Kaigoshu) (wealthy merchants who led self-governing organizations in cities from the Muromachi to the Azuchi-Momoyama period) are consultation organizations, or is a term that refers to the members of this organization which possessed a leading role in the self-government of cities from the Muromachi to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

history.name: Kueiden
history.desc: Kueiden, in a broad sense, is a term used in Japanese history and means lands directly managed by the government while Shieiden (Private land) was managed by private citizens.

history.name: Daimon
history.desc: Daimon is a type of Japanese kimono for males.

history.name: Sakaya
history.desc: Sakaya indicates an operator of the sake-producing/selling business that started in the Kamakura period.

history.name: Wamyo Ruijusho
history.desc: Wamyo Ruijusho is a dictionary compiled in the mid Heian period.

history.name: Nyobona
history.desc: Nyobona was a name that a nyobo (a court lady) called herself in attendance.

history.name: Suo
history.desc: Suo is a kind of Japanese kimono.

history.name: Jinaicho
history.desc: Jinaicho (also called Jinaimachi) refers to self-governing communities formed during the Muromachi period, which centered on the Buddhist temples of the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) and training seminaries (gobo).

history.name: Karita-rozeki
history.desc: Karita-rozeki or Katta-rozeki (刈田狼藉) means to harvest rice crops illegally in order to claim chigyo (tenure) to land# in medieval Japan.

history.name: Shisetsu Jungyo
history.desc: Shisetsu jungyo was a on-site procedure to carry out a judgment which was handed down by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) on shoryo soron (litigation over real estate) in the medieval Japan.

history.name: Kanpyo gyoki
history.desc: Kanpyo gyoki is the Emperor Uda's diary.

history.name: Kabunakama
history.desc: Kabunakama was a type of guild formed as a cartel by warehouse merchants.

history.name: Jomen ho
history.desc: Jomen ho is one of the methods of land tax collection in the Edo period.

history.name: Tsukuda
history.desc: Tsukuda was a rice field directly managed by lord of the manors, shokan (an officer governing manor) or jito (manager and lord of manor) in shoen koryo sei (System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in medieval Japan.

history.name: The second battle of Kizugawaguchi
history.jp: 第二次木津川口の戦い
history.desc: The second battle of Kizugawaguchi was a naval battle between the Mori clan and the Oda clan that occurred on December 14, 1578.

history.name: Mokudai
history.desc: Mokudai was a deputy, such as a retainer, sent to the post in behalf of an appointed provincial governor who remained at his place from mid Heian period to Kamakura period.

history.name: Kenin
history.desc: Kenin refers to a vassal, a servant, etc. of high-ranked people in Japanese history.

history.name: Fuchin
history.desc: Fuchin is a weight put on the tip of a roller of kakejiku (hanging scroll).

history.name: Tanhaku
history.desc: Tanhaku (also called shohaku) is a business custom which had been conducted in East Asia before the early modern times; with this custom, a bundle of copper coins consisting of a certain number of coins less than 100 is treated as equal value to 100 copper coins.

history.name: Naiyakushi
history.desc: Naiyakushi was one of the agencies that belonged to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: The Battle of Hakone and Takenoshita
history.url: history/The Battle of Hakone and Takenoshita.html
history.desc: The Battle of Hakone and Takenoshita was a battle between the Takauji ASHIKAGA forces and Yoshisada NITTA forces that broke out on February 1, 1336 during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

history.name: Dynastic Polity
history.desc: The term "Dynastic polity" is the historical notion which refers to Japan's state regime in a transitional period during which it was in the process of transition from the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo code) to the medieval national polity.

history.name: Togu-No-Fu (an official in charge of education of the Crown Prince)
history.url: history/Togu-No-Fu (an official in charge of education of the Crown Prince).html
history.desc: Togu-no-fu was a kind of educational officer that worked for the Togu (Crown Prince) as stipulated in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Gakkanin
history.desc: Gakkanin is a type of Daigaku-besso (academic facility for nobles) that belongs to Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education under the ritsuryo system).

history.name: Kamon (family)
history.desc: Family, clan

history.name: Nobutane-Kyo-Ki
history.desc: Nobutane-kyo-ki is a diary written by a court noble, Nobutane NAKANOMIKADO, who lived in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

history.name: Goshuin
history.desc: Goshuin is a stamp that is given at a shrine or a temple.

history.name: Jishi
history.desc: Jishi, also called chishi, (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system) referred to the land rent which feudal lords imposed on rice fields, fields (for fruits, vegetables, etc.), mountains and forest, salt fields, or residential areas from ancient and medieval periods to the early-modern times.

history.name: Shiki System
history.desc: The shiki system is the term to indicate the stratified ruling structure in medieval Japan.

history.name: Kyoto Gakuren Jiken
history.desc: Kyoto Gakuren Jiken (Kyoto Affair of the Student Federation) was a suppression incident occurring on and after December 1925 against the left wing student movement in the Kyoto Imperial University and so forth.

history.name: Utaryo
history.desc: Utaryo (Bureau of Traditional Music) was an organization belonging to the Jibusho (the ministry of civil administration) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Togu Gakushi
history.desc: Togu gakushi were one of the educational officers who served the Crown Prince (Togu) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Tsujigiri
history.desc: Tsujigiri stands for the action of a samurai who indiscriminately kills a passers-by with his blade on the street and was observed most frequently during the Edo period.

history.name: Honke
history.desc: Honke is a nominal owner of the highest-graded patches of land under the stratified land ruling structure of Japanese Shoen (refer to the Shiki system in the shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates) section).

history.name: Zoyo
history.desc: The zoyo tax system was one in which taxes were paid in the form of labor, under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in China and Japan.

history.name: Kyujin
history.desc: Kyujin (upper class retainers)

history.name: Gofun
history.desc: Gofun is a kind of pigment.

history.name: Roto
history.desc: Roto (郎党; retainer) or rodo was a family member or a follower of his master's house in the samurai society of medieval Japan.

history.name: Kachi
history.desc: The term Kachi means lower class warriors who fought on foot.

history.name: Shuinchi/Kokuinchi
history.desc: The term Shuinchi/Kokuinchi means the lands which were secured (approval/confirmation of ownership) by the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)/daimyo (feudal lords) in the Edo period as the property of shrines/temples.

history.name: Chingokokka
history.desc: Chingokokka refers to a government policy to stabilize internal affairs using Buddhism or a thought that Buddhism has power to protect and stabilize a country.

history.name: Mizunomi Byakusho
history.desc: Mizunomi Byakusho (water drinking peasant) refer to those who did not have their own harvesting lands, although they were in the census register, since the Edo period.

history.name: Giso warehouse
history.desc: Giso was a warehouse which was constructed in important domestic places to store rice and other grain in case of natural disasters and famine, and the grain in stock was collected from ordinary people or acquired using the cash contributions by the rich.

history.name: Hari Hakase
history.desc: Hari hakase (Doctor of acupuncture) is a member of Tenyakuryo (medical and pharmaceutical department) of the Imperial Household Ministry.

history.name: Shukeiryo
history.desc: Shukeiryo is an organization which belonged to Minbusho (civil and administrative ministry) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Kokugaku (Educational institutes under the Ritsuryo system)
history.jp: 国学 (律令制の教育機関)
history.url: history/Kokugaku (Educational institutes under the Ritsuryo system).html
history.desc: The term Kokugaku means educational institutes established, with the aim of nurturing officials, at each province under the Ritsuryo system (the system of centralized government based on the Riysuryo code).

history.name: Sonae
history.desc: Sonae is a military unit organized during the wartime between the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) and the Edo period.

history.name: Japanese Pigments
history.desc: Japanese pigments are materials used in Japanese traditional painting.

history.name: Teikin Orai
history.desc: Written in an oraimono (exchange of letters) style, Teikin Orai was an elementary textbook used as a copybook and reader at Terakoya (temple elementary schools during the Edo period).

history.name: Shinno-ningoku
history.desc: The term Shinno-ningoku means provinces to which imperial princes were appointed as kokushi (provincial governor) as well as such systems.

history.name: Nenkan
history.desc: The term Nenkan means the right to recommend a person to an official post that was granted to Imperial families and court nobles in the ancient/early medieval period in Japan.

history.name: Nenshaku
history.desc: The term Nenshaku means the right to confer a court rank on a person that was granted to chiten no kimi (the Retired Emperor in power) and sangu (the Three Empresses : Great Empress Dowager, Empress Dowager and Empress) in Japan's ancient/early medieval period.

history.name: Baikan
history.desc: Baikan means selling government posts.

history.name: Jogo
history.desc: Jogo was a system by which those aspiring to a government post would either pay directly to gain an appointment, or pay for expenses that would otherwise have had to be paid from the coffers of the Imperial Court, such as those incurred in carrying out public functions or events for the Imperial Court, building or repairing the palace, or repairing the buildings and pagodas of shrines and temples.

history.name: Nenryo Kyubun
history.desc: Nenryo kyubun is one of the horoku (stipend, pay, salary) systems in the Heian period.

history.name: Uijin
history.desc: Uijin is the first battle that young people in the Japanese samurai hierarchy participated in.

history.name: Tansen
history.desc: Tansen was a form of tax in Japan's Middle Ages.

history.name: Kandaka Sei (system of measuring the amount of rice production based on land size)
history.url: history/Kandaka Sei (system of measuring the amount of rice production based on land size).html
history.desc: The Japanese term "Kandaka sei" refers to the land system, tax system, and military system which used the currency unit "kan" to calculate the yield of rice for a given piece of land.

history.name: The First Battle of Kizukawaguchi
history.jp: 第一次木津川口の戦い
history.desc: The First Battle of Kizukawaguchi refers to the battle between the Mori Clan and the Oda Clan in 1576.

history.name: Kokaho
history.desc: Kokaho (price regulation law) is a law that stipulated the official prices and the conversion rates for goods at the market from ancient times to medieval periods under the Court, kokuga (provincial government offices) and the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Shugouke
history.desc: Shugouke is a system during the Muromachi period in Japan under which Shugo (provincial constable) undertook to pay the land tax on shoen (Manor in medieval Japan) and Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) (koryo (an Imperial demesne)) for the lord of the manor and chigyo-kokushu (provincial proprietor).

history.name: Junshaku
history.desc: Junshaku is a customary practice of conferring a Court rank on kurodo (chamberlain), which developed in the early Heian period.

history.name: Chigyo-koku
history.desc: Chigyo-koku indicates the provincial system and province in ancient and medieval Japan in which dominant nobles, shrines or temples acquired chigyo-ken (also called Kokumu-ken or rimu) (the right to manage the province) and obtained their revenues from there.

history.name: Ruiju Fusensho
history.desc: Ruiju fusensho is a collection of official documents where Daijokanpu (official documents issued by Daijokan, Grand Council of State), imperial decrees and gebumi (reports to upper-class persons) from 737 to 1093 were classified and compiled.

history.name: Rihooki
history.desc: Rihooki (also referred to as Ribuoki) was the diary of Imperial Prince Shigeakira, the fourth son of Emperor Godaigo, and is regarded as an important historical document for understanding the administrative affairs and rituals of the imperial court during the mid Heian period.

history.name: Ochudo
history.desc: Ochudo (or ochiudo) indicates persons who were defeated in a fight and escaped to and lived in a remote rural area or the person's descendants.

history.name: Seiji yoryaku
history.desc: Seiji yoryaku is a written document which gives examples of the governmental management in the Heian period.

history.name: Honcho Gatsuryo
history.desc: Honcho Gatsuryo (or Honcho Getsurei) is the oldest remaining kuji-sho (a document about governmental operations and ceremonies) where, concerning annual events in the middle era of the Heian period, their origins, histories and contents are described.

history.name: The Kanpyo-Engi Togoku War
history.desc: The Kanpyo-Engi Togoku War was a war raised by bandits in the Kanto region in the middle era of the Heian period.

history.name: Shichusen
history.desc: Shichusen refers to privately produced counterfeit money, as differentiated from the official money coined by the government.

history.name: Erizenirei
history.desc: Erizenirei was a ban on the erizeni act (the act of accepting only high-quality coins) enforced by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) or daimyo (feudal lords) in the Muromachi period.

history.name: Bunkyo-hifuron
history.desc: Bunkyo-hifuron was a written literary theory compiled in the early Heian period, in which theories to create prose and poetry were collected through the period of the Six Dynasties to the Tang dynasty of China.

history.name: Shigisan Engi
history.desc: Shigisan Engi (Legends of Mt. Shigi) is a set of picture scrolls made in the late Heian period, and was designated as a national treasure in 2006.

history.name: Oraimono
history.desc: Oraimono is a collective term for primary education text books that were compiled from the late Heian period to the early Meiji period, mainly in the form of letters.

history.name: Kirisute gomen (a privilege granted to samurai warriors)
history.url: history/Kirisute gomen (a privilege granted to samurai warriors).html
history.desc: Kirisute gomen, as well as the rights to bear a surname and to wear a sword, is one of a warrior's privileges in the Edo period.

history.name: Shitaji chubun
history.desc: Shitaji chubun is a term which was used in medieval Japan and it means the division of the land implemented, under the situation where the ruling system of or rights to the land were entangled in a multi-layered way under shoen koryo sei (the system of public lands and private estates), with the aim of achieving the unified land ruling system (Ichien chigyo).

history.name: Sumptuary law
history.desc: Sumptuary laws are a series of laws, ordinances, and orders that ban luxury (Shashi) and promote or force thrift.

history.name: The kokuga forces system
history.desc: The kokuga forces system indicates a historical concept of a national military system established in the period from around the end of ancient times to the early medieval period of Japan (the 10th century to the 12th century).

history.name: Ishinbo
history.desc: Ishinbo was compiled by TANBA no Yasuyori, who was a court physician and acupuncturist in the Heian period.

history.name: Daisenno
history.desc: The term Daisenno means the system of paying kuji (public service), nengu (tribute), and/or jishi (land tax) in cash, instead of in kind, that was introduced in medieval Japan at the shoen (manor), kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office), and/or bukeryo (territories of samurai family).

history.name: The Ako Incident
history.desc: The Ako Incident was a political incident that occurred in the early Heian period.

history.name: Chubunsen (Import duties in the Muromachi period)
history.url: history/Chubunsen (Import duties in the Muromachi period).html
history.desc: Chubunsen was an import duty in the Muromachi period.

history.name: Genin (Low ranked people)
history.desc: Genin denotes domestically subordinative people in pre-modern society.

history.name: Ruiju Myogisho
history.desc: Ruiju myogisho is a dictionary (or glossary) of Chinese characters, compiled in Japan between the late 11th century and the early 12th century.

history.name: Onsho
history.desc: Onsho (reward grants) is defined as follows.

history.name: Shibocho
history.desc: Shibocho refers to a register which was created annually between the times of having new family registers under the ancient Ritsuryo system.

history.name: Keishitsu (Second wife)
history.desc: Keishitsu means second wife.

history.name: Honzowamyo
history.desc: Honzowamyo is the oldest Japanese dictionary of medicines still in existence, and was compiled by Sukehito FUKANE.

history.name: Chodai (a room or a place to sleep especially built for nobilities)
history.url: history/Chodai (a room or a place to sleep especially built for nobilities).html
history.desc: Chodai is a tent-shaped screen with about 242 square centimeters which was built as a nobility's living room or bedroom.

history.name: Shoenezu (a pictorial map drawn in order to clarify the territories and solve disputes caused by the complications of such territories)
history.url: history/Shoenezu (a pictorial map drawn in order to clarify the territories and solve disputes caused by the.html
history.desc: In the ancient and medieval periods of Japan, shoen (manor in medieval Japan) or feudal loads of the villages under the system of public lands and private estates, such as the great and powerful or the local jito (manager and lord of manor) set bounds on their territories (states) and insisted the justice of their domination over such territories.

history.name: Monoawase
history.desc: Monoawase ("mono" meaning things and "awase" meaning comparison) was a game that became most popular in the Heian period.

history.name: Ranbodori
history.desc: Ranbodori was an warrior's act of looting things and robbing people after war from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) through the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

history.name: Juei-ninen Jugatsu no Senji (the imperial decree issued to MINAMOTO no Yoritomo)
history.url: history/Juei-ninen Jugatsu no Senji (the imperial decree issued to MINAMOTO no Yoritomo).html
history.desc: Juei-ninen Jugatsu no Senji is the imperial decree promulgated by the Imperial Court against MINAMOTO no Yoritomo in October (by the old calendar), 1183.

history.name: Senji ryakketsu (占事略决) (the summary of judgments of divinations)
history.url: history/Senji ryakketsu (占事略决) (the summary of judgments of divinations).html
history.desc: "Senji ryakketsu" (or "Senji ryakuketsu") is the oldest existent book of Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; an occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements) which is believed to have been compiled by Onmyoji (Master of Yin yang) ABE no Seimei in the Heian period.

history.name: Tokusei ikki (Tokusei uprising)
history.desc: A Tokusei uprising is a type of peasant uprising.

history.name: Kanbunden
history.desc: Kanbunden is a style of biography written in classical Chinese, influenced by Kidentai (an East Asian historical writing style) of Chinese authentic history and Kokushitai (Japanese historical writing style) of Japanese authentic history.

history.name: Engu oshinke
history.desc: Engu oshinke is a collective term referring to a limited number of imperial families and nobles who gathered strength by taking advantage of their relationship with the Emperor in the early Heian Period (8th to 9th century).

history.name: Shugoshi funyu
history.desc: Shugoshi funyu means that in the Kamakura period and the Muromachi period, the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) forbade shugo (provincial constables) and their officials from entering some specific koryo (public lands), shoen (manors), and so on, which were specified by the bakufu, when pursuing criminals and collecting taxes.

history.name: Enkyu senjimasu
history.desc: An official national measure that was enacted by Emperor Gosanjo in 1072, Enkyu senjimasu (also referred to simply as Senjimasu) was used to implement new manor regulation policies, including a manor regulation ordinance issued during the Enkyu era.

history.name: Gorenju
history.desc: Gorenju was a title of honor used to indicate a legal wife of an aristocrat in Japan.

history.name: Utsuro (samurai family)
history.desc: Utsuro was a quasi family-related community from the late Muromachi period to the Azuchi-Momoyama period that organized family members and vassals around the head of the family, called soryo (heir); organizations such as these were seen among Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) in the Tohoku and Kanto regions.

history.name: Chokodo-ryo (Chokodo's territory)
history.desc: Chokodo-ryo was an Imperial family shoen (manor) under the shoen koryo sei (a system of Public lands and Private estates) during the medieval period.

history.name: Hyoro Bugyo
history.desc: Hyoro Bugyo or Konida Bugyo refers to a bugyo (magistrate) who was in charge of the transportation of provisions (konida) during marches and battles during the Sengoku period (period of Warring States) in Japan.

history.name: Gonaisho
history.desc: Gonaisho was an official document written in the style of a private letter that was issued by the Seii Taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the barbarians) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Choyobun
history.desc: Choyobun refers to the taxation that the Southern Court temporarily imposed on the territories of temples and shrines under their control in order to secure provisions and revenue during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

history.name: Migyosho
history.desc: A Migyosho (or Mikyosho) was a form of ancient document issued by a Keishi (household superintendant) with a court rank of Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher used for conveying the intentions of their masters from the late Heian period to the Muromachi period.

history.name: Dachin-Uma Kasegi
history.desc: Dachin-uma kasegi refers to an occupation in Japan before modern times that engaged in the transportation of freight and people by carrying them on horseback.

history.name: Gosechi no Mai
history.desc: Gosechi no mai was a dance that took place during a Toyoakari no sechie (a ceremony at a seasonal holiday) which was held at Daijo-sai festivals (a festival to celebrate the succession of an emperor) and Niiname-sai festivals (a ceremonial offering by the Emperor of newly-harvested rice to deities); in the dance, there would be four to five women dancing to music sung by the chief of the Outadokoro (an organization that provided the education and management of ancient Japanese music).

history.name: Ate okonai jo
history.desc: Ate okonai jo (also Ote okonai jo or ategai jo) was a style of document used during the medieval period.

history.name: Hirata no Sho
history.desc: Hirata no sho was a manor located in old Yamato Province.

history.name: Kenbokkaishi
history.desc: Kenbokkaishi refers to an envoy sent to Bokkai (Balhae, a kingdom in Manchuria and North Korea, established after the fall of Goguryeo).

history.name: Suzakumon Gate
history.desc: Suzakumon Gate was the main gate built on the southern end of Imperial Palaces (called daidairi) in ancient Japanese cities, such as Heijo-kyo (capital of Japan in Nara from 710 to 740 and from 745 to 784) and Heian-kyo (capital of Japan in Kyoto from 794 to 1868) that had grid-patterned city layouts.

history.name: Daidoruijuho
history.desc: Daidoruijuho was a unique Koiho (school of ancient medicine) document compiled in Japan in 808 during the early Heian period, while it was also the oldest government-designated pharmacopoeia.

history.name: Kashindan
history.desc: The term Kashindan refers to the group of vassals serving samurai families, such as the family of the Seii Taishogun (literally, a general who subsides barbarians) or a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord).

history.name: Kyoto Rekishi Kairo Kyogikai
history.desc: Kyoto Rekishi Kairo Kyogikai (Kyoto "Historic Corridor" Conference) is a Kyoto civil activity.

history.name: Kuragaki no Sho
history.desc: Kuragaki no Sho was a manor in Imizu-gun, Ecchu Province that existed from the late Heian period to the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

history.name: Ingubunkokusei
history.desc: Ingubunkokusei was a system of granting the right to recommend a provincial governor to a specific province to retired emperors, nyoin (women bestowed with the title "in" (usually the empress, imperial princesses, etc.)), second consorts to the emperor, and imperial princesses serving at the Ise Shrine at the time of their appointment, and in return they would receive the financial profits of the provinces in place of a salary.

history.name: Jidoku (imperial tutor)
history.desc: A Jidoku/Jito was a scholar who was an academic tutor for the emperor.

history.name: Ingu kyu
history.desc: Ingu kyu is a nenkan (a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial family (including the emperor), consorts of the emperor, some Court nobles, and so forth in order to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred on occasion of an annual installation as a government official) and a nenshaku (a right granted as a stipend to a retired emperor, the mother of the Emperor Dowager, the Empress Dowager, the Empress, and so forth in order to nominate a person for a certain rank on occasions of annual conferments of ranks) given to Daijo tenno (the Retired Emperor) and Sannomiya (empress).

history.name: Jishi Koeki
history.desc: Jishi Koeki refers to the exchange (buying and selling) of rice as a land tax that was collected from koden (fields administered directly by a ruler) by a provincial governor under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code); rice was exchanged for light commodities that were easier to carry and submit to the central government.

history.name: Fuseya
history.desc: A Fuseya was a temporary relief station and lodging facility for travelers that was established in many parts of Japan during the kodai ritsuryosei (ancient East Asian system of centralized governance).

history.name: Haikomei (name for men representing the order of their birth)
history.url: history/Haikomei (name for men representing the order of their birth).html
history.desc: A haikomei is a type of name for men used mostly in Japan.

history.name: Kuni ikki (provincial uprising)
history.desc: Kuni ikki refers to an alliance (uprising) made up of feudal lords with the aim of securing their rule in the period of Northern and Southern courts and Muromachi.

history.name: Chuko (periodization)
history.desc: Chuko (Middle Ages) is a word used to represent a time period, and is the second of the three words: joko (ancient times), chuko (middle ages), and kinko (early modern age).

history.name: Miyake odoi
history.desc: Miyake odoi was a castle that existed in Miyake-Cho, Masuda City, Shimane Prefecture.

history.name: Bushidan
history.desc: Bushidan (warrior bands) refers to the group of bushi (samurai) that existed mainly from the late Heian, Kamakura, the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) (Japan), and lasted until the Muromachi period.

history.name: Jisha honjoryo no koto
history.desc: "Jisha honjoryo no koto" was a law enforced by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) on July 10, 1368.

history.name: Onshu
history.desc: Under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), onshu was the registration of a person who came forward after having been missing from the family registers or the keicho (yearly tax registers), or after having been away from the place of registry.

history.name: Kojichi
history.desc: During the Middle Ages in Japan, a kojichi was the act of privately seizing the assets of a debtor whose credit had fallen into default.

history.name: Dosoyaku (tax for doso)
history.desc: Dosoyaku, also known as kurayaku, was a tax on doso (pawnbrokers and moneylenders) in Kyoto during the medieval era.

history.name: Shoki Shoen (early shoen)
history.desc: Shoki shoen (early shoen) were shoen (manors) established through an accumulation of wasteland and a collection of reclaimed rice fields from the eighth to the ninth century.

history.name: Ichiban-yari (a group of spearmen or a person to spark a war)
history.url: history/Ichiban-yari (a group of spearmen or a person to spark a war).html
history.desc: The term Ichiban-yari refers to a warrior or group of warriors who engaged in combat using a spear.

history.name: Shidosen (mortuary funds)
history.desc: Shidosen were funds donated to temples for memorial services for the deceased and for the management and upkeep of shido (also known as mitamaya (a place where spirits are enshrined) or jibutsu-do hall).

history.name: Heike no Ochudo (fugitives from the Genpei War)
history.url: history/Heike no Ochudo (fugitives from the Genpei War).html
history.desc: The term Heike no Ochudo means fugitives who retreated to remote regions after their defeat in the Jisho-Juei War (the Genpei War).

history.name: Koden
history.desc: Koden (run-down field) is the term indicating fields that had been cultivated but have been abandoned for some reason during the ancient times and middle ages.

history.name: Koden kanmotsu ritsuho
history.desc: Koden kanmotsu ritsuho was the law (ritsuho) fixing the tax rate of kanmotsu (tribute) of Koden (fields administered directly by a ruler) in the middle of the Heian period.

history.name: Tairo
history.desc: Tairo was the food supplied to Jicho (unpaid workers), Eji (guards) and Uneme (court ladies) working at the central government offices in the ancient Ritsuryo system.

history.name: Menden
history.desc: Menden were rice fields that were exempt from the tax determined by the government during the late ancient times to the middle ages of Japan.

history.name: Kanmotsu
history.desc: Kanmotsu are the tithes that were collected by the imperial court and Ryoseikoku (province) as tax such as Soyocho under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Nenryo Zakki
history.desc: Nenryo zakki was earthenware from Owari Province and Nagato Province appointed by the central government as payments of tribute under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Nenryo betsuno sokoku
history.desc: Nenryo betsuno sokoku was rice kept as seed at the local level, separate from that of So collected in the Shoso (warehouse) of Ritsuryo provinces as Fudokoku (staples for an emergency), and was given to kyokan (an official of the Capital) as Iroku, Kiroku and Ifukuryo based on the Daijokanpu (official documents issued by Daijokan, Grand Council of State) when the central government did not have sufficient funds.

history.name: Nenryo bekko zomotsu
history.desc: Nenryo bekko zomotsu was the system where a designated amount of Zomotsu such as paper, brushes, horse skin and herbal plants were directly tithed to the central government by Ritsuryo provinces.

history.name: Nijugozanmaie
history.desc: Nijugozanmaie was a Nenbutsu (Buddhist invocation) association established in the Heian Period.

history.name: Kyuden
history.desc: Kyuden, Kyuhaku and Kyudenpaku were rice paddies and fields that were granted to shokan (an officer governing shoen manor), jito (estate steward), nengu (land tax) couriers and handicraftsmen by shoen holders and the Kokuga (provincial government offices) during the middle ages in Japan.

history.name: Nenryososhomai (tax payment in milled rice)
history.desc: Nenryososhomai was the term for the shomai (milled rice) itself or the system determined by Daijokanpu (official documents issued by Daijokan, Grand Council of State) during the Heian period which required the raw grain collected as So in the provinces to be tithed to the central government as refined white rice

history.name: Nenryoshomai
history.desc: Nenryoshomai was the term for the shomai itself or the system under the Ritsuryo system which required a designated amount of white rice from the provinces to be tithed to the central government every year.

history.name: Meshikome
history.desc: Meshikome was one of the punishments given out to courtiers in the Heian Period.

history.name: Hyakusho
history.desc: The term "hyakusho," which can also be pronounced "hyakusei" or "omitakara," was originally a word of Chinese origin that indicates all people with a hundred (many) surnames, i.e., all the social class with surnames.

history.name: Horokuhiya
history.desc: Horokuhiya was a weapon invented and used in Japan during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan).

history.name: Tamefusa-kyo Ki
history.desc: Tamefusa-kyo Ki, also called 'Daiki,' 'Daigyoki' and 'Daifuki,' is a diary written by FUJIWARA no Tamefusa, who served as Kurodo (chamberlain) and Kurodo no to (head chamberlain) and was active as Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury) and Sangi (councilor) for Emperors Gosanjo, Shirakawa, Horikawa and Toba.

history.name: Eisho Disturbance
history.desc: Eisho Disturbance refers to an incident during the early Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan) where the kanrei (shogunal deputy) for the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) named Masamoto HOSOKAWA was assassinated in 1507.

history.name: Buyaku
history.desc: Buyaku refers to labor allocation imposed on subjects by each ruler in Japanese history.

history.name: Akita Ranga (Akita Dutch-style painting)
history.desc: Akita Ranga is a genre of Japanese painting in a semi-Western style from the Edo period that was adopted by the lord and statesmen of the Kubota clan (the Akita clan); paintings in this style were composed using techniques of Western paintings with traditional Japanese drawing materials.

history.name: Eishoki
history.desc: Eishoki was the diary of the late Heian Period courtier FUJIWARA no Tametaka.

history.name: Myogyodo
history.desc: Myogyodo was a department that studied and instructed on Confucianism as part the Daigakuryo, an educational institution under the Ritsuryo system (the system of centralized administration established by the ritsuryo legal codes) of Japan.

history.name: Kuramaichigyo
history.desc: Kuramaichichigyo, also known as Kuramaikyuyo, was a system in which the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and domains provided kuramai (written as 蔵米 or in the case of the bakufu as 廩米 - rice preserved in a depository) to their vassals as horoku (salary) instead of chigyo-chi (territory).

history.name: Shibun
history.desc: Shibun was the term for persons with the full social rank as bushi (warrior) class among the bushi during the Edo Period.

history.name: Soma-mikuriya (private estate of Soma ranch)
history.desc: Soma-mikuriya was one of the medieval shoen (manor in medieval Japan) holdings of the commendation type in areas that are today's Toride City and Moriya City, Ibaraki Prefecture, and Kashiwa City, Nagareyama City, and Abiko City, Chiba Prefecture.

history.name: Kinomidokyo (reading of the Great Perfection of Insight Sutra in spring and autumn)
history.url: history/Kinomidokyo (reading of the Great Perfection of Insight Sutra in spring and autumn).html
history.desc: Kinomidokyo was a court function performed during the Heian period.

history.name: Shoju
history.desc: Shoju (followers) was a category of slave that existed in Medieval Japan.

history.name: Gozen-sata
history.desc: Gozen-sata was an informal consultation chaired and attended by Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun.)

history.name: Sankaiki
history.desc: Sankaiki is the name given to the diary of Tadachika NAKAYAMA.

history.name: Kokumori
history.desc: Kokumori refers to the estimated production output (To-dai; one To was about 18 liters) per tan (an old land area unit; 991.7 square meters) of rice in rice paddies, fields and residential areas in a land survey.

history.name: Kokumen no sho
history.desc: Kokumen no sho (also referred to as Kokumensho) was a kind of shoen (manor in medieval Japan) during the late Heian period which was exempt from miscellaneous taxes by kokushi (provincial governor).

history.name: Rinjikyu
history.desc: Rinjikyu was provisional payment of extra nenkan (a regular nenkan means: a right granted as a stipend to members of the Imperial Family [including the emperor], consorts of the emperor, some court nobles, and so forth to nominate a person for a certain government post conferred to them on the occasion of the annual installation of them as government officials).

history.name: Kokujin-ryoshu sei
history.desc: Kokujin-ryoshu sei was a thesis concerning the structure of Japan during the late medieval period (the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), the Muromachi period, and the Sengoku period - period of warring states) -- accordingly, the structure should be comprehended through research of movement of kokujin-ryoshu (local samurai lords) who directly ruled the farmers.

history.name: Kenka Ryoseibai
history.desc: Kenka Ryoseibai was one of the principles of law (jurisprudence) in Medieval Japan.

history.name: Shomu
history.desc: Shomu meant management of territory (trial and collection of nengu [main land tax levied on the peasants based on the estimated productivity of land] and sozei [single land tax or combined land tax].)

history.name: Tashibu no Sho (Tashibu Manor)
history.desc: Tashibu no Sho (Tashibu Manor) was a manor belonging to Usa-jingu Shrine in Kunisaki District, Buzen Province (modern day Bungotakada City, Oita Prefecture).

history.name: Denchu on okite
history.desc: Denchu on okite was a set of regulations Nobunaga ODA made Shogun Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA accept.

history.name: Fuyusoden
history.desc: Fuyusoden was a rice field exempted from tax according to the Japanese ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Tenmon misso
history.desc: Tenmon misso was a practice in ancient East Asia whereby observation of unusual astronomical phenomenon was confidentially reported to the monarch along with observations and astrological divination (prediction.)

history.name: Great Kyoto Fire of the Tenmei Era
history.url: history/Great Kyoto Fire of the Tenmei Era.html
history.desc: Great Kyoto Fire of the Tenmei Era was a fire that broke out in Kyoto on March 7, 1788.

history.name: Kuzen
history.desc: Kuzen was an informal form of official document that came into use from the mid Heian period -- which was used by shikiji (administrative assistant) at kurodo dokoro (the Office of Imperial Household Logistics) (shikiji kurodo, kurodo no to - Head Chamberlain) or goi no kurodo (Chamberlain of the Fifth Rank) in transcribing the verbally received emperor's edict for conveying it to shokei (high-ranking court noble) at Daijokan (Grand Council of State).

history.name: Shirakawa Betsugyo
history.desc: Shirakawa betsugyo was a villa used by the head of the Regents' House of the Fujiwara clan for generations from the ninth century to about the eleventh century.

history.name: Sanbuichiginno (Payment of One Third of Land Tax in Silver)
history.url: history/Sanbuichiginno (Payment of One Third of Land Tax in Silver).html
history.desc: Sanbuichiginno was the payment of one third of the agricultural land tax in silver during the Edo period.

history.name: Battle of Nyoigatake
history.desc: The Battle of Nyoigatake was fought near Mt. Nyoigatake in Sakyo Ward of Kyoto City at midnight of July 14, 1509.

history.name: Zenko Seihyo
history.desc: Zenko Seihyo was a practice of awarding a person for a good conduct and announcing it in public.

history.name: Kobunin
history.desc: Kobunin was a facility considered to be built by WAKE no Hiroyo in Heiankyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Kyoto) at the beginning of the Heian period.

history.name: Monjoin
history.desc: Monjoin was a University Jikiso (facilities) (such as a lecture room and student dormitory) for Kidendo (the study of the histories) of Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education under the ritsuryo system).

history.name: Sando
history.desc: Sando (the study of mathematics) was a department for the study of arithmetic and mathematics in the Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code) in ancient Japan.

history.name: Kagaku
history.desc: Kagaku' means handing down their academic skills within the family or the clan.

history.name: Myobo Kanyosho
history.desc: The Myobo Kanyosho is a law book written in the late Heian period.

history.name: Myomokusho
history.desc: Myomokusho was a book on the study of ancient courtly traditions and etiquette written by Sadaijin (minister of the left) Sanehiro TOIN during the mid Muromachi period.

history.name: Shodo (Daigaku-ryo)
history.desc: Shodo was the study of calligraphy under the Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education) of Japan's Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Ondo
history.desc: Ondo is one of the subjects of Daigaku-ryo, an educational institution under the system of centralized administration established under the Ritsuryo Legal Codes in Japan, to learn the Han pronunciations of Chinese characters in order to allow the reading aloud of the scriptures of Confucianism with the original pronunciations.

history.name: Seiryoden Thunderbolt Striking Incident
history.desc: The Seiryoden thunderbolt striking incident happened when a thunderbolt struck the Seiryoden (literally, Hall of Cool and Refreshing Breezes; the emperor's private residence) in the Dairi (Imperial Palace) on July 29, 930 during the Heian period.

history.name: Sanin-tei
history.desc: Sanin-tei was a private school kept by the Sugawara clan, that had produced Monjo hakase (professor of literature) for three generations; SUGAWARA no Kiyokimi, SUGAWARA no Koreyoshi, and SUGAWARA no Michizane, during the early Heian period.

history.name: Gishiki (Book)
history.desc: Gishiki originally meant court rule and customs in official duties and ceremonial functions at the imperial court under the ritsuryo system, and later, compilations and books for prescribing court rule and customs came to be called 'Gishiki.'

history.name: School Textbooks in Japan Prior to the Modern Times
history.jp: 近代以前の日本における教科書
history.url: history/School Textbooks in Japan Prior to the Modern Times.html
history.desc: This article will explain about the history of the school textbooks in Japan until the school system was established in the Meiji period.

history.name: Choroku no Hen
history.desc: Choroku no hen was an incident that occurred on December 27, 1457 during the Muromachi period when former retainers of the Akamatsu family attacked angu (emperor's temporary palace) of Gonancho (Second Southern Court), made a surprise assault on the brothers of Sonshuo and Chugio who were descendants of the Southern Court emperor (the latter was a seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians" of the Southern Court), and took away Shinji (the sacred jewel).

history.name: Sanyojo
history.desc: Sanyojo (算用状 or 散用状) was the annual settlement of accounts for nengu (annual land tax) and kuji (miscellaneous tax) in each shoen (estate) exchanged between shoen ryoshu (the estate proprietary lord) and shokan (the estate manager) in the medieval shoen system.

history.name: Konin Gishiki
history.desc: Konin Gishiki was one of Gishiki (Court rules and customs Books) considered to be compiled during the Konin era at the beginning of the Heian period.

history.name: Gyochukokyo
history.desc: "Gyochukokyo" is a collection of commentaries on the "Kokyo" (Classic of Filial Piety) compiled by Genso (Emperor Xuanzong [Tang]).

history.name: Engi Gishiki
history.desc: Engi Gishiki was one of Gishiki (Court rule and customs Books) considered to be compiled during the Engi era at the beginning of the Heian period.

history.name: Jogan Gishiki
history.desc: Jogan gishiki is a book of ceremonies that is believed to have been compiled during the Jogan era (Japan) during the early Heian period (book) (book of ceremony).

history.name: Sanji Kentai
history.desc: The term Sanji kentai means concurrently assuming the positions of Goi no kurodo (Kurodo with the fifth rank), Benkan (officials of the Dajokan - Grand Council of State)) and Kebiishi no suke (assistant official of the Police and Judicial Chief).

history.name: Kansenji
history.desc: Kansenji, also called "Benkankudashibumi," are oral decrees (called Kuzen) of a high-ranking court noble (called Shokei) of a Dajokan that officials of the Dajokan (called benkan) during the Heian period sent to Ritsuryo koku and temples.

history.name: Igo
history.desc: Igo is a kind of punishment carried out during the Nara and Heian periods to remove a criminal to another province.

history.name: Daijokancho
history.desc: Daijokancho are official documents sent from Daijokan to organizations not under its direct control such as sogo and Buddhist temples.

history.name: Kibi no Otodo Nitto Emaki
history.desc: Kibi no Otodo Nitto Emaki is the name of a Japanese picture scroll.

history.name: Seishinko-ki
history.desc: Seishinko-ki is the diary of FUJIWARA no Saneyori who acted as a Kanpaku (chief adviser to the emperor) in the mid Heian period.

history.name: Goryakuso
history.desc: Goryakuso is a ceremony conducted during pre-modern periods, in which a Year calendar is presented on every November first (old lunar calendar) by Onmyoryo to the Emperor via Nakatsukasasho.

history.name: The case of student union of Kyoto Prefecture
history.url: history/The case of student union of Kyoto Prefecture.html
history.desc: It is a popular name of a judgment by the Supreme Court of Japan that mainly judged photographing for criminal investigation as lawful and constitutional.

history.name: TAIRA no Tomonobu Asonki
history.desc: "TAIRA no Tomonobu Asonki" is a diary written by TAIRA no Tomonobu who was a government official at the end of the Heian period.

history.name: Appointment to Shogun
history.desc: The appointment to Shogun refers to a ceremony where the Emperor granted the title of seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") as the head of a military government and to govern Japan.

history.name: The list of the shoen (manors in medieval Japan)
history.url: history/The list of the shoen (manors in medieval Japan).html
history.desc: Here, shoen (manors), scattered across Japan, except Hokkaido, from ancient times to medieval times are listed.

history.name: Funaokayama-gassen
history.desc: The Funaokayama-gassen (Battle at Mt. Funaoka) refers to a battle on September 25, 1511, between Takakuni HOSOKAWA along with OUCHI Yoshioki who supported shogun Yoshitane ASHIKAGA and Sumimoto HOSOKAWA who support former shogun Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA.

history.name: Shimazu no Sho (Shimazu Manor)
history.desc: Shimazu no Sho (Shimazu Manor) was a large manor located in southern Kyushu from the Heian period to the first part of the Kamakura period.

history.name: Yokoe on Sho (Yokoe Manor)
history.desc: Yokoe on Sho (Yokoe Manor) was a manor located in Kaga Province from the Heian period to the Sengoku period (period of Warring States).

history.name: Kanzaki no Sho (Kanzaki Manor)
history.desc: Kanzaki no Sho (Kanzaki Manor) was a manor located in Hizen Province from the Heian period to the Muromachi period.

history.name: Nihongi Koen
history.desc: Nihongi Koen was a court function that gave lectures and did research on the national history of Japan or "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) during the early Heian period.

history.name: Myohodo
history.desc: Myohodo is a department of Daigakuryo, an educational institution under the system of centralized administration established under the ritsuryo legal codes in ancient Japan, where the ritsuryo legal codes (the study of law) was taught.

history.name: Gakumonjo (a school)
history.desc: Gakumonjo (a school) was the name of a kind of educational institution in medieval and modern times.

history.name: Jinshin Yakujo
history.desc: Jinshin Yakujo were rules for immigration that were issued by Yi Dynasty Korea against So clan in Tsushima Province in 1512.

history.name: Jinseigata
history.desc: Jinseigata was one of the institutions established during the early Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Bikkaiho (Adultery Control Law)
history.desc: Bikkaiho (Adultery Control Law) was a law that stipulated the handling of adultery.

history.name: Bukeyaku
history.desc: Bukeyaku was a general term for taxation imposed by the Kamakura and Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Shinbutsu-shugo
history.desc: Shinbutsu-shugo (syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism) refers to blending of indigenous belief and Buddhistic faith to reconfigure one belief system.

history.name: Tally
history.desc: Tally (saifu or wappu) was a certificate stamp used to settle money transactions between distant lands in medieval Japan, and it became the origin of currency exchange.

history.name: Shinsei (Law reconstitution)
history.desc: Shinsei ('kugeshinsei') means a written code established based upon imperial order by Tenno (the Emperor) and Daijo Tenno (the Retired Emperor) from the mid Heian period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

history.name: Gakumonryo
history.desc: The term Gakumonryo is a scholarship for Monjosho (students who study poetry and history) who studied Kidendo (the study of history) at Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education under the ritsuryo system) during the Heian period and it was also called Kyuryo.

history.name: Dondon-yake
history.desc: Dondon-yake is the fire that broke out in the city of Kyoto at the end of the Edo period from August 19 to 21, 1864.

history.name: Kenminsen
history.desc: Kenminsen means ships dispatched seventeen times to Ming China in the Muromachi period (the total number of ships was eighty-four) during the period of one and a half centuries from 1404 to 1547 for the purpose of Nichi-Ming trade (trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty, China) (Kango trade).

history.name: Men
history.desc: Men or Menai means the rate of Koso (an annual tax) to the Kokudaka (the annual yield of a land) in the Edo period.

history.name: Unzusho
history.desc: Unzusho is a book on rites that was written in the late Heian period.

history.name: Sechi-e
history.desc: The term "Sechi-e" means official events held at the Japanese Imperial Court on the day of Sekku (seasonal festivals) etc. with the attendance of the Emperor and a large number of his subjects.

history.name: kanmon
history.desc: The term Kanmon means written reports (Kanshin) for various information such as origins/precedents that were submitted by scholars, etc. at the request of the Imperial court.

history.name: Tsunesada-Shino-den (Biography of Tsunesada-Shino)
history.desc: Tsunesada-Shino-den was one of the biographies in classical Chinese which was written in the early Heian period.

history.name: Buke no Toryo
history.desc: The term "Buke no toryo" means the leader of groups of samurai.

history.name: Jitsugokyo
history.desc: Jitsugokyo was a textbook used for elementary education from the end of the Heian Period to the early Meiji period in which precepts for ordinary people were mainly compiled.

history.name: Shishi
history.desc: The term "Shishi" (also pronounced Shiishi) referred to the northern, southern, eastern, and western boundaries of a tract of territory/land in ancient and medieval times.

history.name: Kao no Goso
history.desc: Kao no goso refers a direct petition by Enryaku-ji Temple's daishu (residing monks) demanding the proprietor of the Owari Province FUJIWARA no Narichika into exile on January 18, 1170.

history.name: Myoga
history.desc: Myoga means a kind of tax in the Edo period that was paid to the Edo bakufu or domains in consideration for the use of mountains/fields/rivers/seas or to grant a business license

history.name: Naisogata
history.desc: Naisogata was one of the legal institutions set up in the early stage of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Iyo Shinno no Hen
history.desc: Iyo Shinno no Hen was a political change which occurred in 807.

history.name: Kyodai-Tenno incident
history.desc: The Kyodai-Tenno incident was an incident in which disorder arose between the Emperor Showa who visited Kyoto University on November 12, 1951 and many students who gathered at the campus on that day, and Dogakukai, the student self-governing association of Kyoto University, was ordered to dissolve later.

history.name: Sawayanagi incident
history.desc: The Sawayanagi incident was an internal conflict that occurred at Kyoto Imperial University (current Kyoto University) from 1913 to 1914 in which the president of the university confronted the faculty council.

history.name: Shikienkyuten
history.desc: Shikienkyuten is kuntenbon (a book with guiding marks for rendering Chinese into Japanese) of "Shiki" (Records of the Grand Historian), a Chinese history book written by Sima Qian in the era of Former Han in China, and it was in the form of Kansubon (book in scroll style) transcribed by OE no Iekuni by adding kunten (marks and symbols beside lines of Chinese text to indicate how the text is to be read in Japanese) in 1073 during the Heian period of Japan.

history.name: Ossho
history.desc: The term "Ossho" means the lords of Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) were exempted from and allowed to collect Zatsueki (a kind tax under the Ritsuryo system) (sometimes inclusive of the portion of Kanmotsu (tribute goods -supposed to be paid to Kokuga (provincial government offices) as well as the land of such Shoen.

history.name: Shikimoku
history.desc: Shikimoku was an itemized form of law code used in medieval Japan.

history.name: Ossokata
history.desc: The ossokata refers a lawsuit body of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and the Muromachi bakufu.

history.name: Jikimu
history.desc: Jikimu refers to immediate dominance of shoen (manor in medieval Japan) by the lord of the manor (honjo [the administrative headquarters of a shoen] and ryoke [virtual proprietor of manor]), executing Shomuken (the authority of the jurisdiction and the administration of Shoen).

history.name: Tenryuji-bune
history.desc: Tenryuji-bune refers to official trading vessels of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), dispatched to Yuan Dynasty in order to raise funds to build Tenryu-ji Temple during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

history.name: Kenmu Irai Tsuika
history.desc: Kenmu Irai Tsuika refers to the supplementary law code established by Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Tonjiki
history.desc: Tonjiki refers to food given to lower officials or sometimes respectable persons at a banquet in the garden of the Imperial Court and nobles' residence during the Heian period.

history.name: Kurahoshi
history.desc: Kurahoshi means manager of doso (pawnbrokers and moneylenders) in the Medieval Period of Kyoto.

history.name: Setsuyoshu
history.desc: Setsuyoshu is a series of Yojishu (a collection of useful characters) or Japanese-language dictionary published from the Muromachi period to the early Showa period.

history.name: Jishazoeiryotosen
history.desc: Jishazoeiryotosen is a group of traveling vessels that were dispatched to the Yuan Dynasty under authorization of the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) for the purpose of making profits to cover the costs of repair and construction of major temples and shrines in the first half of the 14th century (from the late Kamakura period through the period of the Northern and Southern Courts -Japan).

history.name: Insei period culture
history.desc: Insei period culture (culture during the period of the government by the Retired Emperor) or the culture of the end of the Heian period refers to Japanese culture from the end of Heian period, the latter half of the 11th century to the period when the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was founded, the end of the 12th century.

history.name: Japanese Cedar Pollinosis
history.desc: Japanese cedar pollinosis is a form of hay fever caused by pollen of the Cryptomeria japonica (Japanese cedar) tree.

history.name: The Battle of Hoju-ji Temple
history.desc: The Battle of Hoju-ji Temple (Hoju-ji kassen) was a military coup on January 10, 1184, in which MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka attacked In no gosho (the retired emperor's court) Hojuji-dono Palace, imprisoning Cloistered Emperor Goshirakawa and Emperor Gotoba and taking over the government.

history.name: Fuyu no ken (Japan)
history.desc: Fuyu no ken (the right of tax exemption) was the right of shoen (manor in medieval Japan) to be exempted from all or part of the land tax to be paid to the government.

history.name: Saikyuki
history.desc: Saikyuki (Saiguki) was a book on Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette) and rites, which was compiled by MINAMOTO no Takaakira during the Heian period.

history.name: Higashiyama gyomotsu
history.desc: Higashiyama gyomotsu (Higashiyama gomotsu) refers to the paintings, chaki (tea utensils), kaki (flower vase), stationery and other items collected by Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the eastern barbarians") of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Funyu no ken (Japan)
history.desc: Funyu no ken is the right of shoen (manor in medieval Japan) to decline the entry of messengers (Kendenshi, Shunoshi, Shidoshi, etc.) from the Kokuga (provincial government offices)

history.name: Jisha seiryoku
history.desc: Jisha seiryoku is a term describing the military, governmental, economical and cultural power of temples and shrines (at that time considered equivalent because of syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism), which shared power with the military government and Imperial Court during the Japanese middle ages.

history.name: Zoyaku
history.desc: Zoyaku (Zoeki) is the term for the taxation system introduced after the middle of the Heian period.

history.name: Sanshichinobe
history.desc: Sanshichinobe was one of the ways to pay nengu (an annual tribute, or land tax) in the Edo period.

history.name: The Three-day War by the Taira Clan (Heian period)
history.jp: 三日平氏の乱 (平安時代)
history.url: history/The Three-day War by the Taira Clan (Heian period).html
history.desc: The Three-day War by the Taira Clan was one of the domestic conflicts which occurred in the Jisho-Juei War during the late Heian period.

history.name: Yowa no Hokuriku syuppei (the dispatch of troops to the Hokuriku region in the Yowa period)
history.url: history/Yowa no Hokuriku syuppei (the dispatch of troops to the Hokuriku region in the Yowa period).html
history.desc: The Yowa no Hokuriku syuppei (the dispatch of troops to Hokuriku region in the Yowa period) was conducted by the Heike in order to track down and kill the rebelling powers in the Hokuriku region, and intensified around September 1181 (ending around December 1181 or January 1182 (November 1181 by the old lunar calendar)).

history.name: Machi-koji Street
history.desc: Machi-koji Street was a street that was central to the townspeople of Kyoto in the middle ages, and was lined with doso (underground warehouses).

history.name: Kamakura Mochiuji ki
history.desc: Kamakura Mochiuji ki is a military diary depicting the Eikyo Rebellion and Yuki Battle during the Muromachi period.

history.name: Katanashi
history.desc: Katanashi (Kessei) was one of the governmental affairs conducted at the Imperial Court during the Heian period.

history.name: The Wake clan
history.desc: The Wake clan was a Gozoku (local ruling family) based in the Wake District (formerly Fujino District) of Bizen Province.

history.name: Yoriudo
history.desc: Yoriudo (Yoryudo) was a term used during the middle ages after the Heian period for certain people, but had multiple meanings.

history.name: Jugonshi
history.desc: Jugonshi (sorcerers) were a type of official who worked in the Bureau of Medicine under the Ritsuryo system.

history.name: Jugon hakase
history.desc: The jugon hakase (Master Sorcerer) was an official for the Bureau of Medicine under the Ritsuryo system.

history.name: Jibugyo
history.desc: Jibugyo was bugyo (magistrate) appointed by the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and the Muromachi bakufu.

history.name: Iken junikajo
history.desc: Iken junikajo (twelve opinions) was the written statement on politics that Kiyoyuki MIYOSHI, a scholar of Chinese classics in the mid Heian period, submitted to Emperor Daigo in 914.

history.name: Kanpyo no goyuikai
history.desc: Kanpyo no goyuikai was the note that Emperor Uda left for the 13-year-old new emperor when he abdicated the throne in favor of Emperor Daigo on August 8, 897.

history.name: Yorioya-Yoriko
history.desc: Yorioya-Yoriko refers to the master-servant relationship similar to the parent-child relationship created in medieval Japan or the relationship of the guardian and the protected person based on the master-servant relationship.

history.name: Nenki-uri
history.desc: Nenki-uri (whose "ki" can be written with three different characters 年期売, 年季売 or 年紀売, all of which relate to time or duration) was a kind of contract of sale (usually of land) used during Japan's medieval period.

history.name: Joji Hen (The Joji Incident)
history.desc: Joji Incident, which occurred in 1366 during the late Northern and Southern Courts Period (Japan) (the early Muromachi period), was an incident by which Yoshimasa SHIBA, shitsuji (steward, later renamed kanrei) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and his father Takatsune SHIBA, an influential shugodaimyo (territorial lord as provincial constables) and a close aid of seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA, fell from power.

history.name: Osamedono
history.desc: The term "Osamedono" means a palace where gold/silver, costumes and/or furnishings were kept.

history.name: List of Material Concerning the Muromachi Period
history.url: history/List of Material Concerning the Muromachi Period.html
history.desc: A list of historical material concerning the Muromachi period of Japan

history.name: Yusoden
history.desc: The term "Yusoden" means rice fields on which denso (rice field tax) was imposed under the taxation system of Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code).

history.name: Oshikai or oshigai
history.desc: Oshikai or oshigai describes an act of purchase by force in a market place without an agreement between the seller and the buyer.

history.name: Shichikuzan Chigogataki Fudomyoo
history.jp: 紫竹山稚児ヶ滝不動明王
history.desc: Shichikuzan Chigogataki Fudomyoo is a historical site located at Magura, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

history.name: Chokan-kanmon
history.desc: Chokan-kanmon (or Chokan no kanmon) was kanmon (written report for what the Imperial court requested) written in the Chokan era (1163 - 1164) during the Heian period.

history.name: Zoyakumen
history.desc: The term "Zoyakumen" (or Zoekiden) means myoden (rice fields named after the local land lords who developed the land in question) which were exempted from zatsueki (levies other than land tax) under the system of shoen (manor) and kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government) during the medieval period.

history.name: Zoyakumen Kei Shoen
history.desc: The term "Zoyakumen kei shoen" means shoen (manor) which were granted Zoyakumen (the right to exempt from all levies other than regular land tax) and whose lords were allowed to secure the amount equivalent to zatsueki (odd-jobs tasks) for themselves.

history.name: Oban
history.desc: Oban was a type of menu for entertaining guests.

history.name: Ichiza
history.desc: Ichiza was the term for the highest seat among court positions at the Imperial Court.

history.name: Gissha Senji
history.desc: Gissha senji was an imperial decree that allowed one to pass the Miya mon (Imperial palace gate) while riding on a gissha (ox-drawn carriage) when visiting the Imperial inner court.

history.name: Hoei taika (the Great Fire of the Hoei Era)
history.url: history/Hoei taika (the Great Fire of the Hoei Era).html
history.desc: Hoei taika (the Great Fire of the Hoei Era) refers to a fire that occurred in Kyoto on April 28, 1708.

history.name: Great Fire of Jisho
history.desc: The Great Fire of Jisho happened within the Heian-kyo on May 9, 1179.

history.name: Ishikiden
history.desc: Isshikiden is a rice field that is required to pay only one type (Isshiki) of tax.

history.name: Chohogannenrei
history.desc: Chohogannenrei is the Daijokanpu (official document of the Daijokan, the office of the supreme political leader) issued as shinsei (a code of new law) on September 9, 999.

history.name: Kashoku
history.desc: Kashoku was a hereditary job or position or official post (and progression pass).

history.name: Chinju-fu (in ancient times)
history.desc: Chinju-fu is an office in charge of military affairs in ancient Japan, located in Mutsu Province.

history.name: History of Noh
history.desc: History of Noh means the history of the development of Japanese traditional art of Noh.

history.name: Hyakki yagyo emaki (Picture scroll of Hyakki yagyo)
