history.url: history/Hyakki yagyo emaki (Picture scroll of Hyakki yagyo).html
history.desc: Hyakki yagyo emaki is a type of Japanese picture scrolls.

history.name: Hokuriku Chotei (The Imperial Court In The Hokuriku Region)
history.url: history/Hokuriku Chotei (The Imperial Court In The Hokuriku Region).html
history.desc: "Hokuriku Chotei" refers to the Imperial Court that is deemed to have existed during the period of Northern and Southern Courts in the present Hokuriku Region, which was backed up - and was claimed to have legitimacy - by warlords taking the side of the Southern Court.

history.name: Hyakuryo Kunyosho
history.desc: Hyakuryo Kunyosho was a book on the study of ancient courtly traditions and etiquette which Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) Yoshimoto Nijo wrote for Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA, seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians) of the Muromachi bakufu.

history.name: I-do (The Medical Service Under The Japanese Ritsuryo System)
history.url: history/I-do (The Medical Service Under The Japanese Ritsuryo System).html
history.desc: "I-do" refers to the medical service under the Japanese "Ritsuryo system" (system of centralized regime based on the ritsuryo code), or the education of the youth to make them offer services.

history.name: Odachijoko shosatsusho
history.desc: Odachijoko shosatsusho is a book of shosatsurei (model sentences for official letters) written by Hisauji ODACHI, a vassal of the Muromachi bakufu from the late Muromachi period to the Sengoku period (Japan) (the book is also called 'Odachi' and Joko was the priest name of the author).

history.name: Yuteihisho
history.desc: Yuteihisho is a book of kemari (Japanese ancient Imperial court game like kick-ball) of Mikohidari school that was written during the Northern and Southern Courts period (Japan).

history.name: Boji
history.desc: The term "Boji" means a notice put up at shishi (northern, southern, eastern and western boundary) of a territory or the important positions of a boundary.

history.name: Sakumondaitai
history.desc: Sakumondaitai was a manual of kanshi (Chinese poem) written during the Heian period.

history.name: Ikenfuji Sankajo
history.desc: Ikenfuji Sankajo was fuji (written opinion presented to the Emperor) submitted to the Emperor Murakami on January 24, 958 by Jugoi no jo (Junior Fifth Rank, Upper Grade) Ushoben (Minor controller of the Right) SUGAWARA no Fumitoki.

history.name: Gyorogusho
history.desc: Gyorogusho was a book on the study of ancient courtly traditions and etiquette which compiled documents relating to the appointment to official positions such as moshibumi (letter of appointment) and omagaki (a list of candidates) as well as other related records such as "Seiryoki" and "Saikyuki."

history.name: Kasuga No Shinboku (The Sacred Tree Of Kasuga-Taisha Shrine)
history.url: history/Kasuga No Shinboku (The Sacred Tree Of Kasuga-Taisha Shrine).html
history.desc: "Kasuga no Shinboku" refers to "Shinboku" (the sacred tree) of Kasuga-taisha Shrine located in the present Nara Prefecture.

history.name: Nenjugyoji Utaawase
history.desc: Nenjugyoji Utaawase means Gojuban Utaawase hosted by Yoshimoto NIJO, Kanpaku (a chief adviser to the Emperor) of the Northern court (Japan), on February 7, 1350.

history.name: Bukeho
history.desc: Bukeho refers to a set of codes enforced on samurai society and on the military government during the medieval and the early modern times in Japan.

history.name: Honjo law
history.desc: Honjo low was enacted and enforced by honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor) for the purpose of ruling over their privately owned Shoen (manor in medieval Japan) as part of their Shomuken (the authority of the jurisdiction and the administration of Shoen).

history.name: Shomu
history.desc: Shomu refers to the actual practice of control and administration over kanno (encouragement of agriculture), trials, and the collection of taxes within shoen (the manor); it also refers to the individuals who were authorized to practice shomu.

history.name: Shomin
history.desc: Shomin refers to the people who belonged to shoen (manors) which were differentiated from the people who lived within koryo (public lands).

history.name: Jisha kogyoho (Shrine restoration policy)
history.desc: Jisha kogyoho was a series of ordinances that imperial court authority and bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) authority enforced to repair the main shrine buildings and the Buddhist temples of the religious institutions and to promote the strict observance of Shinto rituals and Buddhist memorial services.

history.name: Jisha honjoryo (lands of temples and nobles)
history.url: history/Jisha honjoryo (lands of temples and nobles).html
history.desc: Jisha Honjoryo was shoen (private estate) and shoryo (individual holding, domain) specifically meaning kugeryo (estate of the nobility) and jisharyo (estate of local temples and shrines) separately from bukeryo (estate of samurai family.)

history.name: Jishi Menkyo (The Exemption From The Tax That Was Imposed On The land Of The Town's Residential Area During The Early Modern Ages Of Japan)
history.url: history/Jishi Menkyo (The Exemption From The Tax That Was Imposed On The land Of The Towns Residential Area .html
history.desc: "Jishi menkyo" refers to the exemption from "jishi" (the tax imposed on the land of the town's residential area during the early modern ages of Japan) permitted by a feudal lord, and jishi corresponded to "nengu" (the tax imposed on the land of farming villages).

history.name: Seiba ga haru Battle
history.desc: Seiba ga haru no tatakai or Seiba ga haru kassen (Seiba ga haru Battle) was the battle fought between Daimyo (feudal lord) Yoshitaka OUCHI in the Chugoku District (western Honshu) and Daimyo Yoshiaki OTOMO in Bungo Province in May 1534 all over Mt. Omure in Bungo Province (present Yamaura, Yamaga-machi town, Kitsuki City, Oita Prefecture).

history.name: Koriwasen
history.desc: Koriwasen meant a merchant ship that operated a service from Japan to Korea only for the purpose of trade during the Muromachi period.

history.name: Kuji Kongen
history.desc: Kuji Kongen was a book on ancient practices and precedents of the imperial court written by Kaneyoshi ICHIJO during the Muromachi period.

history.name: Kujisen
history.desc: Kujisen was money paid in place of taxes in kind (including labor) as daisenno (paying dues in cash instead of in kind; commutation) for kuji (public duties) during Medieval Japan.

history.name: Jisharyo (Lands of local temples and shrines)
history.url: history/Jisharyo (Lands of local temples and shrines).html
history.desc: Jisharyo was a classification of fief that once existed in Japan.

history.name: Bukeryo (Lands of military families)
history.desc: Bukeryo was shoryo (individual holdings) of military families during the medieval Japan.

history.name: Zaigomachi (local town)
history.desc: Zaigomachi was one of Japanese city forms.

history.name: Jinyamachi (town around feudal lord's residence)
history.desc: Jinyamachi was one of the former Japanese city forms.

history.name: Rekishimachi (Historical town)
history.desc: Rekishimachi was one of Japanese city forms.

history.name: Gafusei (ivory tally system)
history.desc: Gafusei was one of the systems of examining and certificating an envoy (endorsement).

history.name: Cheng Shun-kung (Tei Shunko)
history.desc: Cheng Shun-kung (鄭舜功, Tei Shunko; dates unknown) was an adventurer during the latter half of the Ming period in China.

history.name: Keryo
history.desc: Keryo were such holdings as shoryo (individual estates) and shoen (manor in medieval Japan) inherited by kenmon (an influential family) for generations in Medieval Japan.

history.name: Teibi Yakujo
history.desc: Teibi Yakujo were regulations relating to the control of visitors to Japan which were agreed between the Yi-Dynasty and the So clan in Tsushima in 1547.

history.name: Teiji-In Uta-Awase (The Contest Of 'Tanka' [Thirty-One Japanese Syllable's Poem] In Teiji-In)
history.url: history/Teiji-In Uta-Awase (The Contest Of Tanka [Thirty-One Japanese Syllables Poem] In Teiji-In).html
history.desc: "Teiji-in uta-awase" refers to "uta-awase" (the contest of 'tanka' [thirty-one Japanese syllable's poem]), held on April 22, 913, by Cloistered Emperor Uda at his residence Teji-in.

history.name: Aosamurai
history.desc: Aosamurai were samurai warriors who served domestic governing institution of nobles and court nobles.

history.name: Aoso-Za (The Guild Of 'Aoso' [Boehmeria Nipononivea, A Fiber Material For Clothing])
history.url: history/Aoso-Za (The Guild Of Aoso [Boehmeria Nipononivea, A Fiber Material For Clothing]).html
history.desc: "Aoso-za" refers to "za" (the guild) of "aoso" (Boehmeria nipononivea, a fiber material for clothing), which was established in the later middle ages of Japan.

history.name: Gokeshidai (The Ritual Protocol Of The Oe House)
history.url: history/Gokeshidai (The Ritual Protocol Of The Oe House).html
history.desc: "Gokeshidai" is a collection of the books on "yusoku kojitsu" (court rules of ceremony and etiquette), written in the later Heian period.

history.name: Zaike (Min-oku)
history.desc: Zaike was a house, and the cultivated land and residents belonging to the house.

history.name: Zaike-Yaku (The Tax And The Labor Imposed In Medieval Japan)
history.url: history/Zaike-Yaku (The Tax And The Labor Imposed In Medieval Japan).html
history.desc: "Zaike-yaku" refers to the tax and the labor that were imposed per "zaike" in medieval Japan.

history.name: Shoto
history.desc: Shoto was the tax levied on paddy fields and dry fields in the Medieval period.

history.name: Kenden
history.desc: Kenden was a survey of farmland, recording area, cultivator, soil and so forth.

history.name: Kenchi-Cho (The Land Survey Register)
history.desc: "Kenchi-cho" refers to the register compiled per village, in which the result of "kenchi" (land survey) was added up.

history.name: Kenchucho
history.desc: Kenchucho refers to ledgers for recording the results of kenchu (land surveys) in shoen (manors) during ancient and medieval times in Japan.

history.name: Shugai Sanjurokkasen
history.desc: Shugai Sanjurokkasen is a collection of poems by 36 poets from the Muromachi period to the early Edo period following the example of Sanjurokkasen (36 Master Poets).

history.name: Bukeshisso
history.desc: Bukeshisso is a term that relates to the Court-Bakufu (the Imperial Court and Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) relationship between the Muromachi bakufu and the Northern Court in Japan (the court noble government), and the term has the two following meanings:

history.name: Hoshi
history.desc: Hoshi refers to officers of provincial government who administered ho, which was a type of Kokugaryo (the territories governed by a provincial government office) in medieval Japan.

history.name: Joden
history.desc: Joden (定田) refers to rice fields which were designated, as a result of a kenchu (land survey) on territories belonging to shoen (manors) and koryo (public lands), as taxable lands in regard to the payment of kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes), shoto (tax on rice fields), nengu (annual tribute, land tax), and kuji (public duties).

history.name: Kamakura Bakufu
history.desc: The Kamakura Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) was a samurai government (bakufu) established in Kamakura (currently, Kanagawa City, Kamakura Prefecture) by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.

history.name: Subjugation of Takeda
history.desc: The "subjugation of Takeda" in Japanese history refers to a series of battles fought by Nobunaga ODA, who invaded the territories of Katsuyori TAKEDA (Suruga, Shinano and Kai Provinces) in order to destroy the Takeda clan, whose power was in decline after the Battle of Nagashino.

history.name: Katanagari (sword hunt)
history.desc: Katanagari (written as 刀狩 or 刀狩り) was a policy of heinobunri (separating warriors and peasants) which deprived those in the peasant class of their privilege of wearing swords, which highlighted the policy enacted by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI through the katanagari edict (at the same time, pirate ship interdiction) issued on August 29, 1588 in the Azuchi-Momoyama period (The first person who executed katanagari was Katsuie SHIBATA.

history.name: Shi-no-ko-sho (hereditary four-status order consisting of warrior-rulers, peasants, artisans, and merchants)
history.url: history/Shi-no-ko-sho (hereditary four-status order consisting of warrior-rulers, peasants, artisans, and me.html
history.desc: Shi-no-ko-sho was a Confucian concept of societal ranking (government official, farmers, artisans, merchants) that accounted for the main part of the society.

history.name: Azuchi-jo Castle
history.desc: Azuchi-jo Castle was a flatland-mountain Japanese castle (hirayamajiro) located at present Shimotoira, Azuchi-cho, Gamo County, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: The Battle of Shizugatake
history.desc: The Battle of Shizugatake was a war which occurred in 1583 between Hideyoshi HASHIBA (later Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) and Katsuie SHIBATA near Shizugatake Mountain in Ika District of Omi Province (present Ika County, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Dai Nihonshi
history.desc: Dai Nihonshi is a Japanese history book.

history.name: Bunkokuho
history.desc: Bunkokuho is a law established by warlords during the Sengoku period to govern their domains.

history.name: Hoken system
history.desc: The Hoken system is a political system modeled after the Shu Dynasty in China, which was advocated in the political thought of Kanji using nations, such as China.

history.name: Saccho Domei (Satsuma-Choshu Alliance)
history.desc: Saccho Domei' refers to the political and military alliance concluded on March 7, 1866 in the last days of the Edo period between the Satsuma Domain and Choshu Domain.

history.name: Hanchin
history.desc: Hanchin is a term used for the provincial organization that existed from the Tang Dynasty to the Northern Song Dynasty.

history.name: Kobu Gattai (Alliance between Imperial Court and Shogunate)
history.url: history/Kobu Gattai (Alliance between Imperial Court and Shogunate).html
history.desc: Kobu gattai is a policy promoted in the second half of the Edo period which aimed to reassert the power of the Shogunate by bonding the traditional authority of the Imperial Court to the Shogunate.

history.name: Kyoto Protocol
history.desc: Kyoto Protocol refers to a protocol adopted at the 3rd Session of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (Kyoto Conference on Climate Change, COP3) held at Kyoto International Conference Center on December 11, 1997, according to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

history.name: Mujin
history.desc: Mujin is one type of Japanese financing.

history.name: Kamigata
history.desc: Kamigata is a name used in the Edo period referring to Kinai including Osaka and Kyoto.

history.name: Kyoto stock exchange
history.desc: The Kyoto stock exchange was abolished on March 1st, 2001.

history.name: Tensho Ken-o Shonen Shisetsu
history.desc: Tensho Ken-o Shonen Shisetsu was a mission of four boys and others dispatched to Rome in 1582, acting for Yoshishige OTOMO, Sumitada OMURA, and Harunobu ARIMA, who were the Christian feudal lords in Kyushu.

history.name: Ashina clan
history.desc: The Ashina clan was descended from the Taira clan through the Miura clan with the name Ashina (蘆名) derived from the name of the area known as Ashina (present Ashina (芦名) in Yokosuka City).

history.name: The Aso Clan
history.desc: The Aso clan originated in Higo Province.

history.name: The Battle of Tensho
history.desc: The Battle of Tensho (Tensho no Jin) was one in which the army led by Takakage KOBAYAKAWA, of the Mori clan in the Chugoku region, landed at Nii County, Iyo Province (the present-day Niihama City, Ehime Prefecture) in Shikoku in 1585, doing so at the orders of Hideyoshi HASHIBA (Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI), who was attempting to integrate the entire nation, and defeated the local troops led by the lord of Kaneko-jo Castle, Motoie KANEKO, of the Kaneko clan, with overwhelming force.

history.name: Kiyosu conference
history.desc: The Kiyosu conference was held on the 27th of June (according to the old calendar) during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

history.name: The Battle of Kyushu
history.desc: The Battle of Kyushu was a general name for battles between Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (surname "Toyotomi" was bestowed on September 9, 1586) and the Shimazu clan from August and September 1586 to May and June 1587.

history.name: Hikone-jo Castle
history.desc: tenshu (castle tower), yagura (turret), mon (gate), hei (wall), umaya (stable), ishigaki (stone wall), dorui (earthwork), hori (moat)

history.name: Tenshojingo War
history.desc: The Tenshojingo War was fought between Ieyasu TOKUGAWA and Ujinao HOJO in the provinces of Kai, Shinano and Kozuke beginning in 1582.

history.name: Kawachi-Genji
history.desc: Kawachi-Genji is a school of Seiwa-Genji based in Kawachi province

history.name: The Settsu-Genji
history.desc: The Settsu-Genji (a branch of the Minamoto clan)

history.name: Tada-Genji (Minamoto clan)
history.desc: Tada Genji is the name of the line which originated from MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka (Mitsunaka TADA) among Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) branches and was based in Tada.

history.name: Edict expelling Jesuit missionaries
history.desc: The Edict expelling Jesuit missionaries was a prohibition document concerning the mission of Christianity and trade with Spain and Portugal issued by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in Chikuzen Hakozaki, in July 24, 1587.

history.name: Expulsion Edict (Hitobarairei)
history.desc: The Expulsion Edict is a law Kanpaku TOYOTOMI Hidetsugu issued in 1592 during the Azuchi Momoyama period.

history.name: Sawayama-jo Castle
history.desc: Sawayama-jo Castle was a mountain castle (of which almost no trace remains today) and was located in Hikone City in Shiga Prefecture (what was once Inukami County of Omi Province).

history.name: Kyoto-shugo (military governor of Kyoto)
history.desc: Kyoto-shugo is one of the occupational categories of the Kamakura bakufu.

history.name: The Goto troops in Japan's Invasion of Korea
history.jp: 朝鮮出兵における五島勢
history.url: history/The Goto troops in Japans Invasion of Korea.html
history.desc: Here is the article "The Goto troops in Japan's Invasion of Korea" about the activities of Goto Domain in Hizen Province (Fukue Domain, the present Goto Islands in Nagasaki Prefecture) in the Bunroku and Keicho War led by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

history.name: The Mineyama domain
history.desc: The Mineyama domain was a domain existing in Tango province.

history.name: Sekke shogun
history.desc: Sekke shogun designates two seii taishoguns (great generals) among the shoguns in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government), that is, the fourth FUJIWARA no Yoritsune and his legitimate son, the fifth FUJIWARA no Yoritsugu.

history.name: Tanada
history.desc: Tanada means a rice-producing area located on a slope.

history.name: The Kyoto school
history.desc: The Kyoto school is a school of philosophy formed by Kitaro NISHIDA, Hajime TANABE, and philosophers learned from these two, while a group featured interdisciplinary research centered on Institute for Research in Humanities, Kyoto University, is called New Kyoto school to distinguish it from the Kyoto school or school of philosophy.

history.name: Suigun
history.desc: Suigun is the traditional armed forces on the water in the countries in East Asia where Chinese characters are used.

history.name: Shuinsen (shogunate-licensed trading ship)
history.desc: The Shuinsen was a ship that carried out foreign trade by receiving the Shuinjo (the permit to travel to foreign countries) of the Japanese ruler between the end of the sixteenth century to the early seventeenth century.

history.name: Teppoki
history.desc: Teppoki (Gun Chronicle) is a history book concerning the transmission of guns to Japan, and was completed in 1606 during the Edo period.

history.name: Konden (New rice field)
history.desc: Konden means a newly developed rice field in the Ritsuryo period of Japan.

history.name: Kunikyo
history.desc: Kunikyo (also called Kuni no miya) was a place in Soraku District, Yamashiro Province that was designated as a capital for a period of time during the Nara period.

history.name: Nihon Bijutsu-Shi (Japanese Art History)
history.desc: "Nihon bijutsu-shi" refers to the chronological explanation - or the academic field - of Japanese art history, such as the trend of Japanese art, the transition of its style, the research of the representative works and artists in each period, their mutual influence, and the historical background of the works and artists - that is, the works' and artists' relation with Japanese politics, economy, religion, customs, society, literature and others.

history.name: Sakamoto-jo Castle
history.desc: Nagahide NIWA, Nagamasa ASANO

history.name: Yamaga Domain
history.desc: Yamaga Domain included the areas in and around Yamaga in Ikaruga no kori (Ikaruga County), Tanba Province as its territory.

history.name: Otsu-jo Castle
history.desc: Otsu-jo Castle was located in Otsu, Shiga County, Omi Province in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

history.name: Kannonji-jo Castle
history.desc: Honmaru (the keep of a castle), Ninomaru (second bailey), Kuruwa (a space reserved for various purposes), dorui (earthen walls for fortification), Stonewalls, Moats, Monzeki (temples in which the chief priests are either members of the imperial family or nobilities), etc.

history.name: Minakuchi-jo Castle
history.desc: Minakuchi-jo Castle is located in Minakuchi, Minakuchi-cho, Koka City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: Sobuji-rei
history.desc: Sobuji-rei was an edict that prohibited duels between daimyo (feudal lords), issued by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

history.name: The Ishikawa Clan
history.desc: The Ishikawa clan was a family that assumed the family name of Ishikawa.

history.name: Kanko
history.desc: Kanko ('guanhu' in Chinese) was the name of a social status that existed in premodern China and in Japan under the ritsuryo system.

history.name: The Bunroku-Keicho War
history.desc: The Bunroku-Keicho War was a war conducted during the period from 1592 (Japan: Bunroku one; Ming and Yi Dynasty Korea: Banreki twenty) to 1598 (Japan: Keicho three; Ming and Yi Dynasty Korea: Banreki twenty-six).

history.name: Wakae Hachinin-shu (eight elite retainers of Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI)
history.url: history/Wakae Hachinin-shu (eight elite retainers of Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI).html
history.desc: Wakae Hachinin-shu is a popular term for the group of elite retainers of Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI.

history.name: Kyoto Dento
history.desc: Kyoto Dento was a Japanese electric power company founded in 1888.

history.name: Kaieki
history.desc: In the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), the term kaieki referred to removing someone from their current post and appointing someone new to that position.

history.name: Kunitomo
history.desc: The word "Kunitomo" referred to Kunitomo Village in Sakata County, Omi Province (present-day Kunitomo-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture), which was renowned for its production of firearms along with Sakai City during the Warring States period through to the end of the Edo period, and also to gunsmiths who worked in Kunitomo Village (called "Kunitomo Kaji" in Japanese).

history.name: Goshiki no Sen (the lowly persons of five kinds)
history.url: history/Goshiki no Sen (the lowly persons of five kinds).html
history.desc: Goshiki no sen a status of discrimination in ancient Japan which was constituted under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Instantaneous Discharge Matchlock
history.desc: Instantaneous discharge matchlock is an ignition system for matchlock guns, which are represented by Japanese hinawa-ju (literally, fire rope gun).

history.name: Gradual Discharge Matchlock
history.desc: Gradual discharge matchlock is a gun with a type of matchlock explosion mechanism, 'gradual discharge.'

history.name: Hisara (Flash pan)
history.desc: Flash pan is a receptacle sticking out from the side of the barrel for priming powder in matchlock guns and flintlock guns.

history.name: Mimaki Domain
history.desc: Mimaki Domain is a domain which was in Mimaki, Kuse County, Yamashiro Province (present-day Kumiyama-cho, Kuse-gun, Kyoto Prefecture).

history.name: Hayago
history.desc: A hayago is a pouch for gun powder and bullet which was used to simplify the loading process for muzzle loaders (guns where bullets were loaded from the muzzle) such as matchlock and other guns, presumably from the latter part of the Sengoku period (period of Warring States) or from the Azuchi Momoyama period.

history.name: Omi-Genji (Minamoto clan)
history.desc: The name "Omi-Genji" refers to the clan who originated from Genji (Minamoto clan) and settled in Omi Province as their home base in the Medieval period.

history.name: Shisen no Tatakai (The Battle of Shisen)
history.url: history/Shisen no Tatakai (The Battle of Shisen).html
history.desc: Shisen no Tatakai was one of the Japanese battles which occurred during the Bunroku-Keicho War.

history.name: Moko Shurai Ekotoba
history.desc: "Moko Shurai Ekotoba" is a pair of picture scrolls by an unknown author.

history.name: Zeze-jo Castle
history.desc: Zeze-jo Castle used to stand in present Honmaru-cho, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: The Battle of Ueda
history.desc: The Battle of Ueda is a generic name for the battles between the Sanada clan and the Tokugawa clan fought around Ueda-jo Castle in Shinano Province (present day Ueda City, Nagano Prefecture) and neighboring mountain castles, and around Kan-gawa River that runs north-south in the eastern part of Ueda City, etc.

history.name: Umekita Ikki
history.desc: Umekita ikki (Umekita Uprising) is an uprising instigated by Kunikane UMEKITA, a vassal of the Shimazu clan in July 1592.

history.name: Heredity
history.desc: Heredity means that a specific status or title (e.g. official rank, peerage) held by a parent or their occupation or the like is passed on to their children, family members or in-laws, thus ensuring that such successors obtain social power and authority.

history.name: Tensho o-jishin (The Great Earthquake of the Tensho Era)
history.url: history/Tensho o-jishin (The Great Earthquake of the Tensho Era).html
history.desc: Tensho o-jishin was an earthquake which occurred on January 18, 1586.

history.name: The Northern Tango Earthquake
history.desc: The earthquake in the northern Tango Province occurred at 6:27:39 pm on March 7, 1927.

history.name: Juen-koka (10-yen coin)
history.desc: Juen-koka (10-yen coin) is a subsidiary coin issued by the Japanese government.

history.name: The Naoejo (Naoe Letter)
history.desc: The Naoejo is a letter written in 1600, sent from Kanetsugu NAOE, a senior retainer of the Uesugi family, to Saisho Jotai who negotiated with the Uesugi family ordered by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

history.name: Shinano Genji (Minamoto clan)
history.desc: Shinano Genji is a name given to the Minamoto clan who were native to and based in Shinano Province during the medieval period.

history.name: Oda government
history.desc: The Oda government is a samurai government which existed in Japan from 1573 (virtually 1568) to 1582.

history.name: The Toyotomi Government
history.desc: The Toyotomi government was a Japanese government that ruled the country from 1590 (in fact, 1585) to 1603.

history.name: One-yen coin
history.desc: The one-yen coin is a subsidiary coin issued by the Japanese government.

history.name: 100-yen coin
history.desc: The 100-yen coin is a subsidiary coin issued by the Japanese government.

history.name: Ramrod
history.desc: Karuka, sakujo, komeya were the Japanese names for the ramrod used for loading muzzle loading guns.

history.name: Maizuru Prefecture
history.desc: Maizuru Prefecture is a prefecture established in 1871 based on the policy of Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

history.name: Toyooka Prefecture
history.desc: Toyooka Prefecture is a prefecture established in 1871 based on the policy of Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

history.name: Miyazu Prefecture
history.desc: Miyazu Prefecture is a prefecture established in 1871 based on the policy of Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

history.name: Mineyama Prefecture
history.desc: Mineyama Prefecture was established in 1871 through Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

history.name: The Battle of Otsu-jo Castle
history.desc: The Battle of Otsu-jo Castle took place from October 13, 1600 to October 21, 1600.

history.name: Heimin (commoners)
history.desc: Heimin means ordinary citizens without any official rank or title.

history.name: Nagahama-jo Castle (Omi Prefecture)
history.desc: Nagahama-jo Castle is a castle built by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in Koen-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: Yokoyama Party
history.desc: The Yokoyama Party, centered in the Yokoyama-sho estate in Tama County, Musashi Province (the present Hachioji City, Tokyo), was an armed group from the same family that existed from the late Heian period to the Kamakura period, and based themselves in Musashi Province (Osato County, Hiki County, and Tachibana County) and the northern part of Sagami Province.

history.name: Kyoto Horse Racing Club
history.desc: The Kyoto Horse Racing Club was an organization which used to hold horse races.

history.name: Shido-shogun (Generals Dispatched to Four Circuits)
history.desc: The term "Shido-shogun" refers to four imperial (royal) generals who appeared in the Nihon Shoki (the Chronicle of Japan), namely Obiko no mikoto, Takenunakawa wake no mikoto, Kibitsuhiko no mikoto and tanbamichi nushi no mikoto.

history.name: Yamato-Genji (Minamoto clan)
history.desc: Yamato-Genji, a branch of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan), was started by MINAMOTO no Yorichika, the second son of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka.

history.name: Dai Juroku Shidan (Sixteenth Division) of the Imperial Japanese Army
history.url: history/Dai Juroku Shidan (Sixteenth Division) of the Imperial Japanese Army.html
history.desc: The Sixteenth Division was one of the divisions of the Imperial Japanese Army.

history.name: The Okochi Clan
history.desc: The Okochi clan is part of the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) and Settsu-Genji (Minamoto clan), and is said to have been established when Akitsuna, the grandson of MINAMOTO no Yorimasa, moved to Okochi-go, Nukata County in Mikawa Province (which some have asserted to be the present-day Aza-Okochi, Ohira-cho, Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture) and called himself Okochi.

history.name: Kumihama Prefecture
history.desc: Kumihama Prefecture was a prefecture established in 1868.

history.name: Ikuno Prefecture
history.desc: Ikuno Prefecture was a prefecture that was established in 1869.

history.name: Seyaku-in
history.desc: Seyaku-in (the pharmacy institution), which was established in the Nara period as a ryogenokan (extra statutory office), was a rescue facility for common people as well as a garden of medicinal plants.

history.name: New art movements in the Taisho period
history.url: history/New art movements in the Taisho period.html
history.desc: New art movements in the Taisho period refers to avant-garde art movements under strong influence of overseas art trends (particularly Mirai-ha [Futurism] and Dada) in the Taisho period (from the late 1910s to the early 1920s, but mainly in the early 1920s).

history.name: Kyoto Red Flag Incident
history.desc: The Kyoto Red Flag Incident was a crackdown on socialists that occurred on November 30, 1920.

history.name: Senmin (humble or lowly people)
history.desc: Senmin indicates a rank or a person of such rank who is placed lower than the common person.

history.name: Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums)
history.url: history/Shoryoryo (the Bureau for managing imperial mausoleums).html
history.desc: The Shoryoryo was an organization which belonged to Jibu-sho Ministry (the Ministry of Civil Administration) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Rokoku Hakase (Master of Clock)
history.desc: Rokoku Hakase was a post appointed by Onmyoryo (a government office that had jurisdiction over calendar preparation, astronomy, divination, etc.) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Reki Hakase (Chief Court Calendar-Maker)
history.desc: The Reki Hakase was one of the government posts established under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Tokyo Gyoko (Imperial visit to Tokyo)
history.desc: Tokyo gyoko are the imperial visits to Tokyo which were made twice in 1868 and 1869.

history.name: The Bank of Yanagihara
history.desc: The Bank of Yanagihara was a private bank founded in Yanagihara-cho, Kyoto Prefecture (present Kyoto City) in the Meiji period.

history.name: Monyo (blood line, lineage, connected by blood)
history.url: history/Monyo (blood line, lineage, connected by blood).html
history.desc: The term "monyo" generally referred to families that were related by blood.

history.name: Nichisei Kankeishi
history.desc: Nichisei Kankeishi (or Nissei Kankeishi) refers to the history of relations between Spain and Japan.

history.name: The SHIONOYA clan
history.desc: The SHIONOYA clan is a Japanese clan.

history.name: Eizo Kyoto Film Company
history.desc: The Eizo Kyoto Film Company is a film and television production company.

history.name: Gamo Sodo (The Feud of the Gamo Family)
history.url: history/Gamo Sodo (The Feud of the Gamo Family).html
history.desc: Gamo Sodo was a family dispute occurred to the Gamo clan, which headed the estate of Aizu-wakamatsu with 920,000 koku of rice (165,959 cubic meters of rice-crop yield), which occurred between 1595 and 1598.

history.name: The Shingu clan
history.desc: The Shingu clan is one of the clans in Japan.

history.name: Korokan
history.desc: Korokan was a facility established in the Heian period for diplomacy and overseas trade.

history.name: Bunkakosei-kaikan Hall Affair
history.desc: The Bunkakosei-kaikan Hall Affair is a conflict that started with the Buraku Liberation League, Kyoto Federation being divided into two groups, one (Asada Furen, Asada faction's Federation) with Zennosuke ASADA as a chairman, approved by the Headquarter of the Buraku Liberation League and the other (Miki Furen, Miki faction's Federation) with Ippei MIKI as a chairman, supported by the Japanese Communist Party.

history.name: The Sugimoto clan
history.desc: The Sugimoto clan is one of the samurai families in Japan.

history.name: Misawa clan
history.desc: Misawa clan (which is read Misawa-shi or Misawa-uji) was a clan acting as estate steward in Iijima District, Shinano Province, which were the descendants of Shinano-Genji (Minamoto clan).

history.name: The Asuke clan
history.desc: The Asuke clan is one of the Japanese clans.

history.name: Yokoyama-jo Castle (in Omi Province)
history.desc: Yokoyama-jo Castle was located in Sakata County, Omi Province (the present-day Horibe and Ishida-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Shugosho (provincial administration)
history.desc: Shogosho was the seat of the castle where Shugo (provincial constable) lived in medieval Japan.

history.name: The Battle of the Nakatomi-gawa River
history.url: history/The Battle of the Nakatomi-gawa River.html
history.desc: The Battle of the Nakatomi-gawa River, in 1582, was a battle between Motochika CHOSOKABE, a lord of Tosa Province, who intended to integrate the Shikoku region, and Masayasu SOGO, a lord of Awa Province.

history.name: Conquest of Kishu
history.desc: The words "Kishu Seibatsu" or "Kishu-zeme" refer to the conquest of Kii Province by Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in the Azuchi-Momoyama period).

history.name: The Wakisaka clan
history.desc: The Wakisaka clan is a Japanese clan.

history.name: The Battle of Bitchu Takamatsu-jo Castle
history.url: history/The Battle of Bitchu Takamatsu-jo Castle.html
history.desc: The Battle of Bitchu Takamatsu-jo Castle was a battle in 1582 in which, on the order of Nobunaga ODA, his karo (retainer) Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI conquered Takamatsu-jo Castle, owned by Muneharu SHIMIZU, in Bitchu Province in the territory of the Mori clan.

history.name: The Oguni clan
history.desc: The Oguni clan is a Japanese clan.

history.name: Kidendo
history.desc: Kidendo is a subject in the daigakuryo (Bureau of Education under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code)) in Japan under the Ritsuryo system in which history (mainly Chinese history) was taught.

history.name: Battle of Kawarayama-jo Castle
history.desc: The Battle of Kawarayama-jo Castle is a battle that broke out in Aseri County, Hoki Province in July 1585.

history.name: Japanese tenkoku (seal-engraving) history
history.desc: It is the history of the tenkoku and insho (seals) in Japan.

history.name: Sasakiyama gimi
history.desc: Sasakiyama gimi, or Sasakiyama no kimi (沙沙貴山君), was one of the powerful families in ancient times.

history.name: Kyoto Asahigaoka Junior High School Affair
history.url: history/Kyoto Asahigaoka Junior High School Affair.html
history.desc: The Kyoto Asahigaoka Junior High School affair is a conflict that lasted from April 29, 1953 to June 1, 1954, between conservative and progressive parents/teachers over the education policy of Kyoto Municipal Asahigaoka Junior High school.

history.name: Tenmon Hahakase (Doctor of Astronomy)
history.desc: Tenmon hakase was a government post belonging to Onmyoryo (Bureau of Divination) in the ritsuryo system of ancient Japan.

history.name: Mineyama Naval Air Squadron
history.desc: The Mineyama Naval Air Squadron was one of the squadrons of the Imperial Japanese Navy.

history.name: The Takanashi clan
history.desc: The Takanashi clan was a samurai family that dominated the north of Shinano Province (Takai and Minochi counties).

history.name: The Case of an Attack on the Shichijo Police Station
history.url: history/The Case of an Attack on the Shichijo Police Station.html
history.desc: The case of an attack on the Shichijo Police Station was an assault that occurred on January 24, 1946 in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

history.name: The Case of the Murder of a Shichijo Police Constable
history.jp: 七条警察署巡査殺害事件
history.url: history/The Case of the Murder of a Shichijo Police Constable.html
history.desc: The case of the murder of a Shichijo Police constable is a homicide that occurred on June 9, 1946 in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

history.name: The Tada clan
history.desc: The Tada clan were the descendants of "Seiwa-Genji" (Minamoto clan).

history.name: Soshu Hojutsu Chorenjo (gunnery practice field of Sagami Province in the Edo period)
history.url: history/Soshu Hojutsu Chorenjo (gunnery practice field of Sagami Province in the Edo period).html
history.desc: Soshu Hojutsu Chorenjo refers to a gunnery practice field in the Edo period located on the seashore in Fujisawa City and Chigasaki City, an area that is now within the boundary of Kanagawa Prefecture.

history.name: Yoriai
history.desc: Yoriai is a consultation organization in villages under the goson-sei system (municipal system of small towns and villages) that began in the Middle Ages in Japan.

history.name: Tensho-tsuho Coins
history.desc: Tensho-tsuho are coins that were issued during the Azuchimomoyama period.

history.name: The Battle of Katsurakawara
history.desc: The Battle of Katsurakawara was a battle fought on the riverbed of Katsura-gawa River in the odo-gawa River system in Kyoto Prefecture from the night on March 14 to March 15, 1527.

history.name: Hino Castle
history.desc: Hino Castle was a Japanese castle located in Hino Town, Gamo County, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: Mitoya Clan
history.desc: The Mitoya clan was one of Japanese clans.

history.name: Onmyo hakase (Doctor of onmyo)
history.desc: Onmyo hakase was a teaching position created at the Onmyoryo (Bureau of Divination) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Rekido
history.desc: Rekido is the ancient Japanese study of calendar-making.

history.name: Tenmondo
history.desc: Tenmondo (ancient horoscopy) is an ancient study involving the observation and recording of unusual astronomical phenomena (extraordinary astronomical events/extraordinary natural phenomena) and investigation of their effects on the Earth.

history.name: Kutsuki Domain
history.desc: The Kutsuki clan was a clan located in Takashima County, Omi Province (current Kutsuki, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Tango no kuni Fudoki (the records of Tango Province)
history.url: history/Tango no kuni Fudoki (the records of Tango Province).html
history.desc: "Tango no kuni Fudoki" (The records of Tango Province) is a record of Tango Province (now the northern part of Kyoto Prefecture).

history.name: Kyohachiryu School
history.desc: Kyohachiryu is a legendary school of swordsmanship.

history.name: The Battle of Nejirozaka
history.desc: The Battle of Nejirozaka was a battle fought between pro-Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI forces and pro-Yoshihisa SHIMAZU forces in Nejirozaka, Hyuga Province on May 24, 1587.

history.name: The SHIDA Clan
history.desc: The SHIDA clan (Shidashi, Shidauji) is a Japanese clan.

history.name: The OIKAWA Clan
history.desc: The OIKAWA clan was a Japanese clan.

history.name: The Battle of Jugorigahara
history.desc: During the Battle of Jugorigahara, which was fought in September and October 1588, the allied troops of Kagekatsu UESUGI and Yoshikatsu DAIHOJI, led by Shigenaga HONJO, fought against Yoshiaki MOGAMI's troops, which were led by the brothers Yoshinaga and Katsumasa TOZENJI.

history.name: Budan-ha
history.desc: The Budan-ha (a political faction that is willing to resort to military means to achieve its aims) was a faction in the Toyotomi government.

history.name: The Ina Clan
history.desc: The Ina clan was one of the Japanese shizoku (clans, or samurai families).

history.name: Bunchi-ha Faction
history.desc: The Bunchi-ha was a faction that existed during the Toyotomi administration.

history.name: Shonai Rebellion
history.desc: The Shonai Rebellion occurred in 1599 in Shonai, Hyuga Province (the present-day Miyakonojo City, Miyazaki Prefecture and surroundings) between the Shimazu clan and the Ijuin clan, the chief vassal of the Shimazu clan.

history.name: Yamashiro no Kuni no Miyatsuko
history.desc: Yamashiro no Kuni no Miyatsuko (also known as Yamashiro Kokuzo, written as 山背国造 or 山代国造) was a kuninomiyatsuko (provincial governor) who ruled the south-west part of Yamashiro Province.

history.name: The Yanagisawa Clan
history.desc: The Yanagisawa was a Japanese feudal clan (samurai warriors).

history.name: Ichikaiso Government
history.desc: The Ichikaiso Government was a politically prominent group in Kyoto, the center of politics at the end of the Tokugawa Shogunate; it was formed of Kinri-goshuei-sotoku (Governor-general of the inner palace's guard) Sekkai-bogyo-shiki (Commander of the coastal defense of Osaka-wan Bay) Yoshinobu HITOTSUBASHI, Kyoto-shugoshoku (Military governor of Kyoto) Katamori MATSUDAIRA from the Aizu clan, and Kyoto-shoshidai (Deputy for Governor-general of Kyoto) Sadaaki MATSUDAIRA from the Kuwana clan.

history.name: Minakuchi Okayama-jo Castle
history.desc: Minakuchi Okayama-jo Castle is located in Minakuchi, Minakuchi-cho, Koka-shi City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: Mutsu Ishikawa clan
history.desc: Ishikawa clan was a samurai family from the mid-Heian period to the Warring States period (Japan).

history.name: the Teshima clan
history.desc: The Teshima clan is one of the clans in Japan.

history.name: Diminishing the Territory
history.desc: Diminishing the territory was a type of punishment imposed on samurai including daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and hatamoto (direct vassal of the shogun) during the Edo period, that deprived samurai of their ranks, and partially diminished their territories, castles, and residences.

history.name: Kida Clan
history.desc: The Kida clan was one of the Japanese shizoku families (clan, samurai family).

history.name: the Nose clan
history.desc: The Nose clan was a taishin ryoshu (noble land owner) in Settsu Province (Hokusetsu region).

history.name: Gunyaku
history.desc: Gunyaku (also known as Guneki) was a military service and provisions that was imposed by the lord on a retainer to offer in wartime.

history.name: Kojin-bashi Incident
history.desc: The Kojin-bashi Incident is an incident that occurred on November 11, 1953, where a group of Kyoto University student demonstrators who had been marching up to the large-scale meeting at the Hirokoji campus of Ritsumeikan University, had a collision with the police on Kojin-bashi Bridge (Kyoto City).

history.name: Gojo Rakuen
history.desc: Gojo Rakuen is an old yukaku (a red-light district) site located in the south-east area of Kawaramachi-dori and Gojo-dori Streets in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City.

history.name: The Utsumi Clan
history.desc: The Utsumi clan (also known as the Uchiumi, the Uchimi, or the Uchikai clan) is a Japanese family name.

history.name: Kawakatsu Clan
history.desc: The Kawakatsu clan (Kawakatsu-shi or Kawakatsu-uji) was a Japanese clan.

history.name: Kyoto Province Kamo-gawa River Act
history.desc: The Kyoto Province Kamo-gawa River Act is an act by Kyoto Province.

history.name: Koshibagaki Zoshi
history.desc: Koshibagaki Zoshi (The Tale of the Brushwood Fence) is a picture scroll.

history.name: Fukuro Hoshi Ekotoba
history.desc: Fukuro Hoshi Ekotoba (Picture Book of Fukuro Bonze) is a picture scroll.

history.name: Hachimanyama-jo Castle
history.desc: the Asai clan, Hidetsugu HASHIBA, Takatsugu KYOGOKU, Kuruwa (walls of a castle), stone wall

history.name: Tensho oban
history.desc: The Tensho oban is a type of oban (large monetary gold plate in the shape of a flat oval) that had been struck by the Goto family, time-honored craftsmen of gold, mainly by order of the Toyotomi family since the Azuchi Momoyama period until the early Edo period; it is considered to have been minted first in 1588, and the well-known 'Tensho hishi oban', 'Tensho naga oban' and 'Daibutsu oban' are categorized under it.

history.name: Dainihonkoku Ichinomiya-Ki
history.desc: "Dainihonkoku Ichinomiya-Ki" is an Ichinomiya Ichiran (catalogue of high-ranking shrines of Shinto in Japan) which was written in the Muromachi period, and it was collected into "Gunsho ruiju (Collection of historical documents compiled by Hokiichi HANAWA)" (Volume 23, Part of gods, Collection 2).

history.name: Kazanin
history.desc: Kazanin was a residence that was located in Sancho, Shibo, Ichijo, Sakyo (present Kyoto Gyoen) in Heian-kyo City.

history.name: Usayama-jo Castle
history.desc: Usayama-jo Castle was a yamajiro (a castle built atop a mountain to take advantage of the mountain's topography) constructed in the Medieval Period, and its ruins can be found near Nishikoori, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: Mochizuki-jo Castle (Omi Province)
history.desc: Mochizuki-jo Castle was a Japanese castle which was situated in Koga City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: The Kyoto Old Capital Preservation Cooperation Tax
history.url: history/The Kyoto Old Capital Preservation Cooperation Tax.html
history.desc: The Kyoto Old Capital Preservation Cooperation Tax was one of the local taxes, which was once levied in accordance with a tax ordinance enacted by Kyoto city.

history.name: Oshikoji Karasumadono Residence
history.desc: Oshikoji Karasumadono residence was one of residential palaces in Medieval Kyoto.

history.name: The Battle of Shokusan
history.desc: The Battle of Shokusan was fought between the Japanese army and the Ming army during the Keicho Campaign.

history.name: The Battle of Shimanto-gawa River
history.desc: The Battle of Shimanto-gawa River, which is also referred to as the 'Battle of Watari-gawa River,' was a battle that confirmed the unification of Tosa Province (Kochi Prefecture) by Motochika CHOSOKABE in 1575.

history.name: Shimojima navy
history.desc: The Shimojima clan was an active navy based in Maizuru Bay in Kyoto Prefecture.

history.name: Kinri Goshuei Sotoku (post to guard Kinri Palace)
history.url: history/Kinri Goshuei Sotoku (post to guard Kinri Palace).html
history.desc: Kinri Goshuei Sotoku is the post set up to protect the kinri gosho (Kyoto Imperial Palace) under the understanding of bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in the end of Edo Period.

history.name: War of Arioka-jo Castle
history.desc: The War of Arioka-jo Castle was a siege conducted in the period from August 1578 to November 17, 1579.

history.name: List of buildings and structures in Kyoto Prefecture which have been designated as important cultural properties
history.jp: 京都府にある建造物の重要文化財一覧
history.url: history/List of buildings and structures in Kyoto Prefecture which have been designated as important cultura.html
history.desc: The list of buildings and structures in Kyoto Prefecture which have been designated as important cultural properties lists those existing in Kyoto Prefecture from all the buildings and structures designated as important cultural property in Japan.

history.name: Ryakumyo dodai
history.desc: Ryakumyo dodai (also called rekimei-dodai) was the record book of Ikai-Bunin (directory of Court ranks) of Shii (Fourth Rank) and Goi (Fifth Rank) in medieval Japan.

history.name: Amazuka-kofun Tumulus
history.desc: Amazuka-kofun Tumulus is a kofun (tumulus) at Uzumasa Matsumoto-cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

history.name: Buson Yokai Emaki
history.desc: "Buson Yokai Emaki" is a Japanese picture scroll of specters drawn by YOSA no Buson, a Haiku poet and painter during the middle of the Edo period.

history.name: Sakushazuke
history.desc: A sakushazuke is a book which lists the writers of noh plays.

history.name: Constitution of the Empire of Japan
history.url: history/Constitution of the Empire of Japan.html
history.desc: The Constitution of the Empire of Japan was the organic law of the Empire of Japan based on the idea of modern constitutionalism, promulgated on February 11, 1889, and came into effect on November 29, 1890.

history.name: Himiko
history.desc: Himiko (ca. 175- ca. 248) is said to have been a queen of Wa (Japan) who lived during the later Yayoi period.

history.name: Kofun (tumulus)
history.desc: A kofun generally refers to old grave which has a tumulus.

history.name: Edo Period
history.desc: The Edo period (also known as the Tokugawa period) refers to a period in Japanese history where Japan was governed by the Edo shogunate government.

history.name: The imperial decree of the practice of assigning one era name to the reign of each Emperor.
history.url: history/The imperial decree of the practice of assigning one era name to the reign of each Emperor..html
history.desc: The imperial decree of the practice of assigning one era name to the reign of each Emperor is an imperial decree established on October 23, 1868 (the Gregorian calendar) at the same time of changing Keio year 4 to Meiji gannen (Year of 1868) and it is a system for assigning one era name for each Emperor's reign.

history.name: Charter Oath of Five Articles
history.desc: Charter Oath of Five Articles was basic policy of the Meiji government represented to Kugyo (court nobles) and lords by the Emperor Meiji (15 years old at that time) on April 6, 1868.

history.name: Nara Period
history.desc: The Nara period was a period in Japan's history which, broadly speaking, lasted 84 years from 710 when the Empress Genmei transferred the capital to Heijokyo to 794 when the Emperor Kanmu transferred the capital to Heiankyo.

history.name: Meiji Restoration (Meiji-ishin)
history.desc: The Meiji Restoration was the historic change from the feudal system of the Edo Shogunate to the system of direct Imperial rule by the Meiji government through the overthrow of the Shogunate, and the accompanying series of wars (the Boshin War) and reforms.

history.name: Yamato Kingdom
history.desc: The Yamato Kingdom is a term used to refer to the royal authority and government that developed around a monarch, known as an okimi, and several powerful clans during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

history.name: Yamato Province
history.desc: Yamato Province is one of the ryoseikoku (provinces) once established under the local administration system in Japan.

history.name: Yamato
history.desc: Yamato refers to the current region of Nara Prefecture in ancient times to the early Meiji period and is also another name of Japan.

history.name: Gokishichido (Five provinces and seven circuits)
history.desc: Gokishichido was a name for the broader-based local administrative districts under the ritsuryo system in ancient Japan.

history.name: Introduction of Firearms into Japan
history.desc: The term "Teppo Denrai" (introduction of firearms) generally refers to the introduction of matchlock guns from Europe into East Asia in the 15th century, and in a more limited sense it means the introduction of matchlock guns into Tanegashima Island, Japan.

history.name: Sino-Japanese War; Japanese-Sino War
history.desc: Japanese-Sino War (Kogo war in Chinese, First Sino-Japanese war in English) is a war fought between the Empire of Japan and the Quing Dynasty over Korean Dynasties from July 1894 through April 1895.

history.name: Russo-Japanese War
history.desc: The Russo-Japanese War (Русско-японская война in Russian, February 6, 1904 - September 5, 1905) was a war which broke out between the Great Empire of Japan and the Russian Empire (Although Montenegro, [Then known as the Principate of Montenegro] which was in an alliance with Russia declared war against Japan, it did not participate battle.) and was primarily fought on the Korean Peninsula and southern Manchuria (northeastern China).

history.name: The Railway Nationalization Act
history.desc: The Railway Nationalization Act (the 17th Law issued on March 31, 1906) is a Japanese law to nationalize private railways in order to unify the nation-wide networks of railways under the Tetsudoin (Railway Bureau) in the Cabinet.

history.name: Mokuroku
history.desc: Mokuroku are documents that are made for the purpose of either clarifying the place where something is kept or showing the name, content and the number of articles that are to be assigned or donated.

history.name: Daimyo-gyoretsu (feudal lord's costumed procession); daimyo's procession
history.url: history/Daimyo-gyoretsu (feudal lords costumed procession); daimyos procession.html
history.desc: Daimyo-gyoretsu refers to procession that was formed when daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) went out along with attendants for public purpose.

history.name: Sankin-kotai (daimyo's alternate-year residence in Edo)
history.desc: Sankin-kotai is one of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)'s system that obligated daimyo (Japanese feudal lords) to reside in Edo periodically.

history.name: Edo bakufu
history.desc: Edo bakufu was a samurai government established by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

history.name: Edo
history.desc: "Edo" (also described as Yedo, Yeddo, Yendo, Jedo) is the former name for Tokyo.

history.name: Monme (A Weight Unit in The Japanese Traditional System of Weights And Measures)
history.url: history/Monme (A Weight Unit in The Japanese Traditional System of Weights And Measures).html
history.desc: Monme is a weight unit in the Japanese traditional system of weights and measures.

history.name: Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures)
history.url: history/Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).html
history.desc: Haihan-chiken was an administrative reform implemented on August 29, 1871 through which the Meiji government abolished feudal domains and established prefectures that were under the control of the central government.

history.name: Kan (An Unit of Weight and Currency)
history.url: history/Kan (An Unit of Weight and Currency).html
history.desc: Kan is a weight unit in the traditional Japanese system of weights and measures, and it was also a Japanese currency unit for the silver coin used as the currency by weight before the Edo period.

history.name: Ichibu kin gold coin
history.desc: Ichibu kin gold coin was a kind of gold coin that was distributed in the Edo period.

history.name: Isshukin (a kind of gold coin circulated during the Edo period)
history.url: history/Isshukin (a kind of gold coin circulated during the Edo period).html
history.desc: Isshukin refers to a kind of gold coin circulated during the Edo period.

history.name: Nishukin
history.desc: Nishukin is a kind of gold coin distributed in the Edo period.

history.name: Nibukin
history.desc: Nibukin is a kind of gold coins that was distributed in the Edo period.

history.name: The Yamato Period
history.desc: The Yamato Period is a period in Japanese history.

history.name: Koban
history.desc: Koban is a kind of gold coin that was distributed in the Edo period.

history.name: Chogin (Silver coins)
history.desc: Chogin is the name of the silver coins which were in circulation, mainly for business transaction, from the late Muromachi period to the Meiji Restoration in Japan.

history.name: Mameitagin (an Edo-period type of coin)
history.desc: Mameitagin is a name for silver coins circulated in the Edo Period.

history.name: Ryo (A Former Japanese Weight Unit, And Also A Former Japanese And Chinese Currency Unit)
history.url: history/Ryo (A Former Japanese Weight Unit, And Also A Former Japanese And Chinese Currency Unit).html
history.desc: Ryo served as a weight unit in the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures, and also served as a currency unit in Japan and in China; in Japan, the unit of gold coins in the early modern ages, and in China, the unit of hyoryo ginka (silver coin used as currency by weight).

history.name: Nanryo Nishu Gin (Silver Coins)
history.desc: Nanryo Nishu Gin was a type of silver coin circulated in the Edo period and was high-quality Nishu (1/8 of 1 Ryo) gin issued in the early Edo period.

history.name: Sun (A Length Unit in The East Asian System of Weights And Measures)
history.url: history/Sun (A Length Unit in The East Asian System of Weights And Measures).html
history.desc: Sun is a length unit in the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures.

history.name: Sonno Joi
history.desc: Sonno Joi is a philosophy of respect for the Emperor and rejection of external pressures and foreign enemies.

history.name: Kanei-tsuho
history.desc: Kanei-tsuho refers to coins that were in wide use throughout the entire Edo period in Japan.

history.name: Imperialism
history.desc: Imperialism (sonnoron) is the idea of valuing the emperor above all else.

history.name: Theory of 'expelling the barbarians' (Joi Ron)
history.url: history/Theory of expelling the barbarians (Joi Ron).html
history.desc: The theory of 'expelling the barbarians' (Joi ron) was a view that prevailed in Japan during the end of the Edo period and aims to expel foreigners from Japan.

history.name: Shaku (a unit of length defined by the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Shaku (a unit of length defined by the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Shaku (尺) is one of the units in the traditional East Asian system of weights and measures.

history.name: Jo (丈; a unit of length by old Japanese system of weights and measures) or Take (丈; height of people and objects.)
history.url: history/Jo (丈; a unit of length by old Japanese system of weights and measures) or Take (丈; height of people.html
history.desc: Jo (丈)

history.name: Ken (間; the unit of length by old Japanese system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Ken (間; the unit of length by old Japanese system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: 間 (ken, ma, or aida)

history.name: Tenpo-tsuho (a coin that circulated in Japan during the end of Edo period and Meiji period)
history.url: history/Tenpo-tsuho (a coin that circulated in Japan during the end of Edo period and Meiji period).html
history.desc: Tenpo-tsuho (a coin first minted in Tenpo era [1830 to 1843]) was a coin that circulated in Japan during the end of the Edo period and Meiji period.

history.name: Bunkyu Eiho coin
history.desc: Bunkyu Eiho coin was a coin circulated at the end of the Edo period.

history.name: Shakkanho (traditional system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Shakkanho (traditional system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Shakkanho is one of unit systems for measuring length, area, and so on.

history.name: The Asuka Period
history.desc: The Asuka Period is a period in Japanese history, stretching from the end of the 6th century to the beginning of the 8th century, during which the capital was located in a place named Asuka.

history.name: Bakumatsu
history.desc: Bakumatsu, one of the Japanese periodization, refers to the final years of the Edo period when the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) ruling a county came to an end.

history.name: Rokuyo (6 days of the Buddhist calendar).
history.url: history/Rokuyo (6 days of the Buddhist calendar)..html
history.desc: Rokuyo refers to one of rekichu (various information recorded in the almanac) and has the six kinds such as sakigachi (The day on which bold actions are supposed to turn out well), tomobiki (The day currently believed to pull a friend by superstition), sakimake (The day on which it is supposed to be better to avoid disputes and hurried actions), butsumetsu (Buddha's death or unlucky day), taian (The most auspicious day in the six-day Buddhist calendar) and shakko (The day of great misfortune).

history.name: Treaty of Portsmouth
history.desc: Treaty of Portsmouth refers to a peace treaty of the Russo-Japanese War.

history.name: Seishi (Official Histories)
history.desc: The term "seishi" refers to the following:

history.name: The Battle of Kawanakajima
history.desc: The Battle of Kawanakajima indicates the battles over the control of the Northern Shinano area, fought between Shingen TAKEDA (Harunobu TAKEDA), the warring daimyo (lord) in Kai Province (present Yamanashi Prefecture) and Kenshin UESUGI (Kagetora NAGAO), the warring daimyo in Echigo Province (present Niagara Prefecture).

history.name: Taisho Democracy
history.desc: Taisho Democracy refers to the movements that emerged in Japan's Taisho period, urging for greater freedom and democracy in politics, society and culture.

history.name: Yomei-gaku
history.desc: Yomei-gaku is the Japanese term for the school of Confucianism established by Wang Yangming in Ming Dynasty China, which continued Mencius' doctrine that human nature is fundamentally good.

history.name: Taigyaku Jiken (High Treason Case)
history.desc: Taigyaku Jiken

history.name: Zato
history.desc: Zato

history.name: Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor)
history.url: history/Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor).html
history.desc: Taisei Hokan is a political incident in which the 15th Shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA reported to the Emperor Meiji that he would return the sovereignty to the Emperor on November 9, 1867 at the end of Edo period, and the Emperor gave the imperial sanction to the report on the next day.

history.name: Inyo Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Thought)
history.desc: Inyo (also pronounced Onmyo) Gogyo Shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Xing Thought) is the idea that linked together the principles of Yin-Yang (positive and negative, light and shade) and Gogyo Shiso (Five Elements Theory) during the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period in China.

history.name: Muhon (rebellion)
history.desc: The word "muhon" can be written either as "謀反" or "謀叛" in kanji, Chinese characters used in Japanese writing.

history.name: Suzaku (the Vermilion Bird)
history.desc: Suzaku (also known as Shujaku, or in Pinyin) is one of the legendary divine beasts (God Bird) of the People's Republic of China, and is one of the four gods (also known as the Four Beasts or the Four Phenomena) who rule over the four directions; it is also important in the Five Elements Theory.

history.name: Court (local administrative organ)
history.desc: A local court was established in 1868 as a local administrative organ by the new government in Kyoto for it to govern areas which did not belong to any feudal domains.

history.name: Hakodate Court
history.desc: The Hakodate Court was established quickly as a local administrative organ in Hakodate (present-day, Hakodate City) in 1868 to govern Ezo (a northern island of Japan inhabited by Ainu indigenous people).

history.name: Hiro (a unit of length defined by old Japanese system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Hiro (a unit of length defined by old Japanese system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Hiro (尋) is a unit of length defined by old Japanese system of weights and measures.

history.name: Yoshino Gen
history.desc: Yoshino Gen was a special local administration division or organization established in the Yoshino area in Japan in the eighth century.

history.name: Gojo
history.desc: In China, Gojo refers to five emotions.

history.name: The Development Commission
history.desc: The Development Commission was a local government established between July 8, 1869 and February 8, 1882 to reclaim lands of Ezo (present-day, Hokkaido, a northern island of Japan).

history.name: Sakhalin Development Commissioner
history.desc: Sakhalin Development Commissioner is an authority arranged for the Sakhalin reclamation from February 13, 1870 to August 7, 1871.

history.name: National Isolation
history.desc: National Isolation ("Sakoku" in Japanese) refers to the policy of seclusion by which the Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) prohibited Japanese citizens from going abroad, while imposing restrictions on diplomatic exchanges and trade with foreign countries.

history.name: Ryosei province
history.desc: Ryosei-koku designates Japanese province that was established under the ritsuryo codes.

history.name: Ezo republic
history.desc: The Ezo republic that was built in January 1869 was a familiar name of the Ezo Island Government, a political power belonging to Sabaku-ha which existed for a short time in Ezochi (inhabited area of Ainu) (Hokkaido).

history.name: Jinshin-koseki (family registries in Jinshin)
history.desc: Jinshin-koseki is the family register compiled in 1872 based on the Family Registration Law of 1871.

history.name: The Triple Intervention
history.desc: The Triple Intervention refers to the recommendation made by France, the German Empire and the Russian Empire to Japan on April 23, 1895 that Liaodong Peninsula which was given to the Japan Empire as wartime reparation based on the Treaty of Shimonoseki be returned to Qing, China.

history.name: Restoration of Imperial Rule (Japan)
history.desc: The Restoration of Imperial Rule was a coup planned by the anti-Shogunate group in January 3, 1868, which began with their declaration of 'Direct rule by the emperor.'

history.name: Tenryo (Shogunal Demesne)
history.desc: Tenryo is commonly known as a name for territories that were under the direct control of the Edo Shogunate.

history.name: Wajinchi (Japanese land, southern Hokkaido)
history.desc: Wajinchi is an area division in Hokkaido in the early-modern times.

history.name: Isse ichigen no sei (system of one era per Emperor)
history.url: history/Isse ichigen no sei (system of one era per Emperor).html
history.desc: Isse ichigen no sei (system of one era per Emperor) refers to the system where an era name will not be changed during the reign of a monarch (Emperor or king).

history.name: Omote-daka (face value of kokudaka assessed by the feudal government)
history.url: history/Omote-daka (face value of kokudaka assessed by the feudal government).html
history.desc: Omotedaka refers to kokudaka (yield) on face value of shoryo (territory) that was given by seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") to daimyo (feudal lords) or hatamoto (direct retainers) in the Edo period.

history.name: Uchi-daka (real value of the yield)
history.desc: Uchi-daka (real value of the yield) means kokudaka (crop yield) that was used as the appraisal standard to impose nengu (land tax) to the people of shoryo (territory) of daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and hatamoto (bannermen) in the Edo period.

history.name: Tondenhei
history.desc: Tondenhei refers to a soldier or a troop that undertook the guard and reclamation of Hokkaido in the Meiji period..

history.name: The Normanton Incident
history.desc: The Normanton Incident refers to an event that occurred when the Normanton, a cargo ship of British registry, ran aground and sank off the coast of Kii Province(Cape Shiono-misaki, Kushimoto Town, Higashimuro County, Wakayama Prefecture) on October 24, 1886.

history.name: Gakumon no Susume (Encouragement of Learning)
history.desc: Gakumon no Susume, or Encouragement of Learning, is a book written by Yukichi FUKUZAWA.

history.name: The Battle of Hakusukinoe
history.desc: The Battle of Hakusukinoe (also known as the Battle of Hakusonko) was a battle that took place between the allied forces comprised of Wakoku (later to be named Japan) and the surviving people of Kudara against Silla-Tang allied forces on August 663 in Hakusonko (the current outskirts of South Korea) on the Korean Peninsula.

history.name: Twelve Cap Rank System
history.desc: The twelve cap rank system (kani-junikai) was a court rank system established January 14, 604.

history.name: The Miyoshi Truimvirate (Miyoshi Sanninshu, three chief retainers of the Miyoshi clan)
history.url: history/The Miyoshi Truimvirate (Miyoshi Sanninshu, three chief retainers of the Miyoshi clan).html
history.desc: The Miyoshi Triumvirate consists of Nagayuki MIYOSHI, Masayasu MIYOSHI and Tomomichi IWANARI who stood out in the history of Japan's warring period for their activities in the Kinai region.

history.name: Treaty of Shimonoseki
history.desc: Treaty of Shimonoseki is a common name of the peace treaty signed at the peace conference after the Sino-Japanese War on April 17, 1895.

history.name: The Imperial Court
history.desc: The Imperial Court was a place where an emperor performs political affairs and tasks.

history.name: National Treasures (of Japan)
history.desc: The term "national treasures" ("kokuho" in Japanese) refers to those buildings, artworks or other items, among the larger group designated tangible cultural assets (important cultural properties) by Japan's Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties (according to the second item listed under article 27 of the law), that possess great cultural worth from the viewpoint of world culture, as well as those buildings, artworks or other items, considered peerless treasures by Japan's citizens, that are designated as such by the state (specifically, by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology).

history.name: Seinan War (rebellion of samurai descendants)
history.desc: The Seinan War was an armed uprising of warrior class led by Takamori SAIGO occurred in present Kumamoto, Miyazaki, Oita, and Kagoshima Prefectures in 1877.

history.name: Ritsuryo System
history.desc: The Ritsuryo system is the Japanese term for the system of centralized government seen mainly in ancient East Asia.

history.name: Fukoku kyohei (fortifying the country, strengthening the military)
history.url: history/Fukoku kyohei (fortifying the country, strengthening the military).html
history.desc: Fukoku kyohei refers to a policy that makes state economics grow and encourages reinforcement of military forces.

history.name: Ri (old Japanese unit of length, approximately 3.927 km)
history.url: history/Ri (old Japanese unit of length, approximately 3.927 km).html
history.desc: Ri is a unit of length in old Japanese system of weights and measures.

history.name: Civilization and Enlightenment of Japan
history.desc: The civilization and enlightenment occurred during the transitional phase of Japan in Meiji period, seeing drastic changes in various systems, organizations and cultural customs of Japan as the results of the Westernization.

history.name: Osaka no Eki
history.desc: Osaka no Eki (Siege of Osaka) refers collectively to Osaka Fuyu no Jin (Winter Siege of Osaka) and Osaka Natsu no Jin (Summer Siege of Osaka[ended on June 4 or May 8 in the old calendar]), battles in which the Edo bakufu destroyed the Toyotomi clan (1614 - 1615).

history.name: Return of lands and people to the Emperor
history.url: history/Return of lands and people to the Emperor.html
history.desc: The return of lands and people to the Emperor is one of the centralization enterprises undertaken by the Meiji government in Japan which was established on July 25, 1869.

history.name: Ritsuryo
history.desc: Luli ("律令" or "律例," pronounced as "Luli") is a common term for a legal code system seen among the Eastern Asian countries.

history.name: Shizai (Edo Period)
history.desc: Shizai is one of the 6 types of capital punishment imposed on commoner criminals in the Edo Period, in which the criminal was beheaded and the corpse was used to test the sharpness of swords.

history.name: Christian daimyo
history.desc: The Tensho Boy Mission to Europe (known as the Tensho Keno Shonen Shisetsu in Japanese) was sent to Rome together with Sumitada OMURA and Harunobu ARIMA.

history.name: Kyukei (castration penalty)
history.desc: Kyukei (Castration penalty) is a kind of penalty to castrate criminals.

history.name: Wa
history.desc: 倭 (Wa or Yamato) was the name used by Chinese dynasties to refer to the area centering the Japanese Archipelago and people living there since the days before Christ.

history.name: Heiminsha (Commoners' company)
history.desc: Heiminsha is a newspaper company established by newspaper reporters of "Yorozu-choho" newspaper company, Shusui KOTOKU and Toshihiko SAKAI (KOSEN), to promote and spread socialist thoughts, who retired from the Choho press company in order to insist their claim of pacifism, when the company, which had been claiming pacifism against the move to the Russo-Japanese War, shifted its policy from pacifism to the theory of making war.

history.name: Twenty-six Martyrs of Japan
history.desc: The twenty-six Martyrs of Japan is 26 Catholics executed in Nagasaki City on February 5, 1597 by order of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

history.name: Wakasa Domain
history.desc: The Wakasa Domain was a feudal domain owning areas around Hatto-gun, Inaba Province (Wakasa-cho, Yazu-gun, Tottori Prefecture).

history.name: Three New Local Laws
history.desc: Chiho San Shinpo (Three New Local Laws) refers to three laws on the Japanese local administration system that were enacted during the Meiji period.

history.name: Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho (the law for reorganization of counties, wards, towns and villages)
history.url: history/Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho (the law for reorganization of counties, wards, towns and villages).html
history.desc: Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho (the law for reorganization of counties, wards, towns and villages) was the law regarding a Japanese local government system, established in 1878.

history.name: Ginza (History)
history.desc: Ginza is a name used for mints in the medieval and modern ages of Japan, where coins were manufactured and silver bullion was bought and sold.

history.name: Period of Japanese rule (Taiwan)
history.desc: The period of Japanese rule of Taiwan refers to approximately fifty years during which time Taiwan was governed by Japan as colony from April 17, 1895 when the Qing dynasty ceded Taiwan to Imperial Japan due to the defeat of the Sino-Japanese War to October 25, 1945 when Taiwan was put under the rule of the Republic of China.

history.name: The rules of local assembly (Fuken-kai)
history.desc: Established in the Meiji era, the Fuken-kai rules, which set the rules of local assemblies, were the first rules in Japan which specified the establishment of Fuken-kai in prefectures in Japan.

history.name: Katatagae (The Practice of Changing a Direction to Avoid a Tabooed Direction)
history.url: history/Katatagae (The Practice of Changing a Direction to Avoid a Tabooed Direction).html
history.desc: Katatagae or Katachigae is one of the customs based on Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements) performed from the Heian period (794-1185).

history.name: Muhon (rebellious acts)
history.desc: In today's Japanese, muhon means a rebellion raised by a vassal against his lord.

history.name: The daiku-shoku system (a centralized district system that abolished all preexisting towns, village, their offices and institutions)
history.url: history/The daiku-shoku system (a centralized district system that abolished all preexisting towns, village,.html
history.desc: The daiku-shoku system is one of the local systems set up in 1872 during the Meiji Period.

history.name: Three Mountains of Yamato
history.desc: The Three Mountains of Yamato is the generic name for the three mountains that tower high over the southern area of the Nara Basin in Nara Prefecture (former Yamato Province) and around Asuka.

history.name: Genko (Mongol invasion)
history.desc: Genko is the Japanese name of two invasions (expeditions) that Japan suffered in the middle Kamakura period from the Mongol Empire (Yuan Dynasty), which was then dominant on the continent, and its subjected kingdom, the Kingdom of Goryeo.

history.name: The Battle of Anegawa
history.desc: The Battle of Anegawa refers to the battle which took place in the region around Anegawa kawara, Azai-gun, Omi Province (the present Nomura-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture (around former Nomura, Azai-machi, Higashiasai-gun)) on August 9, 1570 during the Warring States Period.

history.name: The Battle of Nagashino
history.desc: The Battle of Nagashino is a battle fought on June 29, 1575 between the Nobunaga ODA - Ieyasu TOKUGAWA allied forces of 38,000 soldiers and the Katsuyori TAKEDA forces of 15,000 men over Nagashino-jo Castle in Mikawa Province (current Nagashino, Shinshiro City, Aichi Prefecture).

history.name: The normal school order
history.desc: The normal school order was an imperial edict promulgated on April 10, 1886.

history.name: Johyobun (memorial to the Emperor)
history.desc: Johyobun indicates the act of presenting a written document to a monarch or the document itself.

history.name: Yogin
history.desc: Yogin is a foreign silver brought in to Japan at the end of the Edo Period through the beginning of the Meiji Period.

history.name: Japanization Education
history.desc: Japanization education is defined as an edification policy in territories under the governance of the Empire of Japan, requesting fealty toward the Empire of Japan led by its ruler, the Emperor.

history.name: Oie-sodo (family feuds)
