history.desc: Oie-sodo is a term denoting family squabble within feudal lord households in the Edo Period.

history.name: Kakitsu War
history.desc: Kakitsu War is referred to as a series of disturbances occurred in 1441, from when Mitsusuke AKAMATSU, a shugo (provincial constable) of the Harima Province, the Bizen Province, and the Mimasaka Province, assassinated Yoshinori ASHIKAGA, the 6th seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") to when he was defeated and killed by the punitive force of bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in his own territory, Harima.

history.name: Moat settlement
history.desc: A moat settlement is a village surrounded by a moat.

history.name: The Yamashiroya Incident
history.desc: The Yamashiroya Incident was an incident that Wasuke YAMASHIROYA, a government contractor for the Ministry of Army, committed suicide when he was unable to repay the public money he had borrowed from the Ministry without collateral in 1872.

history.name: Ganghwa Island incident
history.desc: The Ganghwa Island incident is an armed conflict between Japan and Korea which occurred in the vicinity of Ganghwa Island, Joseon Dynasty on September 20, 1875.

history.name: The Taiwan expedition
history.desc: The Taiwan expedition refers to the Meiji government's dispatch of military troops to Taiwan in 1874.

history.name: The Sakai Incident
history.desc: The Sakai Incident refers to the case in which a retainers of the Tosa Domain committed seppuku (suicide by disembowelment) to accept the responsibility for the killing of French sailors in Sakai City, Izumi Province in 1868.

history.name: Taiwan Sotoku-fu
history.desc: Taiwan Sotoku-fu (old form of a character: 臺灣總督府) is the name of the Japanese authorities then, which was established for ruling Taiwan, ceded from Qing to Empire of Japan and became Japanese territory.

history.name: Chosen Sotoku-fu (Governor-General of Korea)
history.desc: Chosen Sotoku-fu was a government office established by the Empire of Japan of the day in 1910 in order to govern Korea in the period of Japan's rule by the annexation of Korea.

history.name: The Eulsa Treaty
history.desc: The Eulsa Treaty (Dai-niji Nikkan Kyoyaku [Second Japan-Korean Treaty]) is an agreement concluded between the Empire of Japan and the Korean Empire on November 17, 1905, after the Russo-Japanese War ended.

history.name: Yujo (prostitute)
history.desc: Yujo or Asobime was a prostitute who did sexual service to men at yukaku (prostitute quarters) or a posting station, and the meaning of yujo is generally considered 'a woman who has her guest make merry.'

history.name: Kogaku (Classical Studies)
history.desc: Kogaku

history.name: Isshi Incident
history.desc: The Isshi Incident was a coup which occurred during Asuka period when Emperor Tenchi and FUJIWARA no Kamatari assassinated SOGA no Iruka inside the Imperial Court, which led to the fall of the Soga clan (head family of the Soga clan).

history.name: Nihon Gaishi (historical book on Japan)
history.desc: Nihon Gaishi is a historical book on Japan, written by Sanyo RAI in the Edo period.

history.name: The Sakuradamongai Incident
history.desc: The Sakuradamongai Incident refers to the event of March 24, 1860, when the roshi (masterless samurai) of the Mito Domain attacked the procession including the Tairo (Chief Minister), Naosuke II, and assassinated him outside the Sakuradamon Gate of Edo-jo Castle (Chiyoda Ward, Tokyo).

history.name: Shushigaku (Neo-Confucianism)
history.desc: Shushigaku (Neo-Confucianism) was the new learning system of Confucianism reconstructed by Hsi CHU in Southern Sung.

history.name: Bemin System (the system of Yamato sovereignty)
history.url: history/Bemin System (the system of Yamato sovereignty).html
history.desc: Bemin system is a system during the Yamato sovereignty, which refers to the system of subordination and service to the sovereignty and the system of the division of duties at the Imperial Court.

history.name: Inscriptions of Iron Swords and Iron Blades
history.url: history/Inscriptions of Iron Swords and Iron Blades.html
history.desc: Inscriptions of iron swords and iron blades are letters or sentences inscribed on the iron swords or iron blades.

history.name: Aisho (Compatibility)
history.desc: Aisho refers to the compatibility of qualities and characters between two or more people.

history.name: Okimi (great king) (Yamato sovereignty)
history.desc: Okimi is a historical term which generally refers to the chief of the Yamato sovereignty (Japan) from the latter half of the third century to the end of the seventh century which is from the Kofun (tumulus) period to the Asuka period.

history.name: The Japanese-Korean Treaty of Amity
history.desc: The Japanese-Korean Treaty of Amity refers to the treaty between Japan and the Joseon Dynasty concluded in 1876 and all agreements subsidiary to it.

history.name: Ryosei (systems based on ryo)
history.desc: Ryosei is the systems based on ryo that refer to the administrative law of the Ritsuryo codes.

history.name: Ryo-no-gige (commentary on the Ryo)
history.desc: "Ryo-no-gige" is a commentary on ryo (administrative code) by the decree of the Emperor Junna, selected by 12 people such as udaijin (minister of the right) KIYOHARA no Natsuno as a head, Monjo hakase (professor of literature) SUGAWARA no Kiyokimi and so on.

history.name: Kenzuishi (Japanese Envoy to Sui Dynasty China)
history.url: history/Kenzuishi (Japanese Envoy to Sui Dynasty China).html
history.desc: The term "Kenzuishi" refers to Japanese tributary envoys dispatched to the Sui rulers in China during the reign of Empress Suiko.

history.name: Shikigami
history.desc: Shikigami or Shikijin were fierce gods employed by the Onmyoji (Master of Yin yang) to judge the evil doings and well doings of the populace, and they were also called Shiki no Kami, and in some literature, Shiki or Shiki Kijin.

history.name: Family registration system in ancient Japan
history.url: history/Family registration system in ancient Japan.html
history.desc: Family registration systems in ancient times refer to family registers for keeping tabs on people under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) where were codes selected and compiled in the Asuka period.

history.name: The Anglo-Japanese Alliance
history.desc: The Anglo-Japanese Alliance was the military alliance concluded in the late Meiji Period between Japan and Great Britain.

history.name: Daiei Motion Pictures
history.desc: Daiei Motion Picture Company refers to a film company that operated from 1942 to 2002.

history.name: Toei Company
history.desc: Toei Company Limited is a Japanese film production and distribution company.

history.name: Ashio Mining Pollution
history.desc: Ashio Mining Pollution was a pollution incident which occurred at Ashio copper mine located around Watarase-gawa River in Tochigi Prefecture and Gunma Prefecture at the end of the 19th and the beginning of the 20th century.

history.name: Fuchu (provincial cities which consist of local governments as the core of the city)
history.url: history/Fuchu (provincial cities which consist of local governments as the core of the city).html
history.desc: Fuchu is another name for kokufu, an urban area established around its local government office (kokuga) in the ryoseikoku (province).

history.name: Kurofune (the Black Ships)
history.desc: Kurofune is a term used to refer to large, Western-style sea vessels, used before the Edo Period until the modern age.

history.name: Shotoku no chi (political reforms)
history.desc: Shotoku no chi are the political reforms carried out mainly in the Shotoku era.

history.name: Gold standard system
history.desc: Gold standard system is a monetary system that a fixed quantity of gold represents value of the currency in a country, and so the prices of goods also represent a certain value of gold.

history.name: Junshi (Self-immolation)
history.desc: Junshi is applied to the death of a close relative or a follower of a king, an emperor, a chief, or a priest, resulted from suicide to follow his or her master in death.

history.name: Meyasubako (complaints box)
history.desc: Meyasubako was a box which was set up to collect letters of proposal by the common people for the purpose of collecting opinions about administrative policies and information about the society, or the system thereof.

history.name: Bureaucratic system in Japan
history.desc: In this portion, an overview of the governance in pre-modern times will be given, especially under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) which was abolished.

history.name: Zipangu
history.desc: The term 'Zipangu' refers to an old name of an island which was said to be Japan in Europe.

history.name: Dappan (Leaving the Domain)
history.desc: "Dappan" was the act of a samurai leaving his master's domain to become a Ronin (masterless samurai).

history.name: Gisho (forged document and books)
history.desc: Gisho are documents or books in which the origins of either the author or the time at which it was allegedly written is apocryphal.

history.name: Unequal Treaty
history.desc: An unequal treaty is a category that is formed on the basis of the nature of the treaty, under which one state does not approve the enforcement of authority by another state over nationals of the former state.

history.name: Otsu Incident
history.desc: The Otsu Incident was a failed assassination attempt occurred on May 11, 1891, that the Crown Prince of the Russian Empire, Nicholas (later Tsar Nicholas II) was attacked in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture, by a patrol officer, Sanzo TSUDA, who guarded Nicholas during his visit to Japan.

history.name: Kidentai (historiographical format)
history.desc: Kiden-tai is a type of format of history books in East Asia.

history.name: Tan (a unit of area in old Japanese system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Tan (a unit of area in old Japanese system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Tan (反 or 段) is a unit of area belongs to old Japanese system of weights and measures.

history.name: Tsubo (a unit of area in old Japanese system of weights and measures originated in China)
history.url: history/Tsubo (a unit of area in old Japanese system of weights and measures originated in China).html
history.desc: Tsubo is a unit of area in old Japanese system of weights and measures.

history.name: Haniwa (a clay figure)
history.desc: The Haniwa are unglazed pottery characteristic of the Kofun period (tumulus period) in Japan.

history.name: Minakuchi Domain
history.desc: The Minakuchi Domain was a han (a basic unit of provincial government during the Edo period) that governed around Minakuchi-cho, Koga City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: Gundan (army corps) (in ancient Japan)
history.desc: Gundan refers to a military organization established around the country under the ritsuryo system (the system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in ancient Japan.

history.name: The Satchodohi (Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen Domains)
history.url: history/The Satchodohi (Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen Domains).html
history.desc: The Satchodohi was a generic name of 4 Domains, Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen, which were called 'Yuhan (powerful domain)' in the late Edo Period, implemented the Meiji Restoration and supplied people for major government service in the Meiji Government.

history.name: Shukuba (posting stations)
history.desc: Shukuba refers to urban areas that were established mainly during the Edo period along the Go-kaido Road (Edo Five Routes) and Wakiokan (secondary route that connected the Five Routes) to look after officers who transported luggage from one post station to another.

history.name: Hatago
history.desc: Hatago (inn) is a house where travelers lodge and meals are offered to the travelers in the Edo period.

history.name: Toiyaba (administrative offices)
history.desc: Toiyaba were administrative offices in post stations on roads during the Edo period, which mainly dealt with relays of riders and horses as well as sukego fuka (labor from the neighboring villages to help the primarily imposed village).

history.name: Koku (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures originated in China)
history.url: history/Koku (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures originated in China).html
history.desc: Koku is a physical unit of old Japanese system of weights and measures represents volume.

history.name: Yakusa no Kabane (the eight honorary titles)
history.url: history/Yakusa no Kabane (the eight honorary titles).html
history.desc: Yakusa no Kabane refers to the system of eight titles newly established by the Emperor Tenmu in 684; the eight titles were Mahito, Asomi/Ason, Sukune, Imiki, Michinoshi, Omi, Muraji, and Inagi.

history.name: Meiji roku-nen no Seihen (Coups of 1873)
history.desc: Meiji roku-nen no Seihen (Coups of 1873) is a major political change in the early Meiji era caused by Seikanron (debate on subjugation of Korea).

history.name: Iwakura Mission
history.desc: Iwakura Mission was a delegation which was dispatched to the United States of America and European countries from Japan between December 23, 1871 and September 13, 1873.

history.name: Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code)
history.desc: Taiho Ritsuryo refers to the Japanese Ritsuryo codes established in the beginning of the eighth century.

history.name: Naginata Jutsu (naginata technique)
history.desc: The naginata jutsu is a Japanese martial art using a long-handled sword called naginata which originated in Heian period.

history.name: Asomi
history.desc: Asomi (or Ason) (written as 朝臣) was the second rank of kabane (hereditary title) which was created in a system of Yakusa no Kabane (the eight honorary titles) established in 684.

history.name: Jiyu Minken Undo (Freedom and popular rights movement)
history.url: history/Jiyu Minken Undo (Freedom and popular rights movement).html
history.desc: The Jiyu Minken Undo (Freedom and popular rights movement) was a political and social movement that took place in Meiji-period Japan.

history.name: Heijo-kyo
history.desc: Heijo-kyo (also pronounced Heizei-kyo) used to be the ancient capital of Japan.

history.name: Kusarigama jutsu (art of Japanese chain and sickle)
history.url: history/Kusarigama jutsu (art of Japanese chain and sickle).html
history.desc: The term 'Kusarigama jutsu' refers to a martial art in which a fighter, holding a sickle on a chain in one hand and the chain with a iron weight in the other, and swinging the weight in a circular motion, could throw the iron weight to the opponent's body or use the chain to entangle the weapon to retrieve and then kill him with the sickle.

history.name: Kabane (hereditary title)
history.desc: Kabane refers to the titles given by Okimi (great king) (Yamato sovereignty) to powerful clans which showed ones' relationships to the sovereignty as well as ones' ranks in the Yamato sovereignty of ancient Japan.

history.name: Omi
history.desc: Shin (臣) refers to a retainer who served his lord.

history.name: Muraji
history.desc: Muraji refers to one of kabane (hereditary title to denote rank and political standing) used in the Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) and also denoted one of the highest ranked titles among retainers.

history.name: The Jinshin War
history.desc: The Jinshin War was the biggest domestic war in ancient Japan and broke out in 672 and Emperor Tenchi's younger brother, Prince Oama (later Emperor Tenmu) launched a revolt taking powerful local clans on his side against Prince Otomo (given the name Emperor Kobun later in 1870) who was a son of Emperor Tenchi.

history.name: Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate)
history.url: history/Ansei no Taigoku (suppression of extremists by the Shogunate).html
history.desc: Ansei no Taigoku was an act of suppression conducted by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) between 1858 and 1859.

history.name: Tenka-toitsu (unification of the whole country)
history.desc: Tenka-toitsu (or Tenga-toitsu) refers to the act of putting the whole country of Japan (except for most parts of Ryukyu and Ezo [inhabited area of Ainu]) under own control and unifying it, mainly during the period from the Seongoku Period (Period of Warring State) to the early Edo period.

history.name: Nuhi (slave)
history.desc: Nuhi refers to one of the positions of Senmin (unfree people) against Ryomin (free people) under the ritsuryo system (the system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), and was equivalent to a servile class.

history.name: Fujiwara-kyo
history.desc: Fujiwara-kyo was the first and largest capital in the history of Japan located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture, the northwest of Asuka-kyo.

history.name: Four Fujiwara Brothers
history.desc: Fujiwara shi kyodai/Fujiwara yon kyodai (Four Fujiwara Brothers) was the historical term that refers to the four sons of FUJIWARA no Fuhito who held the reins during the Tenpyo era (729-748) in the early Nara period.

history.name: Sukune
history.desc: Sukune was one of the kabane (hereditary titles) established by Yakusa no Kabane (the eight hereditary titles).

history.name: Mahito
history.desc: Shinjin (真人) is the ideal of human in the thought of Laozi and Zhuangzi and Taoism.

history.name: Kanto Gobunkoku
history.desc: Kanto Gobunkoku was the group of provinces ruled and administered by Shogun families (Kamakuradono) during the Kamakura period.

history.name: Wakoku (Japan)
history.desc: The term 'Wakoku' refers to a name which ancient Chinese dynasties or other countries around China used to designate a political force or its area in the Japanese Islands around that time.

history.name: Taishokkan (Holder of the grand crown)
history.desc: Taishokkan (Daishikikan) was the highest rank which was established in the Taika Reforms in 647 (enforced in 648) by revising the Kan I junikai (twelve grades of cap rank), and which was newly established in the Kan I jusankai (thirteen grades of cap rank) of the cap rank and official rank system.

history.name: Soga Clan
history.desc: Soga clan (Soga no uji) was a shizoku (clan) which ruled between the Kofun (tumulus) and Asuka periods (6th - 7th centuries).

history.name: Hongan (birthplace)
history.desc: Hongan (also called Ubusuna) refers to the registered address on the family register under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo code) in China, the Korean Peninsula, and Japan.

history.name: Rangaku (the study of Western sciences)
history.desc: Rangaku is a general term for European art and science, culture and skills imported into Japan through the Netherlands in the Edo period.

history.name: Tenpyo Culture
history.desc: Tenpyo Culture was an aristocratic and Buddhist culture that flourished in and around Heijo-kyo, the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara, from the end of the seventh century through the middle of the eighth century.

history.name: Rikken seiyukai
history.desc: Rikken seiyukai was one of the two major political parties along with Rikken Minsei-to political party between the end of Meiji period and the early part of Showa period in Japan (September 15, 1900 - July 16, 1940 [the orthodoxy faction, the unificationists] / July 30, 1940 [the reformists]).

history.name: Rikken Kaishin-To (Constitutional Progressive Party)
history.desc: Rikken Kaishin-to or Constitutional Progressive Party (effective from April 16, 1882 to March 1, 1896) was one of the major political parties of Japan in the time of Freedom and People's Rights Movement in the Meiji period.

history.name: Bansha no goku (Imprisonment of scholars of Western learning)
history.url: history/Bansha no goku (Imprisonment of scholars of Western learning).html
history.desc: Bansha no goku was the suppression of free speech that occurred in May 1839.

history.name: Saikashu (Saika group)
history.desc: Saikashu was a group (ikki) of combined local lords, powerful local clans and local samurai who resided in private estates in the center of Saikasho in the north west part of Kii Province (present day Saikazaki, Wakayama City) during the Sengoku period (Warring States period).

history.name: Hanreki-shosha (organization to distribute the calendar)
history.desc: Hanreki-shosha was an exclusive organization to distribute the calendar in the early Meiji period.

history.name: Gunbu Daijin Geneki Bukan sei (Military Ministers to be Officers on Active-duty Rule)
history.url: history/Gunbu Daijin Geneki Bukan sei (Military Ministers to be Officers on Active-duty Rule).html
history.desc: Gunbu Daijin Geneki Bukan sei (Military Ministers to be Officers on Active-duty Rule) is a regulation to limit the appointing authority of Military Ministers (Minister of War and the Navy) to only active military officers.

history.name: Imperial sovereignty
history.desc: Imperial sovereignty is the sovereignty held by the Emperor under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

history.name: Sekki (stone tools)
history.desc: Sekki refers to a general term for tools manufactured through processing stone materials.

history.name: Shokusan-kogyo (encouragement of new industries)
history.desc: Shokusan-kogyo is the policies in which the Meiji government accelerated modernization of the nation by encouraging industry and nurturing capitalism in order to compete with Western countries.

history.name: Oseifukko (Restoration of Royal Rule):
history.desc: "Oseifukko" refers to a country once ruled by a monarch before the monarchy was abolished by coups or civil wars, but then restored its monarchy for some reason.

history.name: Akazonae (red arms)
history.desc: Akazonae (red arms) is a kind of military organization in the Sengoku period (Japan), which is a troop formation of which all arms including armor and flag were colored red.

history.name: The Mononobe clan
history.desc: It is said that the Mononobe clan's ancestor is Nigihayahimikoto, who is believed to have descended to earth in Koho, Kawachi Province (presumably, present-day Katano City, Osaka Prefecture) before the time of the Imperial family.

history.name: Asuka Culture
history.desc: Asuka Culture was a Buddhist culture that flourished mainly in Yamato Province under Empress Suiko.

history.name: The Otomo Clan
history.desc: The Otomo clan was one of the dominant clans in ancient Japan.

history.name: Tateana-shiki (vertical, pit-type) dwelling
history.desc: Tateana-shiki dwelling is built by first digging a depression in a round or quadrilateral shape, then creating a framework in the depression by installing a number of columns, followed by connecting the framework with balks and beams, and lastly thatching its roof with dirt and reed or other plants.

history.name: Kiheitai Army
history.desc: Kiheitai Army

history.name: Toraijin (Settlers)
history.desc: Toraijin refers to people who came to Japan from abroad in a broad sense, but it also refers to people who became naturalized citizens of Japan from the Chinese continent via the Nansei Islands or the Korean Peninsula in ancient times in a limited sense.

history.name: Seikanron
history.desc: Seikanron is the insistence of the members of the "Rusu-seifu" on making Korea open to the world by military power (Rusu-seifu means the government while heads of government are away: the heads of Rusu-seifu were Takamori SAIGO, Taisuke ITAGAKI, Shinpei ETO, Shojiro GOTO, and Taneomi SOEJIMA).

history.name: Konden Einen Shizai no Ho (the law allowing permanent ownership of newly cultivated land)
history.url: history/Konden Einen Shizai no Ho (the law allowing permanent ownership of newly cultivated land).html
history.desc: "Konden Einen Shizai no Ho" was a law which was proclaimed as "choku or mikotonori" (an order under the name of Emperor) on June 27, 743, during the reign of Emperor Shomu in the middle of the Nara Period that allowed permanent ownership of "konden" (land that farmers newly cultivated).

history.name: Buke Shohatto (code of warrior households).
history.desc: Buke Shohatto refers to the code by which Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) governed the territorial lords during the Edo period.

history.name: Kin-za
history.desc: Kin-za was a place or an organization in charge of casting or appraising and approving of gold coins in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Zeniza
history.desc: Zeniza is an organization or agency which minted coins including Kanei Tsuho during the Edo period.

history.name: Rice riots in 1918
history.desc: The rice riots in 1918 were riots due to a sharp rise in rice prices in which lasted in prewar Japan from the Edo period.

history.name: Kaitai Shinsho (New Book of Anatomy)
history.desc: "Kaitai Shinsho" is a Japanese translation of "Ontleedkundige Tafelen" which was a Dutch book of medical science translated from Anatomische Tabellen written by a German doctor Kulmus.

history.name: Ontleedkundige Tafelen
history.jp: ターヘル・アナトミア
history.desc: The "Ontleedkundige Tafelen" was a book of anatomy on which a Japanese language version entitled "Kaitai Shinsho" (New Book of Anatomy) was based.

history.name: Goefu
history.desc: Goefu was the central military organization under the Ritsuryo System whose main missions were the personal protection of an emperor, the protection of Kyujo (place where an emperor lives), the night patrol in Kyoto and so on.

history.name: Hinin
history.desc: The term Hinin is used to describe mainly (1) persons who worked in special occupations or as entertainers in feudal Japan; however they gradually became victims of discrimination, and (2) in the Edo Period, Hinin as well as Eta (Chori) were described as people of the lower classes.

history.name: Kujigata-osadamegaki (the law of the Edo bakufu)
history.url: history/Kujigata-osadamegaki (the law of the Edo bakufu).html
history.desc: Kujigata-osadamegaki were the fundamental codes in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Goseibai-shikimoku (code of conduct for samurai)
history.desc: Goseibai-shikimoku is a law code established for samurai government in the Kamakura period.

history.name: The Shoshikai (a think tank)
history.desc: The Shoshikai is the name of a salon or a group of intelligent people (a think tank) established by people gathered, such as a wide range of scholars or artisans, including those of Western studies or Confucianism, and government officials during the late Edo period.

history.name: Fujiwara Shikike (the Ceremonial House of the Fujiwara clan)
history.url: history/Fujiwara Shikike (the Ceremonial House of the Fujiwara clan).html
history.desc: Fujiwara Shikike is a sub branch of Fujiwara family, started by FUJIWARA no Umakai, the third son of Udaijin (Minister of the Right) FUJIWARA no Fuhito.

history.name: Fujiwara Kyoke (the Capital House of the Fujiwara clan)
history.url: history/Fujiwara Kyoke (the Capital House of the Fujiwara clan).html
history.desc: Fujiwara Kyoke is a sub branch of Fujiwara family, started by FUJIWARA no Maro, the forth son of Udaijin (Minister of the Right) FUJIWARA no Fuhito.

history.name: Tsuko-tegata
history.desc: Tsuko-tegata was a certificate for people in the Edo period to prove that they were traveling with permission.

history.name: Daijoin Nikki Mokuroku
history.desc: Daijoin Nikki Mokuroku is the book recording the politics, social events, culture, and the history of religion written by Jinson, the 27th Daisojo (highest ranked priest among Japanese Buddhist monks) of Daijoin-Temple, which is the related temple of the nobility oriented/established Kofuku-ji Temple in Nara Prefecture.

history.name: Nishu gin
history.desc: Nishu gin silver is a kind of silver coin circulated in Japan in the end of Edo period.

history.name: Hakuho culture
history.desc: Hakuho culture is a magnanimous culture which flourished between the Taika Reforms in 645 and the relocation of Heijo-kyo capital in 710, falling between the Asuka culture represented by the architecture and Buddha statues of Horyu-ji Temple and the Tenpyo culture represented by Buddha statues of Todai-ji Temple and buildings of Toshodai-ji Temple.

history.name: Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara
history.desc: The Historic Monuments of Ancient Nara is the general term for temples and other historical monuments in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

history.name: Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region)
history.url: history/Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region).html
history.desc: Dazai-fu was a local administrative agency established in Chikuzen Province in the late seventh century

history.name: Sueki (unglazed ware)
history.desc: Sueki is earthenware which was produced during periods from Kofun to Heian in Japan.

history.name: Fujiwara Shike (Four families of the Fujiwara clan)
history.url: history/Fujiwara Shike (Four families of the Fujiwara clan).html
history.desc: Fujiwara Shike, also called four families of the Fujiwara clan, means the four family lines founded by four sons of FUJIWARA no Fuhito.

history.name: Peking Protocol
history.desc: The Peking Protocol is a final protocol signed in Beijing City on September 7, 1901, concerning the follow-ups of battles between the powerful countries (Great Powers) and Qing/Boxers in the Boxers Uprising.

history.name: Yuhitsu
history.desc: Yuhitsu is a civil officer who worked as a secretary of samurai family in the medieval and modern times.

history.name: Three Scholars of Dejima
history.desc: The three scholars of Dejima were the ones who came to Dejima in Nagasaki during the Edo period and conducted a study of natural history.

history.name: Heijo-kyu Palace
history.desc: Heijo-kyu Palace was Dai-dairi (the place of the Imperial Palace and government offices) of an ancient capital Heijo-kyo in Nara.

history.name: Shishi (Patriot)
history.desc: Shishi is a historical term describing a commoner in the late Edo Period who actively contributed to the country.

history.name: Imperial Rescript to Soldiers and Sailors
history.url: history/Imperial Rescript to Soldiers and Sailors.html
history.desc: The Imperial Rescript to Soldiers and Sailors was Shochoku (imperial edict) that Emperor Meiji issued to soldiers of the army and the navy on January 4.

history.name: Oyatoi-gaikokujin (foreigners in Japan hired to teach new techniques)
history.url: history/Oyatoi-gaikokujin (foreigners in Japan hired to teach new techniques).html
history.desc: The term "oyatoi-gaikokujin" refers to the practice, common from the late Edo period into the early Meiji period, of hiring Europeans and Americans to foster the importation into Japan of the advanced technologies, scholarship and systems of Europe and the United States under the banner of 'Shokusan-kogyo' (encouragement of production and industry).

history.name: O-oku
history.desc: O-oku was a residential place in Edo-jo castle where the Tokugawa Shogun family's children, lawful wife and oku jochu (maids working in the domestic quarters of a shogun or feudal lords) (also called goten jochu [palace maids]) resided.

history.name: Shogakko Rei (the order of primary school)
history.url: history/Shogakko Rei (the order of primary school).html
history.desc: Shogakko Rei (the order of primary school) was the imperial edict (order) to establish the elementary education system in modern Japan.

history.name: In no Kinshin (the retired Emperor's courtier)
history.url: history/In no Kinshin (the retired Emperors courtier).html
history.desc: In no Kinshin refers to the close associates or the group of close associates of Chiten no kimi (the retired emperor in power) who carried out Insei (rule by the retired emperor.)

history.name: Court noble law
history.desc: Court noble law is a legal system that was valid in the court noble society between the Heian period and the Edo period.

history.name: Sanze-isshin Law (a law allowing farmers who cleared new lands to own them for a period of three generations)
history.url: history/Sanze-isshin Law (a law allowing farmers who cleared new lands to own them for a period of three gen.html
history.desc: Sanze-isshin Law (sanze isshin no ho) is kyaku (amended laws of Ritsuryo codes) which was issued on May 29, 723 during the early Nara period, and the law which allowed a land cultivator to own his land privately for three generations (or only for his own generation) in order to encourage to cultivate rice fields.

history.name: Jori sei (system of land subdivision in ancient Japan)
history.url: history/Jori sei (system of land subdivision in ancient Japan).html
history.desc: Jori sei is a system of land subdivision (management) in Japan from ancient period until the late mediaeval period.

history.name: The Aikokukoto Party
history.desc: The Aikokukoto Party was the first political organization associated under the Jiyu Minken Undo (Movement for Liberty and People's Right).

history.name: Karafuto-Cho (Karafuto Agency)
history.desc: Karafuto Agency (Karafuto-Cho) was a regional administrative agency, which controlled Karafuto under Japanese possession.

history.name: Minpoten Ronso (Disputes over the Civil Code)
history.url: history/Minpoten Ronso (Disputes over the Civil Code).html
history.desc: Minpoten Ronso (disputes over the legal code provided for basic stipulation related to Civil Code) was the disputes whether to postpone or carry out the effectuation of the Old Civil Code (Act No.28, No.29 of 1890) in Japan from 1889 to 1892).

history.name: Chichibu Incident
history.desc: The Chichibu Incident was an armed uprising that peasants in Chichibu County, Saitama Prefecture made against the government from October 31 to November 9, 1884.

history.name: Gakusei (educational system, the Education System Order)
history.url: history/Gakusei (educational system, the Education System Order).html
history.desc: Gakusei

history.name: The Shimotsuki Incident
history.desc: The Simotsuki Incident was a political change in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) that occurred in Kamakura in the latter half of the Kamakura period on December 21, 1285.

history.name: Einin no Tokuseirei (a debt cancellation order)
history.url: history/Einin no Tokuseirei (a debt cancellation order).html
history.desc: Einin no Tokuseirei (a debt cancellation order of Einin era) is considered to be the first Tokuseirei in Japan which was issued in 1927 by Sadatoki HOJO, the ninth regent of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Omi no Miya
history.desc: Imperial Palace Omi Otsu no Miya (近江大津宮) refers to the Imperial palace where the Emperor Tenchi lived and carried out politics in the latter half of the seventh century.

history.name: Dotaku
history.desc: Dotaku are hanging bell-shaped bronze wares produced during the Yayoi period.

history.name: Land-tax reform.
history.desc: Land-tax reform refers to the tax system reform conducted by the Meiji Government in 1873.

history.name: Ie seido (family system)
history.desc: Ie seido was a family system, which was introduced to the Civil Codes established in 1898 (hereunder referred as Old Civil Codes), under the system, a small group consisting of relatives and living in a house is considered as a family and a family has a family head who was given an authority to lead a family.

history.name: Iden (fields given according to the court rank)
history.url: history/Iden (fields given according to the court rank).html
history.desc: Iden refers to the rice fields which were given to the ones higher than goi (Fifth Rank) in the rank and the imperial family, depending on the rank or honi (court rank) in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Kojiruien (Dictionary of Historical Terms)
history.desc: Kojiruien is a kind of encyclopedia compiled and edited in the Meiji period of Japan, providing many references published by the Meiji period that started in 1868, to each and every term in it.

history.name: Eikyo War
history.desc: The Eikyo War (Eikyo no ran) is a war which occurred in the Kanto region (regions surrounding Tokyo) in 1437.

history.name: Tonarigumi (neighborhood association)
history.desc: Tonarigumi

history.name: Hikone Domain
history.desc: Hikone Domain refers to a domain which possessed the northern part of Omi Province.

history.name: Yamato race
history.desc: The Yamato race is the race that has been living since ancient times in the Japanese Islands including Japan's mainland (Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu) and the other islands around them.

history.name: Law Prohibiting Cruelty to Animals (Ordinances of Animal Protection)
history.url: history/Law Prohibiting Cruelty to Animals (Ordinances of Animal Protection).html
history.desc: The Law Prohibiting Cruelty to Animals refers to a large number of proclamations and ordinances issued during the Genroku era in Edo Period.

history.name: Hennentai (a descriptive method of history)
history.desc: "Hennentai" is one of descriptive methods of history, whereby historical affairs are described in chronological order.

history.name: Kansei Igaku no Kin (the Kansei Prohibition of Heterodox Studies)
history.url: history/Kansei Igaku no Kin (the Kansei Prohibition of Heterodox Studies).html
history.desc: Kansei Igaku no Kin was an academic control performed during the Kansei Reforms in 1790, by a roju (senior councilor) of the Edo Shogunate, Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA.

history.name: Satcho
history.desc: Satcho is an abbreviation of the Satsuma Domain and the Choshu Domain.

history.name: Gaichi
history.desc: Gaichi means the territories of Japan (the Empire of Japan) other than the so-called inland in the period before the end of the World War II.

history.name: Gozoku (local ruling family)
history.desc: Gozoku refers to a family who existed within a broader-based political power of a nation, lords and so on, had many lands, properties and private soldiers in a region, and had a certain level of regional sovereignty.

history.name: Kurokuwa (a construction worker)
history.desc: Kurokuwa (黒鍬) (a construction worker) refers to people engaged in civil engineering in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and Edo period.

history.name: Oniwaban
history.desc: The Oniwaban was a position in the Edo bakufu (the Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) created by Yoshimume TOKUGAWA, the eighth Seiitaishogun (the Shogun in charge of conquering barbarian territories) in the Edo period.

history.name: Saigokusuji-gundai (a magistrate of Kyushu region)
history.desc: Saigokusuji-gundai was one of the gundai set in four places in the Edo period.

history.name: Bakuhan-taisei (the feudal system characteristic of the shogunate)
history.url: history/Bakuhan-taisei (the feudal system characteristic of the shogunate).html
history.desc: "Bakuhan-taisei" is a historical concept of social system of early modern Japan viewed basically from feudal homage between bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) (or seii-taishogun, literally "great general who subdues the barbarians) and han (domains) (or daimyo, meaning "feudal lords").

history.name: Banya
history.desc: Banya (a simple lodging house)

history.name: Enkyu Ezo War
history.desc: Enkyu Ezo War was the major warfare occurred in the Heian period.

history.name: Old Provincial Names (Kyukokumei)
history.desc: Old provincial names are the names of the ryoseikoku (province) that were used up to the early Meiji period.

history.name: Senji (imperial decree)
history.desc: Senji refers to the formal name of the documents to transmit orders of the emperor and Dajokan (Grand Council of State) in Japan in and after the period of ritsuryo system (the system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Roju Hosho
history.desc: Roju Hosho was the official document issued by roju (a senior councilor of the Tokugawa shogunate) in the Edo period.

history.name: Danjodai (Board of Censors)
history.desc: Danjodai is as follows.

history.name: Choshu Conquest
history.desc: The Choshu Conquest was the battle between the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and the Choshu clan, which was fought twice in the latter half of the Edo period.

history.name: Kubizuka (tomb of heads)
history.desc: Kubizuka (tomb of heads) is a tomb for the repose of those souls whose heads (kubi; literally means neck in Japanese) were severed because they were killed in battles and the likes, or captured, or punished by beheadings.

history.name: Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881)
history.url: history/Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881).html
history.desc: Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881) is a politically-motivated incident, which occurred during movement of the Freedom and People's Rights and dispute regarding creation of a constitution in government, especially between Hirobumi ITO, who recommended Bismarck's constitution, which preserves the royal prerogative and Shigenobu OKUMA, who recommended constitution from England, which has parliamentary system of government, as a result of the incident in which Shigenobu OKUMA was banned from government.

history.name: Sekisho (Barrier Station)
history.desc: Sekisho (barrier station) were facilities installed at the important points of traffic, in order to collect taxes and perform inspections.

history.name: Miyake
history.desc: Miyake is one of Yamato regime's ruling systems.

history.name: Tabe (a group of peasants set for cultivation of miyake, Imperial-controlled territory in ancient times)
history.url: history/Tabe (a group of peasants set for cultivation of miyake, Imperial-controlled territory in ancient ti.html
history.desc: Tabe was one of the systems that were established during the Kofun period (tumulus period) to control people and land, which also referred to people who cultivated miyake under the direct control of Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty).

history.name: Tadokoro (manor)
history.desc: Tadokoro was one of the systems that were established during the Kofun period (tumulus period) to control people and land, which also referred to the private property controlled by Gozoku (local ruling family).

history.name: Kogo Jihen
history.desc: Kogo Jihen was an incident in which vassals of the Hachisuka clan, who lived in Sumoto City, attacked the second residence of chief retainer Kunitane Inada and a place of study and other places near the Sumoto-jo Castle on Awaji-shima Island, Tokushima domain of that time in 1870.

history.name: Haitorei (decree banning the wearing of swords)
history.url: history/Haitorei (decree banning the wearing of swords).html
history.desc: Haitorei (decree banning the wearing of swords) was an abbreviated expression of the edict titled "Taireifuku narabini gunjin keisatsukanri to seifuku chakuyo no hoka taito kinshi" (decree banning the wearing of swords except for full-dress uniform wearers, military men and police officers) issued by the Grand Council of State on March 28.

history.name: The First Ito Cabinet
history.desc: The First Ito Cabinet was launched when Sangi (councilor), Hirobumi ITO was assigned as the first prime minister and lasted from December 22 to April 30.

history.name: Kuroda Cabinet
history.desc: In this section mentioned are achievemens of Kuroda Cabinet as well as the background of Sanjo Provisional Cabinet lead by Sanetomi SANJO, Minister of the Interior, that existed for two months after Kuroda's stepping down from his position as Prime Minister.

history.name: Shindenbunchi
history.desc: Shindenbunchi is a form of samurai branch family in the Edo period.

history.name: Nisso Boeki (Japan-Sung Trade)
history.desc: Nisso boeki was the trade done between Japan and the Sung Dynasty (Southern Sung Dynasty) in China.

history.name: Oban (the great guards)
history.desc: Oban (the great guards) was one of the organizations of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Isshinkai
history.desc: Isshinkai(イルチンフェ) was a biggest political association of the times which was active in the Korean Empire from 1904 to 1910.

history.name: Hibiya Incendiary Incident
history.desc: Hibiya Incendiary Incident was a revolt caused from the dissatisfaction with the compensation after the Russo-Japanese War, triggered by the rally held at Hibiya Park in Tokyo on September 5, 1905.

history.name: Jingisho (The Ministry of Divinities)
history.desc: Jingisho (the Ministry of Divinities) was a government organization which replaced the old jingikan (Department of Divinities) that had existed since the first days of the ritsuryo system, as the agency ruling the religious services and public administration of jingi (Divinities); it was established on September 22, 1871 and lasted until April 21, 1872.

history.name: Takokushu
history.desc: Takokushu is a territory of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period [period of Warring States]).

history.name: The Battle of Ichinotani
history.desc: The Battle of Ichinotani was a battle at Fukuwara-kyo in Settsu Province on March 27, 1184, during the end of the Heian period.

history.name: Baishin (indirect vassal)
history.desc: Baishin refers to a name indicating a vassal of vassal in the samurai's relationship between lord and vassal.

history.name: The Japan-Qing Treaty of Friendship
history.desc: The Japan-Qing Treaty of Friendship was a treaty concluded between Japan and Qing on September 13, 1871.

history.name: UESUGI The War of Zenshu
history.desc: The War of Zenshu UESUGI was the war that broke out in the Kanto region in 1416, the Muromachi period.

history.name: Naganuma affair
history.desc: Naganuma affair is a case of Naganuma disposal over concession of Naganuma which occurred in Naganuma village, Inba Prefecture (present-day Naganuma, Narita City, Chiba Prefecture).

history.name: Igashi no Hen (Incident of the Iga clan)
history.url: history/Igashi no Hen (Incident of the Iga clan).html
history.desc: Igashi no Hen is a political turmoil that happened in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), which lasted about a month from June 1224 in the early Kamakura period.

history.name: Bushido (the way of the samurai)
history.desc: Bushido refers to systemized thought that generally forms the basis of value and ethical standards in samurai hierarchy during feudal Japan.

history.name: Taihei Gyoran
history.desc: Taihei Gyoran is one of the encyclopedias from the early Northern Song Dynasty.

history.name: Kei-En era (Katsura-Saionji era)
history.desc: Kei-En era (or Kei-On era) was the 8-year period from 1905 to 1912 during which Taro KATSURA, who belonged to the faction led by Aritomo YAMAGATA of the Imperial Japanese Army, and Kinmochi SAIONJI, who assumed the position of president of Rikken seiyukai (a political party) as a successor of Hirobumi ITO, gained power alternately.

history.name: Rebellion of FUJIWARA no Hirotsugu
history.desc: The rebellion of FUJIWARA no Hirotsugu was a domestic conflict in the Nara period.

history.name: Owada no tomari (Owada port)
history.desc: Owada no tomari refers to the port which existed in Hyogo ward, Kobe city, Hyogo Prefecture and corresponds to a part of current Kobe port west side.

history.name: The Soga brothers' Revenge
history.desc: The Soga brothers' Revenge refers to an incident where two brothers, Sukenari SOGA and Tokimune SOGA, took vengeance on their father's enemy, Suketsune KUDO, on July 5, 1193 at the time of Fuji no Makigari (Hunting session at Mt. Fuji) conducted by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.

history.name: Japanese Americans
history.desc: Japanese Americans are U.S. citizens who have roots in Japan.

history.name: Go (a unit of cubic volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures originated in China)
history.url: history/Go (a unit of cubic volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures originated in China).html
history.desc: Go (a unit) is a unit of cubic volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures.

history.name: The Former Foreign Settlement
history.desc: The Former Foreign Settlement is the section of exterritoriality for foreigners built mainly based on the Ansei Five-Power Treaties.

history.name: Dajokan Fukoku and Dajokan Tasshi
history.jp: 太政官布告・太政官達
history.desc: Both the Dajokan Fukoku and the Dajokan Tasshi were a form of law promulgated by the Dajokan (Grand Council of State) during the early Meiji period.

history.name: Bogo no Mitchoku (a secret imperial decree)
history.url: history/Bogo no Mitchoku (a secret imperial decree).html
history.desc: Bogo no mitchoku is an incident that Emperor Komei gave a chokusho (imperial decree) to the Mito Domain on September 14, 1858.

history.name: Supreme command
history.desc: Supreme command is a power of supreme command and direction to the army.

history.name: Daimyo Shonin Seido (feudal lord pawn system)
history.url: history/Daimyo Shonin Seido (feudal lord pawn system).html
history.desc: Daimyo shonin seido was the system that the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) held hostages from feudal loads and their senior vassals and put them up in Edo.

history.name: Heizenmon Incident
history.desc: The Heizenmon Incident refers to the coup which took place in Kamakura in 1293 during the Kamakura period.

history.name: Hokokamai (a kind of punishment during the Edo period)
history.url: history/Hokokamai (a kind of punishment during the Edo period).html
history.desc: Hokokamai refers to a kind of punishment for samurai warriors during the Edo period, which was the circular letter that was issued to vassal deserters or forfeiters of rank by feudal lords.

history.name: Wado-kaichin
history.desc: Wado-kaichin (can be called Wado-kaiho) was the coin minted and issued in Japan in 708.

history.name: Fuhonsen coin
history.desc: Fuhonsen coin or Futosen coin are coins made in Japan around 683.

history.name: Tenmanya Incident
history.desc: The Tenmanya Incident was an incident in which members of Kaientai (an association of roshi (masterless samurai) organized by Ryoma SAKAMOTO) (Roshi association) and Rikuentai (an association of roshi organized by Shintaro NAKAOKA) assaulted a hatago (inn with meals) on Aburanokoji-dori Street, Kyoto called Tenmanya, attacking Yasushi MIURA, who was a feudal retainer of the Kishu Domain, and fought a battle against Shinsengumi (group that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

history.name: Revision of treaties
history.desc: Revision of treaties means diplomatic negotiations to revise the unequal treaties which were concluded between other foreign countries and Japan in Ansei era.

history.name: Ninja hachimon
history.desc: Ninja hachimon is considered the eight kinds of compulsory subjects which are essential to become a Ninjya in the all sects of Ninjutsu (ninja art).

history.name: Karo (chief retainer)
history.desc: Karo was the highest post available for the retainers of a samurai family, and more than one person occupied the post to consult with and assist the master with political and economical affairs.

history.name: Yanagawa Ikken
history.desc: The Yanagawa Ikken was an incident in which Yoshinari SO, the lord of the Tsushima Domain, and his chief retainer Shigeoki YANAGAWA confronted each other over forgery of the sovereign's message exchanged between Japan and Joseon Dynasty in the early Edo period.

history.name: Koizumi Domain
history.desc: Koizumi Domain was a domain which existed in Yamato Province (current Koizumi-cho, Yamatokoriyama City, Nara Prefecture).

history.name: Takatsuki Domain
history.desc: Takatsuki Domain is one of the domains which existed in Settsu Province.

history.name: Tonjutsu
history.desc: Tonjutsu is a technique of Ninjutsu to hide or escape from enemies.

history.name: Iga school
history.desc: Iga school is one of the most famous schools of Ninjutsu as well as Koga-ryu school.

history.name: Doshin (patrol officer)
history.desc: The term "doshin" refers to one of the low-level officials of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Kusarigama (a chain and a sickle)
history.desc: Kusarigama (a chain and a sickle) is a weapon that has a form like a kama (a sickle) for cutting grass attached to a chain weight and it was developed as a weapon from a farming tool.

history.name: Kunai
history.desc: Kunai is a small tool used by ninja.

history.name: Mansen Shukai/Bansen Shukai
history.desc: Mansen Shukai (also called Bansen Shukai; "万川集海" is officially written as "萬川集海" in Chinese characters) is the ninjutsu (ninja art) strategy book including 22 volumes with an additional one volume attached to it written by Samuji Yasutake FUJIBAYASHI, who was a descendant of goshi (country samurai) Nagatonokami FUJIBAYASHI, in Iga Province in 1676.

history.name: Kobe Incident
history.desc: Kobe Incident was an incident that occurred on February 4, 1868, in which in front of Sannomiya-jinja Shrine of Kobe (present-day Kobe City), a troop of the domain of Bizen (present-day Okayama Prefecture) injured French sailors who had crossed the array of the troop, and shot horizontally to the Minister-Counselors from Western countries who were inspecting the place which was supposed to be the settlement site (present-day Former Foreign Settlement).

history.name: Medals for Merit
history.desc: Medals for merit were conferred on persons according to the persons' distinguished services.

history.name: Kinshi kunsho (The Order of the Golden Kite)
history.url: history/Kinshi kunsho (The Order of the Golden Kite).html
history.desc: Kinshi kunsho (the Order of the Golden Kite) is one of Japan's decorative orders.

history.name: Makibishi
history.desc: Makibishi is a tool which is scattered on the ground to escape from pursuers when running away.

history.name: Shinobigatana
history.desc: Shinobigatana is a sword which is said to be used by ninja and is also called Ninjato.

history.name: Kaginawa
history.desc: Kaginawa is a tool that is believed to have been used by ninja.

history.name: Foreign Settlements
history.desc: The term "foreign settlement" ("gaikokujin kyoryuchi" in Japanese) refers to one of the demarcated areas of land created by the government that were specifically set aside as places in which foreigners could reside and trade.

history.name: Gozenkaigi (Conference in the presence of the emperor)
history.url: history/Gozenkaigi (Conference in the presence of the emperor).html
history.desc: Gozenkaigi was a conference convened since the Meiji period to establish important national policies in the presence of the emperor.

history.name: The opening of a country to the outside world
history.url: history/The opening of a country to the outside world.html
history.desc: The opening of a country to the outside world (as opposed to national isolation) means to interact and trade with foreign countries.

history.name: Chinzei Bugyo (a magistrate of Kyushu region)
history.url: history/Chinzei Bugyo (a magistrate of Kyushu region).html
history.desc: Chinzei Bugyo was an appointed position within the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) which commanded the gokenin (shogunal retainers) of Chinzei (Kyushu region).

history.name: Datsua Nyuo (Leave Asia, enter Europe)
history.desc: Datsua Nyuo (Leave Asia, enter Europe) is a Japanese slogan or thought that 'Japan should get out of Asia which belongs to the Third World, and catch up with European powers.'

history.name: Taisho Seihen (Political disturbances in the Taisho Period)
history.url: history/Taisho Seihen (Political disturbances in the Taisho Period).html
history.desc: Taisho Seihen' refers to the collapse of the third Katsura Cabinet in February 1913, which resulted from the Campaign for the Defense of the Constitution (the first) that started at the end of the year before.

history.name: Chitsuroku-shobun (Abolition Measure of Hereditary Stipend)
history.desc: Chitsuroku-shobun was a policy of complete abolition of hereditary stipend implemented by the Meiji government in 1876.

history.name: The scandal over the sale of the property owned by the Hokkaido Development Agency
history.jp: 開拓使官有物払下げ事件
history.url: history/The scandal over the sale of the property owned by the Hokkaido Development Agency.html
history.desc: The scandal over the sale of the property owned by the Hokkaido Development Agency was the incident that the decision to sell the property owned by the Agency made by Kiyotaka KURODA, the director of the Hokkaido Development Commission, was cancelled due to the heavy criticism from the public.

history.name: Women's suffrage
history.desc: Women's suffrage, also known as woman suffrage, refers to the right of women to participate in national and local politics directly or indirectly.

history.name: Imiki
history.desc: Imiki was one of the kabane (hereditary titles) established by Yakusa no Kabane (the eight hereditary titles) in 684, and it was placed as the fourth rank.

history.name: Tenguto no Ran(Rebellion of Tenguto)
history.desc: Tenguto no Ran (Rebellion of Tenguto) was raising of an army at Mt. Tsukuba on May 2, 1864 by the radical party of Sonno Joi (19th century slogan advocating reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners) including Koshiro FUJITA, a feudal retainer of Mito Domain and others, as well as the following related conflicts occurred all over the country (the main leader surrendered on January 14, 1865).

history.name: Yomogami
history.desc: Yomogami is one of ninjutsu (ninja art) used by ninja, disguising himself as multiple persons in order to save himself.

history.name: Kochi Komin sei (system of complete state ownership of land and citizens)
history.url: history/Kochi Komin sei (system of complete state ownership of land and citizens).html
history.desc: "Kochi Komin sei" is a system believed to have been instituted in the process of development of the Ritsuryo system from the Asuka Period to the Nara period, and under the system of Kochi Komin sei, it was provided for that all land and citizens should belong to the public, in other words, to the emperor.

history.name: Kaishin no Mikotonori (the Imperial Reform Edict)
history.url: history/Kaishin no Mikotonori (the Imperial Reform Edict).html
history.desc: "Kaishin no Mikotonori" is an edict which was announced to show the new administrative policy in the Taika no Kaishin (the Great Reformation of the Taika Era) which occurred in the mid-Asuka Period.

history.name: Teisuke turmoil
history.desc: Teisuke turmoil was an uprising which broke out in Niigata Prefecture and Kashiwazaki Prefecture (present-day Niigata Prefecture) in April 1872.

history.name: Sung currency
history.desc: Sung currency is copper coins which were minted in China during the Baisong period.

history.name: Decchi (apprentice)
history.desc: Decchi is a system of training future shopkeepers which was common from the Edo period to the end of the Second World War.

history.name: Kiseijinushisei (The parasitic landlord system)
history.desc: The parasitic landlord system was the system that allowed a parasitic landlord, who owned farmlands such as rice fields, vegetable fields, etc., to lend a farmland to a farmer called kosakunin (a tenant farmer) (also known as kosakuno or kosaku), to have him cultivate the land, and to take away some farm products, such as rice, barley, etc., as the land rent called kosakuryo (farm rent).

history.name: Shizoku no hanran (revolt by family or person with samurai ancestors)
history.url: history/Shizoku no hanran (revolt by family or person with samurai ancestors).html
history.desc: Shizoku no hanran was a series of the antigovernment movement against Meiji government, which was raised by people from former samurai hierarchy at the beginning of Meiji period.

history.name: Uda-Matsuyama Domain
history.desc: The Uda-Matsuyama Domain was a domain which existed in Yamato Province.

history.name: Koga-ryu school
history.desc: Koga-ryu (or Koka-ryu) is the most famous school of ninjutsu (ninja technique) along with Iga-ryu, but it is the name that refers to collectively the schools originating from the Koka region in Omi Province and the school named "Koga-ryu" did not exist.

history.name: Yagyu Domain
history.desc: Yagyu Domain was the ruler of Yagyu-go Village, Sonokami no kori County, Yamato Province (modern day Yagyu District, Nara City).

history.name: Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto (Law on the emperor and the court nobles)
history.url: history/Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto (Law on the emperor and the court nobles).html
history.desc: Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto (law on the emperor and the court nobles) was proclaimed by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to establish its relationships with the emperor and the court nobles.

history.name: Kokyu (empress's residence)
history.desc: Kokyu palace was where the empress of the king or emperor lived.

history.name: Gunga (county district offices)
history.desc: Gunga (county district offices) was a government office attended to the affairs of state by government officials (lower or middle ranked) of the counties (called Gunji) under the kodai Ritsuryosei (ancient East Asian system of centralized governance) in Japan.

history.name: Kanden (imperial estates)
history.desc: The usage of the term, Kanden, in Japan is different from that in China.

history.name: The System of Clans and Hereditary Titles
history.url: history/The System of Clans and Hereditary Titles.html
history.desc: Shisei Seido (the system of clans and hereditary titles) is a system made in ancient Japan in which the Imperial Court gave the nobles living in the capital and the powerful local clans a clan name and a hereditary title according to each person's degree of contribution to the state (Yamato Sovereignty) and the position the person occupies in the Government of the Imperial Court and let them kept the special privilege by the hereditary system.

history.name: Tomonomiyatsuko (the chief of various departments at the Imperial Court)
history.url: history/Tomonomiyatsuko (the chief of various departments at the Imperial Court).html
history.desc: Tomonomiyatsuko is the Gozoku (local powerful clans) who administered each group of tsukasa (offices) in the Yamato Dynasty under or sometimes together with the clans of muraji (one of ancient Japanese hereditary titles denoting rank and political standing).

history.name: Sankan-seibatsu (the conquest of three countries in old Korea)
history.url: history/Sankan-seibatsu (the conquest of three countries in old Korea).html
history.desc: Sankan-Seibatsu (the conquest of three countries in old Korea) was written in the war affairs of the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), on the military expeditions against Silla (pronounced "Shiragi" in Japanese: Kingdom of ancient Korea) by the Empress Jingu who was a descendant of Prince Amenohiboko of Silla.

history.name: The Conscription Ordinance
history.desc: The Conscription Ordinance (Edict of Dajokan [Grand Council of state] Non-number) (1889 Law No.1) was enacted in 1873, which stipulated the obligation of Japanese citizens to military service.

history.name: Kokuga (provincial government office compounds)
history.desc: Kokuga is a term for describing the section in which a government office, a Kokushi (provincial governor) executed the local government functions of the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan, used to be located.

history.name: Miuchibito (Private Vassals of the Tokuso Family)
history.url: history/Miuchibito (Private Vassals of the Tokuso Family).html
history.desc: The term "Miuchibito" or "Miuchinin" refers to warriors who served regent, the Hojo clan during the Kamakura period (1185-1333).

history.name: Giso
history.desc: Giso means reporting conclusions about state affairs to the throne after deliberation by Dijokan (Grand Council of State) under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Certificate of Ownership
history.desc: Certificate of ownership refers to the letter in which lords such as shogun, provincial military governor and feudal lord gave vassal samurais a guarantee for the ownership of a territory and enfeoffment from the Kamakura period onwards.

history.name: Botefuri
history.desc: Botefuri meant selling goods carried on a pole

history.name: Naikaku-kansei (Cabinet organization order)
history.desc: The term Naikaku-kansei refers in the broadest sense to the set of regulations for the Cabinet of Japan that govern its establishment, abolition, naming, organization, authority and so on, while more narrowly the term refers specifically to Imperial edict no. 135, a law passed in 1889.

history.name: Cho (a unit of length in old Japanese system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Cho (a unit of length in old Japanese system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Cho is a unit of length (distance) or area in old Japanese system of weights and measures.

history.name: Junigessho
history.desc: Junigessho (Twelve gessho) refers to the marker that indicates the position of the sun on the ecliptic, and its signs correspond to those of the Western astrology one to one.

history.name: The Taika Reforms
history.desc: The Taika Reforms are political reforms based on Kaishin no Mikotonori (the Imperial Reform Edict) issued in 646 in the Asuka period.

history.name: Karyo (non-penal fine)
history.desc: Karyo (non-penal fine) is the one of sanctions in the collection of money (fines) in Japan.

history.name: Decree of One Castle Per Province
history.url: history/Decree of One Castle Per Province.html
history.desc: The decree of one castle per province was established by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) on August 7, 1615.

history.name: Untei (the first public library in Japan)
history.url: history/Untei (the first public library in Japan).html
history.desc: Untei is a facility regarded as the first public library in Japan.

history.name: Akizuki-no-ran War (turmoil of Akizuki)
history.desc: The Akizuki-no-ran War is a revolt by the warrior class against the Meiji Government which took place in Akizuki, Fukuoka Prefecture (currently Akizuki, Asakura City, Fukuoka Prefecture) in 1876.

history.name: Shimpuren-no-ran War
history.desc: The Shimpuren-no-ran War is a revolt by the warrior class against the Meiji Government which took place in Kumamoto City in 1876.

history.name: Sanda Domain
history.desc: Sanda Domain was the ruler of Sanda, Arima County, Settsu Province and the area around it (modern days Sanda City, Hyogo Prefecture).

history.name: Hagi-no-ran War (turmoil of dissatisfied warriors at Hagi)
history.url: history/Hagi-no-ran War (turmoil of dissatisfied warriors at Hagi).html
history.desc: Hagi-no-ran War (turmoil of dissatisfied warriors at Hagi) was one of Shizoku no hanrans (rebellion by family or person with samurai ancestors) against Meiji government broke out in Hagi City, Yamaguchi Prefecture in 1876.

history.name: Gapsin Coup
history.desc: The Gapsin Coup is an event which happened in Korea in December, 1884.

history.name: Republican Speech Affair
history.desc: The Republican Speech Affair was an event that the speech, which Education Minister Yukio OZAKI of the first Okuma Cabinet (the Wai-han Cabinet) made on August 21, 1898, caused a trouble and triggered a collapse of the Cabinet.

history.name: Tashidaka no Sei (Tashidaka system, a wage system established by the Edo bakufu)
history.url: history/Tashidaka no Sei (Tashidaka system, a wage system established by the Edo bakufu).html
history.desc: Tashidaka no sei (Tashidaka system) refers to an act enforced by Yoshimune TOKUGAWA in July 1723.

history.name: Factory Acts
history.desc: The Factory Acts were a series of acts designed to protect factory workers, children and women in particular, who were forced into hard work during the Industrial Revolution.

history.name: Toshi (messenger from the Kamakura bakufu to the Imperial Court in Kyoto)
history.url: history/Toshi (messenger from the Kamakura bakufu to the Imperial Court in Kyoto).html
history.desc: Toshi, also known as Kanto-onshi, is a messenger dispatched from the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to Imperial Court in Kyoto, to Rokuhara Tandai (the bakufu deputy in Kyoto) or to Kanto-moshitsugi (liaison officer mediating between the bakufu and the Imperial Court), etc. and was employed for communication of the bakufu's opinions of issues of special political importance to Kyoto.

history.name: Chipped stone tool
history.desc: Chipped stone tool is a stone tool made with smashed stone without giving a polish.

history.name: Senior Statesmen's Conference
history.desc: Senior statesmen's conferences, which took over the official duties of genro (retired elder Japanese statesmen), were held during the Showa period in the form of responding to the Emperor's request for advice regarding the selection of a succeeding Prime Minister and the nation's important issues.

history.name: Silver standard
history.desc: The silver standard is a system in which silver forms the basis of a monetary system of a country.

history.name: Shoya (village headman)
history.desc: The Shoya (village headman) and the Nanushi (village headman) are one of village officers ("murakata-sanyaku" in Japanese; the three officers of a village), or one of the machiyakunin (municipal officials) in Edo period.

history.name: Imo Incident
history.desc: The Imo incident, (also known as the Jingo incident) was a massive soldiers' revolt that occurred under the incitement of Daewongun on July 23, 1882, in Seoul special city during the Joseon Dynasty (same as the later Seoul Special City), during which many people such as high-ranking government officials of Queen Min's, a Japanese military advisor, and Japanese diplomat were killed, and the Japanese legation was attacked.

history.name: Sho (a unit of volume in the East Asian system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Sho (a unit of volume in the East Asian system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Sho is a standard unit of volume (capacity) in the East Asian system of weights and measures.

history.name: To (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weight and measures)
history.url: history/To (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weight and measures).html
history.desc: To (斗; a unit of volume)

history.name: Japan-Mexico Treaty of Amity, Commerce, and Navigation
history.url: history/Japan-Mexico Treaty of Amity, Commerce, and Navigation.html
history.desc: Japan-Mexico Treaty of Amity, Commerce, and Navigation is a treaty concluded between Japan and Mexico on November 30, 1888.

history.name: The Chemulpo Treaty
history.desc: The Chemulpo Treaty is a treaty concluded between Japan and Yi Dynasty Korea on August 30, 1882.

history.name: Santo
history.desc: Santo (Three Cities)

history.name: Haji pottery
history.desc: Haji pottery is a type of earthenware that evolved from Yayoi-type pottery and was produced from the Kofun (tumulus) to Nara and Heian periods, until replaced by Kawarake earthenware in the medieval and early modern times.

history.name: The First Okuma Cabinet
history.desc: Among the Constitutional Party in power, the cabinet was organized with OKUMA from the former Progressive Party (Japan) as the Prime Minister and Taisuke ITAGAKI from the former Liberal Party (Japan) as Minister of Home Affairs.

history.name: Architectural History of Japan
history.desc: This section describes the history of architecture in Japan.

history.name: Genroku Ako Incident
history.desc: Genroku Ako Incident is a modern expression for "revenge for their lord," describing an incident which occurred in mid Edo period.

history.name: The First YAMAGATA Cabinet
history.desc: Since the Constitution of the Empire of Japan was enforced on November 29, the parliamentary system (Imperial Diet) was initiated in Japan during administration of this Cabinet.

history.name: The First MATSUKATA Cabinet
history.desc: As the prime minister subsequent to Aritomo YAMAGATA (the First YAMAGATA Cabinet), such as Hirobumi ITO, Tsugumichi SAIGO and Akiyoshi YAMADA were lined up, but the imperial command for organizing the Cabinet was given to Masayoshi MATSUKATA on May 2.

history.name: The Second ITO Cabinet
history.desc: ITO resigned the prime minister in August 31, and Kiyotaka KURODA, the Chairman of the Privy Council (Japan) also served temporarily as the prime minister until organization of the Cabinet by Masayoshi MATSUKATA on September 18 of the same year.

history.name: Ako Roshi (lordless samurai of Ako Domain)
history.url: history/Ako Roshi (lordless samurai of Ako Domain).html
history.desc: Ako Roshi refers to a group of 47 warriors under the former feudal retainer of Ako, Kuranosuke OISHI, who on January 30, 1703 broke into the residence of Yoshinaka KIRA, from a Koke (honorable family) who were enemies of the former lord Naganori ASANO, to murder him and get revenge.

history.name: The Second MATSUKATA Cabinet
history.desc: Summary

history.name: The Third Ito Cabinet
history.desc: Summary

history.name: The Second Yamagata Cabinet
history.desc: Summary

history.name: The Fourth Ito Cabinet
history.desc: Summary

history.name: The First Katsura Cabinet
history.desc: That was the first cabinet of Kei-En era (Katsura-Saionji era) that lasted for more than ten years.

history.name: The First Saionji's Cabinet
history.desc: Summary

history.name: HIKI Conspiracy of Yoshikazu
history.desc: The Conspiracy of Yoshikazu HIKI is a coup within the Kamakura bakufu that took place on October 15, 1203 in the early Kamakura period.

history.name: Rebellion of FUJIWARA no Nakamaro
history.desc: The Rebellion of FUJIWARA no Nakamaro is a domestic conflict which occurred in the Nara period.

history.name: Rebellion of TACHIBANA no Naramaro
history.desc: The Rebellion of TACHIBANA no Naramaro was a coup that occurred during the Nara period.

history.name: Ecchu Kubo (a government which existed in Ecchu)
history.url: history/Ecchu Kubo (a government which existed in Ecchu).html
history.desc: Ecchu Kubo was a government which was established at Hojozu, Imizu county, Ecchu Province by Yoshitane ASHIKAGA who was deposed as the shogun of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and escaped from Kyoto in 1493.

history.name: Tenchu-gumi Incident
history.desc: Tenchu-gumi Incident ("Tenchu-gumi no hen" in Japanese) was an incident that occurred at the end of the Edo period; it was carried out by a group of people called Tenchu-gumi (Heavenly Avenging Force) consisting of a bunch of ronin (masterless samurai) who were Sonno Joi ha (supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor and expelling the barbarians) including Torataro YOSHIMURA; this group rose to action in Yamato Province having a court noble Tadamitsu NAKAYAMA as the commander-in-chief on September 29, 1863 and was subsequently put down and destroyed by the army of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by the shogun).

history.name: The Ikuno Incident
history.desc: The Ikuno Incident was an incident that occurred when the Sonno Joi ha (supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor and expelling the barbarians) raised an army in Ikuno, Tajima Province (Ikuno City, Hyogo Prefecture) in the latter Edo period in October 1863.

history.name: Se (畝; a unit of land area) or Une (畝; ridges in a field)
history.url: history/Se (畝; a unit of land area) or Une (畝; ridges in a field).html
history.desc: Se or Une (畝)

history.name: Kokudaka (The Figure Of Land Productivity)
history.desc: Kokudaka refers to the figure of land productivity shown with koku (a unit), which was used in the early modern ages of Japan.

history.name: Kin (a unit of weight in the East Asia system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Kin (a unit of weight in the East Asia system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Kin (Catty) is a weight unit in the East Asian system of weights and measures.

history.name: Han
history.desc: Han refers to the territories ruled by lords.

history.name: Gobo no keiji (five edict boards)
history.desc: Gobo no keiji were five street bulletin boards erected on April 7, 1868 and the first public prohibitions published by the Meiji government.

history.name: Minbu-sho
history.desc: Minbu-sho (Ministry of Popular Affairs) was a government-regulated organization under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes).

history.name: Gyobu-sho
history.desc: Gyobu-sho (Ministry of Justice) was a government-regulated organization in Japan under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes).

history.name: Jibu-sho
history.desc: Jibu-sho (Ministry of Civil Administration) was a government-regulated organization in Japan under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes).

history.name: Shikibu-sho
history.desc: Shikibu-sho (Ministry of Ceremonial) was one of the eight central ministries under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Nakatsukasa-sho
history.desc: Nakatsukasa-sho (Ministry of Central Affairs, "中務省" in the Chinese characters) was a government-regulated organization under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes).

history.name: Hyobusho (Ministry of Military)
history.desc: Hyobusho (Tsuwamono no tsukasa or Ministry of Military) was an administrative organ taking in charge of military administration for the national defense in earlier times in Japan.

history.name: Togakushi-ryu/Togakure-ryu school
history.desc: Togakushi-ryu (also called Togakure-ryu) school is one of ninjutsu (ninja art) schools.

history.name: Kosatsu (street bulletin board in important streets and crossings)
history.url: history/Kosatsu (street bulletin board in important streets and crossings).html
history.desc: Kosatsu is the method of public notification by setting up a street bulletin board with written laws and ordinances (general law/the fundamental law) on a board, commonly utilized in Japan since ancient periods until early Meiji Period.

history.name: Yoro Ritsuryo Code
history.desc: Yoro Ritsuryo Code is the fundamental law enacted in 757 during the ancient period of Japan.

history.name: Yugisho (testimony by boiling water)
history.desc: Yugisho is a method that was mainly used in trials to judge which of the two claimants involved had a just claim.

history.name: Rienjo (a letter of divorce)
history.desc: Rienjo is a document for confirming a divorce that was issued by a husband to his wife (or his wife's father or brother) during the Edo period.

history.name: Omi-Ryo (Omi Administrative Code)
history.desc: Omi-Ryo is a legal system, believed to have been enacted in the Asuka Period (during the reign of the Emperor Tenchi) in Japan.

history.name: Omi-Miyagawa Domain
history.desc: The Omi-Miyagawa Domain existed in Miyagawa, Sakata County, Omi Province (present-day Miyashi-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Yamakami Domain
history.desc: The Yamakami Domain existed in Omi Province (present-day Yamakami-cho, Higashi-Omi City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Sawayama Domain
