history.desc: The Sawayama Domain was in Omi Province (now Furusawa-cho, Hikone City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Law for Transporting Five Articles through Edo
history.url: history/Law for Transporting Five Articles through Edo.html
history.desc: The Law for Transporting Five Articles through Edo was a law for trading control over raw silk thread, cereals, hair oil, wax and draperies issued by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in 1860.

history.name: Shaku (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Shaku (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Shaku (勺) is a unit of volume in the East Asian system of weights and measures.

history.name: Nishoji Domain
history.desc: The Nishoji Domain refers to a domain which existed in Nishoji, Gamo County, Omi Province (present-day Hino-cho, Gamo County, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Mikami Domain
history.desc: The Mikami Domain was in Mikami, Yasu-cho, Yasu City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: Omi-Takashima Domain
history.desc: The Omi-Takashima Domain refers to a domain which existed in Takashima County, Omi Province (present-day Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Otsu Domain
history.desc: The Otsu Domain refers to a domain which existed in Omi Province (present-day Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Omizo Domain
history.desc: The Omizo Domain refers to a domain which existed in Takashima County, Omi Province (present-day Katsuno, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Katada Domain
history.desc: The Katada Domain refers to a domain which existed in Shiga County and Takashima County, Omi Province (present-day Katata, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture).

history.name: Yanagimoto Domain
history.desc: Yanagimoto Domain covered Shikijo, Yamabe and Uda counties of Yamato Province.

history.name: Tawaramoto Domain
history.desc: Tawaramoto Domain existed in Tawaramoto, Toichi-gun, Yamato Province (present-day Tawaramoto, Tawaramoto-cho, Shiki-gun, Nara Prefecture).

history.name: Tatsuta Domain
history.desc: Tatsuta Domain was a feudal domain that was located in Yamato Province (present-day Tatsuta, Ikaruga-cho, Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture).

history.name: The Johei and Tengyo Wars
history.desc: The Johei and Tengyo Wars' is the generic name given to the two wars that occurred almost at the same time during the mid-Heian period in Kanto and the Seto Inland Sea: TAIRA no Masakado's War and FUJIWARA no Sumitomo's War.

history.name: Ikuno Bugyo (Ikuno Magistrate)
history.desc: Ikuno Bugyo was administered under Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI as well as the Tokugawa Shogunate, and it controlled the area of Ikuno Ginzan Silver Mine.

history.name: Tenpo
history.desc: Tenpo (aka Tenpu) refers to what the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by the seii taishogun [literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"]) changed daimyo's (Japanese feudal lord) territories to different locations.

history.name: Ryonoshuge (Commentaries on the Civil Statutes)
history.desc: Ryonoshuge is a commentary on the Yoro Ritsuryo Code written in the early ninth century (around 868).

history.name: Tsuka-gashira (pommel)
history.desc: "Tsuka-gashira" is the equipment attached to a sword.

history.name: Fudekozuka
history.desc: Fudekozuka is a mound or a memorial tower built by the students of terakoya (private elementary school) or kajuku (private school) which were educational institution for common people in the Edo period, to the memory of their late teacher who taught them reading, writing, arithmetic and other practical arts.

history.name: Sakai Prefecture
history.desc: Sakai Prefecture was a prefecture that existed during the initial years of the Meiji Restoration period.

history.name: Genroin (the Chamber of Elders)
history.desc: Genroin was a legislative organ in the early Meiji era in Japan.

history.name: Shikibunden (rice fields granted to government officials according to their position).
history.url: history/Shikibunden (rice fields granted to government officials according to their position)..html
history.desc: Shikibunden are rice fields that were granted to government officials under the ancient East Asian Ritsuryo system.

history.name: Asukakiyomihara-ryo Code
history.desc: Asukakyomihara-ryo Code is a systematic legal code that was enacted in the second half of the Asuka period in Japan.

history.name: Aomatsuba Incident
history.desc: The Aomatsuba Incident was Sabaku-ha (supporters of the Shogun) crackdown incident which happened in the Owari Domain from February 13 to 18 in 1868.

history.name: Okappiki
history.desc: Okappiki refer to unofficial collaborators who played a marginal role in police functions such as town magistrate's offices and Hitsuke tozoku aratame-kata (literally, "investigative division for arson and organized robbery") in the Edo period.

history.name: In no Cho
history.desc: In no cho was the direct political institution of Daijo Tenno (the Retired Emperor) who took the reins of Insei (a cloister government) or the institution that handled shomusata (trial dealing with land-related issues) and zatsumusata (trial dealing with civil affairs) of Nyoin (woman bestowed with the title "in") in Japanese ancient and medieval period.

history.name: Kizokuin (Japan's House of Peers)
history.desc: The Kizokuin was the upper house of the Imperial Diet from 1890 to 1947 under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

history.name: Kenkyukai (in the House of Peers)
history.desc: Kenkyukai (a study group) was a faction within the House of Peers under the Constitution of the Great Empire of Japan.

history.name: Kani Official Rank System of Ancient Japan
history.url: history/Kani Official Rank System of Ancient Japan.html
history.desc: Kani means Ikai (Court rank).

history.name: Kaiho Rei (Emancipation Edict)
history.desc: Kaiho Rei (Emancipation Edict) is the edict of Dajokan (The Grand Council of State) that mainly announced the abolition of the social status system like Eta (a status of group who were the lowest rank of Japan's Edo-period caste system and usually involved in handling human bodies or animal carcasses) and Hinin (a status of group who were the lowest rank of Japan's Edo-period caste system and often ex-convicts or vagrants) made by the Meiji Government on October 12, 1871.

history.name: Kaiho Rei (Emancipation Edict) opposition uprisings
history.desc: Kaiho Rei (Emancipation Edict) opposition uprisings were incidents of riots and raids which broke out against Kaiho Rei in various places of Japan during early Meiji period.

history.name: Hyakumanto Darani (The one million pagodas and Dharani prayers)
history.url: history/Hyakumanto Darani (The one million pagodas and Dharani prayers).html
history.desc: Hyakumanto Darani is the collection of Dharanis that was dedicated to Buddhist temples by way of being placed in one million mini pagodas during the Nara period for the protection of the nation as well as for repentance.

history.name: Koden, rice fields granted by the state
history.url: history/Koden, rice fields granted by the state.html
history.desc: Koden is rice fields granted to those who did meritorious deeds for the state under the Japanese Ritsuryo system.

history.name: Shiden
history.desc: Shiden is the farmland given by emperors through issuing Shochoku (an imperial edict) to individuals under the rules set in the Ritsuryo Code of Japan.

history.name: Russo-Japanese Agreement
history.desc: The Russo-Japanese Agreement is the agreement in which Japan and the Russian Empire agreed upon mutual interests ranging over 4 times after the Russo-Japanese War.

history.name: Kogisho (Lower House)
history.desc: The Kogisho (Lower House) was the legislative body that was established in the beginning of Meiji era.

history.name: Ishin no Sanketsu (The Three contributors of the Meiji Restoration)
history.url: history/Ishin no Sanketsu (The Three contributors of the Meiji Restoration).html
history.desc: Ishin no Sanketsu are Takayoshi KIDO, Takamori SAIGO, and Toshimichi OKUBO who made efforts to overthrow the Shogunate and contributed to the Meiji Restoration.

history.name: Kujira Domain
history.desc: Kujira Domain was a feudal domain that was located in Yamato Province (present-day Kujira, Gose City, Nara Prefecture)

history.name: Okidome Domain
history.desc: Okidome Domain was a feudal domain located in Yamato Province (present-day Okidome, Ikaruga-cho, Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture)

history.name: Yamato Gojo Domain
history.desc: Yamato Gojo Domain was a feudal domain that was located in Yamato Province (present-day Futami, Gojo City, Nara Prefecture).

history.name: Gose Domain
history.desc: Gose Domain was a feudal domain that covered Katsujo-gun and Katsuge-gun in Yamato Province and part of Hine-gun, Izumi Province.

history.name: Takatori Domain
history.desc: Takatori Domain was a feudal domain what was located in Yamato Province (present-day Takatori-cho, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture).

history.name: Shibamura Domain
history.desc: Shibamura Domain was a feudal domain which was located in Shiba Village, Shikijo County, Yamato Province (present-day Shiba, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).

history.name: A Plot of Usa Hachiman-gu Oracle
history.url: history/A Plot of Usa Hachiman-gu Oracle.html
history.desc: A plot of Usa Hachiman-gu Oracle is an incident in which Dokyo is assumed to try to ascend the throne based on an oracle that says 'Dokyo should ascend the throne'; this oracle was given to Empress Shotoku (Empress Koken) from Usa Hachiman-gu Shrine (present-day Usa City, Oita Prefecture) in 769.

history.name: Tanko (armor)
history.desc: Tanko is one of the formal names of Ko (armor) used between Yayoi Period and Tumulus Period.

history.name: The Ieyasu TOKUGAWA Imposter Theory
history.desc: Although it is commonly believed that Ieyasu TOKUGAWA founded the Edo shogunate, there is another theory that suggests an imposter took the place of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA at some stage of his life.

history.name: Omi Komuro Domain
history.desc: The Omi Komuro Domain was a domain which existed in Komuro, Azai County, Omi Province (Present: Komuro-cho, Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture [Previous: Azai-cho, Higashiazai County]).

history.name: Sai (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures)
history.url: history/Sai (a unit of volume in old Japanese system of weights and measures).html
history.desc: Sai is a unit of volume (capacity) in old Japanese system of weights and measures.

history.name: Rebel army
history.desc: Rebel army is a term opposed to a term "Imperial Army" which was made to deny legitimacy of some armies which appeared in the history of Japan.

history.name: Jinruikan Incident (Humankind Pavilion Incident)
history.desc: Jinruikan Incident, also known as 'Gakujutsu-Jinruikan Incident' or Osaka Exhibition Incident,' occurred at 'Gakujutsu-Jinruikan' in the fifth National Industrial Exhibition held in 1903 at Tennoji, Osaka, at the exhibition, living people dressed in their ethnic costumes and their ethnic houses were exhibited, those people were from Okinawa, Korea, India, Malaysia, Java and Africa as well as the Ainu tribe and the Takasago tribe of Taiwan.

history.name: Goken Undo (Constitution protection movement)
history.desc: Goken Undo refers to movement initiated during the Taisho Period by Kokumin (the people) and political parties to protect constitutional government.

history.name: Ishiyama War
history.desc: The Ishiyama War took place from October 21, 1570 to September 20, 1580 between the Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land sect of Buddhism) Hongan-ji Temple force (or Ikko Ikki [Ikko sect's revolt]) and Nobunaga ODA.

history.name: Japan-Korea Annexation Treaty of 1907
history.desc: The Japan-Korea Annexation Treaty was a treaty concluded on July 24, 1907.

history.name: Tetsugakukan incident
history.desc: Tetsugakugan incident occurred at Toyo University (current Toyo University) in 1902.

history.name: Revolt of TAIRA no Tadatsune
history.desc: The revolt of TAIRA no Tadatsune occurred in the Boso peninsula (Kazusa, Shimousa, Awa Provinces) in the Heian period.

history.name: Kyobusho (Ministry of Religion)
history.desc: Kyobusho (Ministry of Religion) is the central governmental organ founded for the purpose of national edification by controlling religion under Dajokan System (the system of Great Council of State) established in the early Meiji period.

history.name: Chosonsei (town and village system)
history.desc: Chosonsei, as well as Shisei (a municipal system), is the fundamental law governing local autonomy under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

history.name: Gunsei (a domestic law concerning Gun ［County］)
history.desc: Gunsei was a domestic law of Japan during the period of Meiji and Taisho era, which stipulated Gun, a district occupying an intermediate position between a prefecture and a municipality, as a local government.

history.name: Fukensei (prefectural system/law)
history.desc: Fukensei (prefectural system/law) refers to a local administration system established in 1890 as well as the law that stipulates this system.

history.name: Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks)
history.desc: Shitokan, also known as Shitokan-sei system, is a term that refers to the fact that core officials of government offices were comprised of people of four ranks under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government under the Ritsuryo code).

history.name: Fu-han-ken sanchisei (fu-han-ken tripartite governance system)
history.desc: Fu-han-sanchisei is a local administration system established in the first year of the Meiji Era.

history.name: Totsukawa Goshi (Samurai from Totsukawa area in Nara)
history.url: history/Totsukawa Goshi (Samurai from Totsukawa area in Nara).html
history.desc: Totsukawa Goshi is a group of samurai who lived in Totsukawa-go, Minami Yamato (Nara Prefecture).

history.name: Kawachi Juningiri (Ten killings in Kawachi area)
history.url: history/Kawachi Juningiri (Ten killings in Kawachi area).html
history.desc: "Kawachi juningiri" was a murder case occurred in Akasakasuibun Village at the foot of Mt. Kongo in the southwest of Osaka Prefecture.

history.name: Monopolization
history.desc: Monopolization is a system that a government places under its complete control the production, distribution, and sales of specific goods and monopolizes the profits gained from them in order to increase the national income.

history.name: Kanei Mohan Kojou (Government-run model factories)
history.desc: Government-run model factories were set up by the Meiji Government for the promotion of new industries.

history.name: Kinkei no ma shiko
history.desc: Kinkei no ma shiko is one of the licenses of the Imperial Court defined under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

history.name: Genroin gikan (Councilor of the Chamber of Elders)
history.url: history/Genroin gikan (Councilor of the Chamber of Elders).html
history.desc: Genroin gikan were those who organized the Chamber of Elders (Japan).

history.name: Jako no ma shiko
history.desc: Jako no ma shiko was one of the licenses of the Imperial Court defined by the Constitution of the Empire of Japan, in order to treat the peerages and government officials for their contributions, and the person who rendered a distinguished service for the Meiji Restoration.

history.name: Shiryokaku fort
history.desc: Shiryokaku fort is a fort built by the Ezo Republic (the Hakodate Government) at the time of the Hakodate War, in 1869, in the present-day Hakodate City, Hokkaido.

history.name: Suji (administrative district)
history.desc: Suji is an administrative district that was created in the Edo Period, according to geographical conditions.

history.name: Sankakubuchi Shinjukyo Mirror
history.desc: Sankakubuchi Shinjukyo Mirror/Sankakuen Shinjukyo Mirror is a kind of bronze mirror and large mirror engraving divine beasts with a triangular-rim in its cross-section.

history.name: MOMOCHI Tanba
history.desc: In the attack on Iga in 1579, Tanba managed to repulse the Oda's army partly because the command of Nobuo, who was an imbecile Busho (Japanese military commander), was poor.

history.name: Itowappu
history.desc: Itowappu is a system of importing raw silk threads in Japan during the Edo period.

history.name: Makishi Incident
history.desc: The Makishi Incident refers to a coup that took place in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in August, 1205 in the early Kamakura period.

history.name: Nigatsu-sodo (February Rebellion)
history.desc: The Nigatsu-sodo refers to the incident that took place in March, 1272 (February, 1272 in old lunar calendar) in the Kamakura period.

history.name: Kiyosu Alliance (a military alliance formed between Nobunaga ODA and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA)
history.url: history/Kiyosu Alliance (a military alliance formed between Nobunaga ODA and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA).html
history.desc: Kiyosu Alliance was a military alliance formed between Nobunaga ODA, a Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period [Period of Warring States]) of Owari Province, and Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, a sengoku daimyo of Mikawa Province.

history.name: Chonin (Townspeople)
history.desc: Chonin (or machinin) is a term referring to craftsmen and merchants who lived in the urban area during the Edo period.

history.name: Toyo Takushoku
history.desc: Toyo Takushoku Kabushiki Gaisha was a special company established for the purpose of carrying forward colonial enterprises in Korea during the era of the Great Empire of Japan.

history.name: Kozai Kikai Zushiki (Scheme of devices for judicial hanging)
history.url: history/Kozai Kikai Zushiki (Scheme of devices for judicial hanging).html
history.desc: Kozai Kikai Zushiki, the edict of Dajokan (Grand Council of State) No.65 of 1873, is an act which stipulates the scheme of devices to be used for judicial hanging in Japan.

history.name: Kindai shakaku seido (modern shrine ranking system)
history.url: history/Kindai shakaku seido (modern shrine ranking system).html
history.desc: Kindai shakaku seido is a shrine ranking system that was newly established after the Meiji Restoration, being modeled after the system stipulated in the Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Transcendentalism
history.desc: Transcendentalism refers to a philosophy in which individuals stand firm in their position detachedly (nonchalantly) without being influenced by the state of things that surround them.

history.name: Horeki Incident
history.desc: The Horeki Incident is the first incident in which imperialists were oppressed in the middle of the Edo period.

history.name: Naniwa-kyo Capital (a capital established in Osaka City of ancient Japan)
history.url: history/Naniwa-kyo Capital (a capital established in Osaka City of ancient Japan).html
history.desc: Naniwa-kyo Capital was a capital established in Osaka City of ancient Japan.

history.name: Gobosei (Pentagram)
history.desc: Gobosei (Pentagram) is a figure consisting of five lines of equal length that are mutually intersected, and is one kind of star-shaped regular polygon.

history.name: Chihanji (governor in the early Meiji period)
history.url: history/Chihanji (governor in the early Meiji period).html
history.desc: Chihanji was a name for a local government official position in the early Meiji period.

history.name: Statement Requesting the Equal Merger of Korea and Japan
history.jp: 韓日合邦を要求する声明書
history.url: history/Statement Requesting the Equal Merger of Korea and Japan.html
history.desc: The statement of Requesting the Equal Merger of Korea and Japan is a statement to request an equal merger between Korea and Japan sent to Emperor Sunjong (of the Korean Empire), the Resident-General of Korea Arasuke SONE and Prime Minister Lee Wan-Yong on December 4, 1909 by a group of Chinilpa (literally "people friendly to Japan") called Iljinhoe which was under the influence of Japan in the Korean Empire (officially reported membership was a few million but actual membership was a few ten thousands).

history.name: Ikkunbanmin-ron
history.desc: Ikkunbanmin-ron is a theory in which constitutional authority is given to only one ruler, and under this sovereignty any discrimination and distinction from social status shold not be allowed among all other people.

history.name: Hanbatsu (domain clique)
history.desc: Hanbatsu (domain clique) is a critical designation for the group of people from the former domains in southwest Japan (the domains of Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen; they were so-called, Sacchodohi), who occupied important posts in the Japanese government from the Meiji to the Taisho period.

history.name: HIKAMI no Kawatsugu's War (a political event in Nara period)
history.url: history/HIKAMI no Kawatsugus War (a political event in Nara period).html
history.desc: HIKAMI no Kawatsugu's War was a political event in the Nara period.

history.name: Sukuigoya
history.desc: Sukuigoya is a public shelter of the Edo Period, built by the Edo shogunate or local feudal domain for victims of earthquakes, fire, floods, famine and other natural disasters.

history.name: Ata (a unit of length used in ancient China and Japan)
history.url: history/Ata (a unit of length used in ancient China and Japan).html
history.desc: Ata is a length unit used both in China and Japan.

history.name: Jobosei (a city plan where streets were laidout in a grid pattern)
history.url: history/Jobosei (a city plan where streets were laidout in a grid pattern).html
history.desc: Jobosei was the city plan seen in cities that contained the Emperor's palace in countries such as China, the Korean Peninsula, and Japan; furthermore, the Suzaku-oji Street was placed in the center of the city running from east to west.

history.name: Kujo-ryu school (the descendants of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan and a school of Yusoku kojitsu)
history.url: history/Kujo-ryu school (the descendants of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan and a school of Yusoku k.html
history.desc: The Kujo-ryu school refers to the descendants of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan, especially, FUJIWARA no Morosuke and to the school of Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette) handed down the FUJIWARA no Morosuke family.

history.name: Annexation of Korea
history.desc: The annexation of Korea refers to the Japanese annexation of the Korean Empire (which currently corresponds to the area of the Republic of Korea and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea), based on the Japan-Korea Annexation Treaty on August 22, 1910.

history.name: Hansatsu (a Han Bill)
history.desc: A han bill was paper currency issued by each domain for use within their respective territories.

history.name: The Ruins of Shigaraki no Miya Palace
history.url: history/The Ruins of Shigaraki no Miya Palace.html
history.desc: The ruins of Shigaraki no Miya Palace is a national historical site located in Kinose and Maki, Shigaraki-cho, Koka City, Shiga Prefecture.

history.name: Kyodo Unyu Kaisha
history.desc: Kyodo Unyu Kaisha (literary, a joint transportation company) was established in July 1882, with the merger of three transportation companies, Tokyo Fuhansen Kaisha, Hokkaido Unyu Kaisha and Echu Fuhansen Kaisha, and also with the investment from anti-Mitsubishi Zaibatsu powers such as Mitsui-zaibatsu.

history.name: The Yoshino Pact (a pact concluded with Emperor Tenmu and Empress Jito about the enthronement of Prince Kusakabe)
history.url: history/The Yoshino Pact (a pact concluded with Emperor Tenmu and Empress Jito about the enthronement of Pri.html
history.desc: The Yoshino pact was concluded by Emperor Tenmu and his empress who was later known as Empress Jito promising their son, Prince Kusakabe, to be the next emperor.

history.name: Security Police Law
history.desc: The Security Police Law was the law that once existed in Japan.

history.name: The Rodo Kumiai Kiseikai (the Association for the Promotion of Labor Unions)
history.url: history/The Rodo Kumiai Kiseikai (the Association for the Promotion of Labor Unions).html
history.desc: The Rodo Kumiai Kiseikai was an association founded in the Meiji Period for the purpose of forming labor unions.

history.name: Shichihakushi Ikensho (seven doctors' opinion)
history.desc: Shichihakushi Ikensho was a written opinion submitted to the then Prime Minister Taro KATSURA, Minister of Foreign Affairs (Japan) Jutaro KOMURA and so on as of June 10 1903, just before the start of Russo-Japanese War.

history.name: Datsu-A Ron (Argument for Leaving Asia)
history.desc: Datsu-A Ron was an an editorial published in the Japanese newspaper 'Jiji Shinpo' on March 16, 1885.

history.name: Tochi chosa jigyo (land research project)
history.desc: Tochi chosa jigyo (land research project) refers to the land research and land measurement project conducted in Taiwan and Korea which were under the control of Japan.

history.name: Wakon yosai (Japanese spirit with Western learning)
history.url: history/Wakon yosai (Japanese spirit with Western learning).html
history.desc: Wakon yosai (Japanese spirit with Western learning) means adopting Western arts while valuing Japanese traditional spirituality, and harmonizing as well as developing them.

history.name: Hyoron Shinbun (literally, Critical Newspaper)
history.desc: Hyoron Shinbun was a periodical literature which was existed in the Meiji period.

history.name: The first Korea-Japan Agreement
history.desc: The First Korea-Japan Agreement was an agreement signed between the Empire of Japan and the Korean Empire (Joseon Dynasty) during the Russo-Japanese War on August 22, 1904.

history.name: King of Japan (Nihon Kokuo)
history.desc: The king of Japan was a title of the ruler of Japan, which was used mainly by the head of the military government internationally during the medieval and early-modern times.

history.name: Kannonji family feud
history.desc: The Kannonji family feud is the family trouble that broke out in the family of Rokkaku clan that was a warring load of Minami Omi Province in 1563 during the Sengoku period (the Warring State Period of Japan).

history.name: Sakekabu (an official certificate of sake brewing)
history.url: history/Sakekabu (an official certificate of sake brewing).html
history.desc: Sakekabu is one of the licensing systems in the sake brewing industry, which was implemented by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) of Japan as a basic policy for controlling sake brewing.

history.name: Shichijo-shinchi
history.desc: Shichijo-shinchi was once a brothel in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City and today it continues its business under its new name, "Gojo Rakuen."

history.name: The Second Katsura Cabinet
history.desc: Summary

history.name: The Capital of Japan
history.desc: In this article, we describe the history of capitals and their changes in Japan.

history.name: An Ancient Capital
history.desc: An ancient capital can be defined as a place which has been the national capital since the ancient times or a place which was once the national capital city.

history.name: Inyoka (the Yin and Yang School of Philosophy)
history.url: history/Inyoka (the Yin and Yang School of Philosophy).html
history.desc: Inyoka is a philosophy group regarded as one of Shoshi hyakka (the Various Masters of the 100 Schools: Thinkers of Ancient China), and one of the six major schools.

history.name: Angaryo Family (Abe Family and Kamo Family)
history.url: history/Angaryo Family (Abe Family and Kamo Family).html
history.desc: The Angaryo family is the collective name of the Abe clan and the Kamo clan which are the head families of Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements).

history.name: Kugyo-bunin
history.desc: Kugyo-bunin is a historical material of Japan and the directory of successive personnel in the Imperial Court.

history.name: Chugushiki
history.desc: Chugushiki was the office which belonged to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) and was in charge of the consort's household affairs under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: The Conservative Revolution
history.desc: The Conservative Revolution (Konservative Revolution) is a general name that Armin Mohler, a German intellectual historian, gave to a set of anti-Nazi and nationalist intellectual trends during the Weimar Republic.

history.name: Robbery and Murder on the Sanyo Railway Train
history.jp: 山陽鉄道列車強盗殺人事件
history.url: history/Robbery and Murder on the Sanyo Railway Train.html
history.desc: The robbery and murder on the Sanyo Railway train was a robbery and murder case that occurred in the middle of the Meiji period.

history.name: Rikkenseitai no Shosho (An imperial edict for the establishment of the constitutional system of government)
history.url: history/Rikkenseitai no Shosho (An imperial edict for the establishment of the constitutional system of gove.html
history.desc: Rikkenseitai no Shosho was issued by the Emperor Meiji on April 14, 1875.

history.name: The Japan-Korea Protocol of 1904
history.desc: The Japan and Korea Protocol was the treaty which was signed between Japan and the Korean Empire during the Russo-Japan War in 1904.

history.name: The Itsukaichi Constitution
history.desc: The Itsukaichi Constitution is one of the constitution drafts which were made at the beginning of the Meiji period.

history.name: Kawase-mai-rei Law (Rice-purchase Law)
history.desc: In 1730, the Kawase-mai-rei Law was enforced as part of the Kyoho Reforms (the reforms made in the Kyoho era of the Edo period).

history.name: National Bank (Meiji Period)
history.desc: The National Bank (Kokuritsu Ginko) is a financial institution which was established based on the National Bank Act issued in 1872.

history.name: Asuka-kyo (the Capital of Asuka)
history.desc: Asuka-kyo (also known as Asuka no Miyako [the capital of Asuka]) is the name of the ancient capital mainly in the Asuka period, which is believed to be existed in the general area covering present-day Asuka Village, Takaichi County, Nara Prefecture.

history.name: The government offices centralizing plan
history.desc: The government offices centralizing plan was the city plan of the capital of Tokyo which was organized in the Meiji period; it planned to build a splendid baroque city which would be equivalent to Paris or Berlin by centralizing official buildings such as the Congress Hall and government offices around Kasumigaseki area in Tokyo.

history.name: Hachigyaku (eight unpardonable crimes)
history.desc: Hachigyaku means the eight most serious crimes in the ritsuryo code.

history.name: The second Saionji Cabinet
history.desc: On July 30, 1912 during the term of this cabinet, the Meiji period ended due to the death of the Emperor Meiji and the Taisho period started from the same day.

history.name: The Plan to conquest Silla
history.desc: The plan to conquest Silla was a plan for military action in the Korean Peninsula during the Asuka period.

history.name: Ienoko (Follower)
history.desc: Ienoko are constituent members of bushidan (warrior bands).

history.name: Mumon-ginsen Coin
history.desc: Mumon-ginsen coin is the Japan's oldest private silver coin.

history.name: The Arrival of the Black Ships
history.url: history/The Arrival of the Black Ships.html
history.desc: In 1853, the East India Squadron of the United States Navy arrived in Japan at Uraga, near the entrance of Tokyo Bay (Uraga, Yokosuka City, Kanagawa Prefecture)--an incident that came to be known as the "Arrival of the Black Ships."

history.name: Genko borui (Genko [Mongol invasion attempts against Japan]) (borui [fort to prevent enemy's attack])
history.url: history/Genko borui (Genko [Mongol invasion attempts against Japan]) (borui [fort to prevent enemys attack]).html
history.desc: Genko borui is the fort constructed with stone along the coast area of Hakata Bay in Kitakyushu in the Kamakura period.

history.name: Tensha Tsuchimikado Shinto
history.desc: Tensha Tsuchimikado Shinto is a school of Shinto religion/Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements) with its headquarters in Oi-cho (formerly Natasho-mura area), Fukui Prefecture.

history.name: Gonin-gumi (five-household group) (Japanese history)
history.desc: In Japanese history, the Gonin-gumi, or the five-household group system, was a system of the community association organized under the command of a feudal lord.

history.name: Goho-sei System
history.desc: Goho-sei System is one of those introduced from the ritsuryo system of the Tang Dynasty by the Emperor Tenji after the Taika Reforms.

history.name: Shokudo (penalty charges)
history.desc: Shokudo or zokudo is a penalty charge which was paid with copper (or money) to a government official in an amount that corresponds to the crime in exchange for imprisonment.

history.name: Nuidonoryo
history.desc: Nuidonoryo (Bureau of the Wardrobe and Court Ladies) was the office which belonged to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central affairs) and was in charge of personnel affairs of nyokan (court ladies) as well as the supervision of sewing under the Japanese Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo code).

history.name: Okimi no Tsukasa (Imperial Family Office)
history.desc: Okimi no tsukasa was one of the institutions belonging to Imperial Household Agency in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in ancient Japan.

history.name: Sanniryo (the office controlling Sanni, courtiers without a post)
history.url: history/Sanniryo (the office controlling Sanni, courtiers without a post).html
history.desc: Sanniryo was one of the institutions belonging to Shikibu-sho (the Ministry of Ceremonial) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in ancient Japan.

history.name: Zushoryo (the Bureau of Drawings and Books)
history.url: history/Zushoryo (the Bureau of Drawings and Books).html
history.desc: Zushoryo was one of the institutions belonging to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Gakoshi (Painting Office)
history.desc: Gakoshi (Painting Office) was one of the institutions belonging to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Nairaishi
history.desc: Nairaishi (Palace Etiquette Office) was one of the institutions belonging to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Otoneriryo (Bureau of Imperial Attendants)
history.desc: Otoneriryo was one of the institutions belonging to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Shujikan
history.desc: Shujikan were the predecessor of modern-day prisons created in the Meiji period.

history.name: Kyotoshi
history.desc: Kyotoshi (Vessels Office) was one of the institutions belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Genba-ryo (Bureau of Buddhism and Aliens)
history.desc: Genba-ryo was one of the institutions belonging to Jibusho (the Ministry of Civil Administration) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Dokoshi
history.desc: Dokoshi (Public Works Office) was one of the institutions belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Enchishi
history.desc: Enchishi (Gardens and Ponds Office) was one of the institutions belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Shusuishi (Water Office)
history.desc: Shusuishi (moitori no tsukasa) was one of the institutions belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Bunkyu Reform
history.desc: The Bunkyu Reform was a series of policy changes covering personnel affairs, office organization and various rules and regulations carried out by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in 1862.

history.name: Shigi Kenpo (Draft Constitutions of Japan)
history.desc: Shigi Kenpo are draft constitutions created by nongovernmental bodies before the issuance of the Constitution of the Empire of Japan in the Meiji period.

history.name: Ground Stone Tool
history.desc: Ground stone tool is a kind of stone tools in classification by fabrication method.

history.name: Chokyo-Entoku Wars
history.desc: The Chokyo-Entoku Wars were campaigns conducted by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) twice in 1487 and in 1491 in the late Muromachi period against Omi no kuni shugo (the provincial constable of Omi Province) Takayori ROKKAKU, and it is also referred to as Rokkaku Seibatsu (suppression).

history.name: Ishida Sanyaku (Ishida medicinal powder)
history.desc: Ishida Sanyaku was medical powder made and sold by the home of the parents of Toshizo HIJIKATA, a vice chief of the Shinsengumi (a paramilitary group of pro-shogunate ronin formed in Kyoto).

history.name: Shinengo
history.desc: Shinengo (literally means private nengo; nengo is a name of an era) was the name of an era which was not declared by a dynasty that had a stable administrating power in South East Asia, where the name of an era was used as the method of counting years.

history.name: Reformation Of The Shogunate Government
history.desc: Reformation of the shogunate government refers to the reforms of the financial, political, and other systems implemented under the Edo "bakufu" (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Minsen Giin Setsuritsu Kenpaku Sho (The Petition to Establish an Elected Assembly)
history.url: history/Minsen Giin Setsuritsu Kenpaku Sho (The Petition to Establish an Elected Assembly).html
history.desc: Minsen Giin Setsuritsu Kenpaku Sho' was the first petition requesting the government to establish a parliament with democratically-elected representatives supported by people including former Sangi councilors Taisuke ITAGAKI and Shojiro GOTO on January 17, 1874.

history.name: Ishi-gassen (a stone-throwing fight)
history.desc: Ishi-gassen is a stone-throwing fight, in which people are divided into two groups and throw stones at each other, imitating a battle in the Sengoku period.

history.name: Togubo (Crown Prince's Quarters)
history.desc: Togubo existed in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in ancient Japan.

history.name: Shugokushi
history.desc: Shugokushi (Prisons Office) was one of the agencies that belonged to Gyobusho (Ministry of Justice) in ancient Japanese system of centralized governance.

history.name: Miya Sodo (Palace Disturbance)
history.desc: Miya sodo (palace disturbance) is the incident in which Mitsutoki HOJO attempted a rebellion, and the former Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), FUJIWARA no Yoritsune, was banished from Kamakura, and returned to Kyoto in 1246 in the Kamakura period.

history.name: Bronze mirror
history.desc: Bronze mirror is made of bronze alloy.

history.name: Uchikowashi
history.desc: Uchikowashi refers to an action to destroy residences of the people who were considered to act wrong, and it was one of the patterns of grass-roots movements in the Edo period.

history.name: Shukun oshikome (detention of a lord by retainers)
history.url: history/Shukun oshikome (detention of a lord by retainers).html
history.desc: Shukun oshikome (or simply called 'oshikome') is a practice seen in the samurai society beginning in the Kamakura period, and it especially refers to the forcible confinement of the allegedly misbehaving lord based on the decision made by Karo (chief retainers) and others after consultation.

history.name: Hyojosho (conference chamber)
history.desc: The Hyojosho is an institution that handled lawsuits before modern times, or the place where such institution was located.

history.name: Gosho Sendo-mairi
history.desc: Gosho Sendo-mairi is an incident occurred on July 21, 1787, in which many people circled around the Gosho (Imperial Palace) to make sendo-mairi (literally a visit to shrine a thousand times for prayer).

history.name: Mutsu no Kami
history.desc: Mutsu no kami was the governor of Mutsu Province.

history.name: Chucho Jijitsu (The record of the central nation)
history.url: history/Chucho Jijitsu (The record of the central nation).html
history.desc: Chucho Jijitsu (The record of the central nation) is a history book about the thought of reverence for the emperor, written by Soko YAMAGA.

history.name: Oiryo
history.desc: Oiryo (Bureau of Palace Kitchens) is a bureau of Kunaisho (the Ministry of the Imperial Household) under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Kodai Sanjo (ancient castles built on the top of mountains)
history.url: history/Kodai Sanjo (ancient castles built on the top of mountains).html
history.desc: Kodai Sanjo generally refers to ancient mountain castles built in the historical period from Asuka to Nara, which were influenced by the Korean Peninsula.

history.name: Kofun period (tumulus period)
history.desc: In general, the 'Kofun period' (tumulus period) refers to the period ranging from the middle of the third century to the later part of the seventh century, approximately 400 years.

history.name: Jushichijo Kenpo (The 17-Article Constitution; a code consisting of 17 articles in ancient Japan)
history.url: history/Jushichijo Kenpo (The 17-Article Constitution; a code consisting of 17 articles in ancient Japan).html
history.desc: Jushichijo Kenpo was a code consisting of 17 articles, which was described under the article of May 9, 604 of "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and "Sendai Kujihongi" (Ancient Japanese History) as follows: 'In summer on May 9, the Crown Prince himself wrote 17 articles of constitution.'

history.name: Inaba Sodo (Inaba Riot)
history.desc: The Inaba Riot was a large scale uprising of peasants which broke out in the Nishiowari region (133 villages of Inazawa, Bisai, Ichinomiya and Tsushima [today's Aichi Prefecture in Japan]) in January 1870.

history.name: Kagen War
history.desc: Kagen War is a disturbance that occurred in 1305 (in the Kagen era) within the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Keicho Tsuho coin
history.desc: The Keicho Tsuho was a copper coin issued by the Edo Shognate in 1606. (different theories exist.)

history.name: Kura-bugyo (storehouse administrator)
history.desc: Kura-bugyo was an administrator who controlled the government rice storehouses located in major cities in the Edo period, including one in Asakusa, Edo (Asakusa Okura).

history.name: Shoho-gocho (Statistical Book of the Shoho Era)
history.url: history/Shoho-gocho (Statistical Book of the Shoho Era).html
history.desc: Shoho-gocho is a statistical book which the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) ordered daimyo (feudal lords) to prepare by ryoseikoku (province), putting together the names and muradaka (total yields) of villages.

history.name: Soma Jiken (Soma Incident)
history.desc: Some Jiken is one of the family troubles occurred in the Meiji period in Japan.

history.name: Hora Buraku (a discriminated community in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture)
history.url: history/Hora Buraku (a discriminated community in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture).html
history.desc: Hora Buraku was a discriminated community which used to exist in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

history.name: Tokyo Jidai (Tokyo Period)
history.desc: The Tokyo period is a notion devised as a way to refer to the period after 1868, when the Edo bakufu collapsed and the Meiji restoration was started, within the framework of periodization of Japanese history.

history.name: Aka-hata Jiken (Red Flag Incident)
history.desc: Aka-hata Jiken is an incident that clamped down on socialists, occurred on June 22, 1908.

history.name: Nishiki no mihata (The Imperial Standard)
history.desc: The Imperial standard is the banner of the Imperial court army.

history.name: Kobunjigaku (the study of archaic words and phrases)
history.url: history/Kobunjigaku (the study of archaic words and phrases).html
history.desc: Kobunjigaku is a school of Confucianism founded by Sorai OGYU in the Edo period.

history.name: Prince Otomo enthronement theory
history.desc: The Prince Otomo enthronement theory was advocated in the Edo period and it was a long-lasting dispute in the Japanese history.

history.name: Tetsudai Fushin (Large-scale engineering work by federal lords under shogun's order)
history.url: history/Tetsudai Fushin (Large-scale engineering work by federal lords under shoguns order).html
history.desc: Tetsudai Fushin was a large-scale civil engineering work done by territorial lords under the orders from the Toyotomi government and the Edo Shogunate.

history.name: Kayakugata Ninsokuyoseba
history.desc: Ninsokuyoseba, Hitsuke Tozoku Aratame-kata Ninsokuyoseba by formal name, was a self-support facility set up by the Edo Shogunate for minor offenders and those who are likely to commit crimes.

history.name: Bu (Shakkanho)
history.desc: Bu is a unit of length under the shakkanho (old Japanese system of weights and measures).

history.name: Government Organization of Early Modern Japan
history.url: history/Government Organization of Early Modern Japan.html
history.desc: Under the title "Government Organization of Early Modern Japan," this article outlines the changes of major agencies of the central government of Japan from rom January 3, 1868, when the Meiji restoration was started with Restoration of Imperial Rule, to December 24, 1889, when the official organization system under the Cabinet was established.

history.name: Sohatsu (hairstyle)
history.desc: Sohatsu is a hairstyle adopted by male Shinto priests and Confucian scholars from the early part of the Edo period.

history.name: Party Cabinet
history.desc: A party cabinet is a cabinet organized on the basis of political parties with seats in the parliament.

history.name: Sogishi
history.desc: Sogishi (Mourning and Burial Office) is a bureau within Jibusho (Ministry of Civil Administration) under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Shuzeiryo (Bureau of Taxation)
history.desc: Shuzeiryo refers to an institution that belonged to Minbusho (Ministry of Popular Affairs) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Geishogi Kaiho Rei (Emancipation Edict for Female Performers and Prostitutes)
history.url: history/Geishogi Kaiho Rei (Emancipation Edict for Female Performers and Prostitutes).html
history.desc: The Geishogi Kaiho Rei is a law issued by the Meiji Government in 1872, whose main aim was to control human traffic of prostitutes.

history.name: Shuyoshi
history.desc: Shuyoshi (Falcons Office) refers to an institution that belonged to Hyobusho (Ministry of Military) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Kyoshiki (the Capital Bureau)
history.desc: Kyoshiki refers to a capital administrative agency in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Tenka (the realm)
history.desc: Tenka (天下, also pronounced tenga, tenge, or amenoshita) is a notion which means the whole world.

history.name: Shudenryo (Bureau of Grounds)
history.desc: Shudenryo, also referred to as Tonomori no Tsukasa, refers to an institution that belonged to Kunaisho (Imperial Household Ministry) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) of Japan adopting the Ritsuryo system.

history.name: Uetsufumi (Ancient Japanese Literature)
history.desc: "Uetsufumi" is one of the writings called Koshi Koden (ancient history and legends) which contains ancient Japanese history including Ugayafukiaezu dynasty, which was before Yamato Dynasty, written in ancient Japanese characters, but it is said to be gisho (apocryphal book).

history.name: Haruma Wage (the first Dutch-Japanese dictionary)
history.desc: Haruma Wage is the first Dutch-Japanese dictionary.

history.name: 名代 (Myodai or Nashiro)
history.desc: The term "myodai" means to act as a person's proxy.

history.name: The Kawamata Incident
history.desc: The Kawamata Incident was a struggle that took place on February 13, 1900 in Kawamata, Sanuki Village, Oura County, Gunma Prefecture (the present Meiwa Town, Gunma Prefecture) between police and peasants who were marching to Tokyo to protest to the Meiji government against the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident.

history.name: Gunyoshuhyo (Military currency)
history.desc: Gunyoshuhyo is pseudo currency issued during wars for military forces to pay for commodities and other necessaries in its occupying areas or areas under their control.

history.name: Mokuryo (Bureau of Carpentry)
history.desc: Mokuryo refers to an institution that belonged to Kunaisho (Imperial Household Ministry) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) of Japan adopting the Ritsuryo system.

history.name: MINGEI (National Art) Movement
history.desc: MINGEI (National Art) Movement is a movement started by the first issue of "Prospectus for establishment of the Japanese Folk Crafts Museum" in 1926.

history.name: Japanese military history
history.desc: Japanese military history is characterized by the long feudal battles inside the nation and the overseas expedition during the age of imperialism.

history.name: History of Japanese Navy
history.desc: The history of Japanese navy goes back to the early medieval period in which Japan interacted with countries on the Asian Continent.

history.name: History of Japan's trade
history.desc: We will explain the history of Japan's trade, as it concerns foreign trade.

history.name: Bunjin (Literati in China)
history.desc: The term "Bunjin" refers to a type of people in traditional society in China and 'an educated person who is good at literature.'

history.name: Sanketsu (Three Outstanding People)
history.desc: Sanketsu means three outstanding people chosen out of those who made the greatest achievements in historical incidents or in their services to their lords.

history.name: Appointment (Ninkan)
history.desc: Ninkan means being appointed to a government post.

history.name: The Battle of Subushi (a battle fought between the Imperial Army and Emishi in Rikuchu Province in Nara period)
history.url: history/The Battle of Subushi (a battle fought between the Imperial Army and Emishi in Rikuchu Province in N.html
history.desc: The Battle of Subushi was a battle between the Imperial army and Emishi (natives of the Japanese islands of Hokkaido and northern Honshu that opposed and resisted the rule of the Japanese Emperors) occurred in Tohoku region (later Rikuchu Province) in the Nara period.

history.name: The Hoki War (the rebellion of Emishi in Rikuzen Province in the Nara period)
history.url: history/The Hoki War (the rebellion of Emishi in Rikuzen Province in the Nara period).html
history.desc: The Hoki War was the rebellion of Emishi (natives of the Japanese islands of Hokkaido and northern Honshu that opposed and resisted the rule of the Japanese Emperors) in Tohoku region (later Rikuzen Province) in the Nara period.

history.name: Flogging
history.desc: Flogging (jozai or jokei) was one of the five sentences of the Ritsuryo law.

history.name: Heguri Clan (an ancient powerful local clan based in Heguri County, Yamato Province)
history.url: history/Heguri Clan (an ancient powerful local clan based in Heguri County, Yamato Province).html
history.desc: The Heguri clan is said to be a descendant of TAKENOUCHI no Sukune and one of the ancient powerful local clans based in Heguri no go, Heguri County in Yamato Province (present Heguri Town, Ikoma County, Nara Prefecture).

history.name: Written Appointments among the Samurai Class (Kantojo)
history.url: history/Written Appointments among the Samurai Class (Kantojo).html
history.desc: Kantojo (官途状) is a letter which was used after the Muromachi period which stated, that a vassal who distinguished himself in a battle was allowed by his lord to use a specific government post as his private name.

history.name: Goryosho
history.desc: Goryosho, which is also called ryosho or goryo, is the land under the direct control of an official authority such as the Emperor (the Imperial family) or Shogunate.

history.name: Tatsumaru Incident
history.desc: The "Tatsumaru Incident" is a famous incident which triggered the anti-Japanese campaign in China.

history.name: Zoishokenden (list of conferrals of posthumous ranks)
history.url: history/Zoishokenden (list of conferrals of posthumous ranks).html
history.desc: "Zoishokenden" is the title of a book which lists 966 persons who were granted a rank posthumously between 1868 and 1911; a brief biography is provided for each of them.

history.name: Tekkosen (armored warships)
history.desc: A tekkosen was a large-size Atake-bune (a type of naval warship) that Nobunaga ODA ordered Yoshitaka KUKI to build in order to fight against the Mori/Murakami navy.

history.name: Hosho-sen
history.desc: A hosho-sen was a ship carrying not only a shuinjo (license for foreign trade) issued by the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") but also a hosho (permit) written by roju (members of shogun's council of elders).

history.name: Budan Seiji (government by the military)
history.desc: Budan Seiji is an authoritarian government based on military power.

history.name: Agechi-rei
history.desc: Agechi-rei (上知令) is an order for confiscation of lands issued by the government in the late Edo period and the early Meiji period.

history.name: Changes of Dynasties Theories
history.desc: Changes of dynasties theories are doctrines which say, due to the interruption in the imperial line of the Imperial Family in the Kofun period in Japan, dynasties were changed several times.

history.name: Sanshi Incident
history.desc: "Sanshi Incident" refers to the murder of a prefectural government official that occurred in Okinawa Prefecture in the early Meiji period.

history.name: The Battle of Matsukawa
history.desc: The Battle of Matsukawa is said to be the battle where Shigenaga HONJO and Nagayoshi SUDA under the command of Kagekatsu UESUGI fought against Masamune DATE in the central area of the present Fukushima City, Fukushima Prefecture on April 26, 1601, according to "Kaisei Mikawago Fudoki (Foundation of the Tokugawa clan)" (Vol. 42: The battle between Uesugi and Date), "Jozenkidan (a collection of anecdotes compiled in the Edo period)" (Vol. 16: The Battle of Matsukawa between Date and Uesugi in Mutsu Province with the episode of Zenzaemon NAGAI and Sanai OKA), "Togoku Taiheiki (the battle chronicle on the eastern Japan)" (Vol. 15: Attack to the Fukushima-jo Castle by Masamune in the Battle of Matsukawa), "Aizujin Monogatari (stories on the Battle in Aizu)" (Vol. 4: Attack to the Fukushima-jo Castle by Masamune in the Battle of Matsukawa and the episode of Oiinosuke SUDA cutting off the camp enclosure during the Battle of Abukuma-gawa River against Masamune).

history.name: Kioizaka Incident
history.desc: The "Kioizaka Incident" (Kioizaka no Hen: May 14, 1878) was the incident when Genkun (oligarch with merits) of Meiji, Toshimichi OKUBO, was assassinated by six shizoku (family or person with samurai ancestors) on the Kiyomizu-zaka Slope at Kioi-cho, Tokyo.

history.name: Urakami Yoban Kuzure (the fourth persecution of Urakami Christians)
history.url: history/Urakami Yoban Kuzure (the fourth persecution of Urakami Christians).html
history.desc: "Urakami yoban kuzure," which means the fourth suppression campaign against crypto-Christians in Urakami area, refers to a large-scale crackdown on Christians which took place in Nagasaki Prefecture from the end of Edo period to the early Meiji period.

history.name: Shoden (the privilege of entering denjo no ma [denjo room] of the Imperial Palace)
history.url: history/Shoden (the privilege of entering denjo no ma [denjo room] of the Imperial Palace).html
history.desc: Shoden referred to having/giving permission to enter a denjo no ma in the minami hisashi (southern surrounding area) of the seiryoden of dairi (Imperial Palace) to people higher than goi (Fifth Rank) in the rank and people in a position of Rokui no Kurodo (Chamberlain of Sixth Rank) in and after the Heian period.

history.name: Sankokyukei (three high level bureaucrats and nine lords)
history.url: history/Sankokyukei (three high level bureaucrats and nine lords).html
history.desc: Sankokyukei refers to a generic name for posts of administrative officials in the Qin and Han Dynasties of China.

history.name: Nagahama sandoshiyori (Three influential families in Nagahama)
history.url: history/Nagahama sandoshiyori (Three influential families in Nagahama).html
history.desc: Nagahama sandoshiyori refers to most influential three families among Nagahama juninshu (10 influential families in Nagahama), 10 representative families of machi-doshiyori (ward head) in townspeople who built the Nagahama-jo Castle town (49 towns and 10 wards) under the order of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

history.name: Koka fifty-three families
history.desc: Koka fifty-three families refers to jizamurai (local samurai) fifty-three families in Koka, who stood by Rokkaku clan's side in 'Siege of Magari,' who later became the center families of Koga-ryu school ninjutsu (ninja techniques).

history.name: Koga Nijuikke
history.desc: Koga Nijuikke (Twenty-one Families of Koga) refers to the most trusted twenty-one families of all the fifty-three families of Koga, which received letters of commendation from the ROKKAKU clan and later played a central role in the Ninjutsu (Ninja Art) of the Koga-ryu School.

history.name: Ashio Riot
history.desc: The "Ashio Riot" was an event occurred from February 4, 1907 to February 7, that mine workers in Ashio Copper Mine destroyed and set fire to the facilities in the mine.

history.name: Eishi (guards)
history.desc: 衛士 (eishi or eji)

history.name: Sanken-Ikkyoku Jidai (period of three prefectures and one bureau)
history.url: history/Sanken-Ikkyoku Jidai (period of three prefectures and one bureau).html
history.desc: Sanken-Ikkyoku Jidai is one of the periods within the framework of periodization in the history of Hokkaido.

history.name: Gimin
history.desc: Gimin is a ringleader of uprising during a famine and the like.

history.name: Komatsubara Honan (Komatsubara Persecution)
history.desc: Komatsubara Honan is an incident that Nichiren was assaulted and injured in Komatsubara (present-day Kamogawa City, Chiba Prefecture).

history.name: Katakamuna civilization
history.desc: Katakamuna civilization is a super ancient civilization that is said to have existed in Japan.

history.name: Jofu
history.desc: Jofu is a person in the Edo period who lived permanently in Edo and served seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdued the barbarians") without performing Sankinkotai (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo).

history.name: Ezochishimao Kasha
history.desc: Ezochishimao Kasha (or called Ezochishimao Kahi or Ezochishimao Kayu) refers to the name of person who sent an envoy in 1482 to request the Yi Dynasty Korea for Tripitaka Koreana.

history.name: Tsukubo
history.desc: Tsukubo is one of the tools for capturing criminals which was used in the Edo period.

history.name: Railway opening in Japan
history.desc: Here, in "Railway opening in Japan," the background to the official opening of Japan's first railway line between Shiodome Station (Japanese National Railways) and Sakuragicho Station on October 14, 1872 is described.

history.name: History of Japanese Railways (the Meiji Period)
history.url: history/History of Japanese Railways (the Meiji Period).html
history.desc: The history of Japanese railways (the Meiji Period) covers the summary of the changes that took place from the end of the Edo Period to the end of the Meiji Period.

history.name: Josaku (official defense site)
history.desc: Josaku is a historical term for a government office with defending facilities that was located to govern the north part of present-day Niigata Prefecture and the Tohoku region under the ritsuryo system during the ancient Japan.

history.name: Jogan no chi (Glorious Jogan rule)
history.desc: Jogan no chi (Glorious Jogan rule) indicates the politics performed during the Jogan era (Tang, 627 - 649) and the reign of the second Emperor Taiso (Tang tai zong) in the Tang Dynasty (618 - 907) in China.

history.name: Edict on Change of Status (an edict with three articles issued in 1591)
history.url: history/Edict on Change of Status (an edict with three articles issued in 1591).html
history.desc: The Edict on Change of Status was an edict with three articles issued in 1591 by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

history.name: Meryo (Bureau of Horses)
history.desc: Meryo (or Uma no tsukasa) refers to one of the government officials in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Tosho-Chosonsei (town and village system in islands)
history.url: history/Tosho-Chosonsei (town and village system in islands).html
history.desc: Tosho-Chosonsei is a generic term used to refer to the system implemented in island areas apart from the town and village system implemented in Japan's mainland.

history.name: Mochigumi
history.desc: Mochigumi was an organization in the Edo bakufu.

history.name: Ichi no Tsukasa
history.desc: Ichi no tsukasa (Market Office) was the institution that belonged to Kyoshiki (the Capital Bureau) on the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) of the Ritsuryo system Japan.

history.name: The Constitution of 1868 (Seitaisho)
history.desc: The Constitution of 1868 was the proclamation in which the Meiji government determined the governmental organization of the early Meiji period.

history.name: Boxer Rebellion
history.desc: The Boxer Rebellion was the disturbance that occurred at the end of the Qing dynasty in China.

history.name: Datsua-shiso thought (thought of leaving Asia)
history.desc: Datsua-shiso thought is a concept mainly advocated by Yukichi FUKUZAWA, which encourages an abolishment of Confucianism and a departure from Sinocentrism.

history.name: Kyogaku Seishi
history.desc: Kyogaku Seishi is an education policy presented to Sangi (Councilors) Hirobumi ITO and Munenori TERASHIMA (also the Mombukyo [chief of the Ministry of Education]) by the Meiji Emperor in 1879.

history.name: Toki Yasuyuki Rebellion
history.desc: Toki Yasuyori Rebellion was an incident that occurred from 1389 to 1390, during the Muromachi period of Japan, in which Yasuyuki TOKI, a shugo daimyo (shugo is a governor of a province during the middle ages of Japan, and a shugo daimyo is a regional lord who has an official title of shugo from the government of the time) was defeated by the Muromachi bakufu.

history.name: Denshutai (Edo shogunate's army)
history.desc: Denshutai (Edo shogunate's army) refers to the western-style army which was organized by Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) as the elite troops of the bakufu army, and was directly trained by the French Military Advisory Group.

history.name: Besshufusensho
history.desc: Besshufusensho is a law code containing Daijokanpu (official documents from Daijokan to local governments) and imperial decrees issued between 902 and 971

history.name: Kyoroku-Tenbun Rebellion
history.desc: The Kyoroku-Tenbun Rebellion is the general term for the internal conflict within the Hongan-ji Temple sect of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism) over the sectarian reform in the early Sengoku Period and the external war provoked by the conflict.

history.name: Akugyaku
history.desc: Akugyaku was one of hachi-gyaku (eight unpardonable crimes) defined by the ritsuryo (legal codes of the Nara and Heian periods).

history.name: Yushi (privately adopted child)
history.desc: Yushi is a system that existed prior to the Meiji period to establish a parent-child relationship with a child who was not kin.

history.name: Yushi Sensei (Despotism by Domain-dominated Government)
history.desc: Yushi Sensei is a term criticizing the Meiji government for their domain cliques and transcendentalism.

history.name: Northern Trade
history.desc: Northern Trade was the trade between China (Northern Song Dynasty) and the Oshu-Fujiwara clan or the Abe clan (Oshu) and the Dewa Kiyohara clan who dominated Ou before then.

history.name: Shakuzetsu-nichi Day (an unlucky day)
history.desc: Shakuzetsu-nichi Day is a day controlled by Rasetsu-shin God (type of evil spirit) of Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang) (in the customs of nobles and ordinary citizens), and was considered unlucky day.

history.name: Jokoku
history.desc: "Jokoku" (second-biggest provinces next to Taikoku) is one of grade classifications of provinces governed in accordance with the Ritsuryo codes.

history.name: Jin (position)
history.desc: "Jin" was a place where military officers of Rokuefu (six guard divisions) lined up in the Imperial Court.

history.name: Osaka Conference
history.desc: The Osaka Conference is a meeting which took place in Osaka Prefecture on February 11, 1875 and where the dignitaries of the Meiji government, Toshimichi OKUBO, Takayoshi KIDO and Taisuke ITAGAKI, got together to discuss the government's prospective policy (the establishment of constitutional government) and the appointment of Sangi (councillors).

history.name: Sain (Council of the Left)
history.desc: The Sain was a legislative and consultative body in the early Meiji period.

history.name: Chikusen-joirei (an ordinance to ordain a court rank to someone who saved a certain amount of money)
history.url: history/Chikusen-joirei (an ordinance to ordain a court rank to someone who saved a certain amount of money).html
history.desc: "Chikusen-joirei" was an ordinance which took effect in October 711 in order to promote circulation of money and attempt to circulation to the government.

history.name: Goshu Shimazu Clan
history.desc: The Goshu Shimazu Clan rose in Omi Province and was one of the branch families of the Shimazu Clan of Satsuma Province.

history.name: The Jomon Period
history.desc: The Jomon period is approximately from 16,500 to 3,000 years ago (the tenth century B.C.) in terms of date, developed from the end of the Pleistocene epoch to the Holocene epoch in the Japanese archipelago in terms of geological age, and is comparable to the Mesolithic period or the Neolithic period in terms of the world history.

history.name: Taft-Katsura Agreement
history.desc: The Taft–Katsura Agreement was an agreement made between the Prime Minister of Japan Taro KATSURA, who was also the temporary Minister of Foreign Affairs, and William Howard TAFT, the United States Secretary of War and later the 27th President of the United States, who was also a special envoy visiting Japan on the way back from the Philippines.

history.name: Jige Kaden
history.desc: The Jige Kaden, a work of history written during the Tenpo era in the late Edo period, is a collection of the genealogical records of families of Jigenin (low-ranking court officials who were not allowed into the Emperor's living quarters in the imperial palace, usually ranked at the sixth rank or lower except for Kurodo).

history.name: Uin (Council of the Right)
history.desc: The Uin (Council of the Right) was an administrative body in the early Meiji period.

history.name: The Battle of Kyoko-ji Temple
history.desc: The Battle of Kyoko-ji Temple was fought between Nagayoshi MIYOSHI and Takamasa HATAKEYAMA near Kyoko-ji Mura, Takayasu County, Kawachi Province (present-day Kyoko-ji, Yao City, Osaka Prefecture) on May 19 and 20, 1562.

history.name: The distress of Frigate Ertuğrul Fırkateyni
history.jp: エルトゥールル号遭難事件
history.url: history/The distress of Frigate Ertuğrul Fırkateyni.html
history.desc: The distress of Frigate Ertuğrul was a shipwreck that Ertuğrul, a sailing frigate of the Ottoman Navy, suffered off the east of Kashinozaki Lighthouse in Kii-Oshima Island, Kushimoto-cho Town, Wakayama prefecture, on the middle of the night of September 16, 1890.

history.name: Ranpeki (people who devoted themselves to Dutch or Western learning)
history.url: history/Ranpeki (people who devoted themselves to Dutch or Western learning).html
history.desc: Ranpeki refers to people who devoted themselves to Western learning, or yearned and copied Dutch (or Western) manners and customs in the Edo period.

history.name: Ikezuki (the fine horse given by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo)
history.url: history/Ikezuki (the fine horse given by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo).html
history.desc: Ikezuki (生食) was the name of fine horses which did remarkable work in the end of Heian period.

history.name: Bunchi Seiji
history.desc: Bunchi seiji (civilian government) refers to a form of the governance practiced from the fourth shogun Ietsuna TOKUGAWA to the seventh Ietsugu TOKUGAWA.

history.name: The Shindo Incident
history.desc: The Shindo incident is a peasants' revolt that took place in Shindo Village (present-day Hiratsuka City), Osumi County, Kanagawa Prefecture in 1878.

history.name: Bansho-wage Goyo (Government Office for Translation of Barbarian Books)
history.url: history/Bansho-wage Goyo (Government Office for Translation of Barbarian Books).html
history.desc: Bansho-wage Goyo (Government Office for Translation of Barbarian Books) was a translation organization established by the Edo Bakufu in 1811.

history.name: Bankoku koho
history.desc: "Bankoku Koho" is a translated name of a commentary on international law, which gave considerable influences to various countries in East Asia by diffusing modern international law in a period from the second half of the nineteenth century to the first half of the twentieth century.

history.name: Saisekki (microlith; a small chipped stone tools characterized by a cutting edge)
history.url: history/Saisekki (microlith; a small chipped stone tools characterized by a cutting edge).html
history.desc: Saisekki (microlith) is a kind of chipped stone tools, which is small and is characterized by a cutting edge.

history.name: Agemai no sei
history.desc: Agemai no sei was a rule issued by the Edo Bakufu at the time of Kyoho-no-kaikaku (Kyoho reform).

history.name: Bokkaishi (delegate from Bo Hai)
history.desc: Bokkaishi was the envoy to Japan from Bo Hai, and a record stated there were 34 visits (one visit from the Liao Dynasty) of the envoy during 728 to 922.

history.name: Poorly-fed Children
history.desc: Poorly-fed children are children to whom meal is not given enough due to the economic poverty of the family.

history.name: Imperial Defense Policy
history.desc: Imperial Defense Policy was the basic guidelines for military strategy in the Empire of Japan.

history.name: KUME The Incident of Kunitake
history.desc: The Incident of Kunitake KUME was the incident in which a thesis, 'Shinto wa saiten no kozoku' (Shinto Is a Remnant of the Ancient Custom of Worshiping Heaven) was reprinted in 1892, in "Shikai" (Ocean of History) which Ukichi TAGUCHI edited, which caused a problem, and Kume lost his position as professor at the Imperial University.

history.name: Stone Axes
history.desc: Stone axes were a kind of stone tools that were axes made of stone attached to wooden handle.

history.name: Sekizoku (a flint arrowhead)
history.desc: Sekizoku is a type of stone tool also called a Yajiri (arrowhead; 鏃 or 矢尻 in Chinese characters).

history.name: Aikyu
history.desc: Aikyu is a term meaning a form of territory in the early-modern times when the murauke system (a system of village-wide, collective responsibility for tax payment) was established.

history.name: Tokametsuke
history.desc: Tokametsuke was one of the physical trainings of Ninja (a secret agent in feudal Japan highly skilled in stealth and secrecy).

history.name: New Currency Regulation
history.desc: Established on June 17, 1871, the New Currency Regulation was Japan's first coinage act of modern times.

history.name: Warabite sword
history.desc: Warabite sword is one of the Japanese iron swords.

history.name: The Case of Theft of Kusanagi no Tsurugi
history.url: history/The Case of Theft of Kusanagi no Tsurugi.html
history.desc: The case of theft of Kusanagi no tsurugi (alternate name for Ama-no-Murakumo no Tsurugi, the sword of the Imperial regalia) occurred in 668.

history.name: Independent Party or Mushozoku-dan
history.desc: Independent Party (Mushozoku-dan) refers to a faction within the Diet of the House of Peers under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

history.name: Konwa-kai
history.desc: Konwa-kai refers to a faction within the Diet of the House of Peers under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan.

history.name: Hino Incident
history.desc: Hino incident is an incident involving public safety, which took place in Hino-cho, Gamo-gun, Shiga Prefecture on October 18, 1951.

history.name: Kazoku-rei (Peerage Law)
history.desc: The Kazoku-rei was a Japanese act.

history.name: Nori
history.desc: Nori means a person with high political or administrative skill.

history.name: Urushigami Monjo
history.desc: Urushigami Monjo refers to the ancient documents that remained without corruption and were made by using the disposal documents as the paper lid of the container that had lacquer inside and permeating lacquer into the paper.

history.name: Nanshinron (Southward Advance Theory)
history.desc: The Nanshinron (southward advance) theory was one of Japan's foreign policies before World War II, advocating that the country should advance into Southeast Asia and the South Pacific islands.

history.name: Gyoki-zu
history.desc: Gyoki-zu (Gyoki Map) is an ancient-style map of Japan which is said to have been created by a Buddhist monk, Gyoki in the Nara period.

history.name: Kannen
history.desc: In modern samurai society, kannen was the official age of a person reported to the authorities such as the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) or the family of lord of the domain.

history.name: Jigatachigyo
history.desc: Jigatachigyo was the administrative form during Edo period that Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") or a lord of domain gave chigyo (enfeoffment, or the right to direct control of a certain asset) in the form of shoryo (territory) including the peasants living there to their vassals as a stipend and made them control it.

history.name: Ohama Riot
history.desc: Ohama Riot was the riot in Washizuka, Aomi County, Mikawa Province (currently Hekinan City, Aichi Prefecture) in 1871, although it was one of the protest movements against Haibutsu-kishaku (a movement to abolish Buddhism), it was an undesigned and incidental riot.

history.name: Ishi-bocho (a ground stone tools excavated from remains in the Jomon and Yayoi periods in Japan)
history.url: history/Ishi-bocho (a ground stone tools excavated from remains in the Jomon and Yayoi periods in Japan).html
history.desc: The term ishi-bocho (stone implement) refers to a ground stone tool excavated from remains in the Jomon period or Yayoi period in Japan (in Yangshao culture and Longshan culture in China).

history.name: Kuramae nyuyo
history.desc: Kuramae nyuyo was one of the three major taxes called Takagakari Sanyaku that were imposed on the direct control territories of the Edo bakufu (Shogunal demesne) during Edo period.

history.name: Mokuyo-kai (Thursday Association)
history.desc: Mokuyo-kai refers to a faction within the Diet of House of Lords (Japan) in the Meiji Period (July 28, 1897 - January 26, 1913, in addition it was established as a group having a legislative bargaining position in the Diet on March 10, 1898).

history.name: Asahi Club
history.desc: Asahi Club is Innai parliamentary group (May 25, 1898 - December 7, 1901) of the House of Peers existing in the Meiji period.

history.name: Kanin-ryu (a linage of court noble of a branch one of the Fujiwara clique)
history.url: history/Kanin-ryu (a linage of court noble of a branch one of the Fujiwara clique).html
history.desc: Kanin-ryu was a linage of kuge (court noble) of a branch of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan including the Sanjo Family, the Saionji Family, or the Tokudaiji family.

history.name: Bunji Imperial Sanction
history.desc: Bunji Imperial Sanction was the imperial sanction in Japan to permit placement and appointment and dismissal of shugo (military governor) and jitoshiki (manager and lord of manor) in various districts given to MINAMOTO no Yoritomo by the Imperial Court on December 28, 1185.

history.name: Hyakuren sho (History book from the Kamakura period)
history.url: history/Hyakuren sho (History book from the Kamakura period).html
history.desc: Hyakuren sho (百錬抄) is a history book in which extracts from diaries of kuge (court nobles) and other records were complied.

history.name: Doeff-Halma Dictionary (a Dutch-Japanese dictionary compiled in the late Edo period)
history.url: history/Doeff-Halma Dictionary (a Dutch-Japanese dictionary compiled in the late Edo period).html
history.desc: Doeff-Halma Dictionary (also referred as Zufu Halma or Dufu Halma) was a Dutch-Japanese dictionary that was compiled in late Edo period.

history.name: Peddler
history.desc: Peddling (Gyosho) is one of retailing industry(service business) where peddlers sell products by moving from customer to customer without having their specific stores.

history.name: Taihei-genpo (the silver coin in ancient Japan)
history.url: history/Taihei-genpo (the silver coin in ancient Japan).html
history.desc: Taihei-genpo refers to the silver coin in ancient times in Japan.

history.name: Sharitsu (law on pardon)
history.desc: Sharitsu is a law on pardon, which was enacted by the Edo Shogunate in 1862 during the last period of the Edo era in Japan.

history.name: Friendship Club
history.desc: The friendship club was established on December 24, 1912 as an Innai (within the House) faction within the House of Peers (Japan) and existed until May 3, 1947 when the Constitution of Japan was promulgated.

history.name: Ishisaji (stone spoon)
history.desc: Ishisaji is a kind of chipped stone tool made of obsidian, shale, chert, etc.

history.name: Ishiyari (stone spear)
history.desc: Ishiyari is a kind of chipped stone tool used as the spearhead.

history.name: Sekkaku (the stone core)
