history.desc: Sekkaku (the stone core) refers to the ore that remains after tearing off the flakes, which usually serve as the raw materials for chipped stone tools.

history.name: Yonaoshi Ikki (Social reform uprisings)
history.desc: Yonaoshi Ikki refers to a rush of uprisings that the Japanese society experienced from the later Edo period to the early Meiji period.

history.name: Point (Sentoki)
history.desc: Point ('sentoki' in Japanese) is a sharp-pointed chipped stone tool.

history.name: Stone tools resembling a knife
history.desc: Stone tools resembling a knife were characteristics to the end period of the Paleolithic period, and they were made by blunting and exfoliating flakes like stone knives (blades) (i.e. Exfoliation was adjusted so that the sharp edge of flake would be partly remained like a knife blade and the rest of the edge would be blunted), and by forming the flakes into a shape similar to modern knives.

history.name: Blade Technique (Sekijin-giho)
history.desc: The blade technique is a technique of removing vertically-long lithic flakes from stone, which emerged during the upper Paleolithic period and characterizes the period.

history.name: Toa-dobunkai (Toa-dobunkai nationalism group)
history.desc: Toa-dobunkai (1898-1946) was a private diplomatic group which used to be in Japan.

history.name: Kani Sotosei
history.desc: Kani Sotosei was the bureaucrats hierarchy system that set the constant suitability relationship between Ikai (Court rank) and government post given to a government official on the Japanese Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Political Merchants
history.desc: Seisho (Political Merchants) refers to businessmen and companies who obtain exclusive economic benefits and guide certain policies to serve their own interests by taking advantage of their connections with politicians and high-ranking government officials.

history.name: The anti-Nobunaga network
history.desc: The anti-Nobunaga network is a commonly used name for the seige around Nobunaga led by Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA; from the end of the Sengoku period to the beginning of the Azuchi-Momoyama period, Nobunaga ODA was an official backing for Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi shogunate, although, in reality, they were conflicted and Yoshiaki established that anti-Nobunaga network.

history.name: Flake
history.desc: Flake is a thin piece of stone removed from ore by percussion.

history.name: Host Rock
history.desc: Host rock (also known as wall rock) is a rock that is used as a base for something.

history.name: Pebble tools
history.desc: Pebble tools are the stone tools made of rude ore that have not been processed.

history.name: Flake stone tool
history.desc: Flake stone tools are made from thin piece of stone (flake) removed from ore (host rock) by percussion.

history.name: Stone spatula
history.desc: A stone spatula is a kind of flake stone tool in a spatula-like shape, and it is considered to be used for cutting trees or bones, tanning animal skins, or maybe digging ground.

history.name: Core stone tools
history.desc: Core stone tools are made from the core part of the stone (known as stone core), which appears after flakes have been removed from ore (country rock).

history.name: Stone plate
history.desc: Stone plate

history.name: Grinding Stones
history.desc: Grinding stones refer to a kind of small stone tools used to grind nuts and seeds mainly chestnut, walnut and acorn into powder in the Jomon period.

history.name: Kubomi-ishi (Hollow Stones)
history.desc: Kubomi-ishi (hollow stones) refers to the stone tools that have a shallow hollow almost in the center of fist-sized round gravel and elliptic gravel.

history.name: Kyokubumasei-sekifu (edge-ground stone axe)
history.desc: Kyokubumasei-sekifu is a edge-ground stone axe which appeared in the early upper Paleolithic period about 30 thousand years ago.

history.name: Meirokusha
history.desc: Meirokusha, which was established in the early Meiji period, was the first Japanese modern academic society for enlightenment.

history.name: Rekki (Small Stone Tools)
history.desc: Rekki refers to the stone tool made of bigger pebbles.

history.name: Meiroku Zasshi
history.desc: Meiroku Zasshi is a bulletin of the Meirokusha (a publishing company).

history.name: the Central Negotiation Committee
history.desc: The Central Negotiation Committee is parliamentary group (April 23, 1892 - March 1, 1893) during Meiji Period.

history.name: Regulation of national bank
history.desc: Regulation of national bank is a Japanese law enacted in 1872.

history.name: The movement to unite for a common purpose
history.url: history/The movement to unite for a common purpose.html
history.desc: The movement to unite for a common purpose refers to a unification movement took place between 1887 and 1889 among factions of the Freedom and People's Rights Movement to prepare for the establishment of the Imperial Diet.

history.name: The subjugation of the Emishi
history.desc: The subjugation of the Emishi means the conquest of the Emishi (later called the Ezo), the indigenous inhabitants in the northern and northeastern parts of ancient Japan, carried out by the imperial court.

history.name: Campaign of the three biggest petitions
history.url: history/Campaign of the three biggest petitions.html
history.desc: The campaign of the three biggest petitions is a political movement caused by petitions ("The three biggest petitions") submitted to Genroin (the Chamber of Elders) (Japan) by Kenkichi KATAOKA in October 1887.

history.name: Arachi no-seki checking station
history.desc: Arachi no-seki was a sekisho (checking station) on the border between Omi Province and Echizen Province.

history.name: Kuichigai Incident
history.desc: Kuichigai Incident was an assassination attempt on Tomomi IWAKURA, the Minister of Right, which occurred in Kuichigaizaka, Akasaka, Tokyo (now Minato Ward, Tokyo) on January 14, 1874.

history.name: Watakushiikusa
history.desc: Watakushiikusa (also called shisen [private warfare]) is a small-scale military/battle conducted in Japan before the early-modern period for Katakiuchi (revenge) or for self-preservation, without an official order such as Daijokanpu (official documents of Daijokan, which is the office of the supreme political leader), senji (imperial decree) or an order from bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Takefu Riot
history.desc: Takefu riot was a rebellion that occurred in Echizen City, Fukui Prefecture in 1870 after the Meiji Restoration.

history.name: Kumon (official document)
history.desc: Kumon was originally a general term for official documents in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), and derived from it, it also meant the government official who dealt with such documents.

history.name: Naikaku-shokken (Official Powers of the Cabinet)
history.desc: Naikaku-shokken (Official Powers of the Cabinet) is a rule that stipulated duties of the Prime Minister and management of the cabinet in Japan.

history.name: Kugen (legal certificate)
history.desc: Kugen refers to a kind of certificate issued in the Japanese nation under the ritsuryo codes to give a privilege to specific persons.

history.name: Konida
history.desc: Konida refers to dachin umakasegi (a job of carrying by daba, packhorse or cow) or vehicles that carry army provisions, ammunition, set-up tools for encampment and so on needed for wars from the medieval period to modern times in Japan, or a troop that directed the above things, also referred to as konidatai.

history.name: Onshi
history.desc: Onshi refers to an action of monarch who gives some goods to his subject to show his gratitude or expectation for the loyalty and contribution dedicated or to be dedicated.

history.name: Rebellion by MINAMOTO no Yoshichika
history.desc: The rebellion by MINAMOTO no Yoshichika was a rebellion which took place in the middle of the Heian period.

history.name: Local tax regulations
history.desc: The local tax regulations were defined as tax items (items of taxation) prefectures can collect and expense items paid by the tax revenue during Japanese Meiji and Taisho periods.

history.name: Kanin (official seal)
history.desc: A Kanin is an official seal given to government officials and offices to prove their social and public status in China and Japan.

history.name: Takashina Clan (the clan of which the first son of Emperor Tenmu, Prince Takechi [Takechi no Miko] was the ancestor)
history.url: history/Takashina Clan (the clan of which the first son of Emperor Tenmu, Prince Takechi [Takechi no Miko] w.html
history.desc: Takashina clan is the clan of which the first son of Emperor Tenmu, Prince Takechi, was the ancestor.

history.name: Hyoro (army provisions)
history.desc: Hyoro is food supply for the army during times of war.

history.name: Train Arson Attack
history.desc: Densha Yakiuchi Jiken (literally Train Arson Attack) was to cause arson to trains and other facilities.

history.name: Yamagata–Lobanov Agreement
history.desc: The Yamagata-Lobanov Agreement was the agreement signed on June 9, 1896 between the empires of Japan and Russia on disputes over their sphere of influence over Korea.

history.name: The Nishi-Rosen Kyotei (Nishi-Rosen Agreement)
history.desc: The Nishi-Rosen Kyotei was the agreement to settle the dispute over the Republic of Korea (the Korean Empire) signed between Empires of Japan and Russia on April 25, 1898.

history.name: Root-Takahira Agreement
history.desc: Root-Takahira Agreement refers to an agreement between the United States and the Empire of Japan signed by the United States Secretary of State Elihu Root and Japanese Ambassador to the United States Kogoro TAKAHIRA on November 30 after negotiations by those two.

history.name: Rakuin (an illegitimate child)
history.desc: Rakuin is an illegitimate child who is not recognized by his or her father as his child.

history.name: Shoshiki
history.desc: Shoshiki was a term used in the Edo period to indicate the price of commodity.

history.name: Ryuketsu
history.desc: Ryuketsu is a place which is supposed to be flourishing in Onmyodo (way of Yin and Yang; occult divination system based on the Taoist theory of the five elements), ancient Taoism, and feng shui.

history.name: Chosen-dera Temple (Korean Temple)
history.desc: Chosen-dera Temple (Korean Temple) refers to the common name of the temples worshipped by korean people living in Japan, particularly, the women.

history.name: Gekan (removal from office)
history.desc: Gekan means that an incumbent government official is dismissed in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Imperial Property
history.desc: "Imperial property" refers to the property of the Imperial family.

history.name: Local Administrative Assemblies
history.desc: Local Administrative Assemblies was the assembly of prefectural governors summoned and established by the Meiji government in 1874.

history.name: Beipu Incident
history.desc: The Beipu Incident was an anti-Japanese incident in Taiwan that occurred during the period of Japanese rule (in Taiwan) and that was instigated by Tsai Ching-Lin, one of the Hakka people.

history.name: Kaisho (the early-modern times)
history.desc: Kaisho literally means a place where a kind of reunion, party, event, assembly or meeting was held.

history.name: Taishimichi (the road where Prince Shotoku took)
history.url: history/Taishimichi (the road where Prince Shotoku took).html
history.desc: Taishimichi refer to Japan's ancient roads that are taken by Prince Shotoku and which have common name.

history.name: Ono Clan (a clan which was active from the early seventh century to the middle of the Heian period)
history.url: history/Ono Clan (a clan which was active from the early seventh century to the middle of the Heian period).html
history.desc: Ono clan was a clan which was active from the early seventh century to the middle of the Heian period.

history.name: Shozei (the rice tax stored in provincial offices' warehouse)
history.url: history/Shozei (the rice tax stored in provincial offices warehouse).html
history.desc: Shozei (Taizei) refers to tokoku (rice grains plucked off the straws, with chaff on) and eito (reaped rice plants holding grains) stored in shoso (public repository) in ryoseikoku (province) under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Shozeicho (balance sheets of tax rice)
history.desc: Shozeicho refers to one of the account books that kokushi (provincial governor) submitted to Daijokan (Grand Council of State) in the ritsuryo system every year, a balance sheet of shozei (the rice tax stored in provincial offices warehouse) in ryoseikoku (province).

history.name: Gekisei
history.desc: Gekisei refers to a system that Kugyo (high court nobles) who were ministers read moshibumi (a general term for a request or petition submitted by a lower authority to a higher) from shoshi (officials), had conferences and gave decisions on them at Geki Cho, an office of Geki (Secretary of the Grand Council of State).

history.name: Yamato Katsuragi Hozan-ki
history.desc: Yamato Katsuragi Hozan-ki (大和葛城宝山記) is a Shinto book written from the point of view of Buddhism, especially Shugendo (Japanese ascetic and shamanistic practice in mountainous sites).

history.name: Battle of Kanegasaki (the period of the Northern and Southern Courts)
history.jp: 金ヶ崎の戦い (南北朝時代)
history.url: history/Battle of Kanegasaki (the period of the Northern and Southern Courts).html
history.desc: The Battle of Kanegasaki, was a battle between the troop of the Southern Court (Japan) led by Yoshisada NITTA who held Kanegasaki-jo Castle in Echizen Province (Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture), and the troop of the Northern Court (Japan) led by Takatsune SHIBA who attacked the castle, from 1336 to 1337 in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

history.name: Rissho Ankoku-ron (Treatise for Spreading Peace Throughout the Country by Establishing the True Teaching)
history.url: history/Rissho Ankoku-ron (Treatise for Spreading Peace Throughout the Country by Establishing the True Teac.html
history.desc: Rissho Ankoku-ron is a treatise written in 1260 by Nichiren, who founded the Nichiren sect of Buddhism, to be submitted to Tokiyori HOJO, a former regent to the shogunate, who was the head of the major lineage of the Hojo family.

history.name: Gakuryo
history.desc: Gakuryo was one of the articles in the ritsuryo codes (legal codes of the Nara and Heian periods).

history.name: Ninki
history.desc: Ninki is a general term for tools that were supposedly used by the Ninja (a secret agent in feudal Japan highly skilled in stealth and secrecy).

history.name: The case of a condemned, who resuscitated after hanging in Ishizuchi Prefecture.
history.jp: 石鐵県死刑囚蘇生事件
history.url: history/The case of a condemned, who resuscitated after hanging in Ishizuchi Prefecture..html
history.desc: In early Meiji Period the incident occurred and a condemned resuscitated after the execution of hanging in Ishizuchi Prefecture.

history.name: Nanto Yakiuchi (the Incident of the Taira clan's army setting fire to the temples in Nanto)
history.url: history/Nanto Yakiuchi (the Incident of the Taira clans army setting fire to the temples in Nanto).html
history.desc: Nanto Yakiuchi is the incident that the Taira clan army led by TAIRA no Shigehira set fire to Buddhist temples in Nara (Nanto) such as Todai-ji Temple and Kofuku-ji Temple by the order of TAIRA no Kiyomori on January 15, 1181.

history.name: Ten-en-chi-hou
history.desc: Ten-en-chi-hou is an ancient Chinese view of the universe which considers the heaven as round and the earth as square.

history.name: The Doyokai
history.desc: The Doyokai (literally "the Saturday Group") was an internal faction within the House of Peers in Japan's National Diet; the Doyokai lasted from the Meiji period into the Taisho period (from December 7, 1901 to November 15, 1919).

history.name: Fukyo
history.desc: 不孝(Fukyo)

history.name: Eejanaika
history.desc: Eejanaika is a social phenomenon observed from the end of the Edo period, August 1867 (表記の変更) to the beginning of the Meiji period, April 1868 (表記の変更), starting from Edo and extending to the Shikoku region with the Tokai and Kinki regions as its centers.

history.name: Multi-capital system
history.desc: The multi-capital system is a system which places plural capitals in one nation.

history.name: Shichitorikoi (Action of demanding compensation)
history.desc: In the medieval Japan, Shichitorikoi was an action of a creditor, who could not receive compensation from a debtor living in a different region, to capture a third person who lived in the same region as the creditor (regardless of whether the person is acquainted with the debtor or not) or to privately confiscate the person's properties as compensation for the debt.

history.name: Sakaya Kaigi (Council of Sake Brewers)
history.desc: Sakaya Kaigi is the brewers' opposition movement against the sake-brewing tax hike, which took place throughout Japan in the early Meiji period.

history.name: Hayatoshi
history.desc: Hayatoshi (Hayato Office) was the institution that belonged to Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards) and later Hyobusho (ministry of military) on the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Kodencho
history.desc: A kodencho was an account book made to report to the central government on the results of koden (research of public paddy fields in a ryoseikoku [province]) by a kodenshi (koden researcher) or a kokushi (provincial governor) sent by the central government under the ritsuryo system in ancient Japan.

history.name: Ihai
history.desc: Ihai is a policy under which the Ritsuryo-seifu Government (the ancient Japanese government of centralized governance) (Imperial court) forced Emishi (northerners), who lived in present-day Tohoku area, to move to Kanto region and to the west of Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu from the 8th to the 9th century.

history.name: Inpu (compilation of seal marks)
history.desc: An inpu is a kind of books on tenkoku (engraving letters on the material of a seal), that mainly introduces mainly inei (impressions of seals) and inkan (names of authors) for the purpose of appreciation and study.

history.name: Jomai
history.desc: Jomai originally means the annual rice tax from Edo bakufu directly controlled land (so-called 'tenryo'), but later, it means the rice stocked by the bakufu or fudai daimyo domain (a domain of a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) as provisions of rice for the army.

history.name: Taigaiko (a concept to pursue a forceful diplomacy)
history.url: history/Taigaiko (a concept to pursue a forceful diplomacy).html
history.desc: Taigaiko was the idea or concept that considered the situation of Japan in the international community as the critical externally, and only the forceful diplomacy including the military force which denies the international cooperation, and values national independence can defuse a crisis.

history.name: Ke (or Ka) (holiday)
history.desc: A ke (or ka) was a holiday given to nobles and government officials under the ritsuryo system.

history.name: Ge (Official Documents)
history.desc: A "ge" was an official document submitted by a lower grade governmental official (hikan) to a higher grade official (shokan) in the ritsuryo sytem (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Hyomashi
history.desc: Hyomashi (Office of Military Horses) was the institution belonged to Hyobusho (ministry of military) on the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) of Japan.

history.name: Omizo jinya (regional government office of the Omizo Domain)
history.url: history/Omizo jinya (regional government office of the Omizo Domain).html
history.desc: Omizo jinya was a regional government office of the Omizo Domain located in Takashimakatsuno, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture (Takashima County, Omi Province).

history.name: Fudoso (a warehouse sealed after being examined of its degree of sealing)
history.url: history/Fudoso (a warehouse sealed after being examined of its degree of sealing).html
history.desc: Fudoso warehouse was a warehouse which was sealed after being examined of its degree of sealing by the provincial governor and the local official after the content of shoso (warehouse) became full in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Fudokoku (rice tax stored in a warehouse called fudoso)
history.url: history/Fudokoku (rice tax stored in a warehouse called fudoso).html
history.desc: Fudokoku is rice in the husk kept in fudoso (a warehouse which was sealed after the regular warehouse became full) put in provinces in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: The Toyo Jiyuto (Oriental Liberal Party)
history.desc: The Toyo Jiyuto (Oriental Liberal Party) was a political party formed by Kentaro OI, a member of the (Meiji) left wing of the Jiyuto (Liberal Party), along with Tokichi TARUI (a former member of the Toyo Shakaito [Oriental Social Party]), Kishichi KOKUBO, Shogo ARAI and other politicians on November 6, 1892.

history.name: The Dai Nihon Kyokai (Society for Greater Japan)
history.url: history/The Dai Nihon Kyokai (Society for Greater Japan).html
history.desc: The Dai Nihon Kyokai (Society for Greater Japan) was a political organization (October 1 － December 29, 1893) that was formed in the Meiji period with the aim of gathering together hard-liners on foreign nations.

history.name: Sen-ryo-bako (literally, a box to store 1000 ryo; a box to store a lot of money during the Edo period)
history.url: history/Sen-ryo-bako (literally, a box to store 1000 ryo; a box to store a lot of money during the Edo perio.html
history.desc: Sen-ryo-bako was a box exclusively used to store a large amount of koban (former Japanese oval gold coin) during the Edo period.

history.name: The Dong Du Movement
history.desc: The Dong Du Movement (Toyu Undo or Donzu Undo in Japanese: Phong trào Đông Du in Vietnamese) was an independence movement that started in Vietnam at the end of the 19th century.

history.name: Doyoso (public repository to store rice tax, which were allowed to be consumed, in ancient ritsuryo system)
history.url: history/Doyoso (public repository to store rice tax, which were allowed to be consumed, in ancient ritsuryo .html
history.desc: Doyoso is a shoso (public repository) to store doyo, which was shozei (rice tax) allowed to be consumed, in ancient ritsuryosei (system of centralized governance).

history.name: Shuki-daiban (vermilion-lacquered household goods that were the Fujiwara clan's treasures)
history.url: history/Shuki-daiban (vermilion-lacquered household goods that were the Fujiwara clans treasures).html
history.desc: Shuki-daiban are vermilion-lacquered household goods succeeded as the Fujiwara clan's treasures by successive Toshi choja (head of the Fujiwara clan).

history.name: Sacchodo (a generic name of Satsuma Domain, Choshu Domain, and Tosa Domain)
history.url: history/Sacchodo (a generic name of Satsuma Domain, Choshu Domain, and Tosa Domain).html
history.desc: Sacchodo was called 'Yuhan' (powerfull domain) in the end of Edo period, and produced many patriotic samurais, and a generic name of 'Royal three Domains,' Satsuma Domain, Choshu Domain, and Tosa Domain which were the of the Meiji Restoration, or a generic name of the patriotic Samurais from these three Domains.

history.name: Yamato Eikyo War
history.desc: Yamato Eikyo War occurred in Yamato Province in 1429, in the Muromachi period.

history.name: Problem of heir of Shogun
history.desc: The problem of heir of Shogun means a political strife of selection of the next Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo) (Shogun) of the bakufu.

history.name: Osso (petition without legal procedures; retrial regulation)
history.url: history/Osso (petition without legal procedures; retrial regulation).html
history.desc: An osso referred to a suit asking for retrial and so on without taking regular judicial proceedings.

history.name: The Gushikami restraint/murder case
history.desc: The Gushikami restraint/murder case was a lynch murder case that occurred in Gushikami magiri (currently Yaese town), Shimajiri gun, Okinawa Prefecture on May 18, 1907.

history.name: Kokuzekomoku (break a national policy down and analyze it both generally and in detail)
history.url: history/Kokuzekomoku (break a national policy down and analyze it both generally and in detail).html
history.desc: Kokuzekomoku was a petition that Hirobumi ITO who was a governor of Hyogo Prefecture submitted it with three executives of Prefecture (Nobuyuki NAKAJIMA, Mitsuaki TANAKA, Noriyuki GA) and Finance officer/ judge, Munemitsu MUTSU who was in Osaka.

history.name: Rusu-seifu (government while heads of government are away)
history.url: history/Rusu-seifu (government while heads of government are away).html
history.desc: Rusu-seifu refers to the Establishment organized to protect the nation in early Meiji Period while Iwakura Mission, which consisted of leaders of the Meiji government, was visiting Europe and America (December 23, 1871 - September 13, 1873).

history.name: Takanawa negotiation
history.desc: The Takanawa negotiation was a conference held by the the head of the Meiji Government and the ambassadors of England, France, United States of America, Italy, and Germany, in Takanawa, Tokyo Prefecture on August 19, 1869.

history.name: Gold and silver bimetallism
history.desc: The gold and silver bimetallism refers to a currency system where both gold and silver coins are designated as standard money; freedom of minting, importing and exporting such money is maintained; and fixed exchange ratio between gold and silver is maintained

history.name: Kaiseigakari (System reformation department)
history.desc: Kaiseigakari is a department set in Minbusho (Ministry of Popular Affairs) on December 20, 1869.

history.name: Shokon no matsuri (Soul summoning rite)
history.desc: Shokon no matsuri is a ritual practiced by Japanese Onmyodo and Chinese Taoism.

history.name: Asuka-Fujiwara: Archaeological sites of Japan's Ancient Capitals and Related Properties
history.jp: 飛鳥・藤原の宮都とその関連資産群
history.url: history/Asuka-Fujiwara Archaeological sites of Japans Ancient Capitals and Related Properties.html
history.desc: Asuka-Fujiwara: Archaeological sites of Japan's Ancient Capitals and Related Properties is the generic term of archaeological sites in Asuka, Nara Prefecture and has been accepted to the World Heritage (cultural heritage) Tentative List of United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

history.name: The Irtysh surrender incident
history.jp: イルティッシュ号投降事件
history.desc: The Irtysh surrender incident is the incident in which the crew of a special service vessel of the Russian Baltic Fleet called the Irtysh, which had been damaged in the Battle of Tsushima and stalled at sea, surrendered in Waki district, Tsuno village, Naka County (present-day Waki town, Gotsu City), Shimane Prefecture at about 2:00 pm on May 28, 1905.

history.name: Shihai monjo
history.desc: Shihai monjo refers to the monjo (ancient document) written on washi (Japanese paper) before another monjo was then written on the other side of that same piece of paper.

history.name: Shosoin monjo
history.desc: Shosoin monjo refers to document collections kept in Todai-ji Temple Shosoin, which are mainly created by the Sutra copying office at Todai-ji Temple.

history.name: Peasant revolts against the land-tax reform
history.url: history/Peasant revolts against the land-tax reform.html
history.desc: Peasant revolts against the land-tax reform refer to the uprisings by peasants to oppose to the land-tax reform that had been promoted by the Meiji Government since 1873 (we should note that many of the revolts were legal conflicts, as recent studies show).

history.name: Kokyu Junishi
history.desc: The Kokyu junishi is an organization of 宮人(kunin/kyujin or court ladies, later called nyokan) prescribed in the Japanese ritsuryo system.

history.name: Ekitei-Shi (government office in charge of transportation and communication)
history.url: history/Ekitei-Shi (government office in charge of transportation and communication).html
history.desc: Ekitei-Shi is a government office in charge of transportation and communication, formed on June 11, 1868.

history.name: Tenma
history.desc: A tenma refers to a transportation system from ancient times to the early modern times in Japan that carried envoys or goods, or to a horse used.

history.name: The Secretariat of Land-Tax Reform
history.desc: The Secretariat of Land-Tax Reform was a bureau established (and functioned) in the Meiji Government from March 24, 1875 to June 30, 1881.

history.name: Eiseiroku
history.desc: Eiseiroku (a type of premium) was the highest ranked Shotenroku (premium) in early Meiji era, which was awarded to ones with merits for their contribution to the Boshin War and the Restoration of Imperial Rule.

history.name: Tojo (imperial city) System (system for city planning)
history.url: history/Tojo (imperial city) System (system for city planning).html
history.desc: Tojo system is a way of city planning developed in the East Asia cultural sphere by absorbing the influence of Chinese imperial cities.

history.name: Zanpatsu Datto Rei
history.desc: Zanpatsu Datto Rei is an edict of the Grand Council of State submitted by Meiji government in September 23, 1871.

history.name: Okuma Finance
history.desc: Okuma finance refers to the financial policy promoted by Shigenobu OKUMA, the Minister of the Treasury (concurrently filled a post of Councilor) in early Meiji Period.

history.name: Gyojisho
history.desc: The Gyojisho came into existence in the Daijoe (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor) and so on in about the middle ninth century, gradually grew into a functionality-oriented project team in various regular/temporal rites and festivals, and dealt with general affairs of rites and festivals including supplying necessary goods.

history.name: Kimu Rokujo (Six articles about very important affairs of State)
history.url: history/Kimu Rokujo (Six articles about very important affairs of State).html
history.desc: Kimu Rokujo is the agreement between the Emperor Meiji and Hirobumi ITO (Prime Minister and Minister of the Imperial Households), who represented the cabinet (Japan) in September 7, 1886.

history.name: Koshogumi (page corps)
history.desc: Koshogumi (page corps) was an organization in the Edo bakufu and one of the bankata which took charge in the military affairs.

history.name: Kaechi
history.desc: Kaechi is a term used for the switching or transfer of control over any two or more plots of land.

history.name: Europeanism
history.desc: Europeanism is a policy (a policy of Europeanization) which the Meiji Government implemented to make an impression on Western countries by modernizing Japan, that is to say, by Europeanizing Japanese things, regulations, folkways, and customs in Japan in 1880s, and an active movement of thought and folkways of the times related to the policy.

history.name: Treaty of Amity and Commerce between Japan and Austria
history.jp: 日墺修好通商航海条約
history.url: history/Treaty of Amity and Commerce between Japan and Austria.html
history.desc: The Japan-Austria Treaty of Amity and Commerce was an agreement concluded between Japan and Austria/Hungarian empire on October 18, 1869.

history.name: Choya Gunsai
history.desc: Choya gunsai was edited by MIYOSHI no Tameyasu, San hakase (Doctor of Numbers), who classified monjo (written materials) n the Heian period such as prose and poetry, imperial decrees, official documents from the Dajokan (Great Council of State).

history.name: Mizukae nisoku
history.desc: The term "mizukae nisoku (drainage laborers)" refers to those mining laborers engaged in removing the water that collects in mines and pumping it outside the mine.

history.name: The Franco-Japanese treaty
history.desc: The Franco-Japanese treaty is a treaty concluded in Paris between Japan and France on June 10, 1907.

history.name: The Manchuria Corrective Treaty (also known as the Peking Treaty of 1905)
history.url: history/The Manchuria Corrective Treaty (also known as the Peking Treaty of 1905).html
history.desc: The Manchuria Corrective Treaty, a treaty between Japan and the Qing dynasty, was concluded on December 22, 1905, in Beijing.

history.name: Yogaku Koyo (Principles of Early Education)
history.desc: "Yogaku Koyo" (Principles of Early Education) is the 'shushin' (moral education) book compiled by Nagazane Motoda, lecturer in the Imperial Household, under the command of Meiji Emperor and distributed by the Department of the Imperial Household on December 2, in 1882.

history.name: Village Community
history.desc: The village community mainly means the social structure in a village.

history.name: Risshisha-no-Goku (Imprisonment of the Risshisha [Self-help Society])
history.desc: The imprisonment of the Risshisha is an incident in which the Yuzo HAYASHI and Taku OE, who were members of the Risshisha (the political society) were thought to form a plot in Kochi Prefecture with Munemitsu MUTSU, a councilor of the senate, to raise an army against the central government during the Satsuma Rebellion (Satswuma War) in 1877.

history.name: Our Enemy is in the Honno-ji Temple
history.url: history/Our Enemy is in the Honno-ji Temple.html
history.desc: "Our Enemy is in the Honno-ji Temple" is allegedly the phrase uttered by Mitsuhide AKECHI, busho (Japanese military commander) in the Warring States period, during the Honnoji Incident.

history.name: Jodai
history.desc: Jodai is one of the periodizations in the history of Japan.

history.name: Daineiji no hen (the revolt of Daineiji)
history.url: history/Daineiji no hen (the revolt of Daineiji).html
history.desc: Daineiji no hen (the revolt of Daineiji) is a coup happened between September 28 to September 30, 1551.

history.name: Choji-ya
history.desc: Choji-ya (丁子屋) is one of the oldest yago (trade name), which is confirmed to have already existed in the Edo period.

history.name: Kokumin Domeikai (People's Alliance Society)
history.desc: Kokumin Domeikai is the political society organized in the Meiji period, in September, 1900.

history.name: The Rito (Party of Officials)
history.desc: The Rito party was a political party that supported the Meiji government at an early Imperial Diet during the mid-Meiji period.

history.name: Ko Roppa (the hard-line six parties)
history.desc: The Ko Roppa (the hard-line six parties) was a pro-nationalistic federation of six political parties that advocated a strong foreign policy in 1890s.

history.name: Minto (literally, the people's party)
history.desc: Minto is the general term of the political parties such as the Liberal Party (in the Meiji period) and the Constitutional Progressive Party and so on which promoted the Movement for Democratic Rights in the Meiji Period.

history.name: Teikokuzaiseikakushin kai (conference on reform of imperial financial affairs)
history.url: history/Teikokuzaiseikakushin kai (conference on reform of imperial financial affairs).html
history.desc: Teikokuzaiseikakushin kai was a political group established in the middle of the Meiji Period.

history.name: Minryoku-Kyuyou and Seihi-Setsugen (Rest for Financial Resources of People and Reduction of Government Expenses)
history.url: history/Minryoku-Kyuyou and Seihi-Setsugen (Rest for Financial Resources of People and Reduction of Governme.html
history.desc: Minryoku-Kyuyou and Seihi-Setsugen referred to the policy pledge of Minto (general term of the political parties such as the Liberal Party and Progressive Party that conflicted with a han-dominated government when the Imperial Diet was inaugurated) in early the Imperial Diet of the Meiji Period.

history.name: Mimana Nihon-fu (Japanese government in Mimana)
history.desc: Mimana Nihon-fu or Yamato no Mikotomochi is the governing institution of Wakoku (Japan) which is said to have been located in Mimana in the southern area of the Korean Peninsula in ancient times.

history.name: Sakite-gumi
history.desc: Sakite-gumi was one of military systems in the Edo bakufu.

history.name: Japanese Envoys to Tamna (Korean kingdom which ruled Jeju Island in ancient times)
history.url: history/Japanese Envoys to Tamna (Korean kingdom which ruled Jeju Island in ancient times).html
history.desc: Japanese Envoys to Tamna was dispatched to Tamna from Japan (Wakoku).

history.name: Kanjosho
history.desc: Kanjosho is the name of an office or a governing organization established for finance and civil administration in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), in each domain and at each hatamoto (direct retainers of the Edo bakufu).

history.name: The Battle of Sattatoge (the period of the Northern and Southern Courts)
history.jp: 薩た峠の戦い (南北朝時代)
history.url: history/The Battle of Sattatoge (the period of the Northern and Southern Courts).html
history.desc: The Battle of Sattatoge (also referred to as the Battle of Mt. Satta) was a battle fought between the troops of Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA at Sattatoge (Satta-toge Pass) in Suruga Province (Shimizu Ward, Shizuoka City, Shizuoka Prefecture) in December 1351, during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

history.name: Sangen (three major checkpoints)
history.desc: Sangen (or Sankan) is a general term for the three important sekisho (a checkpoint) out of which were established in and around Kinai (five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto) in ancient Japan.

history.name: Jichi to (Autonomy Party)
history.desc: Jichi To was the idea of new political party formed by local renown men such as mayors of towns and villages promoted by Kaoru INOUE from 1888 to 1889 but failed in the end.

history.name: Nihon Seito Osyoku Jiken (Corruption Scandal of Dai-Nippon Sugar Co., Ltd.)
history.url: history/Nihon Seito Osyoku Jiken (Corruption Scandal of Dai-Nippon Sugar Co., Ltd.).html
history.desc: Nihon Seito Oshoku Jiken refers to a bribery scandal in the Meiji Period in which the board members of Nihon Seito in Taiwan conspired to bribe members of the House of Representatives with the aim of extending an effective period of a law.

history.name: The Sino-Japanese Treaty of Commerce and Navigation (The Treaty of Commerce and Navigation between Japan and China)
history.url: history/The Sino-Japanese Treaty of Commerce and Navigation (The Treaty of Commerce and Navigation between J.html
history.desc: The Sino-Japanese Treaty of Commerce and Navigation is the treaty concluded between Japan and Qing Dynasty in Beijing City on July 21, 1896.

history.name: Ogurihangan
history.desc: Ogurihangan is a legendary figure and also refers to tales of this person as a protagonist that have been handed down since the Japanese medieval period.

history.name: The Rikken Kakushinto (Constitutional Renovation Party)
history.desc: The Rikken Kakushinto (Constitutional Renovation Party) was a political party in the middle of the Meiji period (May 9, 1894－February 24, 1896).

history.name: Shihei seiri (paper money readjustment)
history.desc: Shihei seiri (paper money readjustment) was a policy of seeking to recover the public trust in the currency system and the credit system by readjusting and reducing the amount of the notes that were issued by the Meiji government and the National Bank (in the Meiji period) and first went into circulation in the early Meiji period, and by converting the notes into the convertible paper money issued by the Bank of Japan.

history.name: Dokyo (Taoism)
history.desc: Dokyo is one of the Sankyo, (Japanese word translates as "three religions"), the three great religions in China, including Confucianism, Chinese Buddhism and Dokyo.

history.name: Minbusho-satsu
history.desc: Minbusho-satsu is a bank note issued by the Minbusho (Ministry of Popular Affairs) of the Meiji government from November 15, 1869 to the next year.

history.name: Mushuku (homeless wanderer)
history.desc: Mushuku means people in the Edo period whose names were excluded from Shumon-Ninbetsu-Aratame-Cho (The Village People Register of Religious Faith and Relationship) which is the equivalent of today's family register.

history.name: Miyoshi's government
history.desc: Miyoshi's government refers to a Japanese military government that existed from 1549 through 1568.

history.name: Hata bugyo (flag magistrate)
history.desc: Hata bugyo (flag magistrate) was one of organizations in Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Shichu-hikimawashi
history.desc: Shichu-hikimawashi was a kind of punishment in the Edo period, whereby a criminal was brought through the streets in public on horseback to the execution ground, together with 'sutefuda' (official notice board stating the details about the criminal and the crime).

history.name: Monouri
history.desc: Monouri is a street vendor who sells foods or goods, serves as a repairman, buys old things or wastes, or exchanges these things for some goods, traveling by attracting people with musical instruments and distinctive calls.

history.name: Hosokawa's Government (Sengoku Period)
history.desc: Hosokawa's government was a Japanese military government in the Sengoku period which existed from 1493 through 1549.

history.name: The Battle of Sakaiura
history.desc: The Battle of Sakaiura is a battle fought in Sakaiura, Izumi Province (present-day Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture).

history.name: The Battle of Ishizu
history.desc: The Battle of Ishizu was fought on June 10, 1338, during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), in Ishizu of Sakaiura, Izumi Province (areas in and around present-day Sakai City, Osaka Prefecture) between Akiie KITABATAKE, who supported the Southern Court, and KO no Moronao, who supported the Northern Court.

history.name: Mashita Domain
history.desc: Mashita Domain was located in Mashita, Shimashimo County, Settsu Province (present Mishima, Settsu City, Osaka Prefecture).

history.name: The faction of Saiwai-club
history.desc: The faction of Saiwai-club was a union of medium and small parliamentary factions in the House of Peers (Japan) led by the Tea Party group from the late Meiji period to the early Showa period.

history.name: Mutsu diplomacy
history.desc: Mutsu diplomacy means a foreign policy of a Minister of Foreign Affairs Munemitsu MUTSU under the Second Ito cabinet in the Middle Meiji Period.

history.name: Ote club
history.desc: Ote club was a political association during the mid-Meiji Period (October 20, 1894 - February 24, 1896).

history.name: The Ane-gawa River Earthquake
history.desc: The Ane-gawa River Earthquake occurred in August 14, 1909 at 3:31pm with its seismic center near Ane-gawa River in the North East part in Shiga Prefecture (at latitude 35.4 degrees north and longitude 136.3 degrees east.)

history.name: Kokuyaku Kenpo
history.desc: Kokuyaku Constitution defined laws that were formulated by representatives of the people and approved by the ruler (in Japan's case it would be the Emperor) and this procedure served as a sort of promise between the ruler and his people.

history.name: The Sawakai
history.desc: The Sawakai (literally, the Tea Party) was an internal faction within the House of Peers in Japan's National Diet, which was formed under the Meiji Constitution.

history.name: Kinroku Kosai
history.desc: Kinroku Kosai was the public bond issued for people in the class below aristocrats in compensation for the abolition of the Roku-rewarding system after the Meiji Restoration.

history.name: Mizugumo (water spider, a water-crossing device used by ninja)
history.url: history/Mizugumo (water spider, a water-crossing device used by ninja).html
history.desc: Mizugumo (literally, water spider) was one of the tools used by Ninja for crossing waters, such as moat or river.

history.name: Kanbun-inchi
history.desc: Kanbun-inchi was a law established through a series of documents, namely ryochi-hanmono (a shogunal letter of authorization for the possesion of and ruling over a fief), shuinjo (shogunal letters with a red seal) and ryochi-mokuroku (a document supplementing ryoci-hanmono indicating the details of a fief) which were simaltaneously issued by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) throughout the country on April 5, fourth year of the Kanbun era in the old calendar (April 30, 1664).

history.name: the Sino-Japanese Agreement
history.desc: The Sino-Japanese Agreement was the treaty concluded between Japan and the Qing Dynasty which ruled China.

history.name: Maria Luz Incident
history.desc: The Maria Luz Incident is an incident in which the Japanese government freed the Qing laborers the Peruvian ship "Maria Luz" harbored in Yokohama Port in 1872, on the ground that they were treated as slaves.

history.name: Gaertner Cultivation Treaty Incident
history.jp: ガルトネル開墾条約事件
history.desc: Gaertner Cultivation Treaty Incident or Gaertner Incident is a diplomatic incident that occurred over the cultivated land in Nanae Town in the first year of Meiji period.

history.name: Hatamoto-yoriaiseki (a family rank of high-ranking hatamoto, direct vassal of the shogun)
history.url: history/Hatamoto-yoriaiseki (a family rank of high-ranking hatamoto, direct vassal of the shogun).html
history.desc: Hatamoto-yoriaiseki was kakaku (family status) of high-ranking hatamoto with income of 3,000 koku or greater without official appointment, or retirees (known as yakuyoriai) who possessed social standing higher than hoi (those with the rank who wore clothes that did not bear family crests) in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: The movement to create Aimi Prefecture.
history.url: history/The movement to create Aimi Prefecture..html
history.desc: The movement to create Aimi Prefecture was a movement that people requested to create a new prefecture, and the movement was centered in Yonago City, Tottori Prefecture from 1890 to 1891.

history.name: Election interference
history.desc: Election interference means interference to election made by ruling party to eliminate their opponents.

history.name: Dajokan-satsu (Dajokan Bills)
history.desc: Dajokan bills are paper currency issued by the Meiji government from May 1868 until June 1868.

history.name: Bakufu rikugun (bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun] army)
history.url: history/Bakufu rikugun (bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun] army).html
history.desc: Bakufu rikugun is a military organization with western-style armaments which was organized by Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in the Edo Period to accomplish battles on land as a mission.

history.name: The Usei-kai
history.desc: The Usei-kai, which lasted for three days, from June 17th (Monday) to June 19th (Wednesday), 1907, is the name given to an evening banquet held by Kinmochi SAIONJI, then prime minister, at his private residence in Kandasurugadai, to which he invited various Japanese literati.

history.name: Sydney incident
history.desc: This incident occurred between Japan and France during The Sino-Japanese War

history.name: Meiji Tsuho
history.desc: Meiji Tsuho are governmental bills (non-convertible paper money) issued at the beginning of the Meiji period.

history.name: Jun fudai daimyo (quasi fudai daimyo)
history.desc: A quasi fudai daimyo refers to some tozama daimyo (outsider to the ruler) clans, who became treated as fudai daimyo clans (relative or very close to the ruler), mainly in regards to the blood relations to the ruling family of the Edo period in Japan, mainly because of their the clans' achievement over the time.

history.name: Fudaraku-tokai (Crossing the sea to fudaraku [or Potalaka; holy sites associated with Kannon, Deity of Mercy])
history.url: history/Fudaraku-tokai (Crossing the sea to fudaraku [or Potalaka; holy sites associated with Kannon, Deity .html
history.desc: Fudaraku-tokai is a form of the ascetic practice of sacrifice performed in medieval Japan.

history.name: Shinobi-monomi
history.desc: Shinobi-monomi is a way of patrolling during the Sengoku period where a person hides in fields and mountains and searches for the enemy's situation in the battle field.

history.name: Daizenshiki (Office of the Palace Table)
history.desc: Daizenshiki was a government office belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Omi-no-kuni Fudoki
history.desc: Omi-no-kuni Fudoki is a fudoki (Description of regional climate, culture, etc.) of the Omi Province.

history.name: Honke-matsuke-ronso (disputes between head family and branch family)
history.url: history/Honke-matsuke-ronso (disputes between head family and branch family).html
history.desc: A Honke-matsuke-ronso was a dispute between a head family and a branch family of a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) family (particularly early modern daimyo) concerning social standing during the Edo period.

history.name: Meiji Noho (Meiji agricultural methods)
history.desc: Meiji Noho is the general term of accumulation and systemization of the conventional agricultural techniques represented by records on agriculture, as opposed to modern agriculture.

history.name: Uprising of the Hayato People (an ancient tribe in Kyushu)
history.url: history/Uprising of the Hayato People (an ancient tribe in Kyushu).html
history.desc: Uprising of the Hayato people was organized by the Hayato in southern Kyushu in 720 to rebel against the Yamato sovereignty.

history.name: Tonomo no Tsukasa (Palace Equipment and Upkeep Office)
history.url: history/Tonomo no Tsukasa (Palace Equipment and Upkeep Office).html
history.desc: Tonomo no tsukasa was one of the kokyu junishi (twelve offices belonging to kokyu, empress's residence).

history.name: Kushiki-ryo (the law concerning documentary forms of state affairs, contained in the Yoro Code) (a part of the Ritsuryo law system)
history.url: history/Kushiki-ryo (the law concerning documentary forms of state affairs, contained in the Yoro Code) (a p.html
history.desc: "Kushiki-ryo" was one of compilations of ryo (administrative laws in the Ritsuryo law system).

history.name: Hatamoto-satsu (a local currency during the Edo period)
history.url: history/Hatamoto-satsu (a local currency during the Edo period).html
history.desc: Hatamoto-satsu was the paper money that a hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]) who possessed his or her own territory in the Edo period issued independently in his or her own territory.

history.name: The battle of Kumeda
history.desc: The battle of Kumeda was a battle that took place in Japan in which Takamasa HATAKEYAMA attacked Yoshitaka MIYOSHI who lined up around Kumeda-dera Temple (present Kishiwada City, Osaka Prefecture) in Yagi-mura, Izumi Province (Osaka) on March 5, 1562.

history.name: Yayoi period
history.desc: Yayoi period is one of periodizations in the Japanese Archipelago excluding Hokkaido and Okinawa Islands.

history.name: Maruko Clan
history.desc: Maruko (or Mariko) clan is one of the clans of the ancient Japan.

history.name: Santei Ritsuryo Code
history.desc: Santei Ritsuryo Code was a ritsuryo code compiled by Minister of the Right, KIBI no Makibi, YAMATO no Nagaoka and so on in 769.

history.name: Joshu Daimyo (governors of castles)
history.desc: Joshu daimyo (daimyo who is allowed to live in a castle) is a social status in the early-modern times of the Edo period, and refers to a daimyo, who was allowed to have a castle as his residence in his kunimoto (hometown), among Daimyo families (feudal lord families) classified according to their resident provinces and resident castles into five ranks: kokushu (landed daimyos), jun (associate) kokushu, joshu (lord of a castle), joshukaku (joshu class), mujo (without a castle) (jinya [regional government office]).

history.name: Jifuku (Clothes of the Season)
history.desc: "Jifuku" means the clothes, or allocations of these clothes, bestowed by the Imperial Court to the Emperor's family members and their retainers in spring and autumn or in summer and winter, every year.

history.name: Hotobun (formal response speech to imperial rescript) Incident
history.url: history/Hotobun (formal response speech to imperial rescript) Incident.html
history.desc: The Hotobun Incident was an incident which occurred in 1903, as a chairman of the House of Representatives, Hironaka KONO read impeachment of the First Taro KATSURA Cabinet in Hotobun (formal response speech) to the imperial rescript at the opening of the Diet, and this led to the dissolution of the House of Representatives in the end.

history.name: Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei (National paper currency)
history.desc: Kokuritsu Ginko Shihei was paper currency issued by the National Bank in the early Meiji Period.

history.name: Kobu-ochoku juhakka-jo (Eighteen articles of Imperial court and shogunate legislation made by an Imperial order)
history.jp: 公武法制応勅十八箇条
history.url: history/Kobu-ochoku juhakka-jo (Eighteen articles of Imperial court and shogunate legislation made by an Imp.html
history.desc: Kobu-ochoku juhakka-jo was the name for eighteen articles which were said to be issued in September 1615 by Ieyasu TOKUGAWA who received an imperial order from Emperor Gomizunoo to display in Shishin den inside the Imperial palace.

history.name: Jogan-kyaku Code
history.desc: Also, changes were made by deleting the laws of which some parts were not used and the specific phrases which modified the laws.

history.name: Naii
history.desc: Naii were the ranks that formed the core of the Ikai (court ranks) of the Ritsuryo Code in Japan.

history.name: Sanyo-kai (Three-day-a-week Group)
history.desc: Sanyo-kai is a parliamentary group of the House of Peers (Japan) in the Meiji period (March 24, 1891-February 20, 1899).

history.name: Konin-Kyaku
history.desc: The Konin-Kyaku was a compilation of kyakushiki (penal and administrative law and their amendments) that was compiled and enforced towards the beginning of the Heian Period.

history.name: Konin-shiki (Supplementary laws)
history.desc: The Konin-shiki was a compilation of laws that were compiled and enforced from the early Heian Period.

history.name: Shokage/Seikage (vacation request form)
history.desc: Shokage/Seikage was a request form for leave in style of ''ge'' (official document), which the government officials under the ritsuryo system of ancient Japan submitted to the chief priests of Shinto shrines (Guji) they belonged to.

history.name: The Mannyaku-yama incident
history.desc: The Mannyaku-yama incident was the incident in which a dispute concerning a pine tree in the Kume-mura village in Suo Province caused a territory boundary-related dispute, further developing to the abolishment of the Tokuyama clan in 1715.

history.name: Jogan-shiki Code
history.desc: Jogan-shiki Code was a Kyakushiki code (amendments and enforcement regulations of the Ritsuryo Code) that was compiled and enforced in the early Heian period.

history.name: Gakunodo
history.desc: Gakunodo is a name for a facility inside an armed camp during the Sengoku period.

history.name: Miya-ichi (the market in the Imperial court)
history.url: history/Miya-ichi (the market in the Imperial court).html
history.desc: Miya-ichi was a market provided in the Imperial court in the ancient Japan that imitated the Chinese system.

history.name: Daijokan-so (Daijokan's Report to the Emperor)
history.desc: "Daijokan-so" meant for Daijokan (the Grand Council of State) to submit its reports to the Emperor, or the relevant reports, which were operative within the framework of Ritsuryo system (a centralized government system under the Ritsuryo Code).

history.name: Social Democratic Party (Japan, 1901) (Shakai minshuto)
history.desc: The Shakai minshuto is the first socialist party in Japan, which was formed in 1901.

history.name: Industry Association Act
history.desc: Industry Association Act was the Japanese law which existed before.

history.name: Empire Agricultural Association
history.desc: Empire Agricultural Association refers to the central agricultural administration organization approved in 1910.

history.name: Socialism Society
history.desc: Socialism Society was a socialism group in the Meiji Period.

history.name: Japan Socialist Party (1906, Nihon Shakaito)
history.desc: The Nihon Shakaito is a political party in the Meiji Period.

history.name: Geba (dismounting a horse as a manner)
history.url: history/Geba (dismounting a horse as a manner).html
history.desc: "Geba" means to dismount one's horse in order to salute in front of nobles, in the precincts of shrines and temples, or before entering a castle.

history.name: Tenka bushin (nationwide construction projects)
history.desc: Tenka bushin was a type of public works projects which the Edo bakufu (shogunate) ordered daimyo throughout Japan to perform.

history.name: Miho Naval Air Corps
history.desc: Miho Naval Air Corps was one of the troops and educational institutions of the Imerpial Japanese Navy.

history.name: Tsuge no Kuni no Miyatsuko
history.desc: Tsuge no Kuni no Miyatsuko (also called 'Tsuge Kokuzo') was a Kuni no miyatsuko (the head of a local government) who ruled the northern-east of Yamato Province.

history.name: Yamato no Kuni no Miyatsuko
history.desc: Yamato no Kuni no Miyatsuko (also called 'Yamato Kokuzo') was a Kuni no Miyatsuko (the head of a local government) who ruled over the center of Yamato Province.

history.name: Kazuraki no Kuni no Miyatsuko
history.desc: Kazuraki no Kuni no Miyatsuko (also called 'Kazuraki Kokuzo', 'Katsuragi no Kuni no Miyatsuko', or 'Katsuragi Kokuzo') was a Kuni no Miyatsuko (the head of a local government) who ruled over the southern-west of Yamato Province.

history.name: Ekirei
history.desc: Ekirei is a bell provided by the Imperial Court to government officials who traveled on official business, under the ritsuryo system of ancient Japan.

history.name: Horanomiya (detached palace)
history.desc: Horanomiya was an Imperial Palace which Emperor Junnin built in Omi Province in Nara period, which was placed as 'Hokukyo' in the system of multi-capital of Heijo-kyo (the ancient capital of Japan in current Nara).

history.name: Shokokumaki
history.desc: Shokokumaki is a farm developed and controlled by Hyobusho (ministry of military) in ancient Japan, which mainly provided war-horses, horses presented to nobles and ekiden (ekiba (horses for transportation of official travelers) and post horse).

history.name: Syakkonichi (Shiyakukonichi)
history.desc: Syakkonichi (Siyakukonichi) is the day ruled by Hachigokusotsushin (Hachigokusosshin) of onmyodo (way of IN and Yang), and thought to be the bad luck day for kuji (public duties), suit and contract.

history.name: Kingyokushochusho (The book of treasure in the hand)
history.url: history/Kingyokushochusho (The book of treasure in the hand).html
history.desc: Kingyokushochusho is a law book written by NAKAHARA no Norizumi (Norizumi NAKAHARA) in the end of the Kamakura Period.

history.name: Saibanshiyosho
history.desc: Saibanshiyosho is a law book compiled by SAKANOUE no Akimoto on the Imperial command of the retired Emperor Gotoba in 1207, the beginning of the Kamakura period.

history.name: Myobo kanmon
history.desc: Myobo kanmon is kanmon (report) prepared by scholars (Myobo-ke) of Myobodo (study of Codes) including Myobo hakase to respond to consultation.

history.name: Kangakukigen
history.desc: Kangakukigen is a history book of the study of the Chinese classics written by Sueyasu IJICHI of Satsuma domain in the late Edo Period.

history.name: Gakumongenryu (The Origin of Learning)
history.desc: "Gakumongenryu" is a history book of the study of Chinese classics written by Shiso NABA (Rodo NABA, NABA is also pronounced NAWA) in the middle of the Edo Period.

history.name: Fu
history.desc: Fu is an official document used by government officials in the upper grade to give a command to those in the lower grade under the ritsuryo system.

history.name: Omi no kuninomiyatsuko
history.desc: Omi no kuninomiyatsuko (Omi kokuzo) was the kuninomiyatsuko (kokuzo: the head of a local government) who governed the western part of Omi Province (the west coast of Lake Biwa).

history.name: Yasu no kuninomiyatsuko
history.desc: Yasu no kuninomiyatsuko (Yasu kokuzo) was the Kuninomiyatsuko (kokuzo: the head of a local government) who governed the eastern part of Omi Province (the east coast of Lake Biwa).

history.name: Shinzei
history.desc: Shinzei is originally denso (rice field tax) collected from Jinko (the administrative households that was considered as belonging to deities) of specific shrines, stored and used for religious services and repair of the shrine under the ritsuryo system of ancient Japan.

history.name: NUKATA no Kunimiyatsuko
history.desc: NUKATA no Kunimiyatsuko (aka. Kokuzo NUKATA) was the leading local family that ruled the western part of Mino Province (or the eastern part of Omi Province) in ancient Japan.

history.name: Keicho- chogin (Silver oval coin)
history.desc: Keicho-chogin is a kind chogin (collective term of silver) which started to be minted in July 1601, the beginning of Edo period, and it is a silver coin by weight standard as well.

history.name: Kyoho-chogin (Chogin is a collective term of silver) (Kyoho is the era in Edo period.)
history.url: history/Kyoho-chogin (Chogin is a collective term of silver) (Kyoho is the era in Edo period.).html
history.desc: Kyoho-chogin is a silver coin by weight standard as well as a kind of chogin that was issued in September 1714, and it was called by "Shotoku-chogin"as well.

history.name: Bakufu kaigun (navy)
history.desc: Bakufu kaigun (navy) was a navy with western-style armaments which was organized by Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to accomplish battles at sea as a mission.

history.name: Iro (old retainers) in the Kansei era
history.url: history/Iro (old retainers) in the Kansei era.html
history.desc: Iro (old retainers) in the Kansei era refers to politicians who led the bakufu such as Nobuaki MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Mikawa-Yoshida domain), who were chosen by Sadanobu MATSUDAIRA after his downfall.

history.name: Keicho Koban (oval coin)
history.desc: Keicho Koban had been issued since 1601, during the early period of the Edo period,and was currency by table having one Ryo value per one Koban.

history.name: Onuki Clan
history.desc: Onuki clan was one of the Japanese clans.

history.name: Kyoryuchi Keisatsu
history.desc: Kyoryuchi Keisatsu (the Foreign Settlement Police) refers to the police force placed in the foreign settlements throughout the Empire of Japan prior to treaty revision.

history.name: Hoei Tsuho (currency of Hoei) (Hoei is the name of era in Edo period)
history.url: history/Hoei Tsuho (currency of Hoei) (Hoei is the name of era in Edo period).html
history.desc: Hoei tsuho is a kind of coin minted in Edo period, which was issued in 1708.

history.name: Kikokusenkin
history.desc: Kikokusenkin refers to one of the economic thoughts during the Edo period, which respected rice and abhorred money.

history.name: Money Changer
history.desc: A money changer is a store or merchant who mainly deals with changing money and finance.

history.name: Higisho (the taking of a religious oath with red-hot iron)
history.url: history/Higisho (the taking of a religious oath with red-hot iron).html
history.desc: Higisho is a kind of ordeal believed as God's judgment conducted in Japan during the medieval period and modern times, also being referred to as Tekka (red-hot iron) or Kasei (oath of fire).

history.name: The History of Todai-ji Temple
history.desc: In this article, the history of Todai-ji Temple is described.

history.name: Death March of Hakkoda Mountains Incident
history.jp: 八甲田雪中行軍遭難事件
history.url: history/Death March of Hakkoda Mountains Incident.html
history.desc: Death March of Hakkoda Mountains Incident was the incident in which the fifth Infantry Regiment of the eighth Imperial Japanese Army (IJA) division was stranded while on a training exercise on the Hakkoda-san Mountain.

history.name: Miyohajime
history.desc: Miyohajime refers to a series of measures and the policies that are performed as part of the rule of the new reign of the new monarch at the beginning of his assumption after the death or retirement of the previous monarch.

history.name: Komyojimura joko shoshi jiken
history.jp: 光明寺村女工焼死事件
history.desc: Komyojimura joko shoshi jiken ("the incident in Komyoji-mura Village in which female factory workers perished by fire") refers to the fire that broke out in 1900 in a textile factory in the village of Komyoji-mura (the present-day city of Ichinomiya) in Haguri-gun County of Aichi Prefecture and killed 31 female factory workers.

history.name: Gokinaishi (Topography of Kinai region)
history.desc: Gokinaishi (topography of Kinai region) was a local topography of Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) compiled in the Edo period.

history.name: Kawazarae Myogakin
history.desc: Kawazarae Myogakin is votive offering tax imposed by the government for dredging rivers in Osaka in the Edo period.

history.name: Yamatai (The state of Yamatai)
history.desc: Yamatai (邪馬台国) is a vassal state which is mentioned in Gishiwajinden ('Worenchuan' [the account of the people of 'Wa'] in "Wei chih" [The History of the Wei Dynasty]).

history.name: Fu-Rin-Ka-Zan
history.desc: Fu-Rin-Ka-Zan is a common name for the phrase of 'as fast as the wind, as quiet as the forest, as daring as fire, and as immovable as the mountain,' written on the hatasashi-mono (battle flags) of Shingen TAKEDA, a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period in the Kai Province (Yamanashi Prefecture).

history.name: Innochocho (orders issued by innocho)
history.desc: Innochocho is an order document in a form of cho (a kind of document formats) issued by In no cho of Daijo Tenno (the Retired Emperor) to officials and Sogo (Office of Monastic Affairs) that were not under its jurisdiction.

history.name: Zi
history.desc: Zi is monjo (written material) used by lower-ranking government officials equal to or below the rank of Zonin or by the common people or hakucho (inferior servants) when they reported to their superiors, under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Daimyogashi
history.desc: The term "daimyogashi" refers to a loan for a daimyo (Japanese feudal lords) or a domain in financial droughts arranged by influential merchants in Osaka, Kyoto, Edo, and so on.

history.name: Oranda Shogatsu (Dutch New Year Celebration in Japan)
history.url: history/Oranda Shogatsu (Dutch New Year Celebration in Japan).html
history.desc: Oranda Shogatsu was a celebration of the new year on the first day of the new Solar year (the Gregorian calendar) by the Dutch who were living on Dejima, Nagasaki and by Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) in Edo (Tokyo) in the Edo period.

history.name: Cho
history.desc: Cho is a form of official documents under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: I (移)
history.desc: "I" (移) is a form of official documents under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), to be exchanged between government officials when there are no hierarchical relationships between them.

history.name: Coup of the seventh year of Kenkyu
history.url: history/Coup of the seventh year of Kenkyu.html
history.desc: Coup of the seventh year of Kenkyu was a coup that took place in 1196.

history.name: Senior lady-in-waiting
history.desc: The senior lady-in-waiting (`Rojo`) was the most senior high ranking woman serving a samurai or a noble.

history.name: Shotenroku (premium)
history.desc: Shotenroku was a premium which the government gave as a bonus in addition to a hereditary stipend to court nobles, Japanese feudal lords and members of the warrior class who contributed a great deal to Meiji Restoration.

history.name: Ninjindai Oko Chogin
history.desc: Ninjindai Oko Chogin refers to silver coins minted from 1710 for exclusive use for trade of Korean ginseng, and it was a silver-by-weight standard.

history.name: Naisenshi (Palace Dyeing Office)
history.desc: Naisenshi was an institution belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Chiho Kahei (Local Currency)
history.desc: Chiho Kahei was a currency issued principally to be used within a territory and was issued by various domains in the Edo period, and particularly, gold and silver coins issued by various daimyo to be used within their territories from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) to the early Edo period were also called Ryogoku Kahei.

history.name: Kanshi (government official)
history.desc: Kanshi is an authority or a government official in ancient Japan.

history.name: Shakui
history.desc: Shakui is temporal bestowal of high Ikai (court rank) to officials.

history.name: Naizenshi (Imperial Table Office)
history.desc: Naizenshi was an institution belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) in Japanese government-regulated organization or facility, etc.

history.name: Hibyoin (quarantine hospital)
history.desc: Hibyoin was a hospital specialized for infectious diseases built in the Meiji period in Japan.

history.name: Hakari-za
history.desc: Hakari-za is za (trade guild) which imposed a monopoly on manufacturing, distribution, test and repair of scales with the special license of the Edo bakufu during the Edo period.

history.name: Suebe
history.desc: Suebe (or Suetsukuribe) was a group of people who were engaged in manufacturing Sueki (unglazed ware) before Taika period.

history.name: Tokuseirei (a debt cancellation order) in the Kenmu Era
history.url: history/Tokuseirei (a debt cancellation order) in the Kenmu Era.html
history.desc: Tokuseirei in the Kenmu era is an act promulgated on June 13, 1334.

history.name: San-saemon Incident
history.desc: The San-saemon incident was the incident in which former retainers of the deceased father and son, Yoshiyasu ICHIJO and Takayoshi ICHIJO, were arrested for attempting to attack Michichika TSUCHIMIKADO, Gon Dainagon (provisional major counselor).

history.name: Haishakukin (borrowed money)
history.desc: Haishakukin (borrowed money) was money that the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) lent without interest to daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and hatamoto (direct retainer of the Edo bakufu) as a means of financial support.

history.name: Kyoikurei (the 1879 Education Order)
history.desc: Kyoikurei is an order about education promulgated in September 1879 to replace the educational system (the 214th edict of Dajokan [Grand Council of State] of 1872) promulgated in 1872.

history.name: Shinabe (Technicians in Offices)
history.desc: Shinabe (technicians in offices), or 'shinashinano tomonowo' or 'tomono miyatsuko' in the Japanese way of reading, refers to the human group or organization in ancient Japan.

history.name: Kokkagakkai (Society for the Science of the Nation)
history.url: history/Kokkagakkai (Society for the Science of the Nation).html
history.desc: Kokkagakkai is a study group at law school of the University of Tokyo (the predecessor of the Faculty of Law at the University of Tokyo) founded in February 1887.

history.name: Zakko (Special Technicians)
history.desc: Zakko refers to groups of technical experts mainly from handicraft industry, coming from shokugyobe (professional Be [groups of people who belonged to the Yamato Dynasty]) subordinated to specific government offices under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) of Japan before the Taika Reforms.

history.name: Banyu Enzetsu (Speech with Brute Courage)
history.desc: Banyu Enzetsu is a speech made by Navy Minister Sukenori KABAYAMA in the second Imperial Diet in December 1891.

history.name: Shutosho (vaccination institute)
history.desc: Shutosho (vaccination institute) is the name of the medical institute established for the purpose of prevention and treatment of smallpox in Japan.

history.name: Machiyakunin (Municipal Official)
history.desc: "Machiyakunin," also pronounced as "choyakunin," refers to an administrative organization in urban areas which existed during the Edo period.

history.name: Mokkan (Confiscation)
history.desc: Mokkan (also read as Bokkan) is one of supplementary punishments in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), and it refers to the confiscation of corpus or property by the authority.

history.name: Kogosho Conference (the meeting held in the presence of the Emperor in the Kogosho Conference Room of Kyoto Imperial Palace at the night of January 3, 1868, when the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule was issued)
history.url: history/Kogosho Conference (the meeting held in the presence of the Emperor in the Kogosho Conference Room o.html
history.desc: Kogosho Conference is a meeting on national politics held at Kyoto Palace in Kyoto on January 3, 1868 in the end of Edo Period.

history.name: Higashiyama Gobunko (the imperial library)
history.desc: Higashiyama Go-bunko refers to the imperial family library located in northeast corner of Kyoto Imperial Palace.

history.name: Offense and Defense in Omi Province
history.url: history/Offense and Defense in Omi Province.html
history.desc: The offense and defense in Omi Province were a series of battles between Omi-Genji (the Minamoto clan) and Onjo-ji Temple's armed priests versus Heike (the Taira family) during the Jisho-Juei War.

history.name: Ryogoku Kahei
history.desc: Ryogoku (daimyos' own territory) kahei (coins) are gold and silver coins which daimyos (Japanese feudal lords) at various places ordered to mint for circulation in their territories from the Sengoku period to the early Edo period, and are also called Ryogoku Kingin (gold and silver).

history.name: Mido-ryu
history.desc: Mido-ryu was the name of a style of Yusoku-kojitsu (knowledge of court rules, ceremony, decorum and records of the past) and manners for the descendants of FUJIWARA no Michinaga (Sessho [Regent] and Daijo-daijin [Grand Minister]) of Kujo line of Fujiwara-Hokke (the Northern House of the Fujiwara Clan) and the groups who assumed Michinaga as their ancestors.

history.name: Yorifune (drifting ships and wreckage)
history.desc: "Yorifune" meant ships drifting or drifted ashore and their loads after having met with some mishaps in the medieval and modern times in Japan.

history.name: Keicho Oban
history.desc: Keicho Oban is a large-sized old Japanese gold coin issued in the early Edo period, from 1601 more specifically, and this can be classified into several varieties according to writings in ink, karat (gold measurement), timing of issuance, and so on.

history.name: Genroku-Oban
history.desc: Genroku-Oban refers to a large-sized gold coin issued in November 1695 following the issuing of the Keicho-Oban.

history.name: Kyoho-Oban
history.desc: Kyoho-Oban refers to a large-sized gold coin released in July 1725.

history.name: Tenpo-Oban (Large-Sized Gold Coin of the Tenpo Era)
history.url: history/Tenpo-Oban (Large-Sized Gold Coin of the Tenpo Era).html
history.desc: Tenpo-Oban refers to a large-sized gold coin issued from August 13, 1838.

history.name: Manen Oban (Large-Sized Gold Coin of the Manen Era)
history.url: history/Manen Oban (Large-Sized Gold Coin of the Manen Era).html
history.desc: Manen Oban is a large-sized old Japanese gold coin issued in intercalary April of 1860; it is also called Shin Oban.

history.name: Seiin (the Central State Council in the early Meiji period)
history.url: history/Seiin (the Central State Council in the early Meiji period).html
history.desc: Seiin was the highest organ of Daijokan (Grand Council of State) system issued in 1871 after the Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

history.name: Shoban (foreign lands)
history.desc: In ancient Japan, the term "Shoban" meant three countries in the Korean Peninsula called 'Sankan' as well as the clans of settlers originally from there.

history.name: Yakuryo (executive allowance)
history.desc: Yakuryo (executive allowance) was one of the executive allowances that the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) gave to the retainers of the Shogun.

history.name: Tochokufu (official document to enforce the Emperor's order)
history.url: history/Tochokufu (official document to enforce the Emperors order).html
history.desc: Tochokufu refers to a Daijokanpu (the official documents of the Daijokan, the office of the supreme political leader) to deliver and enforce the order of the Emperor.

history.name: Kanjocho (Account Books)
history.desc: Kanjosho is a kind of account book prepared for settlement of balances on rice, soy beans, gold, silver and others.

history.name: Dochu Shohatto
history.desc: Dochu Shohatto, also referred to as Dochu Jomoku, is traffic regulation issued by the Edo bakufu to people of specific status, such as daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), Court nobles and officials of the bakufu.

history.name: Dochuzu (Route Map)
history.desc: Dochuzu is a pictorial map made during the Edo period in which land routes or sea routes are described.

history.name: Yamato no Miyako
history.desc: Yamato no Miyako is a city existed in ancient Japan.

history.name: Yakukin
history.desc: Yakukin is a kind of allowance or expense paid to the retainers of the shogun by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Genna Tsuho (Coin of the Genna Era)
history.url: history/Genna Tsuho (Coin of the Genna Era).html
history.desc: Genna Tsuho is a copper coin named after an era in the Edo period, which is thought to have been minted in around the first or second year of the Genna era (1615 or 1616) in Japan, and it is older than the Kanei Tsuho coin.

history.name: Shigetada HATAKEYAMA Rebellion
history.desc: The Shigetada HATAKEYAMA Rebellion was the rebellion in which Shigetada HATAKEYAMA was killed in an attack by a large army, planned by Tokimasa HOJO and executed by Yoshitoki HOJO; it took place at the Futamata-gawa River in the Musashi Province (present-day Asahi Ward and Hodogaya Ward, Yokohama City) on July 17, 1205 in the early Kamakura period.

history.name: The Kagetoki KAJIWARA incident
history.desc: The Kagetoki KAJIWARA incident is a political incident caused in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in the early Kamakura period from November 15, 1199 to February 6, 1200.

history.name: Keizu Sanyo (Edo Period Pedigree Charts)
history.desc: Keizu sanyo (Edo period pedigree charts) is a collection of pedigree charts compiled in the late Edo Period.

history.name: Nenkiho (a legal principle for the statute of limitations)
