history.url: history/Nenkiho (a legal principle for the statute of limitations).html
history.desc: Nenkiho (also referred to as Nenki no ho) is a legal principle for the statute of limitations developed under the Medieval samurai law.

history.name: Wayakushu aratame kaisho (agency for checking the quality of Japanese medicinal materials)
history.url: history/Wayakushu aratame kaisho (agency for checking the quality of Japanese medicinal materials).html
history.desc: Wayakushu aratame kaisho was an agency established by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) during the Edo period, which performed quality control check on domestic (Japanese) materials of medicines.

history.name: Washu Yoshinogun Gunzanki
history.desc: Washu Yoshinogun Gunzanki (hereafter 'Gunzanki') is a name of the series of the natural history and topography books written by Tomoari MINAMOTO of the Kishu Domain, a scholar of herbalism and natural history in the late Edo period.

history.name: Kuikaeshi
history.desc: Kuikaeshi is an act in which, after a property's ownership was shifted to someone else by compromise or donation, its previous owner or his descendants recover the ownership by disaffirming the previous decision.

history.name: Osamebarai Meisaicho (Tribute Register)
history.desc: The Osamebarai Meisaicho (tribute register) was a register document that was sent each year by regional magistrate offices to the settlements department of the Edo shogunate.

history.name: The history of Nanki Tokugawa clan.
history.url: history/The history of Nanki Tokugawa clan..html
history.desc: "The history of Nanki Tokugawa clan" refers to a history book of the Kishu Domain, completed in Meiji period.

history.name: Omiya Gosho
history.desc: Omiya Gosho was a residence built for Empress Teimei who became an empress dowager when Emperor Taisho had passed away on the premise of Akasaka Rikyu (The State Guest House) (present-day Akasaka Imperial property).

history.name: Hyakuman Chobu Kaikon Keikaku (The million-hectare development plan)
history.url: history/Hyakuman Chobu Kaikon Keikaku (The million-hectare development plan).html
history.desc: The Hyakuman Chobu Kaikon Keikaku (The million- hectare development plan) was a government scheme during the Nara Period.

history.name: Kaso (physiognomy of the house)
history.desc: Kaso refers to the study of fortune telling which is similar to Feng Shui, Kigaku (fortune telling based on Chinese 12 year cycle) and etc.

history.name: Wayojo
history.desc: Wayojo is an agreement signed by the parties in question who make compromises.

history.name: Onna Koshu (Ffemale Head of a Family)
history.url: history/Onna Koshu (Ffemale Head of a Family).html
history.desc: Onna Koshu was defined as a female head of a family according to the Old Civil Codes of Japan.

history.name: Shiki no Mizukakinomiya
history.desc: Shiki no Mizukakinomiya was the palace of Emperor Sujin's dynasty as recorded in the Rikkokushi (Japan's six national chronicles of the seventh and eighth century).

history.name: Wayo
history.desc: Wayo is a legal term used in ancient and medieval Japan.

history.name: Jinka (suspected arson)
history.desc: Jinka refers to suspicious fires which often happened from the late 8th century to 10th century, mainly centering on kanga (government office) in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region).

history.name: Kagami no Shuku (Inn of Mirrors)
history.desc: Kagami no Shuku was an inn on the Tosan-do Road, north of Mount Kagami, in Gamo Country of the Omi Province (present day Gagami, Oaza, Ryuo-cho, Gamo-gun, Shiga Prefecture) that has existed since the Heian Period.

history.name: Kei (a unit of area)
history.desc: "Kei"or qing is a unit of area used in the Chinese traditional system of measurement (unit system).

history.name: Ofuregaki Shusei (The collection of laws and regulations compiled by the shogunate)
history.url: history/Ofuregaki Shusei (The collection of laws and regulations compiled by the shogunate).html
history.desc: Ofuregaki shusei indicates a collection of laws and regulations issued by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

history.name: Oshioki Saikyo-cho (Judicial Precedents Estimated to be Compiled by Edo Machi-bugyo [town magistrate of Edo])
history.url: history/Oshioki Saikyo-cho (Judicial Precedents Estimated to be Compiled by Edo Machi-bugyo [town magistrate.html
history.desc: Oshioki Saikyo-cho was a compilation of legal reports thought to be created by Edo machi-bugyo in Hoei era (1704 to 1710).

history.name: Oshioki Ruireishu (Judicial Precedents of Criminal Cases made by Edo bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun])
history.url: history/Oshioki Ruireishu (Judicial Precedents of Criminal Cases made by Edo bakufu [Japanese feudal governm.html
history.desc: Oshioki Ruireishu was a compilation of law reports dealing with criminal cases, which was created by the Edo bakufu.

history.name: Jungido
history.desc: "Jungido" is a hanko (school for the descendants of feudal lords) founded by the Zeze clan in 1808.

history.name: Kumano Sanzan Kengyo (the Overseer of the Three Kumano Shrines)
history.url: history/Kumano Sanzan Kengyo (the Overseer of the Three Kumano Shrines).html
history.desc: Kumano Sanzan Kengyo was a post to govern Kumano Sanzan (three major shrines, Kumano-Hongu-Taisha, Kumano-Hayatama-Taisha and Kumano-Nachi-Taisha) and was established above Kumano betto (the title of an official who administered the shrines at Kumano) at the beginning of the the 11th century.

history.name: Kyushu ocho setsu (theory of Kyushu dynasty)
history.url: history/Kyushu ocho setsu (theory of Kyushu dynasty).html
history.desc: Kyushu ocho setsu is a theory that a dynasty existed in Kyushu until the end of the seventh century and Dazai-fu was the capital of the dynasty, advocated by Takehiko FURUTA.

history.name: The Surrender of Edo-jp Castle
history.desc: The Surrender of Edo-jo Castle was executed during the ending of the Edo period (the final phase of the Tokugawa shogunate), occurring over the months of March to April in 1868; Takamori SAIGO, a representative of the new Meiji government, and Kaishu KATSU, a representative of the former Tokugawa shogunate troops; together strategically negotiated a peaceful resolution to the surrender of Edo-jo Castle; this peacefully negotiated transfer was to become historically known as, The Bloodless Surrender of Edo-jo Castle.

history.name: Nara Naval Air Corps
history.desc: Nara Naval Air Corps and its predecessor, Nara Detachment of Mie Naval Air Corps, were one of the troops and educational institutions of the Imperial Japanese Navy.

history.name: Fire attack against Mt. Hiei
history.desc: The fire attack against Mt. Hiei was a fire attack mainly against Mt. Hiei.

history.name: Ranpoigaku (school of Dutch medicine)
history.desc: Ranpoigaku (school of Dutch medicine) refers to medical science introduced to Japan during the Edo period mainly through medical officers (doctors) in Dutch Trading Post in Dejima, Nagasaki.

history.name: Efu (tag)
history.desc: Efu was a type of baggage tags which were attached during the Edo period to goods sent by the Imperial Court, the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), court nobles, samurai families, temples and shrines to clarify who sent the baggage in question.

history.name: Keishi (household superintendent)
history.desc: Keishi (also called Ie no tsukasa) refers to personnel who are in charge of household management placed in a household of the Imperial Prince and Princess, or a Court noble or a samurai family of Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher as Shikiji (another term for a royal secretary, kurodo, especially one who is concurrently posted as a controller).

history.name: Movement to Improve Rural Areas
history.desc: Movement to Improve Rural Areas was government-regulated movement which aimed to improve and reconstruct regional societies, cities, towns and villages which had been devastated after the Russo-Japanese War.

history.name: Tan (担) (a unit of weight)
history.desc: Tan (the letter 擔 was used in Yuan) was a unit of weight (mass) under the Chinese shakkanho (the system of measuring length by the shaku and weight by the kan) (shakusekiho, Chinese traditional system of measurement [unit system], Taiwanese traditional system of measurement).

history.name: Seibyobo (the register of standing crops)
history.desc: Seibyobo (the register of standing crops) refers to an account book recording the actual conditions of cultivation of rice field in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Jishinban (security office, security officer)
history.desc: Jishinban is a bansho (an ancient form of security office) installed in downtown areas in Edo and Osaka during the Edo period.

history.name: Keiun no kaikaku (Political reform in the Keiun era)
history.url: history/Keiun no kaikaku (Political reform in the Keiun era).html
history.desc: Keiun no kaikaku is a political reform of Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on Ritsuryo Code) at the imperial court under the reign of Emperor Monmu, which was carried out since 706 at the end of the Asuka period.

history.name: Natori-dan (army corps in Natori County)
history.desc: Natori-dan refers to Gundan (army corps in ancient Japan) deployed in Natori County, Mutsu Province (later Rikuzen Province), Japan from the early 8th century to the 10th century.

history.name: Mikka Heishi War (Three days rebellion of the Taira clan in the Kamakura Period)
history.jp: 三日平氏の乱 (鎌倉時代)
history.url: history/Mikka Heishi War (Three days rebellion of the Taira clan in the Kamakura Period).html
history.desc: Mikka Heishi War (Three-days rebellion of the Taira clan) is a rebellion caused by the remnants of the Taira clan in Ise and Iga Provinces at the beginning of the Kamakura period.

history.name: 日韓通信業務合同 (Japan-Korea Joint Communication Service)
history.url: history/日韓通信業務合同 (Japan-Korea Joint Communication Service).html
history.desc: It was an agreement formally called '韓国通信機関委託ニ関スル取極書' (Memorandum Concerning the Commission of Korean Communication Institution).

history.name: Uda Disturbance
history.desc: Uda Disturbance refers to the family feud which broke out in the Uda-Matsuyama Domain in Yamato Province during the Edo period.

history.name: Kyogoku Soran
history.desc: Kyogoku Soran was one of Kyogoku clan's family battles over the succession to (the headship of) the house in the Omi Province which took place during the time from the Muromachi Period to the Sengoku period (period of warring states) in Japan.

history.name: Ina no Agata
history.desc: Ina no Agata was one of the early form of the local bureaucratic system in ancient Japan (Agata), which was placed in Hokusetsu (northern Settsu Province, the area covering now Suita City through Amagasaki City) during the Kofun period (tumulus period), the era of Yamato sovereignty.

history.name: Saekibe
history.desc: Saekibe is one of the Shinabe (technical groups) that existed in ancient Japan.

history.name: Kasho (passport)
history.desc: Kasho refers to a passport used from the age of the Han dynasty to around the period of Tang Dynasty in China.

history.name: Bunin (appointment)
history.desc: Bunin (appointment) is to grant government officials a government post or Ikai (Court rank).

history.name: Seikyo-sha
history.desc: Seikyo-sha was an opinion group and publishing house, which was established with a total of thirteen people as Dojin (coterie).

history.name: Minyu-sha
history.desc: Minyu-sha was an opinion group and publishing house established by Soho TOKUTOMI.

history.name: Kujishi
history.desc: Kujishi is a Japanese term used to refer to persons who would stand in for the relevant parties involved in a lawsuit in the Edo period.

history.name: Bugei (military art) (Japan)
history.desc: Bugei is a military art practiced by soldiers, military officers, and samurai in order to fight in a battlefield during the period from the ancient times to the medieval period, the early modern period in Japan.

history.name: Buninjo (appointment letter)
history.desc: Buninjo (appointment letter) is a generic term of documents issued by an appointer when a specific person is appointed to a governmental post, Ikai (Court rank), and various posts.

history.name: Hancho (domain office)
history.desc: Hancho is a political term used during the Edo period.

history.name: Ukagaikata (a government officer in the Edo period)
history.url: history/Ukagaikata (a government officer in the Edo period).html
history.desc: "Ukagaikata" indicates the name of a government post in Kanjosho (the department in charge of financial and public affairs) of the Edo bakufu or officers (called kanjo-shu) of that department.

history.name: Sante-gakari
history.desc: Sante-gakari indicates criminal trials in the Edo period for a samurai, his wife or his children with the family status that had omemie ([the privilege to have] an audience [with one's lord, a dignitary, etc].)

history.name: Hanmoto Mitodoke (a government officer job in the Edo period)
history.url: history/Hanmoto Mitodoke (a government officer job in the Edo period).html
history.desc: Hanmoto Mitodoke was a term used to describe the act of confirmation by a government officer that was sent from the Edo bakufu, when a samurai family applied for matsugo-yoshi (adopting a son on the family head's deathbed).

history.name: Banyaku
history.desc: Banyaku refers to working different shifts by rotation in the Japanese history.

history.name: Hanpo (one of appointments of government posts)
history.url: history/Hanpo (one of appointments of government posts).html
history.desc: Hanpo refers to one of Bunin (appointments of government posts) in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

history.name: Bansho
history.desc: Bansho is a facility in which guards were stationed for security and surveillance.

history.name: Banjo (working pattern taken by lower-ranking government officials)
history.url: history/Banjo (working pattern taken by lower-ranking government officials).html
history.desc: Banjo refers to a working pattern taken by lower-ranking government officials such as Zonin and so on in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

history.name: Azuke (punishment)
history.desc: Azuke means a way of detention pending trial or punishment in Bukeho (the law system for the samurai society and the military government) in which a person is interned in some private citizen's place such as relatives.

history.name: Azukarichi (rented land)
history.desc: "Azukarichi" (or "Azukechi") indicates the land a person has entrusted to another person to keep and manage.

history.name: Trade between Japan and the Yuan Dynasty
history.url: history/Trade between Japan and the Yuan Dynasty.html
history.desc: Nichigenn-boueki was the trade relationship held between Japan and the Yuan Dynasty.

history.name: Nittoboeki (trade between Japan and Tang dynasty China)
history.url: history/Nittoboeki (trade between Japan and Tang dynasty China).html
history.desc: Nittoboeki (日唐貿易) is the trade that was carried on between Japan and Tang dynasty China.

history.name: Rokkakushi Shikimoku (Bunkokuho by the Rokkaku Clan)
history.url: history/Rokkakushi Shikimoku (Bunkokuho by the Rokkaku Clan).html
history.desc: Rokkakushi Shikimoku was one of the bunkokuho (the law individual sengoku-daimyo enforced in their own domain) in the Sengoku period.

history.name: Japan Post Office in Korea
history.desc: Japan Post Office was post offices in Korea, which were placed in Korean Peninsula by Japan in Meiji Period.

history.name: Aobyoshi (book on the customs and manners of samurai)
history.url: history/Aobyoshi (book on the customs and manners of samurai).html
history.desc: Aobyoshi is a book on the customs and manners of samurai, written by Hiroki ONO (also called Gonnojo or Ninken), a shogun's retainer and a scholar of Japanese classical literature in the late Edo period.

history.name: Karyaku no Sodo (a rebellion in the Karyaku era)
history.url: history/Karyaku no Sodo (a rebellion in the Karyaku era).html
history.desc: "Karyaku no sodo" (Karyaku rebellion) refers to a conflict in 1326, towards the end of the Kamakura period, between Nagasaki Takasuke, a minister to the Tokuso family and the Adachi clan, whose head was a maternal relative of the Tokuso family over inheriting the head post of the Tokuso family within the Hojo clan, which was regent to the Kamakura bakufu shogunate.

history.name: Kugoden (rice fields for cultivation of rice for emperor's meal)
history.url: history/Kugoden (rice fields for cultivation of rice for emperors meal).html
history.desc: Kugoden refers to rice fields to cultivate rice (Kugomai) for emperor's meals (Kugo).

history.name: Saikudokoro (tooling office)
history.desc: Saikudokoro (or called Saikusho) refers to an institution or craft center for handicraft industry which was permanently or temporarily established by Kenmon (an influential family) in the medieval period.

history.name: Kuji
history.desc: Kuji (Oyakegoto) is one of terms in Japanese history and used in the following meanings.

history.name: Kugoin (Division of rice for the Emperor)
history.url: history/Kugoin (Division of rice for the Emperor).html
history.desc: Kugoin (Division of rice for the Emperor) refers to an auxiliary organization of Oiryo (Bureau of Palace Kitchens under the Ministry of the Imperial Household).

history.name: Takaoka shi (Takaoka Clan)
history.desc: Takaoka Clan was one of the clans of Japan.

history.name: Kyo-masu
history.desc: The kyo-masu is a type of masu (measure) which was designated as the official masu from the late medieval period to the postwar period.

history.name: Yusocho (the field-tax report)
history.desc: Yusocho refers to an account book recording accurate figures of Denso (rice field tax) and Jishi (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system) actually collected in one year in order for the Ritsuryo government (ancient Japanese government of centralized governance) to survey the actual performance of government affairs by Kokushi (provincial governor), which was always carried by Kochoshi, one of Shidoshi dispatched to the capital by Kokushi, in charge of submitting Chocho (list of choyo (tribute and labor) and was submitted by Minbusho (the Ministry of Popular Affairs) by order of the government.

history.name: Nuinotsukasa (Sewing Office)
history.desc: Nuinotsukasa was one of 12 offices in the Ladies Quarters, and responsible for sewing garments, braiding plaited cords, and also managed the court ladies' serving and entering the Imperial Court.

history.name: Omagaki (a list of candidates)
history.desc: Omagaki refers to Myobo (identification) listing names of vacant government posts subject to appointment and candidates for such government posts at the time of appointment in Jimoku (ceremony for appointing officials) regularly held in Spring and Autumn.

history.name: Genisyu
history.desc: Genisyu was a military epic written in the late period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) (in the latter half of the 14th century).

literature.name: The Tale of Genji
literature.desc: "The Tale of Genji" is a Japanese novel written in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Murasaki Shikibu
literature.desc: Murasaki Shikibu (dates of birth and death unknown) was a female author and poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Waka
literature.desc: Waka is a fixed form of poem that has been created since Jodai (mainly the Nara period).

literature.name: The Pillow Book
literature.desc: "The Pillow Book" is a zuihitsu essay (literally, "random jottings"), which is said to have been written by Sei Shonagon, a female writer who lived in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Nihonkoki History Book
literature.desc: Nihonkoki History Book is a collection of histories created by imperial command; it was compiled in the early Heian period after Shoku-Nihongi (Continuation of Chronicles of Japan), being the third volume of Rikkokushi (Six National Histories).

literature.name: Sei Shonagon
literature.desc: Sei Shonagon (966? - 1025?) was a female writer and poet in the Heian period.

literature.name: Ugetsu Monogatari (Tales of Moonlight and Rain)
literature.url: literature/Ugetsu Monogatari (Tales of Moonlight and Rain).html
literature.desc: "Ugetsu Monogatari" is a representative yomihon (book for reading) written by Akinari UEDA at the end of the Edo era.

literature.name: Hojoki (An Account of My Hut)
literature.desc: "Hojoki," written by KAMO no Chomei, is a representative essay in the history of medieval Japanese literature.

literature.name: Tsurezuregusa (Essays in Idleness)
literature.desc: Tsurezuregusa is an essay which was written by Kenko YOSHIDA, or Kaneyoshi URABE (real name).

literature.name: New Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry
literature.url: literature/New Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry.html
literature.desc: "New Collection of Ancient and Modern Poetry" was compiled by order of Emperor Gotoba in the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: KI no Tsurayuki
literature.desc: KI no Tsurayuki (866 or 872? - June 19, 945?) was a poet and essayist from the early to the middle Heian period.

literature.name: The Tosa Diary
literature.desc: In "The Tosa Diary," KI no Tsurayuki wrote about his thoughts and the events that occurred on his journey from Tosa Province to Kyoto.

literature.name: ONO no Komachi
literature.desc: ONO no Komachi (circa 809 - circa 901) was a female poet in around the first half of the Heian period, in the ninth century.

literature.name: Renga
literature.desc: Renga is a traditional form of poetry, and the kaminoku (the first part of a poem) and shimonoku (the latter part of a poem) are linked together by several people.

literature.name: Sagami (poet)
literature.desc: Sagami (dates of birth and death unknown, 998? - after 1061) was a female poet in the early eleventh century, and one of the medieval 36 Immortal Poets.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Shitago
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Shitago (911-983) was a Japanese scholar and poet of the early Heian period.

literature.name: Taiheiki (Record of the Great Peace)
literature.desc: "Taiheiki" is a work of Japanese literature.

literature.name: Okagami (The Great Mirror)
literature.desc: The Great Mirror is a historical tale written in the style of a biographical record.

literature.name: Baishoron
literature.desc: Baishoron is a Japanese war tale and a history of the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) as great as the Taiheiki.

literature.name: Izumi Shikibu
literature.desc: Izumi Shikibu （dates unknown) was a poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: OSHIKOCHI no Mitsune
literature.desc: OSHIKOCHI no Mitsune (859? - 925?) was a poet of the early Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Kinto
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Kinto (966 - February 4, 1041) was a court noble and poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Eiga Monogatari
literature.desc: "Eiga Monogatari (A Tale of Flowering Fortunes)" is a classic work of the Heian period.

literature.name: The Collection of Tales of Times Now Past
literature.url: literature/The Collection of Tales of Times Now Past.html
literature.desc: The Collection of Tales of Times Now Past (Konjaku Monogatari Shu) is a collection of setsuwa (anecdotes).

literature.name: Hogen Monogatari (The Tale of Hogen)
literature.desc: "Hogen Monogatari" is a war tale that describes the Hogen Disturbance.

literature.name: Sosei
literature.desc: Sosei (dates of birth and death unknown, died in 910?) was a poet and a monk who lived during the early and middle Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Tadahira
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Tadahira (880 - September 14, 949) was a court noble of the Heian period.

literature.name: The Literature of the Five Mountains
literature.url: literature/The Literature of the Five Mountains.html
literature.desc: Gozan Bungaku (the Literature of the Five Mountains) was literature in Chinese developed in Zen temples from the late Kamakura period to the Muromachi period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Kinzane
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Kinzane (1053 - December 29, 1107) was a court noble and poet of Heian period.

literature.name: Azuma Kagami
literature.desc: "Azuma Kagami" is a history book completed in the Japanese medieval times, or the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Nihon Montoku Tenno Jitsuroku (Veritable Records of Emperor Montoku of Japan)
literature.url: literature/Nihon Montoku Tenno Jitsuroku (Veritable Records of Emperor Montoku of Japan).html
literature.desc: Nihon Montoku Tenno Jitsuroku is a history compiled in Japan during the Heian period, and is the fifth among the six Rikkokushi (National Histories of Japan, six historical compilations chronicling the mythology and history of Japan between the Nara and Heian periods).

literature.name: Shoku Nihon Koki (Later Chronicle of Japan, Continued)
literature.url: literature/Shoku Nihon Koki (Later Chronicle of Japan, Continued).html
literature.desc: Shoku Nihon Koki is a history compiled in 869 during the Heian period in Japan, and is the fourth of the Six National Histories (Rikkokushi).

literature.name: Masukagami (The Clear Mirror)
literature.desc: Masukagami is a historical tale.

literature.name: The Record of a Pilgrimage to China in Search of the Law
literature.url: literature/The Record of a Pilgrimage to China in Search of the Law.html
literature.desc: The Record of a Pilgrimage to China in Search of the Law is a travel diary written by Ennin (794-864), a Japanese monk who lived in the 9th century and was approved to join the last mission to Tang China in the Jowa era.

literature.name: Kenmu shikimoku (the Kenmu Code)
literature.desc: Kenmu shikimoku (or Kenmu shikimoku jojo) is a political statement showing the governing philosophy of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

literature.name: Sagabon (Saga Books)
literature.desc: Saga Books (Sagabon) are books printed using movable type at the beginning of the early-modern period of Japan.

literature.name: Hobutsu shu (A Collection of Treasures)
literature.desc: Hobutsu shu is a Buddhist setsuwa (anecdotes) collection from the end of the Heian period.

literature.name: Sogi
literature.desc: Sogi (1421－September 1, 1502) was a renga (linked-verse) poet of the Muromachi period.

literature.name: Socho
literature.desc: Socho (1448 - April 11, 1532) was a renga (linked-verse) poet of the late Muromachi period.

literature.name: Senjun
literature.desc: Senjun (1411-1476) was a renga (linked-verse) poet of the mid-Muromachi period.

literature.name: Kensho
literature.desc: Kensho (1130 - 1209?) was a poet-monk who lived from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: FUKAKUSA no Shosho (Major General)
literature.desc: FUKAKUSA no Shosho is a character who appears in a legend about ONO no Komachi, 'Coming-and-going in a Hundred Nights,' which was created by Noh authors such as Zeami during the Muromachi period.

literature.name: Onin-ki (The Record of the Onin War)
literature.url: literature/Onin-ki (The Record of the Onin War).html
literature.desc: The Onin-ki is a historical work of the Muromachi period.

literature.name: Towazugatari (The Confessions of Lady Nijo)
literature.desc: Towazugatari is the diary and travel book thought to have been written by Nijo GOFUKAKUSA-IN (Lady Nijo) in the middle or late Kamakura period.

literature.name: Gyokuyo wakashu (Collection of Jeweled Leaves)
literature.desc: Gyokuyo wakashu is an imperial anthology from the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Shoku Kokin Wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry, Continued)
literature.url: literature/Shoku Kokin Wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry, Continued).html
literature.desc: "Shoku Kokin Wakashu" is an anthology compiled by imperial command in the Kamakura period, and is the eleventh of the twenty one poetry anthologies.

literature.name: Shin Chokusenwakashu (New Imperial Collection)
literature.desc: "Shin Chokusenwakashu" is the first collection of the thirteen imperial anthologies of Japanese poetry, and the ninth anthology in aggregate.

literature.name: Mido Kanpakuki (Diary of a Mido Regent)
literature.url: literature/Mido Kanpakuki (Diary of a Mido Regent).html
literature.desc: Mido Kanpakuki is a diary written by FUJIWARA no Michinaga, a court noble who held the titles of Regent and Grand Minister in the Heian period.

literature.name: Nijo Kawaha no Rakusho (The Nijo River Beach Lampoon)
literature.url: literature/Nijo Kawaha no Rakusho (The Nijo River Beach Lampoon).html
literature.desc: Nijo Kawaha no Rakusho are writings collected in "Kenmu Nenkan-ki," a record of the Kenmu era which was handed down in the Machino clan, which was the head of Monchujo (Board of Inquiry) in Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

literature.name: A summary of the each chapter of The Tale of Genji
literature.jp: 源氏物語各帖のあらすじ
literature.url: literature/A summary of the each chapter of The Tale of Genji.html
literature.desc: A brief summary of each chapter of The Tale of Genji.

literature.name: The Shigure-tei Bunko (the Shigure-tei storehouse/library of the Reizei family)
literature.url: literature/The Shigure-tei Bunko (the Shigure-tei storehouselibrary of the Reizei family).html
literature.desc: The Foundation for the Reizei family's Shigure-tei library was founded by the descendants of FUJIWARA no Teika; it was created both to store and protect the cultural treasures, including old manuscripts, architectural items, and reports of annual events that had been passed down in the Reizei family, which was well known as a poetic family, and for the purpose of instructing succeeding generations in the Reizei school of kokin denju, or interpretation of the poetry in the Kokinshu.

literature.name: The Jinno Shotoki (A Chronicle of Gods and Sovereigns)
literature.url: literature/The Jinno Shotoki (A Chronicle of Gods and Sovereigns).html
literature.desc: The Jinno Shotoki (A Chronicle of Gods and Sovereigns) was written by the court noble Chikafusa KITABATAKE during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) on behalf of the young Emperor Gomurakami; it is a book on history that Chikafusa wrote at Oda-jo Castle in Hitachi Province (present day Oda, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki Prefecture), in which he lays out the case for why the Yoshino Court (often called the Southern Court) and its imperial lineage was the true, legitimate one.

literature.name: Meigetsuki (The Record of the Clear Moon)
literature.url: literature/Meigetsuki (The Record of the Clear Moon).html
literature.desc: "Meigetsuki" (The Record of the Clear Moon) is the Kamakura period diary of FUJIWARA no Sadaie, who is more commonly known as "Teika."

literature.name: The Ouki
literature.desc: The "Ouki" (also pronounced Shoyuki) is the diary of the Heian-period court noble FUJIWARA no Sanesuke.

literature.name: Honamigire
literature.desc: Honamigire is a nickname for the manuscript of "Kokin Wakashu" (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry), which is assumed to have been transcribed at the beginning of the twelfth century.

literature.name: Koya-gire (fragments of the Kokinshu from Koyasan monastery's manuscript)
literature.url: literature/Koya-gire (fragments of the Kokinshu from Koyasan monasterys manuscript).html
literature.desc: Koya-gire is the popular name for the incomplete manuscript of the "Kokin wakashu" (collection of ancient and modern waka poems, usually known as Kokinshu in English) that was transcribed in the eleventh century, near the end of the Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Munetada
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Munetada (1062-May 27, 1141) was a Heian-period court noble.

literature.name: Queen Kishi
literature.desc: Queen Kishi (also known as Yoshiko) was a poet and member of the Imperial Family who lived in the middle of the Heian period, from 929 to 985.

literature.name: Chogetsu
literature.desc: Chogetsu (1714-June 15, 1798) was a mid-Edo period monk and poet.

literature.name: Tona
literature.desc: Tona (1289-April 17, 1372) was a Japanese monk and waka poet who lived in the final days of the Kamakura period and into the Northern and Southern Court period.

literature.name: Keiun
literature.desc: Keiun, also known as Kyoun (born sometime during the 1293-1299, and died in 1369), was a poet and monk of the Tendai sect who lived in the latter days of Kamakura period into the middle of Japan's Northern and Southern Court period.

literature.name: Joben
literature.desc: Joben (date of birth unknown - around 1356?) was a poet and a Tendai sect monk who lived during the Kamakura period.

literature.name: SAIONJI Kintsune
literature.desc: Kintsune SAIONJI (1171 -October 2, 1244) was a Kamakura-period court noble and poet.

literature.name: Ryozen
literature.desc: Ryozen (dates of birth and death unknown) was a monk and a poet who lived during the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: TOKUDAIJI Sanesada
literature.desc: Sanesada TOKUDAIJI (1139 - February 1, 1192) was a court noble and poet who lived in the closing days of the Heian period and into the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Anpo
literature.desc: Anpo (dates of birth and death unknown) was a priest and a poet who lived during the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Sadakata
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Sadakata (873 - September 11, 932) was a court noble and poet who lived from the beginning through the middle of the Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Kanesuke
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Kanesuke (877 - March 21, 933) was a mid-Heian period court noble and poet.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Michinobu
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Michinobu (972-August 25, 994) was a court noble and a poet who lived during the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Sanekata
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Sanekata (birth date is unknown and died January 7, 999) was a mid-Heian period court noble and poet.

literature.name: Taikenmonin no Horikawa
literature.desc: Taikenmonin no Horikawa (dates of birth and death unknown) was a female poet who lived during the late Heian period.

literature.name: TAIRA no Sadafumi
literature.desc: TAIRA no Sadafumi (872? - November 13, 923) was a mid-Heian period poet.

literature.name: Gusai (the Renga master)
literature.desc: Gusai (also known as Kyusei or Kyuzei, 1283 - 1376) was a non-courtier Renga (linked verse) master who lived from the end of the Kamakura period into the Northern and Southern Court period.

literature.name: ANRAKUAN Sakuden
literature.desc: Sakuden ANRAKUAN (1554 - February 7, 1642) was a Jodo (Pure Land) sect monk who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period into the beginning of the Edo period.

literature.name: KYOGOKU Tamekane
literature.desc: Tamekane KYOGOKU (1254 - April 16, 1332) was a late Kamakura-period waka poet.

literature.name: KI no Haseo
literature.desc: KI no Haseo (born 845, died March 6, 912) was a high-ranking court noble and literatus who lived from the early into the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: ASUKAI Masatsune
literature.desc: Masatsune ASUKAI (November 28, 1569 - February 9, 1616) was a court noble and waka poet who lived through the turmoil of the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) and into the beginning of the Edo period.

literature.name: NAKANOIN Michikatsu
literature.desc: Michikatsu NAKANOIN (June 13, 1556 - May 18, 1610) was a court noble, waka poet, and Kokugaku (National Learning) scholar who lived from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) into the early Edo period.

literature.name: The Nijo School
literature.desc: The Nijo school (Nijo-ha) was a medieval waka poetry school, which had its own specific style and philosophy.

literature.name: The Kyogoku School
literature.desc: The Kyogoku school (Kyogokuha) was a school of waka poetry that existed from the middle of the Kamakura period into the beginning of the Muromachi period.

literature.name: The Reizei School
literature.desc: The Reizei school ("Reizeiha" in Japanese) is a school of waka poetry composition that began in the mid Kamakura period and continues to the present day.

literature.name: MIYAKO no Yoshika
literature.desc: MIYAKO no Yoshika (834 - March 25, 879) was a literatus and kanshi (Chinese verse) poet who lived in the early Heian period.

literature.name: SUGAWARA no Kiyokimi
literature.desc: SUGAWARA no Kiyokimi (also "Kiyotomo," 770 -November 26, 842) was the early Heian period court noble and literatus.

literature.name: Dai Nihon Yashi (Unofficial History of Japan)
literature.url: literature/Dai Nihon Yashi (Unofficial History of Japan).html
literature.desc: Dai Nihon Yashi is a Japanese history book written in a style of biographical historiography, and covers the 21 Emperors' reigns from Emperor Gokomatsu (Meitoku era) to Emperor Ninko.

literature.name: Naoeban
literature.desc: Naoeban is the Naoe edition of Chinese classic, 'Monzen' (Wen-hsuan, ancient Chinese poems), published by Kanetsugu NAOE, Karo (chief retainer) for the Uesugi clan, in 1607.

literature.name: Iya Yotsugi
literature.desc: Iya Yotsugi is a history book covering the reigns of two Emperors, Emperor Takakura and Emperor Antoku, and is said to have been written by FUJIWARA no Takanobu in the early Kamakura period, although it is no longer extant.

literature.name: Kosodate Yurei (A Ghost Caring for Her Baby)
literature.url: literature/Kosodate Yurei (A Ghost Caring for Her Baby).html
literature.desc: Kosodate Yurei is a Japanese folktale.

literature.name: New thirty-six major poets
literature.desc: New thirty-six major poets is the name given to certain distinguished poets.

literature.name: Giten Gensho
literature.desc: Giten Gensho (1393-April 17, 1462) was a priest of the Rinzai Sect of Buddhism in the mid-Muromachi period.

literature.name: Hanazono Tenno Shinki (The Records of Emperor Hanazono)
literature.url: literature/Hanazono Tenno Shinki (The Records of Emperor Hanazono).html
literature.desc: Hanazono Tenno Shinki is a diary of Emperor Hanazono.

literature.name: Entairyaku
literature.desc: Entairyaku is a diary of Kinkata TOIN, a court noble called 'Nakazono Dajodaijin' (Grand Minister) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

literature.name: Ichidai Yoki
literature.desc: Ichidai Yoki is one of the chronicles.

literature.name: Fuso Ryakki (A Brief History of Japan)
literature.url: literature/Fuso Ryakki (A Brief History of Japan).html
literature.desc: Fuso Ryakki is a history book privately selected in the Heian period.

literature.name: Kotokunikyo ki
literature.desc: Kotokunikyo ki is a diary of Kotokuni YAMASHINA, a court noble in the Muromachi period.

literature.name: Sanetaka Koki
literature.desc: Sanetaka Koki is a diary written by Sanetaka SANJONISHI, a court noble in the late Muromachi period.

literature.name: Shin Shoku Kokin Wakashu (NEW Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry Continued)
literature.url: literature/Shin Shoku Kokin Wakashu (NEW Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry Continued).html
literature.desc: "Shin Shoku Kokin Wakashu" is an anthology compiled by imperial command in the Muromachi period.

literature.name: Seisuisho (Laughter to Wake Readers from Their Sleep)
literature.url: literature/Seisuisho (Laughter to Wake Readers from Their Sleep).html
literature.desc: Seisuisho is a collection of comical stories which widely circulated among the common people.

literature.name: Taketori Monogatari (The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter)
literature.url: literature/Taketori Monogatari (The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter).html
literature.desc: It is said that Taketori Monogatari is the oldest tale in Japan.

literature.name: Heihan ki
literature.desc: Heihan ki (or Hyohan ki) is a diary written by TAIRA no Nobunori who was a court noble in the Heian period.

literature.name: Go-Nijo Moromichi-ki (The Diary of Fujiwara Moromichi)
literature.url: literature/Go-Nijo Moromichi-ki (The Diary of Fujiwara Moromichi).html
literature.desc: Go-Nijo Moromichi-ki (The Diary of Fujiwara Moromichi) is a diary written by FUJIWARA no Moromichi, who was active during the late Heian period.

literature.name: Yugao (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Yugao (Evening face) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Masasuke's Notes on Court Costume
literature.desc: Masasuke's Notes on Court Costume is a book on court costume and lore written in kana that appeared at the end of the Heian period.

literature.name: Tokushi Yoron
literature.desc: Tokushi Yoron (Lessons from History) is a political history of Japan and historical essay written by Hakuseki ARAI, a scholar and politician of the Edo period.

literature.name: Kenrei Monin Ukyo no Daibu Shu (The Poetic Memoirs of Lady Daibu)
literature.url: literature/Kenrei Monin Ukyo no Daibu Shu (The Poetic Memoirs of Lady Daibu).html
literature.desc: Kenrei Monin Ukyo no Daibu Shu (The Poetic Memoirs of Lady Daibu) was a private collection compiled in the early Kamakura period with approximately 360 poems (including poetic exchanges with others).

literature.name: The Shinkokushi (The New National History)
literature.desc: The Shinkokushi is a national history of Japan that is said to have been compiled in the 10th century, following the "Nihon Sandai Jitsuroku" (Veritable Records of Three Reigns of Japan), the last of the Rikkokushi (Six National Histories).

literature.name: Sarumino (Monkey's Raincoat)
literature.desc: Sarumino is a collection of Shomon (Basho School) which contains hokku (the first lines of waka poems) and renku (linked verses) and was edited by Kyorai MUKAI and Boncho NOZAWA.

literature.name: Kyureki (The Diary of FUJIWARA no Morosuke)
literature.url: literature/Kyureki (The Diary of FUJIWARA no Morosuke).html
literature.desc: The Kyureki is a diary by Minister of the Right FUJIWARA no Morosuke, a court noble in the mid-Heian period and the ancestor of the Kujo lineage, one of the styles of court protocol.

literature.name: Hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons)
literature.url: literature/Hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons).html
literature.desc: Hyakki yagyo, or hyakki yako (Night Parade of One Hundred Demons) are stories about troops of demons and monsters wandering in a group in a city in the middle of the night in a parade, appearing in setsuwa (anecdotes).

literature.name: Oyudono no ue no nikki (Daily Records of the Honorable Lady of the Imperial Office of Housekeeping)
literature.url: literature/Oyudono no ue no nikki (Daily Records of the Honorable Lady of the Imperial Office of Housekeeping).html
literature.desc: Oyudono no ue no nikki (Daily Records of the Honorable Lady of the Imperial Office of Housekeeping) is a daily record that was kept through the years by lower-ranking court ladies at the Imperial court.

literature.name: Chikanaga-kyo ki (The Diary of Chikanaga KANROJI)
literature.url: literature/Chikanaga-kyo ki (The Diary of Chikanaga KANROJI).html
literature.desc: Chikanaga-kyo ki is the diary of Chikanaga KANROJI, a court noble in the late Muromachi period.

literature.name: Angen onga no nikki
literature.desc: Angen onga no nikki is a diary in which the celebration of Emperor Goshirakawa's 50th birthday was recorded by FUJIWARA no Takafusa, a waka poet who lived in the Heian period.

literature.name: NAKAYAMA Kanemune
literature.desc: Kanemune NAKAYAMA (1163 - October 5, 1242) was a court noble and a waka poet who lived in the Heian period.

literature.name: Jokyuki (A Chronicle of the Jokyu Disturbance)
literature.url: literature/Jokyuki (A Chronicle of the Jokyu Disturbance).html
literature.desc: Jokyuki is a war tale concerning the Jokyu Disturbance which occurred between the Imperial court and bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and resulted from Emperor Gotoba taking up arms in 1221.

literature.name: Kikki
literature.desc: Kikki is a diary written by Tsunefusa YOSHIDA (1142-1200), a court noble who lived in the late Heian period.

literature.name: Shoryoshu (Collected Works of Prose and Poetry of Kukai)
literature.url: literature/Shoryoshu (Collected Works of Prose and Poetry of Kukai).html
literature.desc: "Shoryoshu" is a collection of poetry and prose which was written by Kukai.

literature.name: Aki no Yonaga Monogatari (Tales of Long Autumn Nights)
literature.url: literature/Aki no Yonaga Monogatari (Tales of Long Autumn Nights).html
literature.desc: "Aki no Yonaga Monogatari" is a representative chigo monogatari (tales of chigo, or page), about male homosexuality between priests and chigo.

literature.name: Kakimon-in
literature.desc: Kakimon-in (dates of birth and death unknown) was Nyoin (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor) and a female waka poet in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

literature.name: REIZEI Tamehiro
literature.desc: Tamehiro REIZEI (1450-August 30, 1526) was a Japanese waka poet.

literature.name: Yoshino Tayu (a courtesan of the highest rank)
literature.url: literature/Yoshino Tayu (a courtesan of the highest rank).html
literature.desc: Yoshino Tayu II (April 10, 1606 - October 7, 1643) was a Tayu of Shimabara (later moved to Shimabara), who was said to have been born near the Hoko-ji Temple in Kyoto, and her real name was Tokuko MATSUDA.

literature.name: Ise shu (Collection of Ise)
literature.desc: Ise shu is a personal collection of poems by Ise (a poet), who lived during the Heian period.

literature.name: Shin Sarugoki
literature.desc: Shin Sarugoki is a work written by FUJIWARA no Akihira, a scholar who lived in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: MATSUO Basho
literature.desc: Basho MATSUO (1644 - November 28, 1694) was a haikai (seventeen-syllable verse) poet from present-day Iga City, Mie Prefecture in the early Edo period.

literature.name: Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)
literature.desc: Nihonshoki (also referred to as Yamatobumi) is a Japanese history book established in the Nara period.

literature.name: Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters)
literature.desc: According to Kojiki's preface, Kojiki is the oldest Japanese history book dedicated by O no Asomi Yasumaro (or may be called the O no Yasumaro) in 712.

literature.name: The Murasaki Shikibu Diary
literature.desc: "The Murasaki Shikibu Diary" is said to have been written by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Kigo (Season Words)
literature.desc: Kigo, season word or kidai, seasonal topic (in haiku poetry) is a word symbolizing a given season and it is considered desirable that one of either kigo or kidai be contained in a haiku poetry.

literature.name: Heike Monogatari (The tale of the Heike)
literature.url: literature/Heike Monogatari (The tale of the Heike).html
literature.desc: "Heike Monogatari" is a war chronicle which deals with the prosperity and downfall of the Taira family, and seems to have been completed during the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Oku no Hosomichi (The Narrow Road to the Deep North)
literature.url: literature/Oku no Hosomichi (The Narrow Road to the Deep North).html
literature.desc: The Narrow Road to the Deep North is a travelogue written by Basho MATSUO in the Genroku era.

literature.name: Nihon Genho Zenaku Ryoiki (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early 9th century, usually referred to as the Nihon Ryouiki)
literature.url: literature/Nihon Genho Zenaku Ryoiki (set of three books of Buddhist stories, written in the late 8th and early.html
literature.desc: Nihon Genho Zenaku Ryoiki (also known as Nihonkoku Genho Zenaku Ryoiiki) is Japan's oldest collection of anecdotes written in the early Heian period.

literature.name: Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry)
literature.url: literature/Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry).html
literature.desc: "Kokin Wakashu" was the first anthology of poems collected by Imperial command.

literature.name: KAMO no Chomei
literature.desc: KAMO no Chomei (1155 - July 26, 1216) was a famous Japanese poet and essayist who lived from the late Heian period to the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Wakan konkobun (mixed writing of Japanese and Chinese)
literature.url: literature/Wakan konkobun (mixed writing of Japanese and Chinese).html
literature.desc: Wakan konkobun was a Japanese writing style generated in the late Heian period.

literature.name: Kaifuso (Fond Recollections of Poetry)
literature.desc: "Kaifuso" is the oldest Japanese collection of Chinese poems in existence.

literature.name: Thirty-six Master Poets
literature.desc: The Thirty-Six Master Poets is a collective term for the 36 master waka poets included in "the Thirty-six Master Poets Selection" as selected by FUJIWARA no Kinto.

literature.name: The Medieval 36 Immortal Poets
literature.desc: The Medieval 36 Immortal Poets is a collective term for the 36 master poets of waka included in "Nochi no Rokurokusen" (an anthology of poems collected by FUJIWARA no Norikane) compiled by FUJIWARA no Norikane.

literature.name: Hanachirusato
literature.desc: Hanachirusato is

literature.name: Ukiyo Zoshi (stories of the floating world)
literature.url: literature/Ukiyo Zoshi (stories of the floating world).html
literature.desc: Ukiyo Zoshi is one of the major literary forms in the early Kinsei Bungaku (Japanese Edo period literature).

literature.name: Otogi Zoshi (illustrated story books)
literature.desc: Otogi Zoshi are illustrated short stories, and the style, established during the Muromachi period into the Edo period.

literature.name: Kana Zoshi
literature.desc: Kana Zoshi refers collectively to stories/practical texts of Kinsei Bungaku (Japanese Edo period literature) written in kana characters, or a mixture of kanji and kana, during the early Edo period.

literature.name: Fushikaden (Flowering spirit)
literature.desc: Fushikaden is a treatise on Noh (traditional masked dance-drama) written by Zeami.

literature.name: Senzai Wakashu
literature.desc: Senzai Wakashu is one of the Chokusen Wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command).

literature.name: KIYOHARA no Motosuke
literature.desc: KIYOHARA no Motosuke (908 - June 990) was a poet and a scholar who lived during the Heian period.

literature.name: Haikai (seventeen-syllable verse)
literature.desc: Haikai is a form of Japanese literature (or a work of haikai) that generally flourished during the Edo period.

literature.name: Danrin-ha (Danrin school of haiku)
literature.desc: Danrin-ha was a shool of Haikai (seventeen-syllable verse) in the Edo period, which flourished under Soin NISHIYAMA.

literature.name: TAKASHINA no Kishi/Takako
literature.desc: TAKASHINA no Kishi/Takako (date of birth unknown -October 966) was a female poet who lived in the Heian period.

literature.name: Thirty Six Immortal Women Poets
literature.desc: The term "Thirty Six Immortal Women Poets" refers to the thirty-six female poets whose poems were selected for the 'Poetry Contest of the Thirty Six Lady Poets,' which was established in the middle of the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Shika Wakashu (Shika Collection of Japanese Poems)
literature.url: literature/Shika Wakashu (Shika Collection of Japanese Poems).html
literature.desc: Shika Wakashu is the sixth Chokusen Wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command) of the Hachidaishu (the eight Imperial anthologies of Japanese poetry).

literature.name: Kinyo Wakashu (Kinyo Collection of Japanese Poems)
literature.url: literature/Kinyo Wakashu (Kinyo Collection of Japanese Poems).html
literature.desc: Kinyo Wakashu is the fifth Chokusen Wakashu (anthologies of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command), and it was completed before "Shika Wakashu" (Shika Collection of Japanese Poems) and after "Goshui Wakashu" (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poetry).

literature.name: Goshui Wakashu (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poetry)
literature.url: literature/Goshui Wakashu (Later Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poetry).html
literature.desc: Goshui Wakashu is the fourth Chokusen Wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command) of the Hachidaishu (the eight Imperial anthologies of Japanese poetry), and it came out after "Shui Wakashu" (Collection of Gleanings of Japanese Poetry).

literature.name: Makurakotoba
literature.desc: Makurakotoba (枕詞) is a rhetorical device which is used mainly in Japanese poetry, and the word(s) which is placed before the particular words to make pairs to adjust the tones of the words or to add to a kind of atmosphere.

literature.name: Shui wakashu
literature.desc: "Shui wakashu" is the third imperial anthology of Japanese poetry after Kokin wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese poems) and Gosen wakashu (Later Collection of Japanese poems), and is the last one of the so called 'Sandai shu' (The Collections of Three Eras).

literature.name: Gosenwakashu (Later Collection of Japanese Poetry)
literature.desc: Gosenwakashu is the second imperial waka (Japanese poetry) collection compiled in response to a command issued by Emperor Murakami.

literature.name: Ise Monogatari
literature.desc: "Ise Monogatari" (The Tales of Ise) is a poetry narrative completed in the early Heian period.

literature.name: Mother of FUJIWARA no Michitsuna
literature.desc: The mother of FUJIWARA no Michitsuna (c. 936 - June 7, 995) was a waka poet in the mid Heian period.

literature.name: Shoku Nihongi (Chronicle of Japan Continued)
literature.desc: Shoku Nihongi is a collection of history books which was compiled by Imperial command in the early Heian period.

literature.name: Utsuho Monogatari (The tale of the Cavern)
literature.url: literature/Utsuho Monogatari (The tale of the Cavern).html
literature.desc: Utsuho Monogatari ("うつほ物語," sometimes entitled "宇津保物語") is a full-length tale written in the mid Heian period in Japan.

literature.name: Tsutsumi Chunagon Monogatari
literature.desc: Tsutsumi Chunagon Monogatari (The Riverside Counselor's Tales) is a collection of short stories edited in the late Heian period or later in Japan.

literature.name: Torikaebaya Monogatari (The Changelings)
literature.desc: "Torikaebaya Monogatari" is a narrative that was completed in the late Heian period.

literature.name: TAIRA no Tadanori
literature.desc: TAIRA no Tadanori was a Japanese military commander in the Heian period.

literature.name: FUNYA no Yasuhide
literature.desc: FUNYA no Yasuhide (year of birth unknown - c. 885) was a waka poet in the early Heian period and one of Rokkasen (six best waka poets) and the 36 Immortal Poets.

literature.name: Ryojin Hisho
literature.desc: Ryojin hisho was a folk song collection compiled in the end of Heian period.

literature.name: Sakkai ki
literature.desc: Sakkai ki is a diary written by Sadachika NAKAYAMA, Gon Dainagon (chief councilor of state) and Danjoin (President of the Board of Censors).

literature.name: Akazome Emon
literature.desc: Akazome Emon (approximately 956 - after 1041) was a nyobo (court lady) and a waka poet in the Heian period.

literature.name: OTOMO no Kuronushi
literature.desc: OTOMO no Kuronushi (years of birth and death unknown) was a kajin (waka poet) in the Heian period.

literature.name: Kisen
literature.desc: Kisen

literature.name: KI no Tomonori
literature.desc: KI no Tomonori (c. 845 - 907) was kajin in the Heian period.

literature.name: Heiji Monogatari (The Tale of Heiji)
literature.desc: "Heiji Monogatari" is a war chronicle concerning the Heiji War.

literature.name: Semimaru
literature.desc: Semimaru (years of birth and death unknown) was a waka poet and musician in the early Heian period.

literature.name: TAIRA no Kanemori
literature.desc: TAIRA no Kanemori (date of birth unknown -January 21, 991) was a poet who lived in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: The Diary of Sanukinosuke
literature.desc: Sanukinosuke Nikki (The Diary of Sanukinosuke) is a piece of literature in the form of a diary, written by Sanuki no suke (her court name) FUJIWARA no Nagako during the late Heian period.

literature.name: Nijuichidaishu
literature.desc: Nijuichidaishu is a collective term for the 21 anthologies compiled by Imperial command as a state project, beginning with "Kokin Wakashu" (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry) and ending with "Shinshoku Kokin Wakashu" (The New Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry Continued).

literature.name: Kagero Diary (The Gossamer Years)
literature.desc: "Kagero Diary" is a diary of a female writer who lived during the Heian period.

literature.name: Renku
literature.desc: Renku refers to haikai no renga (humorous linked poem).

literature.name: Sarashina Nikki
literature.desc: "Sarashina Nikki" or "Sarashina no Nikki" (As I crossed a bridge of dreams) is a diary written by the daughter of SUGAWARA no Takasue in around the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Gyokuyo
literature.desc: "Gyokuyo" is a diary of Kanezane KUJO, who was Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) and Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state).

literature.name: Ochikubo monogatari (The Tale of Ochikubo)
literature.desc: "Ochikubo monogatari" (The Tale of Ochikubo) is a tale of Japan's middle ages, which reportedly originated around the end of the tenth century.

literature.name: Hamamatsu Chunagon Monogatari (The Tale of Hamamatsu Chunagon)
literature.url: literature/Hamamatsu Chunagon Monogatari (The Tale of Hamamatsu Chunagon).html
literature.desc: Hamamatsu Chunagon Monogatari is a tale reportedly written by SUGAWARA no Takasue's daughter, who also wrote "Sarashina Nikki" (Sarashina Diary).

literature.name: SUGAWARA no Takasue no Musume
literature.desc: SUGAWARA no Takasue no musume (1008-ca. after 1059) was a noble woman who lived in the Heian period.

literature.name: Mizukagami (Water Mirror)
literature.desc: "Mizukagami" (Water Mirror) is a historical tale.

literature.name: Imakagami (The Mirror of the Present)
literature.desc: "Imakagami" is a historical tale.

literature.name: Uji Shui Monogatari (a collection of the Tales from Uji)
literature.url: literature/Uji Shui Monogatari (a collection of the Tales from Uji).html
literature.desc: Uji Shui Monogatari is a collection of setsuwa monogatari (narratives) of medieval Japan that was compiled in the first half of the thirteenth century.

literature.name: Izumi Shikibu Nikki (Diary of Izumi Shikibu)
literature.url: literature/Izumi Shikibu Nikki (Diary of Izumi Shikibu).html
literature.desc: "The Izumi Shikibu Nikki" is a diary written by Izumi Shikibu, and is a notable example of women's literature in diaries.

literature.name: Nashitsubo no Gonin (Five Gentlemen of the Pear Chamber)
literature.url: literature/Nashitsubo no Gonin (Five Gentlemen of the Pear Chamber).html
literature.desc: The "Nashitsubo no Gonin" represents the key members at the Waka-dokoro (the Imperial Bureau of Poetry) established by order of Emperor Murakami in 951 within the Shoyosha, which was one of the Shichiden-Gosha (seven residences and five houses for the Empress and other concubines) inside the Heian Imperial Palace.

literature.name: Tamakazura (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Tamakazura is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Chokusen Wakashu
literature.desc: The term "chokusen wakashu" represents an anthology of Japanese poetry complied under order of an emperor or a retired emperor.

literature.name: Jakuren
literature.desc: Jakuren (ca. 1139-August 9, 1202) was a poet and a monk who lived from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Zoku Kojidan
literature.desc: "The Zoku Kojidan" is a collection of narratives complied during the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: Ima Monotagari (Present-Day Tales)
literature.desc: "The Ima Monogatari" is a collection of narratives which was compiled in the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Kohon Setsuwashu (Collection of Old Tales)
literature.desc: "The Kohon Setsuwashu" is a narrative collection and is believed to have appeared during the end of the Heian period, or at the latest, during the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: Godansho (The Oe Conversations)
literature.desc: "Godansho," written as 江談抄 in Japanese, is a collection of narratives from the Insei period (during the period of the government by the retired Emperor).

literature.name: Fuga Wakashu
literature.desc: Fuga Wakashu is the seventeenth Imperial anthology.

literature.name: Shinyo Wakashu (Collection of New Pages)
literature.desc: Shinyo Wakashu is a collection of waka poetry compiled during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

literature.name: Nakatsukasa
literature.desc: Nakatsukasa (ca. 912-ca. 991) was a female poet who lived in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Kado (The art of versification)
literature.desc: Kado, which literally means an art of poems, is an art of creating waka (traditional Japanese poems of thirty-one syllables) and a study regarding waka itself (treatise on waka poetry and the study of waka).

literature.name: Suzumushi
literature.desc: Suzumushi is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: OBU Suesada
literature.desc: Suesada OBU (also known as MINAMOTO no Suesada) (years of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) and a poet who lived in the late Heian period.

literature.name: Wakana (new herbs) (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Wakana is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Yugiri (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Yugiri (Evening Mist) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Five Line Poems
literature.desc: Gogyoka (Five Line Poems, 五行歌) is a new type of poetry which utilizes ancient ballads and Waka (thirty-one-syllable poems) included in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihon Shoki" (The Chronicles of Japan) and is revived in modern times as prototypes of Japanese poetry.

literature.name: Minori (The Rites)
literature.desc: Minori is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Egyo
literature.desc: Egyo (the year of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese monk and a poet who lived during the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Maboroshi (The Wizard) (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Maboroshi is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Niou Miya
literature.desc: Niou Miya was one of the chapter titles of "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji) which has fifty four chapters.

literature.name: Kobai (The Rose Plum) (The Tale of Genji)
literature.url: literature/Kobai (The Rose Plum) (The Tale of Genji).html
literature.desc: Kobai is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Takekawa (Bamboo River)
literature.desc: Takekawa is a chapter title of "Genji Monogatari "(The Tale of Genji) which has fifty four chapters.

literature.name: Hashihime (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Hashihime is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Shiigamoto (Beneath the Oak)
literature.desc: Shiigamoto is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Tanka
literature.desc: Tanka (literally, short poems) is a type of waka poetry, and has a five-line poem with the 5-7-5-7-7 syllable structure.

literature.name: Haiku
literature.desc: Haiku is Japanese poetry structured in the set form of 5-7-5 syllables.

literature.name: Daini no Sanmi
literature.desc: Daini no Sanmi (ca. 999-ca. 1082) was a female poet who lived during the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Kyoka (comic/satirical tanka)
literature.desc: Kyoka is a parody of tanka (Japanese poem) that contains social satire, irony, and humor in 31 (5-7-5-7-7) syllables.

literature.name: Gikeiki
literature.desc: The "Gikeiki" is a war chronicle focused mainly on MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune and his retainers, and is believed to have been created either during the Nanbokucho period (Japan's period of Northern and Southern Courts) or at the beginning of the Muromachi period.

literature.name: Aoi no Ue
literature.desc: "Aoi no Ue" is a work of nogaku (the art of Noh) which is based on the chapter of 'Aoi' (Hollyhock) in "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Koshikibu no Naishi
literature.desc: Koshikibu no Naishi (ca. 999-November, 1025) was a female poet who lived during the Heian period.

literature.name: Tsutsuizutsu (Curb of a Well)
literature.desc: Tsutsuizutsu (also read as tsutsuitsutsu in some cases. It is written as 'tsutsuizutsu'(つつゐづつ) in the old kana notation) is a story in "Ise Monogatari" (The Tales of Ise) and "Yamato Monogatari" (The Tales of Yamato).

literature.name: Chikamoto Nikki (Chikamoto's Diary)
literature.desc: Chikamoto Nikki is the diary of Chikamoto NINAGAWA (Shinuemon no Jo), who was the deputy steward of the office of administration in the Muromachi Period.

literature.name: Wakamurasaki
literature.desc: Wakamurasaki is the title of one of 54 quires of Genji Monogatari (The Tale of Genji).

literature.name: Shikyo
literature.desc: The term "shikyo" refers to the four historical stories (history books with a narrative style) generically known as 'kagami-mono' (mirror works), which includes "O-kagami" (the Great Mirror), "Ima-kagami" (the Mirror of the Present), "Mizu-kagami" (the Water Mirror), and "Masu-kagami" (the Clear Mirror), that appeared between the late Heian period and the early Muromachi period.

literature.name: Intoku Taiheiki
literature.desc: The Intoku taiheiki is a work of Japanese literature.

literature.name: Noin
literature.desc: Noin (988-1058) was a monk and a poet who lived during the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Agemaki (Genji Monogatari (The Tale of Genji))
literature.desc: Agemaki is the name of one of the fifty-four chapters of "Genji Monogatari."

literature.name: Shomonki
literature.desc: "Shomonki" is an early war chronicle that details TAIRA no Masakado's War, which occurred in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region) in the middle of the tenth century.

literature.name: Sawarabi (Early Ferns)
literature.desc: Sawarabi is one of the fifty-four chapters of "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji).

literature.name: Shune
literature.desc: Shune (1113 - ca. 1191) was a priest and poet in the late Heian period.

literature.name: INPUMONIN no Daifu
literature.desc: INPUMONIN no Daifu (ca. 1130 - ca. 1200) was a court lady and poet in the late Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Kiyosuke
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Kiyosuke (1104 - July 17, 1177) was a court noble and poet at the end of the Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Atsuyori
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Atsuyori (1090 - ca. 1182) was a court noble and poet in the late Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Akisuke
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Akisuke (1090 - June 8, 1155) was a court noble and poet in the late Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Sadayori
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Sadayori (995 - February 8, 1045) was a court noble and poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: ONAKATOMI no Yoshinobu
literature.desc: ONAKATOMI no Yoshinobu (921 - August 991) was a poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: ONAKATOMI no Sukechika
literature.desc: ONAKATOMI no Sukechika (954 - July 6, 1038) was a poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: ISE no Taifu (Osuke)
literature.desc: ISE no Taifu (also known as Osuke) (ca. 989 - ca. 1060) was a lady poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Domyo
literature.desc: Domyo (974-July 26, 1020) was a priest and poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Atsutada
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Atsutada (906 - April 18, 943) was a court noble and poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Asatada
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Asatada (910 - January 19, 967) was a court noble and poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Yoshitaka
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Yoshitaka (954 - November 8, 974) was a court noble and poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Tsunenobu
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Tsunenobu (1016 - February 20, 1097) was a noble and waka poet who lived in the late Heian Period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Mototoshi
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Mototoshi (1060-Feburary 20, 1142) was a court noble and poet of the late Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Toshiyori
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Toshiyori (1055-January 29, 1129) was a official and poet of the late Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Okikaze
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Okikaze (year of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese noble and poet of the Heian period.

literature.name: KIYOHARA no Fukayabu
literature.desc: KIYOHARA no Fukayabu (year of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Shigeyuki
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Shigeyuki (? - around 1000?) was a poet of the mid-Heian period

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Muneyuki
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Muneyuki (year of birth unknown - January 9, 940)was a poet of the early to mid-Heian period.

literature.name: OE no Chisato (poet)
literature.desc: OE no Chisato (year of birth and death unknown, male) was a poet and scholar of the early Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Kanemasa
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Kanemasa (year of birth and death unknown) was a poet of the middle to late-Heian period.

literature.name: Nijoin no Sanuki
literature.desc: Nijoin no Sanuki (Sanuki of Nijoin, ca. 1141 - ca. 1217) was a poetess of the late Heian and the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: Kokamonin no Betto
literature.desc: Kokamonin no Betto (year of birth and death unknown) was a poetess of the late Heian period.

literature.name: Yushi Naishinno-ke no Kii
literature.desc: Yushi Naishinno-ke no Kii (Kii of Princess Yushi's Household, year of birth and death unknown) was a poetess during the cloistered government period of the Heian period, and a lady-in-waiting to the Imperial Princess Yushi, the daughter of the Emperor Gosuzaku.

literature.name: Suo no Naishi
literature.desc: Suo no Naishi (c. 1037-1109) was a female waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) poet during the late Heian Period.

literature.name: SONE no Yoshitada
literature.desc: SONE no Yoshitada (year of birth and death unknown) was a poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Ukon (poetess)
literature.desc: Ukon (year of birth and death unknown) was a poetess of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Hitoshi
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Hitoshi (880 - March 951) was a noble who lived in the early to middle Heian Period.

literature.name: MIBU no Tadami
literature.desc: MIBU no Tadami (dates of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUNYA no Asayasu
literature.desc: FUNYA no Asayasu (dates of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: HARUMICHI no Tsuraki
literature.desc: HARUMICHI no Tsuraki (date of birth unknown - 920) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: SAKANOUE no Korenori
literature.desc: SAKANOUE no Korenori (date of birth unknown - 930) was a Japanese poet of the early and the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Sarumaru no Taifu
literature.desc: Sarumaru no Taifu, or Sarumarudayu (years of birth and death not know) was one of the thirty-six immortal poets.

literature.name: SAKANOUE no Mochiki
literature.desc: SAKANOUE no Mochiki (dates of birth and death unknown) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: KI no Tokibumi
literature.desc: KI no Tokibumi (c. 922 - c. 996) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Kintada
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Kintada (889 - December 7, 948) was a Japanese official and poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Saneakira
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Saneakira (910 - 970) was a Japanese official and poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Takamitsu
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Takamitsu (c. 939 － 994) was a Japanese poet of the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: ONAKATOMI no Yorimoto
literature.desc: ONAKATOMI no Yorimoto (c. 886 - c. 958) was a waka poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Kookimi
literature.desc: Kookimi (date of birth and death unknown) was a female waka poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Zoki
literature.desc: Zoki (years of birth and death not known) was a priest and waka poet who lived in the Heian Period.

literature.name: OE no Masahira
literature.desc: OE no Masahira (952 - August 12, 1012) was a Confucian and poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Yadorigi
literature.desc: Yadoriki is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: OE no Yoshitoki
literature.desc: OE no Yoshitoki

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Nagato
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Nagato (949 - c. 1009) was a waka poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Takato
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Takato (949 - June 22, 1013) was a waka poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Michinari
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Michinari (year of birth unknown - 1019) was a government official (esp. one of low to medium rank) and a waka poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: ARIWARA no Muneyana
literature.desc: ARIWARA no Muneyana (year of birth unknown - 898) was a waka poet in the early Heian period.

literature.name: ARIWARA no Motokata
literature.desc: ARIWARA no Motokata (year of birth and death unknown) was a waka poet in the Heian period.

literature.name: Uma no naishi
literature.desc: Uma no naishi (year of birth and death unknown) was a female poet in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Azumaya
literature.desc: Azumaya is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Ukifune (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Ukifune is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Kagero (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Kagero is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: INAWASHIRO Kensai
literature.desc: Kensai INAWASHIRO (1452 - July 21, 1510) was a renga poet (linked-verse poet) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan).

literature.name: Shua
literature.desc: Shua (year of birth unknown - c. 1377) was a renga poet (linked-verse poet) in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) who belonged to the ordinary people class.

literature.name: Abutsuni
literature.desc: Abutsuni (1222 ? - May 13, 1283) was a female waka (traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) poet in the mid Kamakura period.

literature.name: Keisei
literature.desc: Keisei (1189 - November 18, 1268) was a Buddhist priest in the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Kenreimonin Ukyo no Daibu
literature.desc: Kenreimonin Ukyo no Daibu (c. 1157 - year of death unknown) was a female waka poet from the end of Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: Tenarai
literature.desc: Tenarai is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Yume no Ukihashi
literature.desc: Ume no Ukihashi is the 54th (last) chapter of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Rokujosaiin no senji
literature.desc: Rokujosaiin no senji (year of birth and death is not clear) was a female waka poet in the late Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Michitoshi
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Michitoshi (1047 - September 9, 1099) was a court noble as well as a waka poet in the late Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Nagako
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Nagako (c. 1079 - year of death not known) was a female waka poet in the late Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Tamenori
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Tamenori (date of birth unknown - September, 1011) was a literary person and a composer of Chinese poems in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Morofusa
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Morofusa (1008 - March 20, 1077) was a kuge (court noble) and kajin (waka poet) in the mid Heian period.

literature.name: KI no Yoshimochi
literature.desc: KI no Yoshimochi (date of birth unknown - 919) was a Confucian and a kajin (waka poet) in the mid Heian period.

literature.name: Kagaku (study of waka)
literature.desc: Kagaku is a study that researches everything related to waka, such as its essence and mannerisms, the interpretation of old waka, ancient practices and history.

literature.name: Choka (long epic song)
literature.desc: Choka is a form of waka (Japanese poem).

literature.name: Shinsen Tsukuba Shu
literature.desc: Shinsen Tsukuba Shu is a Jun chokusen renga senshu (anthology of renga) in the late Muromachi era.

literature.name: Keien School
literature.desc: Keien School is a school of Waka (Japanese poem) led by Kageki KAGAWA (1768-1843), a poet in the late Edo period.

literature.name: Dewa no ben
literature.desc: Dewa no ben (around 1007? - date of death unknown) was a female waka poet in the mid Heian period.

literature.name: Asukai family
literature.desc: The Asukai is a branch family of the Nanba family in the FUJIWARA no Morozane line of the Northern House of the Fujiwara clan.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Nagaie
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Nagaie (October 2, 1005 - December 25, 1064) was a court noble and a kajin (waka poet) in the end of the Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Nagakata
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Nagakata (1139 - April 12, 1191) was a court noble and a kajin (waka poet) in the end of the Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Motozane
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Motozane (date of birth and death unknown) was a kajin (waka poet) in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Nakafumi
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Nakafumi (923 to 992) was a kajin (waka poet) in the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Chuyuki
literature.desc: Chuyuki is a diary written by FUJIWARA no Munetada, Nakamikado Udaijin (Minister of the Right), for over 50 years from 1087 to 1138.

literature.name: Kanmon Nikki
literature.desc: Kanmon Nikki is the diary of Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadafusa (Gosukoin, 1372 - 1456).

literature.name: Taiki
literature.desc: Taiki is a diary of FUJIWARA no Yorinaga, Uji-sadaijin (Minister of the Left).

literature.name: Teishinko-ki
literature.desc: Teishinko-ki is the diary of Kanpaku Dajodaijin (imperial regent and grand minister) FUJIWARA no Tadahira.

literature.name: Kashu
literature.desc: In the world of dynastic poems, "kashu" is a collection of waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) compiled from personal or family poems.

literature.name: Mutsuwaki
literature.desc: "Mutsuwa-ki" is a war chronicle that depicts the details of Japan's Early Nine-Years War.

literature.name: Toshi Kaden
literature.desc: The "Toshi Kaden" was written in 760.

literature.name: The tale of Soga
literature.desc: The tale of Soga is a war chronicle based on 'Revenge of Soga Brothers.'

literature.name: Kiritsubo
