literature.desc: Kiritsubo (The Paulownia Court) is one of the smaller houses of kokyu (seven larger houses and five smaller ones which were mainly empress's residences) in the Heian Imperial Palace.

literature.name: Wakan Roei Shu (Collection of Sung Japanese and Chinese poems)
literature.url: literature/Wakan Roei Shu (Collection of Sung Japanese and Chinese poems).html
literature.desc: "Wakan Roei Shu" (Collection of Sung Japanese and Chinese poems) is a collection of poetry compiled by FUJIWARA no Kinto.

literature.name: Sagoromo Monogatari
literature.desc: "Sagoromo Monogatari" (The Tale of Sagoromo) is a story written at the end of the dynastic era of the Heian period.

literature.name: Yowa no Nezame (Awaken at Midnight)
literature.desc: "Yowa no Nezame" is a story of the ocho monogatari (tales of the Heian and Kamakura periods) written in the latter half of the Heian period (supposedly around the latter half of 11th century).

literature.name: The Tale of Heichu
literature.desc: Heichu monogatari (The Tale of Heichu) (written 平中物語 or 平仲物語) is a story told through poems that was completed during the Heian period.

literature.name: The Set of a Hundred Poems
literature.url: literature/The Set of a Hundred Poems.html
literature.desc: Hyakushuuta (The Set of One Hundred Poems, 百首歌) consists of one hundred poems as a unit, which are a type of waka composed with a predetermined number.

literature.name: Korai Futeisho
literature.desc: Korai Futeisho is a textbook on poetry that was completed during the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: Gonki
literature.desc: "Gonki" is a diary of FUJIWARA no Yukinari, who lived during the middle of the Heian period.

literature.name: Tokinoriki
literature.desc: Tokinoriki is a diary written by a court official named TAIRA no Tokinori during the Heian period.

literature.name: Uji Jujo
literature.desc: Uji jujo (The Ten Quires of Uji) is the latter half of the third, last part of Genji Monogatari (the Tale of Genji.)

literature.name: Kakekotoba
literature.desc: Kakekotoba (a pivot word) is a rhetorical device used in waka poetry.

literature.name: Utsusemi (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Utsusemi is the cast-off skin of a cicada (order: Pentatomidae), when it hatches.

literature.name: Suetsumuhana (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Suetsumuhana (The Safflower) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Rakushu
literature.desc: A rakushu (a satirical poem with a 31 syllable verse) is a vehicle of expression which was prevalent from the Heian to the Edo period.

literature.name: Asagao (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Asagao (The Morning Glory) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Aobyoshi-bon (Blue Book) Manuscripts
literature.desc: Among the manuscripts of The Tale of Genji, Aobyoshi-bon (Blue Book) manuscripts designate the ones which seem to have been transcribed by FUJIWARA no Teika, and also the ones which are said to have been transcribed from Teika's manuscript.

literature.name: Oshima-bon Manuscript
literature.desc: Oshima-bon is one of the older manuscripts of "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji).

literature.name: The Tale of Shinobine
literature.desc: The Tale of Shinobine refers to a courtly romance which was completed at the end of the Heian period and was subsequently lost, or to an adaptation of a story produced during the period of Southern and Northern Courts (Japan).

literature.name: Toshiyori's Poetic Essentials
literature.desc: "Toshiyori Zuino" (Toshiyori's Poetic Essentials) is a book with essays on tanka poetry written by MINAMOTO no Toshiyori.

literature.name: Tale of China
literature.desc: Kara monogatari (Tales of China) is a collection of Japanese adaptations of ancient Chinese stories in the form of uta monogatari (poem-tale).

literature.name: Yamaji no Tsuyu
literature.desc: Yamaji no tsuyu (Dew on the Mountain Road) is one of the sequels to "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Gyohen
literature.desc: Gyohen (year of birth and death unknown) was shaso (shrine priest) of Kumano-hayatama-taisha Shrine who did very splendid work from the late Heian period to the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: Engo
literature.desc: Engo (verbal association) is a rhetorical technique in waka poetry, where two or more semantically associated words are used in a poem to express one's sentiments.

literature.name: Momiji no Ga
literature.desc: Momiji no Ga (The Autumn Excursion) is one of the fifty-four chapters of The Tale of Genji.

literature.name: Tentoku Dairi Uta-awase
literature.desc: Tentoku Dairi Uta-awase (Imperial Palace Poetry Contest in the Tentoku era) was a poetry contest hosted by Emperor Murakami on May 3, 960.

literature.name: Kashiwagi (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Kashiwagi is the name of a volume among the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Ruijusandaikyaku
literature.desc: Ruijusandaikyaku is a statute book published in the Heian period (probably in the 11th century).

literature.name: Jakucho
literature.desc: Jakucho (year of birth and death unknown) was a kajin (waka poet) during the end of the Heian period.

literature.name: Rakuyo Dengakuki
literature.desc: Rakuyo dengakuki is a book written by OE no Masafusa.

literature.name: Bunka Shureishu
literature.desc: Bunka Shureishu is a Chokusen Kanshishu (a collection of Chinese verses compiled by Imperial command) compiled at the command of Emperor Saga in 818 during the early Heian period.

literature.name: Ryounshu
literature.desc: Ryounshu (lit. a collection from above the clouds) is the first anthology of Chinese poems compiled in Japan by the command of Emperor Saga in 814 during the early Heian period.

literature.name: Keikokushu
literature.desc: Keikokushu is an anthology of Chinese poems compiled at the command of Emperor Junna in 827 during the early Heian period.

literature.name: Kinpisho
literature.desc: Kinpisho is a book written by the 84th Emperor Juntoku on the history and origin of imperial court ceremonies, whereby serving as an instruction manual for the rules and etiquette concerning such ceremonies.

literature.name: Shizen-ei
literature.desc: Shizen-ei (poems about nature) is a term for a type of tanka (thirty-one syllable poem) (also used in reference to haiku).

literature.name: Shakaiei
literature.desc: Shakaiei is a type of tanka as well as a haiku.

literature.name: Gyosei
literature.desc: Gyosei refers to documents (aside from decrees), poems and paintings that have been personally written or created by emperors or royal family members.

literature.name: Kawachibon
literature.desc: Kawachibon is a group of The Tale of Genji manuscripts allegedly created by Daikenmotsu (duty) MINAMOTO no Mitsuyuki and his son, MINAMOTO no Chikayuki, and their copies.

literature.name: The Tale of Genji Emaki
literature.desc: The Tale of Genji Emaki is a picture scroll depicting the subject matter of The Tale of Genji.

literature.name: Kogetsusho
literature.desc: Kogetsusho (The Tale of Genji Moon on the Lake Commentary) is a commentary on The Tale of Genji written by Kigin KITAMURA.

literature.name: Kagayaku Hinomiya
literature.desc: Kagayaku Hinomiya (Kakayaku Hinomiya) (The Shining Princess) is the title of a chapter of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Kumogakure
literature.desc: Kumogakure (literally, vanishing behind the clouds) is the title of one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Yokobue (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Yokobue (The Flute) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Kyuan Hyakushu
literature.desc: Kyuan Hyakushu is the Hundred-Poem sequences developed by the command of Sutokuin in 1150 during the late Heian period.

literature.name: Kyoun-shu
literature.desc: "Kyoun-shu" (Crazy Cloud Anthology) is a collection of Chinese poetry by Ikkyu Sojun which presents the insane and unconventional world.

literature.name: Dan no Ura Yoru no Kassenki
literature.url: literature/Dan no Ura Yoru no Kassenki.html
literature.desc: Dan no Ura Yoru no Kassenki is the title of a Japanese classic pornographic novel.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Kiyotada
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Kiyotada (date of birth unknown - July, 958) was a court noble and a poet who lived during the mid-Heian period.

literature.name: Shinsen Roei Shu
literature.desc: Shinsen Roei Shu (Newly Selected Collection Singing Poems) is a collection of Chinese poems compiled in Japan.

literature.name: Kanpyono Ontoki Kisainomiya Uta-awase
literature.desc: Kanpyono Ontoki Kisainomiya Uta-awase (Uta-awase held by the Empress during the Kanpyo period) was one of the poetry competitions, which consisted of one volume.

literature.name: Roei Hyakushu
literature.desc: The Roei Hyakushu (a hundred medieval Japanese court songs) is a set of waka written while keeping with a theme set by using verses in various anthologies like the Wakan Roei Shu (Collection of Japanese and Chinese Court Songs).

literature.name: Nise Murasaki Inaka Genji
literature.desc: "Nise Murasaki Inaka Genji" (The Tale of Genji during the Muromachi period) is an unfinished long gokan (bound-together volumes of illustrated books) written by Tanehiko RYUTEI.

literature.name: Kaidoki
literature.desc: Kaido-ki (Travel Diary) is a traveler's journal that is thought to have been written in 1223.

literature.name: Shinsenzai Wakashu
literature.desc: "Shinsenzai Wakashu" (New Collection of Japanese Poetry of a Thousand Years) is one of the chokusen wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by Imperial command).

literature.name: Shinshui Wakashu
literature.desc: "Shinshui Wakashu" (New Collection of Gleanings) is one of the chokusen wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by the Imperial command).

literature.name: Shingoshui Wakashu
literature.desc: "Shingoshui Wakashu" (New Later Collection of Gleanings) is one of the chokusen wakashu (anthology of Japanese poetry compiled by the Imperial command).

literature.name: Honcho Monzui
literature.desc: The "Honcho Monzui" (Anthology of waka poems and prose written in classical Chinese) was compiled by FUJIWARA no Akihira.

literature.name: Roei Gochu
literature.desc: Roei Gochu, written by OE no Masafusa, is a commentary on the Wakan Roei Shu (Japanese and Chinese singing poems).

literature.name: Hahakigi (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Hahakigi (The Broom Tree) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Genji monogatari taisei
literature.desc: Genji monogatari taisei (Comprehensive Study of The Tale of Genji) is a study of The Tale of Genji written and compiled by Kikan IKEDA, and it mainly dealt with the differences among the various versions of text.

literature.name: Narabi no maki
literature.desc: Narabi no maki (parallel chapters) is a name for a chapter which is parallel to another chapter in a work consisting of several volumes, or the chapters themselves called as such.

literature.name: Nochi no Kagami
literature.desc: "Nochi-kagami" is a history book compiled by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) which covers the 15 generations of the Muromachi bakufu.

literature.name: Eiri Genji monogatari
literature.desc: Eiri Genji monogatari (Illustrated Tale of Genji) is a printed book of The Tale of Genji which was published during the Edo period.

literature.name: ARIWARA no Shigeharu
literature.desc: ARIWARA no Shigeharu (dates of birth and death unknown) was a poet who lived during the first half of the Heian Period.

literature.name: Makura no Soshi Shunshosho
literature.desc: "Makura no Soshi Shunshosho" is a commentary on Makura no Soshi (The Pillow Book) written in the Edo period.

literature.name: Beppon
literature.desc: Beppon

literature.name: Old Genealogies on The Tale of Genji
literature.url: literature/Old Genealogies on The Tale of Genji.html
literature.desc: Among the genealogies of The Tale of Genji, in which characters in "The Tale of Genji" were systematically written in the form of genealogy as if they were the real people, Genji monogatari kokeizu (old genealogies on the Tale of Genji) refers to the ones that were made before the genealogy produced by Sanetaka SANJONISHI.

literature.name: The Preface to A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry
literature.url: literature/The Preface to A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry.html
literature.desc: Kokin Wakashu Kanajo (The Preface to "A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry") is a preface to Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry).

literature.name: A Chronicle of the Later Three Years War in Oshu
literature.url: literature/A Chronicle of the Later Three Years War in Oshu.html
literature.desc: Oshu Gosannen Ki (A Chronicle of the Later Three Years War in Oshu) describes the war which was called 'Gosannen no Eki' (The Later Three Years War) or 'MINAMOTO no Yoshiie war' that occurred from 1083 (latter part of the Heian period) to 1088 in the Mutsu and Dewa provinces.

literature.name: Kajin (Waka or Tanka Poets)
literature.desc: "Kajin" is a Japanese term used to refer to poets who write waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) or tanka (thirty-one-syllable poem).

literature.name: Zen-zen Taiheiki
literature.desc: "Zen-zen Taiheiki"is a war chronicle featuring the history from the Nara Period to the early Heian Period.

literature.name: Jokotoba (a preface word)
literature.desc: Jokotoba (a preface word) is a rhetoric used mainly in waka (traditional Japanese poems of thirty-one syllables), which is put before a certain word to modify it using a figure of speech, kakekotoba (a rhetoric in Waka in which one word has more than one meaning), and a homophone, etc.

literature.name: Sakaki
literature.desc: Sakaki (The Green Branch) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Hana no En
literature.desc: Hana no En (The Festival of the Cherry Blossoms) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Suma (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Suma is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Akashi (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Akashi is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Miotsukushi (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Miotsukushi (Channel Buoys) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Eawase
literature.desc: Eawase (A Picture Contest) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Matsukaze (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Matsukaze (Wind in the Pines) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Usugumo
literature.desc: Usugumo (Wisps of Cloud) is the one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Otome (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Otome (The Maidens) is the one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Hatsune (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Hatsune (The First Warbler) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Kocho (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Kocho (Butterflies) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Kagaribi
literature.desc: Kagaribi (The Cressets) is one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Fuji no uraba (Wisteria Leaves)
literature.desc: Fuji no uraba is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Hotaru (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Hotaru (The Fireflies) is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Tokonatsu (The Wild Carnation)
literature.desc: Tokonatsu is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Sekiya (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Sekiya (The Gatehouse) is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Yomogiu (A Wasteland of Weeds)
literature.desc: Yomogiu is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Nowaki (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Nowaki (The Typhoon) is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Makibashira (The Cypress Pillar)
literature.desc: Makibashira is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Miyuki (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Miyuki (The Imperial Progress) is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Fujibakama (Thoroughwort Flowers)
literature.desc: Fujibakama is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Umegae (The Plum Tree Branch)
literature.desc: Umegae is one of the 54 chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Kingyoku Wakashu (Gold gems poetry collection)
literature.desc: Kingyoku Wakashu is a personal collection of poetry written in the mid Heian period.

literature.name: Mumyosho
literature.desc: "Mumyosho" was a karon sho (a document of theory and criticism about classic Japanese poems) in the Kamakura period written by KAMO no Chomei.

literature.name: Honkatori
literature.desc: Honkatori is a technique used to create waka (a traditional Japanese poem of thirty-one syllables) in the study of Japanese poems to take in one or two phrases of old and famous poem (the original) to create a new poem.

literature.name: Rokkashu (the six great collections of poetry)
literature.url: literature/Rokkashu (the six great collections of poetry).html
literature.desc: Rokkashu are the six great private collections of poetry in the age of Shinkokin (Wakashu) (New Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry).

literature.name: Maigetsusho (The Monthly Commentary)
literature.desc: Maigetsusho (The Monthly Commentary) is a treatise on waka poetry written by a kajin (waka poet) FUJIWARA no Teika in 1219.

literature.name: Shinsen Inu Tsukuba Shu
literature.desc: Shinsen Inu Tsukuba shu is a collection of haikairenga (a type of linked verse) that was made during the second half of the Muromachi period.

literature.name: Eikyoki
literature.desc: "Eikyoki" is an account of war that covers the incidents ranging from the Eikyo War and Yuki War in the Muromachi period to the political circumstances in Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region).

literature.name: Genji Monogatari Toshidate (Chronologies)
literature.desc: The "Genji monogatari toshidate," also known as the "Genji monogatari toshidachi," chronologically organize the events in the world of the Tale of Genji on the basis of the age of the main character (Hikaru Genji in the first and the second part and Kaoru in the third part).

literature.name: The Thousandth Anniversary of the Tale of Genji
literature.url: literature/The Thousandth Anniversary of the Tale of Genji.html
literature.desc: The thousandth anniversary of the Tale of Genji refers to various events held to commemorate a thousand years since the Tale of Genji was written.

literature.name: Kumogakure Rokujo
literature.desc: Kumogakure Rokujo (Genji's demise: six chapters) is a supplementary work to the Tale of Genji.

literature.name: Wakatai jisshu (The Ten Styles of Japanese Poetry)
literature.url: literature/Wakatai jisshu (The Ten Styles of Japanese Poetry).html
literature.desc: "Wakatai jisshu" (The Ten Styles of Japanese Poetry) is a treatise on waka poetry written by MIBU no Tadamine, one of the compilers of Kokin Wakashu (A Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry).

literature.name: Kanna ninen dairi Utaawase (Utaawase held at the Imperial Palace in the Kanna period)
literature.url: literature/Kanna ninen dairi Utaawase (Utaawase held at the Imperial Palace in the Kanna period).html
literature.desc: "Kanna ninen dairi Utaawase is an utaawase" (poetry contest) held by Emperor Kazan on July 24, 986.

literature.name: Moshinsho
literature.desc: Moshinsho is a commentary on "The Tale of Genji," written by Tanemichi KUJO, the Kanpaku (regent) during the Sengoku (Period of Warring States) and Azuchi-Momoyama periods.

literature.name: Shofu-haikai (the right style haikai poetry)
literature.desc: "Shofu-haikai" is the word for the concept of haikai (seventeen-syllable verse) which Basho MATSUO completed.

literature.name: Sei Shonagon Makura no Soshi Sho
literature.url: literature/Sei Shonagon Makura no Soshi Sho.html
literature.desc: "Sei Shonagon Makura no Soshi Sho" is a book written in the Edo Period, commentaries on "Makura no Soshi"(the Pillow Book) written by Sei Shonagon.

literature.name: Makura no Soshi Bochu
literature.desc: "Makura no Soshi Bochu" is a book written in the Edo Period, which is a collection of marginal notes on "Makura no Soshi" (the Pillow Book).

literature.name: Kenchumikkan
literature.desc: "Kenchumikkan" is a book written by FUJIWARA no Teika in the early Kamakura Period, which is a collection of commentaries on "Kokin Wakashu" (Collection of Ancient and Modern Japanese Poetry).

literature.name: Genji Shaku
literature.desc: The Genji Shaku is a commentary on "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Rokujoin
literature.desc: Rokujoin (also known as Rokujo no in) can refer to:

literature.name: Okuiri
literature.desc: Okuiri is a commentary on the Tale of Genji written by FUJIWARA no Sadaie.

literature.name: Japanese Literature
literature.desc: Nihon bungaku (Japanese literature) refers either to literary works written in Japanese or to the academic field that studies such works and their authors.

literature.name: Hikaru Genji
literature.desc: Hikaru Genji is a main character in "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji), written by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Murasaki no ue
literature.desc: Murasaki no ue is a heroine in "The Tale of Genji," a classic written by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Urashima Taro
literature.desc: Urashima Taro is one of the Ryugu (Dragon Palace) legends which appear all over Japan.

literature.name: Himetataraisuzuhime
literature.jp: ヒメタタライスズヒメ
literature.desc: Himetataraisuzuhime was the empress of Emperor Jinmu.

literature.name: Monogatari
literature.desc: Monogatari are various events read by a narrator to the reader.

literature.name: History of Medieval Japanese Literature
literature.desc: The history of medieval Japanese literature covers the history of literary works written approximately from the Kamakura to the Azuchi-Momoyama Periods.

literature.name: The History of Classical Japanese Literature
literature.url: literature/The History of Classical Japanese Literature.html
literature.desc: Classical Japanese literature (Chuko Bungaku) refers to literature written in the Chuko (middle-older) era of Japanese history, especially that of the Heian period.

literature.name: UEDA Akinari
literature.desc: Akinari UEDA (July 25, 1734 - August 8, 1809) was a writer of yomihon (books), a poet, an expert in the tea ceremony, a scholar of Japanese classics and a haiku poet in the late Edo period.

literature.name: KAKINOMOTO no Hitomaro
literature.desc: KAKINOMOTO no Hitomaro (male, c. 660 to c. 720) was a poet in the Asuka period.

literature.name: YAMABE no Akahito
literature.desc: YAMABE no AKAHITO (dates of birth and death unknown) was a poet who lived during the Nara Period.

literature.name: Characters in the Tale of Genji
literature.url: literature/Characters in the Tale of Genji.html
literature.desc: The list of characters in the Tale of Genji is the list of fictional characters appearing in the story.

literature.name: Koshi Koden
literature.desc: Koshi koden are historical documents with content that is significantly different from the kiki ("Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan)), which are considered as the major historical documents in the field of ancient Japanese history.

literature.name: Takeuchi Monjo
literature.desc: Takeuchi monjo (or Takenouchi monjo; also called Isohara monjo or Amatsukyo monjo) is the name for a number of documents written in ancient Japanese characters and include their translations in the form of manuscripts written in a mixture of kanji characters and katakana prepared by HEGURI no Matori, the grandson of TAKENOUCHI no Sukune, under the order of Emperor Buretsu and also inscriptions on stones, iron swords, etc.

literature.name: Utamakura (a place famed in classical Japanese poetry)
literature.url: literature/Utamakura (a place famed in classical Japanese poetry).html
literature.desc: Utamakura

literature.name: Manyo-gana (a form of syllabary used in the Manyoshu [Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves])
literature.url: literature/Manyo-gana (a form of syllabary used in the Manyoshu [Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves]).html
literature.desc: Manyo-gana is a kind of kana (the Japanese syllabaries), and it mainly refers to the letters from which Japanese people borrowed Chinese-derived pronunciation in order to express Japanese in ancient times.

literature.name: Yamato Takeru
literature.desc: Yamato Takeru no Mikoto (written in Chinese characters as 日本武尊, also written as 倭建命 in the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters)), who was also called Ousu no Mikoto (小碓命, Prince Ousu) and Yamato Oguna (written as 日本童男), is a person who is regarded as the son of Emperor Keiko and the father of Emperor Chuai.

literature.name: HAYANO Hajin
literature.desc: Hajin HAYANO (1676 - July 7, 1742) was a poet of haiku (a Japanese poem in 17 syllables having a 5-7-5 syllabic form and traditionally containing a reference to the seasons) who lived during the Edo period.

literature.name: Shomon Jittetsu (10 representative pupils under Basho MATSUO)
literature.url: literature/Shomon Jittetsu (10 representative pupils under Basho MATSUO).html
literature.desc: Shomon Jittetsu refers to the 10 particularly excellent pupils among the ones under Basho MATSUO.

literature.name: Nukata no Okimi
literature.desc: Nukata no Okimi (also known as Nukata no Kimi) (dates of birth and death unknown) was a leading female Japanese poet who was active during the reigns of the emperors Kogyoku and Jito with poems in the "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten-Thousand Leaves).

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Maro
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Maro (695 - August 17, 737) was a court noble who lived during the Nara period.

literature.name: Oku no Himemiko
literature.desc: Oku no Himemiko (大来皇女, also written as 大伯皇女, February 15, 661 - February 2, 702) was an Imperial princess of Emperor Tenmu.

literature.name: Prince Otsu
literature.desc: Prince Otsu (663 - October 28, 686) was a prince of Emperor Tenmu.

literature.name: Gobancho Yugiriro (Evening mist Tower of the Fifth Town, a novel)
literature.url: literature/Gobancho Yugiriro (Evening mist Tower of the Fifth Town, a novel).html
literature.desc: "Gobancho Yugiriro" (A House in the Quarter) is a representative work of Tsutomu MIZUKAMI, based on arson of Kinkaku-ji Temple in 1950 and the author's experience.

literature.name: Aoi (Hollyhock) (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Aoi (Hollyhock) is the title of one of the fifty-four chapters of "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Gunki Monogatari (martial tales)
literature.desc: Gunki monogatari (martial tales) refers to literary works written during the Kamakura and Muromachi periods whose subjects are taken from historical battles.

literature.name: Kagami no Okimi
literature.desc: Kagami no Okimi (year of birth unknown - August 5, 683) was a legal wife of FUJIWARA no Kamatari.

literature.name: Jinkoki (a mathematical book written by Mitsuyoshi YOSHIDA)
literature.url: literature/Jinkoki (a mathematical book written by Mitsuyoshi YOSHIDA).html
literature.desc: "Jinkoki" is a book of mathematics from the Edo period.

literature.name: Imperial Prince Toneri
literature.desc: Imperial Prince Toneri (February 8, 675 - December 6, 735) was a prince of Emperor Tenmu.

literature.name: Onna San no Miya
literature.desc: The word Onna San no Miya can refer to the following:

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Mitsuyuki
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Mitsuyuki (1163 - April 3, 1244) was a politician, literary scholar and poet during the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: Lady Aoi
literature.desc: Lady Aoi is a fictional character appearing in "The Tale of Genji" by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Rokujo no Miyasudokoro
literature.desc: Rokujo no Miyasudokoro is a fictional character who appears in "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji).

literature.name: Lady Akashi
literature.desc: Akashi no onkata, Lady Akashi, is a fictional character appearing in "The Tale of Genji" by Shikibu Murasaki.

literature.name: Sorobun
literature.desc: Sorobun is a style of literary language in Japanese used from the middle ages to the modern times.

literature.name: Fujitsubo
literature.desc: Fujitsubo is the name created for a fictional empress who appears in the story and whose real name is unknown.

literature.name: Ochiba no miya
literature.desc: Ochiba no miya is a fictitious character in "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Omiya (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Omiya is a fictitious character in The Tale of Genji.

literature.name: Kinjo no Mikado
literature.desc: Emperor Kinjo or Kinjo no Mikado is the fourth Emperor in "The Tale of Genji" (the period of his reign: after the second volume of 'Wakana' (Spring Shoots)).

literature.name: Onna Ninomiya
literature.desc: Onna Ninomiya is the second princess of the successive emperors.

literature.name: Chokusenshu
literature.desc: Chokusenshu is an anthology collected by Imperial command, or a book which was designated as an official writing among the ones written by the Emperor.

literature.name: MINAMOTO no Chikayuki
literature.desc: MINAMOTO no Chikayuki (year of birth and death unknown) was a writer and politician, a classical scholar, and a poet who lived in the first half of the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Yuge no Miko (Prince Yuge)
literature.desc: Yuge no Miko (Prince Yuge, year of birth unknown - August 24, 699) was the ninth (or the sixth) prince of Emperor Tenmu.

literature.name: OTOMO no Sakanoue no Iratsume
literature.desc: OTOMO no Sakanoue no Iratsume (year of birth and death unknown) is one of the most famous Tanka (31 syllables' poem) poets in "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).

literature.name: Arima no miko (Prince Arima)
literature.desc: Arima no miko (640 - December 13, 658) was a prince of Emperor Kotoku.

literature.name: OTOMO no Tabito
literature.desc: OTOMO no Tabito (665 - September 4, 731) was a politician and poet of the early Nara period.

literature.name: FUJIWARA no Kusumaro
literature.desc: FUJIWARA no Kusumaro (year of birth unknown - October 14, 764) was a court noble during the Nara period.

literature.name: Rashomon (Rashomon Gate, a novel)
literature.desc: "Rashomon" is a novel written by Ryunosuke AKUTAGAWA early in his career.

literature.name: Kiritsubo no Koi
literature.desc: Kiritsubo no Koi is a character in "The Tale of Genji" written by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Nanga
literature.desc: Nanga is a term which came from Chinese Southern Sung paintings, and the term is unique to the Japanese language.

literature.name: Akikonomu Chugu
literature.desc: Akikonomu Chugu is a fictional character who appears in Murasaki Shikibu's novel "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji).

literature.name: Akashi no himegimi
literature.desc: Akashi no himegimi (literally, princess of Akashi) is a character in "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji), a novel written by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Kumoi no kari
literature.desc: Kumoi no kari is a fictitious character that appears in "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji) by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Hokusai Manga
literature.desc: "Hokusai Manga" is a book of sketches issued by Hokusai KATSUSHIKA as examples of paintings.

literature.name: Kaoru
literature.desc: Kaoru is a fictional character who appears in Murasaki Shikibu's novel "Genji Monogatari."

literature.name: YAMANOUE no Okura
literature.desc: Yamanoue no Okura (660? – 733?) was a poet during the early Nara Period.

literature.name: Sedoka (A poem where the head is repeated)
literature.url: literature/Sedoka (A poem where the head is repeated).html
literature.desc: Sedoka (A poem where the head is repeated) is a type of waka (Japanese poem) from the Nara Period.

literature.name: KASA no Kanamura
literature.desc: KASA no Kanamura (year of birth and death unknown) was a poet during the Nara Period.

literature.name: TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro
literature.desc: TAKAHASHI no Mushimaro (year of birth and death unknown) was a contributor to Manyoshu during the Nara Period.

literature.name: TANABE no Sakimaro
literature.desc: TANABE no Sakimaro (year of birth and death unknown) was a contributor to Manyoshu during the Nara Period.

literature.name: Bussokusekika (the Buddha's Footprint Poems at the Yakushiji-temple in Nara)
literature.url: literature/Bussokusekika (the Buddhas Footprint Poems at the Yakushiji-temple in Nara).html
literature.desc: Bussokusekika is a name given to a waka (Japanese poetry) based on its contents and format, and is also referred to as Bussokuseki no uta (the Buddha's Footprint Poems).

literature.name: Emperor Suzaku
literature.desc: Emperor Suzaku (Suzaku no Mikado), or Suzakuin, is the second emperor in "The Tale of Genji" (the period of his reign, the chapter of 'Aoi' (Hollyhock) to 'Miotsukushi' (Channel Buoys)).

literature.name: Emperor Reizei
literature.desc: Emperor Reizei/Reizei-in is the third Emperor in "The Tale of Genji" (period of reign: 'Miotsukushi' (Channel Buoys) to the second volume of 'Wakana' (Spring Shoots), the 18 years of his reign were the golden days of Hikaru Genji).

literature.name: Agata no INUKAI no Michiyo
literature.desc: Agata no INUKAI no Michiyo (665? - January 11, 733 (old lunar calendar) (February 4, 733)) was a court lady during the early Nara Period.

literature.name: Imperial Prince Shiki
literature.desc: Imperial Prince Shiki(志貴皇子, 668?-, September 5, 716)lived from the end of the Asuka period to the beginning of the Nara period.

literature.name: Godai Teio Monogatari (Stories of Five Reigns and Their Emperors)
literature.url: literature/Godai Teio Monogatari (Stories of Five Reigns and Their Emperors).html
literature.desc: Godai Teio Monogatari is a historical tale which was written in the late Kamakura period and arranged in chronological order.

literature.name: Namazu-e
literature.desc: Namazu-e is a general name for nishiki-e (multicolored ukiyo-e (Japanese woodblock prints)) with catfish (namazu, in Japanese) as its subject published in Japan during the Edo period.

literature.name: Nyobo (a court lady)
literature.desc: Nyobo was a female servant who did domestic matters for people in the Imperial court or a distinguished person in aristocratic circles from the Heian period to around the Edo period.

literature.name: Emperor Kiritsubo
literature.desc: Emperor Kiritsubo/Kiritsubo-in is the first Emperor in "The Tale of Genji" (the period of reign: from the chapter of 'Kiritsubo' [The Paulownia Court] to 'Hana no En' [The Festival of the Cherry Blossoms]).

literature.name: Kinkakuji (The Temple of the Golden Pavilion, Novel)
literature.url: literature/Kinkakuji (The Temple of the Golden Pavilion, Novel).html
literature.desc: "Kinkakuji" (The Temple of the Golden Pavilion) is a novel written by Yukio MISHIMA.

literature.name: Watsuji Rinrigaku (Ethics)
literature.desc: Watsuji Rinrigaku is the name of the ethical theory developed by Tetsuro WATSUJI.

literature.name: Shomono (books of commentary on Chinese literary works created from the mid-Muromachi period to the early Edo period)
literature.url: literature/Shomono (books of commentary on Chinese literary works created from the mid-Muromachi period to the .html
literature.desc: Shomono is a general term for books of commentary on Chinese literary works created from the mid-Muromachi period to the early Edo period.

literature.name: Ocho Monogatari (tales from the Heian and Kamakura periods)
literature.url: literature/Ocho Monogatari (tales from the Heian and Kamakura periods).html
literature.desc: Among the novels and tales written from the late Heian period to the early Muromachi period, Ocho Monogatari refers to the ones that are characterized by having Japanese sentences written in Hiragana (the Japanese syllabaries), and having been created on the basis of the customs, aesthetic sense, and the concepts of literature during the period of Court rule.

literature.name: Tsukuri Monogatari (fanciful tale)
literature.desc: Among the Ocho Monogatari (tales from the Heian and Kamakura periods), Tsukuri monogatari refers to the fictitious works in which a story unfolds with a fictitious person as the main character.

literature.name: Sanyo-ki (the Calculation Manual)
literature.desc: "Sanyo-ki" (the Calculation Manual) is the oldest book on Wasan (Japanese mathematics) extant in Japan, however, the author is unknown.

literature.name: Kyoku (a kind of humorous haikai without haikai conventions)
literature.url: literature/Kyoku (a kind of humorous haikai without haikai conventions).html
literature.desc: Kyoku is one type of fixed form verse which developed in the latter half of the early-modern period in Japan.

literature.name: Gen no Naishinosuke
literature.desc: Gen no Naishinosuke is a nickname for a character in "The Tale of Genji."

literature.name: Hahakigi (broom tree)
literature.desc: Hahakigi is:

literature.name: Historical Tale
literature.desc: In Japanese literature, the term "Historical Tale" refers to the works based on real historical events and written in the style of a narrative.

literature.name: An Inquiry Into the Good
literature.desc: "An Inquiry Into the Good" is a book of philosophy written by Japanese philosopher Kitaro NISHIDA.

literature.name: Isonokami no Sasamegoto
literature.desc: "Isonokami no Sasamegoto" is Norinaga MOTOORI's personal views on poetry.

literature.name: Matsura no miya Monogatari
literature.desc: Matsura no miya Monogatari is a story or novel formed at the beginning of the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Manyodaishoki
literature.desc: "Manyodaishoki" is a commentary on "Manyoshu" (the oldest anthology of tanka) by Keichu, who was a scholar of Japanese classical literature during the Edo Period.

literature.name: Matsukage Chunagon Monogatari (The Tale of Matsukage, Vice-councilor of state)
literature.url: literature/Matsukage Chunagon Monogatari (The Tale of Matsukage, Vice-councilor of state).html
literature.desc: Matsukage Chunagon Monogatari is a fictional tale completed during the Muromachi period.

literature.name: Hyobukyo no Miya
literature.desc: Hyobukyo no Miya is a name for a fictitious Imperial prince, for convenience, whose real name is unknown in the tale.

literature.name: Priest Akashi
literature.desc: Priest Akashi is a fictitious character in "The Tale of Genji," which is a novel written by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Otsu-e (Otsu paintings, named after the town of Otsu in Shiga Prefecture)
literature.url: literature/Otsu-e (Otsu paintings, named after the town of Otsu in Shiga Prefecture).html
literature.desc: In a collection at The Cleveland Museum of Art.

literature.name: Chinese classical literature
literature.desc: Chinese classical literature is a general term for the works written in Chinese (classical Chinese) and the study of these classics.

literature.name: Karumi
literature.desc: Karumi is an ideal for the style of haikai poetry founded by Basho MATSUO.

literature.name: Hanafubuki
literature.desc: Hanafubuki is the state in which flower petals are falling like a snowstorm.

literature.name: Wakashu (a collection of waka [Japanese poetry])
literature.desc: Wakashu is a collection of waka (Japanese poetry).

literature.name: Takasebune (The Boat on the River Takase, a novel)
literature.url: literature/Takasebune (The Boat on the River Takase, a novel).html
literature.desc: "Takasebune" is Ogai MORI's short story.

literature.name: Kakyo Hyoshiki (the oldest extant Kagakusho [a book on the study of waka poems] by FUJIWARA no Hamanari)
literature.url: literature/Kakyo Hyoshiki (the oldest extant Kagakusho [a book on the study of waka poems] by FUJIWARA no Haman.html
literature.desc: Kakyo Hyoshiki is the oldest extant Kagakusho written by FUJIWARA no Hamanari.

literature.name: Lemon (Novel)
literature.desc: Lemon is a story by Motojiro KAJII.

literature.name: Sayuri (novel)
literature.desc: "Sayuri" (Memoirs of a Geisha) was a novel by Arthur GOLDEN, published in 1997.

literature.name: Sakimori-no-uta (Poetry of the Sakimori Guards)
literature.desc: Sakimori-no-uta is a group of poems written by the Sakimori guards who were deployed on the coast of Kyushu after Taika no Kaishin (The Great Reformation of the Taika Era).

literature.name: Oborozukiyo (The Tale of Genji)
literature.desc: Oborozukiyo (also called Oborozukuyo) is a fictional character in "The Tale of Genji" written by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: The Naniwa-zu (Waka [a traditional Japanese poem of 31 syllables] composed by Wani)
literature.url: literature/The Naniwa-zu (Waka [a traditional Japanese poem of 31 syllables] composed by Wani).html
literature.desc: The Naniwa-zu no uta (waka of Naniwa-zu Port) appears in the Kanajo (Japanese preface) of Kokin Wakashu (Collection of Ancient and Modern Poems) as 'the poem written on the emperor of Osazaki' composed by Wani (Wang In).

literature.name: Folding Screen of Pine Trees
literature.desc: "Pine Trees" is an ink painting on a pair of six-folded screens, and Tohaku HASEGAWA's best known work.

literature.name: Tonomine Shosho Monogatari (story)
literature.desc: Tonomine Shosho Monogatari (The Tale of the Lesser Captain of Tonomine) is a story.

literature.name: Kurama Tengu (novel)
literature.desc: "Kurama Tengu" is the title of the series of historical novels written by Jiro OSARAGI in Taisho and Showa periods, as well as the name of its protagonist.

literature.name: Waves at Matsushima (Matsushima-zu Byobu)
literature.desc: Waves at Matsushima ("Matsushima-zu Byobu")

literature.name: Koto (The Old Capital, Novel)
literature.desc: "Koto" is a novel written by Yasunari KAWABATA between 1950 and 1955.

literature.name: Haru no Hi (Spring Days, a haikai [17-syllable verse] collection)
literature.url: literature/Haru no Hi (Spring Days, a haikai [17-syllable verse] collection).html
literature.desc: "Haru no Hi" (Spring Days) is a haikai collection.

literature.name: Chanoyu Ichie Shu (Collection on the Oneness of Chanoyu)
literature.url: literature/Chanoyu Ichie Shu (Collection on the Oneness of Chanoyu).html
literature.desc: "Chanoyu Ichie Shu (Collection on the Oneness of Chanoyu)" is a book on tea ceremony written by Naosuke II (title in tea ceremony: Sokan), the lord of the Hikone Domain in the end of the Edo Period.

literature.name: The Big Four of the Kyoto School
literature.url: literature/The Big Four of the Kyoto School.html
literature.desc: The Big Four of the Kyoto school refers to the following four scholars who belonged to the Kyoto School: Masaaki KOSAKA, Keiji NISHITANI, Iwao KOYAMA and Shigetaka SUZUKI.

literature.name: Roppyakuban Uta-awase (poetry contest with 600 matches)
literature.desc: Roppyakuban Uta-awase was an uta-awase (poetry contest) in the Kamakura period hosted by FUJIWARA no Yoshitsune.

literature.name: Doka (literally, poetry on the way)
literature.desc: In contrast to tanka poetry as art, doka refers to tanka (31 syllables' poem) or waka (Japanese poem) that includes Buddhist teachings or that Zen monks composed to make study and spiritual enlightenment easier to understand.

literature.name: Shofu (a style of Haikai)
literature.desc: Shofu is a style of Haikai (17-syllable verse), the originator of which is Basho MATSUO.

literature.name: Uta Monogatari (Poem Tale)
literature.desc: Uta monogatari (poem tale) is the generic term for narrative literature concerning waka poems.

literature.name: Western-influenced paintings
literature.desc: Western-influenced paintings were made prior to the Meiji Period before oil painting tools were imported into Japan, and artists could only mimic examples of Western paintings.

literature.name: Inja Bungaku (literature of reclusion)
literature.desc: Inja Bungaku (literature of reclusion) is the generic term referring to a group of literature written by Buddhist priests and recluses who chose to retire from the secular world in medieval Japan.

literature.name: Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves)
literature.desc: The "Manyoshu"(written as 万葉集 or 萬葉集) is the oldest extant collection of poems, compiled from the latter half of the seventh century to the latter half of the eighth century.

literature.name: Nise-e (realistic painting)
literature.desc: Nise-e are realistic portrayals of courtiers and warriors, as well as drawings of armor on cattle and horses for record purposes, painted in the yamato-e style from the mid-13th century to mid-15th century.

literature.name: Hotaru Hyobukyo no Miya
literature.desc: Hotaru Hyobukyo no Miya is a fictitious character in "The Tale of Genji" written by Murasaki Shikibu (note that he is not the same person as Hyobukyo no Miya, an elder brother of Fujitsubo).

literature.name: Lady Kokiden
literature.desc: Lady Kokiden is the name for fictitious empresses in stories whose real names were unknown.

literature.name: The Unkoku school
literature.desc: The Unkoku school is a school of painting in the Edo period that was started by its founder Togan UNKOKU.

literature.name: Rikyu Doka
literature.desc: Rikyu Doka (literally, Rikyu's teaching poems), also called 'Rikyu hyakushu' (literally, Rikyu's one-hundred poems), are the teachings of SEN no Rikyu in the form of waka poetry to make them easily understood.

literature.name: KASA no Iratsume
literature.desc: KASA no Iratsume (Lady Kasa) was a poet of the mid-Nara period.

literature.name: Senryu (satirical haiku)
literature.desc: Senryu (satirical haiku) is one kind of Japanese poem in lines of five, seven, and five syllables.

literature.name: The Shinkokin Period
literature.desc: The Shinkokin period is a literary period that refers to the era of transition from Heian literature (literature in Chuko) to Kamakura literature (medieval literature).

literature.name: Classics Day
literature.desc: Classics Day, on November 1, refers to an anniversary to publicly honor Japanese classical literature.

literature.name: Honpan Jinbutsushi (brief accounts of the Shimazu clan and its chief retainers mainly during the Sengoku period [period of warring states])
literature.url: literature/Honpan Jinbutsushi (brief accounts of the Shimazu clan and its chief retainers mainly during the Sen.html
literature.desc: Honpan Jinbutsushi is thirteen volumes of brief accounts of the Shimazu clan and its chief retainers for 200 years from the middle of 15th century to the middle of 17th century mainly during the Sengoku period arranged in the traditional Japanese alphabetical order.

literature.name: Un (Fortune, a novel)
literature.desc: "Un" is a novel written by Ryunosuke AKUTAGAWA in his early period.

literature.name: Somon (Love Poetry)
literature.desc: Somon is one of the three main poetic categories to constitute the old collection of poetry "Manyoshu" together with Zoka (Miscellaneous Poem) and Banka (Laments).

literature.name: Atago Hyakuin (a linked verse of Mitsuhide AKECHI and others)
literature.url: literature/Atago Hyakuin (a linked verse of Mitsuhide AKECHI and others).html
literature.desc: Atago Hyakuin was a linked verse known as Renga, which was composed by Mitsuhide AKECHI and others at Mt. Atago in Kyoto immediately before his coup, the Honnoji Incident.

literature.name: Fukurozoshi (a treatise on waka [a traditional Japanese poem of 31 syllables] written by FUJIWARA no Kiyosuke)
literature.url: literature/Fukurozoshi (a treatise on waka [a traditional Japanese poem of 31 syllables] written by FUJIWARA no.html
literature.desc: Fukurozoshi is a treatise on waka poetry written during the Hogen era (1156 - 1159) in late Heian period by FUJIWARA no Kiyosuke, who was a court noble and a poet in a linage of the Rokujo family.

literature.name: Uji Hachi no Miya (the Eighth Prince)
literature.url: literature/Uji Hachi no Miya (the Eighth Prince).html
literature.desc: Uji Hachi no Miya (the Eighth Prince) is one of the fictional characters appearing in "The Tale of Genji" written by Murasaki Shikibu.

literature.name: Jigoku Zoshi (Scroll of the Hells)
literature.desc: Jigoku Zoshi are 12th-century hand scrolls depicting Buddhist hells.

literature.name: Satake version of Sanju-roku Kasen Emaki (hand scrolls of the thirty-six immortal poets)
literature.jp: 佐竹本三十六歌仙絵巻
literature.url: literature/Satake version of Sanju-roku Kasen Emaki (hand scrolls of the thirty-six immortal poets).html
literature.desc: The Satake version of "Sanju-roku Kasen Emaki (hand scrolls of the thirty-six immortal poets)" were made in the 13th century, Kamakura Period.

literature.name: Rokkasen (six famous poets)
literature.desc: Rokkasen are the following six poets that KI no Tsurayuki remarked as "poets of the best known of recent times" and commented on the style of poetry of each in "Kokin Wakashu Kanajo" (Preface of Kokin wakashu written in kana):

literature.name: YOSANO Akiko
literature.desc: Akiko YOSANO (与謝野 晶子 or 與謝野晶子 in orthographic style; December 7, 1878 - May 29, 1942) is a kajin (waka poet), novelist, and thinker active during the Meiji through Showa Periods.

literature.name: KODA Rohan
literature.desc: Rohan KODA (August 22, 1867 - July 30, 1947) was a Japanese novelist.

literature.name: FUTABATEI Shimei
literature.desc: FUTABATEI Shimei (April 4, 1864- May 10, 1909) was a Japanese novelist and translator.

literature.name: Yamata no Orochi (the eight-headed monster serpent)
literature.url: literature/Yamata no Orochi (the eight-headed monster serpent).html
literature.desc: Yamata no Orochi is a legendary creature that appears in Japanese myth.

literature.name: Totsuka no Tsurugi (a sword in the Japanese Myth)
literature.url: literature/Totsuka no Tsurugi (a sword in the Japanese Myth).html
literature.desc: Totsuka no Tsurugi is a sword which appears in the Japanese myth.

literature.name: Nihonjin-ron (Discourses on Japanese People)
literature.desc: Nihonjin-ron is a study, books, and reports discussed on Japanese people.

literature.name: CHIKAMATSU Monzaemon
literature.desc: Monzaemon CHIKAMATSU (1653 - January 6, 1725) was a kabuki and joruri (ballad drama) playwright who wrote many great works during the Genroku era in the early Edo period.

literature.name: Kanshi
literature.desc: Kanshi is traditional Chinese poetry.

literature.name: Nenokuni (Land of the Roots)
literature.desc: Nenokuni is the underworld in the Japanese myth.

literature.name: Ukigumo (Floating Clouds) (FUTABATEI Shimei)
literature.desc: "Ukigumo (Floating Clouds)" is a long novel by FUTABATEI Shimei.

literature.name: Essence of Novels
literature.desc: "Essence of Novels" is a literary critique by Shoyo TSUBOUCHI.

literature.name: General Theory of the Novel
literature.desc: "General Theory of the Novel" is the literary criticism by FUTABATEI Shimei.

literature.name: Tenchi Kaibyaku (creation of heaven and earth)
literature.url: literature/Tenchi Kaibyaku (creation of heaven and earth).html
literature.desc: Tenchi Kaibyaku is a time when the world represented by heaven and earth was first created.

literature.name: Kuni-umi (a myth about the birth of the land of Japan)
literature.url: literature/Kuni-umi (a myth about the birth of the land of Japan).html
literature.desc: Kuni-umi is a myth that tells us how the land of Japan was generated.

literature.name: Kami-umi (a myth about giving birth to gods)
literature.url: literature/Kami-umi (a myth about giving birth to gods).html
literature.desc: In Japanese myths, Kami-umi refers to Izanagi and Izanami's giving birth to numerous gods after they gave birth to various islands (Kuni-umi [a myth about the birth of the land of Japan]).

literature.name: The Oath Between Amaterasu and Susano
literature.jp: アマテラスとスサノオの誓約
literature.url: literature/The Oath Between Amaterasu and Susano.html
literature.desc: Both the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) give an account of an Ukei (an oath) between Amaterasu and Susano, and of the gods who came into being due to it.

literature.name: Onogoro-jima Island (an island in a Japanese myth)
literature.url: literature/Onogoro-jima Island (an island in a Japanese myth).html
literature.desc: Onogoro-jima Island (also called Onokoro-jima Island) is an island appearing in a Japanese myth.

literature.name: Gesaku (literary work of a playful, mocking, joking, silly or frivolous nature)
literature.url: literature/Gesaku (literary work of a playful, mocking, joking, silly or frivolous nature).html
literature.desc: Gesaku is a general term for yomimono (reading) that had flourished in Edo since the late early-modern times, or around the latter half of the 18th century.

literature.name: Sharebon (witty book)
literature.desc: Sharebon (literally, witty book) is a type of gesaku literature in the mid-Edo period.

literature.name: Kokkeibon (humorous book)
literature.desc: Kokkeibon (humorous book) was a genre of gesaku literature (literary work of a playful, mocking, joking, silly or frivolous nature) in the late Edo period.

literature.name: Ninjobon (works of sentimental fiction in the Edo period)
literature.url: literature/Ninjobon (works of sentimental fiction in the Edo period).html
literature.desc: The ninjobon refers to a genre of gesaku literature (literary work of a playful, mocking, joking, silly or frivolous nature) written during the Edo period that mainly dealt with decadent love affairs and contemporary life of Edo (now Tokyo).

literature.name: Shinsengumi Tenmatsuki
literature.desc: Shinsengumi Tenmatsuki was one of the valuable materials on Shinsengumi as an oral history material by Shinpachi NAGAKURA, one of the survivor, one of leading members of Shinsengumi.

literature.name: The Old Book of Tang
literature.desc: "The Old Book of Tang" (Jiu Tangshu or Kutojo in Japanese) was a book of history compiled by Liu Xu and others under the reign of Shi Chonggui of Later Jin of the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms Period in China.

literature.name: Ama no Iwato (Cave of Heaven)
literature.desc: The term, "Ama no iwato" refers to a rock cave that appears in Japanese mythology.

literature.name: Takekunikoriwake no mikoto
literature.desc: Takekunikoriwake no mikoto was a member of the Imperial Family in the Kofun period (tumulus period), and he was written about in "A Record of Ancient Matters," "Chronicles of Japan," and so on.

literature.name: Kinkai Wakashu
literature.desc: Kinkai Wakashu is MINAMOTO no Sanetomo's private anthology in the early Kamakura Period.

literature.name: The Four Heavenly Kings of Waka
literature.url: literature/The Four Heavenly Kings of Waka.html
literature.desc: The Four Heavenly Kings of Waka is the title to praise excellent poets of waka (Japanese poetry).

literature.name: Ashihara no nakatsukuni (葦原中国)
literature.desc: Ashihara no nakatsukuni is a world which exists between Takamanohara (plain of high heaven) and Yomi (world after death), that is, Japanese soil.

literature.name: OZAKI Koyo
literature.desc: Koyo OZAKI (January 10, 1868 - October 30, 1903) was a Japanese novelist.

literature.name: Rangaku Kotohajime (The Beginning of Dutch Studies)
literature.url: literature/Rangaku Kotohajime (The Beginning of Dutch Studies).html
literature.desc: "Rangaku Kotohajime" (The Beginning of Dutch Studies) is memoirs written by Genpaku SUGITA at the age of 83 in 1815, who was thinking back on to the pioneer days of Dutch studies and sent to Gentaku OTSUKI.

literature.name: Shinchoko-ki (A Biography of Lord Nobunaga)
literature.desc: Shinchoko-ki (Nobunagako-ki) is a biography of Nobunaga ODA, a feudal lord in the Azuchi-Momoya period in Japan.

literature.name: Kaminoyonanayo (神世七代)
literature.desc: Kaminoyonanayo is a general term for seven generations of deities who were born when heaven and earth were created in Japanese Mythology.

literature.name: Inaba no Shiro Usagi (The hare of Inaba)
literature.url: literature/Inaba no Shiro Usagi (The hare of Inaba).html
literature.desc: Inaba no Shiro Usagi is one of Izumo mythologies.

literature.name: Yamasachihiko and Umisachihiko
literature.desc: Yamasachihiko and Umisachihiko is one of the anecdotes in Japanese mythology.

literature.name: Ochimizu
literature.desc: Ochimizu is water that was said to bring back youth when it was drank.

literature.name: Honchotsugan
literature.desc: Honchotsugan is a history book in classical Chinese and in chronological order edited by the Edo Shogunate.

literature.name: Yatagarasu
literature.desc: Yatagarasu is a crow with three legs that was sent to Emperor Jinmu by Takamimusubi and led him from Kumanokuni no miyatsuko to Yamato Province on the Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) in the Japanese mythology.

literature.name: Tokoyo (eternal night)
literature.desc: Tokoyo is also known as Kakuriyo (the world of the dead), and it is the holy precincts which is not changed forever.

literature.name: Takamanohara (plain of high heaven)
literature.desc: Takamanohara (also called Takaamahara/ Takanoamahara/ Takamagahara) is a place where Amatsu kami (god of heaven) lives in the Japanese mythology and norito (Shinto prayer) in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

literature.name: Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district)
literature.url: literature/Kumaso (a tribe living in the ancient Kyushu district).html
literature.desc: Kumaso is a name for the family that appear in "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters), "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), and the Japanese mythology.

literature.name: Kanzen Choaku
literature.desc: Kanzen Choaku is a compound word made up of four characters: 勧(kan), 善(zen), 懲(cho) and 悪(aku) and means encouraging good and punishing evil.

literature.name: Kibyoshi (an illustrated book of popular fiction whose cover is yellow)
literature.url: literature/Kibyoshi (an illustrated book of popular fiction whose cover is yellow).html
literature.desc: Kibyoshi is one of the genres of kusazoshi (illustrated story books) which was popular after 1775, the mid-Edo period.

literature.name: Ashihara no Nakatsukuni heitei (pacification of the Central Land of Reed Plains)
literature.url: literature/Ashihara no Nakatsukuni heitei (pacification of the Central Land of Reed Plains).html
literature.desc: Ashihara no Nakatsukuni heitei is a narrative of the Japanese mythology, in which Amatsu kami (god of heaven) was given Ashihara no nakatsukuni by Kunitsu kami (god of the land).

literature.name: Sangyo Gisho
literature.desc: Sangyo Gisho (The Annotation of the Three Sutras) is the collective name of "Hokke Gisho" (believed to have been published in 615), "Shomangyo Gisho" (believed to have been published in 611) and "Yuimagyo Gisho" (believed to have been published in 613) all of which are thought to have been written by Prince Shotoku.

literature.name: Ryugu (the palace of the Dragon King)
literature.url: literature/Ryugu (the palace of the Dragon King).html
literature.desc: Ryugu or Kaigu (the palace of the sea) is a palace of Watasumi no kami (tutelary of the sea) which appears in a legend concerning Watasumi no kami that has been told all over Japan.

literature.name: Tenson Korin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the Sun Goddess)
literature.url: literature/Tenson Korin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the Sun Goddess).html
literature.desc: Tenson Korin is a legend in Japanese mythology, in which the grandson of Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) Ninigi received the order to pacify Ashihara no Nakatsukuni (the Central Land of Reed Plains) and descended from heaven in order to rule Ashihara no Nakatsukuni.

literature.name: The Myth of Okuninushi
literature.desc: The Myth of Okuninushi.

literature.name: Okuninushi's forming of the land
literature.desc: Okuninushi's forming of the land

literature.name: Myth of Food Origin in Japanese Mythology
literature.jp: 日本神話における食物起源神話
literature.url: literature/Myth of Food Origin in Japanese Mythology.html
literature.desc: This article describes myth of food origin in Japanese Mythology.

literature.name: Sankashu
literature.desc: Sankashu is a collection of poems by Saigyo, a poet-priest in the late Heian Period.

literature.name: Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu)
literature.url: literature/Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu).html
literature.desc: Jimmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu) is a tale in Japanese myth of the expedition of the first Kamuyamatoiwarebiko (Emperor Jinmu) of the Imperial family who departed from Hyuga, conquered Yamato and succeeded to Kashiwara no Miya (palace at Kashihara).

literature.name: The Rebellion of Tagishimimi
literature.desc: The Rebellion of Tagishimimi is a tale of Japanese mythology that after Emperor Jinmu passed away, Tagishimimi devised a ploy to become the emperor but was defeated by Kamununakawamimi (later, Emperor Suizei) and his army.

literature.name: Hitakami no kuni
literature.desc: Hitakami no kuni is a province ruled by Emishi (a group of people) as a local sphere of influence, which was located in the present-day Tohoku region (the Kitakami-gawa River basin in Iwate Prefecture) and described in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

literature.name: Kojidan
literature.desc: "Kojidan" (Talks about Ancient Matters) is a collection of fables produced in the early Kamakura period.

literature.name: Mumyo Zoshi (Story Without a Name)
literature.desc: Mumyo Zoshi (Story Without a Name) is a classic from the early Kamakura Period, and the oldest critique of literature in Japan.

literature.name: Fuyo Wakashu
literature.desc: Fuyo Wakashu is a collection of waka (Japanese poems) based on fictional stories in the mid Kamakura Period.

literature.name: Futsunomitama
literature.desc: Futsunomitama is a divine sword described in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and mythology.

literature.name: Amanohabaya
literature.desc: Amanohabaya is an arrow described in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and mythology.

literature.name: The Shinshicho
literature.desc: The Shinshicho (New Tides of Thought) is a Japanese literary magazine.

literature.name: Giretsu Kaiten Hyakushu
literature.desc: Giretsu Kaiten Hyakushu is a collection of waka (Japanese poems) of patriot samurai in the end of Edo period, published in September 1874.

literature.name: Kunibiki Shinwa (Land dragging myth)
literature.desc: Kunibiki Shinwa (Land dragging myth) is a part of Japanese mythology that has been passed down in the Izumo Province.

literature.name: Hakai (Novel)
literature.desc: "Hakai" (The Broken Commandment) is a full-length novel by Toson SHIMAZAKI.

literature.name: Tensho
literature.desc: Tensho (literally the 'Book of Heaven', also called Amatsufumi or Amenofumi) is a chronological history that is said to have been compiled by FUJIWARA no Hamanari at the end of the Nara period.

literature.name: Konjiki Yasha (The golden demon)
literature.desc: Konjiki Yasha is a representative novel of Meiji Period written by Koyo OZAKI.

literature.name: Harima no Inabi no Oiratsume
literature.desc: Harima no Inabi no Oiratsume (year of birth unknown - June 25, 122) was the empress to the twelfth Emperor Keiko who was described in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), and "Harimanokuni Fudoki" (records of the culture and geography of the Harima Province).

literature.name: Gunki-mono (Military Tales)
literature.desc: Gunki-mono refers to the writings which were composed from the end of mediaeval times to the beginning of pre-modern times and which describe the heroic exploits of military commanders or the families of feudal lords.

literature.name: Banana type Myth
literature.desc: Banana type myths are myths regarding the origin of death and the short life span of humans which are found in many countries and regions, mainly in southeast Asia and New Guinea.

literature.name: Kaichoon (collection of poetry)
literature.desc: Kaichoon is the collection of translated poems that Bin UEDA published through Hongo Shoin in October, 1905.

literature.name: Ryomen-sukuna
literature.desc: Ryomen-sukuna is a specter that was said to have appeared in Hida Province in ancient times, in the reign of Emperor Nintoku.

literature.name: SATOMURA Joha
literature.desc: Joha SATOMURA (1525 - June 2, 1602) was a linked-verse-teacher 'Rengashi' during the Warring States period.

literature.name: Tsukubashu
literature.desc: Tsukubashu is an anthology of renga (linked verse) poems collected under Imperial command in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

literature.name: Keien-isshi
literature.desc: Keien-isshi is a collection of waka (Japanese poetry) by Kageki KAGAWA (1768-1843) compiled by himself in the late Edo Period.

literature.name: The Legend of Anchin and Kiyohime
literature.url: literature/The Legend of Anchin and Kiyohime.html
literature.desc: The legend of Anchin and Kiyohime has been handed down in Kii Province.

literature.name: Rokudai Shojiki (war tales concerning six emperors)
literature.url: literature/Rokudai Shojiki (war tales concerning six emperors).html
literature.desc: "Rokudai Shojiki" (or "Rokudai Shoshiki") is a historic tale written in chronological form in the early Kamakura Period of Japan.

literature.name: Tamonin Nikki
literature.desc: "Tamonin Nikki" (Tamonin Diary), written in Tamonin tatchu (a sub-temple on the site of a main temple) in Kofuku-ji Temple, Nara, was kept for 140 years (from 1478 to 1618) by the authors for three generations, including the monk Eishun.

literature.name: Tokusanokandakara
literature.desc: Tokusanokandakara (or Jusshushinpo) are ten kinds of sacred treasures that were handed down by Nigihayahi no Mikoto, sojin (ancestral tutelary) of the Mononobe clan.

literature.name: Hyakunin Shuka
literature.desc: Hyakunin Shuka is an anthology of poems selected by FUJIWARA no Sadaie.

literature.name: Komonjo
literature.desc: In the study of history, komonjo (literally, old documents) refers to methods created to communicate one's intentions to a specific addressee.

literature.name: Tora Gozen
literature.desc: In 'Sogamonogatari' (the tale of Soga) that deals with the famous story of the Soga brothers' revenge that happened in Fuji no Makigari (Hunting session at Mt. Fuji), Tora Gozen (1175-?) is a heroin and a lover of the elder of the brothers, SOGA no Sukenari, the role added depth and color to the story.

literature.name: Kanginshu
literature.desc: Kanginshu is a collection of Japanese songs and ballads.

literature.name: Shokushika wakashu
literature.desc: Shokushika wakashu is a personal collection of poetry in the late Heian Period.

literature.name: Heikoki
literature.desc: Heikoki is a diary of Shonii (Senior Second Rank) Minbukyo (Minister of Popular Affairs) TAIRA no Tsunetaka.

literature.name: Hundred stories concerning last days of the Tokugawa shogunate
literature.url: literature/Hundred stories concerning last days of the Tokugawa shogunate.html
literature.desc: Hundred stories concerning last days of the Tokugawa shogunate are a collection of retrospective stories on the end of the Edo period and Meiji Restoration which appeared serially in Hochi Shinbun (newspaper) in 1902.

literature.name: Ichiaku no suna (A Handful of Sand)
literature.url: literature/Ichiaku no suna (A Handful of Sand).html
literature.desc: "Ichiaku no suna" is the first collection of poetic works produced by Takuboku ISHIKAWA.

literature.name: Futon (Japanese bedding) (novel)
literature.desc: "Futon" is a short novel which was written by Katai TAYAMA.

literature.name: Nan-Taiheiki
literature.desc: Nan-Taiheiki is a book which was completed by Sadayo IMAGAWA (after becoming a priest, known as Ryoshun IMAGAWA) in 1402.

literature.name: Horyakukanki (A History Book of the 14 century in Japan)
literature.url: literature/Horyakukanki (A History Book of the 14 century in Japan).html
literature.desc: "Horyakukanki" is a history book which was completed during the Japanese middle ages, the Northern and Southern Dynasties period.

literature.name: Nozarashi Kiko
literature.desc: "Nozarashi Kiko" (Journal of Bleached Bones in a Field) is a travel record by Basho MATSUO, haikai (seventeen-syllable verse) poet in the mid-Edo Period.

literature.name: Shoku-Gosen Wakashu
literature.desc: "Shoku-Gosen Wakashu" is the 10th Imperial poetic anthology compiled by the command of the Retired Emperor Gosaga.

literature.name: Shoku Shui Wakashu
literature.desc: Shoku Shui Wakashu is the 12th imperial anthology of waka (Japanese poetry) by the command of the Retired Emperor Kameyama in 1276.

literature.name: Shingosen Wakashu
literature.desc: Shingosen Wakashu is the 13th imperial anthology of waka (Japanese poetry) by the command of the Emperor Gouda in 1301.

literature.name: Shokusenzai Wakashu
literature.desc: Shokusenzai Wakashu (Waka Collection of a Thousand Years Continued) is the 15th imperial anthology of waka (Japanese poetry) by the command of the Cloistered Emperor Gouda in 1318.

literature.name: Midaregami
literature.desc: "Midaregami" (Tangled hair) is the first poetry collection of a poet, Akiko YOSANO.

literature.name: ONO no Minemori
literature.desc: ONO no Minemori (778 - April 19, 830) was a noble and a man of letters during the early Heian period.

literature.name: Jogu Shotoku Hooteisetsu (Biography of Shotoku Taishi)
literature.url: literature/Jogu Shotoku Hooteisetsu (Biography of Shotoku Taishi).html
literature.desc: Jogu Shotoku Hooteisetsu is said to be the oldest existing biography of what was called Prince Shotoku, who was a regent of Emperor Suiko.

literature.name: Nihon Gafu
literature.desc: "Nihon Gafu" is an anthology of poems written by Sanyo RAI.

literature.name: Takamagahara kochihi
literature.desc: Takamagahara kochihi is a stone monument placed at Kaya University in Goryeong-gun, Gyeongbuk, Korea.

literature.name: Tosei Shosei Katagi
literature.desc: Tosei shosei katagi (The Character of Modern Students) is a novel written by Shoyo TSUBOUCHI (a nom de plume: Harunoya Oboro).

literature.name: Choshueiso
literature.desc: Choshueiso is a private poetry collection of FUJIWARA no Toshinari.

literature.name: Keikoku bidan
literature.desc: Keikoku bidan (Commendable anecdotes creating a nation: young politicians of Thebes) is a political novel written by Ryukei YANO.

literature.name: Kajin no Kigu (Encounters with Beautiful Women)
literature.url: literature/Kajin no Kigu (Encounters with Beautiful Women).html
literature.desc: Kajin no Kigu is a political fiction written by Sanshi TOKAI (Shiro SHIBA).

literature.name: Secchubai (Plums in Snow)
literature.desc: Secchubai is a political fiction written by Teccho SUEHIRO.

literature.name: Seiyo Dochu Hizakurige (On the road through western countries: comic journey towards civilization)
literature.url: literature/Seiyo Dochu Hizakurige (On the road through western countries comic journey towards civilization).html
literature.desc: Seiyo Dochu Hizakurige is a humorous fiction written by Robun KANAGAKI and Kan FUSO (Volume 12 and subsequent volumes).

literature.name: Ruiju-Karin
literature.desc: Ruiju-Karin is a collection of poetry.

literature.name: Shinsen Manyoshu
literature.desc: Shinsen Manyoshu is a personal collection of poetries.

literature.name: Shinsen Waka
literature.desc: Shinsen Waka is a personal collection of Japanese poetry.

literature.name: Kokashu
literature.desc: Kokashu is a collection of Japanese poetry.

literature.name: Shokugoshui wakashu
literature.desc: Shokugoshui wakashu is an anthology of poems collected by Imperial command.

literature.name: Zokihoshishu
literature.desc: "Zokihoshishu" is a collection of Japanese poetry in the Heian Period.

literature.name: Shizu no iwaya
literature.desc: Shizu no iwaya is a sea cave (approximately 45 m deep and 13 m high) created by coastal erosion in Uotsu, Shizuma-cho, Oda-shi, Shimane Prefecture.

literature.name: Shizu no iwaya
literature.desc: Shizu no iwaya has its origin in a folklore in the myth of the development of the land by Okuninushi no Mikoto and Sukunahikona no Mikoto, and the place was depicted in a Oishi no Suguri no Mahito's poem in Manyoshu (Volume 3-355) "Onamuchi and Sukunahiko lived in Shizu no iwaya; how many generations that have been passed by?"

literature.name: Amenosakahoko
literature.desc: Amenosakahoko (also pronounced as Amanosakahoko) is a kind of halberd (hoko) which appears in the myths of medieval Japan.

literature.name: Heibon (Mediocrity) (novel)
literature.desc: Heibon is a fiction written by FUTABATEI Shimei.

literature.name: Jogaku Zasshi (Education of Women Magazine)
literature.desc: Jogaku Zasshi was a magazine intended for female readers published during the Meiji era.

literature.name: Nanshuo Ikun (The Teachings of the Late Nanshu)
literature.url: literature/Nanshuo Ikun (The Teachings of the Late Nanshu).html
literature.desc: Nanshuo Ikun is a collection of lessons written by Takamori SAIGO.

literature.name: Shugyo Risshihen (Discourses of study for success)
literature.url: literature/Shugyo Risshihen (Discourses of study for success).html
literature.desc: Shugyo Risshihen is a one of the books written by Yukichi FUKUZAWA.

literature.name: Kaname-ishi (spirit rocks)
literature.desc: Kaname-ishi (spirit rocks) are found in Kashima-jingu Shrine in Kashima City, Ibaraki Prefecture and Katori-jingu Shrine in Katori City, Chiba Prefecture.

literature.name: Nakatsukasa no Naishi Nikki (The Dairy of Nakatsukasa no Naishi)
literature.url: literature/Nakatsukasa no Naishi Nikki (The Dairy of Nakatsukasa no Naishi).html
literature.desc: The Dairy of Nakatsukasa no Naishi is a work of courtly literature in the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Okanoya Kanpakuki (The Dairy of Okanoya Kanpaku)
literature.url: literature/Okanoya Kanpakuki (The Dairy of Okanoya Kanpaku).html
literature.desc: Okanoya Kanpakuki is a diary written by Kanpaku (Chancellor) Kanetsune KONOE in the Kamakura period.

literature.name: Enkei Ryokyo Sochinjo (Petition by Two Nobles of the Enkei Era)
literature.url: literature/Enkei Ryokyo Sochinjo (Petition by Two Nobles of the Enkei Era).html
literature.desc: Enkei Ryokyo Sochinjo (The Petition by Two Nobles of the Enkei Era) records Tameyo NIJO's petition against the nomination of Tamekane KYOGOKU, in 1311, as the selector of an imperial anthology of waka poems, Tamekane's subsequent petition against the Tamayo's appeal, and this latter's further rebuttal against the former.

literature.name: Kokon Hyakumonogatari Hyoban (A Critique of Hundred Tales Old and New)
literature.url: literature/Kokon Hyakumonogatari Hyoban (A Critique of Hundred Tales Old and New).html
literature.desc: "Kokon Hyakumonogatari Hyoban" (A Critique of Hundred Tales Old and New) is a collection of kaidan (ghost) tales written and edited by Genrin YAMAOKA who was a litterateur in the early Edo period.

literature.name: Mimitsu
literature.desc: Mimitsu is a place name in Hyuga City, Miyazaki Prefecture.

literature.name: TSURUYA Nanboku
literature.desc: Nanboku TSURUYA IV (1755 - December 22, 1829) was a Kabuki playwright during the latter half of the Edo period.

literature.name: Tenson-zoku (Tenson Tribe)
literature.desc: The Tenson-zoku (Tenson tribe) is a generic term for ancient powers that established the Yamato Dynasty, which appears in the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (The Chronicles of Japan) and which is told in Japanese mythology.

literature.name: Betsuri (Collection of Poems of Bokusui WAKAYAMA)
literature.url: literature/Betsuri (Collection of Poems of Bokusui WAKAYAMA).html
literature.desc: Betsuri is a collection of poems written by Bokusui WAKAYAMA.

literature.name: Jijoron (Self-help)
literature.desc: Self-help is a handbook written by Samuel Smiles which was published in 1859.

literature.name: Shinshosetsu (New Novel)
literature.desc: The second phase, April 1896 (April 1896 issue) to November 1926 (December 1926 issue)

person.name: TOYOTOMI Hideyoshi
person.desc: Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (TOYOTOMI no Hideyoshi)/Hideyoshi HASHIBA was a warrior and a warlord lived in the Age of Civil Wars (late Muromachi Period) through Azuchi-Momoyama Period.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Takauji
person.desc: Takauji ASHIKAGA (1305-58) was a general from the late Kamakura period to the Northern and Southern Courts period.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshimitsu
person.desc: Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA was the 3rd Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate and reigned from 1368 to1394.

person.name: TOKUGAWA Yoshinobu (Yoshihisa, Keiki)
person.desc: Yoshinobu (Yoshihisa) TOKUGAWA was the 15th Seii Taishogun of the Edo Shogunate (held the position from December 5, 1866 to December 9, 1867, both in the old lunar calendar).

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshiaki
person.desc: Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA was the 15th Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate, and its last Shogun (Reigned from 1568 to 1588).

person.name: MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka
person.desc: MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka was a warlord of Shinano Genji clan in the late Heian Period.

person.name: AKECHI Mitsuhide
person.desc: Mitsuhide AKECHI was a warrior who lived in both the Sengoku and Azuchi-Momoyama periods.

person.name: MATSUDAIRA Katamori
person.desc: Katamori MATSUDAIRA was a Daimyo, and the 9th and last Chief of the Aizu Clan of Mutsu Province.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshiteru
person.desc: Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA was the 13th Seii Taishogunn (reigned 1546-1565) of the Muromachi Shogunate.

person.name: SAITO Dosan
person.desc: Dosan or Hidetatsu SAITO was a military commander during the Sengoku period.

person.name: HINO Tomiko
person.desc: Tomiko HINO (female, 1440 - June 30, 1496) is a historical figure who lived in the Muromachi period.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshiakira
person.desc: Yoshiakira ASHIKAGA-July 4, 1330 AD to December 28, 1367 AD-was the 2nd Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshimochi
person.desc: Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA was the fourth shogun of Muromachi Shogunate.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshizumi
person.desc: Yoshizumi ASHIKAGA is the 11th Seii Taishogun of the Muromachi Shogunate (held the position from 1493 to 1508).

person.name: HIJIKATA Toshizo
person.desc: A soldier

person.name: SAKAMOTO Ryoma
person.desc: Revolutionist

person.name: SERIZAWA Kamo
person.desc: Kamo SERIZAWA, (1827? - October 28 or October 30, 1863) was a roshi of Mito Clan during the last days of Tokugawa shogunate, and also the original lead commander of Shinsengumi (Mibu Roshi).

person.name: FUKUI Kenichi
person.desc: Kenichi FUKUI (4 October 1918 – 9 January 1998) was a Japanese chemist.

person.name: SEN no Rikyu
person.desc: SEN no Rikyu (April 21, 1522-1591) was a tea master during the late Medieval times of the Sengoku and Azuchi-Momoyama periods.

person.name: ODA Nagamasu
person.desc: Nagamasu ODA was a daimyo and master of the tea ceremony from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

person.name: KIYOKAWA Hachiro
person.desc: Hachiro KIYOKAWA (October 10th, first year of Tenpo (Lunar Calendar)(November 24, 1830) - April 13th, third year of Bunkyu (Lunar Calendar)(May 30, 1863)) was a Shishi at end of Edo Period, and one of the leaders of the Roshigumi.
