person.name: Izumo no Okuni
person.desc: Izumo no Okuni (1572? - year of death is unknown) was a female artist of the Azuchi-momoyama period who is considered the creator of Kabuki.

person.name: INOUE Yachiyo
person.desc: Yachiyo INOUE is the name given to the head of the INOUE School.

person.name: YOSA Buson
person.desc: Buson YOSA (Born in 1716, died on January 17, 1784) was a Japanese haiku poet and painter in the middle of the Edo Period.

person.name: HOSOKAWA Yusai
person.desc: Yusai HOSOKAWA (Fujitaka HOSOKAWA) was a general of the Warring States Period, and a tanka poet.

person.name: YUKAWA Hideki
person.desc: Hideki YUKAWA (January 23, 1907-September 8, 1981) was a theoretical physical scientist in Japan.

person.name: Goemon ISHIKAWA as 石川五右衛門
person.url: person/Goemon ISHIKAWA as 石川五右衛門.html
person.desc: About Goemon ISHIKAWA

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshimasa
person.desc: Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA was the 8th Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi Shogunate (reigned between 1449 - 1473).

person.name: Honen
person.desc: Honen was a Japanese Buddhist monk from the late Heian Period to early Kamakura Period, and the founder of Pure Land Sect.

person.name: MINAMOTO no Makoto (noble)
person.desc: MINAMOTO no Makoto (810 - February 13, 869) was a noble during the first half of the Heian Period.

person.name: Zendo (Shan-tao, Shandao)
person.desc: Zendo (Shan-dao) was an eminent monk in Chinese Pure Land Buddhism.

person.name: MORI Yoshikatsu
person.desc: Yoshikatsu MORI (year of birth not known - July 1, 1582) was Nobunaga ODA's retainer.

person.name: Saicho
person.desc: Saicho was a Buddhist monk during the Heian Period, and he founded the Tendai School of Buddhism in Japan.

person.name: Rennyo
person.desc: Rennyo (April 4, 1415 to May 5, 1499) was a priest of Jodoshin-shu sect (True Pure Land Sect) of Buddhism during the Muromachi Period.

person.name: ABE no Seimei
person.desc: ABE no Seimei (Haruakira, Hareaki, 921? to October 31, 1005) was one of the most famous Ommyoji (Ommyo diviner), and he is the ancestor of the Abe clan (Tsuchimikado family) who was responsible for Ommyo-ryo (Bureau of Yin and Yang) from the Kamakura Period to the early Meiji Period.

person.name: MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune
person.desc: MINAMOTO no Yoshitsune (源義経, or 源 義經) is a busho (Japanese military commander) of Kawachi-Genji (Minamoto clan) in the late Heian period.

person.name: MINAMOTO no Yoshihira
person.desc: MINAMOTO no Yoshihira is a busho (Japanese military commander) during the end of the Heian period.

person.name: IMAGAWA Ujizane
person.desc: Ujizane IMAGAWA was a warlord of Suruga Province.

person.name: FUJIWARA no Michinaga
person.desc: FUJIWARA no Michinaga (966 - 1027) was a court nobility during the mid-Heian Period, Dajo-Daijin (held the position from December 4, 1017, to February 9, 1018, both in lunar calendar).

person.name: SAIONJI Kinmochi
person.desc: Kinmochi SAIONJI (December 7, 1849 - November 24, 1940) was a noble in the Japanese Court and a politician.

person.name: Ensho
person.desc: Ensho (859-December 6, 929) is a Buddhist monk of the Shingon-shu sect during the mid-Heian period.

person.name: SAIGO Takamori
person.desc: Takamori SAIGO (December 27, 1828 according to the old calendar (Gregorian calendar: January 23, 1828; Julian calendar: January 1, 1828) - September 24, 1877 of the Gregorian calendar) was a Japanese samurai who served as a feudal retainer, soldier, and statesman of the Satsuma clan.

person.name: The Fujiwara clan
person.desc: The Fujiwara were a noble clan that existed in Japan from the ancient period until the early modern period.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshitane
person.desc: Yoshitane (or Yoshiki) ASHIKAGA was the tenth Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") (in office from 1490 to 1493) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

person.name: SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro
person.desc: SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro was a military officer of the Heian period.

person.name: KONOE Fumimaro
person.desc: Fumimaro KONOE (October 12, 1891 - December 16, 1945) was a Japanese politician.

person.name: Kennyo
person.desc: Kennyo (February 9, 1543 - December 27, 1592) was the 11th head priest of the Hongan-ji Temple.

person.name: Luis Frois
person.desc: Luis Frois (1532 – July 8, 1597) was a Portuguese born in Lisbon.

person.name: KITAOJI Rosanjin/Rozanjin
person.desc: Rosanjin/Rozanjin KITAOJI (March 23, 1883 - December 21, 1959) was a Japanese artist.

person.name: YAMAGATA Aritomo
person.desc: Aritomo YAMAGATA (May 15, 1838 - February 1, 1922) was a Japanese soldier and politician.

person.name: HOSOKAWA Katsumoto
person.desc: Katsumoto HOSOKAWA was a shugo (military governor) daimyo in the Muromachi period, a kanrei (shogunal deputy or a chief official) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and the head of the Hosokawa clan (as one of the so-called three shogunal deputies) in the main Hosokawa clan line.

person.name: HOSOKAWA Masamoto
person.desc: Masamoto HOSOKAWA was a Shugo (military governor) daimyo in the mid- to late Muromachi Period.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshinori
person.desc: Yoshinori ASHIKAGA (July 20, 1394 - July 21, 1441) was the 6th Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi shogunate (shogunship from 1428 to 1441).

person.name: MAEDA Toshimasu
person.desc: He was a warlord of the Sengoku period, was an adopted son of Toshihisa MAEDA, and had various nicknames such as Keijiro.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshimi
person.desc: Yoshimi ASHIKAGA was a member of the ASHIKAGA clan from the mid- to late Muromachi period.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshihisa
person.desc: Yoshisa ASHIKAGA was the 9th Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi Shogunate (reigned between 1473 - 1489).

person.name: Yoshihiro HATAKEYAMA (his name can also be read as Yoshinari)
person.url: person/Yoshihiro HATAKEYAMA (his name can also be read as Yoshinari).html
person.desc: Yoshihiro Hatakeyama (1437 - January 30, 1491) was a general of the Muromachi period.

person.name: OUCHI Masahiro
person.desc: Masahiro OUCHI was the twenty-ninth head of the Ouchi clan, Shugo (Military Governor) Daimyo during the Muromachi period.

person.name: YAMANA Sozen
person.desc: Sozen YAMANA (also known as Mochitoyo YAMANA) (July 6, 1404-April 15, 1473) was a Shugo (Military Governor) Daimyo in the Muromachi period.

person.name: ASHIKAGA Yoshiharu
person.desc: Yoshiharu ASHIKAGA was the 12th Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi Shogunate (shogunship from 1521 to 1546).

person.name: HOJO Tokimasa
person.desc: Tokimasa HOJO (1138 - Feb. 6, 1215) was the father of Masako HOJO, the wife of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo.

person.name: HINO Katsumitsu
person.desc: Katsumitsu HINO (1429 - July 15, 1476) was a kuge (court noble) in the Muromachi Period.

person.name: The Ashikaga Clan
person.desc: The Ashikaga clan was a Japanese samurai family.

person.name: HOSOKAWA Sumimoto
person.desc: Sumimoto HOSOKAWA was a war lord and daimyo during the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

person.name: HOSOKAWA Takakuni
person.desc: Takakuni HOSOKAWA was a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) and military commander during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

person.name: HOJO Masako
person.desc: Masako HOJO (born 1157 and died August 23, 1225, which is July 11 on the old lunar calendar) lived from the end of the Heian Period to the beginning of Kamakura Period.

person.name: HOJO Yoshitoki
person.desc: Yoshitoki HOJO served as the second regent to the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

person.name: HOJO Tokiyori
person.desc: Tokiyori HOJO (July 6, 1227 - December 31, 1263) served as fifth regent to the Kamakura Shogunate for the period from 1246 to 1256.

person.name: HOJO Soun
person.desc: Soun HOJO (also known as Moritoki ISE) was a military commander during the mid to late Muromachi Period, and the patriarch of the Gohojo clan (or Late Hojo), a powerful warrior clan of the Warring States Period.

person.name: Shuten Doji
person.desc: Shuten Doji was the chief of the oni (a kind of demon or ogre), who were believed to live on Oi no Saka (Oi Hill Road) in Oe at the border between Kyoto and Tanba Province (he may also have been a robber).

person.name: MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu
person.desc: MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu (948 - September 4, 1021) was a military commander during the mid-Heian Period.

person.name: TSUNA WATANABE no
person.desc: WATANABE no Tsuna (953 - March 23, 1025) was a military commander during the mid-Heian Period.

person.name: URABE no Suetake
person.desc: URABE no Suetake (date of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived during the middle of the Heian Period.

person.name: USUI Sadamitsu
person.desc: Sadamitsu USUI (954-1021) was a busho (Japanese military commander) who lived during the middle of the Heian Period.

person.name: Saga-Genji
person.desc: The Saga-Genji were the descendants of Emperor Saga, the fufty second emperor, and the first to be given the Genji name.

person.name: Empress Dowager Eisho
person.desc: Empress Dowager Eisho (maiden name: Asako KUJO, December 23, 1833 - January 11, 1897) was Emperor Komei's Nyogo (consort) and Emperor Meiji's mother.

person.name: Uesugi Clan
person.desc: The Uesugi clan (pronounced either Uesugi-shi or Uesugi-uji in Japanese) was a Japanese clan.

person.name: OMURA Masujiro
person.desc: Masujiro OMURA (May 30, 1824 - December 7, 1869) was a physician, Western studies scholar and military theorist from Choshu Domain (now Yamaguchi Prefecture) at the end of the Edo era.

person.name: FUJIWARA no Yoritsune
person.desc: FUJIWARA no Yoritsune (February 12, 1219-September 8, 1256) was the 4th Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura Shogunate.

person.name: Imperial Prince Munetaka
person.desc: Imperial Prince Munetaka (December 22, 1242-September 9, 1274) was the 6th Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura Shogunate, and the first from the Imperial family.

person.name: Imperial Prince Koreyasu
person.desc: Imperial Prince Koreyasu (June 2, 1264 - December 3, 1326) was the 7th Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura Shogunate.

person.name: Imperial Prince Hisaaki (his name can also be read as Hisaakira)
person.url: person/Imperial Prince Hisaaki (his name can also be read as Hisaakira).html
person.desc: Imperial Prince Hisaaki (October 26, 1276 - November 24, 1328) was the 8th Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura Shogunate.

person.name: Saisho Jotai
person.desc: Saisho Jotai (1548 - March 23, 1608) was a Rinzai Sect monk who was active from the time of the Toyotomi regime to the Edo period.

person.name: YOSHIDA Toshimaro
person.desc: Toshimaro YOSHIDA (March 16, 1841 - July 8, 1864) was an activist of the Choshu Domain who was active in the late Edo period.

person.name: FUJITA Denzaburo
person.desc: Denzaburo FUJITA (August 2, 1841 - March 30, 1912) was a business heavyweight in the Kansai area during the Meiji Period and founder of the Fujita Zaibatsu (conglomerate).

person.name: TODO Heisuke
person.desc: Heisuke TODO (1844 - December 13, 1867) was a captain of the 8th troop of the Shinsengumi (special police).

person.name: SAITO Hajime
person.desc: Hajime SAITO (February 18, 1844 - September 28, 1915) was a samurai who was active from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.

person.name: SANNAN Keisuke
person.desc: Keisuke SANNAN (1833 - March 20, 1865) was the chief (vice chief) of Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

person.name: CHOSOKABE Morichika
person.desc: Morichika CHOSOKABE was a daimyo and busho (Japanese military commander) in Tosa Province who lived from the Azuchi Momoyama Period to the beginning of the Edo Period.

person.name: FURUTAKA Shuntaro
person.desc: Shuntaro FURUTAKA (1829 - August 21, 1864) was among the patriots of the Joi-ha (supporters of the expulsion of foreigners).

person.name: TANI Sanjuro
person.desc: Sanjuro TANI (? - May 15, 1866) was the leader of the seventh unit of Shinsengumi (an Edo shogunate police force located in Kyoto) and it is told that he was the grand master of the art of the spearmanship.

person.name: SHIMADA Kai
person.desc: Kai SHIMADA (February 29, 1828-March 20, 1900) was the corporal in the second unit of Shinsengumi (a group who guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate) and the Shoshi shirabeyaku ken kansatsu (Shinsengumi's organizational post for investigating movements of the opponents and keeping the Shinsengumi members under control).

person.name: NASU no Yoichi
person.desc: NASU no Yoichi (1169 - date of death unknown) was a warlord at the end of the Heian period.

person.name: KITABATAKE Akiie
person.desc: Akiie KITABATAKE (1318 - June 10, 1338) was a court noble during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

person.name: YOSHIMURA Kanichiro
person.desc: Kanichiro YOSHIMURA (1840 - January 27, 1868)

person.name: KITABATAKE Chikafusa
person.desc: Chikafusa KITABATAKE (March 15, 1293 - June 9, 1354)

person.name: TOKUGAWA Yorinobu
person.desc: Rishinin, Concubine from Ochi clan.

person.name: ITO Shinso
person.desc: Shinso ITO (April 25th 1942-) is a person of religion and the present Shinnyoen Buddhist (heir), whose real name is Masako ITO.

person.name: KANO Washio
person.desc: Washio KANO (December 14, 1839 - October 27, 1902) was an officer and corporal of the Shinsengumi masterless warriors' party; he later became a member of Goryo-eji (guardians of Imperial mausoleums) party (Kodaiji-to party).

person.name: ISHIDA Mitsunari
person.desc: Mitsunari ISHIDA was a feudal warlord in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: ODA Nobukatsu (Nobuo)
person.desc: Nobukatsu (Nobuo) ODA was a warlord/daimyo (feudal lord) who lived in the Azuchi-momoyama and early Edo periods.

person.name: HIRAYAMA Goro
person.desc: Goro HIRAYAMA (born in 1829 and died on October 30, 1863) was a samurai in the Edo period.

person.name: Tsurumatsu TOYOTOMI/ TOYOTOMI no Tsurumatsu
person.desc: Tsurumatsu TOYOTOMI/TOYOTOMI no Tsurumatsu (豊臣鶴松) was the first son of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (although there is a different theory that contradicts this)

person.name: Nisshu
person.desc: Nisshu (born in 1534 and died on May 26, 1625) was a woman who lived from the Warring States period (in Japan) (the late Muromachi period) until the early Edo period.

person.name: FUJIWARA no Shoshi
person.desc: Empress FUJIWARA no Akiko (her given name can also be pronounced "Shoshi") (988 - October 25, 1074) was the chugu (a court title given to a consort of the Emperor) of the sixty-sixth Emperor, Ichijio, and the mother of the sixty-eighth Emperor, Goichijo, and the sixty-ninth Emperor, Gosuzaku (she also held the title Kokumo, meaning empress dowager, and Nyoin).

person.name: FUJIWARA no Teishi
person.desc: FUJIWARA no Teishi (her name can alo be read as Sadako) (977-January 13, 1001) was Chugu and later Empress to the sixty-sixth Emperor, Ichijo, during the Heian period (The date of her death is taken from Kugyo FUJIWARA no Yukinari's diary, "Gonki" of the same period.

person.name: HATAKEYAMA Mochikuni
person.desc: Mochikuni HATAKEYAMA (1398-April 12, 1455) was a Kanrei (Shogun's deputy) of the Muromachi shogunate during the Muromachi period.

person.name: ASANO Nagamasa
person.desc: Nagamasa ASANO was a daimyo who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama and Edo periods.

person.name: MAEDA Geni
person.desc: Geni MAEDA was a busho (military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) during the Sengoku (Warring States) and the Azuchi-Momoyama periods.

person.name: NATSUKA Masaie
person.desc: Masaie NATSUKA (or NAGATSUKA) was a daimyo and member of the Gobugyo (Five Major Magistrates) of the TOYOTOMI Administration during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: KATO Yoshiaki
person.desc: Yoshiaki KATO was a busho (general) and daimyo during the Azuchi-Momoyama and Edo Periods.

person.name: WAKISAKA Yasuharu
person.desc: Yasuharu WAKISAKA was a busho (Military Commander) and daimyo (Feudal Lord) who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama and Edo periods.

person.name: KATAGIRI Katsumoto
person.desc: Katsumoto KATAGIRI was a daimyo (lord) who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama and Edo periods.

person.name: UESUGI Kagekatsu
person.desc: Kagekatsu UESUGI/Akikage NAGAO or Kagekatsu NAGAO was a feudal lord who lived from the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) until the early Edo period.

person.name: Senhime
person.desc: Senhime (May 26, 1597 to March 11, 1666) was a woman of the Azuchi-Momoyama and Edo periods, who was the primary wife of Hideyori TOYOTOMI and later of Tadatoki HONDA.

person.name: NIIZIMA Yae
person.desc: Yae NIIZIMA (1845 - 1932) was a Japanese woman who lived from the closing days of the Tokugawa shogunate until the early Showa period.

person.name: SOGA no Umako
person.desc: SOGA no Umako (male; born c. 551 and died on June 19, 626) was a politician during the Asuka period.

person.name: Ennin
person.desc: Ennin (794-February 24, 864) was the 3rd head priest of the Tendai Sect.

person.name: FUJIWARA no Senshi
person.desc: FUJIWARA no Senshi (her given name can also be pronounced "Akiko") (962 - February 7, 1002) was the nyogo (a court title given to a consort of the Emperor) of the sixty-forth emperor, Emperor Enyu, in the Heian period.

person.name: HIRAMA Jusuke
person.desc: Jusuke HIRAMA (1824- August 22, 1874 (by the old lunar calendar)).

person.name: SHIBUKAWA Harumi
person.desc: Harumi SHIBUKAWA (his name can also be read as Shunkai SHIBUKAWA) (November 1639-November 1, 1715) was an astronomer, go player and Shintoist.

person.name: TAIRA no Tadamori
person.desc: TAIRA no Tadamori was a samurai at the end of Heian period.

person.name: TAKAYAMA Hikokuro
person.desc: Hikokuro TAKAYAMA (June 15, 1747 - August 4, 1793) was a thinker who had fostered a theory of reverence for the Emperor at the end of Edo period.

person.name: MINAMOTO no Yoshitomo
person.desc: Lawful wives: Yura GOZEN (daughter of FUJIWARA no Suenori); Tokiwa GOZEN; a daughter of Yoshiaki MIURA; a younger sister of Yoshimichi HATANO; a prostitute from Ikeda-juku, Totoumi Province; and the daughter of Aohaka Choja

person.name: TAIRA no Shigemori
person.desc: TAIRA no Shigemori was a military commander and a kugyo (the top court officials) at the end of the Heian period.

person.name: TAIRA no Munemori
person.desc: TAIRA no Munemori was a warlord and noble who lived during the late Heian period.

person.name: TAIRA no Tomomori
person.desc: TAIRA no Tomomori was a warlord in the late Heian period.

person.name: TAIRA no Shigehira
person.desc: TAIRA no Shigehira was a warlord in the late Heian period.

person.name: SANJO Sanetomi
person.desc: Sanetomi SANJO (March 13, 1837 - February 18, 1891) was a noble and a politician who was active from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.

person.name: IKEDA Tsuneoki
person.desc: Tsuneoki IKEDA was a warlord during the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States) and Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: FUJIWARA no Tadabumi
person.desc: FUJIWARA no Tadabumi (873 - July 16, 947) was a councilor in the Heian period who served as Minbukyo (Minister of Popular Affairs).

person.name: Imperial Prince Nariyoshi
person.desc: Imperial Prince Nariyoshi (his name can also be read as Narinaga) (1326 - January 29, 1344) was the son of Emperor Godaigo of the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

person.name: MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi
person.desc: MINAMOTO no Tameyoshi was a samurai who lived towards the end of the Heian period.

person.name: TAIRA no Koremori
person.desc: TAIRA no Koremori was a samurai who lived towards the end of the Heian period.

person.name: UEMURA Shoen
person.desc: Shoen UEMURA (real name: Tsune or Tsuneko UEMURA, April 23, 1875, - August 27, 1949), born and raised at Shimogyo, Kyoto Prefecture in the Meiji period, was a Japanese-style painter who drew 'Bijinga' ('Beautiful Woman Painting') from a woman's viewpoint.

person.name: Imperial Prince Kuninomiya Asahiko
person.desc: Imperial Prince Kuninomiya Asahiko (March 27, 1824 to October 25, 1891) was a member of the Imperial family who lived in the closing days of the Tokugawa Shogunate and the early part of the Meiji period.

person.name: KIYOZAWA Manshi
person.desc: Manshi KIYOZAWA, August 10, 1863 - June 6, 1903 was a Japanese philosopher and Buddhist monk in the Meiji period.

person.name: SUGAWARA no Michizane
person.desc: SUGAWARA no Michizane (his name can also be read as Michimasa and Doshin) (August 5, 845 - March 31, 903) was a scholar, composer of Chinese poems, and a politician who lived in the Heian period.

person.name: Unkei
person.desc: Unkei (unknown birth date - January 10, 1224) was a sculptor of Buddhist statues who was actively engaged in his career from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.

person.name: ARIWARA no Narihira
person.desc: ARIWARA no Narihira (825 - July 13, 880) was an aristocrat who lived in the early Heian period.

person.name: Kaikei
person.desc: Kaikei (birth/death dates unknown) was a Busshi, Sculptor of Buddhist Statues, of the Kamakura period (1185-1333).

person.name: IWAKURA Tomomi
person.desc: Tomomi IWAKURA (October 26, 1825 - July 20, 1883) was a Japanese court noble and a politician.

person.name: KANO Masanobu
person.desc: Masanobu KANO (1434? - August 12, 1530?) was a painter of the Muromachi period and the founder of the Kano school.

person.name: KANO Motonobu
person.desc: Motonobu KANO (September 6, 1476 - November 15, 1559) was a painter of the Muromachi period, and the son of the Kano school's founder, Masanobu KANO.

person.name: MARUYAMA Okyo
person.desc: Okyo MARUYAMA, (June 12, 1733 – August 31, 1795) was a mid Edo period painter.

person.name: Tankei
person.desc: Tankei (1173-June 20, 1256) was a sculptor of Buddhist statues during the Kamakura period..

person.name: KANO Eitoku
person.desc: Eitoku KANO (February 16, 1543 - October 12, 1590) was a painter who lived during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: HASEGAWA Tohaku
person.desc: Tohaku HASEGAWA (1539 to March 19, 1610) was a painter in the Azuchi-Momoyama Period through to the early Edo Period.

person.name: IKE no Taiga
person.desc: Ike no Taiga is a literati painter during the Edo Period. He was born June 6, 1723 and died May 30, 1776.

person.name: UMEHARA Ryuzaburo
person.desc: Ryuzaburo UMEHARA (梅原 龍三郎: March 9, 1888 - January 16, 1986) is an oil painter who was active from the Taisho Period to Showa Period.

person.name: TOMIOKA Tessai
person.desc: Tessai TOMIOKA (January 25, 1837 - December 31, 1924) was a literati painter and Confucianist during the Meiji and Taisho Periods.

person.name: NONOMURA Ninsei
person.desc: Ninsei NONOMURA (野々村仁清: date of birth and date of death are unknown) is a potter in the early Edo Period.

person.name: OGATA Korin
person.desc: Korin OGATA (1658 - July 20, 1716) was an artist in the Edo Period.

person.name: TAWARAYA Sotatsu
person.desc: Sotatsu TAWARAYA (date of birth and death unknown, active between 1596 and 1644) was a painter during the early Edo Period.

person.name: KANO Sanraku
person.desc: Sanraku KANO (1559- September 30, 1635 [August 19, 1635 by the old calendar]) was a painter of the Kano School from the Azuchi-Momoyama Period (from 1573) to the early Edo Period (from 1603)

person.name: KAIHO Yusho
person.desc: Yusho KAIHO (1533- June 27, 1615 [June 2, 1615 by the lunar calendar]) was a painter of the Kano School from the Azuchi-Momoyama Period (from 1573) to the early Edo Period (from 1603).

person.name: KANO Tanyu
person.desc: Tanyu KANO (March 7, 1602 [January 14, 1602 by the old calendar] - November 4, 1674 [October 7, 1674 by the old calendar]) was a painter of the Kano School during the Edo Period.

person.name: OGATA Kenzan
person.desc: Kenzan OGATA (1663 - July 22, 1743) was a painter and potter in the Edo Period.

person.name: Goshun
person.desc: Goshun (April 28, 1752 - September 4, 1811) was a painter in the Edo Period.

person.name: AOKI Mokubei
person.desc: Mokubei AOKI (1767- July 2, 1833) was a painter and Kyo ware potter during the Edo Period.

person.name: HONAMI Koetsu
person.desc: Koetsu HONAMI (1558 - February 27, 1637) was a calligrapher and artist during the early Edo Period.

person.name: ITO Jakuchu
person.desc: Jakuchu ITO (March 1, 1716 - October 27, 1800) was a painter in Kyoto during the Edo period.

person.name: SOGA Shohaku
person.desc: Shohaku SOGA (1730 - January 30, 1781) was a painter in the Edo period.

person.name: HOSOKAWA Yoriyuki
person.desc: Yoriyuki HOSOKAWA (1329 - April 2, 1392) was a warrior, politician and Bakufu Kanrei (shogun deputy) between the Northern and Southern Courts period and the Muromachi period.

person.name: Saigyo
person.desc: Saigyo (1118 - March 23, 1190) was a monk and poet during the period between the cloister government and the Kamakura period.

person.name: DOMOTO Insho
person.desc: Insho DOMOTO (December 25, 1891 - September 5, 1975) was a Japanese-style painting artist.

person.name: ONO no Takamura
person.desc: ONO no Takamura (802 - February 7, 853) was a bureaucrat, scholar and poet in the early Heian period.

person.name: KURODA Yoshitaka

person.desc: Iemitsu TOKUGAWA was the third Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") from 1623 to 1651 of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

person.name: ASAI Chu
person.desc: Chu ASAI (July 22, 1856 - December 16, 1907) was a Western-style painter in the Meiji period.

person.name: TAKI Rentaro
person.desc: Rentaro TAKI (August 24, 1879 - June 29, 1903) was a Japanese musician and composer.

person.name: Roben
person.desc: Roben (689 - January 10, 774) was a bonze of the Kegon Sect in the Nara period.

person.name: MASAOKA Shiki
person.desc: Shiki MASAOKA (October 14, 1867- September 19, 1902) wrote haiku (Japanese poems of 17 syllables, arranged in lines of 5, 7, and 5 syllables, that traditionally contained a reference to the seasons) and tanka (short Japanese poems of 31 syllables, arranged in lines of 5, 7, 5, 7, and 7 syllables), and was a researcher into the history and development of the Japanese language.

person.name: ODA Nobuhide
person.desc: Nobuhide ODA is a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) of Owari Province in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

person.name: FUJIWARA no Sadaie
person.desc: FUJIWARA no Sadaie (1162 - October 3, 1241 [September 26, 1241 in the Julian calendar]) was a court noble and poet in the early Kamakura period.

person.name: Shotoku Taishi (Prince Shotoku)
person.desc: Shotoku Taishi (February 9, 574 - April 11, 622 or according to the "Nihonshoki" [Chronicles of Japan], March 6, 621) was a prince during the Asuka period.

person.name: YOKOI Shonan
person.desc: Shonan YOKOI (male, September 22, 1809 - February 15, 1869) is a samurai, feudal retainer of Kumamoto Domain and Confucian.

person.name: OGYU Sorai
person.desc: Sorai OGYU (March 21, 1666 - February 28, 1728) is a Confucian, thinker and philologist in the middle of the Edo period.

person.name: Prince Higashikuninomiya Naruhiko
person.desc: Prince Naruhiko HIGASHIKUNINOMIYA (December 3, 1887 - January 20, 1990) was the 43rd Prime Minister of Japan (in office August 17, 1945 - October 9, 1945).

person.name: TOKUGAWA Yoshisue
person.desc: Yoshisue TOKUGAWA/Yoshisue SERADA (date of birth and death unknown) was a samurai warrior who was active from the end of the Heian period to around the beginning of the Kamakura period, and he was the founder of the Egawa Clan and the Serada Clan, which were branches of the Nitta Clan from the Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto Clan).

person.name: SAKAI Tadatsugu
person.desc: Tadatsugu SAKAI was a Japanese military commander in Mikawa Province who was active from the Sengoku period (Japan) to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: HONDA Tadakatsu
person.desc: Tadakatsu HONDA was a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) who lived from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

person.name: II Naomasa
person.desc: Naomasa II was a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) in the Azuchi-Momoyama and early Edo periods.

person.name: IMAGAWA Yoshimoto
person.desc: Yoshimoto IMAGAWA was a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), who lived during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

person.name: ITO Jinsai
person.desc: Jinsai ITO (August 30, 1627 - April 5, 1705) was a Confucian scholar and philosopher in the early Edo period.

person.name: MINAMOTO no Sanetomo
person.desc: MINAMOTO no Sanetomo was the third Seii-taishogun (literally, "great general who subdued the barbarians") of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

person.name: TOKUGAWA Hidetada
person.desc: Hidetada TOKUGAWA (May 12, 1579 - March 14, 1632) was a Busho (Japanese military commander) from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the Edo period and the second Shogun of the Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

person.name: UTAGAWA Hiroshige
person.desc: Hiroshige UTAGAWA (1797 - October 12, 1858) was an Ukiyoe artist.

person.name: TOKUGAWA Ietsuna
person.desc: Ietsuna TOKUGAWA was the fourth Seitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians) of the Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government) and held office from 1651 – 1680.

person.name: TSUDA Sen
person.desc: Sen TSUDA (August 6, 1837 - April 24, 1908) was a Japanese agriculturist and a Christian.

person.name: ENOMOTO Takeaki
person.desc: Takeaki ENOMOTO (December 5, 1936 [August 25, 1936 according to the old calender] – December 26, 1908) was a samurai, shogun's retainer and statesman during the end of Edo period and Meiji period.

person.name: ODA Nobutada
person.desc: Nobutada ODA was a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) during the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: ODA Nobutaka
person.desc: Nobutaka ODA was a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord)of the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: OKUBO Toshimichi
person.desc: Toshimichi OKUBO (1830~1878):Japanese warrior, feudal retainer of Satsuma, a statesman

person.name: AZAI Nagamasa
person.desc: Nagamasa AZAI (浅井 長政, formerly written as 淺井 長政) was a busho (Japanese military commander during the Sengoku Period [period of warring states] in Japan, at the end of the Muromachi Period) and warring lord in Omi Province.

person.name: ASAKURA Yoshikage
person.desc: Yoshikage ASAKURA was a busho (Japanese military commander) during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan).

person.name: TOYOTOMI Hidetsugu
person.desc: Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI/Hidetsugu HASHIBA was a busho (Japanese military commander), daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) and Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) from the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan) (the end of the Muromachi period) to Tensho period.

person.name: TOYOTOMI Hideyori
person.desc: Hideyori TOYOTOMI (also known as TOYOTOMI no Hideyori or Hideyori HASHIBA) was a daimyo from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the beginning of the Edo period.

person.name: Yodo-dono
person.desc: Yodo-dono (c. 1569 – c. June 4, 1615) was a woman who lived from the Sengoku period (the end of Muromachi period) to the early Edo period, and a concubine of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI (Hideyoshi HASHIBA).

person.name: SHIBATA Katsuie
person.desc: Katsuie SHIBATA was a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) who lived from the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (Japan) to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: ODA Hidenobu
person.desc: Hidenobu ODA was a busho (Japanese military commander) and a Christian daimyo (Christian feudal lord) who lived from the Azuchi-momoyama period to the Edo period.

person.name: TOKUGAWA Ieharu
person.desc: Ieharu TOKUGAWA was the tenth Seitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader) of the Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) (his tenure of office: 1760 - 1786).

person.name: TOKUGAWA Ieyoshi
person.desc: Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA was the 12th Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) (reigned between 1837 - 1853).

person.name: HIGUCHI Ichiyo
person.desc: Ichiyo HIGUCHI (May 2, 1872 - November 23, 1896) was a Japanese novelist.

person.name: OKAMOTO Kido
person.desc: Kido OKAMOTO (November 11, 1872 - March 1, 1939) was a novelist and playwright.

person.name: TOKUGAWA Mitsukuni
person.desc: Mitsukuni TOKUGAWA was the second lord of the Mito Domain in Hitachi Province.

person.name: OKUMA Shigenobu
person.desc: Shigenobu OKUMA (March 11, 1838-January 10, 1922) was a feudal retainer of the Saga clan who was a Japanese warrior, a statesman, and an educator.

person.name: TANUMA Okitsugu
person.desc: Okitsugu TANUMA was a samurai and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) of the middle Edo period.

person.name: KURODA Kiyotaka
person.desc: Kiyotaka KURODA (November 9, 1840 – August 23, 1900) was a Japanese samurai, a feudal retainer of the Satsuma clan, and a politician.

person.name: DATE Masamune
person.desc: Masamune DATE (September 5, 1567 - June 27, 1636) was a feudal warlord who lived during the Sengoku period.

person.name: TAKASUGI Shinsaku
person.desc: Shinsaku TAKASUGI (September 27, 1839 - May 17, 1867) was a Japanese samurai of the Choshu clan.

person.name: MORI Ogai
person.desc: Ogai MORI (February 17, 1862 - July 9, 1922) was a novelist, critic, translator, playwright, surgeon of the Imperial Army and Bureaucrat (Senior Official First Class).

person.name: HOSHI Toru
person.desc: Toru HOSHI (May 19, 1850 - June 21, 1901), was a statesman in the Meiji period (The kanji letter '享' often used for his first name Toru '亨' is incorrect).

person.name: Toyo
person.desc: Toyo (臺與; c. 235 - year of death unknown), also written as 壹與, was a woman who was said to have succeeded Himiko as her relative in the 3rd century of the Yayoi period (c. 250 BC – c. 250 AD; Yayoi derives from the name of district in Tokyo where the pottery representing this period unearthed) in Japan; Himiko was a queen of Yamataikoku (the largest chiefdom in Japan c. 250 governed by a female shaman named Himiko), who was in Gishiwajinden (Worenchuan [account of the Wa people] section of the volume Records of Wei [history of Cao Wei Kingdom; 220 - 265 in China]) in "Sanguo Zhi (a history book)" (Records of the Three Kingdoms; a historical record on the Three Kingdoms of Wei, Shu and Wu in ancient China).

person.name: INOUE Kaoru
person.desc: Kaoru INOUE (January 16, 1836 - September 1, 1915) was a Japanese feudal samurai retainer of the Choshu clan, statesman, and businessman.

person.name: SUGITA Genpaku
person.desc: Genpaku SUGITA (October 20, 1733 - June 1, 1817) was a rangakui (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) during the Edo Period.

person.name: TOKUGAWA Tsunayoshi
person.desc: Tsunayoshi TOKUGAWA (February 23, 1646 - February 19, 1709, reigning from 1680 to 1709) was the fifth seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues barbarians") of the Edo Shogunate.

person.name: Nohime
person.desc: Nohime (1535 - August 5, 1612), was the daughter of Dosan SAITO and lawful wife of Nobunaga ODA.

person.name: HATAKEYAMA Masanaga
person.desc: Masanaga HATAKEYAMA (1442-June 9, 1493) was a busho (Japanese military commander) and shugo daimyo (shugo, which were Japanese provincial military governors, that became daimyo, which were Japanese feudal lords) in the late Muromachi period.

person.name: TOKUGAWA Ienobu
person.desc: Ienobu TOKUGAWA was the sixth seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and took office from June 8, 1709 to November 12, 1712.

person.name: YAMADA Akiyoshi
person.desc: Akiyoshi YAMADA (November 18,1844-November 11,1892) was a samurai (a feudal retainer of the Choshu Domain), statesman and army military man.

person.name: EBARA Soroku
person.desc: Soroku Ebara (born March 10, 1842; died May 19, 1922) was a former retainer of the shogun who subsequently became a Japanese statesman and educator, as well as a Christian.

person.name: Honinbo Shusai
person.desc: Honinbo (Holder of the Honinbo Title for the strongest player of the board game of go) Shusai (June 24, 1874 - January 18, 1940) was a go (the board game of go, hereinafter referred to as go) player who lived from the Meiji period through to the Showa period.

person.name: HOJO Tokimune
person.desc: Tokimune HOJO was the eighth regent of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in the middle of Kamakura period.

person.name: AYUKAWA Yoshisuke
person.desc: Yoshisuke AYUKAWA (November 6, 1880 to February 13, 1967) was a Japanese entrepreneur and statesman.

person.name: UKITA Hideie
person.desc: Hideie UKITA was a Japanese military commander as well as a feudal lord in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: MATSUNAGA Hisahide
person.desc: Hisahide MATSUNAGA was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

person.name: HOSOKAWA Sumiyuki
person.desc: Sumiyuki HOSOKAWA was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the late Muromachi period (the Sengoku period [period of warring states]).

person.name: MURAI Mohei
person.desc: Mohei MURAI (June 10, 1821-May 1873) was a wealthy merchant from the Morioka Domain.

person.name: OTOMO Yoshishige
person.desc: Yoshishige OTOMO (also known as Sorin OTOMO) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

person.name: GODAI Tomoatsu
person.desc: Tomoatsu GODAI (February 12, 1836-September 25, 1885) was a Japanese samurai who served as a feudal retainer of the Satsuma clan at the end of the Edo period, and a businessman in the Meiji period.

person.name: TOKUGAWA Ienari
person.desc: Ienari TOKUGAWA was a Japanese warrior and the 11th Seii Taishogun (literally, "Great General Who Subdues the Barbarians"), who was in office from 1787 – 1837.

person.name: INABA Yoshimichi
person.desc: Yoshimichi INABA/Ittetsu INABA was a busho (Japanese military commander) from the Sengoku to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: II Naosuke
person.desc: Naosuke II was the 13th lord of the Hikone Domain, Omi Province.

person.name: SAIGO Tsugumichi
person.desc: Tsugumichi SAIGO (June 1, 1843 [old calendar] - July 18, 1902), also called Judo SAIGO, was a Japanese samurai serving as a feudal retainer of Satsuma, politician, and military man of the Imperial Japanese Navy.

person.name: KONISHI Yukinaga
person.desc: Yukinaga KONISHI was a daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: TOKUGAWA Ietsugu
person.desc: Ietsugu's stone pagoda located at his grave in the Zojo-ji Temple

person.name: TOKUGAWA Iesada
person.desc: Iesada TOKUGAWA was the thirteenth Seitaishogun (commander in chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians; a great and unifying leader) of the Edo Bakufu.

person.name: ISONO Koemon
person.desc: Koemon ISONO (November 12, 1825 - June 11, 1903) was an entrepreneur, primarily based in Osaka from the end of Edo Period to Meiji Period.

person.name: MATSUURA Takeshiro
person.desc: Takeshiro MATSUURA (March 12 1818-February 10 1888) was a Japanese explorer who was active from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.

person.name: KUSAKA Genzui
person.desc: Genzui KUSAKA (1840 - August 20, 1864) was a Japanese samurai and feudal retainer of the Choshu clan.

person.name: MATSUKATA Masayoshi
person.desc: Masayoshi MATSUKATA (March 23, 1835-July 2, 1924) was a Japanese samurai (feudal retainer of Satsuma) and a statesman.

person.name: KOBAYAKAWA Takakage
person.desc: Takakage KOBAYAKAWA was a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) who lived from the Sengoku period (period of Warring States) to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: MORI Motonari
person.desc: Motonari MORI was kokujin (local lord) and a fighting daimyo (territorial lord) of Aki Province in the late Muromachi to the Sengoku period.

person.name: SAKUMA Shozan
person.desc: Shozan (also known as Zozan) SAKUMA (March 22, 1811 - August 12, 1864) was a Japanese warrior, military strategist, and thinker.

person.name: MACHIDA Hisanari
person.desc: Hisanari MACHIDA (January 27, 1838 - September 15, 1897) was a feudal retainer of the Satsuma clan at the end of the Edo period and was a member of warrior class in the Meiji period.

person.name: SASAKI Takayuki
person.desc: Takayuki SASAKI (November 26, 1830-March 2, 1910) was a samurai of the Tosa Domain, a official in the Meiji government, and also a representative of political conservatives.

person.name: Tekona
person.desc: Tekona is the name of a woman who is believed to have lived in Mama, Katsushika, Shimosa Province (present-day Ichikawa City, Chiba Prefecture) before the Nara Period.

person.name: SAWA Nobuyoshi
person.desc: Nobuyoshi SAWA (February 9, 1836-September 27, 1873) was Kugyo (high court noble) in the end of the Edo period and a politician in the Meiji period.

person.name: INOUE Masaru
person.desc: Masaru INOUE (August 25, 1843, to August 2, 1910) was a samurai in the Edo Period (a feudal retainer of Choshu Domain) and a bureaucrat in the Meiji Period.

person.name: KATSUSHIKA Hokusai
person.desc: Hokusai KATSUSHIKA (c. October 31, 1760 - May 10, 1849) was a painter of Ukiyoe (Japanese woodblock prints) who flourished in the Edo period, a recent time in Japan, and was a representative figure of the late Edo period, Bunka and Bunsei eras (Kasei culture).

person.name: TOGO Heihachiro
person.desc: Heihachiro TOGO (January 27, 1847 - May 30, 1934) was a samurai, a feudal retainer of the Satsuma Domain, and a member of the Imperial Japanese Navy.

person.name: TSUBOUCHI Shoyo
person.desc: Shoyo TSUBOUCHI (坪内 逍遥, orthographic style: 逍遙, June 22, 1859 - February 28, 1935) was a novelist, critic, translator, and playwright in Japan who was active in the Meiji Era.

person.name: FUJIWARA no Yoritsugu
person.desc: FUJIWARA no Yoritsugu (December 17, 1239 - October 14, 1256) was the fifth Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Kamakura shogunate.

person.name: WATANABE Kazan
person.desc: Kazan WATANABE (October 20, 1793 to November 23, 1841) was a politician and painter who lived during the late Edo period.

person.name: MAEDA Toshiie
person.desc: Toshiie MAEDA (前田 利家, January 25, 1539 - April 27, 1599) was a busho (Japanese military commander) and daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) from the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (the late Muromachi period) to the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: SASSA Narimasa
person.desc: Narimasa SASSA was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku (period of warring states) and Azuchi-Momoyama periods.

person.name: HARADA Sanosuke
person.desc: Sanosuke HARADA (1840 - July 6, 1868) was the leader of the Tenth Unit of Shinsengumi.

person.name: MATSUDAIRA Shungaku
person.desc: Shungaku MATSUDAIRA was a Japanese feudal lord, the 16th lord of the Fukui Domain of Echigo Province in the late Edo period.

person.name: MATSUBARA Chuji
person.desc: Chuji MATSUBARA (date of birth unknown, 1835 - October 20, 1865) was a Roshi (masterless samurai) from Harima Province (Osaka, according to Shinpachi NAGAKURA), joined Shinsengumi and became a Fukucho-jokin (assistant vice commander), leader of the Fourth Unit and instructor of jujutsu.

person.name: OKADA Izo
person.desc: Izo OKADA (1838 - June 3, 1865) was one of the Bakumatsu Shidai Hitokiri (Four famous assassins of Bakumatsu, end of the Edo Period) who joined the Tosa kinnoto (loyalist clique of Tosa) in his hometown, Tosa Province.

person.name: TAKEDA Kanryusai
person.desc: Kanryusai TAKEDA (around 1830 - July 23, 1867) was a member of Shinsengumi from the Mori Domain in Inaba Province.

person.name: KUSUMOTO Masataka
person.desc: Masataka KUSUMOTO (April 14, 1838-February 7, 1902) was a samurai from the Omura Domain, Hizen Province, and a Meiji Period statesman.

person.name: SUZUKI Mikisaburo
person.desc: Mikisaburo SUZUKI (August 15, 1837 - July 11, 1919) was the leader of the Ninth Unit of Shinsengumi and a member of Goryo-eji (guards of Imperial mausoleums).

person.name: HATTORI Takeo
person.desc: Takeo HATTORI (1832 - December 13, 1867) was a member of Shinsengumi and Goryo-eji (guards of Imperial mausoleums).

person.name: YAMAZAKI Susumu
person.desc: Susumu YAMAZAKI (around 1833, date of birth unknown - February 6, 1868) was a Shoshi shirabeyaku ken kansatsu of Shinsengumi (Shinsengumi's organizational post for investigating the movement of opponents and keeping the members of Shinsengumi under control).

person.name: SHINOHARA Tainoshin
person.desc: Tainoshin SHINOHARA (December 22, 1828 - June 13, 1911) was a loyalist in the late Edo period.

person.name: HOJO Takatoki
person.desc: Takatoki HOJO was the 14th regent to Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) (office between 1316 - 1326).

person.name: MORI Naritoshi
person.desc: Naritoshi MORI was a busho (Japanese military commander) of the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

person.name: ASHIKAGA Motouji
person.desc: Motouji ASHIKAGA (April 10, 1340 - June 2, 1367) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in Muromachi period.

person.name: ODA Nobuyuki
person.desc: Nobuyuki ODA was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

person.name: NIIMI Nishiki
person.desc: Nishiki NIIMI (1836 – October 25, 1863?)

person.name: Oichi no Kata (Lady Oichi)
person.desc: Oichi no Kata (1547 ? - June 14, 1583) was a woman of the Sengoku ｐeriod (Period of Warring States).

person.name: NAKAMURA Kazuuji
person.desc: Kazuuji NAKAMURA was a Daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) in the Azuchi-Momoyama period.

person.name: KATO Kiyomasa
person.desc: Kiyomasa KATO was a Busho (Japanese military commander) and Daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) from the Azuchi-Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

person.name: IKEDA Shichisaburo
person.desc: A member of Shinsengumi, Shichisaburo IKEDA (December 27, 1849 – January 16, 1938) was the last remaining survivor of Shinsengumi (a special police force of the late Tokugawa shogunate period).

person.name: YAMATO no Aya no Koma
person.desc: YAMATO no Aya no Koma (year of birth unknown - 592) is a person duing the Asuka Period.

person.name: YOKOYAMA Taikan
person.desc: Taikan YOKOYAMA (orthographic style: Taikan, November 2, 1868 - February 26, 1958) was a Japanese artist.

person.name: SHIGA Naoya
person.desc: Naoya SHIGA (February 20, 1883-October 21, 1971) was a Japanese novelist.

person.name: NOGUCHI Kenji
person.desc: Kenji NOGUCHI (1843 – February 4, 1864).

person.name: SAEKI Matasaburo
person.desc: Matasaburo Saeki (year of birth unknown – September 22, 1863) was a Fukucho jokin (assistant vice commander) of Shinsengumi (a special police force of the late Tokugawa shogunate period).

person.name: TANI Shuhei
person.desc: Shuhei TANI (May 20, 1948 - December 2, 1901) was a member of Shinsengumi (a special police force of the late Tokugawa shogunate period).

person.name: HOJO Ujimasa
person.desc: Ujimasa HOJO was a busho (Japanese military commander) and a Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) in Sagami Province who lived during the Sengoku period (period of warring states).

person.name: GAMO Kunpei
person.desc: Kunpei GAMO (1768 - July 31, 1813) was a Confucian scholar in the late Edo period.

person.name: Ohime (A Daughter of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo)
person.url: person/Ohime (A Daughter of MINAMOTO no Yoritomo).html
person.desc: Ohime (1178-August 28, 1197) was a woman who lived from the end of the Heian period to the beginning of the Kamakura period.

person.name: OTOMO no Otomaro
person.desc: OTOMO no Otomaro (731? - July 18, 809) was a Kugyo (high court noble) and busho (Japanese military commander) in Nara and the early Heian period.

person.name: HATOYAMA Kazuo
person.desc: Kazuo HATOYAMA (May 6, 1856, to October 3, 1911) was a samurai, a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain, Mimasaka Province, in the late Edo Period, and a statesman and an advocate (lawyer) after Meiji Restoration.

person.name: Mancio Ito
person.desc: Mancio ITO (otherwise written as Mancio or '満所', circa 1569 - November 13, 1612) was a Christian and one of the senior envoys of the Tensho Keno Shonen Shisetsu (the Tensho Youth Mission to Europe) who lived from the Azuchi Momoyama period into the early Edo period.

person.name: CHIJIWA Miguel
person.desc: Miguel CHIJIWA (1569 - January 23, 1633?) was a Christian who was one of the senior envoy of Tensho Keno Shonen Shisetsu (the Tensho Boy Mission to Europe) who lived during the Azuchi Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

person.name: HARA Martinho
person.desc: Martinho HARA (1569 - October 20, 1632) was a Christian who was one of the vice-envoys of Tensho Keno Shonen Shisetsu (the Tensho Boy Mission to Europe) that lived during the Azuchi Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

person.name: NAKAURA Juliao
person.desc: Juliao NAKAURA (1568 - October 22, 1633) was a Christian and was one of the vice-envoys of Tensho Keno Shonen Shisetsu (the Tensho Boy Mission to Europe) who lived during the Azuchi Momoyama period to the early Edo period.

person.name: KURODA Seiki
person.desc: Seiki KURODA (August 9, 1866 - July 15, 1924) was a Western-style painter who came from Kagoshima City, Kagoshima Prefecture.

person.name: TAIRA no Atsumori
person.desc: TAIRA no Atsumori was a Japanese military commander lived during the late Heian Period.

person.name: TSUDA Sanzo
person.desc: Sanzo TSUDA (February 15, 1855-September 29, 1891) was a Shiga Prefecture police officer and an army sergeant.

person.name: HOJO Genan

person.name: IKEDA Toshitaka
person.desc: (420,000 koku (approximately 76 million liters of crop yield))

person.name: ABE no Yoritoki

person.desc: Seven wise men in Saga was a general name of seven great men of Saga, who made remarkable services in the end of Edo Period (the last days of Tokugawa Shogunate) to Meiji period.

person.name: SASAKI Hideyoshi
person.desc: Hideyoshi SASAKI was a Japanese military commander in the late Heian period.

person.name: MINAMOTO no Mareyoshi
person.desc: Or in 1152.

person.name: KANEKO Kentaro

person.name: GO Junzo
person.desc: Junzo GO (June 12, 1825-December 2, 1910) was a Japanese warrior and shogun's retainer, a bureaucrat of Ministry of the Treasury and statesman.

person.name: SHIMAZU Sadahisa

person.name: OZEKI Masajiro
person.desc: Masajiro OZEKI (1844 ? - February 28, 1892) was a Shirabeyaku ken Kansatsu (Shinsengumi's organizational post for investigating movements of the opponents and keeping the Shinsengumi members under control) of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

person.name: HAYASHI Shintaro

person.name: YAMANO Yasohachi
person.desc: Yasohachi YAMANO (1841 - 1910) was a lowly member of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate), and one of the binan goninshu (five men of beauty).

person.name: UESUGI Shigeyoshi

person.name: TANI Mantaro

person.name: Ujitsune MUNAKATA (The Kamakura Period)

person.name: ASANO Kaoru
person.desc: Kaoru ASANO (year of birth unknown - 1867?) was a Shoshi shirabeyaku ken kansatsu (Shinsengumi's organizational post for investigating movements of the opponents and keeping the Shinsengumi members under control) of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

person.name: NAKAJIMA Nobori
person.desc: Nobori NAKAJIMA (February 25, 1838 - April 2, 1887) was a lowly member of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

person.name: DATE Muneatsu
person.desc: Muneatsu DATE (June 20, 1852 – January 6, 1907) was the governor of the Sendai Domain (although Munemoto DATE, the 30th head of the Date clan and the 14th lord of the Sendai Domain, still remained the head of the Date clan when Muneatsu was in office), a legitimate child (disinherited later) of the 13th lord of the Sendai Domain, Yoshikuni DATE, and a baron.

person.name: YASUTOMI Saisuke
person.desc: Saisuke YASUTOMI (1839 - May 28, 1873) from Ashimori Domain of Bicchu Province is a member of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

person.name: SHIBATA Hikozaburo
person.desc: Hikozaburo SHIBATA (1840 - August 3, 1866), was a lowly member of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

person.name: Aihime
person.desc: Aihime (her name also can be pronounced Yoshihime or Megohime) (1568 - February 21, 1653) was the only daughter of Kiyoaki TAMURA and a lawful wife of Masamune DATE.

person.name: HONDA Shigetsugu

person.name: YANAGIDA Sanjiro
person.desc: Sanjiro(三二郎) YANAGIDA (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of Mibu-Roshigumi (Mibu masterless warriors group) as well as a member of the Shinsengumi (a special force that guarded Kyoto during the end of Tokugawa Shogunate).

person.name: IESATO Tsuguo

person.name: MATSUDAIRA Nobuoki

person.name: NAKAYAMA Tadayasu
person.desc: Tadayasu NAKAYAMA (December 17, 1809-June 12, 1888) was a kuge (court noble) and a politician who lived from the end of the Edo period to the early part of the Meiji period.

person.name: MATSUDAIRA Mochiaki

person.name: FUJIWARA no Momokawa

person.name: UESUGI Norizane

person.name: UMEDA Unpin

person.name: HIRANO Kuniomi

person.name: ASHIKAGA Ietoki

person.name: INABA Sadamichi

person.name: KAWAJI Toshiyoshi

person.name: SHINAGAWA Yajiro

person.name: OYAMA Iwao

person.name: TERASHIMA Munenori

person.name: SANO Tsunetami

person.name: KASHUJI Tsuneosa
person.desc: Tsuneosa KASHUJI (Although he was born on November 21, 1825, his birthday was officially recorded as November 18, 1828): in "Yamashiro no Kuni Kyoto SODEOKA Genbanosuke Kaki" (The Family Chronicle of Genbanosuke SODEOKA in Kyoto, Yamashiro Province), (housed in the National Institute of Japanese Literature), written by Fumikage SODEOKA, a Jige official (the government officials of lower- ranked courtiers who were not allowed to enter the court) and a Zassho (or Karei: butler) served for the Kashuji family, who was asked to be a private tutor of Tsuneosa by Nariko KASHUJI, it is read '.....Mansenhime who came to the family as a bride gave a birth to Tsuneosa on October twelfth in the eighth year of the Bunsei era, so Tsuneosa's true age was fifteen years old this year; however it was recorded that he was only twelve years old when he was conferred Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) as his first court rank....' in the section of April 8, the tenth year of the Tempo era, which means his age was reported three years younger than actual for the official recording.

railway.name: Kyoto Municipal Subway, Karasuma Line
railway.jp: 京都市営地下鉄烏丸線
railway.desc: Karasuma Line is a part of the Kyoto Municipal Subway in Kyoto city, Kyoto, running from Kokusaikaikan Station (Sakyo-ward) to Takeda Station (Fushimi-ward).

railway.name: Sagano Scenic Railway
railway.desc: Sagano Scenic Railway is the company operating Torokko trams on the Sagano Sight-seeing Tram Line, which utilizes the old San-in Line in Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

railway.name: The Sanjyo-Keihan Station
railway.desc: Information

railway.name: (JR) Nara Line
railway.desc: The JR Nara Line is a railway line (arterial line) of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) that runs between Kizu Station (Kyoto Prefecture) in Kizugawa City, Kyoto Prefecture, and Kyoto Station in the Shimogyo Ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

railway.name: JR Kyoto Line
railway.desc: JR Kyoto-sen (JR Kyoto Line) is the unofficial name given to the section of the Tokaido Main Line of the West Japan Railway (JR West) that runs between Kyoto Station and Osaka Station.

railway.name: Kyoto Municipal Subway
railway.desc: Kyoto Municipal Subway is operated by the Kyoto Municipal Transportation Bureau.

railway.name: Kyoto Station
railway.desc: Kyoto Station, located in Higashi-Shiokojicho, Shimogyo Ward / Minami Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, is a railway station served by the lines of West Japan Railway Company (JR West), Central Japan Railway Company (JR Central), Kintetsu Corporation and the Kyoto Municipal Transportation Bureau.

railway.name: Hankyu Railway
railway.desc: Hankyu Corporation (Hankyu Dentetsu) is a major private railway company operating the railways that connect Osaka Umeda Station with Kobe City, Takarazuka City and Kyoto City.

railway.name: THRU Surutto KANSAI (KANSAI PASS)
railway.desc: Surutto KANSAI is the network of the railway cards for the public transport system in Kansai (Kinki area), or the biggest company in its association, which has a head office in Osaka City, Osaka-Prefecture.

railway.name: Biwako Line
railway.desc: The Biwako Line is the name of the train line that runs between Kyoto Station and Maibara Station of the Tokaido Main Line, and also between Maibara Station and Nagahama Station of the Hokuriku Main Line, both of which are run by West Japan Railway Company (JR West).

railway.name: Kyoto Electric Railway
railway.desc: Kyoto Electric Railway is a private rail company established in 1893.

railway.name: Kansai Railway Company
railway.desc: Kansai Railway Company (It's pronounced in kanji characters as either Kansai Railway Company or Kansei Railway Company) is a railway industry that runs railroads across Central Japan Railway Company (JR Central) and West Japan Railway Company (JR West)'s current railroad, which existed during the Meiji period; it is the predecessor of the Kansai Main Line, Kusatsu Line, Katamachi Line, Kisei Main Line, Sakurai Line, Wakayama Line, Nara Line and Osaka Loop Line.

railway.name: ICOCA
railway.desc: ICOCA (ikoka) is an IC card, mainly used as a ticket, electronic money and locker key, that West Japan Railway Company (JR West) launched in the Kinki District Urban Network on November 1, 2003.

railway.name: Keihan Uji Line
railway.desc: The Uji Line is a railway line of Keihan Electric Railway that connects Chushojima Station located in Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture and Uji Station (Keihan) located in Uji City, Kyoto Prefecture.

railway.name: Kintetsu Kyoto Line
railway.desc: The Kintetsu Kyoto Line (Kintetsu Kyoto-sen) is a railway line of Kintetsu Corporation (Kintetsu) and it connects Kyoto Station located in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture and Yamato-Saidaiji Station in Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

railway.name: Hankyu Arashiyama Line
railway.desc: The Hankyu Arashiyama Line (Hankyu Arashiyama-sen) is a railway of Hankyu Corporation that connects from Katsura Station located in Saikyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, to Arashiyama Station (Hankyu).

railway.name: Keihan Main Line
railway.desc: The Keihan Main Line (Keihan Hon-sen) is a railway of Keihan Electric Railway connecting Yodoyabashi Station located in Chuo Ward, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture (Osaka City) with Sanjo Station in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture (Kyoto Prefecture).

railway.name: Keihan Oto Line
railway.desc: The Oto Line (鴨東線: pronounced Oto-sen) is a railway of Keihan Electric Railway that connects Sanjo Station in the Higashiyama Ward of Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture with Demachiyanagi Station in the Sakyo ward of the same city.

railway.name: Hankyu Kyoto Main Line
railway.desc: The Kyoto Main Line is a railway of Hankyu Railway that connects Juso Station in Yodogawa Ward, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture, with Kawaramachi Station (Kyoto Prefecture) in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

railway.name: Omiya Station
railway.desc: Omiya Station (Omiya-eki)

railway.name: Jujo Station
railway.desc: Jujo Station (Tokyo), located in the Kita Ward of Tokyo, is a station on the Saikyo Line (Akabane Line) of the East Japan Railway Company (JR East).

railway.name: Eizan Electric Railway Co., Ltd.
railway.desc: Eizan Electric Railway Co., Ltd. is a railway business operator managing lines between Demachiyanagi Station in Kyoto City's Sakyo Ward and Yase/Kurama.

railway.name: Kusatsu Line
railway.desc: The Kusatsu Line is a railway line (arterial line) of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) that runs between Tsuge Station in Iga City, Mie Prefecture, and Kusatsu Station (Shiga Prefecture) in Kusatsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

railway.name: Kosei Line
railway.desc: The Kosei Line is a railway line (arterial line) of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West) that runs between Yamashina Station in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, and Omi-Shiotsu Station in Nishiazai-cho, Ika-gun, Shiga Prefecture.

railway.name: Fukuchiyama Line
railway.desc: The Fukuchiyama Line is a (trunk) railway line operated by the West Japan Railway Company that connects Amagasaki Station in Amagasaki City, Hyogo Prefecture, and Fukuchiyama Station in Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture.

railway.name: Sanin Main Line

railway.name: Kyoto Uji Rakunan One-Day Ticket

railway.desc: The "Kyoto Uji Rakunan One-Day Ticket" electronic card, which allows unlimited rides and comes with coupons offering various discounts and special benefits as part of the package, is sold jointly by the Osaka Municipal Transportation Bureau, Keihan Electric Railway (Keihan), Semboku Rapid Railway (Semboku Rapid) of Osaka Prefectural Urban Development Co., Ltd., and Nankai Electric Railway (Nankai).

railway.name: Kizugawa Station (Kyoto Prefecture)

railway.name: Higashiyama-sanjo Station
railway.desc: Higashiyama-sanjo Station, located in Furukawa-cho, Sanjoyamato-oji Kudaru, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, was a stop on the Keihan Keishin Line operated by the Keihan Electric Railway Co., Ltd.

railway.name: Keage Station (Keihan)
railway.desc: Keage Station, located in Keage, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, was a stop on the Keihan Keishin Line operated by the Keihan Electric Railway.

railway.name: Kitano Station (Kyoto Prefecture)

railway.name: Keifuku Electric Railroad

railway.name: Ranzan-Tenjingawa Station

railway.name: Nagaokakyo Happy Bus

railway.name: Transportation in Japan

railway.name: Shinkansen (a term related to bullet trains)
railway.url: railway/Shinkansen (a term related to bullet trains).html
railway.desc: Following the Tokaido Shinkansen that the former Japan National Railways (JNR) started operation on October 1, 1964, each of the JR group companies has operated its own high-speed railway system, and the term Shinkansen is used for indicating the railways for high-speed operations, the train-cars, and related railway-based transportation systems as a whole.

railway.name: Yamatoji Line
railway.desc: Yamatoji Line is the nickname for the electrified section of rail between Kamo Station (Kyoto Prefecture) and JR Nanba Station that runs on the Kansai Main Line of the West Japan Railway Company (JR West Japan).

railway.name: Katamachi Line
railway.desc: Katamachi Line refers to the railway (trunk line) of West Japan Railway Company (JR West Japan) between Kizu Station (Kyoto Prefecture) in Kizu City, Kyoto Prefecture and Kyobashi Station (Osaka Prefecture) in Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture.

railway.name: Kansai Main Line
railway.desc: The Kansai Main Line is a railway line (main line) running from Nagoya Station, located in Nakamura Ward, Nagoya City, Aichi Prefecture, to the JR Namba Station, located in Naniwa Ward, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture, via the Kameyama Station (Mie Prefecture) and the Nara Station.

railway.name: JR Obama Line
railway.desc: Obama Line refers to the railway (local line) in West Japan Railway Company (JR West) from Suruga station in Suruga city, Fukui prefecture to Higashi-Maizuru station in Maizuru city, Kyoto prefecture.

railway.name: Kaya Tetsudo (Kaya Railway)
railway.desc: "Kaya Tetsudo" refers to the railway which connected Tango Yamada Station (the present Nodagawa Station of Kitakinki Tango Railway Miyazu Line) located at Nodagawa Town (the present Yosano Town), Yosa County, Kyoto Prefecture, with Kaya Station located at Kaya Town (the present Yosano Town) in the Yosa County.

railway.name: Hokutan Railway
railway.desc: Hokutan Railway is a railway operator which operated a line running northward from the Fukuchiyama Station in Fukichiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture to Komori Station.

railway.name: Kokutetsu (Japan National Railways (JNR)) Steam Locomotive Type 120

railway.desc: Type 120 was a steam locomotive that was imported from U.K. in 1874 when a railway began operation between Osaka and Kobe.

railway.name: Keihanshin Local Line
railway.desc: Keihanshin Local Line is a common name that has been used since the era of Japan National Railway (JNR) for the local line running, as a part of Urban Network of West Japan Railway Company (JR West) in the metropolitan suburban area, between the Kyoto Station and Kobe Station (Hyogo Prefecture) of the Tokaido Main Line as well as between the Kobe Station and Nishi-akashi Station of the Sanyo Main Line

railway.name: Atagoyama Railway

railway.name: Yanagidani Mountain Railway

railway.name: Yawata - Tanabe Bus Route

shrines.name: Udamikumari-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Honen-ji Temple (Kashihara City)

shrines.name: Ofusa Kannon

shrines.name: Aki-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Todai-ji Temple

shrines.name: Yoshihime-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Genkuroinari-jinja Shrine
shrines.desc: Genkuroinari-jinja is a Shinto Shrine located about 500 meters south west of Kintetsu Koriyama Station which is famous for its legends about two foxes, one called Genkuro and one who bought wataboshi (cotton caps).

shrines.name: Fukuchi-in Temple
shrines.desc: Fukuchi-in is a temple of Shingon Risshu sect located in Naramachi, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

shrines.name: Tokugen-in Temple

shrines.name: Tonan-in Temple (Yoshino cho)

shrines.name: Amida-ji Temple (Takashima City)

shrines.name: Daisen-ji Temple (Takashima City)

shrines.name: Ikagu-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Modoroki-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Sakunado-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Yamatsuteru-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Umaji Isobe-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Sakatashinmei-gu Shrine

shrines.name: Ishitsukuri-jinja Shrine, Tamatsukuri-jinja Shrine
shrines.desc: Ishitsukuri-jinja Shrine and Tamatsukuri-jinja Shrine are the shrines located in Kinomoto-cho, Ika County, Shiga Prefecture.

shrines.name: Okitsushima-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Kamisoko-jinja Shrine
shrines.desc: Kamisoko-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.

shrines.name: Shiotsu-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Kosaka-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Kojino-jinja Shrine
shrines.desc: Kojino-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Moriyama City, Shiga Prefecture.

shrines.name: Kawata-jinja Shrine (Minakuchi-cho, Koga City)

shrines.desc: Kawata-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Minakuchi-cho, Koga City, Shiga Prefecture.

shrines.name: Hakunu-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Ikishiro-jinja Shrine

shrines.name: Chikatsuo-jinja Shrine
shrines.desc: Chikatsuo-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Kokubu, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

shrines.name: Juge-jinja Shrine
shrines.desc: Juge-jinja Shrine counts among the seven "upper shrines" of Hiyoshi-taisha Shrine, which consists of the following shrines that have become the branch temple of Juge-gu Shrine.

shrines.name: Kawata-jinja Shrine (Tsuchiyama-cho, Koga City)
shrines.jp: 川田神社 (甲賀市土山町)
shrines.desc: Kawata-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Tsuchiyama-cho, Koga City, Shiga Prefecture.

shrines.name: Abe-jinja Shrine
shrines.desc: Abe-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Kamogata-cho, Asakuchi City, Okayama Prefecture.

shrines.name: Gesshin-ji Temple
shrines.desc: Gesshin-ji Temple is an independent temple under the Rinzai sect lineage, located in Otani, Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

shrines.name: Kokubun-ji Temple (Kashihara City)
shrines.desc: Kokubun-ji is a Buddhist temple of Jodo Sect located in 2-chome, Kitayagi, Kashihara City Nara Prefecture.

shrines.name: Honzen-ji Temple (Yoshino-cho)
shrines.desc: Honzen-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple of Jodo Shinshu Hongan-ji school located in Yoshino-cho, Yoshino-gun, Nara Prefecture.

shrines.name: Sanami-ji Temple
shrines.desc: Sanami-ji Temple is a temple of the Chisan school of Shingon sect located in Imazu-cho, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture and also a branch temple of Chishaku-in Temple, Kyoto Prefecture.

shrines.name: Daishin-ji Temple

shrines.name: Kawase-jinja Shrine (Hikone City)
shrines.desc: Kawase-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Hikone City, Shiga Prefecture.

school.name: The Doshisha
school.desc: The Doshisha is an educational institution, which includes Doshisha University and Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts.

school.name: Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts

school.desc: Doshisha Women's College of Liberal Arts is a Protestant college comprising four faculties and ten departments, having been reorganized in 1949 as a successor of the former Advanced Course of Doshisha Girls' School.

school.name: Kyoto City University of Arts
school.desc: Kyoto City University of Arts is a public university which is located in Nishikyo Ward, Kyoto, and is one of the premiere universities for arts and music in Japan.

school.name: Yasaka Nyokoba Gakuen
school.desc: Yasaka Nyokoba Gakuen (Gion Joshi Gigei School) is an educational institution of Maiko and Geiko located in Kobu Gion, Higashiyama-ku, Kyoto City.

school.name: Kyoto Hosei Gakko (Kyoto School of Law and Politics）
school.url: school/Kyoto Hosei Gakko (Kyoto School of Law and Politics）.html
school.desc: Kyoto Hosei School, a private institution established in 1990 by Kojuro NAKAGAWA,　et. al, was formerly the school of Ritsumeikan University (head office of the Educational Foundation: Nakagyo-ku, Kyoto City).

school.name: Shijuku Ritsumeikan (Ritsumeikan Private Academy)
school.desc: Shijuku Ritsumeikan was a private academy that Kinmochi SAIONJI established in his private residence in the Kyoto Imperial Palace in 1869.

school.name: Doshisha Junior High School
school.desc: Doshisha Junior High School is a private coeducational school located in Karasuma-dori Imadegawa-dori, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto City.

school.name: Rakunan High School / Rakuna Junior High School

school.desc: Rakunan High School and Rakunan Junior High School are private junior and senior high schools, respectively, located in Minami-ku, Kyoto City.

school.name: Bukkyo University
school.desc: Bukkyo University, a private institution established by the Jodo Sect, is located in Kita-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

school.name: Doshisha University
school.desc: Spirit of establishment

school.name: Kyoto Hogakko (Kyoto Law School)
school.desc: Kyoto Law School, a private school established in 1889, is located in Teramachi-dori Shijo-dori kudaru Daiun-in, Shimogyo-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

school.name: The Ritsumeikan University Confucius Institute
school.desc: The Ritsumeikan University Confucius Institute is a private school whose purpose is to propagate education in Chinese and culture.

school.name: Ashikaga School
school.desc: Ashikaga School is a high educational institution of the Medieval period which some say was established in the early Heian period or the Kamakura period.

school.name: Kyoto Jinbun Gakuen (Kyoto Humanism School)
school.desc: Kyoto Jinbun Gakuen (Kyoto Humanism School) founded in 1964 immediately after the end of World War II in Kyoto through private educational movements.

school.name: Higashiyama Joshi Gigei Gakko
school.desc: Located at Miyagawa-cho, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Higashiyama Joshi Gigei Gakko (Higashiyama Girls School of performance arts) is an educational organization for maiko (apprentice geisha) and geisha girls.

school.name: Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station
school.jp: 京都大学フィールド科学教育研究センター森林ステーション芦生研究林
school.url: school/Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station.html
school.desc: Field Science Education and Research Center, Kyoto University, Ashiu Forest Research Station (abbreviated to "Ashiu Forest Research Station, Kyoto University") is a research facility of Kyoto University, located in Miyama-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture (Kyoto Prefecture).

school.name: Kyoto Prefectural University
school.desc: History

school.name: Doshisha English School
school.desc: Doshisha English School (Doshisha Eigakko) is a private school that Joseph Hardy Neesima (Joe NIIJIMA) established in Kyoto in 1875.

school.name: Private school
school.desc: Private schools were private-run educational institutions (whose teachers were the brightest persons and former government ministers, etc.) in China as well as in Japan during the Edo Period.

school.name: Kyoto University Press
school.desc: Kyoto University Press is a circle certified by Kyoto University for publishing Kyoto University's student press "Kyoto University Press" (commonly known as "Kyodai Press") and other related publications.

school.name: Kyoto Prefectural Vocational Training School of Agriculture and Forestry (under the old system of education)
school.jp: 京都府立農林専門学校 (旧制)
school.url: school/Kyoto Prefectural Vocational Training School of Agriculture and Forestry (under the old system of ed.html
school.desc: Kyoto Prefectural Vocational Training School of Agriculture and Forestry was a public vocational school founded under the old education system in 1944.

school.name: Kyoto Prefectural Girls' Vocational Training School (under the old education system)
school.jp: 京都府立女子専門学校 (旧制)
school.url: school/Kyoto Prefectural Girls Vocational Training School (under the old education system).html
school.desc: Kyoto Prefectural Girls' Vocational Training School was a public vocational school founded under the old education system in March 1927.

school.name: Bangumi Elementary Schools
school.desc: Bangumi elementary schools refer to the sixty-four elementary schools established by the towns people in Kyoto in 1869, two years after the Meiji Restoration, based on the then extant municipal-level autonomous administrative unit known as the 'bangumi' (a neighborhood unit).

school.name: Budo Senmon Gakko (Vocational Training School of Martial Arts)
school.url: school/Budo Senmon Gakko (Vocational Training School of Martial Arts).html
school.desc: Budo Senmon Gakko (Vocational Training School of Martial Arts) is a vocational school under the old-education system founded by 'Dai-Nippon Butoku-Kai' (Great Japan Federation of Martial Arts) in present-day, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, to train martial arts coaches.

school.name: Kyoto Koto Sangyo Gakko
school.desc: Kyoto Koto Sangyo Gakko (Kyoto Sericulture High School) founded in 1914 was a vocational school under the old-education system.

school.name: Kyoto Higher Craft School (old education system)
school.jp: 京都高等工芸学校 (旧制)
school.url: school/Kyoto Higher Craft School (old education system).html
school.desc: Kyoto Higher Craft School is an old system vocational school (Specialist School of Business) established in 1902.

school.name: Kyoto Normal School
school.desc: Kyoto Normal School (teacher's training school) was established in Kyoto Prefecture, during World War Ⅱ in 1943.

school.name: Kyoto Seinen Shihan-Gakko (Kyoto Young Men's Normal School)
school.url: school/Kyoto Seinen Shihan-Gakko (Kyoto Young Mens Normal School).html
school.desc: Kyoto Seinen Shihan-Gakko (Kyoto Young Men's Normal School) was a Seinen Shihan-Gakko (Young Men's Normal School) established in 1944.

school.name: Imperial Universities
school.desc: Imperial Universities are the universities established according to the Imperial University Law promulgated in 1886.

school.name: Kyusei Koto Gakko (higher school under the old system)
school.url: school/Kyusei Koto Gakko (higher school under the old system).html
school.desc: Kyusei koto gakko was an institution of higher education in Japan based on the Higher School Order (in 1894 and 1918) that existed until 1950.

school.name: Normal School
school.desc: A SHIHAN GAKKO (normal school) is an middle and advanced educational institution for training teachers for elementary/middle schools (shihan education) under the prewar educational system reform.

school.name: Jinjo Shogakko (ordinary elementary school)
school.desc: Jinjo shogakko was a name for institutions of elementary education from the Meiji period to early Showa period.

school.name: Kobe Naval Training Center
school.desc: Kobe Naval Training Center is a naval officer training Institute and Navy Arsenal that Bakufu established in Kobe City in May 1864 under a proposal of Kaishu Katsu, a government's naval magistrate.

school.name: Narutakijuku
school.desc: Narutakijuku was a private school established in the suburbs of Nagasaki by Philip Franz von Siebold in 1824.

school.name: Rangaku Juku (Institute for Dutch Studies)
school.desc: Rangaku Juku is a kind of gakumonjo (school), spread as a private school in the Edo period, to learn Western studies.

school.name: Choyo Gakko
school.desc: Choyo Gakko was a three-story school with tile-roofing in western style, which was built in the premises of the current Tsuruoka City Hall by order of prefectural governor Michitsune MISHIMA in 1876.

school.name: School of Foreign Languages (old education system)
school.url: school/School of Foreign Languages (old education system).html
school.desc: School of Foreign Languages (old education system)

school.name: Ho-gakko (law school)
school.desc: Ho-gakko (law school) was an educational institution governed by the Ministry of Justice in the early Meiji Period and was one of the previous bodies of the existing the University of Tokyo, Faculty of Law.

school.name: Komori Gakko (Baby-sitter Schools)
school.desc: Komori gakko is a term used to refer to schools made for children who were not able to attend ordinary schools because they had to baby-sit their own little brothers and sisters or other families' little chidren in the early Meiji period.

Shinto.name: Shakaku
Shinto.desc: Shakaku is a ranking system for Shinto shrines.

Shinto.name: Nijunisha (22 Shrines)
Shinto.desc: The 22 Shrines are part of the Shakaku for Shinto shrines.

Shinto.name: Honchi-suijaku
Shinto.desc: Summary

Shinto.name: Amaterasu Omikami
Shinto.desc: Amaterasu omikami (Tensho daijin) is a humanized Shinto god in Japanese.

Shinto.name: Tsukuyomi
Shinto.desc: Tsukuyomi (cited as "月讀" (Tsukuyomi) or Tsukuyomi no mikoto) is one of the gods of Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Miko
Shinto.desc: 巫女 (miko) or 神子 (fujo) are women who mainly serve the gods of Yamato (Japan).

Shinto.name: Chokusai-sha shrine
Shinto.desc: "The Chokusai-sha shrine" is a shrine where festivals are attended by imperial messengers sent by the Emperor (called chokusai).

Shinto.name: Torii
