Shinto.desc: The torii represents a dividing line (kekkai) between sacred and secular areas, serving as an entrance to the sacred world in Shinto shrines and other holy places.

Shinto.name: Komainu
Shinto.desc: A komainu ("石獅子" in Chinese and "imperial guardian lion" in English) is an imaginary mythical beast that resembles a dog and lion mixed together.

Shinto.name: Ommyodo
Shinto.desc: Ommyodo, which owes its origin to ancient Chinese natural philosophical theory and Inyo-gogyo-shiso theory (the way of Yin and Yang, combined with the Taoist theory of the five elements), is a system of natural science and the art of spell-casting that uniquely developed in Japan.

Shinto.name: Kogo Shui
Shinto.desc: Kogo Shui is a piece of writing about Shinto during the Heian period.

Shinto.name: Goryo shinko
Shinto.desc: Goryo shinko is a Japanese belief that threatening natural disasters and epidemics are caused by "onryo" (restless spirits of people who died with a grudge or met an unnatural death) and that awing, reposing, and respecting these souls as "goryo" ("honorable spirits") will help to avoid their curses and bring peace and prosperity to society.

Shinto.name: Shinsen (Food and Alcohol Offering to the gods)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Shinsen (Food and Alcohol Offering to the gods).html
Shinto.desc: Shinsen is an offering to shrines and household Shinto altars in Japan.

Shinto.name: Ukanomitama
Shinto.desc: Ukanomitama is a deity that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).

Shinto.name: Oyamakuhi no kami
Shinto.desc: Oyamakuhi no kami is a Japanese deity.

Shinto.name: the god Inari
Shinto.desc: The god Inari is one of the Japanese Shinto gods.

Shinto.name: Toshigami
Shinto.desc: "Toshigami"(年神, also written as 歳神) is a Shinto god (Shinto).

Shinto.name: Ema
Shinto.desc: "Ema" is a wooden board with a picture of a horse, which is dedicated to a temple or a shrine when making a wish, or when showing gratitude for the granted wish.

Shinto.name: Shinsatsu
Shinto.desc: Shinsatsu is a gofu (talisman) distributed by shrines.

Shinto.name: Sangaku-shinko Faith
Shinto.desc: "Sangaku-shinko faith" is a faith worshipping mountains as being sacred.

Shinto.name: Ubusunagami (Guardian Deity of one's Birthplace)
Shinto.desc: Ubusunagami is the deity that controls or protects one's birthplace.

Shinto.name: DEGUCHI Onisaburo
Shinto.desc: "Onisaburo DEGUCHI," 1871? - January 19, 1948, was the practical founder of a new religion 'Omoto,' who laid out its teachings.

Shinto.name: Magatsuhi no kami
Shinto.desc: "Magatsuhi no kami (or Magatsui no kami)" is a Shinto god.

Shinto.name: Negi (assistant to Guji)
Shinto.desc: Negi is the official title for Shinto priesthood.

Shinto.name: Yoshida Shinto
Shinto.desc: "Yoshida Shinto" is a school of Shinto perfected during the Muromachi period by Kanetomo YOSHIDA, a Shinto priest from the Kyoto Shida-jinja Shrine.

Shinto.name: Tenjin-shinko Faith
Shinto.desc: "Tenjin-shinko Faith" is a belief in Tenjin (heavenly gods) (Raijin (god of lightning)), specifically, a Shinto faith with awe and prayers centered around Sugawara no Michizane as 'Tenjin-sama.'

Shinto.name: Shinkai
Shinto.desc: "Shinkai" are ranks granted to Shinto gods in Japan.

Shinto.name: Azusayumi
Shinto.desc: Aazusayumi is a bow made of Japanese cherry birch used for Shinto rituals.

Shinto.name: Mikogami
Shinto.desc: In a shrine where parent-child gods (Shito religion) are enshrined, the child god is called Mikogami or byoei-shin (descendant deity).

Shinto.name: Hasshin-den
Shinto.desc: "Hasshin-den" is the temple where the eight gods protecting the Emperor are enshrined, built under the ritsuryo system in Japan, in the sai-in (western quarter) of the Department of Worship.

Shinto.name: Gion-shinko Faith
Shinto.desc: "Gion-shinko Faith" is a belief in Gozu Tenno (deity said to be the Indian god Gavagriva), Susanoo, and is a syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism.

Shinto.name: Goryo-e
Shinto.desc: "Goryo-e" is a courtesy for reposing the soul, to prevent curses by the goryo (spirit of the deceased person) who died unexpectedly, and is also referred to as Goryo-sai Festival.

Shinto.name: Bunrei (Branch Shrine for a Deity)
Shinto.desc: The bunrei or wakamitawa is a term used in the Shinto religion that refers to a separated god or divine spirit when an enshrined deity of main shrine is dedicated to a different shrine.

Shinto.name: Shinji
Shinto.desc: "Shinji" are worshipping and rituals related to god.

Shinto.name: Shinko-sai Festival
Shinto.desc: The Shinko-sai Festival is a shrine festival where the divine spirit makes an imperial visit.

Shinto.name: 神人 (jinin, jinnin, kaminchu, shinjin)
Shinto.desc: 神人 means:

Shinto.name: Ryobu Shinto
Shinto.desc: "Ryobu Shinto" is a combination of Shinto and Buddhism based on interpretation of Shinto from a Buddhist Shingon Sect (esoteric Buddhism) standpoint.

Shinto.name: Tawara no onda
Shinto.desc: "Tawara no onda" is a shinji (Shinto ritual) performed every year on May 3, at the Taji-jinja Shrine in the Tawara district of Hiyoshi-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Yaotome
Shinto.desc: Yaotome refers to 8 female shrine media called miko who serve gods mainly by performing sacred music and performing a dance called kagura (also known as Miko kagura - dances by shrine maidens) and mikomai (female Shinto dance where the young girls each carry a small baton with bells).

Shinto.name: Daishogun (hoi-jin)
Shinto.desc: "Daishogun" (commander-in-chief) is one of the Hasshojin (of eight general gods) responsible for the fortune of directions in Onmyodo (the way of Yin and Yang; occult divination based upon the Taoist theory of the five elements).

Shinto.name: Reikoden-tenmangu Shrine
Shinto.desc: Reikoden-tenmangu Shrine is a shrine in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Shinto.name: Oi-jinja Shrine (Kameoka City)
Shinto.desc: Oi-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Oi-cho, Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Oi-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City)
Shinto.desc: Oi-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Togetsukyo kitazume, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Shinto.name: Ikumi-tenmangu Shrine
Shinto.desc: Ikumi-tenmangu Shrine is a shrine in Sonobe-cho, Nantan City, Kyoto Prefecture

Shinto.name: Atago-shinko Faith
Shinto.desc: "Atago-shinko faith" is a Shinto faith about fire prevention, which originated at the Atago-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) enshrined on the top of Mt. Atago in Kyoto City.

Shinto.name: Suminomiya-jinja Shrine
Shinto.desc: "Suminomiya-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Nagaokakyo City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Yamashina-jinja Shrine
Shinto.desc: "Yamashina-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City)
Shinto.desc: "Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine is a shrine in Saikyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Shinto Taii
Shinto.desc: "Shinto Taii" is the name of Shinto books written by various Shintoists in the middle and modern ages.

Shinto.name: Sanjuban shin
Shinto.desc: "Sanjuban shin" is a synchronism of Shinto and Buddhism, with 30 gods taking turns every day guarding the nation and the people.

Shinto.name: Mikoshi Togyo
Shinto.desc: Mikoshi togyo refers to a Shinto ritual where a mikoshi (portable shrine) parades to pray for happiness of people lining the path of the parade.

Shinto.name: Kamo Taketsunumi no mikoto
Shinto.desc: "Kamo Taketsunumi no mikoto" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Yuki-jinja Shrine
Shinto.desc: "Yuki-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Kurama-honmachi, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Shinto.name: Asashiro-jinja Shrine
Shinto.desc: "Asashiro-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Asashiro, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Mihotsu-hime
Shinto.desc: "Mihotsu-hime" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Three Great Tenjins of Japan
Shinto.desc: The three typical Tenmangu Shrines are collectively called as "Nihon Sandai Tenjin" or the Three Great Tenjins of Japan.

Shinto.name: Daishogunhachi-jinja Shrine
Shinto.desc: "Daishogunhachi-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Okawa-jinja Shrine
Shinto.desc: "Okawa-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Okawa, Maizuru City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Momodayu
Shinto.desc: Momodayu (also called Hyakudayu) is a deity in a folk belief.

Shinto.name: Mito-jinja Shrine
Shinto.desc: "Mito-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Teradamitosaka, Joyo City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Imamiya-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City)
Shinto.desc: "Imamiya-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City.

Shinto.name: Sudo-jinja Shrine
Shinto.desc: "Sudo-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Kamitakano, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

Shinto.name: Chokusai
Shinto.desc: Chokusai is a religious service at a shrine where imperial messengers are sent by the Emperor.

Shinto.name: Amenouzume
Shinto.desc: Amenouzume (Amanouzume) is a deity who appears in Japanese Shinto mythology.

Shinto.name: Daikokuten
Shinto.desc: Daikokuten means Maha kala (Sanskrit:, transliteration: 摩訶迦羅) that is a reincarnation of Shiva, a deity of the Hindu religion.

Shinto.name: Kannazuki
Shinto.desc: Kannazuki (Kaminashizuki) is an another name for October (lunar calendar) in Japan.

Shinto.name: Sakaki
Shinto.desc: The sakaki (cleyera japonica) is an evergreen tree that belongs to the cleyera species of the theaceae family.

Shinto.name: Fu or Kannagi (Female Spiritual Medium)
Shinto.desc: The fu or kannagi, also called "fugeki," refers to those who worship and serve gods and take responsibility for conveying gods will to secular people.

Shinto.name: Mihashira no Uzuno Miko
Shinto.desc: Mihashira no Uzuno Miko refers to final three deities that came into the world when Izanagi came back from Yominokuni (Hades) and cleansed dirtiness from the Yomi (world after death), according to the Kiki-shinwa (the Kojiki, Nihonshoki and mythology).

Shinto.name: Kotodama
Shinto.desc: Kotodama was usually the spiritual power believed to be contained within words in Japan.

Shinto.name: Kamikaze
Shinto.desc: Kamikaze (also called as Kamukaze and Shinpu) was Shinto vocabulary.

Shinto.name: Engishiki
Shinto.desc: Engishiki is a set of Kyakushiki codes (detailed enforcement regulations of the Ritsuryo codes) compiled in the middle of the Heian period.

Shinto.name: Kokugaku
Shinto.desc: Kokugaku was a study that took place in the mid-Edo period in Japan.

Shinto.name: Yomi
Shinto.desc: Yomi is the world of the dead.

Shinto.name: Doso-shin (Japanese Shinto deity)
Shinto.desc: Doso-shin (also referred to as Doso-jin) is a deity on roadsides.

Shinto.name: Koshinto (as practiced prior to the introduction of Confucianism and Buddhism to Japan)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Koshinto (as practiced prior to the introduction of Confucianism and Buddhism to Japan).html
Shinto.desc: Koshinto was the ancient Japanese religion which was the origin of Shintoism and was called Kodo, Shintoism before 6th century.

Shinto.name: Kotoamatsukami
Shinto.desc: Kotoamatsukami refers to the five deities that appeared at the Creation according to the Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters).

Shinto.name: Izanagi
Shinto.desc: "Izanagi" is a male god who appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Hiruko
Shinto.desc: Hiruko (Ohirukomuchi no Mikoto, Hiruko no Kami, Hiruko no Mikoto) is a god that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Kagutsuchi
Shinto.desc: Kagutsuchi is the god of fire that appears in Kiki-shinwa (the Kojiki, Nihonshoki and mythology).

Shinto.name: Takemikazuchi
Shinto.desc: Takemikazuchi is a god that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Soja
Shinto.desc: Soja refers to a shrine that has collected gods of local shrines and enshrined them together.

Shinto.name: Amatsukami and Kunitsukami
Shinto.desc: Amatsukami (天津神; gods of heaven) and Kunitsukami (国津神; gods of the land) are the grouping of gods (Shinto) that appear in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Nigihayahi
Shinto.desc: Nigihayahi no Mikoto is a god (Shinto) who appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Ugayafukiaezu
Shinto.desc: Ugayafukiaezu is a deity in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Amenooshihomimi
Shinto.desc: Amenooshihomimi (Masakatsuakatsu kachihayahi amenooshihomimi) is a god (Shinto) that appeared in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Ninigi
Shinto.desc: Ninigi (Amenigishi kuninigishi amatsuhiko hiko hononinigi) is a deity in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Okuninushi
Shinto.desc: Okuninushi is a god that appears in a type of Japanese mythology called Izumo Shinwa (Myths of Izumo).

Shinto.name: Omononushi
Shinto.desc: Omononushi is a deity in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Susano
Shinto.desc: Susano (also known as Susano no Mikoto) was a deity (Shinto religion) that appeared in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Rin (bell)
Shinto.desc: A "rin (鈴)" a Buddhist instrument.

Shinto.name: Sukunabikona
Shinto.desc: Sukunabikona (also called Sukunahikona, as well as Sukunaminokami, Sukunahikona, Sukunahikone, and so on) is a god in the Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Toyouke-bime
Shinto.desc: Toyouke-bime is one of the gods from Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Norito (Shinto prayer)
Shinto.desc: "祝詞"

Shinto.name: Okutsuki
Shinto.desc: The word 'Okutsuki' refers to tombs of ancient times.

Shinto.name: Shinshoku (Shinto Priest)
Shinto.desc: The term "shinshoku" refers to a person who serves god and performs a religious ceremony and clerical work at a shrine of Shinto.

Shinto.name: NOMI no Sukune
Shinto.desc: NOMI no Sukune is a person who appears in "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

Shinto.name: Takamimusubi
Shinto.desc: Takamimusubi is one of the gods who appear in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Ame no Minakanushi no Kami
Shinto.desc: Ame no Minakanushi no Kami is one of the gods (Shinto) who appear in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Kamimusubi
Shinto.desc: Kamimusubi (or Kamimusuhi, Kamumusubi) is a god (Shinto) in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Imi
Shinto.desc: What is imi (忌み or 斎み) ?

Shinto.name: Sengu
Shinto.desc: A sengu is the temporary transfer of a shintai (an object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity).

Shinto.name: Myojin
Shinto.desc: 明神 (pronounced as 'myojin') is an honorable title used in Japanese Shinto for gods.

Shinto.name: Kojikiden
Shinto.desc: "Kojikiden" or "Furukotofumi no tsutae" is forty-four volumes of commentaries on "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) by Norinaga MOTOORI, a scholar of Japanese classical literature in the Edo period.

Shinto.name: Amenohohi
Shinto.desc: Amenohohi is a god (Shinto) who appears in the Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Sarutahiko
Shinto.desc: Sarutahiko is a deity who appears in Japanese mythology (Shinto).

Shinto.name: Amenooshihi-no-mikoto
Shinto.desc: Amenooshihi no Mikoto is a god (Shinto) which appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Omoikane
Shinto.desc: Omoikane is a god who appears in the Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Amenokoyane no Mikoto
Shinto.desc: Amenokoyane no Mikoto (written in kanji as 天児屋命) is a god (Shinto) that appeared in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Oyamatsumi
Shinto.desc: Oyamatsumi is the god described in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Ogetsuhime
Shinto.desc: Ogetsuhime (Ohogetsuhime) is a deity who appears in the Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Ame no Hoakari (one of the gods in Japanese mythology)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Ame no Hoakari (one of the gods in Japanese mythology).html
Shinto.desc: Ame no Hoakari is a Shinto god that appears in Japanese mythologies.

Shinto.name: Takeminakata no kami
Shinto.desc: Takeminakata no kami is a god who appeared in the Japanese mythology (Shinto religion).

Shinto.name: Aratama and Nikitama
Shinto.desc: Aratama' (also referred to as 'Aramitama') and 'Niki(gi)tama' (also referred to as 'Niki(gi)mitama') are concepts used by Shinto to express two different aspects of spirits and souls of gods.

Shinto.name: Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi
Shinto.jp: アシナヅチ・テナヅチ
Shinto.desc: Ashinazuchi and Tenazuchi are a couple of deities (Shinto deities) that appear in a Japanese Mythology about the Yamatanoorochi snake.

Shinto.name: Ajisukitakahikone
Shinto.desc: Ajisukitakahikone or Ajishikitakahikone is a Shinto deity who appears in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Hoori
Shinto.desc: Hoori (Hoori no Mikoto) is a god that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Hoderi
Shinto.desc: Hoderi is a god that appears in Japanese mythology in the Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters).

Shinto.name: Hitokotonushi
Shinto.desc: Hitokotonushi is an ancient Japanese god.

Shinto.name: Kuebiko
Shinto.desc: Kuebiko is an ancient god that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto god).

Shinto.name: Munakata Sanjojin
Shinto.desc: Munakata Sanjojin (Three Goddesses of Munakata) is a collective name for Mihashira no menokami (three female gods) enshrined at Munakata-taisha Shrine (Munakata City, Fukuoka Prefecture).

Shinto.name: Kukurihimenokami
Shinto.desc: Kukurihimenokami is a Japanese deity.

Shinto.name: Konohana no sakuya-bime
Shinto.jp: コノハナノサクヤビメ
Shinto.desc: Konohana no sakuya-bime is a goddess that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Futodama
Shinto.desc: Futodama is a god that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Ameno Tajikarao
Shinto.desc: Ameno Tajikarao is a god that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).

Shinto.name: Ishikoridome
Shinto.desc: Ishikoridome is a god appearing in the Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Tamanooya no Mikoto
Shinto.desc: Tamanooya no Mikoto was a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Iwanaga-hime
Shinto.desc: Iwanaga-hime is a goddess that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).

Shinto.name: Wakumusubi
Shinto.desc: Wakumusubi is the god of grain and sericulture, appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Kushinadahime
Shinto.desc: Kushinadahime is a goddess that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).

Shinto.name: Kuninotokotachi no Kami
Shinto.desc: Kuninotokotachi no Kami is a god appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Kotoshiro nushi
Shinto.desc: Kotoshiro nushi (a Japanese ancient god) is a god that appears in Japanese Mythology (Shinto religion).

Shinto.name: Jichin-sai (ground-breaking ceremony)
Shinto.desc: Jichin-sai (also pronounced "tokoshizume no matsuri") is a Japanese word used to describe the ground-breaking ceremony that is performed prior to the construction of an architectural structure or civil engineering work in order to appease the Shinto god or spirit of the land (known in Japanese as the Ujigami, the guardian god or spirit of the family or the community) and receive permission to use the land.

Shinto.name: Kamidana
Shinto.desc: A "Kamidana" (a household Shinto altar) is a shelf used to enshrine the Shinto gods (Shinto) at home, in office, and in other places.

Shinto.name: Umashiashikabihikoji
Shinto.jp: ウマシアシカビヒコヂ
Shinto.desc: Umashiashikabihikoji is a god appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Kami (Shinto)
Shinto.desc: The "kami" found in Shinto are objects of faith that are to be feared or held in awe.

Shinto.name: Amenohiboko
Shinto.desc: Amenohiboko is a deity in Japanese mythology, who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

Shinto.name: Amenotokotachi no Kami
Shinto.desc: Amenotokotachi no Kami is a god (Shinto) appearing in the Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Tajimamori
Shinto.desc: Tajimamori is a person appearing in Japanese mythology, and is the god (Shinto) of confection.

Shinto.name: Jingiin (Institute of Divinities)
Shinto.desc: The Jingiin was an organ of the national government of Japan.

Shinto.name: Engishiki Jinmyocho (register of shrines in Japan)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Engishiki Jinmyocho (register of shrines in Japan).html
Shinto.desc: The Engishiki Jinmyocho is the name given to the ninth and the tenth volumes of the "Engishiki" (an ancient Japanese book of administrative regulations and ceremonial procedures that was completed in 927), which provide a list of shrines throughout the country that were designated as 'kansha' (official shrines) at that time.

Shinto.name: Hime no kami
Shinto.desc: Hime no kami is a Shinto god (Shinto).

Shinto.name: Shiotsuchinooji
Shinto.desc: Shiotsuchinooji (Shihotsuchinooji) is a deity (in the Shinto religion) who appears in the Japanese Mythology and is also called Shiogama-myojin.

Shinto.name: Mizuhanome
Shinto.desc: Mizuhanome is a deity (Shinto religion) that appears in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Okami no Kami
Shinto.desc: Okami no Kami is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Shinatsuhiko
Shinto.desc: Shinatsuhiko is a deity (Shinto religion) who appears in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Shingun
Shinto.desc: A Shingun (also called a Kamikori) is a special district type that came into existence with the establishment of the Kokugun system, and is considered to be the holly precincts of a shrine (domain of a kami), and differs from other types of districts.

Shinto.name: Shrine Merger
Shinto.desc: Shrine Merger is a policy to consolidate shrines.

Shinto.name: Suseri-bime
Shinto.desc: Suseri-bime is a deity (Shinto religion) who appears in the Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Saho-hime
Shinto.desc: Saho-hime is the god of spring.

Shinto.name: Tatsuta-hime
Shinto.desc: Tatsuta-hime (竜田姫) is the god of autumn in Japan.

Shinto.name: Kayano-hime
Shinto.desc: Kayano-hime (or Kayanu-hime) is a god (Shinto) of grass appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Hoki-Naiden
Shinto.desc: The Hoki-Naiden is a treatise on divination that was handed down to subsequent generations as a text compiled by ABE no Seimei.

Shinto.name: Ujigami (Tutelary Deities in Shinto)
Shinto.desc: Ujigami is a Shinto god (Shinto) jointly enshrined by the people living in a community (village) in Japan.

Shinto.name: Amatsumikaboshi
Shinto.desc: Amatsumikaboshi is a god of stars (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Toyotama-hime
Shinto.desc: Toyotamahime no Kami (Toyotama-hime) is a god (Shinto) appearing in volume one of "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), and the mythology of Yamasachihiko and Umisachihiko.

Shinto.name: Watatsumi
Shinto.desc: Watatsumi (or Wadatsumi) is a sea god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Age of Calamity
Shinto.desc: As propagated by Onmyodo (the traditions of Yin-Yang divination and astronomy), a person is believed to suffer misfortunes during their age of calamity.

Shinto.name: Misogi (Ablution)
Shinto.desc: The term,"misogi," (ablution) has two meanings.

Shinto.name: Shikinensai (Periodic Religious Rite)
Shinto.desc: Shikinensai is a religious rite performed at specified intervals.

Shinto.name: Omonoimi no Kami
Shinto.desc: Omonoimi no Kami is a god (Shinto) believed to dwell in Mt. Chokai.

Shinto.name: Ukei (Ancient Divination)
Shinto.desc: Ukei is the act of divination practiced in ancient Japan.

Shinto.name: Shinsosai (Shinto Funeral)
Shinto.desc: Shinsosai refers to funeral rites performed by Shinto, Japan's original religion.

Shinto.name: Soreisha (ancestral altar)
Shinto.desc: Soreisha (or Mitamaya) are household altars that are used in Shinto to enshrine ancestral spirits.

Shinto.name: Sorei
Shinto.desc: Sorei (or Mioyanomitama) is an ancestral soul.

Shinto.name: Ikihagi (skinning animals alive)
Shinto.desc: Ikihagi' is a sense of sin, a concept in Shinto, and one of "amatsu-tsumi " (heavenly sins) appeared in Oharae no kotoba, one of 'Norito' (Shinto prayers) collected in the eighth volume of "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers)

Shinto.name: Amenowakahiko
Shinto.desc: Amenowakahiko is a deity from Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Naobi no kami
Shinto.desc: Naobi no kami (or Nahobi no kami) are deities in Shintoism.

Shinto.name: Futsunushi no kami
Shinto.desc: Futsunushi no kami is a deity that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Shintai
Shinto.desc: A shintai or goshintai ('go' is an honorific prefix) means the body of a kami (deity) in the Shinto religion.

Shinto.name: Repose of souls
Shinto.desc: Repose of souls ("chinkon", or "tamashizume") refers to the quieting of a persons soul.

Shinto.name: Kayanarumi
Shinto.desc: Kayanarumi is a female deity whose name is written 賀夜奈流美 in "Izumo kokuso kamuyogoto" (Divine Words of the Ritual Priest of Izumo Taisha Shrine), which can be found in the section on prayer rituals in the "Engishiki" (Regulations and Laws of the Engi Era), and 加夜奈留美 at Asukani Imasu-jinja Shrine and Kayanarumi-jinja Shrine.

Shinto.name: Ichikishimahime
Shinto.desc: Ichikishimahime (or Itsukishimahime) is a deity of water that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Nainokami
Shinto.desc: Nainokami is a deity of earthquakes from Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Magatama
Shinto.desc: Magatama (also written with the characters for "curved jewels") have been used for personal adornment in Japan since ancient times.

Shinto.name: Musuhi (Life-producing spirits)
Shinto.desc: Musuhi, a concept embraced in Shinto, refers to a spiritual influence that produces all the things in the universe and helps them develop and complete their cycle.

Shinto.name: Kegare
Shinto.desc: Kegare is a notion in Buddhism and Shinto and means a dirty, bad, not clean state, such as being unclean, impure etc.

Shinto.name: Kinen
Shinto.desc: Kinen (incantation) is a traditional magic (spell) in Japan.

Shinto.name: Shaku
Shinto.desc: Shaku is a narrow board held in the right hand when one wears sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress) in Japan.

Shinto.name: Tamagushi
Shinto.desc: Tamagushi means a branch of sakaki tree decorated with shide (paper cascade) and yu (strips of cloth) and offered before the gods by Shinto priests and visitors during Shinto rituals.

Shinto.name: Amatsumara
Shinto.desc: Amatsumara is a deity of ironworking that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Kiyome
Shinto.desc: Kiyome means people who were engaged in the disposal of animals and cleaning on behalf of priests who were prohibited to kill animals in a temple.

Shinto.name: Ko
Shinto.desc: Ko is a society organized by people having the same faith.

Shinto.name: Chinju Gami
Shinto.desc: Chinju gami is a (Shinto) god enshrined to guard a particular building or a certain area of land.

Shinto.name: Kasuga no kami
Shinto.desc: Kasuga no kami is a Shinto deity.

Shinto.name: Haraedo no Okami
Shinto.desc: Haraedo no Okami refers to Shinto deities in charge of "harae" (purification or redemption).

Shinto.name: Tamayoribime
Shinto.desc: Tamayoribime, also known as Tamayorihime, is a Shinto goddess from Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Isotakeru
Shinto.desc: Isotakeru is a Shinto god appearing in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Seishi (Deification of a Living Man)
Shinto.desc: Seishi (生祀) means to honor or worship the spirit of a living person.

Shinto.name: Kariginu
Shinto.desc: Kariginu are informal clothes worn by Court nobles in the Heian period and afterwards.

Shinto.name: Himorogi
Shinto.desc: Himorogi is an object that is designated as yorishiro (representative of a divine spirit) to enshrine a divine spirit temporarily when a festival is held in a place other than a shrine or a household Shinto altar.

Shinto.name: Masakaki
Shinto.desc: Masakaki is a ceremonial implement that is placed on both sides of an altar at Shinto rituals.

Shinto.name: Hosuseri no Mikoto
Shinto.desc: Hosuseri no Mikoto is a Shinto god in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Amenomahitotsu no Kami
Shinto.desc: Amenomahitotsu no Kami is a Shinto god of iron manufacture and blacksmiths who appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Ukemochi no kami
Shinto.desc: "Ukemochi no kami" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Akaru-hime
Shinto.desc: Akaru-hime is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Achiki
Shinto.desc: "Achiki" is an envoy, scholar, and a naturalized citizen dispatched from Baekje to Japan, who is described in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) and "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters).

Shinto.name: Kukunochi
Shinto.desc: "Kukunochi" (Kugunochi) is a god of trees (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Kanayamahiko-no-kami
Shinto.desc: "Kanayamahiko-no-kami" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Amenoohabari
Shinto.desc: "Amenoohabari" is a sword appearing in Japanese Mythology, as well as the name of a god (Shinto).

Shinto.name: Kataku Rokushin
Shinto.desc: Kataku Rokushin is a generic name for the six gods (Shinto) representing (or protecting) a house in Shinto.

Shinto.name: Oharae no kotoba
Shinto.desc: Oharae no kotoba is a Norito (Shinto prayer) that is used in Shinto religious service.

Shinto.name: Ogotooshio-no-kami
Shinto.desc: "Ogotooshio-no-kami, Ohogotooshiwo-no-kami" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Onusa (Shinto)
Shinto.desc: Onusa is one of the instruments used for purification at religious services of Shinto.

Shinto.name: Shinshi (Divine Servant)
Shinto.desc: Shinshi (Divine servant) is, in Shinto, an animal specified as a messenger (servant) of god.

Shinto.name: Shide
Shinto.desc: Shide is strips of paper cut and folded in a specific way that are attached to and suspended from Shimenawa (a sacred straw rope), tamagushi (branch of a sacred tree), haraegushi (branch of a white tree), or gohei (wooden wands).

Shinto.name: Nyakuichioji
Shinto.desc: "Nyakuichioji" is a god (Shinto) from syncretism of Shinto and Buddhism.

Shinto.name: Chimata-No-Kami
Shinto.desc: "Chimata-No-Kami" or "Tsuji-no-kami" are gods (Shinto) who are believed to prevent evil gods and evil spirits who bring epidemics and disasters from entering the village in Japanese folk beliefs.

Shinto.name: Yamatonookuni tamanokami
Shinto.desc: "Yamatonookuni tamanokami" is a god (shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Jotoshiki (the roof-laying ceremony)
Shinto.desc: Jotoshiki is a religious service of Shinto for building a new house in Japan.

Shinto.name: Kujirazuka
Shinto.desc: Kujirazuka is a mound enshrining the whales that were washed up ashore on the beach, and is a uniquely Japanese custom.

Shinto.name: Awashima no kami
Shinto.desc: Awashima no kami is a god (Shinto) in Shinto and Japanese folk religion.

Shinto.name: Norai (Feast)
Shinto.desc: Naorai is an event that is held at the conclusion of a festival at the shrine where everyone who assembled for the Shinto ritual is made to drink sacred sake and eat the sacred food (a ritual to share drink and food).

Shinto.name: Wakahirume no mikoto
Shinto.desc: "Wakahirume no mikoto" is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Obiko no Mikoto
Shinto.desc: Obiko no Mikoto (year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial Family.

Shinto.name: Tatari
Shinto.desc: Tatari refers to a condition wherein a god, Buddha, or a soul of human being causes a calamitous condition for human beings, or a supernatural force that works within that condition.

Shinto.name: Yamanokami (God of the Mountain)
Shinto.desc: The term "Yamanokami" refers to:

Shinto.name: Suijin (The God of Water and Rain)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Suijin (The God of Water and Rain).html
Shinto.desc: Suijin (or Mizugami) is the generic term for the gods relating to water (mainly fresh water).

Shinto.name: Amatsu Tsumi and Kunitsu Tsumi
Shinto.desc: "Amatsu tsumi" and "Kunitsu tsumi" are concepts of crime in in the Shintoism.

Shinto.name: Azuminoisora
Shinto.desc: Azuminoisora (written in kanji as 阿曇磯良 or 安曇磯良) is a deity within the religion of Shinto.

Shinto.name: Gohei
Shinto.desc: Gohei is one type of heihaku used in the religious services of Shinto, made by clipping two shide (zigzag strips of paper) into a heigushi (staff) made of bamboo or other wood.

Shinto.name: Shitateruhime
Shinto.desc: Shitateruhime is a deity in Shinto described in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Chinju no Mori (Sacred Shrine Forest)
Shinto.desc: Chinju no Mori" are forests attached to Shinto shrines, managed and maintained so as to enclose the Sando (approach to the temple) and the Haisho (place of prayer).

Shinto.name: Kunitama (The Spirit of the Land)
Shinto.desc: Kunitama is a concept of Shintoism, referring to the sanctification or spiritualization of a province (an administrative division in feudal Japan) or the land itself.

Shinto.name: Shake
Shinto.desc: Shake is a Japanese social class.

Shinto.name: Funadama
Shinto.desc: Funadama (ship spirit) is a deity to which seafarers pray for the safety of a voyage.

Shinto.name: Kanbari Nyudo
Shinto.desc: Kanbari Nyudo is a deity or monster of toilets according to Japanese folk beliefs.

Shinto.name: Ugajin
Shinto.desc: "Ugajin" is a folk religion god (Shinto) worshipped since the medieval period in Japan.

Shinto.name: Hyaku-do Mairi
Shinto.desc: Hyaku-do mairi (the hundred-fold visit) is a folk religious practice in Japan, in which a person visits a temple or shrine in order to pray to the gods and then, at that same temple or shrine, pays his or her respects one hundred times.

Shinto.name: Oshirasama
Shinto.desc: "Oshirasama" (also written おしらさま, お白様, オシラ様, オシラサマ) is a god of the home (Shinto) worshipped in the Tohoku region of Japan, generally considered the god of silkworm, god of agriculture, and god of horses.

Shinto.name: Ninen Mairi
Shinto.desc: Ninen mairi (two-year shrine visit) is one style of hatsumode (the practice of visiting a Shinto shrine on New Year's Day).

Shinto.name: Hoso Kami
Shinto.desc: Hoso Kami (also pronounced as Hoso gami, Hoso shin) is an apotheosis of hoso (smallpox), and is a kind of Yakubyo-gami, a deity for the transmission of epidemics.

Shinto.name: Binbo-gami
Shinto.desc: Binbo-gami is a god who brings poverty to the people whom they cling to or their families.

Shinto.name: Amatsuhikone
Shinto.desc: Amatsuhikone is a god (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Makami
Shinto.desc: Makami is deification of a Japanese wolf which is now extinct.

Shinto.name: Mishaguji
Shinto.desc: Having been handed down in Japan from old times, Mishaguji is a kami (of Shinto) whose origin is not very clear.

Shinto.name: Heihaku
Shinto.desc: Heihaku is a general term used for anything other than food and drink that is offered to the Shinto gods during a Shinto ceremony.

Shinto.name: Toyokiiribikono-mikoto
Shinto.desc: Toyokiiribikono-mikoto (豊城入彦命) (the year of birth and death unknown) is a member of the Imperial Family (the royal family) of the Tumulus period according to the Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).

Shinto.name: Goshi
Shinto.desc: "Goshi" is a Shinto term that refers to the enshrinement of kami (deity, spirit) from one shrine at another shrine (this is called yosemiya).

Shinto.name: Kugatachi
Shinto.desc: "Kugatachi" (also known as kukatachi and kukadachi) refers to trials by ordeal held in ancient Japan.

Shinto.name: Sanbo (Shinto)
Shinto.desc: A sanbo, also known as a sanpo, is a small stand used in Shinto rituals for presenting shinsen (offerings of food and alcohol) to kami (deities, spirits).

Shinto.name: Kinomata no kami
Shinto.desc: According to the Japanese mythology, Kinomata no kami (木俣神) (also read as Konomata no kami) was born between Okuninushi (chief god of Izumo in southern Honshu Island, Japan, and the central character in the important cycle of myths set in that region) and Yakami hime of Inaba.

Shinto.name: Akiyamanoshitabiotoko
Shinto.desc: Akiyamanoshitabiotoko is a Japanese deity.

Shinto.name: Altar
Shinto.desc: An altar is a structure for making sacrifices and offerings to gods, spirits, and death.

Shinto.name: Yorishiro
Shinto.desc: The term "yorishiro" refers to an object that divine spirits are drawn or summoned to, and it denotes a shintai (an object believed to contain the spirit of a deity) or sometimes a shrine precincts.

Shinto.name: Shinme
Shinto.desc: Shinme (or Jinme, sacred horse) is a term used to refer to a horse that is dedicated to a Japanese shrine or one used in rites and festivals.

Shinto.name: Hakushu
Shinto.desc: The term "hakushu" or "kashiwade" (both of which mean clapping) refers to a gesture people make when they offer prayers to gods (deities, spirits) at Shinto religious services or before Shinto shrines or household altars.

Shinto.name: Saijin
Shinto.desc: Saijin is a Shinto term that signifies a deity enshrined in a Shinto shrine.

Shinto.name: Taimatsu torch
Shinto.desc: Taimatsu is the Japanese word for torch, a lighted piece of wood which can be held and used as a light source and for illumination.

Shinto.name: Hono
Shinto.desc: Hono is a religious act performed by ujiko (shrine parishioners) and danka (supporters of a Buddhist temple) aimed at respecting or appeasing and pleasing Shinto and Buddhist deities in which people offer 'something of value' to such deities (including tombs).

Shinto.name: Otabisho
Shinto.desc: Otabisho means the place where a deity (usually the mikoshi, or portable shrine, that carries the deity) takes a rest or stays overnight while on a ritual procession during a shrine festival (Shinko-sai Festival).

Shinto.name: Iwakamutsukari no mikoto
Shinto.desc: Iwakamutsukari no mikoto, who appears in the Japanese Mythology, is a courtier of Emperor Keiko.

Shinto.name: Reisai (regular festival)
Shinto.desc: Reisai is a term used to to describe one kind of saishi, religious services that are performed annually at shinto shrines.

Shinto.name: Rei-taisai
Shinto.desc: Rei-taisai is the common name of the most important reisai (regular festival) that is performed on a day associated with the shrine.

Shinto.name: Shrine Shinto
Shinto.desc: Shrine Shinto is a form of Shinto.

Shinto.name: Jade magatama
Shinto.desc: Jade magatama refers to magatama made of jade.

Shinto.name: Eirei
Shinto.desc: Eirei is a 'term used to honor the spirits of dead persons who performed an outstanding act.'

Shinto.name: Toyokumono
Shinto.desc: Toyokumono is a Shinto deity appearing in the story of the creation of heaven and earth (the Japanese Mythology).

Shinto.name: Nunakawa hime
Shinto.desc: Nunakawa hime is a Shinto deity appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Hitorigami
Shinto.desc: Hitorigami is a Shinto deity which came into being not in pairs but alone.

Shinto.name: Shimotsuki kagura
Shinto.desc: Shimotsuki kagura is kagura (sacred music and dance performed at shrines) that is performed in November (according to the old lunar calendar; December through to January of the following year according to the Gregorian calendar).

Shinto.name: Mikumari no kami
Shinto.desc: Mikumari no kami is a Shinto deity (Shinto).

Shinto.name: Shimenawa Rope
Shinto.desc: The Shimenawa rope (sacred straw rope) is a ceremonial article of significance in Shinto and, the rope has religious meaning when adorned with shide (zigzag shaped paper talisman).

Shinto.name: Hinohakama
Shinto.desc: Hinohakama (scarlet hakama (divided trouser-like skirt)) (also known as 'hibakama') is also called 'Kutenai no hakama' (Red hakama) because of its deep scarlet color and to indicate the red thread used in the hakama.

Shinto.name: Chihaya
Shinto.desc: The chihaya (outer vestment garment) has existed in Japan since ancient times and is a piece of clothing used when performing religious rituals and duties that is principally worn by women.

Shinto.name: Josei shinshoku shozoku
Shinto.desc: Josei shinshoku shozoku are costumes for female Shinto priests, which appeared after the Second World War.

Shinto.name: Sculpture of Deities
Shinto.desc: A sculpture of deities is a statue or a portrait to represent Kami, an object of worship.

Shinto.name: Hatsuho
Shinto.desc: In Japan, hatsuho is a ripe rice ear presented to God (Shinto) before autumn rice harvest.

Shinto.name: Haniyasu
Shinto.desc: Haniyasu is the god of soil (Shinto) appearing in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Izuna-gongen
Shinto.desc: Izuna-gongen (also pronounced as Iizuna-gongen) is a syncretized god of Shintoism and Buddhism which is said to originate from a belief in the mountains of Mt. Izuna in Minochi County, Shinano Province (now Nagano Prefecture).

Shinto.name: Ohanjin
Shinto.desc: Ohanjin (also pronounced as Oubanshin) is deification of Rago, one of Kuyo (nine-planet crest), and is mainly enshrined as a stone monument on the border of settlement, in the center of a village, on the border of villages, crossing, or T-junction.

Shinto.name: Omodaru and Ayakashikone
Shinto.jp: オモダル・アヤカシコネ
Shinto.desc: Omodaru and Ayakashikone are kami (god) in Japanese Methodology (shinto).

Shinto.name: Otonoji and Otonobe
Shinto.jp: オオトノヂ・オオトノベ
Shinto.desc: Otonoji and Otonobe are kami (god) in Japanese Methodology (shinto).

Shinto.name: Tsunugui and Ikugui
Shinto.desc: Tsunugui and Ikugui are kami (god) in Japanese Methodology (shinto).

Shinto.name: Uhijini and Suhijini
Shinto.desc: Uhijini and Suhijini are kami (god) in Japanese Methodology (shinto).

Shinto.name: Akuru
Shinto.desc: Akuru is an evil god in Japanese Methodology.

Shinto.name: Nakisawame
Shinto.desc: Nakisawame is a kami (god) in Japanese Methodology (shinto).

Shinto.name: Hayaakitsuhiko and Hayaakitsuhime
Shinto.jp: ハヤアキツヒコ・ハヤアキツヒメ
Shinto.desc: Hayaakitsuhiko and Hayaakitsuhime are kami (god) in Japanese Methodology (shinto).

Shinto.name: Takiri-bime
Shinto.desc: Takiri-bime (also known as Tagiri-hime) is a Shinto goddesses from Japanese mythology and one of the 'Munakata-Sanjoshin' (the three goddesses enshrined in Munakata-taisha Shrine).

Shinto.name: Tagitsu-hime
Shinto.desc: Tagitsu-hime (also called Takitsu-hime) was a god (Shinto religion) appearing in Japanese Mythology and one of Munakata Sanjojin (three goddesses enshrined in Munakata Taisha Shrine).

Shinto.name: Torinoiwakusufune no kami
Shinto.desc: Torinoiwakusufune no kami was a god (Shinto religion) appearing in Japanese Mythology, and also the name of the ship that the gods rode.

Shinto.name: Iwasaku and Nesaku
Shinto.desc: Iwasaku (also called Ihasaku) and Nesaku were gods (Shinto religion) appeared in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Iwatsutsunoo
Shinto.desc: Iwatsutsunoo (Ihatsutsunowo) is a god (god of Shinto) featured in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Kumanokusubi
Shinto.desc: Kumanokusubi is a god (god of Shinto) featured in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Amanozako
Shinto.desc: Amanozako is a Japanese goddess who is depicted in "Wakan-sansai-zue" (an encyclopedia compiled in the Edo period).

Shinto.name: Tamagaki
Shinto.desc: Tamagaki is a fence around a shrine or shiniki (the holy precincts of a shrine).

Shinto.name: Myotara-ten
Shinto.desc: Myotara-ten or Myotara-tennyo is a Japanese god who is a guardian of Shinto and Buddhist deities, good people and children, and also a god of exorcism and matchmaking.

Shinto.name: Kotoage
Shinto.desc: Kotoage (word rising) ritual is to make the religious principle or interpretation in Shinto clear by word.

Shinto.name: Kannagi
Shinto.desc: Chinese characters representing Kannagi include "巫" and "神なぎ (神和ぎ・神薙ぎ・神凪)," which are also read as "kaminagi" or "kamunagi."

Shinto.name: Ichirei shikon
Shinto.desc: Ichirei shikon (one spirit, four souls) is an idea of Japanese Shintoism in which the mind consists of a spirit called 'naohi' that is connected with the heaven and four souls.

Shinto.name: Misogiharae
Shinto.desc: Misogiharae is a word combined by misogi (purification ceremony) and harae (exorcism).

Shinto.name: Torimono
Shinto.desc: Torimono are the tools used by miko (a shrine maiden) and performers of Kagura, (sacred music and dancing performed at shrine) in Shinto rituals and Kagura.

Shinto.name: Kagurauta
Shinto.desc: Kagurauta is a song performed in Kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines).

Shinto.name: Shiniki
Shinto.desc: Shiniki is precincts of a shrine or a place where gods dwell (yorishiro).

Shinto.name: Takeinadane no mikoto
Shinto.desc: Takeinadane no mikoto is a Japanese god.

Shinto.name: Toyobiwake
Shinto.desc: Toyobiwake (also pronounced Toyohiwake) is a god that appears in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Ikutsuhikone
Shinto.desc: Ikutsuhikone no mikoto, written as 活津日子命 (in Kojiki: The Records of Ancient Matters) or 活津彦根命 (in Nihonshoki: Chronicles of Japan), is the fourth son in five sons and three daughters given birth from the pledge made by Amaterasu (the Sun Goddess) and Susano (Amaterasu's brother: a deity in Japanese Mythology), and he was born from a bead which Amaterasu was wearing on her left wrist.

Shinto.name: Tanokami
Shinto.desc: Tanokami (deity of rice fields and harvests) is a deity (Shinto religion) that Japanese agricultural people believe watches over a rich or poor harvest and brings about a bumper crop of rice.

Shinto.name: Kazami
Shinto.desc: Kazami is a lightweight top (clothing) for girls of the noble class during the Heian period.

Shinto.name: Marebito
Shinto.desc: Marebito is a term in Orikuchiism that refers to a spiritual or deity-like being who visits from the afterworld at a specified time.

Shinto.name: Kasanuimura
Shinto.desc: Kasanuimura, or Kasanui no mura, is the place where Toyosuki iribime no Mikoto, who was given responsibility, enshrined Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) after she was transferred from her place of enshrinement at the Imperial Court in the sixth year of Emperor Sujin's reign.

Shinto.name: Tatari-gami
Shinto.desc: Tatari-gami are Shikon (four spirits) which are held in awe but avoided, and believed to become a powerful guardian god if treated cordially.

Shinto.name: Omigoromo
Shinto.desc: Omigoromo is an outer garment used in Shinto rituals that has been handed down since ancient times.

Shinto.name: Kanayago-kami
Shinto.desc: Kanayago-kami god (also pronounced as Kanayako-kami god, etc.) was a god which is believed by blacksmiths to live mainly in Chugoku Region (Shintoism).

Shinto.name: Ikasuri no Mikannagi no Matsuru Kami
Shinto.url: Shinto/Ikasuri no Mikannagi no Matsuru Kami.html
Shinto.desc: Ikasuri no mikannagi no matsuru kami god is a god in Shintoism (Shintoism).

Shinto.name: Takuhatachijihime no Mikoto
Shinto.desc: Takuhatachijihime no Mikoto is a female deity (Shinto) in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Takehiratori no Mikoto
Shinto.desc: Takehiratori no Mikoto is a male deity (Shinto) in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Jinpo
Shinto.desc: Jinpo or kamudara refers to items which are stored within the inner sanctum located in the sanctuary of a Shinto shrine.

Shinto.name: Konsei-shin
Shinto.desc: Konsei-shin, who is also called as Konsei-daimyojin or Konsei-sama, is the god representing a goshintai (object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a god) made of stone, wood or metal which is shaped like a phallus.

Shinto.name: Amanoiwatowakenokami
Shinto.desc: Amanoiwatowakenokami is a god (of Shinto) who appears in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Yasakatome no kami
Shinto.desc: Yasakatome no kami is a goddess in the Shinto religion, Kisakigami (God Empress) married to Takeminakata no kami.

Shinto.name: Hisatsu-hime
Shinto.desc: Hisatsu-hime (比佐津媛) is a goddess enshrined in Yoso-jinja Shrine in Oaza-Hidaka, Hita City, Oita Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Amatsukume no mikoto
Shinto.desc: Amatsukume no mikoto is a god (Shinto) who appears in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Moriya-shin
Shinto.desc: Moriya-shin (also pronounced as Moreya-shin) is an indigenous god (Shinto) believed to live around the Suwa region in Nagano Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Oyatsu-hime
Shinto.desc: Oyatsu-hime, written as "大屋都比賣神" or "大屋津姫命," is the goddess of trees in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Iwakura
Shinto.desc: Iwakura is one form of worship within Koshintoism (Shintoism practiced prior to the introduction of Confucianism and Buddhism to Japan), which worships nature (worshipping of spirits, animism) that has been in Japan since the ancient times.

Shinto.name: Hobei
Shinto.desc: Hobei (hohei) means to offer heihaku (paper, silk cuttings or red and white cloth presented to deities) to shrines and the Imperial mausoleums by the Emperor's command.

Shinto.name: Kamu-oichi-hime
Shinto.desc: Kamu-oichi-hime is a Shinto goddess from Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Jissha-daimyojin
Shinto.desc: Jissha-daimyojin refers to a group of ten gods, comprising Mikenu no Mikoto (nephew of the sea god and brother of the legendary first emperor, Jinmu), his wife and their children.

Shinto.name: Izunahime no Mikoto
Shinto.desc: Izunahime no Mikoto is a goddess enshrined at Izuta-jinja Shrine on Mt. Kochi, Tosashimizu City, Kochi Prefecture and at the Izuta-jinja Shrines in Tamura and Maehama districts of Nankoku City.

Shinto.name: Tsumatsu-hime
Shinto.desc: Tsumatsu-hime is a goddess in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Kamowakeikazuchi no Mikoto
Shinto.desc: Kamowakeikazuchi no Mikoto is a Shinto god (Shinto).

Shinto.name: Yadaijin
Shinto.desc: Yadaijin is one of the two deity statures in Zuijin (Imperial guards during the Heian period) costumes that are placed at the both sides of Zuijin-mon gate, holding bows and arrows on the observer's left.

Shinto.name: Tsunofurihayabusa-myojin
Shinto.desc: Tsunofurihayabusa-myojin is a deity enshrined at Tsunofuri-jinja Shrine, which used to be located in Fuchu-cho, Aki-gun, Hiroshima Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Shichimen-tennyo
Shinto.desc: Shichimen-tennyo is the former name of Shichimen-daimyojin, a goddess whom followers of the Nichiren school of Buddhism believe protects the Lotus Sutra ('Hoke-kyo' in Japanese).

Shinto.name: Kogakusho, Kangakusho
Shinto.desc: Kogakusho (the Imperial Learning Place) and Kangakusho (the Chinese Learning Place) were higher educational institutions established in Kyoto by the Meiji Government immediately after the Restoration of Imperial Rule.

Shinto.name: God of the Hearth
Shinto.desc: The god of the hearth is enshrined at hearths, irori (traditional Japanese open hearths) and other places where fire is used.

Shinto.name: Izanami
Shinto.desc: Izanami (written as 伊弉冉, 伊邪那美, 伊弉弥) is a goddess in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Shingu
Shinto.desc: "Shingu" refers to tools or utensils used for Shinto religious services.

Shinto.name: Shinboku
Shinto.desc: Shinboku refers to a tree or a forest as Himorogi (a temporarily erected sacred space or "altar" used as a locus of worship) in Koshinto (ancient Shinto) and an object of worship.

Shinto.name: Yudate-kagura
Shinto.desc: Yudate-kagura (Yutate-kagura) is one of Japanese traditional kagura forms.

Shinto.name: Goryu-shinto
Shinto.desc: Goryu-shinto is the ho-ryu school (school by a Priestly Imperial Prince) of Shinto handed down among people such as hosshinno (Imperial Princes who became Buddhism priests).

Shinto.name: Seoritsu-hime
Shinto.desc: Seoritsu hime is a shrine of Haraedo no okami (gods of purification in Shinto religion).

Shinto.name: Muto-shin
Shinto.desc: Muto-shin is a deity which appears in Somin shorai setsuwa (anecdotes of Japanese old stories).

Shinto.name: Mihashira-torii
Shinto.desc: Mihashira-torii (literally, three-column shrine gate) is formed by coupling three torii (shrine gate).

Shinto.name: Tsukinami-no-matsuri
Shinto.desc: Tsukinami-no-matsuri (literally, monthly festival) is a festival in shinto.

Shinto.name: Gonansanjoshin
Shinto.desc: Gonansanjoshin are the deities who were born when Amaterasu and Susanoo, deities who appear in Japanese Mythology, made ukei (pledge) in Amanomanai (a geographical name in Japanese Mythology).

Shinto.name: Amabe-shi Keizu
Shinto.desc: Amabe-shi Keizu are genealogical documents passed down by the Amabe family, a shake (family of Shinto priests serving a shrine on a hereditary basis) of Kono-jinja Shrine located in Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture, which comprises one book of "Kono-myojin-yashiro Hafuribe-uji Keizu" (Family Tree of the Family Serving for Kono-jinja Shrine, hereinafter referred to as 'Hon-keizu)' (main family tree)) and one book of "Kono-myojin-gu Hafuribe Tanba Kuninomiyatsuko Amabe Jikito-uji no Hongi" (Records of the Amabe family, an ancient local ruling family in Tanba Province, Serving for Kono-jinja Shrine, hereinafter referred to as 'Kanchu-keizu' (genealogical records based on surveys)).

Shinto.name: Amenonaemasu no mikoto
Shinto.desc: Amenonaemasu no mikoto (spelled '天苗加命,' or alternatively '天苗益命') is a deity (Shinto) in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Higashiyama-tenno (Takanaga) kensho-no-kanro
Shinto.jp: 東山天皇（尊良）顕彰の串呂
Shinto.desc: Higashiyama-tenno (Takanaga) kensho-no-kanro (kanro [a way to clarify things, also called physiography] to clarify the fact on Emperor Higashiyama (aka Imperial Prince Takanaga)) is one of 'Shinpu-kanro' which was a physiographic book clarified by Hosei MIURA, and was a Shinpu-kanro which clarified and praised the fact that the Imperial Prince Takanaga who was the first prince of the Emperor Godaigo was enthroned on Mt. Hiei on November 20, 1336 and was an emperor of the genuine Imperial line enthroned at takamikura (a rank of an emperor).

Shinto.name: Kisagaihime and Umugihime
Shinto.jp: キサガイヒメ・ウムギヒメ
Shinto.desc: Kisagaihime and Umugihime were gods (Shinto religion) that appear in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Ujisha
Shinto.desc: Ujisha is a shrine in which ujigami (ancestors of a family who were worshiped as a god) was worshipped.

Shinto.name: Amenokaguyama no mikoto
Shinto.desc: Amenokaguyama no mikoto was the Japanese god (Shinto religion).

Shinto.name: Nagashiraha no kami
Shinto.desc: Nagashiraha no kami was a god appearing in Iwato-gakure (the hiding of Amaterasu Omikami, the sun goddess, in the heavenly rock cave) of Kogo-shui (History of the Inbe clan).

Shinto.name: Tahirikishimarumi no kami
Shinto.desc: Tahirikishimarumi no kami was a god (Shinto religion) who appeared in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Fukuden
Shinto.desc: Fukuden is a deity bringing happiness in folk beliefs in Japan.

Shinto.name: Miyaza
Shinto.desc: Miyaza is the empowered group in a village or its qualified members engaged in rituals of a shrine, a guardian god or a local deity of a village.

Shinto.name: Mitsutorii
Shinto.desc: Mitsutorii is a combination of three myojin-gate torii (a pillared gate-like entrance to a Shinto shrine), and it is sometimes called yotsuashi torii (four-legged torii) because it has four pillars.

Shinto.name: Shinto (Shinto religion)
Shinto.desc: Shinto (or Kannagara no michi) is an ethnical religious framework in Japan and a polytheistic religion that is unique to Japan.

Shinto.name: Japanese Mythology
Shinto.desc: Japanese mythology is a collection of myths that have been passed down in Japan.

Shinto.name: Shintoshu (collection of shrine legends)
Shinto.desc: Shintoshu is a collection of anecdotes and Shinto books in medieval Japan.

Shinto.name: Sanshu no Jingi or Mikusa no Kamudakara (The Three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Sanshu no Jingi or Mikusa no Kamudakara (The Three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family).html
Shinto.desc: The Three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family refer to a mirror, a sword and a jewel that are believed to have been granted by Amaterasu Omikami (also known as Tensho daijin or the 'Sun Goddess') to her grandson Ninigi during 'Tensonkorin' when he descended from heaven to rule over the country.

Shinto.name: Kiki
Shinto.desc: Kiki is a collective designation of the "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki."

Shinto.name: Rikkokushi (the Six National Histories)
Shinto.desc: "Rikkokushi" represents six national historical books which were compiled by the Japanese nation under the ritsuryo codes in ancient times.

Shinto.name: Fudoki (description of regional climate, culture, etc.)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Fudoki (description of regional climate, culture, etc.).html
Shinto.desc: "Fudoki" is a title of Chinese books.

Shinto.name: Ama no Murakumo no Tsurugi
Shinto.desc: The 'Ama no Murakumo no Tsurugi' (also called 'Ame no Murakumo no Tsurugi', translated literally as, "Sword of the Gathering Clouds of Heaven) is one of the 'Sanshu no Jingi' (the Three Imperial Regalia) and a 'shintai' (an object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of a deity) of the Atsuta-jingu Shrine.

Shinto.name: Nagasunehiko
Shinto.desc: Nagasunehiko is a character that appears in Japanese mythology.

Shinto.name: Saishu (Chief Priest)
Shinto.desc: Saishu was a post within Shinto priesthood that was set up exclusively in the Ise-jingu Shrine.

Shinto.name: Guji
Shinto.desc: Guji (or Miyazukasa) is a job grade for chief Shinto priests, who manage all other Shinto priests and miko (shrine maidens).

Shinto.name: Shinkan
Shinto.desc: "Shinkan" is a person serving a certain God or working as a government official at a facility where God is worshipped.

Shinto.name: Yata no Kagami
Shinto.desc: Yata no Kagami is a mirror and one of the Sanshu no Jingi (Three Imperial Regalia).

Shinto.name: Sendai Kujihongi
Shinto.desc: Sendai Kujihongi is a book on ancient Japanese history.

Shinto.name: Kenji (Divine Sword and Jewel)
Shinto.desc: Kenji is the term used when combining the Ame no Murakumo no Tsurugi (literally "Heavenly Sword of Assembled Clouds") and the Yasakani no magatama (comma-shaped jewel), two of the Sanshu no Jingi (Three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family).

Shinto.name: Kyuji (A Record of Stories Current at Court)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Kyuji (A Record of Stories Current at Court).html
Shinto.desc: "Kyuji" is regarded to be a history book handed down by each clan, which was used as basic information for editing "kiki" (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki), but it was lost and is not existent, just like "Teiki" (a genealogy of the imperial family).

Shinto.name: Gunsho Ruiju (Collection of Historical Documents)
Shinto.desc: "Gunsho Ruiju" is a library of Japanese literature.

Shinto.name: Omoto Shinyu (Divine Revelations)
Shinto.desc: "Omoto Shinyu" is a collection of literary work in which Ofudesaki (the Holy Scriptures of Omoto) was edited.

Shinto.name: Shugo
Shinto.desc: Shugo is a mixture of Buddha, bodhisattvas and deities worshipped by various religions, or a category that considers them as one religion.

Shinto.name: Shaku Nihongi (annotated text of the Nihon Shoki)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Shaku Nihongi (annotated text of the Nihon Shoki).html
Shinto.desc: "Shaku Nihongi" is an annoted text of "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) which is assumed to have been compiled at the end of Kamakura period, probably between 1274 and 1301.

Shinto.name: Kokuiko (Thoughts on the Meaning of the Nation)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Kokuiko (Thoughts on the Meaning of the Nation).html
Shinto.desc: "Kokuiko" is a literary work by KAMO no Mabuchi, a scholar of Japanese classical literature in the Edo period.

Shinto.name: Kokushi Taikei (Compilation of historical and juridical texts from the fourteenth century)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Kokushi Taikei (Compilation of historical and juridical texts from the fourteenth century).html
Shinto.desc: "Kokushi Taikei" is a library of books which collected historic materials essential for the study of the Japanese history and added revisions to them.

Shinto.name: Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine).html
Shinto.desc: Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine) was an ancient book introducing the origin of the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine that resided there from ancient times.

Shinto.name: Shinto Gobusho (five-volume apologia of Shinto)
Shinto.desc: "Shinto Gobusho" was a foundational book of Ise Shinto (also known as Watarai Shinto - a school of Shinto thought established by priests of the Grand Shrine of Ise in the medieval period) and a collective term for the following five-volume apologia.

Shinto.name: Chusei Nihongi (A set of medieval Japanese myths)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Chusei Nihongi (A set of medieval Japanese myths).html
Shinto.desc: Chusei Nihongi collectively refers to a set of Japanese mythologies that were variously reinterpreted and revised based mainly on the Honchi Suijaku theory (the theory that Japanese deities were the multi-faceted embodiment of Buddha) in the medieval period while founding its base on classics such as "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

Shinto.name: Senkyoshi (The Office of Indoctrination)
Shinto.desc: "Senkyoshi" was one of the government offices of Japan in the Meiji period.

Shinto.name: Bureau of Shrines and Temples
Shinto.desc: Bureau of Shrines and Temples was one of the bureaus of the Meiji government.

Shinto.name: Bureau of Shrines (Jinja kyoku)
Shinto.desc: The Bureau of Shrines was one of the bureaus of the Meiji government.

Shinto.name: Yuiitsu shinto myoho [myobo] yoshu
Shinto.desc: "Yuiitsu shinto myoho [myobo] yoshu" (Compendium of the Doctrines of the One-and-Only Shinto) was written by Kanenobu URABE, but it is supposedly a fake edition made by Kanetomo YOSHIDA, who made a pretext of an ancestor.

Shinto.name: Shinto Shusei
Shinto.desc: "Shinto Shusei" was written by Mitsukuni TOKUGAWA.

Shinto.name: Hachiman Gudokun (Exegesis of Hachimanshin Legends for the Ignorant and Children)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Hachiman Gudokun (Exegesis of Hachimanshin Legends for the Ignorant and Children).html
Shinto.desc: "Hachiman Gudokun" is a history of temples and shrines that narrates the miracle and divine virtue of Hachimanshin (Shinto god of War), which is considered to have been compiled in the middle or late Kamakura period.

Shinto.name: Honcho Jinja Ko (a study of Japanese shrine)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Honcho Jinja Ko (a study of Japanese shrine).html
Shinto.desc: "Honcho Jinja Ko" (a study of Japanese shrine) is a book authored by Razan HAYASHI.

Shinto.name: Ryukyu Shinto-ki
Shinto.desc: "Ryukyu Shinto-ki" is a Buddhist books.

Shinto.name: Takahashi Ujibumi
Shinto.desc: "Takahashi Ujibumi" (histories compiled by the Takahashi family) is a history book, a collection of records, in ancient Japan.

Shinto.name: Zoku-Gunsho Ruiju (The Library of Historical Documents, Continued)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Zoku-Gunsho Ruiju (The Library of Historical Documents, Continued).html
Shinto.desc: "Zoku-Gunsho Ruiju" is a collection of books.

Shinto.name: Nihon isshi (Supplemental History of Japan)
Shinto.desc: "Nihon isshi" is a history book.

Shinto.name: Koshitsu (study books about ancient history)
Shinto.desc: "Koshitsu" is a series of books authored by Hakuseki ARAI, which analyze ancient Japanese history.

Shinto.name: Yomotsu-shikome
Shinto.desc: Yomotsu-shikome is a female demon of Yomi (the world after death) in Japanese Mythology.

Shinto.name: Yomotsuikusa (recurring demon)
Shinto.desc: "Yomotsuikusa" were demons in Japanese Mythology, which were said to live in the land of the dead.

Shinto.name: Haitei no Yashiro Shrine (Shrine of the Dethroned Emperor)
Shinto.url: Shinto/Haitei no Yashiro Shrine (Shrine of the Dethroned Emperor).html
Shinto.desc: Haitei no Yashiro Shrine was located on a knoll in Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Yasakani no Magatama (comma-shaped jewel)
Shinto.desc: The Yasakani no magatama is one of the Three Sacred Treasures of the Imperial Family, along with the Yata no Kagami (the eight-span mirror) and the Ame no Murakumo no Tsurugi (the sword Ame-no-Murakumo, literally "Heavenly Sword of Assembled Clouds").

Shinto.name: Kannabi
Shinto.desc: Kannabi (also called kamunabi or kaminabi) refers to a place that holds numerous spirit replacements or material objects in which divine spirits reside; or one form of divine replacement in which the natural environment is an object of worship that contains the spirit of a deity.

Shinto.name: Shinto scripture
Shinto.desc: Shinto scripture is a general term for the literature which provide the basis for religious belief in Japanese Shinto.

Shinto.name: Hitsuki Shinji
Shinto.desc: Hitsuki Shinji is the Divine Revelation that Tenmei OKAMOTO (1897-1963), a painter and a Shintoist, claimed to have received from a holy spirit called 'Kuninotoko Tachinokami' (国常立尊 or 国之常立神) by automatic writing.

Shinto.name: Tokusen Shinmyocho
Shinto.desc: Tokusen Shinmyocho (also read jinmyocho) is a commentary on 'Engishiki Jinmyocho' (the Register of Deities of the Engishiki)

Shinto.name: Jinjakakuroku (historical investigation of old shrines)
Shinto.desc: Jinjakakuroku is the book of historical investigation of ancient temples and shrines, such as Shikinai-sha (shrines listed in Engishiki laws).

Shinto.name: State Shinto
Shinto.desc: State Shinto is the name given by historians to the state religion, as well as the religious services, that were established under a policy of the Empire of Japan from the Meiji period (1868-1912) to the end of the Pacific War.

Shinto.name: Onda
Shinto.desc: Onda (ota, mita, omita, onta, onda, oden) refers to the territories owned by temples, shrines and the Imperial family and it also refers to the rites and festivals held there.

Shinto.name: Animism
Shinto.desc: Animism is a concept that every thing regardless of a living thing or a non-living object has a spirit or a soul.

Shinto.name: Koten Kokyujo
Shinto.desc: Koten Kokyujo (1882 - 1946) was an institute established in Japan for the research and education on Shinto.

Shinto.name: The Inbe Clan
Shinto.desc: The Inbe clan (also called Imibe clan) was a vocation-based group having characteristics of a clan, which existed from the Yamato period through the Nara period.

Shinto.name: Jinpu
Shinto.desc: Jinpu is fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrine and temple) donated to a shrine.

Shinto.name: TOYA Manabu
Shinto.desc: Manabu TOYA (1953 -) is a Shintoist, novelist and business enterprise consultant in Japan.

Shinto.name: Shinchoku (an oracle)
Shinto.desc: Shinchoku is a word that refers to Heaven's will, and also its writing.

Shinto.name: Sanno Shinto
Shinto.desc: Sanno Shinto (Sanno Shintoism) is a school of Shintoism developed by Hieizan Enryaku-ji Temple, the headquarters of Tendai Sect of Buddhism, from the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period.

Shinto.name: Kososhin (Imperial Ancestor)
Shinto.desc: Kososhin is the god deemed to be the ancestor of Imperial Family.

Shinto.name: Jinposho
Shinto.desc: Jinposho is a list of various districts of Ise-jingu Shrine (both Naiku (the inner shrine) and Geku (the outer shrine)) territory.

Shinto.name: the Imperial Edict (of 1870) for Establishment of Shinto
Shinto.url: Shinto/the Imperial Edict (of 1870) for Establishment of Shinto.html
Shinto.desc: The Imperial Edict (of 1870) for Establishment of Shinto is a Shosho (imperial edict, decree) which was issued on February 3, 1870.

Shinto.name: Saniwa
Shinto.desc: Saniwa is a person who receives shintaku (oracle) and interprets providence in religious services of Koshinto (as practiced prior to the introduction of Confucianism and Buddhism to Japan).

Shinto.name: Jinja-cho (Shrine Agency)
Shinto.desc: Jinja-cho is a local administrative organ of Jinja-honcho (the Association of Shinto Shrines).

Shinto.name: Shintai-zan Mountain
Shinto.desc: Shintai-zan Mountain is a term mainly used in Shitoism meaning a mountain believed to be where deities dwell in the concept of mountain worship and also called Kannabi, a mountain where deities dwell.

Shinto.name: Shinpu Kanro
Shinto.desc: Shinpu Kanro is a method of clarifying things created by Yoshimasa MIURA (1904 - 1971), Toyokawa City, Aichi Prefecture, who claimed he was an authentic Imperial descendant of the Southern Court.

Shinto.name: Seven Shikobuchi
Shinto.desc: Seven Shikobuchi' means major seven shrines which enshrine 'Shikobuchi gods,' which are the gods of belief native to Ado-gawa River basin, runs Kyoto Prefecture and Shiga Prefecture.

Shinto.name: Tenson Kigen
Shinto.desc: Tenson kigen is a Japanese year-reckoning system which sets the year of tenson korin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess) as its first year.

Shinto.name: TAIMA no Kehaya
Shinto.desc: TAIMA no Kehaya is a person that appears in Japanese myths.

title.name: Kyoto Shoshidai
title.desc: When Nobunaga ODA went to the capital with Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA in hand and put Kyoto under his dominion, he made his vassal Sadakatsu MURAI the Kyoto Shoshidai, in charge of maintaining the peace in Kyoto, imitating the organization of the Muromachi Shogunate.

title.name: Osho
title.desc: Osho (Sanskrit: upādhyāya) is an honorific title for Buddhist priests.

title.name: Seii Taishogun
title.desc: Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") was one of the Shogun positions in Japan's Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system).

title.name: Daimyo
title.desc: Daimyo is an expression that came from Daimyoshu.

title.name: Onmyoji
title.desc: Onmyoji (pronounced as on-myo-ji or on-yo-ji, meaning oracle) was the name of a government post in the Onmyoryo (Bureau of Divination) of the Nakatsukasasho (Central Affairs Ministry) under the Ritsuryo legal system of ancient Japan.

title.name: Shugodai
title.desc: Shugodai is an official post that was placed under the Shugo in the Kamakura and Muromachi periods.

title.name: Kampaku
title.desc: Kampaku is a post held by a person who governs in the Emperor's stead.

title.name: Regent
title.desc: A regent (Sessho), in a state with a monarchy, is the practice of carrying out government and national affairs in place of the monarch, or the post that does so, when the monarch is unable to do so because he is an infant, ill or not in the country.

title.name: Kanrei
title.desc: Kanrei is the name of a post in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Shugo
title.desc: Shugo was a samurai office in Japan's Kamakura and Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and was a military commander and administrative official placed in each ryoseikoku (province).

title.name: Udaijin (Minister of the Right)
title.desc: Udaijin was one of the positioins in Daijokan (Grand Council of State), which was the highest body in the organization of the imperial court.

title.name: Naidaijin (inner minister)
title.desc: Naidaijin is one of Japan's official titles.

title.name: Ajari
title.desc: Ajari (also Azari, Sanskrit: acarya, also transliterated as Ajariya) means a "model/example" in Sanskrit, and is a master who is an example to his disciples and teaches the dharma.

title.name: Ongoku Bugyo
title.desc: Ongoku Bugyo were placed in important places within Shogunate-owned land (tenryo) outside of Edo, and were divided into bugyo (magistrate)and yakugata who handled the governance of that land.

title.name: Omandokoro
title.desc: Omandokoro

title.name: Kubo (shogunal representative)
title.desc: The term "Kubo" originally referred to the embodiment of public affairs in the premodern Japan or the national sovereign power, that is, the Emperor or the Imperial Court in olden times, and the Shogun in the Kamakura and the Muromachi periods.

title.name: Ikai (the court rank)
title.desc: "Ikai" (the court rank) is a ranking system of the government officials.

title.name: Sadaijin (Minister of the Left)
title.desc: The Minister of the Left was a government post in the Daijokan (Grand Council of State), the central administrative body of the Imperial Court.

title.name: Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state)
title.desc: Positioned above the Sadaijin (minister of the left) and the Udaijin (minister of the right), the Daijo-daijin (grand minister of state, also known as Dajo-daijin) was the highest official post in the Daijokan (Grand Council of State) under the Ritsuryo system.

title.name: Nyoin (a close female relative of the Emperor or a womwan of comparable standing)
title.url: title/Nyoin (a close female relative of the Emperor or a womwan of comparable standing).html
title.desc: Nyoin indicates a title bestowed upon a woman, such as the three empresses (grand empress dowager, empress dowager, empress) or an equivalent status (jugo, honorary rank next to the three Empresses and princess, etc.) and is a system that continued from the middle of the Heian period until the Meiji Restoration.

title.name: Rokuhara Tandai (an administrative and judicial agency in Rokuhara, Kyoto)
title.url: title/Rokuhara Tandai (an administrative and judicial agency in Rokuhara, Kyoto).html
title.desc: "Rokuhara Tandai" is a job title in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Jusanmi
title.desc: "Jusanmi" (Junior Third Rank) is a rank in court ranks and shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods).

title.name: Jushii
title.desc: "Jushii" (Junior Fourth Rank) is a rank in court ranks and shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods) in Japan.

title.name: Juichii
title.desc: "Juichii (Junior First Rank)" is a rank in court ranks and shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods) in Japan.

title.name: Shoichii
title.desc: "Shoichii (Senior First Rank)" is one of court ranks and ranks granted to Shinto gods in Japan.

title.name: Dainagon (chief councilor of state)
title.desc: Dainagon

title.name: Chunagon
title.desc: "Chunagon" (vice-councilor of state) is a post ranking below Dainagon (chief councilor of state) in the Daijokan (Grand Council of State), the highest organ in the Imperial Court, and is Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system), corresponding to Suke (assistant director) in the Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks).

title.name: Choteki
title.desc: "Choteki" refers to those who inflict vengeance on the emperor (imperial line) in Japan.

title.name: Sento gosho
title.desc: "Sento gosho" is the imperial palace of an abdicated emperor (retired or cloistered emperor).

title.name: Kugyo
title.desc: "Kugyo" is a term referring to court noble posts responsible for national politics as the top-ranking officers of Daijokan (Grand Council of State) based on provisions of the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), namely, the top officials (collectively called giseikan), Daijo-daijin (Grand minister of state), Sadaijin (minister of the left), Udaijin (minister of the right), Dainagon (chief councilor of state), Chunagon (vice-councilor of state), and Sangi (imperial advisor) (or Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher).

title.name: Kokujin
title.desc: "Kokujin" are the samurai class, mainly originating from the jito (manager and lord of manor) class in the Kamakura period, who engaged in the development of provinces from the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) to the Muromachi period.

title.name: Hokumen no bushi (the Imperial Palace Guards for the north side)
title.url: title/Hokumen no bushi (the Imperial Palace Guards for the north side).html
title.desc: "Hokumen no bushi" were samurai who served the retired emperor, standing by as the gero (servant) on the north side of the in (imperial palace of the retired emperor), and guarding or accompanying the retired emperor when he made trips outside..

title.name: Sangi
title.desc: "Sangi" is one of the posts in the Daijokan (Grand Council of State), which is the highest organ in the Imperial Court organization for Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) in Japan.

title.name: Akuto
title.desc: "Akuto" generally refers to a person who disturbs the order of society, or a group of people who commit wrongdoing, but in Japanese history, it refers to a person or class rebelling against the existing system in the middle ages.

title.name: Jingikan
title.desc: Jingikan (Jingikan/kamizukasa/kanzukasa) was a state organization in Japan.

title.name: Kitano mandokoro
title.desc: Kitano mandokoro is the title given, through an emperor's proclamation, to the legally wedded wife of the person in the position of Sessho (regent) or Kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor).

title.name: Rronin (masterless samurai)
title.desc: 浪人 (ronin) indicated a person who wandered about provinces other than the one that was recorded in his family register, and was also called a furo (vagabond)

title.name: Hokoshu
title.desc: Hokoshu was a govermental position established by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Samuraidokoro
title.desc: Samuraidokoro was the organization that played military and police roles in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and in the Muromachi bakufu.

title.name: Koto no naishi
title.desc: Koto no naishi was a female court noble during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

title.name: Toshi choja
title.desc: Toshi choja indicates ujichoja (the head) of the Fujiwara clan.

title.name: Shogun family
title.desc: The shogun family was a houshold system where the head of samurai, who was designated as seii taishogun (literally: "great general who subdues the barbarians") or for the head of palace guards, generated, in the medieval times in Japan, imitating the houshold system of kuge (the court noble) when establishing his government.

title.name: Obanyaku
title.desc: Obanyaku was the post assigned to samurai from non-capital areas to maintain the security of Kyoto during the later Heian to early Muromachi period or to maintain the security of Kamakura city during the Kamakura period.

title.name: Kanto moshitsugi
title.desc: Kanto moshitsugi, also called Knato shisso, was a post introduced in the imperial court during the Kamakura period and played, together with the Rokuhara Tandai (an administrative and judicial agency in Rokuhara, Kyoto) on the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) side, the role of doing communications and adjustments between the bakufu and the imperial court or the government by cloistered emperors.

title.name: Inshi/In no tsukasa
title.desc: Inshi (or In no tsukasa) is an official of In no cho (Retired Emperor's Office) set up directly under the retired emperors and nyoin (empress, empress dowager or grand empress dowager) during the ancient period to the middle ages in Japan.

title.name: Naishi no tsukasa
title.desc: Naishi no tsukasa was one of the cutcherry in government-regulated organizations in Japan.

title.name: Yakata
title.desc: Yakata means a mansion of exalted personage such as kuge (court nobles) and buke (samurai families).

title.name: Kokushi
title.desc: Kokushi was a shigo (a posthumous name) given to monks by the Emperor and used to express the emperor's respect to the monks.

title.name: Hyoefu (the Middle Palace Guards)
title.desc: The Middle Palace Guard was an administrative office in the Ritsuryo system.

title.name: Saio (the Priestess)
title.desc: Saio or Itsuki no miko (the Priestess) was an unmarried princess of the blood or female relative of the Emperor who served as a shrine maiden at the Ise-jingu Shrine and the Kamo-jinja Shrine.

title.name: Saiin (the Priestess or the residence of the Priestess)
title.url: title/Saiin (the Priestess or the residence of the Priestess).html
title.desc: The name of Saiin was given to a Priestess who served at the Kamo-jinja Shrine from the Heian to the Kamakura period, or at the residence of the Priestess.

title.name: Hoshinno
title.desc: Hoshinno was an Imperial Prince who became a priest and renounced the world remaining within the imperial court.

title.name: Buketenso
title.desc: Buketenso was one of the job titles within the Imperial Court from Muromachi to the Edo period.

title.name: Junii (Junior Second Rank)
title.desc: Junii (Junior Second Rank) was a court rank and shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods) in Japan.

title.name: Yasedoji/Yasenodoji/Hasedoji
