title.desc: Yasedoji, Yasenodoji, or Hasedoji was a group of people who lived in Rakuhoku Yasego, the Yase Village in the northern Kyoto (present day Yase, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture) serving as Yotei (koshi carrier) for the Emperor from the Muromachi period.

title.name: Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Gate Guard)
title.url: title/Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Gate Guard).html
title.desc: Emonfu was a government office under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code).

title.name: Naishoryo (Bureau of Skilled Artisans)
title.desc: Naishoryo is one of the ranks outside the Ritsuryo system belonging to the Nakatsukasa-sho (Ministry of Central Affairs) under the Ritsuryo system.

title.name: Shobanshu
title.desc: Shobanshu was a status indicating a position in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Seito taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the eastern barbarians)
title.url: title/Seito taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the eastern barbarians).html
title.desc: Seito taishogun was a military official temporarily set up by the new government during the Boshin Civil War.

title.name: Jugo
title.desc: Jugo is an aristocratic title equal to the following three titles: taikotaigo (Emperor's grandmother), kotaigo (Empress Dowager) and kogo (Empress Consort).

title.name: Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank)
title.desc: Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank) is one of the ranks in the ranking order (ikai) and the ranking order of Shinto gods (shinkai) in Japan.

title.name: Doboshu
title.desc: Doboshu were people who had the responsibility for miscellaneous duties and entertainment near the shogun since the Muromachi period.

title.name: Takiguchi no musha (Takiguchi samurai)
title.desc: Takiguchi no musha (Takiguchi samurai) were bushi (samurai warriors) who guarded the dairi (imperial palace) under the command of the Kurodo dokoro (imperial secretariat) from the end of the ninth century.

title.name: Jodai (Castellan)
title.desc: The jodai is a person who took care of a castle in the absence of the lord.

title.name: Kanto Bugyo
title.desc: Kanto bugyo was a post held by an officer in the Kamakura bakufu or Muromachi bakufu (both of which were Japanese feudal governments headed by a shogun) who would confer ranks and titles on gokenin (immediate vassals of the shogun).

title.name: Kyoto Daikan
title.desc: Kyoto daikan was a post of an officer which was set up in Kyoto in the Edo period under the control of Kyoto shoshidai (the chief administrator of the imperial capital and of imperial lands), mainly administering the finance of the Edo bakufu and the Imperial court in Kinai (the five kuni in the immediate vicinity of Kyoto), such as administrating tenryo (bakufu-owned land), fief of the imperial family, and fief of the nobilities.

title.name: Kyoto Mimawariyaku (a post of Kyoto patrols)
title.url: title/Kyoto Mimawariyaku (a post of Kyoto patrols).html
title.desc: Kyoto Mimawariyaku was a post established by the Edo bakufu to maintain public order in Kyoto at the end of the Edo period.

title.name: Kubo-okura (financial branch)
title.desc: The Kubo-okura was the financial branch of the Muromachi bakufu, in charge of managing revenues and expenditures.

title.name: Onshogata (office for administering reward grants)
title.desc: The Onshogata was a department set up in the Kenmu Government and the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), which took charge of desk work relating to administering Onsho award (reward grants).

title.name: Nosenkata (an institution to collect taxes from moneylenders and sake breweries)
title.url: title/Nosenkata (an institution to collect taxes from moneylenders and sake breweries).html
title.desc: The Nosenkata was an organization commissioned to collect the dosoyaku (taxes imposed on pawnbrokers and moneylenders by the Muromachi bakufu - Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and sakayayaku (taxes imposed on sake brewery by the Muromachi bakufu), whose members were appointed by the Muromachi bakufu from among influential figures belonging to the doso (pawnbrokers and moneylenders) or the sakaya (sake breweries).

title.name: Naidankata
title.desc: The Naidankata, that functioned from 1344 to 1349, was a Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) controlled deliberative organization managing the shomusata (trial dealing with land-related issues).

title.name: Nenyo (one of the positions in the In's or retired emperor's) office
title.url: title/Nenyo (one of the positions in the Ins or retired emperors) office.html
title.desc: The Nenyo was an official position during the middle ages in Japan.

title.name: Shokei (court novels who work at the Imperial Court in high ranking posts)
title.url: title/Shokei (court novels who work at the Imperial Court in high ranking posts).html
title.desc: The Shokei, mainly in the Heian period, referred to a person of the highest rank in an organization or a function that nobles were involved in, but the Shokei commonly served in the following two posts:

title.name: Heian Cavalry
title.desc: Heian cavalry (Heian Kibatai) is the cavalry of the Kyoto Prefectural Police.

title.name: Kokushi (provincial governor)
title.desc: In medieval Japan, a kokushi was a government officer who was sent by the central government to administer a ryoseikoku (an area of regional administration).

title.name: Sengoku Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period)
title.url: title/Sengoku Daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period).html
title.desc: The term sengoku daimyo refers to a daimyo who exercised unitary control over several districts or provinces during Japan's sengoku (warring states) period.

title.name: Shishiki
title.desc: The Shishiki(Shishoku) represents the ranking or social status of samurai families in the Muromachi Period.

title.name: Jito (manager and lord of manor)
title.desc: Jito was a post established by Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Muromachi bakufu to manage and control shoen (manor) and kokuga-ryo (koryo (duchy), or an Imperial demesne).

title.name: Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system)
title.url: title/Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system).html
title.desc: Ryoge no kan was a newly established government post which was not defined within the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

title.name: Kotaiyoriai
title.desc: Kotaiyoriai (交代寄合） is one instance of having hatamoto (a direct retainer of a shogun) family status within the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Umamawari (horse guards)
title.desc: The Umamawari was established in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) (Japan) and was a job based on the government service system for samurai families.

title.name: Living National Treasure
title.desc: Living National Treasure is a Japanese popular term for individuals certified as Preservers of Important Intangible Cultural Properties by the Minister of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology based on the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties.

title.name: Jisha-bugyo
title.desc: Jisha-bugyo was one of the shogunate administrators in military government from the Muromachi to Edo eras, and was in charge of temples and shrines.

title.name: Kamakura Kubo
title.desc: Kamakura kubo was an administrator post in Kamakura Government which was established as an outpost position for the ten provinces of the Kanto region by the Seii taishogun (literally, 'great general who subdues the barbarians) of Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) during the Muromachi period.

title.name: Kebiishi (police and judicial chief)
title.desc: Kebiishi was a Ryoge no kan post (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code).

title.name: Gonkan
title.desc: The term "Gonkan" means official court posts that were created beyond the prefixed number of personnel.

title.name: Genji choja
title.desc: "Genji choja" means the head of the Minamoto clan.

title.name: Shitsuji
title.desc: A term "Shitsuji" generally means a person who oversees a clerical job, and in the case of prestigious families or temples/shrines, it means a person who presides over household affairs or administration.

title.name: Oryoshi
title.desc: "Oryoshi" was a ryoge no kan (official posts outside of the Ritsuryo code) under the Japanese Ritsuryo system (ancient centralized government system based on the Ritsuryo code).

title.name: Kurodo no to (the name of a post)
title.url: title/Kurodo no to (the name of a post).html
title.desc: The Kurodo no to, an official position outside of the Ritsuryo system (these positions were known as Ryoge no kan), was effectively the head of the Kurodo dokoro (chamberlain's office) (the nominal head, also known as the Kurodo betto, was also a minister).

title.name: Mandokoro
title.desc: Mandokoro was an administrative board for domestic economy that was allowed to be set up by Imperial princes, princesses and court nobles ranked Sanmi (Third Rank) or higher.

title.name: Kosho
title.desc: Kosho （小姓） is the name of a post in a samurai family similar to a page or squire.

title.name: Shokan
title.desc: Shokan was the general name of an officer governing Japanese shoen (manor) entrusted by the lord of the manor.

title.name: Jundaijin (a government post)
title.desc: Jundaijin was a government post in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

title.name: Kindachi
title.desc: The term "kindachi" in a wide sense refers to Shoo (princes without imperial proclamation), but, in a more limited sense, it is used as a term referring to imperial princes and the children of Sekke (the family of regents and advisers), or the Seiga family (the important family next to Sekke).

title.name: Kengyo
title.desc: Kengyo (one of the officers governing Shoen manor) is the highest title of official rank for blind officers during the middle and early modern ages.

title.name: Konoefu (Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards)
title.url: title/Konoefu (Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards).html
title.desc: Konoefu was one of Ryoge no kan (official organizations outside of the Ritsuryo code).

title.name: Uchitsuomi
title.desc: Uchitsuomi (Naishin) was one of Ryoge no kan (official posts outside of Ritsuryo code) which existed from the Asuka period to Heian period under the government based on the Ritsuryo code.

title.name: Shibichudai
title.desc: Shibichudai was a household agency of the Empress Komyo (at the time when Shibichudai was established, she was already Empress Dowager Komyo since her husband the Emperor Shomu had abdicated the throne to his daughter the Empress Koken) which was established by FUJIWARA no Nakamaro (also referred as EMI no Oshikatsu) in 749.

title.name: Kageyushi
title.desc: Kageyushi was a Ryoge no kan (official posts outside of the Ritsuryo code) under the Japanese Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo code).

title.name: Tsuibushi (Pursuit and Apprehension Agent)
title.desc: Tsuibushi (Pursuit and Apprehension Agent) was a Ryoge no kan (a Japanese government post which was not established by the Ritsuryo codes).

title.name: Kansatsushi (inspector)
title.desc: Kansatsushi refers to a government post which was established in Tang Dynasty China, in Yi Dynasty Korea, and in Japan in the early Heian period, for the purpose of inspecting the local administration.

title.name: Kurodo (Chamberlain)
title.desc: Kurodo refers to one of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes) in Japan.

title.name: Gundai
title.desc: Gundai （a magistrate of a region or an administrator of a town) is the name of a post set in the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and in clan domains from the Muromachi period to the Edo period.

title.name: Bugyo
title.desc: Bugyo is the name of a profession for a samurai family from the Heian period to the Edo period.

title.name: Kyoto Fuchishu (京都扶持衆)
title.desc: The Kyoto Fuchishu were samurai warriors who established master-subordinate relationships with the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in the Muromachi Period in the Kanto (currently, Tokyo and six other prefectures) and Tohoku (north of the Kanto region) regions.

title.name: Jusenshi (mint)
title.desc: Jusenshi (also referred as Chusenshi) was one of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) established in ancient Japan.

title.name: Kobushichishoku
title.desc: Kobushichishoku refers to a collective name of craftsmen engaged in seven processes in manufacturing the Hikone Buddhist altar.

title.name: Naikyobo (training center of imperial dancing girls)
title.url: title/Naikyobo (training center of imperial dancing girls).html
title.desc: Naikyobo refers to a Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system of ancient Japan.

title.name: Niedono
title.desc: Niedono was an institution attached to Naizenshi (Imperial Table Office) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) of Ritsuryo Japan.

title.name: Kiden hakase (Professor of History)
title.desc: Kiden hakase refers to a post established in Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education under the Ritsuryo system) in the early Heian period and taught Kidendo (the study of the histories), but, was integrated into Monjo hakase (Professor of Literature) later.

title.name: On hakase (Professor of Pronunciation of Chinese Language)
title.url: title/On hakase (Professor of Pronunciation of Chinese Language).html
title.desc: On hakase (also known as Koe no hakase) was a hakase position (professor) established under the Ritsuryo system in Japan.

title.name: Tono Chujo (a government post)
title.desc: Tono Chujo is the name of a government post in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

title.name: Shurishiki (The Palace Repairs Office)
title.desc: Shurishiki (also known as Surishiki) refers to a Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) established in the Heian period.

title.name: Uji no shaku
title.desc: Uji no shaku refers to conferring a rank of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) on one person each annually from among persons ranked Shorokuinojo (Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade) in the O clan, Minamoto clan, Taira clan, Fujiwara clan, Tachibana clan and others when the investiture was conducted on January 6 (old calendar) of every year from the Heian period.

title.name: Eishaku (an honorable position or rank)
title.desc: An eishaku indicates an honorable position or rank.

title.name: Kamonryo (Bureau of Housekeeping)
title.desc: Kamonryo refers to Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) under the Ritsuryo system in Ritsuryo Japan.

title.name: Ashigaru taisho (general in command of a troop of foot soldiers)
title.url: title/Ashigaru taisho (general in command of a troop of foot soldiers).html
title.desc: An Ashigaru taisho was a commanding officer who lead Ashigaru troops (foot soldiers) under a daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) during Japan's Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

title.name: Sodaisho (a commander in chief)
title.desc: Sodaisho was a commander in chief who lead an army composed of more than one corps.

title.name: Kurodo no betto (Chief of the Chamberlain's Office)
title.url: title/Kurodo no betto (Chief of the Chamberlains Office).html
title.desc: Kurodo no betto was a post of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) that was equivalent to a Kami (chief) of the Kurododokoro (Chamberlain's Office).

title.name: Goi no Kurodo (Chamberlain of Fifth Rank)
title.url: title/Goi no Kurodo (Chamberlain of Fifth Rank).html
title.desc: Goi no Kurodo was a post of Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Japanese Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

title.name: Rokui no Kurodo (a government post)
title.desc: Rokui no Kurodo was a Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) post for officers at Kurododokoro (the Chamberlain's Office).

title.name: Shunshi
title.desc: From the Heian Period, "Shunshi" was the title given to monjosho (students of literary studies at Imperial universities).

title.name: Tandai
title.desc: "Tandai" （探題） is a position set in a Buddhist temple.

title.name: Zuijin
title.desc: Zuijin (also called as zuishin) was a government official in Konoefu (the Headquarters of the Inner Palace Guards) during and after the Heian period; zuijin followed nobles to guard them when they went out.

title.name: Senke jissoku
title.desc: Senke jissoku is an honorific title for the 10 shokka (family of artisans) such as nurishi (lacquerer) and sashimonoshi (woodworker) who are involved in the sado (tea ceremony) and who pay visits to the san senke (three Sen families, namely, Omote, Ura and Mushakoji).

title.name: Sanboku-Isso
title.desc: "Sanboku-Isso" was the name given to the four meritorious retainers who received the Emperor Godaigo's favor under the Kemmu Restoration.

title.name: Tamori (field administrator)
title.desc: Tamori was a position in charge of managing fields on public lands, which was set up by the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Shoen-ryoshu (lord of a manor)
title.desc: "Shoen-ryoshu" was a lord that governed a Shoen (manor).

title.name: Yomei no suke (a sinecure post as honorary deputy governor)
title.url: title/Yomei no suke (a sinecure post as honorary deputy governor).html
title.desc: Yomei no suke is a vice minister of kokushi (provincial governors), an honorary post without official duties and benefits.

title.name: Sanshi (a government post)
title.desc: Sanshi is a government post in charge of calculation in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

title.name: Otomoshu
title.desc: "Otomoshu" were a group of busho (military commander) attendants who proceeded to the ancient capital of Kyoto from Kamakura and devoted themselves to raising Shogun Takauji ASHIKAGA's army.

title.name: Bugyoshu (group of magistrates)
title.desc: Bugyoshu, also called Yuhitsukata, were of group of Bugyonin (magistrates) who were lawyers of the bureaucracy within the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Naidanshu (judges)
title.desc: Naidanshu were in charge of judging trials dealing with land-related issues in hikitsukekata or naidankata (both are offices of adjudication) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Daijokan chuke
title.desc: The Daijokan chuke essentially indicated the kitchen that belonged to the Daijokan (Grand Council of State), but in ancient times the term referred to the government officials who administered the Daijokan kitchen.

title.name: Ichinokami (the ranking Council Member)
title.desc: Ichinokami was the head of the Kugyo (top court officials) and usually referred to the Minister of the Left.

title.name: Shomyo (lesser daimyo)
title.desc: Shomyo were samurai who were not well known.

title.name: Myoho hakase (Professor of Law)
title.desc: Myoho hakase was an official post affiliated with the Daigaku-ryo (Bureau of Education) under the ancient Japanese ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

title.name: Kuniyaku (Public duties)
title.desc: Kuniyaku were duties imposed by the Imperial Court and kokuga (provincial government offices) from the Heian period to the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan).

title.name: Naiju
title.desc: The term "Naiju" means children officials who was engaged in miscellaneous jobs at the Imperial palace in the Nara and Heian periods.

title.name: Naijudokoro (Imperial Pages Office)
title.desc: Naijudokoro was a government office of Ryoge no kan (official post outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Japanese Ritsuryo system.

title.name: Senkokushisho (History Compilation Bureau)
title.desc: Senkokushisho was the organization which was established while Japan was under the Ritsuryo system, for the purpose of compiling official history book Rikkokushi (the Six National histories) and "Shin-kokushi" (the New National History).

title.name: Chokushisho
title.desc: Chokushisho was the organization that succeeded Chokushisho (Bureau of Edicts) abolished in 782.

title.name: Kanrei-dai (representative of a shogunal deputy)
title.desc: "Kanrei-dai" was a job title within the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Jokan
title.desc: "Jokan" (written as "上官" or "政官") is the collective term for government officers who were mainly engaged in clerical work in the Daijokan (Grand Council of State) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of a centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code).

title.name: Jun-Sessho (associate regent)
title.desc: Jun-Sessho refers to the permission given by the Emperor to a Kanpaku (Chief Advisor to the Emperor) or minister to govern affairs of state as a Sesshu (regent) under the Ritsuryo system, and it also refers to the person who received this permission.

title.name: Jinryo bugyo
title.desc: "Jinryo bugyo" was an official post in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Suito (Shoen)
title.desc: "Suito" is a position set up for the lower-lanked officers in the Shoen manor in medieval Japan.

title.name: Suino
title.desc: Suino was the officer of Kurododokoro (the Chamberlain's Office) and was in charge of all of general affaires including the receipts and disbursement of the treasury of Kurododokoro.

title.name: Rinjizoyaku
title.desc: "Rinjizoyaku" is a collective term for the odd-job tasks that kokuga (provincial government office) obliged local farmers to perform as a kind of tax payable in labor or in kind.

title.name: Shinagon
title.desc: "Shinagon" refers to the four court nobles (MINAMOTO no Toshikata, FUJIWARA no Kinto, FUJIWARA no Tadanobu, and FUJIWARA no Yukinari) who were active in the era of Emperor Ichijo in the middle Heian Period.

title.name: Moshitsugishu
title.desc: "Moshitsugishu" was the name of a post in Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Banshu
title.desc: "Banshu"(a guard) is a person who keeps watch at night as part of guard group (ban).

title.name: Azukari (official post)
title.desc: Azukari was a post which was set up at government offices, temples or shrines and shoen (manor) in the Heian period.

title.name: Azukaridokoro
title.desc: "Azukaridokoro" (also Azukesho, Azugasso, Azukarisho) was a deputy position the medieval Shoen manor, and integrally controlled it with the official appointment of honjo (proprietor or guarantor of a manor).

title.name: To no ben
title.desc: The term "To no ben" refers to a person who assumed the position of Benkan (Controller) concurrently with the position of Kurodo no to (Head Chamberlain) under Japanese government officials system.

title.name: Kugokata
title.desc: "Kugokata" was a position in charge of preparation and service of meals to the seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and his family in the Muromachi bakufu.

title.name: Seisei taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the western barbarians)
title.url: title/Seisei taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the western barbarians).html
title.desc: The term "Seisei taishogun" is a general who was nominated by the Emperor (Imperial court) in the Heian period in order to conquer Kyushu region.

title.name: Seito taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the eastern barbarians)
title.url: title/Seito taishogun (literally, great general who subdues the eastern barbarians).html
title.desc: The term "Seito taishogun" is the title for general which was used in China and Japan in the past.

title.name: Local Lord
title.desc: A local lord (or "Zaichi ryoshu" in Japanese) is an appropriator with the authority to control farmers and fishermen in his territory by executing authority under the Shoen koryo sei (System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in Medieval Japan.

title.name: Shikken (regent for the shogun)
title.desc: Shikken is a name of a post in the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Tozama Daimyo (nonhereditary feudal lord)
title.desc: Tozama daimyo was a class of daimyo in Edo period defined according to ancestry.

title.name: Fudai Daimyo
title.desc: Fudai daimyo were a class of daimyo (Japanese feudal lords) in the Edo period defined according to their ancestry.

title.name: Gokenin
title.desc: Gokenin is a word used to describe the samurai retainers of the shogun but its meaning differed between the middle ages and early modern period.

title.name: Observation
title.desc: Observation means to watch an object carefully to find out its actual condition.

title.name: Gokamon
title.desc: Gokamon refers to a family with distinguished family lineage.

title.name: Gorenshi
title.desc: Gorenshi refers to brothers of prestigious families such as the Imperial Family and families of kuge (court nobles) and seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), and so on.

title.name: Nanate-gumi
title.desc: Nanate-gumi (Hideyoshi's seven troops) is a group of vassals that was organized by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI..

title.name: KASHIN Koji
title.desc: Koji KASHIN (year of birth unknown) was a magician who made his appearance at the end of the Muromachi period.

title.name: Chinju-fu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North)
title.url: title/Chinju-fu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North).html
title.desc: Chinju-fu Shogun was an official who served as shogun, belonging to Ryoge no kan (class outside of the Ritsuryo system), which was set up for the defense of the northern area during the Nara period and the Heian period in Japan.

title.name: Kokushu
title.desc: Kokushu was one of social statuses of daimyo (feudal lords) which existed during the early modern Edo period, and it referred to the daimyo having domain of one or more provinces; another name for kokushu was "kunimochidaimyo".

title.name: Samurai daisho
title.desc: Samurai daisho is a man who commands an army under Dai Shogun (the great general).

title.name: Myoseki (Family Name)
title.desc: Myoseki (名跡: Family Name) is a traditional naming convention that closely links family names of individuals with succeeding generations of a family.

title.name: Hyakkan na
title.desc: Hyakkan na refers to an official-rank-style name that samurai called himself.

title.name: Ichiryo Gusoku
title.desc: Ichiryo gusoku (literally means a set of armor) was a designation for a part time soldier and farmer and their organization (in sociology) which was formed and managed by Chosokabe clan, the daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) of Tosa Province in the Sengoku period targeting on armed peasants and jizamurai (local samurai) before heinobunri (a policy to strictly separate soldiers and farmers).

title.name: Official court titles for samurai
title.desc: The Japanese term Buke-kani is used to refer to the official ranks (official posts and court ranks) that samurai were granted or adopted for themselves mainly from the Sengoku period (Japan) to the Edo period.

title.name: Shodaibu (aristocracy lower than Kugyo)
title.desc: Shodaibu is the name of class of government officials (especially one of low to medium rank), which was used from ancient times through medieval period to the early-modern times in Japan.

title.name: Goshi (country samurai)
title.desc: Goshi is historical terminology referring to samurai hierarchy that existed during the Edo period.

title.name: Sotsuzoku (low-ranking samurai)
title.desc: Sotsuzoku was a name of social status in the early Meiji period.

title.name: Azechi
title.desc: Azechi (Inspector of the provincial government)

title.name: The Seven Great Spearmen in Japan
title.url: title/The Seven Great Spearmen in Japan.html
title.desc: The Seven Great Spearmen in Japan are the seven people who were praised for their yaribataraki (spear works) by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

title.name: Otogishu (advisers)
title.desc: Otogishu is the official duties, which existed in families of Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lords in the Sengoku period) from the the Sengoku period (period of Warring States) to the early Edo period.

title.name: Vice Shogun
title.desc: Vice shogun is the post of military officer which was ranked the next position of "Dai Shogun (the great general)" or shogun in Japan.

title.name: Joshi (upper-class samurai)
title.desc: Joshi was an upper-class feudal retainer in the Edo period.

title.name: Kyooyaku (a person in charge of the entertainment)
title.url: title/Kyooyaku (a person in charge of the entertainment).html
title.desc: The Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) established the post of 'Kyooyaku' during the Edo period to have someone provide entertainment for messengers of the emperor (who were known as "chokushi"), messengers of the retired emperor (who were known as "inshi"), or messengers of the empress (who were known as "nyoinshi") that had been sent to Edo.

title.name: Chokushisho (Bureau of Edicts)
title.desc: Chokushisho was an extra statutory office established in the latter half of the Nara period under the ritsuryo system.

title.name: Tenjobito/Uebito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace)
title.url: title/TenjobitoUebito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace).html
title.desc: Tenjobito/Uebito was a court official of fifth rank or above in Japanese pre-modern government organization and permitted to enter the emperor's private living quarters, i.e., the south side of the emperor's residence Seiryoden.

title.name: Saiguryo (the Office of the High Priestess [of the Ise-jingu Shrine])
title.url: title/Saiguryo (the Office of the High Priestess [of the Ise-jingu Shrine]).html
title.desc: Saiguryo was an extra statutory office established under the ritsuryo system, placed in Ise Province.

title.name: Cavalry
title.desc: Cavalry was a military force formed by soldiers mounting on horseback, armed with swords, spears, and guns.

title.name: Genjina
title.desc: The Genjina (professional names) are nomenclature named after the classic book Genji Monogatari (The Tale of Genji).

title.name: Kihei Taishogun (commander of cavalry)
title.desc: Kihei Taishogun was a military official established in the Nara period under the ritsuryo system.

title.name: Jigenin/Shimobito (government official who were not allowed to see the emperor)
title.url: title/JigeninShimobito (government official who were not allowed to see the emperor).html
title.desc: Jigenin' or 'Shimobito' is one of the statuses of aristocrats in Japan.

title.name: Yonin (steward)
title.desc: Yonin was a member of the organization that formed part of a samurai family during the Edo period.

title.name: Kokumo/Kokubo (imperial mother)
title.desc: Kokumo (or Kokubo) is the title for real mothers of emperors or kings.

title.name: Hikan (low ranking clerks)
title.desc: Who were Hikan?

title.name: Zojishi (Officials in Charge of Building Temples)
title.url: title/Zojishi (Officials in Charge of Building Temples).html
title.desc: Zojishi was an extra statutory office established in the Nara period for building national temples or those corresponding to national temples.

title.name: Zogusho (Ministry of Making and Mending Palaces)
title.url: title/Zogusho (Ministry of Making and Mending Palaces).html
title.desc: Zogusho was an extra statutory office responsible for castle building and repairing headed by Zogukyo (Minister of Making and Mending Palaces).

title.name: Machidai
title.desc: "Machidai" was a town official in Kyoto in the Edo period.

title.name: Seven Generals
title.desc: The Seven Generals (or "Nanasho") are the feudal lords who were reared by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI from an early age and famous as the brave generals.

title.name: Naijusho (Ministry of Royal Pages)
title.desc: Naijusho was an extra statutory office established in the latter half of the Nara period under the ritsuryo system.

title.name: Gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate) in Kyoto
title.url: title/Gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate) in Kyoto.html
title.desc: The term "gokenin in Kyoto" (zaikyo gokenin) refers to a gokenin (an immediate vassal of the shogunate in the Kamakura and Muromachi through Edo periods) who was permanently stationed in and around Kyoto under jurisdiction of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Junsatsushi (a circuit-riding inspector or investigating commissioner) (China)
title.url: title/Junsatsushi (a circuit-riding inspector or investigating commissioner) (China).html
title.desc: Junsatsushi (a circuit-riding inspector or investigating commissioner) was a government official title which originated in the Tang Dynasty of China.

title.name: Saiho Shochishi (an investigating commissioner)
title.desc: Saiho Shochishi (an investigating commissioner) was a title of the government official in Tang dynasty of China.

title.name: Kuge-ryo (the land and land rights of the court nobles called the kuge)
title.url: title/Kuge-ryo (the land and land rights of the court nobles called the kuge).html
title.desc: The term 'kuge-ryo' is the generic name for landed holdings belonging to 'kuge' (Japanese imperial court nobles) which includes 'kugyo' (high court nobles of third rank or above) and 'kanjin' (government officials), where the 'kugyo' consists of [1] 'ko' which includes the 'daijo daijin' (the Great Minister of State or Chancellor), the 'sa daijin' (Minister of the Left) and the 'u daijin' (Minister of the Right), and [2] 'kei' which includes 'dainagon' (Major Counselor), 'chunagon' (Middle Counselor) and 'sangi' (Consultants of senior fourth rank).

title.name: Genji Shoguns
title.desc: Genji Shoguns (Warrior Generals) were the Minamoto clan members given the responsibility of seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").

title.name: Shogun
title.desc: Shogun is a job grade and title given to the commander of a relatively large armed force and is also the rank of a military clique leader.

title.name: Marquis
title.desc: A "marquis" or "marquess" is the second of five peerage ranks.

title.name: Duke
title.desc: A Duke or Prince is the highest of the five peerage ranks.

title.name: Baron
title.desc: Baron (called danshaku in Japanese) is a title of nobility.

title.name: Gotairo (five administrators in Toyotomi regime)
title.desc: Gotairo indicates the five most powerful daimyo clans, appointed as Karo (or Tairo) of the Toyotomi family, and acted as executive organs of the Toyotomi Administration at the last days of the administration, during the Bunroku era (1593-1598).

title.name: Roju (member of shogun's council of elders)
title.url: title/Roju (member of shoguns council of elders).html
title.desc: Roju was a post in the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and domains in the Edo period.

title.name: Wakadoshiyori
title.desc: What is Wakadoshiyori?

title.name: Tairo (chief minister)
title.desc: Tairo was the highest post in the Edo bakufu government system, provisionally placed above Roju as an assistant to Shogun.

title.name: Machi-bugyo (town magistrate)
title.desc: Machi-bugyo was a name of a governmental post in the Edo period that was in charge of administration and judicature in an urban area (called machi-kata) in a territory.

title.name: Kanjo bugyo (commissioner of finance)
title.desc: Kanjo bugyo was a governmental post in the Edo period and the highest accounting officer, who was in charge of finance and control of the tenryo (the areas controlled directly by the bakufu).

title.name: Sanchuro (three mediators in Toyotomi Administration)
title.desc: Sanshuro, which literally means three high-ranking officials called Churo, were the posts established in the last days of the Toyotomi Administration, allowing those three men in the posts to participate in politics, and to mediate between Gotairo and Gobugyo when they cannot agree.

title.name: Gobugyo (magistrates of Toyotomi Administration)
title.desc: Gobugyo indicates a system consisting of five government officials (whose duties can be called magistrate or commissioner), that mainly took charge of practical businesses of the Toyotomi Administration at the last days of the administration during the Azuchi Momoyama period.

title.name: Daishogun (Command in Chief)
title.desc: Daishogun (also Taishogun)

title.name: Ometsuke (inspector general)
title.desc: Ometsuke was a governmental post in the Edo period belonging to Roju (the second highest post in the Edo bakufu government) in the government system, and played a role of an inspector who watched daimyo (Japanese feudal lord), koke (privileged families under Tokugawa Shogunate), and the Imperial court to protect the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) from rebellion of these powers.

title.name: Koshu (title)
title.desc: Koshu (公主) indicates the daughters of the Chinese Emperors.

title.name: Shogoi
title.desc: Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) is one of the ranks in Japan's aristocratic and religious hierarchies.

title.name: Agatanonushi (territorial ruler)
title.desc: The term "agatanonushi" refers to a post or kabane (hereditary title) of Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) before the introduction of the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

title.name: Kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)
title.url: title/Kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan).html
title.desc: Kuni no miyatsuko was a post, or an official to the post, placed to govern regions across Japan before the Ritsuryo legal code system was introduced.

title.name: Daijokan, Dajokan (highest organ of state power)
title.url: title/Daijokan, Dajokan (highest organ of state power).html
title.desc: Daijokan

title.name: Genro (an elder statesman)
title.desc: Genro indicates a senior top-level statesman in the Japanese government in the era from the latter half of the Mejia period to the early Showa period.

title.name: Shonii
title.desc: Shonii (Senior Second Rank) is one of the ranks in Ikai (court ranks) and Shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods) in Japan.

title.name: Hyojoshu (government post)
title.desc: Hyojoshu was a government post established during the periods of Kamakura and Muromachi.

title.name: Danjonokami (also known as Danjoin) (the head of Danjodai)
title.url: title/Danjonokami (also known as Danjoin) (the head of Danjodai).html
title.desc: Danjonokami (also known as Danjoin) was the head of Danjodai under the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Seijisosaishoku (president of political affairs)
title.desc: Seijisosaishoku was one of the three most important posts in the Edo bakufu, which was newly established towards the end of the bakufu system in the late Edo period, together with Shogun-kokenshoku (the post for the guardian of shogun) and Kyoto shugoshoku (the military governor of Kyoto).

title.name: Taishin
title.desc: Taishin (person of high rank and income) refers to a person who has a high rank and a high stipend.

title.name: Oe (title or appellation)
title.desc: Oe was an appellation and title for powerful Imperial Princes, used in Wa (ancient Japan) from the first half of the 6th century to the middle of the 7th century.

title.name: Dazai Gonnosochi
title.desc: Dazai Gonnosochi was the Provisional Governor General of Daziafu in Kyushu.

title.name: Sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies)
title.url: title/Sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).html
title.desc: Sojaban (or Soshaban) was a governmental post in the Edo bakufu or domains.

title.name: Successive Ministers of Education
title.desc: This section "Successive Ministers of Education" carries lists of successive Ministers of Education, Monbukyo (chief of Ministry of Education), which was the predecessor of Minister of Education, and Ministers of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (the present title of the former Minister of Education) in Japan.

title.name: Dazai no sochi (also known as Dazai no sotsu) (Head of Dazaifu)
title.url: title/Dazai no sochi (also known as Dazai no sotsu) (Head of Dazaifu).html
title.desc: Dazai no sochi was the head of Dazaifu.

title.name: Hatamoto (direct retainers of shogun)
title.desc: The "hatamoto" is a general term indicating those who were direct retainers of the Tokugawa shogun family, provided with an amount of rice crop less than 10,000 koku (approximately 180 liters/koku) and the family status of omemie (vassal with the privilege to have an audience with the shogun) or higher who attended the ceremonies in the shogun's presence.

title.name: Jo (Third official among Shitokan)
title.desc: Jo was the third official among Shitokan under the Japanese ritsuryo system.

title.name: Shonagon (Post in Daijokan)
title.desc: Shonagon was a post in Daijokan, which was the highest organization in the Imperial Court.

title.name: Benkan (Collective name of posts in Daijokan)
title.url: title/Benkan (Collective name of posts in Daijokan).html
title.desc: Benkan collectively means the posts of Sadaiben, Udaiben, Sachuben, Uchuben, Sashoben, and Ushoben in Daijokan which is the highest organization of the Imperial Court.

title.name: Genkun
title.desc: Genkun (the statesmen who contributed to Meiji Restoration) refer to the politicians who made considerable achievements in the overthrow of the Shogunate and the Meiji Restoration, played an important role in the Meiji Government, and were from Kinno-no-Shishi (a royalist).

title.name: Sobayonin (lord chamberlain)
title.desc: Sobayonin was a post in the bakufu and domains in the Edo period.

title.name: Kizoku (nobles)
title.desc: Kizoku indicated persons whose social privileges were generally recognized due to their blood lines or their family statuses and also indicated the clans of such persons.

title.name: Azuma Hyakkan
title.desc: Azuma Hyakkan referred to a person's name that looked like a government post and was used by the samurai in the Kanto region.

title.name: Six great educators in the Meiji period
title.url: title/Six great educators in the Meiji period.html
title.desc: The term "the six great educators in the Meiji period" refers to a special, collective title of six great educators who contributed a great deal to promoting the modern education in the Meiji period.

title.name: Kaiganbogyo-goyogakari (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu)
title.url: title/Kaiganbogyo-goyogakari (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu).html
title.desc: Kaiganbogyo-goyogakari was a governmental post of the Edo bakufu.

title.name: Kanjoginmiyaku (a governmental post in the Edo period)
title.url: title/Kanjoginmiyaku (a governmental post in the Edo period).html
title.desc: Kanjoginmiyaku was a governmental post in charge of auditing all jobs in the Kanjo-sho office (the office for finance) in the Edo Bakufu.

title.name: Konoe no daisho
title.desc: Konoe no daisho (Major Captain of the Palace Guards) is one of the government posts in the ritsuryo system.

title.name: Otsukegaro (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu, or a person or persons in the post)
title.url: title/Otsukegaro (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu, or a person or persons in the post).html
title.desc: Otsukegaro is a karo (chief retainer) in the early Edo bakufu period who, when kikoshi (a young nobleman) in the linage of the Tokugawa Shogun family became the lord of a domain (daimyo), was appointed directly by Seii taishogun (literally, "the great general who was to subdue the barbarians") for serving the lord.

title.name: Gunji
title.desc: Gunji (district manager) was:

title.name: Metsuke (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu)
title.url: title/Metsuke (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu).html
title.desc: Metsuke is

title.name: Nyogo (rank of court lady)
title.desc: Nyogo was one of the ranks and titles of the imperial consorts in the pre-modern days of Japan, and its role was to attend on the emperor in his bedroom.

title.name: Oban-gashira or Obanto
title.desc: Oban-gashira Or Obanto have the following meanings:

title.name: Banto
title.desc: Banto

title.name: Hitsuke-tozoku-aratame-kata (literally, investigative division for arson and organized robbery)
title.url: title/Hitsuke-tozoku-aratame-kata (literally, investigative division for arson and organized robbery).html
title.desc: The Hitsuke-tozoku-aratame-kata post was for mostly cracking down such felonies as arson, robbers (burglars) and gambling.

title.name: Eiten
title.desc: Eiten (honor) is a generic term for treatment, positions and titles that the nation gives as a commendation to a person who has rendered distinguished service to the nation and the public.

title.name: Yoriki (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu)
title.url: title/Yoriki (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu).html
title.desc: Yoriki was a typical governmental post in the Edo bakufu.

title.name: Shomotsu-bugyo (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu)
title.url: title/Shomotsu-bugyo (a governmental post of the Edo bakufu).html
title.desc: Shomotsu-bugyo was a governmental post of the Edo bakufu.

title.name: Kanshoku (Government Post)
title.desc: Kanshoku (government post) means the posts of government officials.

title.name: Otoshiyori
title.desc: Otoshiyori was a female servant post (or also indicated the servant herself) in O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants resided) in the Edo period, and was often called Rojo as well.

title.name: Kenrei
title.desc: Kenrei refers to:

title.name: Shosanmi
title.desc: Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) is one of the ranks in Ikai (court ranks) and Shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods).

title.name: Taifu/Daifu/Tayu
title.desc: Taifu refers to a social status of nobility with territory from the Zhou period to the Spring and Autumn period and the Warring States period in China.

title.name: Saemon no jo (Government Post)
title.desc: Saemon no jo was a government post under the Japanese ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Shoshidai
title.desc: Shoshidai (representative of shoshi) is:

title.name: Shorokui
title.desc: Shorokui (Senior Sixth Rank) is one of the ranks in Ikai (court ranks) and Shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods).

title.name: Ushutandai (Post in Muromachi bakufu)
title.desc: Ushutandai was a post of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) placed in Dewa Province during the Muromachi period.

title.name: Udoneri (government post)
title.desc: Udoneri was a government post under the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Moshitsugi
title.desc: Moshitsugi (an official for conveying a message) which is also called Souja/Shosha, refers to a position in charge of reporting information to a lord, or refers to the act of reporting information itself.

title.name: Yunonagashi (a government post in ancient Japan)
title.url: title/Yunonagashi (a government post in ancient Japan).html
title.desc: Yunonagashi was a government post established in Japan during the Asuka period and took charge of managing Tomokuyu (also known as Yu no mura) that was a territory of the Imperial family.

title.name: Rusui (a governmental post placed in the Edo bakufu and in domains)
title.url: title/Rusui (a governmental post placed in the Edo bakufu and in domains).html
title.desc: Rusui was a governmental post placed in the Edo bakufu and in domains.

title.name: Zuryomei (Honorary titles)
title.desc: Zuryomei were unofficial names for government posts.

title.name: Ikoku keigobanyaku (military service)
title.desc: Ikoku keigobanyaku was a military service imposed by the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) on Gokenin in Kyushu.

title.name: Jikatasanyaku (the three officers of a village)
title.url: title/Jikatasanyaku (the three officers of a village).html
title.desc: Jikatasanyaku was a generic name for village officers in the early-modern times of Japan (the Edo period).

title.name: Dochu-bugyo (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu)
title.url: title/Dochu-bugyo (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu).html
title.desc: Dochu-bugyo was a governmental post in the Edo bakufu.

title.name: Jikata kosha
title.desc: Jikata kosha was an Edo Period bureaucrat overseeing domain agriculture who had extensive knowledge of regional affairs.

title.name: Hakucho (the ordinary people or inferior servants)
title.url: title/Hakucho (the ordinary people or inferior servants).html
title.desc: Hakucho is a term referring to male ryomin (ordinary people) with no special rank or title and no public employment in the Chinese and Japanese ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

title.name: Mokushi
title.desc: Mokushi was a govermental post in the Edo period which was in charge of maintaining ranches under direct control of the bakufu, as subordinates of an officer in the bakufu, and it is said that the officers in the post were responsible for managing the Goyoboku of the Tokugawa bakufu (public ranches of horses + hunting grounds for Shogun).

title.name: Tsukasa (a rank in government offices)
title.desc: Tsukasa (also known as Shi) was a rank in government offices mainly placed under the ministries in the ancient Japanese ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Ryo (a rank in government offices under ritsuryo system)
title.url: title/Ryo (a rank in government offices under ritsuryo system).html
title.desc: Ryo was a rank in government offices under the ancient Japanese ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Shiki (a rank in government offices under ritsuryo system)
title.url: title/Shiki (a rank in government offices under ritsuryo system).html
title.desc: Shiki was a rank in government offices under the ritsuryo system.

title.name: Bunin or Fujin (consort of the emperor or one's wife)
title.url: title/Bunin or Fujin (consort of the emperor or ones wife).html
title.desc: Fujin or Bunin (one's wife)

title.name: Naiki (government posts)
title.desc: Naiki was Honkan, the collective name of government posts, which belonged to Nakatsukasasho under the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Kenmotsu (officials belonging to Nakatsukasasho)
title.desc: Kenmotsu was officials of Honkan that belonged to Nakatsukasasho under the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Shurei (officials belonging to Nakatsukasasho)
title.desc: Shurei was officials of Honknan that belonged to Nakatsukasasho under the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Monjo Hakase
title.desc: Monjo hakase of Daigaku-ryo (大学寮: an institute for the training of government officials established under ritsuryo-sei [a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes], which belonged to Shikibu-sho [Ministry in charge of ceremonies in the Nara and Heian periods]) was a teacher of kiden-do (the study of histories, one of the subjects taught at Daigaku-ryo), and was ryoge-no-kan (a government post outside those determined under ritsuryo-sei).

title.name: Kannin (officials)
title.desc: Kannin (also known as Kanjin, Tsukasabito) means an official and a civil servant.

title.name: Shihan (grand master)
title.desc: Grand master

title.name: Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) (a rank in Japan)
title.url: title/Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) (a rank in Japan).html
title.desc: The term "Jugoi" (Junior Fifth Rank) refers to an Ikai (court rank) or a Shinkai (ranks granted to Shinto gods) in Japan.

title.name: Zejo
title.desc: Zejo was the title of the chieftain of the Tachibana and O clans in the Heian period.

title.name: The Nara Peerage
title.desc: The Nara Peerage refers to a family line and its people, who returned to the court noble society and entitled to be the peerage after the Meiji Restoration due to the special circumstances described below.

title.name: Myobu
title.desc: Myobu is a woman who has Ikai (court rank) above Jugoinoge (junior fifth rank), or a title representing a rank of a government official's wife under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

title.name: Sanpitsu (three famous ancient calligraphers)
title.desc: Sanpitsu is the name to call three excellent calligraphers.

title.name: Kojunin (小十人) (escort guards)
title.desc: The term "Kojunin" refers to a post of the security and military division (Bankata [security officials]) of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

title.name: Shinban
title.desc: Shinban is a post in a samurai family in the area of security and military affairs (bankata)

title.name: Uneme
title.desc: Uneme was a maid-in-waiting who attended to the emperor or empress in the Imperial Court to exclusively take care of the emperor or empress including meals.

title.name: Tomei (Tang name)
title.desc: Tang names (tomei, tomyo, or karana) are Chinese names of government posts or departments each of which corresponds to a Japanese name of a government post or department whose official duties were similar to those of Tang under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) in Japan.

title.name: Homen
title.desc: Homen was the name of Shimobe (miscellaneous servants and attendants) of Kebiishi (a official with judicial and police power) which was Ryoge no kan (a post outside the original Ritsuryo code created by Imperial edicts) in Japan.

title.name: Sakan (Kokushi)
title.desc: Sakan was the fourth among the four official ranks of Shitokan under the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Sho no sansei (three saints of calligraphy)
title.url: title/Sho no sansei (three saints of calligraphy).html
title.desc: Sho no sansei are three masters of calligraphy.

title.name: Toei Daio
title.desc: Toei Daio is one of the honoric titles for Sanzan Kanryo no miya.

title.name: Feudal Lords
title.desc: The term "feudal lord" is used to refer to a person who holds feudal dominion over a certain area of land and its residents (territory).

title.name: Satsumanokami
title.desc: Satsumanokami was the post of Kami (chief) of Kokushi in Satsuma province.

title.name: Joro otoshiyori
title.desc: Joro otoshiyori is the title of women serving in the O-oku during the Edo Period.

title.name: Torimi
title.desc: Torimi (officer for falconry) is a position in the Edo shogunate.

title.name: Geki (government post)
title.desc: Geki was one of the government posts belonging to Daijokan, which was the highest organization of the Imperial Court under the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Fushin bugyo
title.desc: The fushin bugyo was a post held by hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu, which is a form of Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) during the Edo period.

title.name: Tenyaku (government post)
title.desc: Tenyaku referred to Honkan, a government post, which belonged to Nakatsukasasho in the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Kanjo-kumigashira
title.desc: Kanjo-kumigashira is a bureaucratic post in the Edo shogunate.

title.name: Mikinotsukasa (branch office of ministry)
title.desc: Mikinotsukasa (also called Sakenotsukasa) was a branch office of Kunaisho, erected under the ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Kunin-chojakunin
title.desc: Kunin-chojakunin is a post that existed in the Edo Period.

title.name: Shogun-kokenshoku
title.desc: Shogun-kokenshoku is one of the three key posts in Edo shogunate created in the final years of the Edo period, along with Seiji sosaishoku (president of political affairs) and Kyoto shugoshoku (military governor of Kyoto).

title.name: Tenka-bito
title.desc: Tenka-bito (or tenka-nin) refers to the people who controlled the world as they knew it (in this case, the Japanese islands).

title.name: Oomi (a government post in ancient Japan)
title.url: title/Oomi (a government post in ancient Japan).html
title.desc: Ooomi was a post in the Yamato Kingdom in the Kofun period.

title.name: Omuraji (ancient Japan)
title.desc: Omuraji is one of the governmental posts of the Yamato sovereignty (the ancient Japan sovereignty) during the Kofun period (tumulus period).

title.name: Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank)
title.url: title/Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank).html
title.desc: Naishi no suke was a government post in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) and an undersecretary (a court lady) of Naishi no tsukasa (female palace attendants in kokyu [empress's residence.])

title.name: Daikan (local governor)
title.desc: A daikan (local governor) meant a person, who performed the public administration and construction in a designated territory on behalf of his monarch (state), and his rank.

title.name: Otsu-bugyo
title.desc: Otsu-bugyo (Otsu magistrate) is a post created in Otsu domain of Omi Province (present-day Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture) in the Middle Ages.

title.name: Junkenshi
title.desc: The junkenshi is an envoy of the Edo shogunate dispatched for surveillance of the daimyos (feudal lords) and hatamotos (shogunal retainers), and for research on the situation.

title.name: Tsukaiban
title.desc: Tsukaiban is a post in the Edo shogunate.

title.name: Kahan
title.desc: Kahan, also called Kahan no retsu (joint surety) means originally a chief retainer who had authority to sign or put seal at carrying out an order of a lord.

title.name: Fudai genin (low-ranked people in the hereditary succession)
title.url: title/Fudai genin (low-ranked people in the hereditary succession).html
title.desc: Fudai genin were also called Fudai hokonin (servant and hereditary vassal) and meant genin (servants who served their masters as slaves) and hokonin (a servant) who were in personal slavery and served their master by providing roeki (labor service) as Fudai permanently and patrimonially in the agricultural community of modern times.

title.name: Shi (government post)
title.desc: Shi was a collective name of Daishi and Shoshi established in Jingikan and Daijokan (Benkankyoku) under the Japanese ritsuryo legal code system.

title.name: Daisanji (second to a governor)
title.desc: Daisanji was a government post next to a chief of chihokan (local officials) placed during the time of fu-han-ken sanchisei (fu-han-ken tripartite governance system) in the early Meiji period.

title.name: Suruga no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)
title.url: title/Suruga no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan).html
title.desc: Suruga no kuni no miyatsuko (珠流河国造), also known as Suruga kokuzo, was a kuni no miyatsuko ruled over the east part of Suruga Province in ancient Japan.

title.name: Iohara no kuni miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)
title.url: title/Iohara no kuni miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan).html
title.desc: Iohara no kuni miyatsuko (廬原国造), also known as Iohara kokuzo, was a kuni no miyatsuko that ruled the west part of Suruga Province.

title.name: Totsuomi no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)
title.url: title/Totsuomi no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan).html
title.desc: Totsuomi kuni no miyatsuko (遠淡海国造), also known as Totsuomi kokuzo, was a kuni no miyatsuko ruled the west part of Totomi Province in ancient Japan.

title.name: Izu no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governer in ancient Japan)
title.url: title/Izu no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governer in ancient Japan).html
title.desc: Izu no kuni no miyatsuko (or Izu kokuzou) was a Kuni no miyatsuko that governed Izu Province in ancient Japan.

title.name: Sagamu no kuni no miyatsuko (regional governor in ancient Japan)

title.desc: Honkan was a general term of government posts which did not belong to the system for shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks) of each government official in the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code [historical law system]) of Japan.

title.name: Shimozami
title.desc: Shimozami was a subordinate of gate watcher serving at Mitsuke (area lying outside the gates of a castle) in Edo.

title.name: Yari-bugyo

title.name: Sakuji bugyo
title.desc: Sakuji bugyo was a post held by hatamoto during the Edo Period.

title.name: Jisha denso
title.desc: Jisha denso was a post placed in the Kuge (court nobles) Government in the medieval period and modern times.

title.name: Han-i
title.desc: Han-i was a doctor who served a feudal domain in the Edo period.

title.name: Honjo bugyo
